text: This is a nice design.But if you're trying to match Crate and Barrel Gourmet, it isn't quite a match, at least not for the flatware marked 18/8 Stainless Japan.The biggest difference is the color.  Compared to the C&B version, it has grayish cast that some might describe as more like nickel.  It's subtle but easily noticeable, though maybe not in dim dinner lighting.  I prefer the silver stainless color. Even if I were buying an entire new set and matching color weren't an issue, I'm not sure I'd buy these.This also has the Boda Nova Vietnam marking, in black or dark gray, most noticeably on the knife blade.  For too prominent, even if one weren't trying to match the C&B set.The size of some pieces are also slightly different.  In addition, the shape of the pieces is slightly different - the C&B have a shape that varies in all three dimensions more.  Although you'd likely only notice either issue if you put them side by side and looked carefully.Obviously, these are issues that won't matter to lots of people.  Whether this set works for you depends on your needs and tastes, and the price.  Just FYI.

THE QUICK TAKE:  The Bose 251 Environmental speakers are a well built, well designed set of outdoor speakers, with some distinctive and effective features.FULL REVIEW:TWO TWIDDLERS FOR A WIDE SOUND FIELD:  High frequency sound, typically delivered by the "tweeter" in a speaker, is much more directional than low frequency sound (that's the bass and mid-bass, generated by the "woofer" in a speaker).  In an outdoor area, the listening positions are fluid and often located over a wide area.  With a conventional speaker design - with a single, front firing tweeter - only some areas will hear full-frequency sound; other areas will lose the high end.The design of the Bose 251 addresses that issue by including two 2.5" "twiddlers" (a Bose trademark) in each speaker.  These are larger than typical 1" to 1.25" tweeters, and cover a broader frequency range.The two speakers "fire" or face in two directions, to the front right and front left of the speaker (about 4 o'clock and 8 o'clock if you were looking at the speaker from above - so a little more than 90 degrees rotation).  (There's a good picture at the Crutchfield site, which isn't shown here at Amazon, that illustrates the tweeter configuration much more easily than I can describe it.)The result of the design of the Bose 251 is that the mid and higher frequency sound is dispersed over a much wider area than in a conventional speaker design.  That's more than a theoretical benefit  - it's a meaningful advantage in most real-life, outdoor areas where speakers are used.EFFECTIVE CABINET DESIGN:  Speaker design is a matter of physics and acoustics.  The cabinets are large enough (13.5" high x 6" wide x 8.5" deep) to deliver meaningful bass for music, providing well-rounded tone.  Just note that no speaker this size can deliver home-theater, chest-compressing bass, or anything close to that - the laws of physics don't allow it.  Also, it's much harder for a system to deliver bass outside than indoors.FLEXIBLE MOUNTING OPTIONS:  The shape of the speaker and the design of the bracket make mounting fairly easy, and give you options.  These can be mounted on a wall or rail, right side up or upside down.  However, they should be mounted vertically, not horizontally.SOLID BUILD QUALITY:  The cabinets are durable and designed to last.  Bose's tests suggest they are an option for a boat or a dock, not just outdoors.  They include a 5 year warranty.In a mid to higher end installation, or for anyone seeking a speaker that will hold its value, the Bose 251 is a good option.

QUICK TAKE:  The Energizer LED Pop Up lantern is a good compact option among small LED lanterns.  It collapses to 4" tall and is bright for its size.  Depending on your needs, also consider the lighter but not as bright Coleman High Tech LED Mini Lantern.FULL REVIEW:Well done, compact LED lanterns are relatively new products.  The latest models use more efficient LEDs that last longer, and have more useful designs.More importantly, the best LED lanterns and flashlights offer a choice of a number of light levels.  That allows you to adjust for the amount of light you need, or the amount of battery life you require.  That can provide critical flexibility in make the most of every ounce you're carrying. Being able to use a lower light level can dramatically extend your runtime.In addition, human eyes will adjust pretty remarkably if you allow them - the light levels you need are far less than you may think.  Lower light levels also allow your eyes to adjust so you see better outside the immediate area illuminated by the lantern.The natural comparison in this class of lantern is between this Energizer Pop Up Lantern and the Coleman High Tech LED Mini Lantern: - The Energizer's key distinguishing features are its ability to collapse to just 4" tall, and its brightness.  It uses 4AA batteries, and weighs about 11 ounces with the batteries.Light levels are adjusted by holding down the on/off button; this has the significant drawback of requiring you to re-set the level each time you turn it on or off.  If your eyes have adjusted to the darkness, this isn't entirely pleasant.  The lantern also seems to make a high pitched noise when set to dimmer levels.The collapsible portion of the lantern is a diffraction grating - the LED lights remain inside the base.  The LED doesn't cast light directly, which means you don't see the bright LEDs but makes for a less even diffusion of light.Unfortunately Energizer feels the need to hide the true performance of their lanterns.  The specs say up to 150 lumens and up to 100 hours.  But that misleads more than it informs - you get one or the other, not both. - The Coleman lantern uses 3AA batteries, and weighs about 7.5 ounces with batteries, lighter than the Energizer.  It's about 6" high and about 2.2" in diameter.  The frosted glass gives a slightly smoother dispersion pattern than the diffusion pattern on the Energizer.The Coleman lantern produces 85 bright lumens on high and 5 lumens on low, with up to 200 hours runtime on low setting.  While 85 lumens is enough for most uses, 5 lumens is barely usable.  Still, it's good to have that option - the six light levels give you a lot of options.  It's also nice that there's a dial to adjust the intensity as well as an on-off switch - you don't want to have to cycle through the light levels in the dark to turn the light on.For my needs, I prefer the Coleman High Tech Mini Lantern.  I'd rather have the lighter weight.  I much prefer the way the light levels can be set to a level that is maintained even when the lantern is turned off and on.

QUICK TAKE:  While this Toyota Tsusho LED bulb has good build quality and is dimmable, the evolution of LED bulbs means better options are available.FULL REVIEW:There are a few key factors to keep in mind when shopping for LED bulbs.  Since you're going to be living with the bulb you choose for several years, it's important to choose carefully.DIRECTIONALITY / LIGHT DISPERSION:  Until recently, most LED bulbs would tend to direct the light primarily in one direction, rather than omni-directionally like a traditional incandescent.  Many fixtures and lamps function poorly and look strange with a directional LED bulb.  Bulbs are now becoming available that are less directional than this bulb, and work better for many lamps and fixtures.LIGHT COLOR:  While the 2700K (sometimes called "soft white") of this bulb is much better than early 5000K ("daylight") LED bulbs, because it's close to incandescent, I've come to prefer 3000K ("bright white") bulbs that are a little less yellow than incandescent.  That is, I don't think the goal is to replicate the color of incandescents - slightly whiter than that is a better option.  Again, more LED bulb options are becoming available as the technology evolves.QUALITY:  Obviously one of the main selling points of an LED bulb - that it will pay for itself over time - only works if the bulb functions well for long enough to make it worthwhile.  Not all bulbs are instant on, maintain their light color, and last.EFFICIENCY:  While the differences aren't substantial, or as important as the first three factors for most uses - new bulbs use slightly more efficient LEDs than this bulb.

QUICK TAKE:  If you want the ability to do large format photo printing and cost or value is a consideration, it's hard to beat the Canon Pixma Pro-100 Photo Printer.FULL REVIEW:VERY GOOD PRINT QUALITY:  The Pixma Pro-100 uses eight ink tanks to deliver very good - though not always perfect - print quality.MODEST UP FRONT COST:  The up-front cost of the Pixma Pro-100 is modest for a printer this size and capability.  That's especially true if you're able to take advantage of one of the frequent rebate promotions Canon runs on this printer (sometimes along with a camera).ABOVE AVERAGE OPERATING COSTS:  Ink costs for this printer are higher than average, and higher than Canon's other pro printers.  However, if you're not printing large volumes, the overall value is still there.  (For those who need higher volumes or perfect quality, there are probably better options, at a higher up-front cost.)A FULL RANGE OF PAPER SIZES AND MEDIA:  The Pro-100 can handle prints from 4" x 6" to 13" x19", also including 5" x 7", 8" x 10", Letter, Legal, and 11" x 17".  It seems to handle every type of paper within reason, as well as printable CD/DVDs.  Most sizes and papers need to be fed manually, rather than using the auto-feed tray.LARGE SIZE: With the breadth of capabilities comes the breadth of size - 27.2" wide x 15.2" deep x 8.5" high, and 43.2 lbs.MODEST POWER CONSUMPTION:  Power consumption is modest at 19 watts, and just 2.3 watts on standby.WIRED CAN BEAT WIRELESS FOR PRINTING PHOTOS:  While wireless printers can be a great idea, for graphics intensive uses it's very dependent on the wireless connection and interference.  If you live in the city, next to lots of neighbors with wireless, try to use a wired connection for the printer - you don't want the printer to stall out halfway through a 13" x 19" print.

The Panasonic EW-DS32-P Kids' Electric Toothbrush has a mild action that may make it suitable as a young child's first electric toothbrush.  The "sonic vibration" effect is very gentle.However, many parents would find it a better choice to get the Oral-B Pro-Health Dual Clean Electric Toothbrush, especially for children that are 4-5 or older.  That is not a rechargeable version, but that reduces the cost if you're not sure it will work for you, and the batteries last a fairly long time.  (The Oral-B Vitality Toothbrush is a modestly priced rechargeable version.)  Use the Oral-B Sensitive Brush Heads to get more gentle action.Electric toothbrushes are incredibly effective at keeping your teeth clean.  Just remember there's no need to apply a lot of pressure.  Google for tips on how to use the brush.

QUICK TAKE:  The Mohu Sky HDTV Antenna is a fairly small and stylish antenna, and includes most of what you need to install it.  The amplifier improves the signal somewhat in most locations.  But the key to HDTV satisfaction is to figure out how to install a big enough antenna, if that's possible.  If this works in your location, and the style and features appeal to you, it's a solid and somewhat unique option.FIRST, DO YOUR RESEARCH: It's essential to do some research before buying.  Enter your address in at antennaweb dot org for information on (1) the strength and direction of TV signals in your areas and (2) suggestions of the right antenna for your location.  Needs vary widely, depending on the channels in your area and your location.  Find out what you need before buying.BE SKEPTICAL OF REVIEWS OF HDTV ANTENNAS:  For many people, the simplest antenna - or even a coat hanger - will bring in spectacular HDTV for some stations.  They rave about the antenna, when really what they should be impressed with is HDTV broadcasting technology.  So pay more attention to those who seem to have some experience with other antennas.  Ignore reviews from people who just got their first HDTV antenna.AN ATTRACTIVE ANTENNA THAT'S EASY TO INSTALL:  The antenna is the most important part of the system.  This antenna is large enough to pick up a good signal for many locations, and includes the hardware needed for most installs.THE AMPLIFIER ADDS A LITTLE OOMPH:  The Jolt Amplifier is attractive and well designed.  It's convenient for me that it includes an option to power the amplifier using a USB port, as I have a port on my TV.  It does improve the signal somewhat, and reduces the number of disruptions in the signal.However, it doesn't make a dramatic difference for us.  We get good reception most of the time.  We're about 10-12 miles from the antennas, with a direct line of sight, so pretty well located.  We still lose signal at times during snow or rain storms.SIGNAL IS BETTER THAN AMPLIFICATION:  While Mohu says the amplifier has some special tweaks, in general you're better off getting a decent signal in the first place, rather than trying to amplify a signal that's too weak.  That means a suitable antenna and a location that allows it to work.FIRMLY INSTALL YOUR ANTENNA:  Vibration, rocking or other movement is the enemy of a good HDTV signal, so try to install your antenna as firmly as possible.

QUICK TAKE:  The Mohu Jolt HDTV Antenna Amplifier is a good option to have if you really must have a tiny TV antenna.  You're better off figuring out how to have a big enough antenna, if that's possible.  But this may appeal to those in small spaces or who have no options for placing an antenna.While this is sold separately, it's also available as a combination product with one type of small antenna this is meant to be used with, theMohu Leaf Ultimate Amplified Indoor HDTV Antenna.  Compare prices, that may be a better value.The Jolt Amplifier is attractive and well designed.  It's convenient for me that it includes an option to power the amplifier using a USB port, as I have a port on my TV.  It does improve the signal somewhat, and reduces the number of disruptions in the signal.However, it doesn't make a dramatic difference for us.  We get good reception most of the time.  We're about 10-12 miles from the antennas, with a direct line of sight.  We still lose signal during snow or rain storms.While Mohu says the amplifier has some special tweaks, in general you're better off getting a decent signal in the first place, rather than trying to amplify a weaker signal.  That means a suitable antenna and a location that allows it to work.It helps to do some research before buying.  Enter your address in at antennaweb dot org for information on (1) the strength and direction of TV signals in your areas and (2) suggestions of the right antenna for your location.

I've been using adapters in the UK for years, and these are by far my favorites. The Tmvel adapters seem well made and solid, are as compact as they can be, and often work to plug two devices into one adapter.TWO PLUGS IN ONE:  These are "2 in 1" adapters because the front universal input accepts plugs from most countries, while the second input on the top accepts two-prong plugs from a number of countries. There is a something of a space limitation on the two-prong adapter - the charger or cord has to fit in the space between the openings and the wall -  but it worked well for us with iPhone chargers and many phone chargers.The top, two prong plug also holds short-ish two prong adapters well.  I've had a problem with some UK adapters that the short US prongs didn't go deep enough into the adapter to hold well, or even connect.THREE PRONG PLUGS:  The front universal plug accepts three-prong grounded US plugs, which many adapters don't.  I've been caught by surprise with laptop chargers, some of which are three-prong.  So these adapters are a good option for laptops.CHECK THE VOLTAGE:  Just remember to check the charger or device before you plug it in, to make sure that it can handle 220 or 240 volts, as well as US voltages.  While many phone and device chargers are dual-voltage, not all are.  If they are not, you'll need a voltage converter as well as an adapter.

In case you're wondering what makes it a ladies umbrella - the base of the handle has a large clear portion, which together with the silver handle gives it a jewelry-ish and very definite lady-like appearance.  Even the black umbrella seems like a ladies umbrella.A nice product and a good value, smallish but not tiny (though stronger as a result).  Automatic open, but not close.

So much of how people experience a movie has to do with their expectations before seeing the movie.  That explains many of the reviews here.  This isn't an action movie, though there is some action during the "Flight" that gives the movie its name.  This isn't really a movie about flight, though, or at some level even about a pilot - while that element gives the movie its dramatic tension, it could be about anyone.  Almost all of the movie happens while the lead character is grounded, after the crash.Flight is a good movie with a very good performance by Denzel Washington.  If you go in expecting a realistic movie about alcoholism and addiction, with an often wrenching story, you'll be better able to appreciate the movie for what it is - rather than being surprised at what it is not.

If you're looking for an entry-level digital piano - the point you likely shouldn't go below - the Casio CDP-120 is probably your choice.  The key action is sufficiently realistic, and from time to time it can be found at a significant discount from the list price.  (But note that at close to list price, there are probably better options for the money - such as the Casio Privia PX150.)WEIGHTED KEY ACTION:  Anyone interested in playing a digital piano that feels like an acoustic piano - and most people should be - will want to get a digital piano that uses weighted keys and responds well to how hard or soft you strike the key.  The Casio CDP-120 and the Yamaha P35 are currently the least expensive digital pianos that provide a reasonably realistic feel.Note that you won't find a 76-key or 61-key keyboard with an effective weighted action, so you'll have to buy an 88-key piano. Even if you think that's more than you need or can fit in your space, it's worth finding a way.ENOUGH TONES:  While the CDP-120 has a limited range of instrument tones (5), that won't matter much.  Most people will use just the primary grand piano tone.  In addition, there is always the option to connect out through the USB port to use a computer to achieve any tone you'd like to use.LOOKING GOOD:  In addition, the Casio CDP-120 is attractively designed - sleek and simple, not a lot of switches and displays on the top.  The controls are simple and clear.A few people have commented that they are not impressed with the built-in speakers.  Attaching an external amp/speaker is relatively easy and not expensive, so that's always an option if you wish.It's well worth reading the AZ Piano News blog for a useful review of this piano, as well as a comparison to other alternatives such as the Yamaha P35 Digital Piano and many more expensive pianos, including the Casio Privia PX150, a good option if you're considering spending a little more.ACCESSORIES:STANDS:  You'll probably want a stand.  The Casio stand designed for this piano, the Casio CS44 Stand, works well and is fairly attractive.  If portability, storage or height adjustment are a factor, consider a Z-stand such as the Roland KS-18Z Keyboard Stand or On Stage KS7350 Keyboard Stand.DUST COVER:  One inexpensive, non-shedding option is the Gator Cases Stretchy Cover - GKC-1648USB CONNECTION:  The CDP-120 has a USB B port, standard size, so a cable such as the Belkin 3FT USB A to B Cable will work.IPAD CONNECTION:  To connect to an iPad, you'll need the Apple iPad Camera Connection Kit (MC531ZM/A), but be sure not to pay Apple prices for one of the many counterfeit ones on sale.

This stand is a good fit for the Casio CDP-120 Digital Piano, of course, as it's designed especially for it.  It's stable, compact, and fairly attractive with the piano attached.There are two things you really care about with a keyboard stand:  that it's the right height, and that it's designed for how you use it:THE RIGHT HEIGHT:  Since the height of this stand was designed to take into account the height of the Casio CDP-120, it's just the right height for seated use - it's the same height from the floor to the top of the keys as a grand piano.ROOM TO PLAY:  If you plan to play the piano in a seated position, a stand like this works well because there is room for your legs.  It's better not to get an X-stand if you plan to play in a seated position.Overall the design is compact and effective:COMPACT:  The stand is 51.3 inches wide (so slightly narrower than the piano) by 14.7 deep (at the feet) by 24.9 inches high (without the keyboard).  It's about as small as it could be and still work effectively.STABLE DESIGN:  The way the legs extend on either side of the vertical pieces makes it less likely to tip forward or back (some older Casio stands had no extension to the back of the stand).There are a few other factors you might want to consider:PORTABILITY:  This stand could be moved in the house, but isn't something you could easily take with you.  If being able to store or travel with the piano and stand is important, consider a Z-stand like the Roland KS-18Z Keyboard Stand or On Stage KS7350 Keyboard Stand.HEIGHT ADJUSTMENT:  The Casio CS44 stand is of course not adjustable in height, whereas some of Z-stands are.  If that's important to you, consider one of the Z-stands.But note that the Z-stands are quite a bit deeper than this Casio CS-44 stand - around 20 inches deep - perhaps for stability and to accomodate various size keyboards.The Casio CS44 is easy to assemble, using typical flat-pack techniques (as with Ikea furniture).  It uses four wing bolts to attach the stand to the piano, so it's reasonably easy to remove the piano if you wish.  The material of the main pieces is a black plastic veneer over a solid composite board.While the feet are probably strong enough, I was disappointed to see that they are made from plastic and without a lot of substance to them.  It might not be necessary, but for something we may have for many years they could splash out on a little more plastic.  Also, there are no rubber or felt pads on the feet - you'll have to add those yourself if you want them, but think carefully about how it affects the height and stability.The box is well-designed and protective, so don't hesitate to have it shipped to you. In fact, in some ways the box seems more nicely designed than the stand. ;)The instructions are on the internet if it would be helpful for you to see them before you buy.  Search on casio cs-44p pdf.

Overall, the Paula Deen Tatnall Street dinnerware set is a nice option for everyday use.WELL DESIGNED PIECES:  The pieces are nicely shaped and proportioned.  The coffee mugs are elegant.  The bases and the edges of the pieces are reasonably finished. The edges of the plates and the lip of the mugs are fairly thin rather than bulky.  The plates are about 1/2 inch deep, neither too thin nor too flat.NICELY DECORATED:  The design is interesting and attractive.  The bowls have a pattern inside, a nice touch.  The overall effect is very pretty.There are a couple potential issues.  The ceramic used is slightly less white than I expected or might have preferred, but some may actually like this shade better than a pure white.  And it is true that the edges of the pattern are somewhat abrupt.  I'd think they could have used the same manufacturing process to apply the design, but use something more irregular rather than a straight line.SHADES OF BLUE:  Finally, a note on the color.  The product photos are generally quite useful, but they don't quite give you the feel for the different shades of blue unless you look carefully.  Look at the image of the plate.  You'll see the various sections are done in two shades of blue - a fairly dark shade, and a medium blue.  Once you get the idea, have a look at the other pieces.  It's attractive, but it helps to know what to expect.

It's hard to think of who The Chef's Toolbox 8 Piece Knife Set would be a good choice for, at the current price ($175-190).  Those looking for top quality, and willing to put in the time to care for the knives, can buy the premier knives for not much more, if you shop carefully and buy only the knives you need and use.  Those looking for a bargain, or unwilling to make a commitment to care for expensive, quality knives, can get alternatives for less money.IT'S GOT THE EDGE:  The most attractive feature of The Chef's Toolbox knives is the blades: well designed, sturdy and made from high quality steel.  Though keep in mind that you'll need to care for the knives to get the benefit - wash them by hand, and keep them sharp.MAYBE NOT THE FEEL:  Like others, I'm not thrilled with the feel of the handle or the balance of the knives.THE RIGHT KNIVES?  The idea behind a knife set is that you get more knives for your money.  But that only works if they are the knives you want and will use.  Fewer, better knives would be an option some should consider.And really, they should be a pleasure to use.  The shears in this set don't make the cut in that respect.ALMOST GOT THE BLOCK RIGHT:  I actually like the idea of this block, as the traditional wood block is impossible to keep clean, and leaves a trail of wood dust (and more) wherever it goes.  But they just didn't get the design quite right.I like Magnetic Knife Bars, they keep knives clean and out of reach of little hands.GUARANTEE?  A guarantee is only as good as the company behind it, and their customer service policies.  If you're really interested in a long term commitment to high quality knives, going with a well established company seems a better bet.ARE YOU REALLY READY TO COMMIT? If you, and everyone who uses the knives, isn't ready to take care of knives properly, factor that into your choice of knives.  Though I'm careful with our Wusthof Classics, it's a constant battle to keep the others in the house, and the sitters, from putting them in the dishwasher.ALTERNATIVES:  Consumer Reports top choices all around were the Zwilling J.A. Henckels Twin Professional S and Wusthof Classic Knives (in general, not just those sets).Value options include the Ginsu Chikara Knives and Wusthof Silverpoint II Knives.  (Again, those product lines, more than those sets.)Be very careful when shopping, as knife brands have a lot of similar names with very different quality.

There are a number of things the Home Design LED lamp does well: - Most importantly, it works well as a source of light.  The 3 watt LED (about the equivalent of a 40 watt bulb) is a good brightness for a desk lamp, neither too much nor too little.  (Luckily it's not "super bright.")  The light is even, with no rings or artifacts. - The color of the light is a nice neutral color, not too white/blue and not too yellow. - Because it's an LED lamp, you don't get slowly roasted like you would with a halogen lamp. - The clamp holds well on the edge of a surface like a desk.  It will comfortably handle up to about 1-1/8" thick.Unfortunately, unless you're specifically looking for a lamp like this, it's hard not to feel like the design leaves some things to be desired. - Somehow in real life, the head of the lamp looks larger than in the photo.  It's about 4-5/8" across, and since it's usually close to my head (so it illuminates what I'm looking at), it looms a little large. - The neck is not very flexible.  The first 5-1/2" are a solid tube, which is probably good for durability.  But that limits the range of flexibility for where the head is positioned.  That's especially true if you're trying to mount it on something vertical so the lamp extends horizontally. - The clamp is not very attractive, and again looks larger than the photo.  (I think the photo was taken from a distance.)  I don't think it really saves much space to have a clamp instead of a base. - It has a strong smell - rubber or something.I always wonder about the dimensions on Amazon, so often they are the dimensions of the box.  But 14" is about right for the height, installed.  You could have as low as 12", or somewhere in between.

This is an exceptionally efficient flashlight - 83 lumens for over 9.5 hours.  That's bright enough to provide good light, but not blindingly bright.  It's a flood design, meant to light up a wide, nearby area (rather than a distant object such as a sign, or an animal).  So it's a great, practical choice for indoor and nearby use.The 2 x AA design is perhaps the most useful general purpose design.  It's much smaller and lighter than C or D cell flashlights, but still has enough capacity to last a long time.  (AA batteries have about three times the power capacity of AAA batteries.)The Coast G series of flashlights are well made, but don't include the features of the more expensive professional and technical flashlights.  If that matches your needs, this is a good option.Also, many of the better quality flashlights use twist-on and off switching, rather than push button, for the greater durability that offers.  But for convenience, push button is handy.  It's also easier for normal people to figure out.The beam is fairly smooth, a little irregular around the extreme edges but most people won't notice at all.One feature this lacks that can be useful is a low light mode, for when you want to extend battery life or use it to read a map, etc.  But most implementations of those introduce new issues - like having to click in a certain way to change modes.Be careful reading reviews of LED flashlights, to make sure the product is being evaluated against standards that match your needs.  Most reviews are written by hard core flashlight nuts, who measure a light by it's "throw" - that is, how far the beam will go.  That's a good test for outdoor use, but not what you want for a flashlight you plan to use around the house for short distances.If you're looking for the next level up, without spending a serious amount of money - consider the Fenix E25 Flashlight.

Gerber makes good flashlights that offer better value for use around the house than some of the high end producers, but better quality than the mass market sellers.  So at less than $10, this is a good price on a quality light.2 x AA lights are also one of the most useful designs.  They're smaller and lighter than C or D cell designs, but have lot more power capacity than AAA or single AA designs.The catch is that the technology is less efficient than what's available in newer lights.  A 2 x AA light should put out more than 20 lumens for longer than 5.5 hours.So this is a good value if you need a light for light use, where battery life isn't such an issue.  Others may want to invest in a more efficient light that will get more light and life out of a pair of batteries.For example, the Coast G25 Flashlight will deliver 83 lumens for 9.5 hours.  (In a floodlight design, best for indoor use.)  Or, the Fenix E25 Flashlight will deliver 27 lumens for 26 hours, 90 lumens for 6 hours, or 180 lumens for 2 hours.  It's much more expensive, but it does show what the latest technology can do.Or, if you're OK with twist-on/off, consider the amazing Fenix E01, a 1 x AAA flashlight - a tiny, handy flashlight with lower light levels (13 lumens) but extraordinary life (20 hours).

THE QUICK TAKE:  The Joby GorillaPod Micro Tripod is a well-designed, well-built and reasonably priced accessory that will add significant flexibility to your photography.  While you might not always have it "Always On", it's well worth owning and carrying.GIVE YOURSELF MORE OPTIONS:  A good micro tripod gives you some very useful options with smaller to medium sized cameras, of all types:- YOU CAN BE IN THE PICTURES:  Don't leave everyone wondering whether you were actually on the trip.  A good, small tripod lets you use the self timer to include yourself in photos, and actually get good pictures.  (That is, not pictures like the ones where you put the camera on the table at lunch and set the timer, and cut off half the heads in the group.)- GET SHARP EXPOSURES:  In low light situations, you can use the tripod and the self timer to take excellent photos with long exposures without flash.  With careful handling, the camera will be still while the shutter is open.  Even the simplest camera will usually give remarkably good pictures if you can keep the camera still while it's shooting the photo.Similarly, even on bright days, you may want to use a tripod and the self timer to take photos of landscapes, to hold the camera perfectly still and get a really sharp photo of a detailed landscape.- LESS INTRUSIVE VIDEO:  I've used a mini tripod for a small video camera while talking to relatives about family history.  It's much a more natural conversation than holding the camera myself - cameras can be so distracting, for both the subject and the photographer.  If the camera has a remote that makes it a little more manageable, but with careful setup you can film without a remote.WELL DESIGNED AND WELL BUILT:  They've clearly put a lot of thought into designing the Micro 250 tripod to be compact without sacrificing usability.  I like the way the three legs fold together into one.  And, they've built it so it works.  For example, the ball joint on the head that lets you tilt the camera holds it well, so it stays where you set it.You can buy a mini tripod for a couple bucks, and it may be better than none at all.  But the Joby is much nicer to use, and won't let you down the way cheaper ones will.USE IT CREATIVELY:  With a little thought you can cope with a lot of situations and cameras.  For example, one of my Sony cameras is a heavier point and shoot, with the tripod mount at one end of the camera.  (What were they thinking?)  The Joby tripod has no trouble holding it up, as long as I'm careful to run one of the legs of the tripod under the camera to keep the weight of the camera from tipping the tripod.ALWAYS ON?  I'm a minimalist about what I carry, so there are a lot of times when I won't bring the tripod.  I don't really need it for kid's birthday parties and so on.  But it's useful to have the "Always On" design when traveling, because the truth is I won't remember to take it out of my bag and carry it or use it.  So for sight-seeing, when I'm willing to carry a little more, the GorillaPod Micro 250 is a great accessory.TRIPLE TRIPODS?  I own a full size tripod and a mini tripod, besides this micro tripod.  You may also want another tripod for more complex uses or heavier cameras.  Some of the GorillaPod options are described above.  Also consider the popular Pedco UltraPod II Lightweight Camera Tripod.

THE QUICK TAKE:  The Interior Design Business Handbook is a useful survey and overview of the business side of interior design.But this is probably a tough type of book to write.  It's meant to be all things to all people - residential, commercial, big firm, small firm, etc. It has to be encyclopedic in scope, but in just one volume, so it can't always go deeply into any one topic.  Within the limits of that format, it does a reasonably good job of covering a lot of ground.FIVE EDITIONS OF REFINEMENT:  This book has been recently revised, and has now been through five editions.  That revision and refinement shows in the current edition.  Generally, the selection and discussion of topics is well done.MORE USEFUL AS AN INTRODUCTION:  The book will will be probably most useful to those learning about the industry, whether in school or in the initial years in the business, or for those who split their time with another functional or industry role.  It may also be useful as a reference for more experienced designers, but I suspect it would tend to be out of sight and out of mind most of the time.  Though experienced designers who are still learning the business side may find it especially useful.MORE EMPHASIS AND GUIDANCE WOULD HELP:  The book is designed and written in a way that somewhat equally emphasizes and covers all of the topics.  That's a missed opportunity.  It would be much more helpful to emphasize and focus on certain topics - both with the design of the book and the discussion - to guide the thinking of those using the handbook.For example, there's some fairly flat discussion of the issues around your firm's strengths and what type of clients to seek.  But client targeting and client selection are critical to your success, your sanity, and your profitability.  It helps a lot to know when to say no to a potential new client.To put it another way, there are 5-10 aspects that are critically important to an interior design business.  But the presentation style of the book won't do much to help you quickly learn what they are.At times it seems this book was written more as a textbook, for that lucrative publishing market, than as a practical business guide.NOT STRONG ON TECHNOLOGY OR ITS MEANING:  Some of the the discussion of technology aspects seems a little outdated.  This book really ought to have been updated to reflect how people work now, and edit out some things.More importantly, I was hoping to see (and didn't find) useful information about how to use technology to support the business, especially marketing.  For example, there's too much discussion of marketing brochures, and too little discussion of websites and email.Now in fairness, that may be really be another book that needs to be written.  But I do think it's the job of this type of book to get you oriented and point you in the right direction, and in some areas it falls short.MOVE THE APPENDICES TO A BOOK COMPANION WEBSITE:  Much of what's in the appendices of the book - such as the list of schools offering design programs - would be better placed on a companion website to the book.BUSINESS HANDBOOK:  Note that this is the business handbook, not a more general handbook to interior design.  Look elsewhere for how to calculate how much fabric you need!Some other Amazon books you may want to consider adding to your bookshelf:Interior Design in Practice: Case Studies of Successful Business ModelsInterior Design Clients: The Designer's Guide to Building and Keeping a Great ClienteleMarketing Interior DesignThe Interior Designer's Guide to Pricing, Estimating, and Budgeting (Second Edition)Interior Designer's Portable Handbook: First-Step Rules of Thumb for the Design of Interiors

A PRETTY FACE:  The face of the watch is pretty, with nice colors and an attractive butterfly theme.  I actually like how the second hand is a curved antenna, even if it's a little hard to read that way.Though the hour hand is hard to see, as the dial is white and the hand is as well.  That's a real mistake in a watch meant to help teach time - the hands should be very easy to see.A CLUNKY, LARGE BAND:  There's one big plus to the band - it uses velcro to make it easy to attach and adjust.But the band is so thick and clunky that it's not that comfortable for our six year old.Just as importantly, the band doesn't size down small enough to fit her.  Even at the maximum tightness, it's still too loose.  While this is a common problem with watches, I'd think that a teaching watch for girls would do a better job of comfortably fitting younger girls.The cardboard time telling kit that is included is a nice idea, but they should have spent a few more pennies to make something more durable and usable.So some good ideas, but not well executed in some ways.  On balance, I can't really recommend this watch for small children.  (If older girls or women find it attractive, it may work better for them.)

Our girls find this to be a fun toy, and it does a little to help ease the "Santa please bring us a dog" problem.  (The problem being, he won't be.  Not happening.)The noise and jumping are active enough to be fun.  The videos (at the top of the product listing, in with the photos) give you a good idea of what to expect, be sure to watch them.The puppy's big head spins around, and I think the big head moving helps her jump around.  (Though the big head creates an imbalance so it sometimes tips over when it's on a carpet, rather than a hard floor.  Not ideal, but a reasonable tradeoff to get more motion from the toy - better than last year, see below.)The fact that the toy can be activated by someone walking by, or a light coming on, helps add to the fun.Personally, I'd prefer a more realistic face to the cartoon-ish face of this puppy, but it is cute (and not scary, like some toy pets can be!), and our little girl seems to like it.It's easy to figure out how to use it.  And they've marked the box well to remind you that it arrives set in store display mode ("Try Me"), rather than fully On.BETTER THAN LAST YEAR'S MODELS:  We bought two of last year's less expensive Fur Real Friends, Furreal Friends Walkin Puppies - King Charles Spaniel and a white cat.  They were OK, especially given the low price we paid.  But this Bouncy Pup is much more fun - more movement, more sound.  In a way, it's what we'd hoped last year's model would be.DON'T PAY A MARKUP:  Last year, there was a time last year when it seemed resellers were the only source for these toys, but there were lots of Fur Real Friends on Amazon and in stores in the weeks before the holidays last year.  So if the Grinches try to corner the market again this year, don't waste your money paying a marked-up price.  Just buy early, or wait for new stock to arrive.My only real complaint is that it's beastly getting this thing out of the package.  The box is open so it can be on display, so as an anti-theft measure the feet are tightly tied to the bottom of the box.  Which wouldn't be that big a deal, except that the toy is on while you're trying to figure out how it's attached and how to get it loose.  So the toy is jumping and yapping, and so is your child, all during the long process of trying to get it out of the box.  (Look for that scene in an upcoming Christmas comedy.)

The Epson WorkForce 840 is an excellent product if it meeds your needs.  It offers a full suite of multi-function capability.I buy only Epson and Canon printers and scanners.  Both are committed to developing excellent products that are an excellent value (given their capability).  Epson tends to have slightly better hardware and deliver technically better results, so when I'm seeking top performance I find I usually choose Epson.  But Canon seems to have a much better understanding of user experience and usability in the software, so if it's something used by other people, I often choose Canon.WIRELESS:  If you haven't used a wireless printer, you may be surprised at how useful it is.  Wireless networks have gotten much easier to use, and more reliable.  Not having to tie your decision about where to place the printer to where you can reach it with a cable can be very useful, especially for larger equipment.Note that newer printers allow you to print directly from iPhones, iPads and tablets.  While that may sound frivolous, it can be handy not to have to transfer files to your computer to get a print.  The newer Epson WorkForce 845 has this feature.TAKE CARE:  While this is a well designed printer, at this price level you won't get as heavy duty as you will for more expensive models. Also, ink jet printers tend to have somewhat light weight construction, as that is adequate for the printing mechanism.  So take care in how you handle the printer if paper jams, etc.IT'S BIG:  This is a somewhat large printer for many home office environments, have a look at the dimensions - 17.6" x 22.3" x 12.0" - and think about how it will fit in your space.SMALLER OPTIONS:  In the last year or so, some good options for multi-function in a smaller size have become available.  If something more compact would work better for you, consider the Epson Expression Home XP-400 Wireless All-in-One Color Inkjet Printer, Copier, Scanner. (no fax).NEW MODEL AVAILABLE:  The new model of this printer, with more features and at a lower cost, is now available.  It has gotten very positive reviews:  Epson WorkForce 845 Wireless All-in-One Color Inkjet Printer, Copier, Scanner, Fax, iOS/Tablet/Smartphone/AirPrint Compatible (C11CB92201)

There are a number of pros and cons to the X-Acto School-Pro Pencil Sharpener.  It offers a good set of features for the price.But the biggest issue is that it's simply not realistic for X-Acto to promise a heavy duty electric sharpener at this price level.  There are too many compromises.  If price is critical, I'd suggest going with a manual sharpener.Note that this sharpener only has a single cutter.  If you're after quality, look for a twin cutter model.  While the adjustable pencil guide (with various size holes) helps somewhat, it's hard to get consistently good sharpening with a single cutter model unless you're very careful about it.Replacement cutter blades are available on Amazon: X-ACTO S Replacement Pencil Sharpener Cutter/Carrier RackA similar alternative to consider is Stanley Bostitch QuietSharp6 Pencil Sharpener.Manual pencil sharpeners to consider include the Westcott School iPoint Manual Pencil Sharpener.Or, a couple basic options:  Staedtler Metal Sharpeners, Double Hole for Pencils and Colored Pencils or Staedtler Metal Double Hole Sharpener with Tub (but see the reviews for the same product here)

I'm a recent convert to power toothbrushes, so I'm still in that evangelical phase where I feel like I have to tell everyone I know about how great they are ... here goes:At the suggestion of my periodontist, I got the Oral B Vitality Floss Action Rechargeable Power Toothbrush [Amazon item B003UKM90Q or B008CYFJX4, though oddly unavailable right now].  It makes my teeth feel much, much cleaner than even a careful brushing with a regular toothbrush, and is a big help in maintaining my gums.The Floss Action heads work well for me, as they help clean food and plaque.  Of course, they may not suit everyone, and won't actually get food and plaque from between two teeth - you still need to floss.These heads hold up well for me.  They actually last much longer than a regular Oral-B toothbrush for me - I was replacing those every month.  So the cost of heads hasn't been that much more than the cost of toothbrushes for me, and it's certainly well worth it for the results in terms of dental health.A few points from my periodontist (who practices in a large, downtown practice and is a heckuva a nice guy besides):- The affordable Oral-B Vitality line cleans as well as the more expensive toothbrushes.  (So price isn't a reason to wait to get one.)- It's OK to use these toothbrushes along the gum-line or on the gums, but ...- Don't use them with a regular toothpaste, those are too abrasive.  It's the toothpaste that causes gums to recede, not the toothbrush.  Use Sensodyne Toothpaste or something similar.As others have noted, you may need to experiment with the amount of pressure you use - you really don't need much, let the head do the work - and the type of head you use.  The other top choices may be Precision Clean brush heads and Sensitive brush heads.

THE QUICK TAKE:  Family Tree Maker 2012 is useful as a tool to organize and collect your information and related media (photos, documents, stories) about your family history.  However, the really powerful tool is Ancestry.com.  Ancestry should help you greatly expand what you know, not just organize what you know.  FTM 2012 Deluxe includes a three month membership to Ancestry.com, so if you use it well you can get a lot of value from this package.Before I get into the details of the review, some general advice: - Talk to your older living relatives now, while they are still around.  Try to get the stories, copies of photos, find out who is in the photos, and so on.  You won't be able to do that later. - Keep backup copies of all your files, and backup your files before you make any substantial changes or sync your tree.  Work on the assumption that you will have computer problems or a hard drive failure, because at some point you will.  You're going to put a lot of work into your family history, you want to make sure you always have a copy.GET PREPARED BEFORE YOU START:  To protect the privacy of living people, government records aren't made available for decades.  So before you start using Ancestry and FTM, try to find out some details about your parents and your grandparents - birth, marriage, death, places they lived.  Then you'll be able to start to link to the publicly available information online.  Without information on your recent ancestors, it will be hard to get very far.FAMILY TREE MAKER IS USEFUL:  FTM is a useful tool.  It seems reasonably easy to use even for those less expert at using the web and computers.  For example, there are tools to allow you to capture text and photos from the web.The tutorials are worth reviewing.  They are well done, brief, and will help get you started on key tasks.The software can also do some tasks that you can't currently do on the website, such as split and join trees.For me, the software installed easily on an older XP machine.  It needs .net 4.0 to run, so will install that if it's not already installed.  FTM Deluxe 2012 comes on 2 CDs, one with the software and the other with the PDF books in the Family History Took Kit (see below for a list).REGISTER LATER?  When you first run Family Tree Maker, it asks if you want to register the software.  You may want to wait to register, as that seems to start your three months subscription to Ancestry.  You may want to organize yourself a little, and get the basic facts about your family, before you go online.ANCESTRY.COM IS POWERFUL:  I was able to find a lot of additional information about the ancestors I knew I had, and turn up some new ancestors and new connections.  I found Ancestry's hints and matching to be useful, but then I guess I don't mind searching through dozens of possible matches to see which ones are a fit.CHECK ALTERNATE SPELLINGS:  Census records are surprisingly uneven in terms of the accuracy of names.  If you can't find what you're looking for, try searching on alternate spellings of a name.INCLUDE THE WHOLE FAMILY:  Even if your interest is primarily in your ancestors, it's very useful to add the data about all their siblings to your tree, for two reasons.  First, it's incredibly helpful to match the data when you have more than just one person.  Knowing the names and ages of siblings can make it clear whether another record is your family, or not.  It helps confirm a link when a name is common, or when there are mis-spellings.  Second, it makes the story much more interesting to see who was in your ancestor's family and what was happening in their lives.BE SKEPTICAL:  There are a lot of mistakes in the family trees already online, so don't assume that someone else has done their homework unless there is backup.KEEP TRACK OF YOUR SOURCES:  Don't rely on your memory.  Make notes and add documents to support the info in your tree.CENSUS DATA IS INTERESTING, REALLY!:  I found myself surprised at the amount of data in the census.  It collects several interesting facts if you review it carefully.  It's also interesting to see what happens over time to families - the joy of births, tragedy of deaths and mysteries of life. (For example, why was great grandma living apart from great grandpa, and telling the census she was a widow?)DON'T UNDERESTIMATE GOOGLE:  I chuckled a little that FTM includes Google as a link.  But it's probably not obvious to everyone, and so it's worth saying.  I've turned up a lot of useful information searching on Google, though it really helps to use a targeted search and to try a few alternatives.CHECK ROOTSWEB:  There are a number of family trees on RootsWeb as well.  It's worth searching for your family.  It can be a useful starting point in your research, but be sure to verify the information, and also make sure it's really your family.PLAN ON A LONG PROCESS:  Most people spend a little time over years or decades collecting information about their family.  While you can make a lot of progress in a short time, filling out more details or finding new ancestors can take a long time.CANCELING IS EASY:  Note that if you don't want your subcription to auto-renew, you need to cancel it.  You can do that anytime, and still use the balance of your subscription.  It takes several clicks online, but it's not hard to cancel.PRINTED MANUAL INCLUDED:  I appreciate that they have included a printed manual for the software.  That's a corner that many other companies cut to save costs, a false saving in my opinion.FAMILY HISTORY TOOL KIT:  The following PDFs are included as part of the Family History Tool Kit.  They look like useful information, but don't feel that you need to read them to get started. - Abbreviations and Acronyms: A Guide for Family Historians - List and explanation of abbreviations and acronyms found in census schedules, soundex indexes, mortality schedules, court records, etc. - Ancestry's Concise Genealogical Dictionary - Definitions of unusual terms, especially in cemetery, probate, court, medical, etc. - Hidden Sources: Family History in Unlikely Places - Overview of sources that are often overlooked, where and how they can be found, etc. - Printed Sources: A Guide to Published Genealogical Records - Guide to printed sources such as vital records, definitions and explanations of how to use them. - The Official Guide to Ancestry.com - Become more proficient with searching the site. Explore obscure databases you didn't know existed. Create and develop your own family tree. - The Official Guide to RootsWeb - How to use RootsWeb, and success stories of the RootsWeb Community.

The Atlantic Technology SB-900 front-firing subwoofer is a well-designed and well-built compact subwoofer, from a reliable company.  It's a good option for those looking for full-range sound for music or to add some impact to home theater in a small- to medium-sized room.YOU NEED A SUB:  While you can certainly get much-better-than-TV-quality sound with small speakers and soundbars, you can't get a true home theater experience without a subwoofer.  You may also find music is a little lacking in the low end, unless you use large stand-mounted or floorstanding speakers.BUT YOU DON'T WANT TO DEDICATE SPACE:  While many people would like to have a full home theater, the reality for most is that the space is shared for other uses.  So size and looks become more important - sound quality alone isn't the only factor. The SB-900 is compact and attractive.  While it won't deliver the sound output and home theater impact that a dorm-fridge-sized sub will, it fills the need for bass and low frequency effects without the compromises and costs of tiny subs.THIS IS THE SWEET SPOT IN SIZE AND POWER TRADEOFFS: The physics of speakers, and especially subwoofers, mean that there is a tradeoff between the size of the driver (the speaker) and the enclosure (the box), and the amplification applied, and the output of the sub.The size and output tradeoffs can be somewhat offset with a lot of power and equalization of the sound, so subwoofers like the Velodyne MiniVee can be even more compact - but you're paying a lot more for the small size, and the extra amp power needed to make up for the small size, not for more performance.  That is, you can buy a smaller subwoofer, but you'll pay more or get less performance, or both.The Atlantic Technology SB-900's size is at the sweet spot for those looking for compact size, reasonable price, and reasonable performance.I ran a set of low frequency tones through the SB-900, and their claim to reach 32 hz at -3db seems about right.  Atlantic Technology's specs say that it will reach 103 db in a 1500-2000 cubic foot room.  That's good performance for this type of sub.DIMENSIONS:  With the feet and the grille and the controls, the sub is 11" wide, 13.75" high, and 14.5" deep.  (The website gives the dimensions of the box only.)POWER:  The SB-900 is rated at 125 watts RMS of amplification, a respectable level for this design.  If you're making comparisions, be sure to use the RMS ratings, not the much higher peak output ratings that often appear in marketing materials.FEATURES AND FLEXIBILITY FOR MANY SYSTEMS AND SITUATIONS:  The SB-900 includes a full set of features and controls, allowing it to be used in a variety of situations:- It has a bypass-able, continuously variable crossover (40-220 hz), so you can use the sub or a receiver to manage the bass.- Speaker level (amplified) inputs and outputs let you use this with amplifiers that don't have a subwoofer output.  The sub passes along only the sound above the crossover to the speakers.It also includes the usual auto-sensing on; and phase setting.While this sub can be used with a variety of systems, it's helpful to realize it was specifically designed to work with the Atlantic Technology soundbar.  The Atlantic Technology FS-7.1 Surround Sound Soundbar is a high end solution to the need for a convenient and compact multi-channel sound system, and gives you an idea of the quality of the product line.ATLANTIC TECHNOLOGY: Atlantic Technology has established a solid reputation with hi-fi fans, though they probably aren't as widely known among those unfamiliar with home theater. AT is also highly regarded by custom installers of sound systems.SETUP:  Setting up a sub can be a little complicated.  Search the Internet for a guide.  Two things to pay particular attention to:- Crossover frequency:  To get your sub to "integrate" well with your speakers, you need to properly set the crossover - the frequency at which the sound transitions from being handled by the sub to being handled by the speakers.  Most speakers, especially satellite speakers, don't reach as low as their manufacturers would like you to think.  Experiment with a higher crossover point than the speakers are rated for.  Also, be sure to use the bypass setting on the sub crossover if your receiver is handling the crossover.- Placement:  The location of the sub in the room, and relative to the other speakers and the listeners, can have a big effect.  If you're not happy with the sound, experiment with the location of the sub.One final note, don't assume your sub will arrive with the "default" settings.  My sub arrived with the level (volume) turned all the way down, and the phase switch set to inverse.

THE QUICK TAKE: The Belkin Galaxy Tablet Charger Kit is well built, and has sufficient power for a tablet.  You can use the USB connection with any tablet or phone, though you will need to provide the right cable.GOOD BUILD QUALITY: I've been happy with the Belkin chargers and cables I've owned, the build quality is solid. I've found that the cheaper cables come apart, often leaving parts stuck into the plug on the device.And I've never thought that the cheap knockoff chargers made sense - it's going to be plugged in almost all the time, in my house, where my family sleeps. And powering an expensive piece of electronics. For that use, I'm not going to give up quality just to save a few bucks.2.1 AMPS WILL CHARGE YOUR TABLET: The wall charger is rated at 2.1 amps, which is enough to charge a Galaxy, iPad or other tablet.  (Phone chargers are typically only 1 amp, and won't charge tablets well, if at all.) The car charger is also rated at 2.1 amps.FOUR FOOT CABLE:  The cable is a useful 4 foot length - not too short or too long.TYPICAL, LARGER SIZE CHARGER FOR TABLETS: Both the car and wall chargers are around the size of many higher-power (2 amp) chargers. - The car charger isn't really micro (I have smaller ones for my phone), but it's about as small as 2-amp tablet chargers get, and certainly small enough. - With the prongs folded, the wall charger is a reasonably compact 2.2" H x 1.1" wide x 1.8" deep.INTERNATIONAL VOLTAGE: The wall charger can accept 100 - 240 V, so it offers flexibility.FOLDING, SWIVELING PRONGS: The outlet prongs fold into a recess in the back of the charger, which is a nice feature if you pack it in a briefcase or your luggage.  They also swivel 90 degrees, so you can fit it into an outlet or power strip the way you choose.

THE QUICK TAKE:  The Seagate Expansion 2TB USB 3.0 External Hard Drive STBV2000100 is a good option as a backup drive, or as an expansion drive that isn't used intensively.  It may also serve well as a working drive that's used more intensively but for temporary or replaceable files - such as a scratch drive or a media server.This drive is large enough and priced low enough that you can backup multiple computers for not a lot of money.However, if you're looking for an expansion drive - a second drive to augment a laptop or desktop - that you will use intensively, consider options with cooling and perhaps backup, especially if you will use the drive for your only copy of files.A DESKTOP DRIVE:  This is a desktop drive, not a truly portable drive.  You could use it to backup multiple computers around a home or office, but you're not going to enjoy carrying the drive and the power supply.A FAST CONNECTION:  USB 3.0 really is fun to use, if you have the right port on your computer to use it.  No more sitting around watching file transfers - the speeds are similar to those of a built in drive.KEEP A BACKUP: One of the keys to happiness in modern life is to keep at least two copies of every computer file you need.  If you have anything you would rather not have vanish tomorrow, get a hard drive - any hard drive - and make a copy. Right now.  Err on the side of caution.ALL HARD DRIVES FAIL - SO REPLACE THEM BEFORE THEY DO:  Hard drives are complex mechanical devices. They will absolutely, inevitably fail.  So manage them accordingly.I replace all my drives after about three to four years (if they survive that long).  It's much easier to replace a drive before it fails - it's very easy to copy a readable drive.  It's much harder to recreate a drive, especially a boot drive, after it fails - you need to reinstall all the software and settings, and maybe reconstruct the folder structure.And hard drives are cheap enough to make it not worth the risk to keep drives around longer than that.  I can usually get a bigger, faster drive for much less money than the original drive.Once you start to accept the reality that hard drives will fail, and manage your drives and data appropriately, you can drastically reduce the disruption that hard drive failures cause.BUY A GOOD MODEL OF DRIVE, THEN KEEP A CURRENT BACKUP:  As much as people like to claim that particular brands are better or worse, statistics don't really seem to back that up.  Buy a good model from one of the top brands - Seagate, Western Digital, Hitachi, Samsung - and then manage them as described above.That being said - some drives (or the firmware they are shipped with) have turned out to be real lemons.  Most of the big manufacturers make good drive models, and they have made bad drive models.  So much like your uncle, who never bought a new model car until they'd worked the bugs out of it - let someone else be at the bleeding edge of hard drives.  Buy models that have been tested by other users.It's a little soon to tell for the drive installed in this particular model, and some of the early feedback is mixed.COOLING QUESTIONS:  I can't really figure out why the cooling is so unconvincing on almost all external drives (like this one).  A tight-fitting plastic case, with no effective ventilation?  Really?  While drive temperature isn't perhaps quite as big an issue as some would make it out to be - that level of cooling just doesn't seem adequate for a drive that's running more than a fraction of the time.  If your needs fit that description - that is, if you need a back up drive, or an intermittently used expansion drive - then this Seagate external drive may be a good matchFOR AN INTENSIVELY USED EXPANSION DRIVE, CONSIDER OTHER OPTIONS:  If you need more space in an expansion drive, and plan to use the drive intensively, consider other options.  Perhaps a NAS (network attached storage) or a drive enclosure with more effective cooling, and possibly something with multiple drives and built in backup.WATCH HOW YOUR DRIVES ARE SHIPPED:  One of the key factors in whether a drive will last is how it's handled and shipped.  External drives such as this one are usually packaged somewhat well, although online vendors still don't seem to really get the concept of filling the shipping box so the product inside doesn't bounce around on its way to you.

THE QUICK TAKE:  Ben MacIntyre has found a subject well-suited to his talents - the spies who helped confound German intelligence in the run-up to and early days after the D-Day invasion.  I found it a compelling read - a "Friday book" as described in one of the comments, as I started it on Friday and finished it by Sunday - because it is both incredible and true.IT'S ALL ABOUT THE PEOPLE:  As it should be, the book focuses on the people and personalities on all sides - the double-agents themselves, as well as British and German intelligence.  That's the interesting part, that hasn't been covered before - there are plenty of books about the rest of D-Day already.QUITE A STORY:  The story is a fascinating one, based on careful research and told with just the right amount of detail.  It's easy to feel what the people involved might have been going through as the process unfolded.  MacIntyre calls the operation a "an undisputed, unalloyed, world-changing triumph," (p. 331) and as I was reading the book it certainly felt that way.  It's a fine tale.A BIT DRAMATIC:  Of course, even while enjoying the writing and the research, one might view the whole operation with a bit less histrionics as to the importance of this operation to the success of the Allied war effort.  The German side was Colonel Klink-esque - filled with clumsiness, indifference, and quiet sabotage.  The Allies had military superiority (especially air superiority) and the benefit of being able to read all of the German transmissions thanks to the code-breakers.  Still, the story is a fascinating one. And of course we have the benefit of hindsight from our comfortable armchairs - those who lived through this faced enormously serious consequences.The Soviets seem the true masters of espionage here, with the "Cambridge Five" deeply penetrating British intelligence - but ironically, the Soviets were unwilling to believe in their success.  (They believed their spies were double agents trying to deceive them, when in fact they received many of the most important secrets.)  It's unfortunate that MacIntyre is unlikely ever to have access to the Soviet records, as that would even top this tale.

THE QUICK TAKE:  The Peugeout Saint Malo Pepper Mill is attractive, nicely compact, and easy to grind.  You can get good results, if you're a little careful, once you know how.ATTRACTIVE AND COMFORTABLE DESIGN:  The pepper mill is attractive, and the size makes it less obtrusive and unwieldy than the classic, somewhat absurdly large mills that are more common.  It's nice to use.GOOD RESULTS ONCE YOU LEARN HOW:  One of the key features of this grinder is the ability to get pepper ground the way you want it - fairly fine, or more coarse.  (If that seems a little obsessive to you, think about why phrase "the spice of life" means something that gives meaning to life - it's because spice and flavoring can make all the difference in food.  Pepper is important!)  You can have a consistently fairly small grind; or something more mixed and coarse.Unfortunately, the mechanism for adjusting the grind isn't quite as easy to use as I'd like.  You adjust the grind by turning the knob counterclockwise, but that also loosens the knob to the point where it's easily moved.  If, for example, you accidentally move the crank counter-clockwise, it moves the knob with it, and changes the setting.So the way to get dependable results is to tighten the knob all the way down before you use the pepper mill, then (if desired) back off a turn or two to get a coarser grind.GOOD BUILD QUALITY:  The crank and grinding mechanism seems solid.  But call me old fashioned - given the half-a-Benjamin price I was expecting better build quality.  It looks fine, but doesn't have the heavy-metal, over-engineered look - like the inside of an old clock - that I would have expected.  And I'm a little surprised the sleeve inside (between the pepper storage compartment and the wood) is plastic.  Plastic, to me, is the sign of something that isn't designed to last a lifetime (or two or three - for those of use that have some of granny's kitchen gear!).  Even though it's not a stress-bearing piece, plastic doesn't age well - it becomes brittle.WOULD YOU LIKE PEPPER?  The mill arrives with just a small amount of peppercorns to get you started.  In one way that makes sense - if you care enough about food to enjoy this pepper mill, you don't necessarily want peppercorns that have been stored who-knows-where for who-knows-how-long.  On the other hand, it seems a missed opportunity to make this more special - they could have included a little packet or jar of a special pepper.PACKAGING ISN'T ALWAYS A BAD THING:  While overall it's great that Amazon is trying to reduce packaging, it's worth remembering that packaging can be a good thing.  I would have expected this pepper mill to be packaged in a small box, both for protection and to make it more attractive as a gift.  Perhaps those who don't receive this through the Amazon Vine, as I did, will get a mill packed in something other than a plastic bag.

As noted, this is an exceptionally fast drive.  The write speed is where it really shines, writes are when you find yourself wishing it would finish already - though read speeds are excellent too.I'm a big fan of Mushkin drives for the build quality and speed.  But I was a little surprised by the size of the Ventura Pro - for some reason I was expecting it to be the same size as the (ultra compact) Ventura non-pro drive I have.  But it's a bigged-up version of that - almost 3 inches long (73.36 x 19.88 x 9.07mm) vs. just over two inches long (56.7 x 19.8 x 6.8mm) for the regular Ventura.I'd still recommend it highly, of course - but just an FYI in case it would matter for your particular use.

Overall, the pros of the Duracell Mini Charger (CEF-20) are balanced by the cons.  It's OK, so if you're looking for an inexpensive but smart charger with good build quality, and don't mind that it's slow and bulky, then it may be a fit for your needs.  But for those willing to spend more, there may be better options out there.  (Check NLee's most recent recommendations, that's the go-to source for battery and charger reviews.)PROS:"SMART" CHARGING:  Each battery is charged separately, so you get the right amount of charge to recharge each battery.INTERNATIONAL VOLTAGES:  It can handle 110 - 240V, so all you need is an adapter for the prongs or access to a US-style "shaver" outlet.FOLDING PRONGS:  It will play nice with the other things in your luggage.CONS:SLOW:  As NLee notes, the current this outputs to charge is low (280 mA AA, 110 mA AAA).  Duracell estimates 8 hours to charge.NOT SMALL:  To me, this seems about 30%-40% larger than it needs to be.  It's 4.5" long, 2.25" wide, and  1.6" thick.  (You can get a sense for it's not-mini size by looking at the photo - those are AA batteries in the pictures, and the charger is much larger.  I have a 4-battery charger that's not much bigger than this.  That picture of someone putting it in their jeans pocket is do-able but ridiculous.)This "mini" charger is longer, wider and thicker than it needs to be.  Someone should have told the designer what "mini" means.Also, the color of the cover is a lovely metallic color (green in my case), but the cover seems pointless or worse - charging batteries get hot.  The cover is pretty but superfluous.

THE QUICK TAKE:  This is a very good arm blood pressure monitor.  It's essentially identical to the Omron 10 Series BP785, which was the top-rated arm model in the June 2012 issue of Consumer Reports.  If it fits your needs, the Omron BP791IT is an excellent choice.GET A WELL DESIGNED MONITOR:  There are many monitors available now that will give an accurate reading.  Most have a data-averaging function and a risk category indicator.  However, they vary quite a bit in ease of use and comfort.  Also, not all have multiple-user memory; irregular heartbeat detection; or multiple cuffs for best fit.  This monitor does well on all those counts.CONSIDER THE FEATURES YOU NEED:  The table above in the Amazon product description does a nice job of comparing the Omron models.  The key difference between this model, the BP791IT, and the Omron BP785 Arm Monitor, is that this model allows you to use the Microsoft Health Vault.  If that's important to you, go with this model.  If not, consider the BP785.WRIST MODELS:  Also, now that some wrist models provide accurate results (a recent development), you have another alternative.  The Omron BP652 Wrist Monitor is the top rated wrist model in Consumer Reports, with high marks for both accuracy and convenience, and good marks for comfort.  (In fact, the overall score was higher than the arm models.)GET A GOOD READING:  Remember that these monitors are only as accurate as you allow them to be.  Sit for several minutes before taking a reading; sit up with your feet on the floor; avoid moving; and try to take your measurements at the same time each day, if possible.

THE QUICK TAKE:  The Canon ELPH 300 is a very good point-and-shoot camera.  The size makes it easy to carry, which means you're more likely to have it when you need it.  The 5x, almost-wide-angle optical lens provides flexibility while maintaining quality.  And while small cameras like this involve a number of compromises, Canon has made the right compromises.CARRY A REAL CAMERA:  Some people would argue that the camera on their phone means they don't need a point and shoot camera.  Ummmmm .... sort of.  It is great to always have a "camera" with you, so a phone does let you catch some photos you might miss.  But if you know you're traveling or going to an event - give yourself a chance to get some good pictures, carry a real camera (such as this one).  The photo quality is so much better than any phone, and it provides much more flexibility - to zoom, use flash, etc.THIS IS A VERY GOOD SMALL CAMERA:  The Canon ELPH 300 is a very small camera, about as small as a camera needs to be.  It's reasonably quick (except when you're taking a series of flash photos - but it's not unusual to need some time for the flash to recharge).  The photos generally have good exposure, focus and color balance.  The Auto selections are generally well made, though it doesn't seem to pick up on backlit subjects and force the flash on or otherwise adjust.  The flash works well enough for something this size.  HDMI output is nice to have.THE USUAL COMPROMISES, WELL BALANCED:  Small cameras have small lenses and small sensors.  Small lenses and small sensors capture less light, so perform best in bright light.  The processing and shooting modes help somewhat to address that.  (If you learn to use the Scene shooting modes in Program mode, that should help as well.)  Small lenses also don't have the sharpness of large lenses.  The extra megapixels of this sensor help a little with the sharpness - you're probably not printing 16x20 photos from these.  Overall, Canon has done a good job of balancing the inevitable compromises that come with a point and shoot camera.THINK ABOUT THE VIDEO SIZE:  While it's really cool to shoot 1080-line video, I'm not sure what I'd be able to do with that.  To reduce the file size and processing complexity, I've mostly been shooting 720-line.  That's still better than DVD-quality (480-line).By the way, the microphones seem to work well given the limitations of this type of camera.SOME ROOM FOR IMPROVEMENT:  There are a couple areas that Canon could improve:- The biggest problem, and it is significant, is that sometimes highlights are washed out or lost altogether.  The dynamic range of the camera seems surprisingly limited.  So the face of a child laying in dark grass will lose a lot of detail.  So I'll be taking a more capable camera some of the time, to get better picture quality.- Mostly an annoyance, but an unnecessary one - you can choose to set the Review feature (how long a photo stays on the screen) for 2, 3, 4, etc seconds.  All are too long in real life shooting situations with any action.  How about half a second, or one second?- It seems you can't force the flash to fire, or force the camera into Macro mode (for close ups), unless you switch to Program mode.  That's an unnecessary extra step for very commonly used features.As far as the other reviewers disappointed by this camera, I can only think of three reasons:(1) They paid full list price.  It wasn't worth that, but at current prices (not much more than half that, look for a deal), it's a very good value.(2) They got a defective camera.  It does happen.(3) They're just not realistic about what to expect from a small camera.This is a very good, and in some ways remarkable camera, given what's possible with current technology.

THE QUICK TAKE:  The E900 is an easy to use, well-made router suitable for basic routing and wireless needs. It's recently released (2012), so it's the latest evolution of Linksys routers.  If you get a good deal on one, and your needs are limited, it may be a good match.  Many people, though, can get a lot more router for not too much more than the regular price of this router.FULL REVIEW:Apparently making a wireless router that does what it's supposed to do is very difficult, as demonstrated by thousands of reviews of routers on Amazon full of anger, frustration and disappointment.So the recent Linksys E series of routers are welcome on that count.  They're fairly simple to install and use, and work reliably.  If your needs are simple - you want a wireless connection, over not too far of a distance - the Linksys E900 may work just fine.But the bar for speed, features and range is also getting raised all the time.  Many people will do better by looking for a router with a few more features and capabilities than the E900 offers.GOOD SPEED:  With 2 transmit and 2 receive antennas (2T2R, in the lingo), this router can achieve N speeds if you have the right adapter on your computer.  In theory each antenna can handle 150 Mbps of traffic, thus the spec shows 300 Mbps.  In practice, it's much lower speeds - so you're doing very well if you get 50-80 Mbps on a 2.4 Ghz band router.MODEST RANGE:  Router range varies, depending on the transmit power; the antennas; and other factors.  This router does best with shorter range applications.A LITTLE SHORT ON FEATURES:  There are some features that are not available on the E900 that, even in a simple setup, you might find will be useful: - One of those is guest access - now that everyone who visits you is carrying around a wifi device or two, it's nice not to have to give them your network password and access to your shared files.
