A guest setup lets someone get access to the internet, without having access to everything on your network. - The other feature is parental controls, which the E900 also lacks.ATTRACTIVE BUT INFLEXIBLE DESIGN:  A lot of people will like the sleek design, and the fact that the lights are in the back (not on the front).  Personally, I'd rather have the ability to configure the router in various ways - standing, turned, on its side - and this design limits that.  I also like the option of hanging the router, something the design of the E900 doesn't allow.IT TAKES TWO:  Your connection will only be as good as both ends of the connection.  Some laptops don't come with the speediest wireless network adapters built in.  So to make the most of this or any router, remember that you need a good wireless adapter on the computer the router is connected to.  It's usually fairly easy to change the little wireless card in a laptop if you want to upgrade the internal adapter.In particular, look at the antenna configuration of an adapter or laptop - often you'll see something like 1T2R,  or 1x2, which means there's 1 transmit and 2 receive antennas.  That will give good download speeds, but slower upload speeds (which may be fine for many people).LOOK AT THE CHANNEL AND NETWORK SETUP:  Some reliable websites suggest that you may actually get more throughput using single-width (20 Mhz wide) channels for wireless N.  It may be worth experimenting with.  Similarly, it's conventional wisdom that mixing G and N adapters will slow all the devices.  That's worth testing with your setup as well.Some router manufacturers have taken to putting a sticker on the router with the default IP address and username / password, I've found that useful.Bottom line, it's a nice, simple router that should work well over short distances.  You could do a lot worse.  But, you could do better, too.

If you're using a regular toothbrush, you have no idea of how really effective a toothbrush can be.  The Oral-B Vitality does a much better job of cleaning your teeth, and will easily get to areas at the gum line that you would really have to work to clean effectively with a regular brush - so you won't.The 5 star rating is not because this is perfect, but because the results you get are well worth the price.  (To be perfect, it would need to be able to handle international voltages - but it can't.)Get one, use it, and your teeth and gums will be happy.  Go for the rechargeable version, like this one (not the battery operated version).

Panasonic shavers are among the best, from my experience, and the ES-LT41-K is right at the sweet spot.  It offers a high level of performance and useful features - good blades, 13,000 cycle per minute cutter - without unnecessary frills.  To match the shaver to your needs, see the charts in the product listing for a great summary of the differences in the models.GIVE IT TIME:  If you're making the change to electric shavers, or switching brands, don't be hasty in reaching a decision about the shaver.  Electric shavers are very different from a razor, and vary quite a lot among different brands.  It will take a little time to figure out how to best use a given electric shaver.That said, you really can't get the same shave with a shaver that you can with a razor.  But then again, a shaver can be a lot more comfortable to use, especially on your lip and chin (where it can feel like your beard is being pulled out, rather than cut, with a razor).  To me it's worth the tradeoff, though I do usually clean up with a razor to catch hairs and stubble I've missed.GIVE IT TIME, PART 2:  You may find you need to shave a little longer than you'd like to, or go over the same spot more than you think you ought to.  But with a little bit of patience, you can get a remarkably close shave with this shaver.WET OR DRY:  If you only use this shaver dry, you may be missing something.  It's a different shave wet, and it's great that this shaver is built to let you shave wet or dry.EASY TO CLEAN:  The wet or dry construction also makes it easy to clean - just run it under the faucet (with the cleaning mode on, if you like).GREAT BATTERY LIFE:  I can go weeks between charges.  If possible, it's best to let the battery run all the way down and then recharge it fully to get the best charge capacity.  Also, while the charge indicator is useful, it seems it can stay at 10% for a long time.  Don't put the shaver on the charger when it reaches 10% - use it for more shaves.THREE BLADES OR FOUR?  Those with especially tough beards seem to swear by four blades, but to me the four blade shavers are just too large. Personal preference will vary - neither one is right for everybody.PRICES FLUCTUATE:  There are certain items on Amazon which seem to have wide price fluctuations, and Panasonic shavers are among them.  So it may be worth tracking the price a little, or searching the web, to catch it on sale.SKIP THE CLEANING STATION:  Some may find it useful, but to me the cleaning station seems like a holdover from the days of harder-to-clean models.  I had one on my last Panasonic shaver and never used it.I used Braun shavers for many years, but after being disappointed with the declining performance of their more expensive shavers, I switched to Panasonic and haven't looked back.  The Panasonic ES-LT41-K is an excellent choice among electric shavers.

The Lonely Planet Spanish Phrasebook & Dictionary is a handy, compact guide for travelers to Spain.  At 5-1/2" by 3-3/4" by 1/2", it's the portable size you'd expect from a phrasebook (or slightly larger).  The book does seem to reflect the Lonely Planet approach to travel - it seems to assume you're going to spend some time in one country, so it goes into more detail than the casual traveler may need.  (So something even more abbreviated may be better for a quick trip.)For the most part, they did a good job with the selection of what's in the book and how it's organized.  The colored page edges help find things, once you're a little bit familiar with them.  The main body of the book has a well-organized series of sections for various needs.  The last 75 pages of the book have a menu decoder; an English to Spanish dictionary; and a Spanish to English dictionary.Putting grammar at the beginning seems a waste, though.  I'm all for learning some grammar, but I don't think that's where you start.  (In fact, I think the best way to start learning a language is with no book at all - see below.)  But again, they seem to be going for a little more depth than usual in this book, on the assumption you'll be in the country for a while.  Still, a selection of more of the most useful phrases (there are a few there) would be a better use of the first section of the book.OPEN IT BEFORE YOU NEED IT:  You can't really expect to carry a phrase book and open it to find the right phrase just as your taxi is hurtling past your destination.  You'll have a lot better luck if you spend a little time on the plane or before you leave with the book.  Practice a little, so you don't stumble so badly with pronunciation.  Figure out where the phrases that seem most useful to you are located in the book.SPANISH AS IN SPAIN:  Many people know, but many people don't - Spanish, especially everyday spoken Spanish, varies quite a bit in different countries.  The dialect spoken in much of Spain is called Castilian or European, and varies somewhat from that spoken in the Americas.  So look for another book if you're headed to Latin America, such as the Lonely Planet Latin American Spanish Phrasebook or the Lonely Planet Mexican Spanish Phrasebook.There are a few basics for the other dialects spoken in Spain - Basque, Catalan and Galician - at page 115.START WITH THE SPOKEN WORD:  If you've studied a foreign language, you probably started with a book, and followed by listening.  But consider spending a little time with an audio-based language program before you go.  It's something you can do around the house or in the car.  I like the Pimsleur language series - though they seem to have a lot more product options for Latin American Spanish.  I've also found the Living Language programs to be useful. Finally, there are a number of language websites available if you want to hear spoken Spanish.

The illy issimo Cappucino coffee drink is a well-made, medium-body and moderate calorie drink.  It's produced in Denmark and imported.  It has 100 calories and 1.5 grams of fat in an 8.45 ounce drink.A bottled Starbucks Coffee Frappucino has 200 calories and 3 grams of fat (and it's slightly larger at 9.5 ounces), so the illy drink offers a lighter alternative if that's what you're seeking.Personally, I prefer a stronger coffee flavor, and am not as concerned about the calories.  For a pick-me-up, I often want some calories as well as caffeine.  I found the illy drink pleasant, and it's probably right for some, but most of the time I'd probably buy something else.The label mentions that it has cocoa, so I was looking for the flavor, but it didn't seem to me to have much if any cocoa flavor.  Since I don't really want that in a cappucino drink anyway, that's actually a plus.  But if you're looking for a mocha flavor, try something else.

Congratulations to Penny Reid who is quite the Ninja herself - jugging the responsibilities of being an author, a mom of three (including a 4 month old baby) and the seemingly disparate world of biomedical research.  Perhaps not so disparate given that all Penny's books show smart, funny characters, with the assumption that the reader will be able to keep up.  Having recently read a novel where the author thought it necessary to explain what a penthouse is, I appreciate the assumption that I, too, have a brain.Every time Penny writes a new book, I reread all the others.  If you are new to Ms. Reid, start with Neanderthal Seeks Human.  Yada, yada, stand alone... You will have a much richer understanding of the characters by starting at the beginning.  Like most of Penny's fans, these are books that I happily reread a number of times.  There are just so many interesting characters and fabulous lines that need to be stolen/appropriated into one's own repertoire."Also, FYI: Gentoo penguins mate for life. Whereas Adlie penguins prostitute themselves for rocks. Id like to be your Gentoo penguin. -GregP.S. Unless youre open to a rock arrangement. If so, please find my first down payment enclosed."Fiona has always been an intriguing character in the Knitting in the City series and the snippets about Greg always make you want more.  Reid converts will be familiar with some of the swoon-worthy lines in this book, but seeing them in the context of Greg and Fiona developing their relationship is a delight.Thank you to the unsung hero, Mr. Reid, who shares Penny with the rest of us.  Her creativity brings laughter and insight.

The premise of the story had potential, but the continual stretch of the disbelief  cord and disjointed plot elements made this a tough slog.What are the chances that you would randomly catch the eye if some guy in a bar, that he would be in the parking lot  at exactly the moment you were going to get attacked and that the next morning at the courthouse, you would literally run into him when you snuck into an employee's lounge area?  Oh yes, and he just happens to be your soon to be ex-husband's  attorney.If you are still willing to go along with this, then add in that he also just happens to be on the scene when she is carjacked AND that when you inherit a farm two  hours away, it turns out that the hero had purchased the adjacent property a couple of months ago AND guess who is the district attorney  in the county where you have moved to?I liked the yummy description of how cute the Hero was, but the poor guy was no brain surgeon.  Putting a dead bolt on the front door but not the back was one of several things that caused eye-rolling. The worst one was later in the story.Not sure about all the time spent on the wind technology element which turned out to have nothing to do with advancing the plot or involving relevant characters.  The scene with the heroine been lauded for her fifth grade analysis of wind technology was laughable.  I'm not sure whether it was an insult to the heroine or perhaps to the IQ of the readers.When I saw the ratings for this, I ordered the book, only to realize it was already on my ereader.  I had started it and stopped many months ago.  Now I know why.

There weren't any screams or anything coming from the inside.  Good sign or bad?  Hard to tell-this was my first felony and I didn't know the proper procedure."Like Marie, in Book 1 of this series, Sophie has grown up outside the MC world and has done her best to stay removed from it, despite the fact that her son's uncle is a Reaper.  "I might not have my life entirely together, but I was pretty sure about one thing -- parties that ended with stabbings weren't part of the long-term plan."Ruger's tough guy image takes a beating when he steps in to be a presence in his nephew's life.  One of my favorite scenes involves a one-sided conversation between Noah and Ruger."Yup.  Still talkin' about Skylanders," Ruger said, his voice strained and his expression dark.  "Been talkin' about Skylanders non-stop.  I think we ran out of new material a while ago....  We got almost three and a half more hours.  This might kill me."Sophie and Ruger have an extremely complicated relationship that dates back years.  I like that this wasn't one of those "we wasted time because of a misunderstanding" stories.  Both Sophie and Ruger have good reasons for having kept their mutual distance in the past, but sparks start flying.  There is a great secondary cast of characters from the first book.This is definitely a book to enjoy more than once.

If you liked Motorcycle Man by Kirsten Ashley, then I am sure you will love Book 1 of the Reapers Motorcycle Club series.  Every time Ms. Wylde adds to the series, I go back and start from the beginning. It's one of the few books that is as fun to read the third time as the first.You have to be willing to suspend your disbelief as these are romance novels.  Ms. Wylde has done a good job of showing an MC, warts and all.  These are not choir boys. They are hot, bossy alpha males.  Readers who don't like the fact that Horse is too controlling miss the fact that 99% of readers would not like this lifestyle in real life, but it is certainly enjoyable as a steamy escape.  I love that Marie is feisty.  Both Horse and Marie are interesting, three-dimensional characters who evolve throughout the novel.  There is just the right amount of humor as well.  Best surprise of all... there's a great plot!"It's a .38," he said proudly.  "I know you're a .22 girl, but it's time for us to take the next step in our relationship."

To those readers new to Kristen Ashley, start with the book that inspired the whole Chaos series -- Motorcycle Man.  This will be a richer read for having the background knowledge even if it is possible to read it as a stand-alone.DON'T let any spoilers ruin the plot in Walk Through Fire.  While I am not a huge fan of the 20 year love reunion, Ashley does a great job of building the tension about what split up the couple two decades apart.  This novel is full of interesting characters; some who have already had their share of the limelight, but are still relevant (Tack and Cherry) and characters who NEED to have their own novel (Elvira and Malik).Elvira just about steals the show in this one.  She is a slightly tone-downed version of her crazy self with a mission to get her hunk of delicious man down the aisle.  "Malik'll be the one with the bad luck if that man don't put a ring on it AND SOON.  He don't, I got two choices.  Kick his black butt out or kill him.  And just sayin' I'm leanin' toward door number two.  As far as I'm concerned, my girl Beyonc made a call to arms and I listened."  Malik is only in a couple of scenes, but his yumminess is definitely preseent.Logan (High) is a really good guy who acts like a jerk at the start of the novel.  He has plenty of reason to be bitter.  This is a biker full of romance who has stiletto prints all over his heart.  "Millie, you give me your number, do you think I'm gonna forget a single digit?"  "Safe with me.  Never won't be, babe."Millie has been living in a state of suspended animation for the past twenty years.  She has the perfect shell, but is hollow.  Ashley does a great job of having her come back to life.  There are some very interesting moments when both the characters and reader get to wonder if these two would have still been together if they hadn't broken up in the first place.  I really like that they were both evolved adults of their original selves as opposed to to a Sleeping Beauty type scenario.  Life has had its impact on both Millie and High.This book has much less of the convaluted double-negative speak of previous Ashley books and was a much more enjoyable read as a result.  High's kids are both realistic and I liked that his ex-wife wasn't the stereotypical, revengeful witch.  An interesting surprise is Alan, Millie's brother-in-law who pulls out all the stops to protect Millie.  Although not a biker, he definitely has an edge and puts High through his paces.  I'd love to see what Ashley could do with his character.Quibbles?  I could have lived without the bar scene with Hop singing and the guys getting revenge.  Seemed a little high school-ish.I had pre-ordered this book, so was surprised when it showed up on my e-reader.  Needless to say, my plans for the evening changed and I got to work with only three hours of sleep.  I would definitely read this again starting all the way back with the Unfinished Hero series.

One of the main reasons I was attracted to this book was it didn't feature the instant love connection prevalent in Force's other novels.Ryan definitely makes a great book boyfriend.  Susannah, sadly, is much less likable.  She makes a tremendous number of lousy decisions in the book and doesn't seem to learn from them.  Her "doubting Thomas" routine gets old pretty quick.The bad guys are wildly over the top and a situation which could easily destroy Ryan's reputation and multi-million dollar endorsement deals is wrapped up in the epilogue without explanation.

Oophhh. ...  I need to get a neck brace from the emotional whiplash caused by reading this book.  Is there such a thing as love at first sight?  Yes, but it is often confused with lust at first sight.Having most of the characters in a book suffer from the same condition "I've just seen her/him and know she/he is THE ONE" is trite.  In a way ii is a lazy form of writing because the author never has to create a plausible romantic build up.  We are told the characters are in love and it's a done deal.  Some of the characters don't even have to hear the other person speak before being hit with an arrow from the fast food version of Cupid.This is two minutes after Ted meets Caroline:"He wanted to talk to her forever. With a clarity he couldnt begin to fathom just then, he knew hed never run out of things to say to her."The whole drama in the book results from a ridiculous amount of immature behavior by adults who should know better.  Smitty needs some big boy panties.  The demise of a six week relationship, especially when you went into it light-heartedly should not make you leave the hemisphere.  Ted and Caroline could have handled the initial situation so much better. We have a bunch of successful males in their thirties acting like Grade 8 girls.Even if you are okay with the Jello pudding quickie romance, what is the huge rush to want to have babies with someone you've just met?Ted's mother morphs back and force between wonderful and harpy.  Her verbal scud missile near the end followed by another 180 made me scream "Pick a persona already!"Ted shows his wishy washy nature not only in his personal life,  but at work.  Imagine a pediatric oncologist leaving his job with 12 hours notice and his boss saying come back any time.  Hmmm... If you are working 90 hour weeks doesn't that mean you are dumping a lot of work without notice on your colleagues?There are at least three more quickie romances, but ultimately it is Caroline's weakness that causes the book to fail.  We are told that she has survived and learned a lot from a previous bad relationship, but all we get is a Tammy Wynette version of Stand By Your Man. Having the magic poof back in was a huge disappointment.  I feel like we need a Dr. Phil intervention.  Caroline does make a great point when she says, "It was right out of a bad soap opera, for heavens sakes."  Yep.  Couldn't agree more.The ironic thing is that I really like how Marie Force writes, which is why this gets two stars instead of one.  It would be great to read a crock pot romance instead of the microwave popcorn version.

Imagine working at a resort for the super - wealthy.  You break the policy by kissing one of the guests and then you compound the transgression by blabbing about not only what happened, but relaying the info from a private  phone call to another guest. Oooph!Imagine you are the billionaire who has been betrayed.  Do you track down the loose lipped waitress to have sex with her and give her more to blab about??The surprise in the novel is that the chemistry and romance are almost nonexistent.  You have two damaged adults who take turns shutting each other out.Don't even get me started about the whole fake wedding scenario or the ridiculous subplot tossed in at the end of the book.Two stars instead of one because it was free.

Ogle the cover.  Avoid the book.  Here's why."The future was the future, and if her vision foretold the future, which she was sure it did, then she was on her way to the future right now, and everything she was doing was right and taking her to that future.""And when I see you or think of you, a sense of fully knowing who you are and your relationship to me fills my senses - almost like how I can think of a strawberry and know what it would look like, smell like, taste like, and feel like."

After reading this book, I am wondering if it is possible for an author to plagiarize her own work.  The Kathleen Turner series was so good I've read it at least three times.  So, was I up for another of Ms. Snow's love triangles?  You bet!The main issue is that Sage isn't nearly as likable a heroine as Kathleen. Kathleen was spunky, brave, and enterprising.  Sage feels a little like she is faking being middle - class (wanting to know what kind of boat they've been invited on and noticing the restaurant was more Bar than Grill).  Add in the disappointment at being offered beer,  and it just seems as if she is slumming a little when she is with Ryker.Parker is not particularly well - rounded as a leading man. We have basic facts about him, but that's it.  Ryker ' s character seems as if he is a consolation prize for Sage because she can't have Parker.  Her indecision takes over the plot.The whole mafia don scenario could have been more interesting.  It ends up feeling a little artificial.If you love Tiffany Snow,  the so - so reviews likely won't deter you.  If you haven't read any of her books before, don't start with this series.

Book 1 in the Titan series flirted with believability issues a couple of times,  but was still an enjoyable,  steamy read.Garrison's Creed goes well beyond the bounds of believability into eye-rolling terrain.  Imagine a witness protection program where you are allowed to live NEAR your friends and family.  Imagine being able to take the last name of someone very close to you as your new identity AND that you get to keep your first name.  The whole witness protection and testifying storyline was totally glossed over.There are too many villains in this novel with plot twists that are WAY over the top.  Some of the bad guys are so dumb that they give you back your purse because you need lip gloss and untie you when you are captured.There really is no adequate justification for Nicole's decision to avoid her family once she was no longer in the program and it makes her a less likable heroine.  Cash had delicious moments, but was often pouty.  There was a fair bit if time spent on advancing future plots -- Jared and Sugar,  Roman and Beth.If this had been Book 1, I wouldn't continue reading the series.  Because of my fondness for Winter's Heat,  I am willing to try one more book.

I understood this was a prequel when I downloaded it, but having just finished Winter's Heat (Book 1 in the Titan series), I felt like I was reading something by a totally different author.  The action and intensity from Book 1 had morphed into teen angst with a ridiculous plot twist.  Frankly, it was all rather off-putting.I think it might be better for readers to go straight from Winter's Heat to Garrison's Creed and then double back to this if they are curious. After being so happy with the first novel, this has actually damped my interest in reading further.2.5 stars rounded up for freebie

If you are willing to approach this book like you would an action movie and you enjoy a sexy alpha male, then this book is definitely worth a read.  Just be prepared to suspend your disbelief along the way.  This is an adventure story as opposed to a novel about the meaning of life.Harber is such a good writer that when I should have been shaking my head about a couple of plot points, I was too engrossed in the storyline to care.Colby makes a yummy book boyfriend.  The secondary characters were interesting and I am looking forward to Book 2 in the Titan series.

Humphrey Bogart and Audrey Hepburn starred in a black and white movie called Sabrina.  This would appear to be the Harlequin adaptation.I am not sure if I have ever read anything quite so ironic.  Characters who refer to something as being clich while spouting clichs is a new device.  Two of the characters even play a clich game. Think of every overused romantic phrase from the past fifty years.... which made her breath catch...... made her tremble ...... made her skin flush and her heart race... and butterflies would mass and throng in her tummy...  (okay thronging butterflies is a new twist)... every fibre in his being...... the sky was a blue as Barrett English's eyes...... his eyes were dark as a stormy sea...... growing awareness than spread through her gut like molten lava...... she was an angel, a vision...... we might just be a match made in heaven...... his heart literally stopped working for a moment...  Holy clich overuse, Batman!  Don't even get me started the "making this so hard/that's my line/that's what he said" references.Heroine:  "This is such a clich."Hero:  "You're a clich."Truer words were never spoken.  Part of me wondered if the book was the result of a nefarious bet whereby money exchanged hands each time the word clich was used or when a clich was included.  Is there such a thing as a clich of a clich?  A derivative clich?Sadly, the novel lacks a couple of romantic tropes.  There is no amnesia or foundling baby, but since this is the first in a series, perhaps these will appear in future books.  Virgin. Check.  Multi-millionaire/billionaire. Check.  Older hero who held her the day she was born and who has been apparently waiting for her ever since.  (Creepy, but check.)  Repeated female lip biting that sends the hero into a sexual frenzy.  Check.  Fake fiance. Check."... for as long as Emily Edwards had drawn breath, Barrett English had wanted her."A number of other reviewers have mentioned the creepiness of an older male watching a young female teen in a rather inappropriate fashion.  My understanding is that some changes were made from the original version to help deal with this.  The eight year age difference would never have been a big deal if the characters had MET when they were 24 and 32 years old.  Holding her as a baby would not have been creepy if they actually spent a lot of time together as friends and their close relationship developed over the years.  Instead, we have two people who only know each other based on limited interactions a few times a year at most. There is still a stalkerish element when a man of 22 is watching a girl of 14 or even 24 and 16.Not everything in the novel is a rehash of former romances. In a Shakespearean twist, the novel stops and the author speaks directly to the reader.  "Here's what Barrett learned ...  You are giddily happy that you're actually together for real with no more artifice.  You are aroused to the point of discomfort..."  Who talks like this??  Why the need to stop the story to tell us this?Speaking of aroused to the point of discomfort, there is one scene I have ABSOLUTELY NEVER read before.  Barrett's mother enters his bedroom at the family mansion and sits on his bed.  She wants to know what he is doing with Emily.  While his mother is sitting on his bed, this 32 year man GETS AN ERECTION!  Does the ick meter go higher than this??"His body reacted to his thoughts, and he shifted under the covers."Oh, Barrett!" she(mom) exclaimed, springing up from his bed.  She scrunched up her lips in disapproval and shook her head.....SHE FLICKED HER GLANCE AT THE SHEETS DISDAINFULLY before returning to his face."What???  Seriously???  What kind of man gets a hard on while he is talking to his mother about his girlfriend???  This really does push the whole sexually inappropriate male a little far and lends credibility to the creep factor.Although Barrett is fabulously rich and not opposed to spending $30,000 on a ring for his fake fiance, he is oddly cheap in the wardrobe department.  Emily is only given two outfits to go on business dates with him.  One is a black dress and the other is a blue tweed suit.  Tweed?  Suit? She also receives an oddly sensible pair of black heels.Emily and Barrett have apparently learned something called the overview approach at university.  At different times in the story, the characters stop to use this approach to analyze what is going on.  This is apparently a useful device when you are in the middle of a romantic quandry.Don't hang around for the witty dialogue."You and me."  "You and me?"  "You and  me?""Are you okay?"  "I'm perfect.""You're definitely okay?"  "Way better than okay.""What about you?  I was ... okay?"Barrett does a 180 by the end of the book and goes from having a golf club up his nether regions to being more malleable than Gumby.  Mr. English Learns to Grovel might have been a better title.My best advice is to download before you buy.  Two stars instead of one since this was a freebie.

Are you kidding me?? Here is a quote from the book's leading male character, a police detective:"What was it with women and the careers they picked these days?"Apparently our Romeo is shocked to find out that today's Juliet might be employed as a medical examiner or an FBI computer specialist. I was STUNNED to see this was written in 2010 and not 1960.  I'm not sure how making a modern day male cop think like a Neanderthal is romantic.Equally outdated are the computer references.  They simply don't match real life.  It's as if the author in 2010 was many years behind in computer knowledge and teen use of computers.  Before the trolls descend, let me explain that I have worked in high schools for three decades and am in direct contact with hundreds of teens per year.  Teens don't download chat records.  Teens in 2010 would have chat messages on their phone, on Facebook (6 years old when this book was written) or in their email.  They could delete the messages, but even that would be highly unusual behavior. PARENTS of misbehaving teens and SPOUSES who worry about a partner cheating are the ones who download conversations.I felt like the author wanted to lecture readers who were parents not to let them have computers in their bedrooms. This was already old news in 2010.  Having the location of the computers be an element of the plot was forced given that ALL the girls had been lured away from their homes, regardless of where the computer was.In another very odd example,  one of the teen victims saves an email to a special file on her computer after hiding all the references to who the email was from.  This was very contrived.  You would either keep the whole message, delete it all, or download it to your secret spot.  The ONLY reason to download a doctored version is to not give away the plot info even earlier in the book.There are more editing errors than I would expect for a book of this cost, but the biggest issue is that if this is really supposed to be a mystery, the author shouldn't be lobbing clues like hand grenades in the first 10% of the book.It seemed extremely ironic that our police detective was aware of his failings as a dad and felt that he needed to catch the predator so his daughter didn't become a victim.  Wouldn't addressing the relationship issues promptly have been a smart move???Could you do serious praying for Jenna, Connors daughter?Shes in trouble? Ill start now.I'm glad the description of this book has been updated to include a Christian category.  I was surprised to have two different characters talking about church in the first 7% of the book and that in the middle of a crime scene a discussion about the need to be religious became an issue.  Fair enough.  There are many of people who complain about sexual content when there isn't enough warning in the book summaries.I'm pleased for the author that there is a market for this novel.  It certainly wasn't me, and I would suggest that anyone who isn't sure, should download a sample prior to purchasing.

This novel is a safe bet for readers who like romance,  but not steam.  The plot is interesting which helps to balance out the insta-love nature of the story.  The heroine is a woman of many talents.  Given the closeness she has had with her brothers, it is surprising that none of them clued into her despair over the years.There are a few editing glitches (waste/waist), but not enough to impede your enjoyment.  There are some awkward computer moments (password vs code), but my biggest complaint centers on the fact that when someone is in grave danger, you should phone to let them know there is a problem, BEFORE driving to help them.3.5 stars, bonus .5 for being free

The title of this review is a statement made by a character in this novel.  For some readers, this might be enough of a red flag.  If this appeals to you, click the buy now button and skip the rest of this review.A number of reviewers have made comments related to editing issues.  Although the author indicates the novel was re-edited, there are still a number of errors. The editing, though, was the least of my concerns.A major issue is that this reads like a poorly written young adult novel.  There is a juvenile quality to both the writing and plot. As a result, there is nothing that appeals to me as a 40 year old female and my teenager was snorting when I read her some passages.Well written characters have strengths and weaknesses.  It was very clear that the characters in this book all fall into the good or bad category.  Aimee  is good.  Her sister is bad.  Shane is a good guy.  Blake was a very good guy who suddenly morphs into to a bad guy.Aleks is a good guy.  His brother is evil.  Don't be looking for nuance in this novel.There is a revolving door of emotions running throughout the book.  Aimee has always loved Shane until she meets Aleks.  Shane has always loved Aimee even though he dated her evil sister.  We get many chapters of Aimee playing emotional ping pong.  There are great examples of love triangles, but this isn't one of them.Much of the behavior of the main characters makes little sense.  Aimee ridicules Shane for mentioning that his property once belonged to an ancient shaman.  She starts referring to it as a pet cemetery for some bizarre reason.  Later in the book she is screaming at him in ALL CAPS because he doesn't believe her when she tells him something undead related.This is the type of novel where the reader is supposed to believe that a rapist would bring the same recognizable drinking glasses to different parties to put the date rape drug in!!!  This is how Aimee recognizes the poisoned drink.  What kind of clown school criminal is this?Aimee accuses Aleks of not being honest with her from the start.  The fact that he meets her AFTER the death of her mother and has nothing to do with the date rape scenario goes over her head, even when he spells it out for her.  Sadly, she is the smart twin.If you have ever met identical twins, you know the whole point is that you can't tell them apart -- hence the word identical.  In Cursed, the twins are identical EXCEPT:"Where she had JET-BLACK hair and SILVER eyes like our mom, I had BLONDE and BLUE."  Shoot me now.....  So what is the point of calling them identical?Aimee has no respect for her sister or her friends until she becomes instantly smitten with one of them.  Smitten enough to wear Giselle's dress to a party, but not enough to keep tabs on how the old liver transplant situation is going.The author makes a couple of references to Nancy Drew in the book and I did have a few Hardy Boy moments.  When Giselles's mom visits her in the hospital,  the mom's boyfriend pats Giselle's leg and says he always wished he had a daughter.  This morphs into:"Giselles mom is dating an Internet pervert. Hes an actual ped. Do you think were cursed, Dad?"I'm not sure what the health care is like where you live.  In Cursed, patients can swap hospital rooms at will.Okay, but I was wondering if we could share a room. The nurse nodded at us. Ill have your stuff moved over right away."  HA!  This isless believable than the notion of demons and vampires.The attempt at world - building is very basic and even one of the characters says something about not understanding how it works.  Oooph. ..Still not sure?  How about a cliffhanger alert?  On the off chance that you enjoy the story, you need to be aware that there is no resolution.

Anne Calhoun is one of the most talented authors of smart, steamy romance you will come across.  That being said, if you haven't read any of her novels, don't start with this one.  Breath on Embers,  The List, Uncommon Passion, Uncommon Pleasure, Liberating Lacey are all books I have reread several times and love.This was just a quick read.  I am usually willing to go on whatever literary adventure Calhoun offers, but this story fell flat.  Simon has appeared as a secondary character in previous novels and deserved a much more interesting romance than she got in Evening Storm.  Ryan remained two-dimensional and the  HEA wrapped up too easily.  Without giving any spoiler details, I'd have to say the helicopter episode killed it for me.So, Calhoun auto - buy fans should not be deterred.  I just don't want any potential fans to miss her best work by reading this one and giving her other books a wide berth.

I am going to go look for a neck brace due to the hours of head-shaking while reading this book.  I thought Book 1 was fun in an over the top way (4 stars), but this went straight into ludicrous.  I use an orange highlight on my ereader when there is an issue -- editing, plot points that don't make sense, behavior that is ridiculous....  I stopped counting at 100 examples for this novel.If you had some concerns about the believability factor in book 1, I suggest you keep reading this review.Evie wins the Nudie Award for the suspense heroine most likely to rush from a building naked or in her underwear.  There are at least three examples of this.  I've never read a book where this behavior became the norm.  Remember when your kids were three and wanted to run around naked in the back yard.  That's Evie.The biggest issue, of course, is why, at the end of Book 1, Evie has been made a Key Master.  If you are dealing with the potential destruction of the world, MAYBE you want someone a LITTLE less impulsive and more experienced.  That really is a huge deal in Book 2.  If Evie had morphed from soccer mom to super spy with good decision making abilities, that would be one thing.  Instead, we have romantically confused Evie who is a killing machine.  Not so great on the planning or listening to Cooper who is supposed to be in charge of the assignment.One of the reviewers said that the sex components were the best part and I agree.  The love triangle between Servario, Evie, and Cooper is interesting, which is why I gave this two stars instead of one.  What is NOT appealing, though, is the frenetic whiplash in Servario's change of behavior.  Grabbing the heroine's hair and shoving her head into your crotch doesn't rank high of the romantic meter.  The "I'll always be in the shadows to keep you safe", doesn't balance out how he treats her for most of the book.  Neither does being a drug and gun dealer who participates in sexual trafficking.  Wow, he's so good because he doesn't traffic children. When Servario wants her, Evie doesn't want him.  Lather rinse, repeat.If you would like to see a love triangle that works, try Tiffany Snow's Kathleen Turner books.While the world order is in danger, Evie is on a three week time out at boot camp.  Little progress is evident by the rest of the team and Cooper is hanging around watching Evie.  There is time for Evie and Coop to spend the morning in playground equipment spying on her kids' first day at school, but then we are told that they are short on time to hunt down bad guys.If Servario is like Jekyll and Hyde in his behavior toward Evie, Coop is like a junior version of this.  He only wants sex, not a relationship.  Then he doesn't want her to be conflicted about her feelings for him.  Then he loves her kids and treats them like a father.  Then he tells her they can't have a relationship while on the job.Evie:  "What is so wrong about falling in love?"Coop:  "Everything."  His eyes hardened.  "It gets you killed, Evie.  If I loved you I would always save you.  You.  Not me.  This job is about keeping ME alive, not you."  A paragraph later his words are "cutting and venomous", but don't worry, it will be totally different in a page or two.  Seriously exhausting.The men go from snarling over her and wanting to mark their territory to joking about her references to giving birth and her hemorrhoid stories.  Stick a pin in my eye!Evie is no better than the men.  Servario treats her like a ho and she loves him ten minutes later when he buys her Jimmy Choo shoes.  She goes pantiless DURING a mission to drive both guys crazy.  "Call it petty, but seeing him and Servario go berserk over some underwear was awesome."Sex trafficking?  End of the world anyone?  Quit focusing on your vagina.At one point in the plot, we have a character who is so busy trying to lose a tail that he spends THREE WEEKS hitchhiking, walking, and riding a motorcycle in circles before delivering a message.  What???  Why put crazy stuff like this in the story?  The same goes for Servario's reaction every time Evie swears.  The gun/drug/human trafficker doesn't like his women to have a potty mouth and blows up every time it happens.  This of course, makes Evie with the emotional maturity of an eight year old really let loose.  Again -- focus people!  End of the world potential!  One of the most ridiculous scenes is where a character from the first book comes to find Evie.  She is in the bedroom sleeping of the apartment he comes to.  He goes to the living room, but is apparently unable to figure out that the other doors in the apartment could open.  What??Evie's mother could be the conductor of the bipolar train flipping between water boarding granny and a cooking baking Mary Poppins.There are many nudge, nudge, wink, wink moments in the book as if the author is actually admitting how ludicrous it is all getting.* "The spy  and arms dealer is a story for the romance novels, not real life.  Stop being so melodramatic and naive."  You nailed it, Servario!* "It was like Kill Bill.  It was like Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas.  It was like a James Bond movie."* "I didn't know why I had agreed to even do the stupid mission.  It made made no sense."  YES!  I agree!* "My mom shook her head.  "It's not as cheesy as it sounds."  Sorry mom, there is more cheese in this plot than in all of Wisconsin.* "Wow, this sounds like a really bad plan."  Yup!  Of course, two paragraphs later, she says "whatever" and walks away, because world order and all that...Add in the dildo lady and that's when I cracked open the Advil.If this had been a rom com about who wasn't putting the right items in their recycling bin, it could have been a hoot.  You can't combine end of the world scenarios with a hero who makes Dumb and Dumber look like like a treatise on rocket science.

I love the idea of the heroine being a retired government agent who is now a soccer mom.  What if you gave up the life you loved to create a family and found out that your marriage was a sham?  That is the starting point of this book.  Evie is a delight -- feisty, witty and about to get her sexual groove back on."I readjusted by boobs, 'cause they were not nineteen anymore either.  At thirty-six, sometimes they got a little excited about what we were doing and ended up out of my shirt.  I was pretty sure they had tried to jump in Coop's face.""He was a bad man.  A bad man my vagina crazy loved."I pointed at his face.  "You've got a bit of arrogance, just there in your teeth."  Love this!The plot is a little (okay, more than a little) over the top, but still fun. Approach it like you would an action film and you probably won't roll your eyes until the end.  Romance fans will love that there are some steamy scenes and swoon-worthy lines in the mix.  As well, you get two hunky leading males -- Cooper and Servario.  As yummy as the 28 year old Cooper is, calling Evie (36) a cougar  puts him at a distinct disadvantage!"You deserve someone who would cherish you and respect you, and make you more important than everything in the world."A number of editing errors involving sentence structure, word usage, spelling (Roxy called Rozy, defiantly/definitely) and too many muttering characters (27 times).If you are looking for serious suspense or are not interested in romance, give this one a miss.  Romance fans who want a fresh plot with lots of twists will likely enjoy it a lot.

It is believable that two people could have a loving sibling type relationship when young and have these feelings morph into romance as they aged. I would have been on board for that.This novel starts with a highly unlikely situation where the heroine just happens to have taken a burlesque course and the hero just happens to be in the audience as she is doing her graduation routine.  Sigh....I think I could have handled this if we're not for Finn calling Veronica "little one" all the time.  She tells him she doesn't like it.  There is something slightly creepy about the phrase as if he us still seeing her as pre-adolescent.It's a fairly crowded romance with too many secondary characters.  The whole quick wrap up after an afternoon of unplanned babysitting was worthy of an eye-roll.Very light, quick beach read.  Download the sample first.

Brett is a great female lead.  She's spunky without being a pain and comes with a reasonable amount of baggage.  Her father and brothers make great secondary characters.AJ is a good book boyfriend.  He's successful,  good looking, and has an MMA background so you know there's a bit of a bad boy lurking.  The only issue is that he's spent his life being a people pleaser.I loved that there were no "I'm not worthy"/TSTL moments or the revolving door of "I hate him, I love him".  Just two adults getting to know each other.  Really liked how they both stood up for each other.  Definitely some awww moments.My only quibble is that the ending was a little too quick.  Definitely worth reading.

Believability Issues:1.  The whole plot hinges on the fact that you would be willing to test a new invention for your ex-boyfriend who you broke up with because he was having sex with your sister.2.  You don't test the invention in your own country.  You travel with it to a country where using this device is much more likely to cause problems.3.  You are an elite spy who has access to photos online that could change the safety of the world.  Do you a) SEND the files immediately to his boss for safekeeping and to start getting the situation under control  or b) DOWNLOAD them onto a memory stick  or c) print out the photos and carry them away while knowingly being chased by bad guys.  Yes, the answer is c.  Then your boss asks to you SCAN the photos and send them to him.  Ha!4.  Our heroine morphs from a woman who can't even dial a phone under pressure into a butt-kicking marvel in a few days."Em, put your phone on speaker and dial Frank."  (Heroine is wide-eyed, stunned, speechless, and on the edge of hyperventilating.)"Any day now, Em," Mac bit out between clenched teeth.  (Heroine trembles and drops phone twice.)"Now, Em!" (Heroine screams that she is trying.)5.  Your best friend is kidnapped and you report this to your brother who is a police officer.  Does he a) take your statement and open a file  or  b) talk to his superior about what to do with the information  or  c)  lean back in his chair and say that if her boyfriend works for Falcon Securities then you don't have a lot to worry about because he HEARS they are the best of the best.  Then he offers to pray that something doesn't happen to her.  Never mind eye-rolling, I was hooting at this point!Typical Dialogue:"He was waiting for me when I walked into my room.""So he was waiting in your room?"  Hmmm....  and people say there's no such thing as a stupid question."Can you be a good boy off your leash?"  (Hershey the dog barks.)"No, I need a nod."  (Hershey the dog nods.)  After nodding, Hershey asks to discuss the theory of relativity."Yeah, what kind of yahoo blows up a woman's home?"  What is a person supposed to answer to this?  A bad yahoo?  A clumsy yahoo?"Don't be nice.  Em could die any minute.""You can count on me.""I know Jake.  That's why you're the one I called."  Is it just me, or does this have a Hardy Boys feel?Gagworthy Lines:"He deepened the kiss and his tongue joined the DISCOVERY CHANNEL."  What?  He is the Jacques Cousteau of French kissing?"Sometimes a bullet hurts less than a broken heart."  Doesn't it make you want to get a mug or t-shirt with this on it or better yet write a country song?""She couldn't find a thing out of order and the spareness UNRUFFLED her instantly.  Emily met heaven and loved it immediately."  (All this to say she likes the hero's style of decor which is really his neighbor's doing.)THE SIMILES:This is our hero thinking about his life --  "Inside, it was empty as a spent chamber.  His emotions felt like they had been spit out of a blender."  Wow!  Gun and cooking similes together."Darkness closed in like a fog rolling off a turbulent sea.  Mist engulfed her completely sealing her off from the world."  Okay. We get it.  She fainted."Her eyes drank him up like margaritas during Happy Hour."Funniest Mistakes:"You have two nephews.  Eight and Ten."  This reminds me of an elementary joke where Nine is missing because Ten Eight Nine.At one point the hero AVERTS the heroines eyes.  This one had me thinking.  Remote control eye averting.Add to this an over the top sister, villain, and sappy ending.  The result is a two star rating only because the book was free.

If you're looking for a great novel about a female with untapped powers who becomes entangled with a mysterious otherworldly stranger, I have two strong recommendations:a) The Fever Series by Karen Marie Moningb) The Night Huntress Series by Jeaniene FrostWhat is fabulous about these series is that they are rich in plot and character development. I've read through both series at least three times.King's was difficult to get through once.King's seems to be a diluted version of the Fever Series in particular. Both heroines have a missing sibling and are unable to resolve the situation on their own. Enter the tall, dark, rich, handsome mysterious stranger. The Fever Series hero (Jerricho Barrons) is also a collector of mysterious items and uses the power of the heroine to locate what he's after. He even brings her to parties filled with unscrupulous people. At that point, it felt like King's was much too similar to Ms. Moning's work.The winner of the most annoying fictional heroine goes to Mia Turner. I thought I would stick a pin in my eye if she asked another ridiculous question.They go to a party hosted by Vaughn. Mia asks if this is Vaughn's party.Vaughn greets Mack as Mr. Taylor."Mr. Taylor? Is Mack's last name Taylor?"By Chapter 5, Mia is still asking herself melodramatically why she made the deal with King.  Given that all of us know why the deal was made in the first chapter, having this repeated melodramatically throughout the book is frustrating.Whats with King and deals? Is he Monty Hall? Did he brand you, too?" It just never ends!!At one point she does a machine gun question rant:WHO are you really, King? HOW can you vanish into thin air? HOW can you hurt someone with just a touch? HOW did you track me to Edinburgh?Here's where I was in complete agreement with Mia:Im such an idiot. Yup!and with King:I was getting to that. Perhaps, if youd cease with the QUESTIONS, I might be able to explain myself.I am still amazed that my assistant isnt able to speak, answer phones, or, he paused briefly, follow a simple set of instructions." Ha!Slightly less annoying, is that Mia refers to King as a devil 16 times in the book, not including the multiple times she asks if he is a demon. This is in between hating him and wanting to rip his clothes off. In terms of romance, there is none.Minor quibbles:assuring vs ensuringThat meant ensuring (oops) me hed switched over to autopilot.bawling vs ballingMia was balling (ha!) her eyes out.Two stars because it was free. Check out Moning and Frost.

I love J.R. Ward and have reread the Black Dagger Brotherhood series several times.  There is no quibbling with Ms. Ward's ability to tell a story.  The surprise to me was that the paranormal vampires featured in her previous series are more believable than the characters The Bourbon Kings.Part of the problem is the sheer number of characters. We get a sense of each of them, but not the type of character development that sucks you into a novel.  Lane and Lizzie, the leading characters, are two-dimensional and have a Harlequin-type romance. There certainly isn't the strong, passionate vibe so evident in other of Ward's novels.  The old "a lie broke us up for two years" trope is used.  Lane has been laying on a couch for two years in between poker games while Lizzie puts her horticultural degree to use on the family estate.  Finally back together, neither one of them has learned a lesson.  He doesn't give her crucial information which she needs and she doesn't trust him when the chips are down.  Without giving any spoiler details, her behavior at the end of the book is enough to give you literary whiplash.My other issue is the melodramatic nature of the characters and their actions.  Lane's father isn't just flawed, he's EVIL.  Any one of his at least four major transgressions would have been enough.  Chantal is not just a bad wife, she's also EVIL with multiple transgressions.  Gin, Lane's sister, comes with more baggage than Louis Vuitton.  As if her almost two decade relationship with Samuel already worthy of a Jerry Springer episode, Ward pairs Gin up with a new man who is EVIL.  The whole true confessions, a day too late, was a bit corny.The oldest brother, Edward, takes the prize for the most emotionally and physically damaged of the family.  He is probably the most well-developed of the main characters.  Unfortunately,  the scene featuring Edward and Sutton (think Romeo and Juliet with a twist of Pretty Woman) had me rolling my eyes for the first time ever in a Ward novel.  Luckily, Edward is provided with a female who is plucky and GOOD.  She's so good that she gets upset when he swears.The most interesting character is the one least likely to make it into future novels.  We know up front that Miss Aurora's health is in jeopardy.  I like the relationship she has with Lane and Edward during the course of the novel.  It's somewhat ironic, given the importance that she is supposed to have in both their lives, that neither one of them has had any connection with her for two years.  Interesting, also, that she seems to have no connection to Gin, who lives in the same house.  I was on Team Aurora until the "win one for the Gipper" speech.The cast is rounded out by a virtually catatonic mother and a mysterious,  missing brother.If you are looking for a book boyfriend, your best bet is Deputy Sheriff Mitchell Ramsey.  This hunky guy is not only a hero, he's the one who has to clean up all the Bourbon messes.

Violet sums up my sentiments exactly at 77% into the book when she says, "Yada, yada, yada."After the humor and interesting character portrayals in Books 1 - 4, I was stunned to see how much of Book 5 was extraneous filler.So where are you? I asked her.Sitting on my back deck.When did you get home?About an hour ago.How was Arizona?Fun, lots of laughs, kind of crazy. My cousins are nuts.You sure didnt fall far from that family tree.Take a train, peanut brain, she said, throwing one of our childhood insults back at me. So what have I missed here?"The dialogue has morphed from sparkling to deadly dull."Lose the ax, though. Try leveling the playing field for once.The ax? The albino looked down at the blade in his hands and then back at me. You speak of this?Yes, that weird battle ax thing youre holding. I must have conjured that up thanks to the old Conan the Barbarian movie Id watched the other night with Natalie.It is a scythe, he clarified.I rolled my eyes. Are you seriously going to stand here and argue with me about the name of that stupid thing?  Sadly,  he is.Perhaps the biggest disappointment is that although many hints are dropped in Book 4 about Aunt Zoe, she continues to stay on the fringes of the paranormal activities in Book 5.The Donald Duck villainous doppelganger.... sigh....

What I Like:1.  The humor.  Good thing I REALLY like Ann Charles' sense of humor which I will mind meld and spew out at appropriate moments.Mastersons daddy had to be a few clowns short of a rodeo."Violet:  Im not obsessed with Doc.Harvey snorted. Right, and Mount Rushmore is chiseled out of marshmallows."Doc:  "The next time I have you naked, I want to take my time and explore every inch of your soft skin.Hmmm. There were a couple of inches here and there on my body that Id rather he never found. After having the twins, Id roped off a couple of areas and labeled them as no mans land.""... she was always falling for the guys who promised her the moon and then delivered stinky cheese with a side of infidelity."2.  New story line for Aunt Zoe.  Charles lays a series of hints throughout the novel about what to expect in future books.What I Don't Like:1.  Cliffhangers.  I think there could be a better way to finish each book without the OMG moment.2.  No income.  I'm starting to believe in demons and zombies more than I am in Violet's ability to pay for the weekly groceries.  Let this woman sell a house or start poke dancing so she can earn some money!3.  Lack of Communication:  Violet's mistrust of Cooper made sense in the earlier books.  Now it is just getting old.4.  Cornelius.  I think he's the first character in the series that doesn't hold any appeal.What I'm ambivalent about:1.  The illustrations.  In earlier books when you had oat and pig heads melding together, having an illustration made sense.  In this book, we have illustrations of a urinal,  two vehicles, and a hand holding teeth.2.  Given the slow moving nature of the plot and the romance, I think the four books could have been reduced to two or three great books.  That would get rid of much of the irksome, repetitive behaviors.Still a fan and will buy Book 5.

Make sure you read these books in order.  I find it strange that some people start at the third book of a series that is clearly numbered and then complain they don't understand some of the references.If you adored the first two books you will likely feel the same way about this one.  If you had concerns about Violet's propensity for rushing headlong  into danger in Book 2, you might have issues with TSTL behavior in this book.  I began to feel sorry for both Doc and Coop.The element I love most about the previous books (humor) is definitely present in Book 3."His lack of patience with my wakeup routine prompted my current caffeine deficiency, which explained this mornings forecast: bristly with a chance of a black eye.""Jealousy wasnt a pretty sight, and on me it looked like Medusa with bed head.""You have unbelievably soft skin.Its the peanut butter fudge ice cream I lather in every night."

Having enjoyed the literary casserole of paranormal mystery,  humor, and romance that is Nearly Departed (Deadwood Book ), I immediately downloaded Book 2.I've discovered that I actually don't care about the plot as much as I enjoy Ann Charles' ability to create engaging characters.  Doc makes a great book boyfriend.  Violet is surrounded by an amazing cast of secondary characters;  her 10 year old twins, Aunt Zoe, and best of all, Will Harvey.Charles' other talent is her ability to make the reader laugh out loud."One trip to the moon had apparently been enough for Doc, whereas I was all suited up and ready to rocket out of my boots again.""But Im telling you, youre going to like this one.  You said that the last two times.Yeah, well, he has no visible rashes and isnt trying to become a famous ventriloquist.Is that as far as youre going to bend?On this subject, yes. But Im willing to bend a lot more for other purposes.Speaking of sexy, you look nice. That little blue number hugs you in all the right places.Thanks. I had all of the wrong places sucked in and battened down."If you break out in hives at the thought of romance or steamy scenes, this book is not for you.  If you need a laugh and a break, get downloading.

This was definitely a quirky read for me.  I'm sure that a number of readers will be frustrated because it doesn't fit neatly into one category.When in the mood for escapist reading, I am a fan of humorous romance (Penny Reid and Ruthie Knox) and of paranormal romance (J.R. Ward, Jeaniene Frost,  Karen Marie Moning).  Most of all I am a fan of good writing.Dearly Departed is a well - written book.  You might be somewhat frustrated with certain elements in the story or because it is more of a literary casserole than a straightforward meat and potatoes read,  but Ann Charles deserves kudos for creating a very funny, well - written novel.Here's the opening paragraph:"The first time I came to Deadwood, I got shot in the a&&.  Now, twenty-five years later, as I stared into the double barrels of Old Man Harveys shotgun, irony was having a fiesta and I was the piata."Some of my other favorites:"Whats a Broker Associate?  Its someone who is going to lose her job if she doesnt sell a house in the next three weeks."Men had a history of fouling up my life, from burning down my house to leaving me knocked up with twins. These days, I liked my relationships how I liked my eggs: over-easy.""I picked up my stapler with every intention of imprinting Swingline on Rays forehead via blunt force trauma."Violet is the single mom of young twins who is struggling financially.  The kids make for great secondary characters and there are many funny scenes as Violet tries to juggle her personal life with her other responsibilities.Im going on this date, even if it means carrying a barf bag in my purse and slipping off to the restroom every ten minutes."Turns out being single in Deadwood made me as popular as free pancakes at IHOP.""I may not have dated since acid-wash jeans were in style , but I knew a brushoff when I heard one."I thought the dialogue was great and had a number of chuckles.  I certainly liked the novel well enough to be looking forward to Book 2.

The problem with most series, especially in the romance genre, is that by the time you've read three books in a row by the same author you want to throw your ereader at the wall.  Usually it's the same plot with the names of the characters changed.  Sometimes it's a literary quirk that starts to grate on your nerves.That's why THIS series is such a treat.  Katie Reus is a very good writer.  Her plots are interesting,  well - paced and the alpha males are matched with strong females.  One of them, Grant, even says one of the reasons he likes Belle is because of her temper.At no time during this trio did I feel like there was too much rehash from one novel to another.  Each of the brothers gets a complete, well told story.Just a warning for those who are a little shy... there's plenty of heat in the Caldwell kitchens.

The idea behind this novel had a lot of potential.  The reality not so much.  I am willing to suspend my disbelief to go on a paranormal literary adventure, but this was more like stroll to the mall.  Much better examples of a hero and heroine with  psychic connections are Jeaniene Frost's Once Burned and Twice Tempted.The steamy scenes were okay, but Katie Reus has written much better ones.  There was a reveal at about 95% that was an "oh brother" moment.Clearly we are being set up for a four part novel featuring each of the four brothers.  This is not a book I would reread nor would I be tempted by the follow-ups.  My advice would be to download a sample first.

When over 60% of the people who read this book think it is worth five stars, I begin to despair. Since I have not bashed them for opinions I cannot relate to, I hope to be afforded the same courtesy.The plot is nothing short of formulaic - billionaire dom wants control over "helpless'" female. There are mant books like this. Think of a toned down version of 50 Shades or  Aleatha Romig's Consequences.Kyrie comes with more baggage than the Kardashians -- a mentally ill mother, grandparents who need financial help, and a brother she is putting through university for some reason. Big surprise is that she ends up in the clutches of a man who after a year of giving her $10,000 per month sends a minion to get her and whips out the blindfold. The climax is only slightly less obvious than Caitlyn Jenner getting a reality show.If the steam was hot enough, the reader could forgive the lack of original plot or believability. Sadly, there is nothing new or appealing here either. Corny phrases wreck whatever potential mood might have been created and repeated references to Valentine's Godzilla-like body part are yawn-inspiring.The author clearly assumes readers have the IQ of a turnip. Get a load of this:"My sexual partners have always been carefully chosen for their willingness to engage in sex with me upon my terms. By contract, actually. Not a financial contract, as I have never paid for sex, but a CONTRACT OF SILENCE. MEANING, THEY CAN NEVER SPEAK OF THEIR TIME WITH ME."Thank goodness that that tricky contract of silence phrase was explained. PHEW! Had to have a little laugh when someone who has forked over $120,000 before picking up a girl thinking that he's never paid for sex. Especially since that she is told if she leaves she owes him the money he PAID her. Hmmmm... Maybe if you don't leave it on the beside table, the money doesn't count.Then, because we are all apparently country bumpkins, the author does this:"What is usually referred to as the 'penthouse' meaning the uppermost floor of the building...." Gosh, golly gee! Let me get the hay out of my hair and see if I can imagine something taller than a barn. Honest to goodness, people!About 25% into the book, Kyrie goes into a rant over two pages long about why she doesn't like body builders. It felt like the author had realized she hadn't met the minimum word count.The inanities don't stop coming:* "I worked directly for Mr. Roth for almost a year before he even gave me that much of his name."* "Can I try a sip of yours? I've never had tea before. Not the way you're drinking it, at least." Yeah, because Earl Grey tea with a little milk is as unusual as unicorn juice.Here's what qualifies as sexy reparte:"Expect to be woken up bright and early, then." "Oh, goody. Cock-a-doodle-doo." I was extremely surprised there wasn't an explanation or diagram for this witty word play."You don't need coffee, babe. You just need to take this vibrator up your ... for me." Man, he's a smooth-talker.You know the old saying, 'What has been seen, can not be unseen'? I'm hoping that isn't true with books. If the memory of this book is hanging around my skull for another day, I'm going to need an intervention.

Having read all of Ms. James' N.Z. series more than once, I was curious to read her newest novel set in Idaho.From the first chapter, there is a definite sense of being on edge that runs through the novel.  You know something bad is going to happen and it does.  It makes it hard to put down the book.  (The proof is that we are have pizza delivered for dinner tonight.)Cal is an interesting character -- the small town jock who makes it big in the NFL and has to learn how to rebuild his life after a career - ending injury.  Something that bugged me about the story was the mysterious farm (not ranch) he owned.  It is so financially successful that he is able to pull out $200 000 from farm profits per year to pay his brother and sister, not including his share of the profits It was made very clear that this wasn't football money he had earned... Having lived in the west for most of my life, I have never come across any family farm this profitable that wasn't heavily involved with raising horses or cattle.  Given that we know that Cal spends a good part of his time driving up and down the highway, it would be nice to know what kind of magical farm this is.  Maybe Idaho is introducing the same cash crop that Colorado legalized.I liked the back-story about Cal which help balance his Mr. Perfect person.  There is a lot of great banter between Cal and Zoe.  One of my favorite scenes is where Cal ends up choking by how turned on he is by Zoe who tells him that everything she is wearing, including her underwear,  belongs to his mom.  Cognitive dissonance!I wanted to like Zoe more than I did.  Although she has a feisty attitude,  she was overly reserved and lacked confidence.  I wasn't a big fan of the relationship with her father where she seemed overly dependent for someone in her late 20's.So, this was an enjoyable read, but I can't imagine wanting to reread it.

I love stories about quirky characters. Penny Reid 's Neanderthal Seeks Human comes to mind.  The idea of having a hunky leading male with ADD and perhaps a learning disability was incredibly appealing.  Atticus Spenser, an FBI special agent, is a great hero.  Okay, I could have lived without the "My bad" and True that" hackneyed slang.Dr. Caitlyn Cassidy comes with more baggage than Louis Button.  She was definitely intriguing, but I found the more I read, the less I liked her.Somehow I got the idea that this was a romantic suspense.  For those readers who only want banter, mostly one - sided,  this will be to your liking.  There is no inappropriate exchange of bodily fluids here.  If I just wanted suspense or crime, I would turn to someone like Lee Child or Michael Connelly.  This plot  became ludicrous at 80%.If you would like to try an intellectual mix of romance and suspense, try Rachel Grant's Evidence Series.

Since I am a huge fan of Rachel Grant's writing, I was more than willing to suspend my disbelief in order to go on a culturally inspired paranormal journey.A mask as the central character in the book was no problem.  My source of angst was that Sienna is much more the standard, insecure romance heroine than one of Ms. Grant's normal female leads.  Given that this was a short story to begin with, too much time was spent with Sienna worried about her body and why Rhys was with her.  I began to wonder that, too.Given what we know about the power of the mask, it makes Sienna even more bland.  In looking back over the events, we actually know very little about Sienna since she is not in charge for 98% of the book.Sad to say, but if  this was the first book I'd read by Rachel Grant, I wouldn't read another.

Rachel Grant writes the literary equivalent of the best action movies you've ever watched.  Even better is the fact that her characters are all strong, intelligent people with suspense and romance that is off the charts.It is such a great treat to find an author who knows that romance readers actually have a brain.  I loved the idea that Lawrence of Arabia, the Syrian conflict and an innocuous filing cabinet could converge to create such a great read.I am always thrilled to go on whatever literary ride Ms. Grant is offering.  The Evidence Series contains the best cast of characters in this genre.

Rachel Grant cooks up another winner with a hunky ex - SEAL and a sexy historian."I think I just got harder with your use of the word whom in a sexual context.  Wait until you find out how else I can use my tongue in a sexual context.In addition to Grant's ability to write great steamy scenes, she always has a great story - line taken from real life.  Book 3 in the Evidence 3 features a gripping combo of Wiki-Leaks and Somalia.  The plot is great until the end.  Without going into spoiler territory, I would just that the weak link involving a secret that could ignite international hostilities would not be allowed to rest on the hope that things will be okay.This is still a great read.  I just wish that a better effort had been made to tie up all the loose ends.

Rachel Grant is one of those rare romance authors who can weave three dimensional characters and a lot of a steam into a fabulous, suspenseful plot.  To top it off, you don't have to surrender your IQ when reading her books.  Ms. Grant is clearly a smart cookie and treats the reader with intellectual respect.What a treat to have fresh story lines and strong female leads.  The men are alpha, but respectful and the woman have interesting jobs.  No TSTL heroines are allowed in a Grant novel.Imagine a great series where every book becomes your new favorite.

"I underestimated the amount of pure stubborn pigheadedness running through her veins.  She passed out rather than admit she might actually be in the wrong."  And there you have Josephine Maxwell to a T!  Josephine is not always an easy heroine to like and she certainly gives Marshall Hayes a run for his money.  Both characters were introduced in Book 1 of this series, HER SANCTUARY, and although this works as a stand-alone, I would advise you read them in order.There is a lot going on in this story.  Toni Anderson is one of the few romance authors who is able to deliver both steamy scenes and a fast moving plot.  This one involves a serial killer and art theft.There are two secondary characters, Vincent Brandt, the yummy former SEAL who is Josie's bodyguard and Steve Dancer, a brilliant, young FBI agent.  Both of these characters deserve their own novel.Advice to Vince:  "Don't let her out of your sight until I get back tonight."  Marsh looked down at the angelic countenance of the Blade Hunter's first victim. "And don't trust a word she says."

Serenity Woods has written a number of books that I enjoyed, but this wasn't one of them.  There are thousands of books that qualify as a quick, summer read.  They are not all worth five stars.  I haven't bashed the reviewers who left high ratings, and hope to be able to voice my opinion without getting a bunch of negative comments or non-helpful votes for voicing my opinion.  I wonder if the fact that the book was initially offered for free had an impact on reviewers rating it more easily.  The insta-love, insta-forgiveness doesn't merit 5 stars in my opinion.Garth and Chloe meet in a novel way, jumping out of an airplane.  Garth immediately falls in love while plummeting to the earth.  The potential for Garth to be a complex character was there -- war veteran held hostage for over a year and betrayed widower.  Come to think of it maybe he was a bit over the top in terms of his emotional baggage.  Toss in the whole billionaire aspect and he becomes even less believable.  Garth's behavior at the end of the book toward Nick is equally cringe-worthy.There was nothing to "grab onto" with Chloe.  I understand her concern about not wants to be like her bi-polar mother, but other than she smells like chocolate, I don't get what Garth sees in her.  The fact that Chloe blasts her mother with 25 years of verbal angst and then asks for a favor a few days later is also less than admirable.  Over a two week period, Chloe will have your head spinning at her back and forth romantic decisions -- or more accurately indecision.  "This time, I was determined to go slow, and yet, after only days, I knew I loved him."  Honestly, this was more exhausting than a two hour tennis match.Here's a sample of their typical dialogue:"Garth.  I'm serious.  You don't love me.  You can't."  "Are you telling me how to feel?"  "I'm telling you your're mistaken."  "I'm not.  I love you, and I want to spend the rest of my life with you."  "Stop it.  That's ridiculous."Chloe betrays Garth's confidence with two different people, including his mortal enemy.  Not sure this makes her a candidate for future bride of the year.  No wonder Garth says at one point, "I can't believe I'm doing this."  I'm with you Garth.  I couldn't believe you were doing it either.Serenity Woods has written much better books, so if you are new to her, don't start with this one. For all others, I would recommend you start by downloading a sample, with the understanding the first chapter is the most interesting and most believable.If you are still on the fence, maybe this will do it for you:"Love doesn't appear overnight, like... like mould on bread.  It develops and matures, like whisky or cheese."  Enough said.  Literally.

If you haven't read anything by Samanthe Beck, start with Private Practice.  Although you could read this as a stand - alone, meeting Jake and Ellie first will help with the backstory.Josh is a yummy fireman who moves to Bluelick.  Melody has just spent 10 years engaged to a man only to discover that he wants to bat for the other team.This was a cute story, but almost too similar to the late 20's heroine needing to up her sexual game from Private Practice.  The mystery part of this story fell a little flat.Surprised at how good the cover is for Beck's first book compared to this one.

I've just reread this novel and can't believe it was Samanthe Beck 's first book!What I love about the novel is that it is a mixture of sweet, sassy, and funny.  There is no TSTL heroine, billionaire, or 50 Shades wannabes to make you roll your eyes.Tyler and Ellie are both trying to come to terms with how their pasts impact their present lives.  The way Beck gets the two characters to connect is a hoot.  Seeing Tyler morph into relationship guy is definitely worth a read.This is a delightful romance that will make you smile.

My big issue with this book is that it is trying to do too many things at the same time -- unfortunately none of them successfully.You can't label this a mystery since the author lobs clues the size of boulders about who is the bad guy.
