There is a teeny attempt to muddy the waters early in the book, but with a villain the size of a great white shark, there is little suspense.For some reason, our hero Jake, is paired with another woman a couple of times early in the book with another woman.  This character serves to pique the heroine's curiosity and is instantly banished like the wannabe suspects.  The love between the two leading characters is of the insta/rapid cooking oats variety without the steam.There is just enough sex to annoy people who don't want any, but it is too stilted and quick for those who do."Now, now!"  I want you in me, now." is a frequent refrain from our heroine throughout the novel. Emily switches it up once with, "Be in me now!  Ho hum..The dialogue is stilted."Don't get puckish with me.  I just declared my love to you."  PUCKISH??  Who talks like that anymore?"I feel something malevolent when I'm around him and I'm not a woo-woo woman!"  WOO-WOO??"Your fear is our greatest enemy.  We will defeat it."  I felt a Winston Churchill vibe with this one."Watch us become one."  GAK!"Sometimes in a relationship, I've felt like a bird whose wings have been cut.  And all I can do is hop morosely on the bottom of the cage."  Aaahhh, Now I get why Jake was instantly smitten.  The old morose bird analogy...I didn't mind the back story about the battle between cattle and buffalo ranchers.  It might have been more interesting if this became the focus of the story and the book morphed into a non-fiction analysis of the ranching problem (vaccination programs, bloodlines, western American history,  impact of wolf culls....)Definitely not a book I would reread.  I would suggest downloading a sample before purchasing.

If you have't read a book by Julianna Keyes, don't start here.  I absolutely adored her other books, but JUST ONCE has none of the great qualities evident in her other stories.Kate is an extremely odd heroine, difficult to relate to and hard to like.  Even the situation she finds herself in seems contrived.  Apparently highly successful, jet-setting travel writers who have their own trust funds are dying to find meaningful work supervising inexperienced waitresses and cleaning crews at a dude ranch.  I get that she was at a time where she was looking for a new start, but this doesn't seem realistic.  Yes, I'd much rather scoop up condoms and sling hash than lie on the beach and visit exotics locations.Her relationship with Shane is stilted.  There is a ten page description of him massaging a knot in her shoulder.  I had a knot in my shoulder by the time I was done reading that part.  30% into the book I was totally aggravated by Kate and felt I knew little about Shane.  Shane is not a very likable hero, so in that way, they are well suited.  Shane seems to have the unrealistic impression that by working on the multi-million dollar ranch long enough, that he will be able to save enough to buy it.  Not sure what the rate of pay is for cowboy/jack of all trades, but don't think this is a feasible ambition.Kate has an incredibly immature relationship with her high school nemesis, Cassidy.  Given that this is a decade after high school, both women end up looking foolish.  The secondary characters aren't any more compelling.We learn that Shane is extremely fond of nipple pinching, even when Kate doesn't appreciate it. "Why don't you like this?" he asks, twisting my nipples again, making me whimper.  "It hurts."  "Does it?  This is nothing.'"  Are you kidding me?  Kick this guy to the curb!The whole mechanics of the ranch is confusing.  Imagine having to fill out a REQUISITION SLIP to get a live bat removed from a cabin.  What?We hear a lot about Kate's book.  It turns out that she documented working for a month in Vietnam as an unskilled laborer to build a school for the needy.  Her unedited JOURNALS were submitted to a publisher and were of course not only published, but became such a hit that she earned a lot of money off the royalties.  Does the trust fund baby donate the money to the people involved with this humanitarian project?  NO!  Again, what's to like about this woman?No spoilers, but if you can get through the ending without rolling your eyes, you are a stronger person than I am.TIME SERVED and GOING THE DISTANCE are great reads and do a much better job of showcasing Ms. Keyes' talents.  I worry that if people read this book first, they won't bother with her other novels.

SEALS are known for their intelligence and alpha qualities.  Here we have a SEAL who has been interested in a girl and didn't notice she had been flirting with him for a YEAR!!  A self-described Man-Ho, we find out that he hasn't had sex in more than a year. Gee, wouldn't that have made it easier to pick up on the vibes she was tossing his way?Overhearing a conversation about her that she doesn't like, our heroine decides to show her sexual prowess by asking for a threesome.  This of course instantly morphs into our hero and heroine realizing how much they love each other.  I guess there's nothing like seeing the woman you've idolized for a year giving lip service to your best friend to cement those romantic feelings....It would be hard to describe the characters as more than one-dimensional and equally difficult to see the romance in this.Within a few hours, our hero can't believe how things just getting better between them.  What???  Sadly, within an hour he is stomping off to war in a snit because she had the nerve to ask if he would be faithful to her while he was overseas.  Hmmm.... maybe a couple hours after a threesome isn't the best time to try to talk about the whole monogamy issue.  His over the top "our friendship has taught you nothing about me (he didn't let her know anything about himself during the course of their friendship).... everything that happened last night didn't make an impact on you..." is trite.Luckily, a chopper load of SEALS off to a mission waits around for the twelve hour girlfriend to make amends.  Oooph!  I guess not all SEAL missions are time sensitive or that important.  Maybe it was a donut run.Maybe the witty dialogue will capture your fancy:"No getting up."  "I have to."  "I forbid it.""You should go."  Yeah, I really should."  "Go."  "Fine."  You'd think if you were writing a novella, you'd want to make the most of every word.My advice:  download a sample first.

I think Kaylea Cross does an excellent job portraying the men and women in the different branches of the military. Readers can learn a lot about how the different forces operate.  Lethal Pursuit is no exception.The three star rating reflects the romance side of this novel.  Jackson and Maya had one unpleasant encounter in a previous book.  She sees him singing and then crawls into bed with him while he was sleeping.  It was one of the most awkward sex scenes ever.  I get that she is damaged, but why would those brief encounters make Jackson instantly smitten?I'm glad that others readers enjoyed the novel.  For me, when the hostage and escape scenes are more interesting and believable than the romance, there is a problem.

If you are just discovering the wildly talented Julianna Keyes,  you are in for a huge treat.  She's a literary unicorn:  a romance author with who can create a plot with enough tension that you have to reminder yourself to breathe.  The steamy scenes are off the charts and the dialogue rings true.Anyone who has traveled alone will be able to empathize with Olivia teaching kindergarten in rural China.  Anyone who has had to kick-start their life after a traumatic event will see themselves in her.  Keyes does an incredible job of creating suspense by referring to the trauma without explaining it for about a third of the book.  What did this golden girl do that made her flee her home town?Out of loneliness, Olivia starts spending time with Jarek.  Now a construction worker who takes jobs around the world, his military past was all about searching for the truth.  He has spent his adult life building emotional walls only to be challenged by this kindergarten teacher in the process of rebuilding her own life. These are interesting, complex characters that make it almost impossible to put your ereader down.There are a number of amusing scenes where Jarek is trying to figure out how he ends up trying to please Olivia when such behavior is the antithesis of his normal style.  Watching him gradually open himself to the possibility of caring for someone else has him reeling like a concussed boxer.Ms. Keyes does a GREAT job of describing Olivia's experiences at school.  Imagine being responsible for creating a play about Red Riding Hood starring thirty students where the wolf can't be bad and Spidermen rule.I ended the book without being able to understand the behavior of Olivia's parents, but was too enamored of Olivia and Jarek to care.At the time of this writing Julianna Keyes has only three novels.  I suspect I will be rereading these books as I continue my search to find another author in this genre with the same literary chops.

Readers who love erotic romance know that it is highly unusual to find everything you want in one book.  Sadly, sex and good writing don't often go together.  It seems as if many readers are satisfied with mediocre storylines and two-dimensional characters.  Preserve me from billionaire boyfriends, anything to do with amnesia and the dreaded "I need to marry you to get my inheritance".After a series of disappointing recent purchases,  I began rereading Anne Calhoun novels where interesting characters and steamy scenes are written with intelligence.Luckily, a reviewer who  loves Calhoun,  had given an enthusiastic response to Julianna Keyes.TIME SERVED is the real deal -- a great plot with enough heat to singe your eyebrows.  Rachel is a strong heroine worth cheering for.  Dean is an incredibly complex hero with enough emotional baggage to fill a 747.  The dialogue is realistic and there are is a great cast of secondary characters -- not the usual "here are five hunks who will appear in upcoming novels".  Even more amazing is that this book has a very engaging plot.This is the kind of novel where everything on your to-do list gets put aside for the day. I'm looking forward to more literary adventures with Ms. Keyes.

Cara Mckenna is the queen of erotica and erotic romance.  Her characters are complex and the steam is off the charts .  There are no billionaire boss or amnesia plots to cause your eyes to roll which is an added bonus.While McKenna ' s books are always on my reread list, this one was difficult to connect with.  It's not the mfm plot or my ovaries are humming that individually cause my reluctance, but the combination of the two in a twist that was just out of the limits I am willing to stretch my believability.Without giving away the ending, Noah was no longer a believable character and the future is awkward at best.It's not a bad book,  but if you haven't read McKenna before, I wouldn't start here.

Perfect purchase. This is exactly what I was hoping for, and much better than my older, heavier one.I love the small size and comfortable design, so it's not scary at all coming at my daughter's head. She's not the easiest being when she's sick, and this does the trick fast and flawlessly. It feels intuitive, whereas my old one felt awkward. Great instructions come with it. If you are comparing to others, note that this one has really smart placement and excellent design for one-handed operation, so it's easy to use on yourself or others. It's fast, and that makes a difference with kids too. Great solution and terrific product I have confidence in.

I love Lyn Murray's books. This one is indeed a rich tapestry and a compendium of research, stories, images and historical documents that all serve as a meditation on the perplexing nature of time disturbance. This is a hefty volume, and it's easy to read on an e-reader, but you might want the print version because some of the documents are elaborate.My favorite are the narrative stories. Murray writes with tension and a convincing authority that put you right in the scene with her. She illustrates the confusion and wonder that comes with examining rips in time beautifully and to great effect.Some of the research within is disturbing. Why have stories of time travelers disappeared from news media reports? My second favorite section, after Murray's own accounts, was the section devoted to people who may have been time travelers, because that's fascinating to explore. There is also in-depth look into reports from a confessed time traveler that ended up feeling very reassuring about the fabric of time. In all, there is a lot here, and there's bound to be things that pique your interest on this fascinating topic we know so little about.

Lying is so much fun! I loved Book 1, Web of Lys, so I knew I could count on really fantastic characters and a heros journey that didn't feel like a repeat of the standard fare. I'm delighted the second book is even better than the first Lawdon does a great job of expanding the universe and offering great details and developments to the franchise.A huge appeal is that after the initial foray into flying star fighters in the first book, Ly goes to the Star Fighter Academy. This focus on learning to fly is vicariously rewarding to us as readers, and I was happy to be along for the ride, and to have attention paid to fantastic space ships. Add in constant action with lots of great space battles, and our trusty main character who just keeps getting himself deeper and deeper in trouble, and you have a great pageturner!I loved the amped up pace, the increasing problems and how they are resolved, and the persistent threat of the evil Vultarians. The galaxy is at stake, so thankfully we can count on Ly!

I think I'm like a lot of people in my generation, where I'm carrying a lot of student debt--so much that money is sort of abstract--and I didn't receive much financial advice because my family emphasized saving off the top but not budgeting per se. Since I don't have excess income to save, I need to work a budget to find it. Enter Clark's book. He thoughtfully walks readers through goal setting and budgeting in this guide that also serves as a workbook.Clark doesn't waste time. He gives specific instructions on how to set up your accounts (and he interestingly recommends setting up multiple actual accounts) if you are single and how to approach it if you are in a couple. The book closes with actual budget examples.I really appreciate his step-by-step, clear instructions and his no-nonsense approach.

You will not read another book like The Frycook's Revenge!  Deliciously inventive, wacky and wild, this narrative takes readers into the unhinged mind of Billy Bob and sort of shakes you like a dog might shake a rope toy. Think Tom Robbins meets Shark Tank, wrapped in a un-PC wonton wrapper of Ocean's Eleven. Billy Bob is one of those guys who always in on the lookout for the windfall he hopes will come from his next big idea, but he settles for running a con against his former employer. The blow-by-blow and quirky aftermath make for a hilarious tale.The story is stuffed with bizarre characters and details skewering small towns, small businesses and small minds. McClain delights in word play, puns, twisting narratives and a teasing storytelling style. It adds up to a great skewering of everything from Internet culture to consumer obsessions, and it's all a lot of fun. I wish I were as funny as McClain--but you don't want to end up on his bad side!

I've read a few of Slater's novels, and this one has been my favorite so far. I haven't encountered a storyline like this one, so that is a delight. Virginia's story is one of awakening from the dead zone into a full sensory aliveness through her experiences as she's invited along with a bevy of models for a special gathering with Mason Dixon. After that, it's truly one long sensory explosion after another, with Virginia trying new experiences and couplings, and all of it thoroughly described.I dare you to top the blindfold scene midway through the book. It's best in class. I also liked the dialogue where the women were getting to befriend each other as well as discuss their own artistry. There's a line in a scene where the women are mentoring Virginia where it's mentioned that she is learning how to be herself and someone else at the same time, and that truly describes the fun of roleplaying and performance that is a dominant theme through out. All together, Model Behavior is a keeper.

Slater is a master of inventive scenes that breathe hot life into this erotic story. The genius in Binding Contract is first we meet a smart, beautiful, talented woman and then we are shown how whereas Cassie thought she was freely expressing her power through alter egos before, only under what is essentially a series of contracts and agreements (and riding crops and blindfolds, and and and) does she truly find freedom and herself. Her ability to reflect on  this transition and the freedom from the conflict of her thoughts that she eventually gives up adds the kind of depth to this erotic novel that really raises readers' own emotions and involvement.The descriptions are first rate and perfectly handled to be hot, intense and exciting. The pacing is perfect, teasing here, going full throttle there. Many of the scenes are unforgettable. A great story and hot erotic scenes. Well done, indeed.

Beautiful! I recommend this book to seekers of any kind. It is a powerful distillation, offering gentle wisdom to be considered, and it is bringing a sense of connection and synchronicity to my life.In a series of chapter, various threads of guidance are imparted, each featuring anecdotes, quotes or illustrative stories. Each is summed up with a a rule that can be brought into your self-inquiry or medication, or re-read at a later time as a meditation or affirmation.I really needed to read the guidance on creating thoughts for good health and how to trust connections to the positive good around me. You might need something different or the same! This is definitely a lovely tool to welcome into your thoughts.

Intrigue, romance, friendship, conflict, revenge and sadistic personal plus exploitive cultural abuse--it's all in here in this layered historical romance. From the fast-paced beginning to the solid ending, I found Shiri to be an enjoyable read and a memorable adventure. I happen to have an affinity to Egypt as a setting, so this was a major plus for me.Shiri's character was also terrific. Through her experiences we see the devastation of colonialism, slavery and control.  I liked how Shiri had personal motivations for revenge as well as a mission in a broader sense related to freeing people from slavery. The characters seem real--appealing, flawed, and it's easy to be empathetic to their pain. I think the history is fairly broadly painted, but that was okay with me because the point is the story--the love and longing, the brutality endured, the vows of retribution.This is a great debut that got stronger as the narrative progressed, so I'm looking forward to more from this author.

Dark Promise is an excellent end to this fantastic tale. Lara and Trevor are further pushed to the brink, and of course it finally sinks in that it doesn't really matter where they try to escape to. There is no real escape. I loved seeing Lara's powers continue to grow under test and pressure. The passages about her pregnancy were so very good, and then the impact on Lara was immense. We already have seen the couple prove they would do anything for love, and now their family escalates that impulse even deeper because now that they are even more special and vulnerable, the demonic forces are amped up too.It was wonderful to see Gimpel elaborate on the myths and fairytales surrounding new motherhood, as these themes are the perfect fit for the Soul Storm series. What would you do to protect your beloved, and what would you do to protect you baby, who may have even stronger powers than you and your partner combined? Gimbel goes there, in dark and twisted ways, and you won't be able to predict the twists and turns (or as Lara might say, how magic has costs) but they will resonate with you.The ending is rich and complex, with Lara have a sustained reason to keep developing her powers. There is a solid conclusion and also an in-depth Epilogue to complete the structure of the story into the future. A great series full of wonderful characters with real relationships and terrifically inventive paranormal action.

This is a smart, targeted guide to help health care or personal care businesses quickly master marketing and client-base communication in the digital era. The information is specifically targeted for local businesses who perform care services for individuals, though the expertise could be applied to other businesses with similar needs to define their practice and communicate it via a website, social media, and direct communication with a client list. It's really not an option any longer to avoid these parts of running a business,and the benefits of doing it well are lucrative and unmatched in defining your brand.I really enjoyed reading the strategic thinking that guides this information about first building a web presence and then leveraging that presence to communicate and market. The author explains in easy-to-grasp language how to think through choices, and then shows precisely how to implement a plan, down to the nitty gritty of how various platforms, tools and resources work. I feel smarter and empowered to know what to do and when to do it going forward.The book itself is really well-organized with lots of sub-chapters to organize the steps and the information, and with a detailed, hyper-linked table of contents so that you can find info fast. This means that after you read it cover to cover it will serve as a reference book to keep handy, and I really appreciate that. In all, a great guide to an essential top for all local practitioners.

This book offers a research-driven plan to treating and overcoming IBS that anyone can follow. I found it clearly written and super approachable, and I now feel empowered to understand just why the inflammation is so painful and how the problems relate to other parts of my body. More importantly, I understand what to do about it so I can sustain my training. There are specific pain relief and inflammation relief strategies, as well as strengthening work to diminish the impact of IBS.I loved all of the visual additions to the book, including sketches, physiological drawings and photos. All of this is a boon for replicating the strategies and remembering the content, and it made the information easy to understand. The book is also organized thoughtfully. Overall great guide for a painful problem.

Invest Like a Millionaire is a great, well-written guide that distills tons of investment information into easy-to-understand advice you can act upon. It's written in a very friendly, even-handed style. The content starts with basic concepts and then increases in complexity bit by bit in organized chapters. The author gave me the feeling that he was right there with me, anticipating my next question and guiding my decision-making about the right investment choices.I liked the emphasis on gaining a thorough awareness of risk, work and reward that is possible with various vehicles, and I really appreciated the many tricks and secrets that can be especially helpful to those of us who weren't raised with many moneyed advisers around us or who didn't study finance in school. I'm self-educated on these topics, so it's great to have an insider's guide on pitfalls and strategies I need for avoiding fees, hidden costs, tax implications of various choices, and other key topics covered.You have to be informed, even about set-it-and-forget-it funds, and this book is the right size: smart but boiled down so that it's actionable and approachable. I'm working hard to create a secure future, and this book is a really helpful tool in my financial toolbox.

This book is a wild ride fueled by psychological and sexual obsession, and it's several steps above the norm. Its larger than life, bold and daring, pushing the boundaries in the erotic thriller genre just as it pushes the boundaries of the lead characters.The narrative is told in alternating first person accounts, which means we truly get inside the heads and emotions of Alexander and Elena, both of whom know themselves very well and are detailed observers, so that builds connections for readers. The author does an incredible job of keeping the voices of the two characters distinct. Alexander is hard, discerning and commanding, while Elena knows that submission and the ability to forgive is a sign of strength. Their interactions are smart and it's easy to understand the hooks they place into each other. The sex scenes are intense and perfectly executed, as are the other highly eroticized, luxury experiences.It's the pacing that carries the whole novel well, building to a fever pitch place of no return. There's a lot to enjoy in this dense story of pain, replenishment, captivity, submission and the ultimate intrigue of obsession.

Intern Training expertly teases and seduces as it puts you inside the mind of the beautiful lead character, Tara as she encounters increasing tasks that require naked submission. Confused, vulnerable and conflicted, she none-the-less is drawn to the sexual requirements demanded of her by powerful Jacob Henry, and is equally enticed by the inherently controlling world of advertising and the other model-beauties she encounters.Things escalate when Tara moves into his home and meets his wife. Together the couple seduce and train Tara in all sorts of sexual pleasures, including her first time touching another woman. The Cinderella aspects of the story, full of gifts and grand gestures, is fun and appealing, and the scenes with Tara and Genevieve as well as the trio are inventive, highly descriptive and pitch perfect. Jacob is up for the task of teasing, training and satisfying the secret desires of both women.Most importantly, the descriptions of everything from their bodies to sexual exchanges to pain practices was very well done, putting you right in the scene, and it's all paced incredibly well. It's a rich tapestry of an erotic novel that builds and rewards, and the way it all ties into the advertising world makes the book well rounded and distinctive.

Pleasure Bound achieves all of my objectives in an erotic novel. This book is centered on intriguing characters who are well defined, with a good story that advances with an engaging plot, and full of well paced erotic scenes. Erica is a young widow whose sexuality had been primarily most successful in fantasy's and self pleasure. She pledges to finally experience life and explore her fantasies, attraction to exhibitionism, and deepest desire, and the answer to her needs is found in Johnson James, the hot and intense brother of her late husband.Set against the backdrop of Key West, Johnson takes control with seduction and with an awareness of power and submission. Because the author has done such a good job of creating realistic characters we see all of Erica's emotions, from vulnerability to fear to discovery to pleasure, and we are right along with her as she lives out her fantasies of exhibitionism and submission, as well as seeing the impact of her allure and her training on Johnson.The themes and practices of sub/dom relationships and bondage are authentic, respectful and incredibly, unabashedly hot.

Sacha is a moving ending to this thoughtful and challenging series. It definitely went in an unexpected and intriguing direction, and I was glad to have a new generation to meet and learn from in this brilliant family. It's interesting to think about the evolution of understanding on this micro level, and to imagine how the developing conscious awareness and spirituality of a parent could lead to a child who could take that expansion further still, and how all generations would communicate with and guide each other. Sacha is prepared for limitlessness, and he is gifted beyond expectation.It feels as though Law's writing and this trilogy similarly prepares a curious reader to gain knowledge and awareness of world religions, spiritual journeys, matters of consciousness and metaphysical realms. Nothing could have prepared me for the rousing conclusion, though that's what made Sacha all the more rewarding. I highly recommend readers start from Book 1 and read in order. The stories work independently, but the layers of growth and understanding build one upon each other towards a memorable conclusion.

I loved visiting the dark justice of Celestine's world in Redford's terrific, twisted novel. Celestine carries burdens and gifts with her through her days in 1940s New Orleans. She is rightfully angry about the murder of her mother in a race-related incident, and she vows revenge. She is gifted with unusual power rituals from her grandmother's lineage as a practitioner of the dark arts. She is also gorgeous and seductive. Oh, and she has a mean steel blade.  Put those qualities together and you have an undeniable serial killer.The plot is a page turner, mostly to see what Celestine will do next. Will she get caught? Will love safe her from herself? Will her head games when she in under investigate be her undoing? It's all in there and more. I loved the writing, which was full of juicy action and adventure, erotic descriptions of Celestine's seductions, and vivid presentations of her killings, as well as French phrases beautifully woven throughout. I also appreciated the sense of place imparted, because the bayou is a fascinating place.But most of all, I loved this unconventional character, with all too many reasons to develop this misandric hobby, and though she does horrible things, I still found myself somehow cheering her on, and that's a credit to the complexity of the narrative. What's more, I now want a Conjuring Room of my own. In all a juicy gem of a tale!

If you are ready to commit to paying down debt, this is a smart and thorough guide that will give you a systematic approach to getting free from the debt trap.I really appreciated the how the author comes with personal experience about being swallowed by debt and provides concrete examples of how she got there and what she changed to get out. That personal experience is then augmented with research and information to educate readers about the pitfalls and reality of debt economically and psychologically. Then the book moves into really useful strategies guided by an overall call-to-action that prompts you to commit and follow through on everything from new budgets to strategies for managing the old debt. At the end of each chapter there are homework questions to either prompt self examination or action--serious action. I have a lot of anxiety and denial about this stuff, and the homework helped me get all the details of my various debts onto paper which made it approachable.Clear and easy-to-understand, and very importantly for me, non-intimidating (I have enough bad feelings about my student-acquired debt and how that sets me up for more debt), Moore's book is a winner. I plan to stick with it and I recommend it if you are looking for a good guide to getting yourself out of the red.

This is a gem of book, a great story in the hands of a superior writer. Two intertwining mysteries snake through heart of this nuanced take of rural Gulf Coast life. A Sheriff investigates the death of a man held in jail overnight and also investigates, through memory and relationships, his own past -- including the life of his father, who also served in law enforcement. The result is literary fiction that relies on and transcends the mystery genre, replacing what we think we know about how things work with a true-to-life character and a study of how things really are.Carefully observed details illustrate a host of characters, a distinctive place and traditional Gulf Coast Florida life. Dietrich has an obvious affection for and facility with the language and stories of the windswept construction workers, fisherman, sheriff deputies, drunks et al -- good ol' boys who learn to fish, hunt and skin a squirrel as part and parcel of becoming a man. He captures a slice of life and conveys a sense of place with able, affecting prose that is in equal measure moving and engaging, with great country sayings and a dry wit in many of the conversations. So many bits stay with me, and most of them were small things carefully observed, like how a woman might woo a grief-stricken family with food but not get the rice right because she rinses hers, but the departed did not. Just fantastic, the meaning in that space between the rice and the way Dietrich weaves in such observations and motifs.The story is integral to this, showing how people are all known and not known to each other, and to themselves, and how they handle grief, duty, denial and disruption. There's a lot in this novel to recommend and I really enjoyed the time I spent in Dietrich's world.

Compelling layers of stories and reports weave a dark and mysterious narrative in The Tuck. Murray is a master of suspenseful storytelling and reportage, weaving together story, research, first-hand reports and data all on the topic of experiences with unknown large monsters/animals in the woods. When I lived outside Seattle these stories were not uncommon and always told with a bit of trepidation but a lot of conviction. What is behind the enduring nature of these legends?Murray explores the topic with an open-mind so that readers can drawn their own conclusions, or add this to their own piles of anecdotal research, or just enjoy this cultural fascination. Much of this content was new to me. i had no idea we had President with a Sasquatch-type sighting, so that part of the book was incredibly interesting. The first hand reports were fascinating to consider from a logical point of view, and from a paranormal one as well.This collection has fun material for Big Foot fanatics, too, including some puzzles and artwork. The best part, though, is the titled tale, wherein a narrator tells a campfire-like suspenseful tale of an encounter that offers a paranormal take on the Big Foot phenomenon. It's well told with just the right amount of tension, humor and lots of imagination. In all, a rewarding collection for anyone fascinated with reports of spooky monsters in the woods.

Murray has a fine hand with complicated and disturbing paranormal content, and this collection is unsettling and chilling! I have never heard of the BEK phenomenon before, so the hair on the nape of my neck is suitably raised, and Murray is to blame because she's such a skillful writer, bringing the worst imaginings to life with her perfect prose and really clever way of pacing with both urgency and elaborate detail everything from first-hand stories to case studies and research. She's really in command with these tales, like a reporter from the dark side of the paranormal mind.This book is a collection of stories about BEK experiences and other related topics. I am very intrigued with the way the concept of alien hybrid babies was discussed, though it is deeply disturbing stuff. The collection also goes deeply into many aspects of the New World Order theories that might have relevance. Murray's elaborations are compelling and give insight into what these stories might mean to all of us, past, present and future, even if we can't discern what BEK's really are or what people's visions of them represent.This book has a lot of diverse content that is well presented and accompanied by haunting image renditions of BEKs. Myth, legend, paranormal mystery, fact of life -- whichever you decide this is a great collection to prompt your research or your nightmares, or both!

As a lifelong bookworm-type Im finally admitting that I need to pay attention to creating fitness and wellness in my life. Weight gain, middle-aged spread and general lethargy are starting to creep in but I'm finding it harder than ever to lose weight, so this book was really helpful in explaining that the problems of my metabolism can be fixed. This great guide is just what I needed in order to fast-track my plans. It hones in on the information I need to understand how to counteract what years of previous inactivity has done to my metabolism and how to reverse that damage by leveraging solutions for weight loss, fitness and energy. The book presents this content in a really easy-to-grasp way that makes sense.The author lays the groundwork for understanding the expert advice by first discussing the medicinal and scientific information that explains the importance of our metabolism, including the hows and why of metabolic functioning. I really wish I had read this information years ago, but better late than never. It really is a keystone to understanding the systems of the body and why some of us struggle with weight gain and loss of energy as we age. Fortunately the author then offers expertise about how to boost metabolic rates through optimal life choices that will naturally lead to weight loss and energy gains. Lots of tips, strategies, and guidance is offered.If you are looking to gain information fast about how to understand the role of metabolisms and how to get yours working optimally, this guide can be a great resource and inspiration. I really appreciate how the author made it all very approachable without judgement and I now feel as though better health is within my grasp now that Im on the right path in all, very empowering information!

If you are in the mood for a sexy, lush romp with intriguing characters leading fabulous lives, this is a great contemporary adult romance that will deliver a hot, satisfying escape. Chemistry explodes between a Renaissance man just home and recreating his life after being a UN Peacekeeper  (JD) and a beautiful seductress (Melanie) who lives in the high fashion world. They have an obvious powerful attraction, but plenty is in the way. Their timing is off, and I liked it that the author has the empowered female character being the one who wants to move faster. There are betrayals and broken places to heal, and then there's the matter of JD's crazy parents who are stuck in a horrible marriage--making them a sort of reverse romance where you are rooting for them to break up and leave JD alone!What's terrific about this novel is the characters are absolutely realistic and then they are put in uber glamorous locations, surrounded by art and fine dining with all the world as a playground. We get insider peeks into high fashion life in NYC as well as into the goals of JD's admirable work. This takes all of the seduction up several notches as we are taken along this glamorous ride in a believable way. And even better, the hot scenes are super well written, steamy and satisfying. All around, a great read!

I absolutely love Josephine and her friends and foibles. Lots of great stuff is going on in this book. First of all, it's very funny, while at the same time being propelled by a good plot, making for a really engaging read. The humor arises from the biting dialogue, which is really clever, believable, and adds depth to the characters. For example, one character called her ex 'Spot" in reference to his complexion and his doggish behavior, and funny details like that are liberally sprinkled in to the scenes. Josephine is a great character, an aging wizard who just wants to retire. She's fantastic and if she were my aunt I'd be thrilled to visit her in Siesta Key, even though trouble follows her, or rather calls on her, as she is required by the government to assist in the solving of crimes based on her keen abilities to read energy in a room or off of a victim, much like a forensic scientist reads physical evidence. Really cool concept that is well executed throughout.Another strength in the story is the creation of the world of wizards, with all of their powers, limitations, strength and vulnerabilities. O'Riley has done a great job of invoking complex rules of how a world that somewhat accepted these powers would try to use and control them, and having Josephine up against all of that as she tries to solve a serial murder case is excellent. It's all very well done, unfolds visually like a rewarding movie, and readers will be satisfied with the way it crosses many genres.

This companion to Station Eleven offers a lot of smart analysis that added depth to my understand of St.John Mandel's novel. I read a lot of apocalyptic genre fiction, so I knew I'd love Station Eleven from that point of view. Since the book hit so many "Best Of 2014" lists I wanted to better understand why this book broke out of its genre to become respected in all literary corners. This summary and analysis provided those answers.The analysis helped me look deeper into things like character names (I did not pick up on the connections before reading this Book Sense companion reader) and the reason for the repeating motifs of airplanes. This companion reader turned out to be a really helpful way to add to your understanding, do research on the book or prepare to discuss the book after reading it.

I've spent the last few days putting the tips and practices outlined in this book to work, and it's a whole new me. The Cleanup Artist is full of really useful advice to help turn those of us who didn't get the cleaning and organizing gene into adults who can create and maintain a nice home. Best of all, the author's tone in a great combination of inspirational, expert and non-judgmental. This is reflected in the great organization of the book and the easy to understand (and then find again when you want to refer to it) presentation of how-to advice and guidance.The book gives specifics for tools, for how to prepare to clean, and for products to choose across budget lines and with family safety in mind. I really appreciated the safety angle, as an awareness of allergens and chemicals in important to my family. Similarly, as a parent I loved the discussion of age-appropriate chores! The room-to-room guides is the info I'm really putting to use, and I'm finding it smart and easy to remember because it is all so detailed and well-described.This guide is helping me meet my goal of a cleaner, more welcoming home that doesn't put me into a panic at the thought of a friend knocking on my door, so I can recommend it to anyone looking for strategies, tips, ideas and best practices in household happiness.

Rightful Owner is an excellent whodunit worthy of Agatha Christie -- though I'm not sure I can picture Dame Agatha in a Cambridge area swingers club!  Martin skillfully unwinds a page-turning procedural for a murder that happens while couples are swapping partners at an exclusive gathering, and it turns out to be a brilliant backdrop for secrets, lies, and mayhem of all sorts. The crimes get worse before all is solved, and this makes for a riveting plot.What is exceptional about this novel is that Martin shows the story from all points of view. We have a detective team to follow, and they are great characters in a complicated relationships of their own. We got to know the thoughts, and reluctance to swing, of the murder victim from her point of view, and throughout the procedural part of the novel we saw various convos between the party goers from their points of view. Telling this story in this way made it all the more tantalizing, because we weren't only privy to what the detectives knew, and we often knew when suspects were lying to each other and in the investigation.It all came together fabulously at the end, well-paced and smartly done, and it's possible to solve the mystery with all of the facts present but not everyone will because it's juicy and layered with secret agendas. Nothing is more rewarding than that!

This is a great story from a promising new writer on the scene. Mercenary gave me everything I look for in an epic fantasy. First, the characters were full portraits of dimensional beings speaking good dialogue, and this hooked me into the story. Secondly, the action has to be compelling and exciting, and Kiln delivers very well. The book is broken down into more than 50 chapters, each moving the story along brilliantly. The universe is tight and fully realized, so it wasn't long before I could turn myself over to the writing and just escape into the world. And third, I look for books that have a good story that is elevated somehow through themes or uniqueness. I really likes how Kiln has presented this hero's journey and showed the growth of his caring for Princess, and I liked how both sides of the loyalty coin were explored, because that is something we don't always think about in wars or power struggles--that each side has its own definition of what it means to be honorable.In all, a great book to jump into. I really admire his writing, which has an ease in everything from describing action to the foreboding feeling of evil to the little details, like an egg and crumpet breakfast, that really put you there in the book. Looking forward to more from this author!

With an exacting and poetic layering of concepts and observations, the author explores some of James Hillman's concepts as applied to her personal experiences with fencing in the farm and cattle land of the plains. This jogged so many entry points for me in integrating the necessary framework of psychologizing into the American journey and to understanding where we have faltered or been deluded, and this is particularly useful to my ongoing research as well as having applicability to many fields. "Why does our ego feel defended by fences" and how have we inherited both the yearnings and the pathologies of the nation's "settlers" psychologically AND formalized in land use policy are concepts and question raised in this essay that will stay with me for a long time.And as the author further guides by example, this externalization yields understanding when turned inward as well. Where have I drilled down fence posts? What deer and bison (as representative of fantasies, dreams, and true wild nature) am I keeping out and at what cost. Beautiful, smart writing like Paton's is a sure pathway into connections and discoveries, and Living on the Land: The Earth Itself rich and resonant inspiration.In both a gained understanding of what we've done to our land and national psyche with Manifest Destiny to an evocation of my own relationship with fencing internally and externally, I am ultimately comforted in the author's reminder that true progress is not a linear function, because remembering that allows space and hope that we can make corrections and change. The book itself is flawlessly presented with lovely photographs adding to the messages. In all, I highly recommend this book as specific research and as an important mind-opening letter in consideration of how our land's divisions reflect and affect us.

I read The Goldfinch last year, and needed to brush up on the themes to see if there are examples I can use in an essay I'm writing. This Sidekick publication was just what I needed. It offers a thorough chapter-by-chapter summary plus really thoughtful analyses of themes, symbols, characters and motifs. This made it easy to brush up on what I had read while also expanding my understanding and appreciation of Tartt's novel. I had missed, for example, the importance of ships as a motif entirely, and I had a lot of questions about the order of events in Amsterdam with Boris that this Sidekick was able to address.If you need an easy-to-comprehend resource to help you increase your understanding of The Goldfinch as a student, book groups or engaged readers, this guide is a great solution.

This is a smart, well-written and incredibly well-researched look at religion, at the questions, logic and fallacies surrounding various belief systems and at the role religious beliefs and organized religion play in shaping (and manipulating) society. I am personally committed to rigorous engagement on these topics, because I think we all need to be able to do three things: understand our own ethics, understand the choices/beliefs/actions of others even when they arise from a different framework from ours, and maybe most importantly, talk with others about these topics. This book helps with all three. It will challenge you with a rich array of thought leadership from the ancients to contemporary thought to help you shed misconceptions and to find your own truth, will help you understand the framework of the religious maybe even better than they understand it themselves, and will arm you with the info you need to have intellectual and useful conversations with religious believers, atheists, and those in between.The book is organized well to serve first as a cover-to-cover read and then to serve as a reference book where you can look up various thought leaders, logic arguments, and religions which are broken down in chapters to explain the history, tenets and impact, including the "dark side" of each.  I learned plenty of new information (for example I thought I knew Ghandi's story but it turns out I didn't) as well as finding lots of aha moments where the author very aptly described feelings or assessments I was having but didn't know how to express about some aspects of Christianity, Buddhism and Islam. There's much more.This book is a celebration of thinking, ethics and morality that is rooted in truth, not in blindly assuming religious thinking that is offered to you. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good way to understand the history of religious thought, the logic people try to use to defend it, and the many alternatives for ethical thinking that are possible.

This book is a balm and a treasure. I find it necessary to have thoughtful guidance on my path toward individual growth and towards a more humane society, and The Rainbow Bridge offers just the kind of guidance I need: smart, deeply compassionate, embracing of all people and possibilities, open-hearted, centered on kindness (to ourselves and others). The author deftly is challenging and supportive in just the right measures. This is a volume to turn to again and again.In the first part of the book, Hunter defines the concept of Rainbow Bridges and the phenomenon and yearning for connection that carries it forward.  The second part delves into an exploration of the principles of the concept, making connections between various other religious and philosophical teachings to show the cross-cultural universality of the principles. I really loved how the ideas are presented so beautifully and easy to understand, making the material broadly accessible and making it a model of the very open, friendly connectedness it teaches. There are 60 sections that can easily serve as daily thought meditations individually after you have finished reading the entire book. The concepts at the end of Part II are necessary reading and felt truly supportive of seekers and had direct relevance to my individual path.  Part III focuses on cultivating inner peace and contains excellent meditation instruction along with other tools for mindfulness and an integration of the concept of The Rainbow Bridge, and then the book supports and challenges readers with an in-depth analysis of how we can share that inner peace outward by building a human-centered society and world politically, economically and culturally. It's rare to find an author who can first of all make all of these connections, and secondly share it all so eloquently with readers. I left the book feeling wiser, centered, purposeful and empowered.There's much more, including inspiring quotes, resources and specific examples. In all, I am struck by the way The Rainbow Bridge synthesizes important universal principles and puts handles on them so that are easy to grasp and integrate. This is an essential read and is most definitely one to share, creating bridges of wisdom with the recipients!

Wow. This is a book, a series actually, that you want to press into your friends' hands and compel them to read it. The Aquarius Trilogy uses storytelling to weave together a stunning inquiry and answer to what our society is experiencing, and imbues the story with the richness of eons of myths, religion and philosophy. On just a storytelling level it works as a novel with twists and turns, disaster, rebirth and triumph visited on our beloved characters. Beyond that it functions as a philosophical gift. Are we moving forward or backwards? Are we evolving, devolving, or circling to a realm we don't yet comprehend? These themes run through OLYMPUS along with so much more in a text so rich each reader is bound to have their own experiences with what stands out the most and with what is most resonant. In short, it's a love story between people and with all of humanity, with all the ups and downs inherent in that which is alive.I would love everyone to read this smart, fabulous series. Truly great!

If you are already addicted to grant Reed's super witty and clever cross-genre mysteries, you will not be disappointed in Something Stinks. If you ARE a newbie, dive in, you have found a good series and author! This book stands on its own and you can then move towards others by Reed. Fair warning: he brings his universe so brilliantly to life that you'll end up wanting a robot that cleans and a smart talking dragon of your own.I love both the big, overarching story, which is packed with twists and action, and the small moments that add fun, and dimension and are a hallmark of a great storyteller. For example, noting that Merle the dragon would need slits in his prison garb for his wings. Or describing in just a few sentences how a letter from a long-lost love interest who views herself as your sister because you had the same teachers in learning to protect this realm would feel. So many good choices and great dialogue make this series a great binge-reading choice with just the right blend of darkness and wackiness. Something Stinks has a solid resolution and is a good entry point for new fans and a delight for those already in the club.

This is a super useful companion text to Moriarty's novel. It is well-written and incredibly well organized, with summaries of the characters and chapters enhanced with smart analysis of the plot, themes and motifs in the original work. This makes this summary and analysis incredibly useful for students, for fans and casual readers who want to delve deeper into the text, and for book group members who might want to brush up on plot developments or review some analyses to enhance their understanding of "What Alice Forgot."I appreciated the way this guide gave me a entry point for an examination into Alice's character, her journey, and her struggle with both the passage of time and with recovering memories. The Book Sense analysis summed up in a cogent way these pressing themes and makes it easy to find specific examples in the original text. Excellent resource and companion to this fantastic novel.

After reading this beautiful exploration of the author's deep connections to the places around her, I feel inspired and moved to conduct my own examinations of the places I have lived and the connections they have formed internally and collectively. Paton's writing is lovely, at turns lyrical and also rigorously informed major thought leaders across many ecological, cultural, linguistic, rhetorical and psychological disciplines. I was enlightened by her specific attention to the archetypes and histories of the Great Plains, which have universal connections to our conception of the most compelling of American archetypes, so as I traveled along with her I was able to interrogate my relationship with (or selective memory of) what it means to be shaped by the mythos of pioneers and Manifest Destiny Her discussions about everything from land and space to weather to the archetypes spawned by our relationship with land were so provocative I was further inspired to apply the same questions to my homeland of Florida, which is rich with history, space, similar weather-related destruction, and now a particularly American imagination.This is great writing that educates, illuminates, provokes and inspires. I highly encourage you to engage with the text whether as research about the archetypal power and resonance of place, as a specific look at the soul of the plains of North America, and/or as a prompt to your own engagement with the land that shaped and continues to shape you. Thank you to the author for this heartfelt work!

This is an essential guide for anyone, particularly senior woman, considering or currently using Internet dating sites. Finding companionship and maybe even more happens everyday through the connectivity offered by the Internet, but as wonderful as Internet dating can be, there are so many options and lots of pitfalls to navigate. The author addresses all of this and more in a serious, detailed, supportive way.The author offers an immense amount of tips, insider information and advice in this rich resource. I love her style -- it's direct, focused, smart, and witty, like the friend or sister who has read everything and tried a lot of options and can boil it down to the essentials for you. Pure, distilled creme de la creme of how to succeed in online dating. She calls out the truth -- good, bad and ugly, cites numerous resources, and leaves readers informed, confident and empowered.The book organization is clever and intuitive. She starts with YOU -- how to choose a platform, how to safety set up accounts (really important tips for that are included) and how to market yourself honesty and with an understanding of who you plan to meet. The next section of the book is focused on HIM --- how to read profiles, how to interact, spotting red flags, how to interpret his behaviors or messages, and how to date him/flirt with him/get to know him online first, and then how to handle transitioning to real life dating. Lots of links and resources are included. In all, a great primer from someone who understands her audience and their special needs, goals, concerns and opportunities for finding love and companionship via online dating.

This is a well-written and impeccably organized guide laying out the essentials of travel for India, with a complete offering of extra tips and authentic advice, as well. I really appreciated the detailed advice and reassurances on everything from clothing options that are culturally-respectful for travelers to touring with children in tow. How to shop, what to eat, where to go in each region--it's all here.I really appreciated how every mode of transportation was explained with very concrete tips on how to procure and ride. From how trains work to rickshaws, this is essential information for safety, budget management and effectiveness while traveling. This expert advice provides a lot of comfort and help! In all, a fantastic resource for travel planning and to understanding how to approach beautiful India as a visitor.

This cogent guide is just what I needed to focus my attention on manifesting my goals. To the point and written in an easy-to-comprehend style, this book is a pure distillation of Law of Attraction principles. The author makes a convincing case for the power of conviction and for setting outrageous goals that will prove that the theories and principles within The Secret Book of Manifestation work.Chakra lays out the principles and theories on why and how to manifest what you might have called coincidences in the past. Most importantly he describes specific actions to take to manifest goals, desires and rewards in your daily life. I appreciate how the information is distilled and concentrated, with no fluff, and therefore its super powerful, like a vitamin or a stick of dynamite. Many thanks to the author for this powerhouse guide!

A NutriBullet is a commitment to a new way of preparing nutrition, so this guide is a really well done bridge to help people previously used to blenders truly know how to put the NutriBullet's extra abilities to pulverize to work. This book has great recipes that are drool-worthy and get you to start planning the next day's smoothie after you finish each one! The best part, as far as the organization of the book, is that the smoothies are ranked for beginning users to help kids and non-green-smoothie types get used to benefits of our new habit (like how to hide spinach in a berry smoothie) while scaling up towards less-sweet smoothies along the way. This is great for me as a parent, and also useful for me as smoothies are a new commitment to healthy eating for me as well. This added editor's guidance sets this book apart, and it's a huge bonus.The central success, though, is the recipes, and all are appealing and balanced, usually offer possible variations, and all contain detailed nutritional value information. I'm learning a lot about everything from the benefits of parsley to ways to use grains in my NutriBullet. All in all, a delicious guide I can highly recommend.

Really useful guide to the best movies with lesbian characters and themes. Each listing includes a plot summary and some details, like date of release, stars, writers and director. It's a blast to thumb through remembering oldies (Go Fish) and finding new ones (like I've never heard of Mango Kiss, and now I need to see it because the synopsis pulled me in.) The rankings seem right on to me -- of course each person might want to shift some around based on personal preference, but that's half the fun of having rankings. I could argue with myself for a bit about whether to rank Aimee and Jaguar above or below Foxfire, for example. I can see this list settling plenty of debates! All in all, a fantastic resource for helping quantify and define the leading dramas and comedies with lesbian stories or characters.Read via Kindle Unlimited

If you need a juicy, glittery tale of the glitterati featuring fun dialogue and plenty of scandal, power plays and romance, this is a great choice. Tiah is our narrator to the fast and glam world of a young rich crowd, with money to burn on gowns for charity events and a scintillating network of gossip, backbiting and, at turns, hot romance pursuit, humiliations, sexy rumors, abuses of power, old wealth and entrepreneurial dreams and drama of all kinds.Of course we're rooting for her to survive bad relationship moves and to score a triumph of the heart. Beyond the soapy and humorous back and forth in this fantasy land of the young, rich and restless, there is plenty to also relate to as people are coming of age and learning about adult life for better or worst. Highly addicting reading and a great start to a series!

Wow, what a harrowing and hopeful tale. I'm a big fan of Samantha Johns' writing, having loved all 3 books in her "Repentant Demon" trilogy, so I trusted I would find similar high-level plotting, story and character development in Finding Jayda. I was richly rewarded! The writing soars, and the character of Jayda is a winning, well-defined woman we come to relate to, root for and suffer with throughout the novel. Along the way there are great scenes including romance, courtroom drama, and relationship and family drama.Her journey is a punishing one, and it wasn't long into it before I was wishing miracles upon poor Jayda. The author shows us is many small ways what it is like for a person to live with PTSD and to operate on the survival level while praying for more. I liked it that Jayda struggled because I really related to it, and it made her redemption so emotional. She fell into a shallow relationship without feeling truly connected to that man, but he had a profound impact on her life nonetheless.Her self awareness and attempt to take care of her self added even more danger to herself. I see her as a heroine, trying hard to rid her life of snakes while finding her spirit and her way to grace and miracles. That's the real "finding" in the title, and it had me cheering loudly, even if I had to gasp and worry here and there along the way. Samantha Johns has done it again!

Witty paranormal detective work featuring two acid-tongued bickering vampires and a cool female protagonist as the Normal? Yes, I'm in! What's better than finding Vol 1 of a clever new series?  I'm really looking forward to exploring more of West's writing.I loved the humor, and the dialogue that really sings --and sometimes stings--between Frederik and Ebenezer. The story is strong, providing complete escape and a solid mystery as its base. The details are what elevated the story for me, too, like the funny, dry conversations in a morgue about how people all to often assign fangs to the wrong teeth. Very fun new writing to enjoy, I highly recommend.

What brilliance this is. I'm a longtime fan of Stan's writing, and it's nearly impossible to find comparable smart, curious, insightful and imaginative writing on his level. In The Gate he turns his formidable mind and keen vocabulary on a heartfelt and sensitive subject that suits his philosophies very well. How do we construct a life with love? How do we teach ourselves how to die?I knew I'd find his typical brilliant wisdom on everything from how time unfolds to how faith, loyalty, love, distractions and our self concept affects the way we live. But I was delighted to find even more in The Gate, including interesting characters (my favorite was Father Mulligan) and the humor that was brought to bear by the many observations of human behavior in the chapters (like the absurdness of a physiotherapist screaming at a circle of dementia patients to return the ball.)Most importantly, the book does something I've never experienced before in moving from very self aware memoir towards an awareness of the dementia/dying processes, and then to a lack of awareness of them. Achingly beautiful and so very human in the best ways, I highly recommend The Gate.

Brilliant! I love everything about this book, from the concept to the execution to the characters. Alex, a girl, is adrift in a new realm, putting her on a heroic journey, which is terrific on it's own given that good female leading roles in adventure and battle books are so preciously rare. She comes to learn that what will save her is harnessing her smart brain, and that unlike the common assumption that math, science and adventure are not girl things, she will be taught to focus on the magic of math.Modeling a great student-teacher relationship, the great Archimedes guides her, assuring her that math is not something she can cordon off or that one needs to be a STEM genius to master- "Math is everywhere and everything involves it."  Math and science equal magic, and this concept played out alongside myth, mystery -- plus tribal council and hierarchical politics -- creates a compelling read. Overall, n this new alternative world, themes of the role of destiny, power, emotions,  rebellion, dreams and self direction are presented in a rich, satisfying way.I loved the language in the book, too--war stories can be hard to write and this strikes a nice balance of strategy, procedure and vivid battle scenes. We have a real sense of the high stakes through the characters. In all a great read that will leave YA fans ready for more.

This book is full of love and positive Celestine light. It functions beautifully on more than one level. On the page-turner level, it is a well-described story told through Lazarus' eyes as he grapples with the events of his death, his awakening knowledge of an expansive, layered reality and his new 2,000 year mission which is necessary to provide stewardship to a world under disease, attack and decline.The writing is clear and vivid, both opening doors in readers' imaginations and making heady concepts accessible at the same time. The author definitely kept me intrigued and wanting to understand the realms, ideas and missions Lazarus was describing and that the Tazkuvel is tasked with delivering.If you are interested in a mind-blowing conceptual guide to the powerful destiny of Miriam and the power of Celestine Light, this is the book for you. I found many words to focus on, including: It is in times of greatest challenge that the true person of light and power can emerge from within the shell in which they are usually held by every day life." I highly recommend that you delve in if this book calls to you.

This tale soars in every way. First and foremost the story is solid, with a lot of tension and high stakes as Max finds ways to understand the worlds he, as the previously hidden son of Merlin, is thrown into as he meets the heavy challenge of saving Earth and enduring peace for Camelot. The adventure unfolds chapter by chapter and can work for independent readers or as a nightly family or school read along introducing readers to this interpretation and elevation of the great myths, many heroes, legends and a host of mythical creatures. The alternative universe is complex, with readers holding onto various realms, portals, magical principles, heavens and realities, and the clear writing and dialogue makes it all accessible and delightful.The characters are affecting and believable, and I liked it than in addition to Max there is an additional strong female heroine in Trudesile who has a really satisfying mystery surrounding her mission/identity in the adventure that is ultimately revealed.Readers can select this book with confidence that they'll have a fun, engaging adventure based on the excitement of restoring peace and preventing worlds from being devoured along with some of literature's great heroes. and overall witness a thematic celebration of the force of imagination in our lives, so this tale is a true winner in every way.

I'm finding this to be a solid, thorough resource to have on hand when trying to study or research the Greeks. Key schools of thought are distilled to basic thought leaders and tenets and presented very clearly in a few pages each. What's really helpful is that each thought is linked to the overall Hellenic framework and in comparison to the developments that led to its adoption as well as similar or differing philosophies in comparison, so you can seamlessly be reminded of the context and import of the ideas and of the rigorous debates each represents. Well written, researched and hyperlinked to chapters and a footnoted glossary. Incredibly welcome guide for students at the college and university level, and written clearly enough that parts would be helpful for Advanced Placement or Honors class high schoolers as well.

I really enjoyed this story and would recommend it to YA readers and adults alike. Mara is both a skilled storyteller -- easily weaving between fantasy world and every day life -- and a keen wordsmith. She creates a lush and magical universe full of dramatic challenges and throws her character, the struggling Lucas, into it without the skills or knowledge he needs to survive.He is tested in every way (physically, mentally and spiritually) and as he finds his way we get a real hero's journey. His character grows against these challenges and through knowing his guides, including Amira, who is a fantastic female role model of a character. Her higher calling challenges him to move beyond base emotions, like fear and anger, and into holding a higher purpose, as represented by the Four Kingdoms. The overriding themes include seeing a world beyond yourself, rising to challenges in life even though you are ill-prepared, finding redemption through self-lessness and recognizing that the most powerful magic of all is, of course, love and care, all of which are inside of oneself all along.It all comes to life through clear writing, extra vivid descriptions and solid dialogue that makes Lucas a believable teen character who is surly on the outside and often a mess of tenderness inside. Without giving the cliffhanger away, this is a satisfying start where there are layers of reality at play and where Lucas is doled out information about his life as he is ready to act on it, and the stakes get huge at the end with a bomb of information from other the key women in his life. I look forward to where ever Mara takes these characters, since as Cecelia would, she knows "magic is a part of your soul."

Clear and well written, this guide is a satisfying bit of geekery divided into two sections. The first looks at Munroe's work, which I felt was very even-handed and thought-provoking. Munroe gets a lot of internet attention for admirably contextualizing and packaging science and tech while also making them fun and entertaining subjects, though sometimes becoming gimmicky or too distilled in the process. Mullins makes a cogent point when comparing those gimmicks to the special effects in movies--it looks like science, but you can't really learn from them. So part II takes off where Munroe leaves off, by exploring real answers to the types of every day science questions that Munroe's readers mull around. In Mullins' able pen, the questions are explored and succinctly answered in a way that is memorable and can create a-ha learning moments. As a teacher, I know that this is not as easy as Mullins makes it, and that is vastly to her credit. The book is fun, clever and real science with handles on it anyone can pick up. Highly recommend!

The absolute brilliance of this novel is that it somehow manages to push through the WALLS of form just as effortless-seeming as its characters move through the walls around them in every way. It's a love story at core--between two characters, between human experience and what lies beyond our perceived barriers. There is a heady mix of myth, religion, physics, history, espionage, adventure, romance and philosophy woven throughout a compelling story. What happens if you begin to apply practice dedication to learning how to free yourself from barriers, even though physical barrier of your body on this plane? What freedom could you find? Who would want to steal that from you?I loved the way the relationship is presented, because in breaking down the physical barrier between himself and another, the central character began a hero's journey that expanded to include all other realms.Together they physically travel to Greece, receive tutoring from the coolest mother-in-law in the world, and then expand their travels to other planes that neither could achieve alone. The relationship evolution, shown through solid dialogue and beautifully seductive prose, anchored the heady conceptual ideas but also brought them to life. It's easy to feel like a fly on the wall during some of the grand conversations, because walls are down. The author said the following about death, but it applies to the overall spirit of the book: "We dissolve into an ocean of love." Indeed.This is clear, smart writing, and it's also fun, sly and witty with lots of winks to mythology. I highly recommend it if you like compelling fiction that helps you break open your own barriers.
My family loves this. No duds, small kernels, works great in our Whirley Pop!

What an epic ending to a successful trilogy! This one is a page-turner rich with ideas and fully realizing Cal's purpose and mission. I finished the book late last night and can't stop thinking about it. The plot introduced in the second book unfolds into full-blown terrorism attacks on the nation, and that means we see our characters faced with building a new community of evacuees, grappling with standing up as leaders against a system that is suspect, and dealing with a modern war around them while beginning their own family.The writing is as honed and brisk as in the first two, with lots of fantastic action and adventure that is grounded in an interest in the moral questions of humanity, but also woven through with great dialogue that makes the story specific. I loved it that at the center of the action is the story of Cal and Abigail's marriage, including some family twists I didn't see coming. I really love a writer who can give us big political and war themes but also take the time to give scenes like seeing one character really thoughtfully selecting a Christmas gift for another or birth stories, symbolizing so much about the journeys of those characters and their intentions for the future of their own principled lives as well as the future of society.You don't find that kind of rich, layered storytelling every day but that's the kind of thing that stays with me. I'm asking myself lots of questions today, about what I would do in Abigail's situation, or Cal's, or as someone meeting Cal, so I'm really glad I found The Repentant Demon Trilogy!

Like start-ups themselves, sometimes humor is the greatest disruptive force, helping you see things or solve problems in a new way. That's definitely the case with Secret to Startup Failure. Rich with insights and a-ha moments, I loved how this book defined the startup immersion experience brilliantly while offering the kind of immediately understandable advice that entrepreneurs needs from their trusted inner circle.The book is full of snippets you'll want to share with others, because it's just that dead-on. Should you get a co-founder...or a cat? The perils of measuring success by "likes" and the rollercoasters of launch? Holiday conference calls? It's all in here. Lots of idea prompts, with comics to illustrate the topic in fresh ways, and jewels of insight to help you hone in on where your startup is at and what might help. The book is a great debrief to startup up culture and experience, and I recommend you get it for yourself to help you survive, and for your team to share some insight and the type of laughs that lead to innovation.

I am definitely a reluctant networker and am much happier behind the keyboard than shaking hands in person. This guide gave me so really needed advice, practical tips to use, and a shot of encouragement.I like how the author focuses on reprogramming your old beliefs in yourself as shy to transform your confidence going forward. I know I'm going to read the "Preparation" tips often, as he helped me see I neglect this area while using up energy being nervous instead. There is also specifically useful info about optimizing your networking abilities at and after networking events, and well as general coaching on networking.This is a straight-talking guide that's a good mix of supportive thinking, encouragement, and the confidence boosts that come when you know you are as knowledgeable about a topic as you can be. I'd recommend this book to anyone who feels less that confident about their ability to network their way to success or who wants a confidence-boost refresher on the power of networking.

This is a great and accessible guide to understanding wills and trusts, and to empowering yourself to enact a trust that will ensure that your property transfers without delays and costs in case of your death. Way too many of us put these decisions and tasks off too long, creating needless nightmares for those we leave behind. The author has done a great job of presenting this information clearly for all readers, and for offering forms that are immediately actionable.  If you don't have a complicated estate you might not need a high-cost attorney and might be able to handle your own legal issues including a trust. This book helps you decide if you are a good candidate, and if so, what to do each step of the way.
