It includes various approaches to marriage, single and trusts for children, how to update an existing trust, and what not to do and who not to include in your trust. If you end up going to an attorney, this book still functions as great education on the topic and on the decisions you need to make. This is a useful and comprehensive guide so that you know your options and handle these necessary arrangements with all the information you need.

Sometimes we need support to realign our point of view to focus in on happiness. I loved this inquiry into the process of becoming happy because it's full of insight, information, inspiration and real tips to help promote personal happiness. The stories and anecdotes serve as a celebration of the immediate and lasting benefit of focusing on happiness as our most important aspect in creating a high-quality life.The author examines many areas in our lives where happiness needs to be optimizes and offers solutions, encouragement and secrets to success on topics including conquering stress, time management and interpersonal relationships. She focuses on positive attitude, developing self-esteem, using creativity and making cognitive choices to be happy to help readers identify their vulnerable areas and create action plans to improve their sense of contentment and joy in life.Readers will find themselves jotting down ideas on sticky notes and posting positive sayings on their walls after reading this inspiring work!

This is a genius app in a few ways. The phonics instruction is solid, with appealing graphics, fun animal connections and most importantly, excellent sound quality. Animals are an ideal way to illustrate phonics because we are used to talking about what animal barks or calls sound like with our kids, so it makes sense to then talk about the word for the animal and what that word's first sound sounds like. I really like the apps approach, and the graphics, color, and screen performance when loading or animating is superior.It's also deeply engaging, incorporating storytelling and rewards, including a train incentive that ups the ante while playing. Adventure incentives like the train's promise to take you to the treasure if you perform well heightens the part of the brain that creates memory, so it adds to the learning process. Smart!Phonics are an essential skill for early learning, and this app is perfect for both introduction to the concept and for repetitive learning.

This is a option-rich app full of fantastic choices to tailor a learning session for a young user or a play session with your child or to keep them engaged on their own or with a sibling--it's really ideal for that, and 5-7 year olds love to teach their young siblings with flashcard and match apps like this. The colorful animated graphics will appeal to all kids, and the monkey (Abby) is a charming and welcome center to the learning games.I really appreciate the high quality of the sound and pronunciation. I've had some bad experiences with other apps that are either annoying or robotic, and I'm delighted that this app took great care with all of the sounds. The app loads easily between different modes and is great for developing vocabulary, fine motor coordination, and the ability to make choices.Definitely a high-quality winner you'll have on your front page for easy access.

I loved this inquiry into the creative process because it's full of insight, information, inspiration and provocation to dig deeper into your creative process. The stories and anecdotes serve as a celebration of the role of creativity in all of our lives and as a deeper understanding into how some individuals foster an accelerated creative connection. I like how the author draws from many disciplines, including the traditional arts, forms of expression we don't always think of as arts (like cooking.) and also sectors like charitable work. education and politics.Some of the information is intellectually exciting (like case studies about notable creatives and innovative applications of creativity, and a conversation about nature vs. nurture) and other parts create direct takeaways (like curating a creative homebase for your work.)  The discussions about technology, contemporary innovation and what creativity will look like in the near future were eye-opening and catalyzing. The author makes a clear case for creative fluidity being the imperative of our times. This is a rich work that is deeply inspiring while being both accessible and provocative. Highly recommend it to reinvigorate your commitment to living with optimal creative output and an innovative point-of-view.

I loved the first book in this series, and Book 2 was even better. The former-demon Cal has a tough time learning to use his human body and starting his human life, which made for fun reading and also makes you think about how complex we've made the modern world. Fortunately he has lots of help from Abigail, and some of the keen skills he had from a long life as a demon, including a proficiency with language and keen observation skills, now make him incredibly useful in a high-stakes situation. Seeing his character develop is a great exploration in faith as he confronts how to be of value, how to honor his chance at forgiveness and how to make his short time as a human matter. I liked seeing how he was inspired by others who he in turn inspired, and how he pushed himself and ultimately had human emotions bloom.I also loved the romance that developed between Abigail and Cal, and felt like it contributed to the strength of the book. It's like with Abigail recovering from grief and Cal essentially a newborn, the author created an incubator for their love that acknowledged their faith and allowed them to grow together. I like how the author explored the relationship of marriage in this context.The end of the story in Book 2 emphasized the action and intrigue and this part was really exciting, making me wonder what is in store for the next book. I loved the character development and plot turns in Book 2, so I'm looking forward to it!

When we meet Clara, she tentatively seeing signs that she might be ready to date again. She's been through so much, including the loss of her mother to cancer and a shattering divorce rooted in betrayal, but she's muscled herself into a routine with work, her friends and her cats. The author sets the stage through great character development to have us invested in Clara's next steps. Things are stuck, and it makes sense why. Her friends aren't really helping her move forward in a way that works for Clara, though, and something needed to give.Enter a plot point that does several things: shakes up Clara from the way she's been sleepwalking through life in her post-grief stuckness, gives her guidance that reminds her of her mother, raisies her caretaking feelings which puts her in touch with how much of a caring person she is and how she has so much love to offer, takes away a comfort possession and her sense of control, and most importantly, leads her to a sexy and smart man who seems as interested in her as she is in him. The ensuing romance is fun but inevitably brings up important questions. He's younger, does that matter? Is he serious enough to risk the pain? Is she ready to be reawakened? Is he ready for a woman like her and for the romance to turn into a relationship?  Gage is hot and in lots of ways a perfect find, but in other ways a risky connection. There are plenty of twists and turns to keep you engaged, just like with a real relationship.I loved how the author takes us through Clare's emotions, desires and needs, including those affected by a history of loss that is a part of one's life by the time one is older than 40. Fully formed characters guide the plot, and we see how the romance helps both characters reach their next stages in personal development. I loved how the author showed that the 9-year age gap with the woman being older might be a positive, not a negative, and that Clara had a bank of confidence to tap, including knowing she could survive if she couldn't go farther with Gage because of his own limitations or differing needs, and how they both knew to talk about those issues early in their connection.

Getting clean and sober is only part of the battle. STAYING that way as life continues to throw it's twist and turns is a whole other ballgame, and deserves special support. This is a direct, unflinching look at how to stay mentally strong and healthy during a lifelong commitment to sobriety. It addresses a diversity of issues, including old thought patterns that might creep up, a need to learn how to be assertive, open and clear in relationships, and how to maintain overall stability to avoid relapse.I've enjoyed the articles in Bajeerao's blog tour, and the book exceeds my expectations. It's well organized. with each chapter centered on one theme or guidance. The narrative includes personal anecdotes, case study examples and advice that is useful, compassionate, and also no-nonsense. Then each chapter offers resources for further exploration and workbook questions to make sure that the reader understood the topic and can truly use it for personal development. This is the kind of work you can read cover to cover, and then open up from time to time for random inspiration of a chapter now and then or a complete re-read. Good work on an important topic for addicts and the people in their lives.

As an educator, I can attest that safety and discipline is paramount to individual capacity to learn and to the success of the entire school, and that these issues are especially of concern at some schools due to the at-risk population or administrative problems. But despite the importance of these issues, teacher education barely skims the surface of techniques that work. I'm thrilled to see lessons learned from the field of law enforcement and juvenile justice applied to traditional classroom settings, as the federal and state departments of juvenile justice have supported a lot of curriculum development and studies to verify the efficacy of field approaches. The author has extensively researched this topic and offers all of the useful pre-service training techniques, strategies and outcome research in this incredibly well substantiated and well-written volume. I really appreciated the emphasis on the ways that law enforcement pre-service training and skills in conflict resolution, crisis management and peer mediation can be models we can use.This is a great resource for teachers, parents and administrators looking for solutions and ways to back up our requests for more training and policies to help our students and increase safety and discipline at our schools.

But despite the importance of these issues, teacher education barely skims the surface of techniques that work. These poems reach out from the page to connect with the lonely, the misfits, the struggling and the lost. Grounded with a lyrically-articulated compassion, the author bares all and shares all to create a volume full of meaning and solace. Through varying techniques and styles, the author gracefully uses language, rhythm, repetition and rhyme to give form to feeling and shape to emotions. Individually the poems tell stories that feel both personal and universal. I often found the poems reminded me of someone who might relate and to whom I should send the poem because it sums up so eloquently those hard-to-define feelings of deep love, regret, longing for second chances, confusion, or particular life or emotional struggles.The title describes a self-acceptance credo and a call-to-action for understanding that threads throughout, as well as serving as the title of the last poem. The last two poems in the volume work as a powerful pair, with "A Work in Progress" answering the cries of "Broken Girl." These two are diamonds to be shared widely. Another poem that deeply connected with me is "The Journey." Several of the works in this volume explore duality and are a reminder that as with nature, people can contain many seasons. A Work in Progress is a tender and provocative work that would be a lovely gift for someone who needs affirmation and connection, and a lovely gift for yourself.

The author synthesizes a stunning array of social media and marketing strategies and brilliantly applies them to a diverse line up of goals. Branding isn't just for business or products, because now all individuals are brandable whether you actively do so or not, so you better seek guidance on how to manage this essential part of today's communication-driven world. Featuring specific steps that take you through all of your choices on establishing your story, your voice and your platforms, this book is an excellent guide. The author makes a compelling case for getting organized and consistent in your messaging, and he gives insider's secrets on how to bring brand tenets to life through specific actions for not only initial branding but also for rebranding.What sets this book apart from others are the pages and pages of actionable, detailed guidance. Lewis' advice is not vague or general. He is specific about helping reader's nail their goals, values, messages and tactics. You are going to need to read this more than once to get everything out of it and will use it as a resource to dip into after achieving one level of your goals. There's a lot here to transform your brand for personal success, networking, income optimization and overall online mastery. I recommend this highly for individuals, entrepreneurs, and traditional employees alike.

Assassin's War ranks with the true spirit of science fiction in it's ability to do two things simultaneously: tell a fantastic tale that offers inventive ideas about the future, other species or similar topic, while at the same time giving us relevant themes to apply to contemporary life. I love how Vann is able to brilliantly excel in both veins in this novel.On the story level, Assassin's War is a winner. We're thrown right into it, as it the time of war, and there is a specific need for a murder to be avenged. The lethally-trained Tien, whom the Udek desperately need to deploy, first needs to be resurrected, though. And in his resurrection, of course he wants his wife to be reborn. Those who can do this transfer are the Bodhi, and neither they nor Tien know if they will be protected by the Udek after the war. All of this creates friction as power plays line up against in other and play out.The action and adventure is exciting and compelling, the battle maneuvers are fierce and strategically thrilling and the one-on-one work brutal. Then what's incredibly engaging is the levels below the story. What does it mean to be or have a soul? How would it change us to be in another body, or truly experience another way of life? Do we carry karma from past deeds? Are we all just one step removed from animals--are any of the species in the book any better than any others? Shared consciousness/mental connections is a theme that returns in several different ways, and you can't help but be captivated by the big questions raised by the Bodhi's neo-Buddhist rituals and transfer process.As experience wears holes into Tien's training and conditioned belief systems that justified his brutality for the Udek, he evolves and we as readers have to question where we have similar growth to do.  In all, this is a highly rewarding read that packs a galaxy-sized punch.

This recording has been around for more than 40 years now, so I'm going to skip reviewing the performance and focus on the 4.0 surround mix, which is the obvious selling point of this reissue.Unlike most 4.0 quad recordings from the 1970s (and surround sound recordings in general), this recording uses the rear channels discretely with the choirs, soloists and off stage instruments. The choirs are placed in the left and right rears, and the soloists take discrete positions around the listener rather than all of them being arranging front-and-center (so Mephistopheles tends to be placed in the right-front corner). And as the performance progress, they are moved around. For example, in the beginning of Part 4 Marguerite starts out in the front, but when the sound of the students and soldiers seep into her room she's moved to the right rear channel.Some people may think this is gimmicky, but I've attended plenty of choral music and in-concert opera performances where conductors do exactly this. And in this recording the results are pretty thrilling. The listener is placed in the center of the action and the discrete location of the soloists and chorus, combined with their movement adds a sense of spontaneity to the recording. It doesn't sound like you're just living to a reproduction of a performance but something created uniquely for home listening.Sound quality is mostly excellent. Putting aside the discrete use of rear channels, this is truly a recording that gives little hint that it's over 40 years old. The sound is spacious, warm and robust. There's no hint of tape hiss. My only complaint is the recording is overly reverberant in places, especially with the choirs.For those that already own a previous incarnation of this recording it's worth buying again if you have a surround sound system. If you only have stereo systems, then benefits are obviously fewer.

SETUP: Very easy. You connect the the extender wirelessly, select your network, enter its password, and that's it. If your router puts out both 2.4GHz and 5.0GHz networks it will extend each.PERFORMANCE: I tested this in a single-story home where my download speed is approximately 65 Mbps down/6 Mbps up . When I walk two rooms over from my router -- 30 feet away -- the download speed drops to 15 Mbps on my iPhone 6. When I walk through one more room and go outside -- an additional 15 feet -- the download goes to zero.I placed the Linksys Extender at the 30 foot mark. At 120 feet away (outside through two walls) I get about 30 down/4 up. Wow! That range is more than enough to blanket my entire house and my whole backyard.

SETUP: Very easy. Downloaded the app to my iPhone 6 and in the app paired to the iGrill in seconds.USE: The iGrill doesn't just tell you the temperature of the probe, but it allows you to setup alerts with presets. You select what you're grilling (beef, pork, lamb, etc.) and then how well you want it cooked (rare, medium well-done, etc.). For example, beef/medium sets it to 140F. The app graphs the the temperature overtime to help you predict when you'll hit the goal temperature.Also note that the app can control multiple probes.RANGE: The iGrill is advertised as having a "150' Bluetooth Smart range," but for me it cuts out on my iPhone 6 at about 50 feet (that includes the signal going through the outside wall of my house and an interior wall). Unfortunately, the distance between my grill and TV/couch is greater than 50 feet, so I cannot watch TV and monitor what's grilling without having to get up from the couch and walk into the next room. To the iGrill's credit, as soon as I move back into range the thermometer kicks back in  there's no need to re-pair the device.While the iGrill is an excellent thermometer, the range is so limited that I'm still going to have to walk near my grill to check the progress of what's cooking, which partially defeats the purpose of a wireless remote thermometer. While it would likely make it more expensive, if the iGrill could connect to my home's WiFi network I would never be out of range because I have a WiFi repeater installed near the back of my house that extends the network to my yard where the grill is.

To test the headphones I listened to about a dozen hours of movies, orchestral music, opera, jazz and solo piano.The sound is clean, punchy, with a natural amount of bass. The quality was consistently excellent across all genres of music.The headphones deliver a very upfront perspective which is particularly flattering to recordings of only several musicians  it creates the effect of it sounding like you're surrounding by them. The only downside is that the headphones amplify ambient sounds from the recording venue, such as noises from the audience.The ear cups block out a good bit of ambient noise helping to minimize how much you need to turn the volume up to hear quieter passages of a recording. If you're hoping to use them at work to block out noisy co-workers they'll definitely do the trick (I tested the headphones at my office).Overall the sound is pretty similar to Sennheiser over-ear headphones, which I regard as the best prosumer headphones for music. That being said, I do feel Sennheisers costing about one-third of the Monster Octagon deliver the same audio quality.The construction of Monster feels pretty strong. While they are on the heavy side, they don't cause any pain when wearing for a while. It certainly helps that there is a good amount of padding on the cross strap that rests on your head.My only complaint is that given the high cost the headphones should have come with a hardshell carrying case rather than a fabric bag. Even though they feel tough I still wouldn't want them flopping around in bag.

Lightroom 6 isn't that much different than version 5, so I'm not going to rehash explaining what the program does and why it is so great.There are four new features that are intended to convince version 5 users to upgrade:-Better performance-Facial recognition-Panorama merge-HDR mergeI suspect what people care most about are Panorama and HDR. (I've never had performances issues with LR5, and I doubt LR users are taking tons of pictures of friends and family over and over again that they need facial recognition).Here's the good news about these features:The output file for both the HDR and Panorama merge is Adobe DNG (RAW) so you can continue to modify the photo as a RAW film in Lightroom. This is pretty cool. Every program I've used for HDR and Panorama can only output a JPEG or TIFF even when they can accept a RAW files as an input (and of course, it's a major pain to have to convert your RAW files to TIFF or JPEG for programs that cannot accept RAW). (If I'm wrong on these please let me know and I'll change my review).The process has also been designed to run in the background so that you can continue using Lightroom while it's running -- it doesn't eat up all of the resources forcing you to take a break while it runs.Here's the bad news:You have almost no ability to fine-tune the HDR and Panoramic merge process. It's pretty much all automatic. Now both process work pretty well despite this. And programs that give you a tons of options can encourage endless unnecessary fine tuning that will ultimately get you to the same place as what Lightroom provides. But it's still strange we're given so little control over these processes, especially given how Lightroom is all about giving you the ability to manipulate ever aspect of a photograph to help you achieve your artistic vision.More about the HDR process: It doesn't produce the surreal look that's characteristic of HDR images where light glows.Take a look at the two photos I've attached. The one with more orange in the sky was done with HDR Darkroom, the other Lightroom. I didn't do any editing after the merge. I imagine most people will prefer the HDR Darkroom output, but the Lightroom version more accurately captures what the Hong Kong skyline looked like when I took the pictures. And I probably could get the Lightroom version to look more like HDR Darkroom through modifying the image more.One other complaint about how Lightroom does HDR and Panorama: there's no option to queue up a lot of images and let it rip at a scheduled time.So is it worth upgrading?Probably.Despite the lack of controls for HDR and Panoramic merge, there's a huge plus to having these features built into Lightroom and having the output file kept in RAW. For me that's worth the tradeoff of not having much control over the processes. I don't regret the upgrade and I'll abandon the third party programs I had been using. And when I consider what these third party programs cost vs the upgrade cost, it's about even.But if you want the ability to control the process than the upgrade may not be worth it for you at this time (especially if you want that surreal look to your HDR images).

This Hefty bag lives up to the claim of being strong with an airtight seal.To test this I filled it with water, seated, and held upside down (see picture). No water leaked out, even when I squeezed the bag.The plastic also feels strong enough for the bags to be used as storage random parts, pieces and screws.

The french press hasn't really changed much since Bruno Cassol's 1935 patent -- his major innovation was the helical spring around the filter. Pretty much the only difference from one french press to the next are aesthetics. Unless someone completely screws up the filter and plunger, the taste from one to the next should be no different (which is the beauty of the french press -- everyone's works exactly the same).That being said, most Bodum french presses have a functional feature that this Bialetti made press does not: a groove on the top at the back that ensures the opening on the lid is always aligned towards the spout. See my picture. Having used a french press to make coffee for many, many years, I'm not afraid to say that from time to time I forget to make sure the lid is properly aligned before I pour my coffee. Bodum's top saves you from having to make sure you have it on right.This is a bit minor, but the Bodum beaker has a larger, better designed spout. See my picture.The Bialetti certainly looks handsome, but there are no shortage of french presses on the market, and given that they all make coffee exactly the same way, it looses points to Bodum's better functionality.

Let me just jump right into this and say that I had two major issues:1. Motion Sensor. It has an extremely narrow line of sight. Look at the picture of the front of my house; what activates the camera are cars in the street. People walking on the sidewalk and even up to my house do not trip the sensor. The sensor won't activate the system unless you're right under it with your hand on the door nob. And because the system doesn't begin recording until about a second after the sensor has been tripped, someone can get underneath the camera and completely avoid being recorded.2. Camera Quality. It's awful -- worse than any five year old camera phone. I understand the resolution is low so to take up a minimal amount of storage space, but it's so poor hat you cannot identify anyone from it -- which more or less makes it worthless. Take a look at the screenshot of myself from the camera. There's just no excuse for how terrible the picture quality is.Not quite major issues:1. Where the wire goes into the camera is way too close to the mount (see photo). It can make installation difficult.2. There's no dedicated iPad version of the app. You have to run the iPhone version on your iPad.There were some features I did like:1. Setup is extremely easy and the smartphone app is pretty intuitive.2. The camera doubles as an intercom which use via your smartphone or tablet. So wherever you are in your house, as long as you have one of those devices on your body you can answer the door.

As a soap it works well. It doesn't leave your skin feeling dry. It has a pleasant mild fragrance that lingers on your skin after you've left the shower and dried off.The bars are unusually large -- bar soaps are typically 4 oz; these Irish Spring bars are 6 oz. So given the already low price, these are a particularly excellent value per ounce.

As a soap this seems to work just fine. Despite the claim of being a "hydrating" body wash it didn't leave my skin feeling any different than most other liquid body wash soaps (I typically use Alba Botanica body washes they don't use parabens, sulfates, or phthalates).Its fragrance is pretty mild and difficult to detect after you're out of the shower, dried off and wearing clothes. And even in the shower there isn't too much of a fragrance. So if you're looking for an invigorating smell while showering in the morning, this soap isn't going to do the trick.At the time of this review the price was only $3.97. That's an excellent value.

If you thought that the iPhone 6 was too large or close too large for your pocket, this Belkin case increases the phone's footprint considerably.As you can see in my pictures, it's a little more than .5 inches wider than an iPhone 6, and is noticeably wider than your generic bumper case.For me it was too large for my pants pockets. I did not like the feeling.That being said, the case is well constructed, does not obstruct buttons or jacks, can easily hold two credit cards, drivers license and metro card (I can get through 95 percent of days with just those four things), and the case can be used to prop-up the phone if you're watching video on it.If you primarily carry your phone in your pants pocket, definitely consider what it would be like if the phone were .5 inches wider.

While Apple has made a lot of improvements over the years with the battery life of iPhones -- I can often go up to 48 hours without a charge -- on day when I'm using my phone almost non-stop I do need to bring a portable battery with me in case I run low on power and there is not an outlet around.So combining a case and an external battery makes a lot of sense -- it's one less thing to carry.But the ZuZo is completely worthless as a protective case.1) The rim is not thick enough to protect the phone screen if you place the phone screen-side down. This is one of the primary functions of any cell phone case, and the ZuZo does not do it. If your phone was placed screen-side down and dragged across a surface the screen could become scratched if you do not use a screen protector (and even with one it could still become scratched).2) The case covers the headphone jack in such a way that it prevents headphone jacks with a 90 degree bend in them from being plugged in. This means swaths of headphones cannot be used with the case, such as any of the very popular Bose noise canceling headphones. One of the instances where I'm most often using my phone while charging it with an external battery is when I'm on a plane AND using my Bose noise canceling headphones.3) Unlike most other cases, the on-off/lock and volume buttons are not covered by the case. Instead there is an opening for them and the opening is so small that you can only use your nail to access the buttons (or at least my fingers are too fat).4) When charging the battery the LED battery life indicator lights on the screen-side of the case remain on. This is extremely annoying and distracting if you're watching something on your iPhone while trying to charge it. And again, that's a scenario I run into with external batteries while traveling on planes.As advertised it will recharge a near empty iPhone 6 one time -- I cannot find any fault there.One last complaint: the kickstand is wedge so hard in there I had to use a screwdriver to get it out. Other reviewers have had the same problem.Given all of these issues I'd rather prefer continue using my current case and carrying around an external battery and USB cord. That way I have a case that actually protects the phone screen, I can use any headphones I want, and I don't have to use my nails to access the buttons. And, I can get multiple chargers out of an external battery.

In the winter my skin gets dry enough that I need to use a moisturizer on my face and hands to prevent my skin from cracking. So Nivea's body moisturizer was right up my ally.So let me get right to it:As soon as you apply the Nivea lotion you can feel the affect on your skin. It's a pleasant, almost tingly sensation -- it's rather refreshing. There's no doubt that it works as a moisturizer, and hours after application I can still feel the affects.That's the good. Now the bad.I find its smell to be unbearable. It's like baby powder with perspiration. And the smell lingers all day. 12 hours later I can still smell it on my skin.A lot has been said by other reviewers about the risk of slipping in the tub, and the bottle even comes with a warning; maybe I didn't apply enough, but I had no such issues.While the odor is a deal breaker for me, I understand that others may have no such issue. However, I'd still recommend trying to smell it before buying, or, if you buy blindly, start with just one bottle.

Here's what you get:A 4-foot lighting USB cable and a single port 2.1 AMP USB car charger adapter.The 2.1 AMP adapter will charge iPhones very fast -- about as fast as your AC outlet. Charge times with iPads are noticeably slower (Note: in my experience a 1 AMP adapter cannot provide enough power to charge an iPad -- it can only maintain the current battery level -- so definitely get the 2.1 AMP).So it's a complete package for charging your late model iOS devices, and gives you the flexibility to plug any other USB cord you have into the adapter for non-lighting port devices.Having owned many of these USB car adapters and countless aftermarket USB cords for iPods, iPads, iPhones, Kindles and other USB devices, I do not believe that Belkin's adapter and cord is any better than the competition -- there's certainly no justification for the $35 MSRP.Further, you should also consider the other options available, such as multi-port USB adapters and voltage inverters that include an AC port.

(This was review was written using iOS devices: iPhone 6, iPhone 3GS, iPad 3rd gen, and iPod Classic)NOTE: this unit does not have a CD player.OVERALL: This unit is an excellent value. For relatively little money you can overhaul the music system in older cars and fully utilize all of the media on your phone (music, streaming, apps), and add handsfree calling.Let me start with what are the best features of the pioneer media player before I go into more detail:1. Whether connected via Bluetooth or USB, when you turn your car on and the media player powers on, it begins playing exactly where you last stopped listening to audio. If you were listening to audio in an app, such as the podcast app (as opposed to the iPhone's native music app), it will resume playback there. I consider this a major plus because many factory installed car radios will not do this -- when powered up they always play the first track of music on your phone or iPod. I rent a lot of cars for work and it's shocking how many cars radios still do this.2. You can control playback of audio from your phone or iPod -- meaning, that when it is connected to the media center you are not forced to navigate and select audio through the media player. Again, lots of factory radios won't let you do this, and it's always easier to navigate on your device than through the media player.3. You can listen to audio from any app. Some car radios can be funky about allowing playback through third party apps, like the NPR app.INSTALL: If you've never installed a car radio before in can seem daunting, but it's really pretty simple. However, Pioneer's instructions are mediocre, and the wiring harness does not come pre-stripped, so you will need to have a wire stripper for the install. You also need wire nuts, or at least electrical tape. IMPORTANT: If your cars warning sounds and chimes are stored in the factory installed radio, then you'll also need to buy an aftermarket wiring interface to retain them (usually in the mid-$20s). You'll probably also need an antenna adapter (~$10) and a dash kit (~$15).BLUETOOTH: I had no problems paring several devices. Up to 3 can be stored in the media player's memory so that you can easily toggle between them without having to go through the pairing process each time you want to switch which device the media player is pulling audio from. When you turn on your car and the radio powers up it quickly finds my iPhone, connects, and begins playing audio.PHONE: This unit comes with a wired microphone. It has a clip that you can use to hang it from your visor or clip above the steering column; I installed it on the latter. When phone calls come in the media player displays what you'd see on your phone -- if it's from a number of a stored contact you see that contact's name; if not, you see the number. Through the media player's menu you can easily access the most recent call list and bring up your contacts directory. You can also turn the 1 through 6 number buttons on the media player into speed dial buttons for selected contacts. I think that's pretty spiffy. People on the other end of my calls said that my sound quality was good -- no issues hearing me.INTERFACE: The buttons are too small. You'll end up always controlling things from your phone.SOUND QUALITY: It's excellent, including through Bluetooth.OTHER FEATURES: This is actually a lack of feature: no CD player. It's crazy the the overwhelming majority of aftermarket radios still include a CD player. When was the last time anyone listened to a CD in the car? Compared to the rest of the Pioneer line you only seem to save a few dollars by opting to go without it. The lack of CD player does make the install easier because the unit is about half as deep as ones with the player.The media player also comes with a remote. I suppose it could be useful for allowing people in the back seat to change the radio station on their own.Some people have complained that the display is difficult to impossible to read during the day. I've had no such issues, even when sun light is shinning on the display and I'm wearing sunglasses. I think folks just need to adjust the settings.CRITICISMS: I cannot figure out how to display both the track name and the clock at the same time.As I mentioned early, it's ridiculous that the wire harness doesn't come pre-stripped. If you don't own a wire stripper or have access to one, that's an additional expense.I'm taking a star off for that.

Compared to other bumper cases I've owned going back to the iPhone 3G, this case feels no stronger or weaker. Short of performing a drop test with my own phone, I have no way of verifying if its "shock-absorbent rubber core," "polycarbonate exoskeleton" and "air cushioned corners" provide superior protection to other cases. The manufacture offers no evidence of this either. With the lack of such evidence, I'm concluding that it offers no better or worse protection than the average bumper case. (It is described as "military-grade" but there is no explanation of what this means, such as if it is built to the standards that the US Army uses to protect electronics in the field).Ease of removing the phone from the case and accessing buttons and ports is also neither better or worse than other bumper cases.With iPhone 6 cases, I also own a Incipio NGP case -- which at the time of this review is the top recommendation on Wirecutter. I feel it offers the same amount of protection, is slimmer, and cost several dollars less.So far that reason I cannot recommend this case -- go with the Incipio.Note: included in the package are 3 different colored plates so you can add some level of customization if you so desire. It also comes with a screen protector which I never use because it interferes with the tactile interface experience -- your fingers don't glide as easily across plastic as glass. I'm on my 3rd iPhone and have never had problems with the screen getting scratched (I am careful not to put it in the same pocket as my keys). And the touch experience with glass is superior enough that I can live with some scratches, which are only really visible when the screen is off.REVISED 12/15/14

Pros:It's pretty difficult if near impossible for the top to somehow come loose and cause water to spill out (where as this is a concern with bottles that have a latch).Size is perfect for bottle holder pockets on backpacks.The filter makes a difference, though the degree of that difference depends on the quality of the the water.Cons:There are no markings to indicate what's the max the bottle should be filled accounting for the space the filter takes up. If you fill all the way up to the top water spill out when you place the filter in. So you cannot fill up quite the whole way, and it's up to you to figure out what that point is.As for the BPA concerns, the bottle is advertised as BPA-free. If you don't trust that because it's a soft plastic, you could try putting some kind of sleeve on it to block out UVA light which is what causes chemicals in plastic to leach into the water. Or, just buy a stainless steel or glass bottle.

No real surprises here -- it's a baking pan.Despite being a non-stick pan grease will stick to it when it cools. I still use a silicone pastry mat or parchment paper to minimize clean up.My one complaint is that if you take it out of the oven and place on an uneven surface it will warp. It's not thick enough to prevent this from happening. But that's what you get with thin baking pans.

This has to most pleasant smelling disinfect cleaner -- it doesn't leave the bathroom reeking of bleach or a chemical smell.Cleaning strength is good -- definitely helps remove stains.My only complaint is that you need to be careful about how much pressure you apply when you squeeze the bottle or you'll end up emptying half of it.

Overall this is a perfectly fine body wash -- certainly no worse than the many other body washes out there.As for the claim of providing "maximum hydration," its moisturizing abilities seem no better than other bar and liquid soaps that don't make such bold claims. So yes, that's all marketing.The smell is that generic "sport" male deodorant scent.

Putting aside difficulties with flying the quadcopter, I ran into major connectivity issues. About every two minutes the connection between the remote and quadcopter would go out, requiring that the battery be unplugged, reconnected, and the remote turned on and off. It was extremely frustrating to have to go through this so often.Oh, and how stupid is it that there isn't an on/off switch on the quadcopter? To power it on and off you have to literally connect and yank the cord.I had a hard time flying it -- no matter how much I tried, I could not get it to just hover. As others have noted, the scant directions provide no help with how to fly it.Also, you really need a very large wide open space to fly it, like a baseball field.I'll concede that I may just stink as a quadcopter pilot, but the connectivity issue is reason enough to junk it.

This review was written using a Mac with OS 10.10 and an iPhone with iOS 8.1SETUP: To install wirelessly I had to first download Brother's software. The whole process took several minutes. Unlike most other wireless printers, you have to install the software -- the printer cannot be added to your wireless network using the control panel (there's no way to select a network and enter in the password).PRINTING: With both graphics and text it's fast. Text is crisp; graphics have horizontal lines as if it were printed on an ink jet, and the contrast is pretty poor. I'm impressed that such an inexpensive printer will print double-sided. I had no issues printing from my iPhone.SCANNING: Unlike a lot of other all-in-one printers, you can scan directly to your computer. That is, press the scan button and a file is dumped into your pictures folder (you can specify JPEG or PDF). You *do not* have to initiate the scanning process on your computer. Scan speeds are good, even when set to the highest resolution (600 dpi).COPYING: From either feeder or laying on the glass it's fast. You can have single sided pages converted to double-sided.WHO IS THIS PRINTER GOOD FOR: Small businesses that need a scanner and have to print maybe a dozen or so pages a day -- things like invoices. It might also be good for students who have professors who still require that papers be submitted as hard copies instead of electronically because the cost per print is much lower with laser than ink (and you only have to buy one color). Similarly, it would make a good printer for light personal use -- printing out a page or two every now and then.The printer also has an ID card print feature. You put your ID on the glass, press ID copy, then flip the ID over, press ID copy again, and it prints out a copy of both sides of your ID on a single page. I imagine certain niche businesses, such as health care, will find that very useful.FINAL VERDICT: There are lots of options in this price range with similar features, and I'd go with the Brother primarily because it's a laser printer -- ink cartridges are a money pit.

Hyperbole aside, this may be the best designed roller luggage bag -- certainly the best in its price range. It brings together a number of smart design elements that make the bag easy to handle and ensure that it can fit into practically any overhead bin (except the bins on the CRJ planes).Below are the major features:-Rounded top. The reason that flight attendants are always telling you to put your bag in wheels facing out to the aisle is because the end of the overhead bin is curved. It's literally a square peg into a round whole situation. Depending on how large your bag is and how overstuffed it is, the top size can be squeeze it into the rounded end, but the wheels side cannot because they are rigid.This bag has a rounded top side so that the bag's shape actually fits the shape of the overhead (and this is why it opens at the mid section).This feature is especially important on smaller planes like the MD90 (typically used for less than 2 hour flights on major routes) where the overhead bins can be pretty unforgiving for bags that are slightly too long or too tall.-Wheels. The wheels on most bags tend to be dinky crap, and are often the first thing to breakdown. Timbuk2 uses skateboard wheels! They are extremely durable, large size provides a smooth glide, and they are easily replaceable (that is, it's not a proprietary part).-Handles on all sides. Sounds simple, but take a look at the bags people are using during your next flight. It's amazing how many do not have handles on the sides.-Exposed frame. Specifically, the frame for the wheels and telescoping handle is exposed to allow for easy repairs. I appreciate that the bag was designed so that when it breaks it can be fixed, rather than tossed (especially given how expensive it is).-Cannot be overstuffed. A lot of bags have a large top pouch that when fully stuffed can prevent the bag from fitting into narrow opening overhead bins. Timbuk2 was wise not to include such a pouch that would tempt you to over stuff, resulting in a situation when you need the help of two other people to squeeze the bag into the bin.Size: I went with the small because it's only a matter of time until airlines start cracking down on people who bring large bags on planes. European airports are already very strict about this, and during summer 2014 Delta was actually enforcing its  22" x 14" x 9" rule, forcing people to check bags that were only inch over even though they would fit into the bin. The medium bag may fit into the overhead, but in the not too distant future (and already in Europe), you may not be allowed to take it on.I've used the small on several 5 night work trips without doing laundry  I think it's plenty big enough for most travel.Construction: like all Timbuk2 bags it's built like a tank. It should last many years before needing repairs.Final comment: Yes, the bag is on the expensive side, but think of luggage as an investment  it should not be something that has to be replaced every few years  it should last at least a decade (my old Boyt bag lasted 14 years). And the design should make travel as effortless as possible.

Assembly: It took me about 15 minutes. No tools are required, but you will need something to cut two zip ties. The pieces certainly don't need to be forced into place, but a good bit of pressure needs to be applied to make sure the polls go in all of the way.Build quality: Once assembled it is light enough that a person can easily carry it. It feels solid, but note the weight limits. It also has a slight wobble -- enough that I placed my air mattress on the bottom rack to help anchor it.Uses: I've put it in a guest room for guests to use to unpack their close, as well store guest sheets and towels.Because of the weight limits, I would not treat this as your primary closet, loading it up with all of the jackets and suits you own -- it simply cannot carry that much weight.

I'm going to review this product through the lens of its intended use: a space saving speaker. I say that because it's not meant to deliver audiophile sound, but provide better sound than you'll get from your TV speakers without taking up much space (and I say that as someone who owns a 5.1 surround sound system with floor standing speakers).Size: Assuming that your TV is elevated about an inch or so by its stand and that the rim around the screen is also an inch or two,  The mono speaker is short enough that if placed in front of your TV it should not block the screen. But you should still measure everything before buying.Sound: Not surprisingly it's a big step up from the speakers on your TV. I tested it on a mix of TV shows with lots of dialogue, music competition shows, and movies. Sound was warm and crisp, with good bass response from the woofer. Simply put, it's results in a much more pleasurable viewing experience than you'll ever get with TV seekers.For fun I compared it to my 5.1 system -- perhaps not a fair comparison, but this is a pretty pricy speaker system. The center channel in my system provides a much more spacious sound with more bloom. It also helps that the center speaker is substantially larger than the Bose.Bose includes a universal remote that can be programmed to control all of your other boxes: cable, Blu-ray, etc.I also have to give Bose credit for including all of the connecting wires you may need, such as the optical cable for connection the speaker to your TV (it's amazing how most Blu-ray players do not ship with an HDMI cable).My one criticism is that Bose uses a proprietary cable of their own making to connect the woofer to the speaker, preventing your from buying a third party cable if you want to place the woofer farther from the TV than the included cable will allow. In fairness the speaker cable is 10' long, but take that into account before buying in case you do plan on placing the woofer way off to the side.I'm taking a star off for that, as well as the fact that I feel it's slightly over priced (at the time of this review Amazon is selling it for 600 dollars).

This is basically a coarse sponge on a telescoping poll. Despite the simplicity, it does save you from having to bend over when scrubbing the tub or toilet.The poll seems well constructed -- I gave my tub a thorough scrubbing without running into problems. And for those wondering, I use Bar Keepers Friend for cleaning my tub.One word of caution: Until someone comes up with an aftermarket replacement sponge, you're locked into using OXO's, which at the time of this review is about the same price as the poll + scrubber.

I don't doubt that there is specific functionality that Toast has which some users require, but for the average user, a lot of the core functionality can be provided by free programs.For example: ripping DVDs and converting them into videos for your smart phone or tablet -- HandBrake does that, and I actually think it's a bit more user friendly.Capturing web videos: the NetVideoHunter extension for Firefox does this.Further, I couldn't get Toast to capture any videos from the web, including YouTube videos. I followed all of the directions but nothing seemed to work.Video screen capture: The Quicktime Player does this (and it comes with all Macs).I could keep going on and on, but I think you get the point.Obviously Toast brings this all under one roof, but the price just seems like a lot for functionality that is given away for free.So before buying Toast I would urge you to try using what's available at no cost.

For decades the "Joy of Cooking" was a cornerstone of kitchens because it covered the basic principals of cooking -- everything from how to cut specific kinds of fruits, vegetables and meats, to detailed explanations of ingredients and cookware, and even directions on how to set the dinner table."The America's Test Kitchen New Family Cookbook" takes things to the next level. It's designed to be as much as a reference book as recipe book.In addition to having an unfathomable number of recipes, on practically every other page there are series of colored photos (usually three to six) that demonstrate the preperation process of a recipe, typically focusing on steps that are applicable to other recipes. There are also all kinds of tips and tricks, such as how make a panini without a panini press -- use a grill pan and a dutch oven as a weight.Like the "Joy of Cooking" there are many pages devoted to cooking equipment, explanations of various foods (meats, cheese, pasta, grains, etc), directions of what to look for when buying fresh foods, and suggested brand name ingredients.Cookbooks are a snapshot in time, reflecting the culinary zeitgeist of when they were made. As such, "Test Kitchen" accurately captures current tastes and trends, devoting a good number of pages to dishes like pizza, barbecue, asian noodles, as well as all of the different kinds of grains and beans sold at the bulk grain section of stores like Whole Foods. If you're looking for recipes to lots of classic French dishes, buy "The Art of French Cooking."One word of warning: the serving size for most of the recipes is 4-6; if you're cooking mainly for two and don't want to deal with scaling down recipes, than this book may be of less value.

When it comes to bed sheets you get what you pay for. The fiber of the sheets, thread count and weave all affect how the sheets feel against your skin, as well as the cost. Cheap sheets tend to skirt on all of these dimensions.The reason these sheets are so cheap -- while also coming with a comforter -- is because they're made of polyester. Bed sheets are traditionally made of 100% cotton. Not only do people generally prefer the feel of cotton, but it has several advantages.I'll get to the feel of the material in a second, but the two main disadvantages of polyester vs cotton, is that: 1) Polyester isn't as breathable as cotton. It traps more heat and does not wick moisture from your skin; and 2) The sheets will pill over time (from use and washing), meaning that small hard bumps appear on the surface. Good quality cotton sheets will not pill.As for the feel, polyester is much smoother than cotton. This isn't necessarily bad, but it's different enough that I wouldn't recommend buying polyester sheets blindly. Buy a pillowcase and sleep with that for a few nights.Before writing this review I slept with this sheet set for a week. It did get hotter than my cotton sheets, but I did not have any issues with how the fabric felt against my skin -- it didn't interfere with ability to sleep.Further, despite the heat issue, the texture of the sheets was a lot more palatable than cheep cotton -- cotton sheets around this price range can have an unbearable coarse texture.Who are these sheets good for? I think it's worth spending money to have good quality sheets. No only can they impact the quality of your sleep, but good sheets will last you many years (I have sheets that have lasted over a decade). I think this set is good for a situation where you only need the sheets for several years and don't want to make a huge investment, like a college student. Or, if you need sheets for more cosmetic reasons, such as just to keep a bed in a guest room covered. These are certainly stylish and polyester stays wrinkle free.Two final things to note: 1) The sheets are so thin they're transparent -- to the point that if you have a stain on a pillow or mattress (or mattress cover) it will come through; and 2) The queen size is a bit large. This could be a good or bad thing depending on if your mattress runs a bit small or large.

Overall the WF-2660 is a solid printer for light home use.The ideal user is someone who occasionally needs to print something out from the web, scan a document to e-mail to someone, or make a copy of a document. Given the cost of ink, if you're planning on doing a lot of printing there are much more cost effective options out there. So I would not recommend this for college students or for a home business.SETUP: Super easy. Removed all of the tape, inserted the ink cartridges, and connected the printer to my home network using the touch screen menu. When I went to print a document on my computer (MacBook running 10.9.4) it found the printer and automatically installed all necessary software.To recap the main functions of the WF-2660:-Scan via feeder or flatbed;-Copy B&W or color from feeder or flatbed;-Print single-sided or double-sided (I'm particularly pleased such an inexpensive printer can do double-sided printing);-Print from mobile devices, including iOS; and-Fax (people still do that?)It does all these functions reasonably well. That is, if you need to scan a document, print out something from the internet or word document, copy a short document, etc, it does these things just fine. But don't expect that the print quality, for example, is good enough that you can print your photos on photo paper and frame them, or, scan a picture at a high enough quality to use for any kind of artistic purpose.Print speeds depend on the file size of your document. It zips out word documents and web pages; when I tried printing a 60 MB TIFF file it took about ten minutes! Similarly, scan times widely range by resolution; color 300 DPI color is about a minute whereas 1200 DPI color takes several minutes.I've removed a start because the 2660 does not have a USB or SD ports -- so there's no way to print from a removable media drive or save a scan to it. I find such ports quite useful -- I've used them to print and scan documents on friends' printers.

1:11 MinsThe Bissell Bolt is essentially a dustbuster with a brush roll attachment for cleaning floors and carpets.Used as a hand vacuum it's pretty ineffective due to low suction and a very short wand -- you have to be right on top of what you want to pickup. It becomes much more effective with the roll brush because it does a job of kicking up debris. As a test I sprinkled a rug with baking soda and it sucked it all up in a single pass. But for really getting dust and dirt our of a rug, you're going to need something more powerful.I would say the Bissell Bolt's ideal use is to supplement your current vacuum cleaner, such as taking advantage of its light weight for use on stairs, or keeping somewhere handy for small jobs when you don't want to breakout your primary vacuum. Think of it as a high powered broom. And, in studio apartments where space is a premium, it would be better to have this than nothing.There is a major flaw in the design. As you can see in the video, to empty the vacuum you have to stick your hand into the air filter, getting your hand dirty with whatever you've been vacuuming. Frankly, that's disgusting.This is just lazy work on Bissell's part -- it could have easily be designed with some kind of release so that you don't have to get your hands dirty.I think this is a pretty serious flaw, making it difficult to recommend.

Philips Windshield treatment does what it claims, but the results are hardly night-and-day.And more to the point, there's a good bit of effort and planning involved in applying the treatment.For the DIY enthusiast this is all pretty minor, but for the average person it's probably a bit too much.First, the glass treatment cannot be applied in direct sunlight, and can only be when the temperature is between 40 and 80. So if don't have a garage, there could be several months in the summer when it can only be applied at night or very early in the morning, and in the winter only during the day (provided the car is not in direct sunlight).Apparently the chemicals in the treatment are dangerous enough that you need to wear googles during the application process, as well as gloves, and avoiding getting any of it on your skin. I try to avoid using things like bleach, so I wasn't thrilled having to deal with cleaning chemicals that come with so many warnings.Finally, the process of cleaning your windshield and then applying the treatment involves lots of scrubbing. I say this not to complain about having to use a bit of elbow grease, but to point out that between only being able to apply the treatment under certain weather conditions, having to deal with a somewhat hazardous chemical, and then having to vigorously scrub down the windshield multiple times, it's a whole lot of work for a pretty mild payoff.Definitely check out the directions before buying so that you know what you're getting into.

0:31 MinsThe main selling point of these measuring cups is the snapping feature that holds them together.As you can see in the video, it does in fact work well -- it's quite secure.The scrapper has a large hook on it so that you can easily hang all of the cups.I'm also particular impressed that OXO has etched in the cup sizes onto the cups (in addition to painting them on the sides). The paint always comes off over time, but the etching will last forever.

0:26 MinsI've been an electric kettle convert since the late 1990s. I love the fast boil time, being able to leave the room while the water is boiling because it automatically shuts off, and the freed up space on the stove. I use mine 1 to 2 times a day -- coffee in the morning, usually tea in the evening.Electric kettles come in three varieties: glass, stainless steel and plastic.Even though plastic kettles are BPA-free, that doesn't stop people from fretting over them.While glass (which the Oster is) and stainless steel will put your mind to rest about issues with plastic, they are heavier, the surface gets hotter, and it retains heat longer.In the time lapse video I compared this Oster to my Braun WK200W Aqua Express Electric Water Kettle purchased in 2008 to see which could boil 2 cups of water faster. The Braun won, coming in at 2:07; it took the Oster 2:33. That's a pretty big time difference considering the price of the Oster and how old the Braun is (and remember, the Braun has been used at least once a day since 2008!).As expected, the surface of the Oster gets hotter than the plastic Braun, but not as hot as stainless steel kettles (my parents have the Cuisinart CPK-17 PerfecTemp 1.7-Liter Stainless Steel Cordless Electric Kettle and it gets so hot you can burn yourself on it).The Oster lacks some functionality found on other kettles in same price range -- namely the ability to set the temperature you want to heat the water to, and holding that desired temperature. The previously mentioned Cuisinart does this, as does Bonavita 1.7-Liter Variable Temperature Digital Electric Gooseneck Kettle.So that's why I give it three stars -- slow boil time and that other kettles that cost about the same have more functionality.

1:11 MinsThe Bissell Bolt is essentially a dustbuster with a brush roll attachment for cleaning floors and carpets.Used as a hand vacuum it's pretty ineffective due to low suction and a very short wand -- you have to be right on top of what you want to pickup. It becomes much more effective with the roll brush because it does a job of kicking up debris. As a test I sprinkled a rug with baking soda and it sucked it all up in a single pass. But for really getting dust and dirt our of a rug, you're going to need something more powerful.I would say the Bissell Bolt's ideal use is to supplement your current vacuum cleaner, such as taking advantage of its light weight for use on stairs, or keeping somewhere handy for small jobs when you don't want to breakout your primary vacuum. Think of it as a high powered broom. And, in studio apartments where space is a premium, it would be better to have this than nothing.There is a major flaw in the design. As you can see in the video, to empty the vacuum you have to stick your hand into the air filter, getting your hand dirty with whatever you've been vacuuming. Frankly, that's disgusting.This is just lazy work on Bissell's part -- it could have easily be designed with some kind of release so that you don't have to get your hands dirty.I think this is a pretty serious flaw, making it difficult to recommend.

As a test I wiped down half my dash using Cockpit Premium and the other half with Armor All 10228 Original Protectant - 28 oz..In terms of ability to remove dirt and the resulting "finish," I could not see any difference.While I'd hardly call the results "showroom new," the Cockpit did help remove dirt that had accumulated.It should be noted that the Armor All is much cheaper. And given that these products are really just water with a little bit of alcohol and fragrance, an even cheaper option would be a little bit of dish soap and water.So yes, Cockpit works as a car cleaning product, but there's nothing special about it, and there are cheaper options.

Poultry nipples are certainly the best and cheapest way to water your chickens.Depending on your needs and ambitions, you can use them to create a basic waterer -- just put a nipple into the bottom of a plastic container -- or create an elaborate watering system with PVC pipe.Personally, I've been using them with large yogurt containers and plastic bottles that I hang around my run.Installation is very simple. You'll need a drill gun with a 5/16" bit and plumbing tape. Drill a hole in your container, wrap the backside of the nipple in tape, and twist into place. That's it.Keep in mind that if it's going into a sealed container there needs to be an air hole somewhere in it or water won't come out.

As the product name notes, this is a pretty basic apron.I'm 5'10" and it goes down to my knees.There's a single pocket in the front that's a bit shallow. I wish there was an additional small pocket/slot for things like a thermometer.Fabric is soft and thin -- it's not going to be able to absorb much water from a splash before it comes through to the other side.If you want a basic apron, this is it. But personally, I rather spend a little more money to get something that's more fun, and/or offers better protection from splashes.

Glue traps certainly aren't humane, but they're the most affective way to eliminate a rodent problem.After Sandy hit NYC, mice invaded my apartment (I was living in the UWS side fairly close to the Hudson). In three days I caught 5 mice. After that I was mice free.So being somewhat familiar with glue traps, the Tomcat traps are sufficiently sticky. The price is also quite reasonable. This isn't space-age technology -- it doesn't take much to catch a mouse -- so you should never be paying much for glue traps. And you don't need any bells-and-whistles like scented traps. Just put a dab of peanut butter in the center and mice flock to it like moths to a flame.Sticky pads also work quite well for catching insects.My super lines the trash room floor in the basement of our apartment building with them, and they catch all kinds of bugs that attempt to get near the trash cans. It's a bit disgusting, but it works -- none of these bugs ever make it up to my apartment.

(This review is for the R30 - 1100 Lumens)If you haven't converted all of the lights in your home to LED, it's worth the expense.They're night and day better than CFL:Use less power; do not require any warm up time; light output does not diminish after just several years, light output is not affected by cold weather; and last substantially longer.The Kobi Electric flood is extremely bright and puts out what appear to be a true 1100 lumen (a lot of times the light output ratings are suspect).The power usage is equally impressive -- 17 watts. A comparable halogen will use 75 watts.Despite being "designed for commercial applications where voltage is 90v to 277v," it will work in any light fixture in your home with 110v power. But I doubt you'd want something this bright in your home. It's more appropriate for use in a garage or large enclosure, like a barn.In general LED bulbs are heaver than CFL, and this bulb in particular is fairly heavy. So it could be a problem if you're planning on using it in a flimsy fixture.

Sony has really pulled out all of the stops here, producing a highly versatile media unit at a pretty affordable price.The S6200 replaces the BDPS790 to become Sony's new flagship Blu-ray player.The only lost feature is that the 790 came with dual HDMI ports to support people who have a 3D TV and an A/V receiver that does not support 3D passthrough. And the construction of the 790 was arguably a bit better.Not only is the 6200 significantly cheaper than its predecessor, but it comes with some notable upgrades.Let me go through the various capabilities of the unit.1. Blu-ray: At this point there's really no measurable difference in picture and sound quality between players -- they all produce vibrant picture and sound. The main difference is load time, and the 6200 is very fast with its dual core processor.2. Streaming: The 6200 supports a slew of streaming apps (HBO GO is the major exception, and at the time of writing this review, Amazon Instant is not yet ready). Sony's new Netflix app is quite impressive. Not only are load times extremely fast, but it takes about a second for the video video quality to get to the optimal level. There's virtually no lag with scrubbing. Finally, the new Netflix app supports Dolby Digital Plus.Hopefully the new Amazon will prove to be as well designed.3. Music: Audiophiles rejoice. New to the 6200 is support for multichannel FLAC and DSD (DFF and DSF) files. As far as I'm aware, only the significantly more expense OPPO BDP-103 and 105 can do the latter.Sony continues to provide SACD support with DSD over HDMI.Suggested audio settings:DSD Output Mode: OnBD Audio MIX Setting: Off (has to be off to bitstream DTS-HD and DD-HD)Digital Music Enhancer: OffDTS Neo:6: OffAudio DRC: OffDownmix: SurroundI personally turn off all of the video enhancer settings  -- the video on Blu-rays is authored with assumption that no such settings will be used.Overall, it's quite impressive everything the 6200 will do, especially at its price point. In fact, anyone thinking of buying an Oppo should reconsider, especially if you plan on using an A/V receiver to process all of the sound.===============UPDATE #1: Sony says the Amazon App will be available in early April.UPDATE #2: I've now installed the Amazon App. As far as I can tell, the UI is the same as the one found in other recent devices, such as smart TVs. While it's certainly an improvement from the old Amazon App that the came with previous Sony Blu-ray players, navigation is sluggish (especially compared to the Netflix app), and the load time to get to optimal video quality is a solid 30 seconds to 1 minute. Further, my Roku circa 2009 has a superior UI and much faster load time. Given that the Sony has the processing power to load video very fast -- as displayed by the Netflix app -- I can't help but wonder if Amazon is purposely throttling speeds so to push people into buying their streaming device -- make it seem like the only way to get Amazon Prime videos to instantly load is with their box. Despite the disappointment with the Amazon app, the 6200 is still a solid video streaming unit, but depending on your needs (such as HBOGO), it doesn't quite match Roku.

Not a lot to say here -- it's a toothbrush after all.At home I use an electric toothbrush, but when traveling, I go old school.While this toothbrush obviously isn't as good as an electric in dislodging food between my teeth, it's still pretty good for something "analog."My only criticism is that I find the compact head version of this toothbrush easier to use, especially when focusing in on a spot on my jaw where something is stuck hard.

I've been using Colgate sensitive toothbrushes for years.I have a tendency to brush too vigorously -- my dentist has scolded me on this -- so the softer bristles minimize irritating my gums.I'll get a about a month or more of use out of it before it needs to be replaced.

You cannot review products in a vacuum.There are no shortage cell phone holders for cars. The suction cups on many will stick to any surface, including the dash, even if it is textured (that is, not smooth like glass). The Panavise PortaGrip's suction cup will only work with glass. For that reason, I'm taking it down to 1 star. This severely limits its functionality.I have a iOttie HLCRIO104 Easy Flex 2 Windshield Dashboard Car/Desk Mount Holder that will stick to anything, and I find that incredibly useful. On some cars hanging my cell phone from the windshield simply isn't optimal -- it obstructs my view too much. Being able to mount the holder to the dash gives me a wider set of options.And incredibly, despite having a much better suction cup, the iOttie is significantly cheaper.The Panavise also has too many pieces for adjusting the positioning -- there are three bolts you have to tighten and loosen. If I'm in a rush or driving, I want to be able to quickly position the holder without having to screw or unscrew anything.Given all of the other, better options out there, I see no reason to recommend the Panavise.

As a longtime Rowenta user (I'm replacing my DZ5080 purchased in 2008), I wouldn't use any other iron. Having used other Rowenta models and non-Rowentas, I find that Rowentas glide the easiest, and require the fewest number of passes to remove wrinkles.The DW9280 is like no iron I've ever used before. It puts out an incredible amount of steam -- so much so that it can be used as a steamer to remove creases from suits, skirts, hanging curtains, etc.What this practically means, is that you can iron clothes very fast -- you don't have to keep passing over the same spot over and over again. It takes very little time to iron a shirt and have it looking like it was pressed.I've also found that unlike my older DZ5080, the DW9280 stays hot all of the time -- after extended periods of use it doesn't go into reheat mode which can take a minute or two.While I'm sure many people will balk at spending so much on an iron when there are so many out there for less than $50, the ROI works out pretty well. If you cold wash and iron clothes like men's dress shirts instead of dry cleaning them, it doesn't take long for the iron to pay for itself (and you can clean dress shirts this way -- I can get about five years of life out of them). Given the cost of dress clothes, you want an iron that's not going to damage them. I've made the mistake of using irons in hotel room and have had them leave permanent marks on shirts; in 6 six years my DZ5080 never once damaged an article of clothing. And of course, you want something that produces good results, and fast, so it doesn't feel like you're moonlighting as a dry cleaner. (And with this iron in particular, there's added value in how it can be used as a steamer).My only complaint is that like every other iron I've ever used, the water tank's inlet remains poorly designed. If you pour too fast, you end up spilling. How water gets into the iron simply needs to be completely redesigned.Bottom line: highly recommended.

While this can seem like an instance of someone inventing a better mouse trap, the valve on this bottle really is frustration free compared to typical bike bottles.The valve is essentially open all of the time, but water will only come out if you squeeze it -- not so easy that it will come out when handling it, such as removing it from the bottle holder, but still not requiring much force. So you never get into instances when you're using your teeth to open the valve, sucking on the bottle or putting a death grip on it just to get the water out.As for its insulation abilities, reviewers are grossly overstating just how cool it will keep liquids. There simply isn't much insulation -- and not room for much -- so on a sunny summer day the ice will still melt pretty fast. Don't expect that it will keep your liquids ice cold for much more than an hour after filling it up.

I personally wouldn't spend much on an air mattress because no matter how expensive they are, they always have an ephemeral life cycle. It's just the nature of them.The construction quality feels a bit heavier duty than other mattress in this price range. So far it is holding air well -- I've kept it inflated for 3 and 4 days without having to refill.It feels as comfortable as any other air mattress I've used -- certainly comfortable enough for guests staying a few days.While it doesn't come with an air pump, the air pump I have for my car works with it (it has an attachment specifically for inflating air mattresses and rafts). And based on the price, it looks like you save some money by not having a pump come with it.My one complaint is the design of the valve. It does not have a way to allow air to flow in but not out at the same time -- so if you stop inflating, you have to immediately close it. I've had other air mattresses where the valve could do that.

Not much to say here. I've been using these socks for sitting out in cold weather December football games. They certainly provide much more insulation and warmth than your standard pair of cotton socks.One word of warning: don't wear them around the house. Unlike cotton, the wool provides little traction on hardwood floors -- they're very slippery.

While this DVD doe not fill in any holes in Szell's discography -- he recorded all of these pieces in studio with Cleveland -- it does provide a rare opportunity to watch Szell conduct, and conduct an orchestra that wasn't the Cleveland Orchestra.It's also especially fitting the one of the performances captured on video is Walton's "Hindemith Variations," and that Walton was present at this concert and called to stage to take a bow. The "Variations" was probably Szell's favorite contemporary piece of music. After he conducted it for the first time in Cleveland during the 62-63 season, he conducted it again in 4 out of the next 6 seasons. I doubt there are many other instances of a conductor programming a new piece of music season after season like it were a Beethoven symphony.The interpretations of the three pieces on this DVD (also included are the Bruckner 3 and "Eine Kleine Nachtmusik") are not much different than the studio versions made with Cleveland (and they're a bit more polished thanks to being studio recordings).Recorded sound is serviceable. The Walton and Mozart are from 12/68. While the sound is clear with a good bit of presence, there's a high pitched buzz throughout the performances. It's not that loud and becomes white noise after a little bit, but it is there. The Bruckner is from 6/66 and is coarser, with distortions -- most noticeable when the brass are playing loudly. The sound is unfortunately nowhere need as good as the quality of radio broadcast recordings from this era -- and ORF's tended to be pretty good.In sum, this disc is for Szell fans -- they'll delight in getting to watch him conduct. For everyone else, stick with the Cleveland studio recordings of these pieces.

I need another Mahler 5 like I need a hole in my head, but I've been buying Ivan Fischer's Mahler cycle (admittedly) because the sound quality of Channel Classics' surround sound recordings are phenomenal, and Ivan Fischer tends to do pretty good work.
