Frankly, I had a lot of trepidation prior to buying this but I thought, well, the most I can lose is less than $30.00 so it's worth trying.I'm glad I did.One of my newer Garmins is the Garmin nvi 285W/285WT 4.3-Inch Widescreen Bluetooth Portable GPS Navigator with Traffic ('Traffic' is no longer supported but I never used it anyway); I also like this unit very much and I see that Innovate88 offers a battery replacement for it (Battery Replacement Kit for Garmin Nuvi 285W with Installation Video, Tools, and Extended Life Battery.). When the time comes, I'll buy one of these too.The Innovate88 company packed everything very carefully and shipped very quickly (two days from Texas to NJ). Therefore I highly recommend this product and this company.I hope that this review has been useful to you and I thank you for reading it.Lawrence H. Bulk

When I saw this Nico New York 2 Tone Bracelet Set offered by Amazon Vine, I thought my wife would like to have it.Unfortunately, she is displeased (and that is the "polite" term).Please IGNORE the two-stars I give it; please read on for the reason for that rating.The following are my wife's complaints.First, the "three" bracelets are permanently entwined; they cannot be separated.Second, this bracelet is obviously intended for a large-boned woman. The size cannot be adjusted and, on my wife's wrist (which measures about 6 1/4 inches), when her arm is down, the bracelet slips down over her hand (which is also very small) and, when her arm is up, it slips halfway up her forearm.Plus it really does look much too large on her (she is 5' 4").So, after trying it (and letting me know in no-uncertain-terms what she thought of it), it has been put back into its plastic pouch, there to remain.It is constructed of painted metal beads and looks to be well-made, considering the low price. The two-star rating is my wife's opinion of its styling, fit, and functionality, and her opinion does not consider its construction quality which, as I said, appears to be fine. Taking that quality into consideration (plus my own personal opinion of the styling), I myself would give this bracelet at least FOUR STARS (and a case could be made for giving it FIVE STARS). But I must defer to my wife ...To sum up, there are certainly some women on whom it would look good and who would like it, especially if they're tall and/or large-boned.Unfortunately my wife is not one of them.But, if you are, you might want to give this bracelet a chance. I think that it's nice.I hope that this review has been informative and of some help to you.

I ordered this Revlon RVDR5111BLKD Ultimate Snub Nose 1875 Watt Pro Styler for my wife. It arrived yesterday and she used it this morning.She is very pleased with it. She has been using Remington hair dryers of which she has three different models; the model she likes best of the three is this Remington D8410 Keratin Therapy Dryer.This new Revlon model is smaller than her Remingtons and much lighter in weight. This weight difference is immediately apparent and is very important to her. It's not as though that the Remington is inordinately heavy, but lighter weight does make for an easier-to-use hair dryer.However, the Revlon model has one fewer heat setting than the Remington. The Remington has three heat and two speed settings; the Revlon has two heat settings and two speed settings. Both have a cold-shot button.But the settings offered on this Revlon are all one needs, according to my wife. Like that Remington, the Revlon has rocker-type switches which are arranged very conveniently.This new Revlon model also comes with a concentrator attachment as well as a diffuser attachment, both packed in the box. The Remington comes with a concentrator and does offer a free diffuser attachment but, oddly, you must order it separately, rather an annoyance.Cleaning the filter is not nearly as convenient on the Revlon as it is on the Remington. On that model, you cannot lose the cap. Its clever design keeps the cap attached permanently. Not so on this Revlon; its snap-on/off cap could be dropped or lost, but, really, only if you are very careless.Both are fairly quiet, as these things go, but she always uses ear plugs when drying her hair, something she recommends to everyone.This morning she found that the warm (the lower of the two) heat setting and the high speed setting dried her hair very quickly and left it very nice (she has baby-fine hair). She said that most probably the low speed setting would have done just as well, though she did not actually try it.The light weight of the Revlon is most welcome but it does raise a question: the much heavier Remington comes with a four-year warranty but this Revlon has only a two-year warranty. We suspect that the extra weight may be a result of the sturdiness of the Remington's motor but of course we do not know this for certain. Nor are we certain if this will make any difference in real world longevity.However one thing is definitely certain: this new Revlon model costs just a little more than half of what that Remington sells for! Thus this Revlon hair dryer offers very good value for money.All in all, my wife is very happy with her new Revlon hair dryer. While it remains to be seen whether it will hold up as well in the long run as the Remington models have done, based upon her use this morning, which went very well especially due to the light weight of this hair dryer but also, most importantly, for the way her hair came out, she (and I) give this dryer our highest recommendation.Thank you for reading this.===============================================================================================================================================Update: March 19, 2014My wife likes this hair dryer so much that today she had me order another one as a 'spare.' We recently returned from a trip. She states that it dries her hair noticeably faster than any other dryer she has previously used which is why she took it along on our trip. As she always takes a 'spare' when we travel, she wanted another one of these to take along rather than one of her other older models which she had brought on this trip.Once upon a time when we were traveling, her hair dryer broke. ***Horrors!!!*** We had to quickly find a store and buy another one (which was whatever they had in stock and not what she wanted). So now she always takes two hair dryers with us which is why she wanted another one of these.She had been happy with most of her older models until she got this one. She has been using it constantly since September 2013 and it has become her favorite. So now, due to have two of them, she is a very happy lady! (She also says that its current price here on Amazon is a bargain.)We continue to give it our highest recommendation.

The title of this review says it all: this truly is a superb USB to S/PDIF converter. And at its current price here on Amazon, it is a true bargain.This review will be of most interest to those who use a computer with a GNU/Linux operating system though much about the quality of this converter will be applicable to anyone.I have a home theater installation with, among other components, a Yamaha RX-Z9 9.1 Home Theater Surround Sound Receiver which I purchased new in 2004, a ZaReason MediaBox 5330 (a media center computer, purchased last year, running the Xubuntu Linux operating system) through which I can play music, movies, etc. and, of course, use it for whatever else one would normally use a computer), and ten (10) loudspeakers (including a subwoofer).The receiver has no HDMI inputs (it was designed just before the introduction of HDMI) but it does have digital sound inputs (both TosLink and Coaxial).I wanted to have the best sound quality possible in this system, for movies as well as music. I recently purchased a StarTech.com 7.1 USB Audio Adapter External Sound Card with SPDIF Digital Audio Sound Cards ICUSBAUDIO7D which is a fine unit and it represents very good value for money.But it is limited to 16-bit depth and 48kHz sample rate. Though the sound coming through it was really fine, I thought I'd like to have a converter which offered "true" 24-bit 192kHz output. (But, if you choose to purchase the StarTech unit - its price is only about 1/6 of the V-LINK 192 under discussion - you won't go wrong. I'm keeping mine.)I did some research on the web as well as here on Amazon and, as a result, I purchased this Musical Fidelity - V-LINK 192 - Asynchronous USB To SPDIF Converter.Its performance is nothing short of superb. And at Amazon's current price of half the manufacturer's list price, it represents outstanding value for money. (The unit is being sold by a company called ListenUp which sets the price; the orders are fulfilled by Amazon.)Now if you are familiar with GNU/Linux operating systems, you know that the default sound output is done by ALSA (Advanced Linux Sound Architecture). PulseAudio is also commonly used. The default digital USB output through ALSA is set to 16-bit 44.1/48KHz and that is true for PulseAudio as well.So when I placed this device in my system (no special drivers are necessary when using this in a GNU/Linux environment), according to its LEDs, I was hearing only 44.1 or 48kHz sample rate, no matter how the original (FLAC) file was encoded (I have several 24-bit 192kHz FLAC files).ALSA's sample rate, I understand, cannot be changed, but PulseAudio's can be. So I changed my sound output from ALSA to PulseAudio.I found the following instructions for Linux on the web (they're what you'll find if you search):Instructions to change PulseAudio sample rate in /etc/pulse/daemon.conf fileIn the Terminal, type< gksudo gedit /etc/pulse/daemon.conf >Then look for the following line:; default-sample-rate = 44100and change it to look like this:default-sample-rate = 48000Note:- Make sure you have removed the " ; "Save and exit the fileNow you will need to restart pulseaudio for that to take effect.To restart pulseaudio use the following commands in the Terminal:< pulseaudio -k >  and< pulseaudio -D >Naturally, when I did all of that, it did NOT work. (I had even restarted the computer.) According to the Musical Fidelity converter's LED indicator lights, my media center computer was still outputting only 44.1 or 48kHz. So, rather than giving up, I tried making some other changes.In the file there is also a second line which reads ;alternate-sample-rate = 48000 to which the instructions make no reference; at first I left it alone, then I changed that rate (only) to 44100 on my second try and then on my third try to 192000 (removing the " ; "). But these changes did NOT work either.I "Googled" the problem but found no answer.So I became "creative" myself.What I did was this:I followed the same (first two) initial instructions as given above:--- In the Terminal, type--- < gksudo gedit /etc/pulse/daemon.conf >--- Then look for the following line:--- ; default-sample-rate = 44100but I then edited the file so that the appropriate section looks like this:  default-sample-format = s24le  default-sample-rate = 44100  alternate-sample-rate = 192000; alternate-sample-rate = 176400; alternate-sample-rate = 96000; alternate-sample-rate = 88200; alternate-sample-rate = 48000; default-sample-channels = 2; default-channel-map = front-left,front-right(Notice that I ADDED four more lines (all with the " ; ") - there had previously been only two, one default and one alternate - and I changed the default sample format from s16le, the standard default, to s24le as well. Also please note - very important - there are three spaces before the words 'default' and the first 'alternate' - unfortunately Amazon does not allow this to be shown. In other words, all of the words 'default' and 'alternate' are placed directly underneath one another.)Then I restarted the computer.NOW --- everything works! My 24-bit 192kHz files play at 24/192 and my 16-bit 44.1kHz files play at that level.This applies only to music played through the Audacious music player. If I play music with the VLC Media Player, the sound is outputted only at 48kHz (but I do not listen to music via the VLC player as it introduces gaps between the files; Audacious plays everything gapless). Movies are always at 48kHz - 48kHz is VLC's maximum so nothing playing in VLC is up-converted plus I left VLC's bit-rate setting at s16le - and the V-LINK passes full surround sound.I have to tell you - I have had my home theater for twenty years now and there have been many changes in electronic equipment within it over the years. But this change, with the Musical Fidelity V-LINK 192 as well as the changes in the PulseAudio sound settings, has effected a MAJOR improvement in sound quality. I can hear it myself by merely comparing music files played through the VLC Media Player (48kHz) compared to those played through Audacious (set to up to 192kHz) and even sound played via the analog connections.My son is a sound professional who lives on the West Coast and he will be coming to visit in late November. He has a better "ear" than I do and I am anxiously awaiting his visit so he can hear for himself what has been achieved. (I want his opinion on the whole thing!)In the mean time, I am enjoying music played in this home theater more than I ever have in the twenty years I've had the theater and I believe that this V-LINK is the "key" to producing the superb sound I am hearing.Obviously I give it the highest recommendation possible for me to give and I thank you for reading all of this.Lawrence H. Bulk

I have a home theater in which I have a media center computer; this uses a GNU/Linux operating system (Xubuntu). Its default sound is good (it has a TosLink output) but I wanted something better, to wit, USB sound output. (This review will be of most interest to those who also use Linux.)I received this StarTech.com 7.1 USB Audio Adapter External Sound Card with SPDIF Digital Audio Sound Cards ICUSBAUDIO7D yesterday and I now have it set up.Frankly, it is not quite as easy to use as one might think; this has nothing to do with the product itself which is nothing short of superb. Rather the difficulties are due to the nature of your computer and just how knowledgeable you are about changing parameters.The default in almost all computers is for the sound to be routed through the computer's internal sound card to the line or headphone output jack. These are analog jacks. The quality of the computer's sound card determines the quality of the sound you will hear.Unfortunately, most internal computer sound cards are mediocre. Of course there are some which are superlative but these are few and far between (not even to mention very expensive).This little inexpensive device allows complete bypassing of the computer's sound card in favor of your amplifier or receiver. If you have a high quality one, it and it alone will determine the quality of the sound you hear (of course this also depends upon the quality of that to which you are listening!).As stated, I use a GNU/Linux operating system on my media center computer located in my home theater (it is a ZaReason MediaBox 5330 model with the Intel i5 processor and 16 GB RAM).Hooking this device to a computer is very easy. You merely take the included USB cable, plug one end into your computer, and the other end into this device.Then you connect one end of a Toslink cable to the S/PDIF output on the back of this sound card and you plug the other end into the appropriate Toslink connection point on your amplifier/receiver.Will you then immediately hear digital sound?No.First you must go into your sound settings section and change the settings from the default analog to the appropriate USB digital setting.After you do this, will you then hear digital sound?Again, no.You must go into the sound settings section of the programs you use to play media. In my case, I use three: VLC Media Player, SM Player, and Audacious.Each of these has its own settings menu (in VLC's case, you'll want to use the advanced menu rather than the simple one).Once all of THOSE are set properly, will you THEN hear digital sound?You bet!!!And it's just great. The sound in my theater, whether playing music (FLAC files) via Audacious, or movies (videos), especially ones with "surround" tracks, through VLC or SM Player, is so much better than the analog (surround) sound I previously used as to make such a comparison meaningless. There is no comparison! My wife can easily hear the difference and I would guess that almost ANYONE would hear the difference.DTS (regular or lossless)? Not a problem. Dolby Digital (regular or lossless)? Not a problem. 7.1 output? Again, not a problem.Just a pleasure!Why would I need a device such as this? It is because my receiver, a Yamaha RX-Z9, was made just before the introduction of HDMI connections. If you have a receiver AND a computer with modern HDMI connections, you don't need this. One HDMI cable will carry picture as well as audio. But if you want digital sound output from your computer, with all of its advantages, and your computer does not have an HDMI output, and/or you have a receiver which does not have HDMI but DOES have digital audio connections, then this is your device.And, at 33 bucks or so, it won't break the bank!It also has analog outputs which carry up to 5.1 analog channels if your receiver has those inputs. Naturally it will also output straight stereo. It even has a headphone jack as well as an analog line input jack. It's quite a versatile instrument!By the way, the changes in audio configurations I mention above apply to ALL computers regardless of the operating system (Windows, Mac, Linux, etc.). It may be a bit trickier to use with a Windows computer (a CD with the necessary drivers for Windows is included; no special setup is required for Mac or Linux) but it still shouldn't be too difficult for fairly knowledgeable people.Its specifications claim it supports 16-bit 44.1/48 kHz sound output. But I can tell you that playing a 24-bit 48 kHz sound file sounds tremendous. I played a "record" downloaded from a company called Pristine Classical. It has several pieces within it: all of the experimental stereo recordings made by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony, recorded in 1954. I chose to buy the 24-bit 48 kHz FLAC file and I played it through this device just this morning.I need not say any more than that it sounded as if it had been recorded yesterday!For all practical purposes, no one need worry about any "limitations" in this unit's specifications.Just please take my advice: if you are comfortable about changing parameters within a computer, or, if you know someone who is, or even if you are willing to spend money to hire someone who can install this properly, then by all means buy this item if you have need for such a device.If you are not comfortable, for any reason, then merely use the default sound settings of your computer. Frankly, they are adequate for many people.But I truly am extremely happy I bought this StarTech device. (It is not the first item I have bought from this company; in my experience, their products are first-class in every way.)I give it my highest recommendation for anyone who has need for it.Thank you very much for reading this.Lawrence H. Bulk

I am enjoying my new Neptor 5600mAh 3.1A Output 2nd Gen Dual Port Fast Charging External Portable Battery Pack Travel Battery Charger for iPhone 5C/5S, iPad mini, Samsung Galaxy S4/S5, Note, Nexus, LG, HTC and Motorola - Retail Pack Includes Flashlight Color Matching USB Ca... which is made in That Country Where All Things Are Made.Its input voltage is listed as 5V 1.0A and its output is rated at 5V 2.1A + 5V 1.0A. Its capacity is a claimed 5600mAh.Note that while both outputs, the 2.1A and the 1.0A, can be used at the same time, if that is done the unit will throttle back the electrical output to a total of 2.3A. The instruction manual states that "Concurrent use of the two ports will make the charging speed slower." So unless you have an overriding need to use both ports at the same time, essentially this is a one-port battery pack.I charged mine up fully and attempted to power a set of speakers (Kinyo UC-270) which are usually powered via a computer's USB port (or an AC or DC USB adapter). Unfortunately, after about two or three minutes, the unit shut down. (I have a Verbatim 2,200 mAh Portable Micro-USB Power Bank Charger 97927 which does the same thing - it shuts down after powering those speakers for a while.) It's not that the speakers draw too much current, it is evidently something inherent in the design of these small external chargers; they may "sense" that they're not actually charging anything. A different external charger, mentioned below, has no trouble at all powering these speakers.But this little Neptor unit does power and charge (at the same time) my SanDisk Sansa Clip Zip 4GB MP3 Player (Blue) which is my primary use for it. It also charges my cell phone and works as well with that phone as it does with the Clip Zip player. (I have not yet charged my phone from "zero" charge so I can't tell you how long that would take. My cell phone is a LG Volt White - Prepaid Phone (Virgin Mobile).)As you may have read in other reviews, this device comes packed with a wrist strap. Why anyone would want to carry this battery pack around in his or her hand while having it secured with a wrist strap is beyond me. In any case, as you may have also read, the strap is very difficult to attach due to the fact that the lanyard is fairly thick and the hole through which you must thread it is ridiculously small. It can be done but, for me, it is not worth the effort. The wrist strap has been put back into the box where it will stay unless I come up with another use for it.This device also features a flashlight which can be used in an emergency in a dark room or outside at night to see your door's keyhole, a nice touch. Unfortunately it is not adequate for use as a regular flashlight.I charged my Neptor fully exactly two weeks ago. Of course at this time I cannot state whether it will hold 80% of its charge after one year but if I do not actually use it for one year, I'll report on this claim.Like the Verbatim pack I mentioned above, this unit does not come with any case or means to carry the USB cord and the unit itself together conveniently. Fortunately we have a "dollar store" not far from us where I bought a semi-hard side "camera case" which holds both of the items together (I did the same for the Verbatim).Overall, while in my opinion, this is a very good unit and can be recommended, in view of the fact that it actually needs to sense that it is charging something (not merely powering an item), there is another one you may wish to consider - the rather ungainly Burro Mobile Charger - AA-Powered, USB Power Pack - Building Better Lives in Africa which, even considering the extra cost of 4 NiMH rechargeable batteries and a charger, is less costly than this neptor one. (Even if you buy two sets of rechargeable batteries, the Burro's cost is less.) This Burro has its own set of, shall we say, anomalies but, in my opinion, it is an excellent external phone chargers and it powers my Kinyo speakers as long as I need; I have run them several hours and I still had battery power left. While this will not be important to most of you, it is to me.So, in conclusion, again I'll state that I do indeed recommend this Neptor Model: NP056K external battery charger but I do suggest that, if you have need for something which can power a device but not actually charge it, you investigate some others, especially that Burro model I mentioned. But if that is not a concern, then in my opinion you can't do much better than this Neptor 5600mAh 3.1A Output 2nd Gen Dual Port Fast Charging External Portable Battery Pack Travel Battery Charger for iPhone 5C/5S, iPad mini, Samsung Galaxy S4/S5, Note, Nexus, LG, HTC and Motorola - Retail Pack Includes Flashlight Color Matching USB Ca....Thank you for reading this and for considering my opinions.Lawrence H. Bulk==========Update: December 30, 2014I had put this device away in the fall of 2013 and had not used it since. Yesterday I took it out of its case, turned it on, and discovered that it had actually held most of its charge, supplying enough power to fully charge my Sansa Clip-Zip (which was almost 'flat') as well as my LG Volt cell phone and, after all that charging was finished, three of the four indicator lights still remained lit.I was amazed!This is truly excellent performance and I can now wholeheartedly recommend this Neptor device to you.Thank you again for reading this.

Back in 2011, I bought an LG BD630 Network Blu-ray Disc Player from Amazon. (At the time it sold for $87.99.) It is a very nice Blu-ray/DVD/CD player but it does not have Wi-Fi capability. It must be connected to the Internet via an ethernet cable.(We have Verizon DSL and use an Actiontec 300 Mbps Wireless-N DSL Modem Router (GT784WN).)Unfortunately I have the player in a room on our second floor and our router is on the first floor. Until now, if I wanted to connect the unit to the Internet (for example, to utilize its Netflix and other Internet services), I had to run a 50-foot cable, not the most convenient (or elegant) solution.This ACTIONTEC 500 Mbps Powerline Ethernet Adapter and 4-Port Hub Kit (PWR514K01) has come to the rescue.It works PERFECTLY.Not only that, but it is extremely easy to set up. I shall go so far as to say that if you can read and comprehend the English language and if you have enough technical acumen to be able to change batteries in a flashlight, you can set this device up.It took longer to unpack it from its box than it did to connect my Blu-ray player! (It will take you longer to read this review than it will to set it up!)It is packed with everything you need in order to connect one device. If you need more than one connected to it, all you need buy are Mediabridge - BLue RJ45 Computer Networking Cat5e Ethernet Patch Cable - (14 Feet) or similar (in whatever length you need). The Hub can handle up to four devices.Supposedly you can also buy additional 4-Port Hubs (the adapter can transmit, over your power lines, to several Hubs) but I have been unable to find any of the Actiontec branded ones here on Amazon; perhaps they will be available at a later date. There are other brands of Hubs but I do not know if they will work with the Actiontec Adapter. In any case, if you wish to use the hub any place in your house (even outdoors if you have an electrical outlet outside), you merely unplug the 4-Port Hub Connector, plug it into whichever outlet you wish, and connect the Ethernet cable to your device.I do not know the speed of transmission but suffice it to say that Netflix HD streaming runs perfectly. I couldn't (and wouldn't!) ask for anything more.The instructions state that neither the Adapter nor the Hub should be plugged into a power strip or anything with surge protection or the product may not work. Well, that may be true in some instances, but, at least in my case, BOTH elements are plugged into power strips which also have surge protection circuits - and everything works perfectly.If all of the above weren't enough, take a look at the price of this device! It's hard to believe that something as totally-well-designed and capable as this can be priced so amazingly low.*Five stars aren't enough. I'd give it 100 stars if I could.Obviously I highly recommend this item.Thank you for reading this review. I hope that it has been of some use to you.Lawrence H. Bulk*Update of July 9, 2013When I wrote the original review, the price was $44.99. It has since gone up $30.00 - still low-priced, just not "amazingly" low-priced.

We formerly owned a George Foreman grill (model unknown) for many years. Finally its non-stick surface on the plates wore out and, though the grill was still functioning perfectly, to replace those plates would have cost almost as much as buying a new one.So we bought a George Foreman GRP4 Next Grilleration 4-Burger Grill with Removable Plates, White from Amazon on January 12, 2012. We have been using this unit, which is fully satisfactory, until two days ago when we got this new George Foreman GRP2841R 5-Serving Removable Plate Grill with Variable Temperature.I have to tell you - this is BY FAR the best George Foreman grill we have ever owned. Even if its styling is a bit strange (it reminds me of the top of "David Bowman's" [Keir Dullea's] space helmet from the film "2001"), who cares?It cooks well and FAST, much faster than either of our older ones. Using nearly the highest heat setting, my wife cooked four (4) large (though not the thickest) frozen (only partially thawed) hamburger patties to fully-well-done (that's how we like them) in a bit less than twelve (12) minutes! She clocked it. Amazing! She did not pre-heat for the recommended eight minutes; she pre-heated only for about two minutes.And the taste? Practically as good as hamburgers cooked over a charcoal grill outdoors.The drip tray was even greatly improved over the ones on our previous models; it slides and fits in exactly under the unit so that the grease will fall right into it. There's no chance of misalignment.But our burgers seared and cooked so fast that there was hardly any grease at all. This, I am sure, contributed to the exceptional taste.While you'll want to try various heat settings (and they will vary according to what you're cooking), we recommend that, for burgers and the like, you use the highest or near-highest heat setting. I think that will satisfy many people.The plates, top and bottom, remove easily for cleaning and they can be reattached just as easily. The design is near-perfect; maintenance couldn't be more convenient. The two plates and the drip tray can all be washed in a dishwasher. (These items can all be purchased and replaced by the user - but watch out for the prices. These replacement parts do not appear to be offered by Amazon at this time.)Obviously we are keeping our older GRP4 grill as it is still in excellent condition.But we shall now be using this new one - it is so much better.I think the smartest thing George Foreman ever did was to license the use of his name to the company that produces these - and that company has done George Foreman proud. In our opinion the name "George Foreman" equates to "top-quality."It's too bad that Amazon doesn't allow awarding more than five stars. I'd award it 100 stars if I could! My wife and I give this new George Foreman grill our highest possible recommendation.Thank you for reading this review and for considering my opinions.Lawrence H. Bulk

I have purchased four (4) of these Blu-Ray Player External USB DVD RW Laptop Burner Drives. The price is right and is far below that of any other competitor offering the same quality in my opinion.This player will NOT "burn" Blu-rays; it will only read the Blu-ray discs, allowing for playback on your computer (or television if you have the necessary input), but it WILL "burn" DVDs or CDs if you so desire.And, of course, it will allow you to archive any of your Blu-rays, DVDs, and/or CDs, creating appropriate computer files for playing and/or storage. I myself play my Blu-ray discs solely from the files I create thus protecting my Blu-ray discs from possible harm.The quality of this machine appears to be high. The power to run the player comes from two of your computer's USB ports (you could also use an AC-to-USB power adapter if you wish).Now I have read some reviews here in which the writers complain of this player not being "compatible" with their Windows or Mac computers. Without meaning to be obtuse or annoying, I can only say that that's their problem! I use a GNU/Linux operating system on my computers and ALL FOUR of these players work perfectly with ALL of my computers.If you wish, you can buy one through Amazon making certain that the order is actually fulfilled by Amazon. That way, if you do have an unfortunate problem, you can easily return the unit to Amazon at absolutely no cost to you.Now, as I mentioned, the quality appears to be high. That said, the consistency is not. Let me explain: here are details of all four of my machines as copied from my computer's properties list.Blu-Ray Player External USB DVD RW Laptop Burner DriveNumber 1:Drive InformationOS device name: /dev/sr1Manufacturer: SlimtypeProduct: BD E DS4E1SRevision: EA27Serial number: 908180348936Number 2:Drive InformationOS device name: /dev/sr1Manufacturer: HL-DT-STProduct: BDDVDRW CT21NRevision: 1.00Serial number: K0Z9CG41355Number 3:Drive InformationOS device name: /dev/sr1Manufacturer: HL-DT-STProduct: BDDVDRW CT30PRevision: NR01Serial number: KZ1B4QJ5649Firmware date: 2011-01-27 11:39:Bus encryption flags: 1ANumber 4:Drive InformationOS device name: /dev/sr1Manufacturer: HL-DT-STProduct: BDDVDRW CT30PRevision: NR01Serial number: KV7B1F21731Firmware date: 2010-12-08 15:42:Bus encryption flags: 1AAs you can see, all four are different. Numbers 1 and 2 are completely different and Numbers 3 and 4, though apparently the same actually have different firmware.I bought the Number 1 from TPC Technology and Numbers 2, 3, and 4 from T&J World, all the orders being fulfilled by Amazon.Number 1 is a "slow" copier; it never goes above 2.0X speed in copying a Blu-ray. It is very quiet however, far quieter than the LG external Blu-ray drives which I own.Number 2 is equally slow but it is noisier, especially when loading a disc. During the actual copying process, it is quiet.Number 3 is also slow and just as quiet as Number 1.Number 4 appears to be the best of both worlds: it copies fast (over 4.0X though I did not watch all the way through; it may well have speeded up even further) and it is very quiet.If you order, which version will you get?'Who knows? Numbers 2, 3, and 4 all came in the same package from the same dealer!Why did I buy four? I won't answer that completely but suffice it to say that I do not know for how long these units will be available at this price. I believe in getting while the getting is good.I have to tell you that one of my LG Blu-ray drives "died" after less than a year. While it is still technically covered under warranty, having read quite a few complaints about LG's service (or lack thereof), I don't hold much hope in getting it repaired.I use an external Blu-ray drive very heavily. I am in the process of archiving every one of my Blu-rays and DVDs. If one or more of these units "die," the pain won't be as bad considering the very low price (the LGs were $99.00+ apiece!).So, in conclusion, I want to say that I am very happy with all four of my new players and I highly recommend them to everyone.Thank you for reading this and for considering my opinions.Lawrence H. Bulk

This Combo Rapid Car Charger + Home Wall Charger + USB Data Charge Sync Cable for Kyocera S2100 is a genuine bargain. For its low price, you get an AC adapter, a DC (car) adapter, and a USB (cable) adapter, all of which terminate in a mini-USB connection.Not only will all three power a Kyocera S2100 cell phone (a basic model), they will power almost ANY item which has a mini-USB port as a power connection. More and more electronic items are featuring that kind of power port. I have tried all three of the included items with my SanDisk Sansa Clip Zip 4GB MP3 Player (Blue) and all worked perfectly with it.The AC adapter has a bright red LED to show that it is functioning; the DC adapter has a large area which glows blue when it is functioning. I know that some people are bothered by bright LED indicators but I myself am not. I would much rather have the LEDs glowing so that I know that my adapters are continuing to function.Both the AC and the DC adapter are very small in size with cords of adequate length (the DC cord is one of those curled types); the USB cord is approximately five feet in length.Is there a "fly in the ointment?" Of course! (Isn't there always?) The AC adapter is not UL-listed. I wish it were. But I ordered two of this item and both work perfectly. Obviously I hope that they continue to do so and that there is never a fire-hazard discovered with this AC adapter (there would be none with the DC or USB adapters).I bought mine from CobraCables/CableForge one of the 'alternate' sellers which, though they charge more, offer free shipping. (If you buy from the 'main' dealer which offers a very low price but charges shipping, and if you have a problem, you will only get as a refund the cost of the product, not the shipping, whereas if you buy from a dealer who offers a higher price but free shipping, if there is a problem and you want a refund, you'll get all of your money back.)In the event, I was very satisfied with CobraCables/CableForge's fast shipping as well as with the product itself; I do wish the packaging would have been somewhat more protective but everything arrived (via USPS) in perfect condition. I am so pleased that I just ordered four (4) more of them from the same seller!In my opinion, you just cannot go wrong with this adapter set and I give it my highest recommendation.

I am extremely pleased with this Behringer UFO202 Audio Interface. It works exactly as it should and its price is very low for the quality and functionality it supplies.Now there are already 151 Amazon reviews prior to mine and most of them are thoughtful, well-written, and informative. As a matter of fact, it was reading most of those previous reviews which impelled me to buy this device. That said, I want to emphasize something for which many of the reviewers have unjustly, in my opinion, downgraded the product: any resemblance of what is claimed on the box or in the instruction manual that you WILL get, and what you actually DO get, is strictly coincidental.You will get NO discs (when you see the size of the outer box you will realize that a disc wouldn't even fit into it!), NO "included" software and, even though in the instruction manual it is claimed that there is a TOSLink output on the unit, there is NOT.So please just forget about any ancillaries promised. You're not going to get them.What you DO get is a superb instrument which allows you to create excellent digital recordings from any source you wish including records. And frankly, in my opinion, that's plenty!Thus, though the labeling on the box and the error(s) in the manual are completely inexcusable (and absolutely should be corrected), the product itself, again in my opinion, is all that matters and this one, at around $40.00, is, I believe, an amazing bargain.The manual states that the interface has a 16-bit converter and samples up to 48 kHz but, in fact, you can (and I did) make 24-bit (or 32-bit) 192 kHz (or even higher) files depending on the software you use.Now if you already own a USB turntable, and all you want to do is to create digital files from only your records (files which you can play on your computer or from which you can create CDs), you do not need this item. But if you don't own such a turntable, and wish to copy tapes as well as LPs, 45s, etc., then I believe that you will be quite satisfied with this device.Its phono section works ONLY with turntables using moving-magnet cartridges. If you have a turntable with a ceramic cartridge, you would use the line-level setting on the interface. (There is a small switch which changes the inputs to "phono" - with the appropriate RIAA curve setting - and "line" which handles everything else.) If your turntable has a moving-coil cartridge, you would need to insert a pre-preamp between the turntable and the interface.But in most cases, for recording records, all you need do is to plug the RCA outputs from your turntable into the requisite inputs on this unit and switch the unit to phono; you must also attach the ground cable to this interface. Then merely plug in the USB cable to your computer. The cable transmits the sound and also supplies power to the interface (you will see its green LED light up when you plug in the USB cable).The manual and the box state that the unit supports Windows-XP and Windows 2000 operating systems (as well as an older Mac system) but this is incomplete. This interface, having no drivers of its own, will work with ANY computer running ANY operating system as long as that computer is equipped with a USB port.Then use the software of your choice. As I use a GNU/Linux operating system on my computer, I use the Audacity software (which I like very much) but there are any number of other choices available. I believe that there are also many choices available for Windows and Mac computers as well. You may need to do a bit of searching (there are many available on Behringer's site but I believe that you can find more, and more satisfactory ones, just by doing an ordinary search on the Internet) and then you may need to practice with the software of your choice but I'm certain that the results will be as satisfactory to you as they are to me.Please note that I strongly recommend that you try "free" software (such as Audacity) first; in my experience, the free software is AT LEAST as good as most "pay" ones - and often even better. If you use free software, then the total cost to you is just the price of the unit itself (and any necessary cables you would have to buy if you do not already have them). But of course whether you use free software or software for which you must pay would be your own choice.This unit arrived just a couple of days ago; I have had time to copy only one LP. But the recording turned out perfectly. I had to make one or two "test" recordings to find out the proper settings in the Audacity software, but attaching and using the Behringer UFO202 itself was completely straightforward. Almost anyone could do it.My digital copy of my record sounds EXACTLY the same as the LP itself. Perhaps some "golden-eared" person MIGHT be able to distinguish between them but, if the test were effected in a double-blind fashion, I'll bet that he/she could not. I certainly can't hear any difference! Note that, as I mentioned above, I made a 24-bit 192 kHz FLAC file from my record.I own several other Behringer products: the Behringer MICROPHONO PP400 Ultra-Compact Phono Preamp, the Behringer UCA202 Audio Interface, the Behringer UCA222 U-Control Ultra-Low Latency 2 In/2 Out USB Audio Interface with Digital Output And Downloadable Software Bundle, and the Behringer HPS3000 Studio Headphones.Some people have "knocked" Behringer for poor customer service and I have no doubt about their unfortunate experiences. But I myself have had NO problems whatsoever with any of my Behringer products so I have never had the need to contact Behringer. If you buy their products from Amazon, as I did, and if you were to have a problem, you merely contact Amazon and they will effect an exchange or refund, as you wish (they will even arrange to pick up the product at your home if you desire) - all at no cost to you.But I have found that, with all of my Behringer products (and I own six pair of those headphones), their manufacturing and quality control are absolutely first-rate. So are their designs - and so are their prices!So, in conclusion, I should like to say that, if you wish to easily create digital files from your records and/or tapes, I strongly recommend that you consider this Behringer UFO202 Audio Interface. While you could plug the outputs from a tape deck directly into the microphone input on your computer, the resultant sound files will generally be inferior. And you cannot plug a turntable directly into a microphone input and expect anything good. So, for its low price, this device affords you the opportunity to make the music on your records and tapes available to you in digital format; playing these digital files exclusively ensures that your originals will not be damaged or worn further.Thank you for reading this and for considering my opinions.Lawrence H. Bulk

Please note that this review is primarily for those people whose computers use a GNU/Linux operating system.Without a doubt, this Seagate Slim 500 GB USB 3.0 Portable Hard Drive - Black (STCD500102) is the smallest and slimmest hard drive I have ever gotten. I also got the Seagate Slim 500 GB USB 3.0 Portable Hard Drive for Mac (STCF500102), essentially the same drive, merely formatted differently. This review applies to both.They are less than 4-inches long, about 3-inches wide, and about -inches in depth. That's small!The Windows version has a black aluminum front face, glossy black sides, and a black matte-finish metal back. The Mac version has a silver aluminum front face instead of the black one but the sides and back are the same. Thus the only real difference between them is the styling; if you're a Linux user who is going to reformat a drive, you can pick either of these depending on your color preference (or the price at the time you order). They're both really good-looking!Both appear to be very sturdy and make no noise that I can hear when in use.If you have a computer with USB 3.0 ports, with either of these drives you will get very high transfer speeds, typically far higher than that which can be obtained via USB 2.0.When I receive a drive, the first thing I do is to shake it to see if there are any loose parts (I actually did get such a defective drive once upon a time).There was nothing loose in either, so the next thing I do is to attach one at a time to my computer and reformat the drive to EXT4 (the Linux standard). (With the Windows version, there is only one partition to unmount so reformatting is straightforward. However on the Mac version, there are two partitions, both of which must be unmounted prior to the reformatting.)That partitioning achieved with nothing out of the ordinary, I then transfered some folders/files to each of the drives.That too proceeded uneventfully - and FAST.These drives are as good as any I have ever owned yet are much smaller in physical size. It is amazing to me what can be packed into such a small device!Both come only with a two-year warranty; this is somewhat disappointing as many of my other drives come with three-year warranties. Nonetheless, two years is better than the one year warranty with which some drives are now shipping.I like both of these drive very much and I highly recommend either one of them (or both!) to any GNU/Linux user who needs a backup for his/her folders, files, photos, music, etc.Thank you very much for reading this and for considering my opinions.

0:42 MinsThe title says it all - these Behringer HPS3000 Studio Headphones produce very good sound, especially when the price is considered.I'm sure you have read the many negative reviews here, especially those which complain about the longevity of this product. I can sympathize with those people who may have had some problems but I cannot claim to have had any myself.Well, you could say, "Okay. He bought ONE set and he was lucky; his are good ones."You could say that - but you'd be wrong.I did not buy one set; I bought SIX sets - and from two different vendors at different times. The last three were purchased from Amazon.You can see all six in my video.All have functioned perfectly from Day 1 and all continue to function perfectly. Most importantly, all have functioned identically, a sign of superb design and quality control. Two of them have been across the country and back.Over the years I have owned many headphone sets (including a very expensive one made by another German company whose name begins with S and ends with R; this set, which lasted about four years, is now a permanent resident of our local landfill).I use headphones extensively. I bought one of these HPS3000s some time ago and I was surprised (actually astounded) by the clarity of sound they produced.These Behringers have sound quality which, in my opinion, is superior to that of those other German headphones, especially in the bass and the crystalline highs produced.It is also superior to most other headphones I have heard, including Sony and Bose. (But I have to say that they are noticeably inferior to the TASCAM TH Series TH-MX2 Studio Headphones which, however, are somewhat more costly - though the difference won't break the bank.)I listen frequently via these headphones to CDs on the Lyrita Recorded Edition label; if you are familiar with that name, you know that they have achieved the finest sound quality yet available on CD (not quite, of course, as good as that available on SACD - but very close). Do you want to try a sampling? Try this: Celebrating 50 Years Devoted To British Music, Set One; if you like that set, then try this one: Celebrating 50 Years Devoted To British Music, Set Two. Not only is the sound quality spectacular, so is the music quality!In my opinion, these Behringer headphones are very good - in terms of sound quality, construction quality, and value for money. Period. That's why I wound up buying a total of six of them. (And yes I have specific uses for all six.) My older headphones, of which I have many, now reside in a box in my basement. (But my new TASCAMS are the ones I shall use when listening seriously via headphones.)As for comfort, I think that is highly subjective. I have found these to be at least as comfortable as any I have owned in the past and really a bit better than most. They are lightweight (though 'clunky' looking) and they cover my ears completely (but they are not noise-canceling). The headband is also very comfortable. Once I put them on, I do not have to adjust them further and I listen generally for three or four hours at a time. But the only way for you to know for sure if they fit you comfortably is to try them. They fit me just fine. (My older headphones are also, for the most part, comfortable.)Obviously I highly recommend these Behringers to you. I also highly recommend that you buy them from Amazon. If by chance you were to receive a defective pair, you could return them to Amazon at absolutely no cost to you. (If you ask, Amazon will schedule a pickup at your home or place of business so you don't even have to take the package to the post office or a different shipping facility.) You can request an exchange or a refund. The choice is yours.But after buying, owning, and extensively using these six pair, I am confident that, if you buy a set, you will have the same experience as I have had. (I should also say that I own several other Behringer products: Behringer UCA202 Audio Interface, Behringer UCA222 U-Control Ultra-Low Latency 2 In/2 Out USB Audio Interface with Digital Output And Downloadable Software Bundle, and Behringer PP400 Ultra-Compact Phono Preamp. I am 100% satisfied with all of them. And, other than as a completely satisfied customer, I have no connection whatsoever with the Behringer company.)I would give these headphones 50 stars if I could, especially when you consider the ridiculously low price asked for them (compare the price to that of any other high-quality set of headphones). I paid far less for my six Behringers than I did for the one expensive set I mentioned above.In conclusion, it is my opinion that, if you want "prestige" or "coolness," then you buy Beats by Dr. Dre, Bose, Sennheiser, or some other $300.00+ headphones. However, if all you want is comfort and fine sound quality over many hours, then you buy these.I thank you for reading this, for watching my video, and for considering my opinions.Lawrence H. Bulk

1:06 MinsI received this Leslie Dame CD-612D Solid Oak Mission Style Multimedia Storage Cabinet, Dark Oak yesterday and my wife and I are thrilled with it. The video will show you how it looks in my room and the amount of storage space it offers (both in the main part of the cabinet as well as in the doors).I admit I ordered it with some trepidation after reading some of the previous reviews here which mentioned shipping damage. But ours arrived in absolutely perfect condition. Its packing is superlative; it has to be because the cabinet, almost completely assembled, is shipped from China to the West Coast and then, in our case, across the country to our home on the East Coast. Frankly, I think shipping damage to this item would be a real rarity.When I say "almost completely assembled," I mean just that. The only things the buyer must do is to remove, with a small Phillips-head screwdriver, two (or four) L-shaped metal attachments which holds two long shelves affixed by the factory for sturdiness in shipping (removing these attachments and placing a shelf on another level may not be necessary, depending upon what you intend to put on it; I only needed to remove two of the L-shaped attachments for one of the shelves to place that shelf on another level), insert the small plastic bolts (four per shelf) into the appropriate holes and then put each shelf into place. The buyer determines where the shelves are placed depending upon the use(s) he/she is contemplating. This can be changed at any time in the future should circumstances warrant.There are five long shelves and ten shorter shelves included; you may or may not need all of them. (There are sixty plastic bolts included; I wish Leslie Dame had included four more "just in case" but that is a small 'nit.')This gives you a maximum of 18 spaces in which to store your discs or tapes, 6 short spaces in each of the doors (12 total), and 6 long spaces in the center of the cabinet.In our case, I used all of the shelves (and all of the bolts) because I am going to use the cabinet exclusively for CDs. The bolts were tight going in but this means, of course, that they will not fall out.The instruction sheet is complete and clear. It took me less than an hour to get it completely ready, from the time of arrival, to the time of completion.Now Leslie Dame states that the cabinet will hold 612 CDs. They obviously mean 612 CDs in 612 standard "jewel box" cases. However, I own the Arturo Toscanini: The Complete RCA Collection which has 84 CDs and 1 DVD in a box taking up less space than 30 standard CDs (the CDs/DVD in this box are stored in cardboard sleeves) so I shall be able to get many more than 612 CDs into this cabinet.(I also own the Mercury Living Presence Boxed Set as well as several other boxed sets, all of which contain CDs in cardboard sleeves rather than CD "jewel boxes.") So the "612" figure will not apply to me; Leslie Dame's "Holds 612 CDs, 298 DVDs, or 172 VHS tapes, or any combination" may or may not apply to you. You may be able to store more too. Certainly you'll store no less than the numbers specified.It is a beautiful piece of furniture made of solid oak (the joins on the doors are even dove-tailed!) and, unlike most vinyl-clad fiberboard cabinets, it will look quite nice in any room of your house.Some people have mentioned, in a somewhat negative fashion, that it is made in China. It is. Would I myself have preferred that it had been Made in USA? Certainly! But I have to say that, no matter where it would be made, in my opinion the quality of construction couldn't be bettered, especially at the price.In conclusion, like most other reviewers here, I am completely pleased with this cabinet and I recommend it to anyone needing a nice media storage center.Thank you for reading this and for watching the video.Lawrence H. Bulk

I received this Belkin SuperSpeed USB 3.0 4-Port Hub (F4U058tt) the other day from Amazon Vine and I am happy with it.I tried it today for the first time, transferring three folders containing a total of 14 GB to three separate external hard drives. The process took just a couple of minutes.I attached the USB cords of the three USB 3.0 drives into slots 1, 2, and 3 on the hub, attached the supplied power cord to the device, plugged in the power cord to an AC socket, attached the supplied USB 3.0 cable to the hub, and finally plugged the other end of the cable into one of my computer's USB 3.0 ports. (I recommend that you make your connections in that same order.)All three drives were recognized instantly. Three blue lights (two to the left and one centered, more or less) came on, showing, I guess, that the unit was powered, connected, and functioning. (There was no instruction manual included with my unit nor is there any mention of these lights on the packaging so I have no true idea of what they stand for; these lights are not shown in any of the pictures.)The unit will handle four external drives and, while I have not tried using it yet with four drives, it worked perfectly well with my three.Now I must tell you that I am using a GNU/Linux operating system (specifically Xubuntu) on my computer so I know that your experience (using Windows or Mac) may not be entirely the same as mine (Linux is faster both in connection time as well as in transfer time), but, as the hub specifically states that it is compatible with Windows 7 (and earlier, back to XP SP3), I expect that there will not be too much difference; ditto for Mac though there is no mention of Mac at all on the packaging. I have read that some people using a MacBook Air have had some problems but note that if you buy the hub from Amazon and are dissatisfied with it, you merely contact Amazon and you can return it at absolutely no cost to you.There was no mention of Linux on the packaging either but, as I stated, it works perfectly with my computer.I see from a few previous reviews that certain people have had some difficulty with the hub; I have read similar reviews complaining of similar problems with other hubs (a couple of which I also own). I can only say that, with one exception (and that was due to extremely poor physical construction in which a USB port on it came completely apart! I threw it out!), I have had no connection or transfer problems with any of my hubs over the years. They have all been reliable. I expect no less from this one.This particular hub is quite small. It comes with a power cable and a USB 3.0 cable, both of adequate length. If these cables are not long enough for your particular installation, extension cords (AC and/or USB) are inexpensive and readily available.I shall be taking it along when my wife and I travel. I know it will come in handy and it will take up little room. It appears to be constructed with integrity.Obviously, if your computer has only USB 2.0 ports, you will not achieve USB 3.0 speeds of transfer, but, if your computer does indeed have at least one USB 3.0 port, and if you are in the market for a USB 3.0 hub, I recommend this one to you.Thank you for reading this and for considering my opinions.Lawrence H. Bulk

I am very pleased with this C2G / Cables to Go 28733 Digital To Analog Audio ConverterDAC Black. This product is a hidden gem among Amazon's audio offerings. Though it's not much to look at and it doesn't have a "prestigious" name (the name printed on its case is "TRULink" - sounds like something you'd find in an ultra-low-end discount store), you must take into account that physical styling and impressive names have absolutely nothing to do with sound quality - and it's in its sound quality that this device really shines. Wait until you hear what it can produce!While it appears that most of the reviewers of it are using it for TV sound output, I am using it to send computer sound to my stereo system. It is a superb device for use in this type of application. Please note that, if you plan to use it with a television set, it will output stereo sound only, not Dolby Digital or DTS surround sound.It has three inputs: digital optical, digital coaxial (for use with televisions, etc. - HDMI sound output from your television will not work with it) and a USB input (for use in conjunction with a computer). When using it with your television, I believe that you must use the USB power adapter (included) (I have not tried this so I am not sure about this statement) but, when using it to convert computer digital sound to analog (my primary use), no addition power supply is necessary. You merely attach the USB cable (included) to a USB (2.0 or 3.0) port on your computer and then run RCA cables (not included) from the unit to your receiver or amplifier.It can also be used as a high-quality headphone amplifier (the sound coming from any source, optical, coaxial, or USB). The volume control works only with the headphone amp; it has no effect on the output from the RCA jacks.Unlike the Behringer UCA202 Audio Interface or the Behringer UCA222 U-Control Ultra-Low Latency 2 In/2 Out USB Audio Interface with Digital Output And Downloadable Software Bundle, it cannot be used for digital recording though it could, of course, be used for cassette tape - remember that? - recording with your stereo system. Otherwise, it is strictly a playback unit.It does support 24-bit/192 kHz audio (evidently without conversion) and the sound quality obtained from a computer using this device, as opposed to using the headphone-out jack on the computer, is audibly superior.Will it work with your computer? Yes, definitely! It requires no external drivers and, though it's only claimed to work with various Windows distributions, it will in fact work with ANY computer which has USB ports, Windows, MAC, or GNU/Linux (which is what I use).All you need, in addition to the unit itself, is this Cables Unlimited AUD-1605-06 6-Feet Pro A/V Series RCA Audio Cables or this C2G / Cables to Go 3-Feet 3.5mm Male to 2 RCA Type Male Audio Y Cable for iPod-White (depending upon the type of input on your amplifier or amplified computer speakers; other lengths of cable are also available).This DAC carries the usual one-year warranty and, if you buy it from Amazon, you are doubly protected. It seems to be well-built and, though I have had it for only a few days, it appears to be fully satisfactory for the use to which I put it (playing computer sound through my audio system).Is there a fly in the ointment? You bet - it is the accompanying documentation (or lack thereof). Neither the box nor the instruction sheet tells anything about the specifications of this device. For that, you must go to their web site and even that information is not given anywhere on the box or sheet. (See my first comment to this review for the applicable URL.) Frankly, I think that this is unconscionable.But the unit is indeed a simple "plug-and-play" device (as long as you know how to adjust sound output from your own computer). It is easy to set up and use and it produces superior sound quality, much better than the sound quality one can obtain from a computer's own audio circuitry via a headphone jack or line output.For listening to internet radio, FLAC (or ALAC) files, mp3s, or even CDs via your computer, this device will afford the best possible sound quality, limited only by the capabilities of your audio equipment.And its price is "right."I highly recommend it and I thank you for reading this.Lawrence H. BulkP.S. By the way, I like it so much that I bought a second one for use in my "second" audio system.

I have read most of the reviews concerning the excellent Behringer UCA222 U-Control Ultra-Low Latency 2 In/2 Out USB Audio Interface with Digital Output And Downloadable Software Bundle and the equally excellent Behringer UCA202 Audio Interface and I have seen several questions asked repeatedly.While I cannot truly add anything to the fine reviews already written, as an owner of both models, I may be able to answer definitively certain of these common questions.1) Will it work with my computer? Yes it will if your computer has USB 2.0 or 3.0 ports. While I believe it will also work with older computers which have only USB 1.1 ports, I have not tried it with such so I cannot comment about that older port (which has not been offered for about ten years now). The USB port supplies all necessary power to these devices; no external power is necessary (nor can external power be applied).2) Will it work with my operating system? Yes it will. My older '202 (purchased several years ago) states it is compatible with Windows XP and Mac. My newer '222 (which I just purchased last week) states it is compatible with Windows XP, Windows 7, and Mac. In actual fact, as it requires no external drivers of any kind, it is compatible with ALL operating systems; I use a GNU/Linux OS (Xubuntu) on my computer and both work perfectly with it.3) Does it come with software? Well, Behringer's instructions state that a free CD is included. It is not. But you can download some software from Behringer's site; this software may or may not work with your computer but this really does not matter. Suitable free software is readily available all over the web. If you use a GNU/Linux OS, you need only enter "Digital Audio" into the search box of the Ubuntu Software Center or, preferably, into the Synaptic Package Manager's search box. There you'll find plenty of software which works with Linux (more software than anybody would ever need!).4) Can you monitor sound as it is being recorded? Yes, using headphones, you can, choosing to listen either directly from the USB output or from the RCA inputs; there is a small switch which makes the adjustment between the two.5) Is there a digital output? Yes there is, an optical one. If your equipment has only a coaxial digital input, optical-to-coaxial converters are readily available at low cost (Amazon sells several). Note that the optical output transmits only two-channel sound; there is no provision for Dolby or DTS multi-channel.6) Is there any difference between the two units, the UCA222 and the UCA202? Yes there is. The UCA222 is red in color with a red LED. The UCA202 is silver in color with a green LED. You buy either of these units based on a) price at the time you order one, and b) color preference (if any). THAT'S IT! Color is the ONLY difference between these units. The circuitry is identical and so is the operation and performance.Please note that these are strictly 16-bit / [up to] 48 kHz units. They WILL play back 24-bit 192 kHz files but they will convert them down to 16-bit 48 kHz. Will you hear a difference? That depends upon a) the equipment you're using and b) the sensitivity of your hearing. Remember that, if you're playing CDs or files made from CDs, they are 16-bit 44.1 kHz only so that's all you'll hear regardless of the DAC you use.I use these devices for travel. They are lightweight and robustly built. $30.00 (approximately) is a true bargain for something of this quality. The sound produced is superior to the sound supplied from your computer's headphone output and that improvement can be heard by anybody.I hope that I have touched on some salient points. If anyone has any questions, please feel free to ask them in the Comments section.I highly recommend these Behringer Digital-to-Analog USB devices.Thank you for reading this.Lawrence H. Bulk

This is a superlative flash drive, certainly the best one I have ever owned.Please note that this review will be of interest primarily to those who use a GNU/Linux operating system and whose computers have USB 3.0 ports. People using Windows or Mac can either read it just for information or can ignore it altogether (except, perhaps, for my first and last sentences; I hope everyone takes note of them!) and I say that without meaning to be disrespectful to anyone.My wife and I are currently using two ZaReason Strata 7330 Laptop Computers, both of which have two USB 3.0 ports (as well as two USB 2.0 ports). We have customized them with additional RAM and have upgraded them to the new Intel Ivy Bridge processors (hers i5-3210, mine i7-3720). Their operating systems are Xubuntu.I received my SanDisk Extreme 32 GB USB 3.0 Flash Drive SDCZ80-032G-X46 today. On the box is stated that it is compatible with Windows XP, Windows Vista, Windows 7, and Mac OS X v10.5+.Well, guess what! To that you can add any GNU/Linux distribution!The drive was recognized instantly via both of the USB 3.0 ports on my computer and functioned perfectly until I unmounted it. It was also instantly recognized (and functioned perfectly) via the USB 2.0 ports on two older computers, one running Ubuntu and the other Linux Mint.The drive comes pre-formatted with FAT32 and, of course, contains some 'bloatware' (software) which I immediately deleted.Then I ran an experiment with it just to determine its capabilities.I have three movies in a folder on my computer, all of which are in MKV format, and the entire folder is 5.4 GB in size.Without changing the format of the drive, I copied this folder to it; the time elapsed was 49 seconds. That's fast (about 110 MB/s).I then deleted the folder, reformatted the drive to the NTFS file format (on computers using a GNU/Linux operating system, reformatting anything is quick and easy) and, after the conversion was completed, I re-copied the folder to the drive. This time the transfer took 69 seconds, still fast, but slower than when the drive was formatted as FAT32. I do not know why NTFS was slower than FAT32.Then I deleted the folder from the drive again (by the way, both times I completely deleted the copied folder using SHIFT + DELETE so it was completely gone from the drive) and reformatted the drive to EXT4, the native Linux file system (to which my computer is also formatted).I then recopied the 5.4 GB folder.This time the operation was completed in 28 seconds. TWENTY-EIGHT SECONDS!! I checked the transfer times carefully (using an 'atomic' clock). There is no mistake (and, with the drive formatted as EXT4, I did the transfer experiment twice just to make sure of the time for transfer! It was the same both times!).You figure out the speed!Suffice it to say that I am absolutely amazed and pleased with this drive. I have always used SanDisk flash drives but this one 'blows out of the water' any I had used previously.By the way, the format to which I had the drive configured did not make any difference in the recognition of the drive on my computer. As I stated above, it was instantly recognized via either of the two USB 3.0 ports and continued to function until I unmounted it.This one is as well-made as any SanDisk drive I have used before (I own five or six of them, the largest previous one being 8 GB). It is sturdy, quite well-made, and features a small blue activity light as well as a key chain attachment. While it is slightly longer than my previous ones, it is nonetheless quite small and the sliding port protects the USB connection (and works very nicely). This 32 GB drive will hold all the information I would ever want to transfer in such a manner, at least for the foreseeable future.Now I cannot tell anyone about the performance of this drive when using Microsoft Windows or the Apple Mac operating systems but I should suspect that, assuming that those computers are equipped with USB 3.0 ports, it will be very fast on those systems too.I shall continue to use my older SanDisk drives (formatted as FAT32) if I want to copy something from someone else's Windows (or Mac) computer and transfer it to my own; EXT4 formatted drives generally do not work on Windows (or Mac) computers whereas FAT32 works on everything and NTFS works on Windows computers.Obviously I am leaving this particular drive formatted as EXT4 as I have several computers, all of which use a GNU/Linux OS and, while none of the others has USB 3.0 ports, nonetheless, drives formatted as EXT4 transfer much faster between Linux devices than do drives formatted any other way.And, just as obviously, I highly, highly, highly recommend this drive to all who can take advantage of its capabilities.

I own several AmazonBasics SD cards but this one has, by far, the largest capacity of any of them.It is formatted in the new exFAT file system; not every camera can use that (nor can all cameras handle such a large-capacity SD card) but this card, like all such cards, is easy to reformat to whatever file system you wish. (If, however, your camera can accept an exFAT formatted card, you'll want to use this card as is - I understand that that new file system is superior to most of the the older systems.)As I had a specific need at first, I reformatted mine to the Linux-native file format of EXT4. After I had completed the task at hand, I reformatted it to FAT32.Then I inserted it into my Canon G1 X 14.3 MP CMOS Digital Camera with 4x Wide-Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom Lens Full 1080p HD Video and 3.0-inch Vari-Angle LCD in which, as expected, it functioned perfectly. I do not know how many pictures it will actually hold, but it certainly will be a LOT!This card's speed is not quite in the same league as the SanDisk Extreme 64 GB SDXC UHS-I Card 45MB/s (SDSDX-064GB-X46), for example, yet it is certainly fast enough for most practical purposes. It is a Class 10 card.I have been buying AmazonBasics products of all kinds almost since they were introduced and I have had a problem with only one of them - and, even though I had had that product for over a year, Amazon IMMEDIATELY replaced it WITHOUT EVEN REQUIRING ME TO RETURN THE DEFECTIVE ONE!Their SD cards are of top quality and Amazon's support for their own products after the sale (in my case, WELL after the sale) is second-to-none. This card's price is lower than SanDisk's Extreme with only a very slight loss of performance and thus represents good value for money.I highly recommend this AmazonBasics 64 GB Class 10 SDXC UHS-1 Flash Memory Card.

I am very impressed with this Seagate Backup Plus 500 GB USB 3.0 Portable External Hard Drive STBU500100 (Black). This is my first Seagate external hard drive. It is easy to use and it functions very well.Specified to work with Microsoft Windows and Apple Mac, it is actually cross-platform and will work well as a storage device with any computer operating system.As is usual these days, as soon as you connect the drive to your computer, it will be recognized and will be operational.It is nicely styled. Its case looks as though it were made of metal but it's actually made from a very good grade of plastic. The top face looks 'brushed,' the sides look 'glossy,' and the bottom face looks 'matte-finished.' It is available in several other colors as well as black.The top portion is actually a removable module. It just pulls right off the rest of the drive. This is the first time I have seen such a feature and it's quite unique. (If I had my 'druthers,' I would wish for a positive lock for the module. Nonetheless, the connection seems sturdy and firm enough and this complaint is a very small one.)This module is connected to the rest of the drive via an internal port and it can be swapped for other modules which feature different types of computer connections (see below).The USB 3.0 port is placed at the top of this module and there is a white LED on the front of module which lights up when the unit is connected. It is, of course, fully backwards-compatible with USB 2.0 (I have not tried it with a USB 1.1 connection).The removable module allows access to the internal port which can connect to different, optionally-purchased modules and these, instead of using USB 3.0, can use the new Thunderbolt or the older FireWire technology should the user wish to use those means of connection. The Seagate GoFlex Thunderbolt Adapter (STAE121) (rather expensive just now) is available as is the Seagate FreeAgent GoFlex Upgrade Cable FireWire 800 - STAE102.This modular design appears to make this drive 'future-proof' as future, not-yet-invented, connections will be able to be used with this drive merely by buying a new module. Whether other manufacturers will adapt this type of technology is a question I cannot answer. And I also cannot say if the internal port connection is a proprietary or a 'universal' type which will be adapted by those other manufacturers. But this type of modular design does seem to me to be quite desirable, especially in view of the fact that this Seagate drive, which has it, costs little, if any, more alone than competing drives which do not have this feature.However, I must say that, even without other modules and/or other means of file transfer, USB 3.0 is VERY fast (transferring FROM a Western Digital USB 3.0 drive TO this one via my computer's two USB 3.0 ports, I got over 85 Mbps speed - that's real-world) and I think that transferring files to and from this one is at least as fast as anyone would currently desire.Otherwise, this hard drive is typical of its breed. It comes with backup and some control software installed, usable only with Windows and Mac, which, as I use a Linux operating system, is of no use to me whatsoever. And from what I have read, it appears that few Windows and Mac users would find this proprietary software useful either. I immediately deleted all of it, leaving an empty drive which, delivered formatted as NTFS, offers 465+ MB of storage space. NTFS is native to Windows but also works perfectly in Linux; nonetheless, I reformatted the drive to EXT4, the native Linux file system. I do not know how well it works with a Mac but if you own a Mac, you can easily reformat this drive to HFS+.Though it's still small enough to easily fit into a man's pocket, it is slightly 'longer' than the Western Digital portable external hard drives I have previously used and does not fit in the AmazonBasics case which I use for those drives. So I bought this equally inexpensive Drive Logic DL-64 Portable EVA Hard Drive Carrying Case Pouch (Black) which holds the drive (plus its 18-inch connection cable) with room to spare. Unusually, this case also has a full-width stretchable pocket on its front which could hold something fairly thin such as business cards, small papers, etc. (maybe even a small, thin MP3 player!). The only thing I do not care for about the case is the fact that the zipper opens from the bottom rather than the top; to me, this is counterintuitive. (But that's a minor 'nit.')Obviously I am using the drive exclusively as a storage device to back up my documents, music, pictures, and videos. I suspect that most people will also wish to use it strictly for that purpose.It operates at 5400 RPM and gets just barely warm in extended use. (I think that most people will not even notice this slight warmth.)Seagate drives have always had a fine reputation and this particular Seagate drive comes with a 2-year warranty (which is typical for this type of product).Prices for external drives have been falling of late from the high levels seen last year (as a result of weather conditions and other natural disasters) and, at least at this time, this one is priced 'right,' especially in view of its new modular technology.I highly recommend it.==================================================================================================================================Update: November 21, 2012Two days ago, courtesy of Amazon Vine, I received another of these drives, this one of 1 TB capacity. It is just as good as the 500 GB drive and, because of the large difference in capacity coupled with the small difference in price, it the one I recommend that you buy.

Courtesy of Amazon Vine, my wife has received two previous-model Remington Hair Dryers (Ac2015 and D3710) in the last couple of years, both of which she liked better than any other brand she had owned before.Yesterday this new model, the Remington D8410 Keratin Therapy Dryer, arrived. While performance of the three Remington models she now owns is about the same, this new one is, due to its superb design, the best of the three.All three of Remington's models feature an 1875W high torque motor along with a "cool shot" to set your style, 3 heat and 2 speed settings for styling control, and a removable air filter for easier cleaning.
