And the food definitely did cook faster (much faster) and more evenly than it had with our older Acme pans which are much lighter in weight than these new Circulons. She says this new set even appears to cook faster than the older Circulon pans she had purchased previously. In any case, the food came out delicious (as always). My wife is a truly superb cook (among her other wonderful attributes, one of which is putting up with me!) and, though I admit I am highly prejudiced, I believe that she deserves a high-quality set like this Circulon Symmetry one.

I have quite a few portable devices which require charging or powering via a USB power adapter. (Look around: I'll bet you do too!) Over the past few years, I have purchased a number of USB Power Adapters and, while all are satisfactory in SOME ways, until I received this one, none were fully satisfactory in ALL ways.For example, some adapters will work ONLY via AC power. And others will work ONLY via DC (car) power. When I wished to use the AC ones in my car (or I wish to use the DC ones in my home), I had to plug those adapters into suitable additional adapters. This, of course, makes for a 'clunky' arrangement (especially in a small car such as we have).I really wanted ONE adapter which could work with both types of power - in other words, an "all-in-one."Amazon has many such adapters for sale but all that I investigated had some VERY negative comments about their claims vs. actual performance.While investigating, I came across this Maximal Power AC DC USB Universal Dual USB AC/DC Wall and Car Power Adapter Charger for All USB Powered Devices, iPhone, iPod, and iPad; at that time, it had no reviews at all. But, when I saw that Amazon itself was selling it, I decided to take a chance. (If it were no good, Amazon would take it back and they would even pay for the return shipping. But I have found that, in my experience, if Amazon itself sells it, it's good!)Well, while it is the first such "all-in-one" adapter I have bought, I can say that its claims are 100% accurate. This single compact adapter will work both in the home as well as in the car.Not only is it an "all-in-one" adapter, it also provides plenty of power to charge or power ANY device which requires a USB power supply. It has two USB outputs: one of 2.1 A and the other of 1.0 A.1.0 A is sufficient for most USB-powered devices but 2.1 A is necessary for some. This supplies both. I have used it with my Dell Streak 7 Wi-Fi Tablet using the 2.1 A outlet and, not only did it power the device, it also charged it up very fast, even while I was using the Streak on the internet.It also quickly charges my new SanDisk SDMX22-004G-A57B Sansa Clip Zip 4 GB, Blue using the 1.0 A outlet while it is operating too.I have not yet tried charging/powering two high-powered devices at the same time but, in the real world, I would never do that anyway (especially in a car which is where I'll be using it most of the time). I don't know, but I'd be willing to bet that it could power both the Dell Streak and the SanDisk Clip Zip at the same time. (Maybe some day I might try that just to see, but not right now.)As far as I am concerned, its performance is splendid and exactly as described. Its construction quality appears to be first-rate. It has an unobtrusive yet bright blue LED indicating that the unit is powered and is supplying power. Both its plugs fold conveniently into the body, making for a small unit to carry about (it easily fits into a pocket). In addition, I think its price is reasonable.So, in conclusion, I can say that I am very pleased and fully satisfied with this device. How pleased and satisfied? I just ordered three (3) more of them!Thank you for reading this. I hope it has been of some help to you.Lawrence H. Bulk

This Belkin USB 2.0 4-Port Ultra-Mini Hub (F5U407) is not perfect (what is?) but, especially at its price, it offers excellent performance and value.My situation is somewhat unique.I have an OPPO BDP-93 Universal Network 3D Blu-ray Disc Player which has two USB 2.0 ports, one on the front of the unit and one on the rear. The rear port is used primarily for connection of the Wi-fi antenna (powered via the USB port), necessary if you are, as I am, using Wi-fi for the Oppo's Internet connection. The front connection is primarily for external hard drives used when operating the Oppo as a media center (which is how I use the Oppo most of the time).But I wanted to plug a Western Digital My Book for Mac 1 TB USB 2.0 Desktop External Hard Drive which has its own AC power supply into the rear USB port and leave it there permanently along with the Wi-fi antenna (leaving the front port available for other drives) so I bought this little hub.With both items connected, the hub works perfectly and both of the devices function normally.Now in at least one previous review, I had read that USB 3.0 devices do not work with this hub. I own several Western Digital My Passport Essential SE 1 TB  USB 3.0 Portable External Hard Drive (Black); these units are powered by the USB port.I left my two previous devices connected and I added one of these USB 3.0 drives to the hub.It functioned perfectly; the hub displayed both of my hard drives and the Oppo remained connected to the Internet via the Wi-fi antenna. So, as is evident, two USB-powered devices (the antenna and the drive), along with the AC-powered drive were connected and all of them worked.And a USB 3.0 USB-powered device works perfectly through this hub, at least with my Blu-ray player.Naturally the speed of transfer is only that of USB 2.0; the Oppo's ports are only USB 2.0. But for music and HD video, USB 2.0 is all one needs.Then, just for fun, I connected a second WD My Passport Essential USB 3.0 drive (so I had four devices connected, two USB 2.0 and two USB 3.0, three USB-powered and one AC-powered). This second USB 3.0 drive was initially recognized too but, when I closed it and went back into the Oppo's menu, only the first WD My Passport (3.0) and the WD My Book (2.0) were shown.I turned the Oppo off and then on again and, as before, all three drives were shown but, again as before, when I closed one of the My Passports out, only the two other drives were displayed. (The antenna remained fully functional at all times, as did the AC-powered USB 2.0 drive.)It appears to me that I can connect three items to the Oppo, its Wi-fi antenna, a self-powered USB 2.0 drive, and a USB-powered USB 3.0 drive, and these all work perfectly, but I cannot reliably connect a fourth device (another USB 3.0 USB-powered drive).This is certainly not important for me at all, nor, can I imagine, for anyone else; I tried this just as an experiment (and note that I did not use the front USB port at all). I will be keeping the powered WD My Book (USB 2.0) permanently connected through this hub along with the Wi-fi antenna; when I wish to use one of my WD My Passport USB 3.0 drives, I'll just plug that one into the front USB port (as these are portable, I remove them from the port when they're not in use).I have seen some complaints about the longevity of this product. I cannot comment about this just now as I received mine only yesterday. But Belkin offers a "Lifetime Warranty" (though there were no details enclosed in my package). Of course, as it would cost almost as much to mail a defective hub back to Belkin as it would to just buy a new one, I'm pretty sure that few, if any, people will use the warranty.I must say that I have owned another hub (a different brand) for ten years now (it's so old that it's only USB 1.1) and it has always worked perfectly. So I am somewhat confident that this hub will last for a while too (hubs are, as computer accessories go, relatively simple affairs). Please take into account this hub's extremely low price: I'm going to order a couple more of them and even if one (or more) lasts only a year or two, I won't feel that I've been "taken."Please note again that I am not using this hub with a computer; I am using it with an Oppo BDP-93 so my situation may or may not apply to you. However I feel sure that my comments would apply when using this hub with any Blu-ray or DVD player which has a USB input.Thus I highly recommend this very inexpensive Belkin USB 2.0 hub. Thank you for reading this review and I hope it has been of some interest to you.

I bought this Seiko Women's SUP052 Two Tone Stainless Steel Analog with White Dial Watch for my wife for her birthday (which has not yet arrived). She had seen it in a major department store's advertisement and had shown it to me. But she had no idea that I would actually buy it for her.Of course, prior to purchasing it, I checked here on Amazon. (I ALWAYS do that before I buy ANYTHING!) I'm glad I did. Not only does Amazon offer this watch for MUCH less than that department store's 'sale' price, Amazon is now offering the watch themselves with free shipping (when I bought mine, receiving it on December 15, 2011, Amazon was selling it only through a 'partner' which nonetheless offered excellent service and an excellent price).As my wife does not yet know that I have bought the watch, I have kept it hidden from her. Since it is a solar watch, each day I put it on a windowsill (well out of her sight) so that I can keep the battery fully charged until I give it to her.I have had it for three weeks now - and it keeps perfect time. It has not gained or lost even one minute (there is no second hand). Seiko has always had a good reputation for reliability and this one certainly lives up to that reputation.I can highly recommend this wristwatch to any woman who likes its styling (and to any man who wants to surprise a woman in his life).Thank you for reading this and for considering my opinion.Lawrence H. Bulk==================================================================================================================================Update: February 1, 2012I gave the watch to my wife on her birthday. I had hidden it in our kitchen (in a place where she would never find it) and, the night before, I put out a birthday card for her. She always goes down to the kitchen before I do, and she saw the card, but no present. When I came down and wished her a Happy Birthday, she grumpily said, "Well I guess that's what I would expect from you - no present."I had kept the original major department store advertisement and just then I "accidentally" found it.I said to her, "Now why did I keep this?," showing her the advertisement which had several watches featured.She replied, "Because I liked one of the watches.""Which one?," I asked."I don't remember," she replied.I then asked, "Could it be THIS one?" as I pulled out the watch from its hiding place and opened its box.I won't tell you what happened next - but I WILL tell you that she was both VERY surprised and VERY pleased.By the way, the watch has STILL not gained nor lost even one minute!

This HDMI switch, 5 in, 1 out, with remote control; HDMI certified, Built-in Equalizer, Blue Jeans Cable brand is an excellent unit. It is very well-designed and very well-constructed. It has no on/off switch so it is always powered when plugged in to an AC outlet (I have mine plugged into an external switch so I can manually turn it on or off without unplugging it but I think that for most people this would be unnecessary).The Blue Jeans Cable Company is also excellent, packaging this switcher so beautifully that I can only compare it to the way fine jewelry is packaged.I attached my three (3) HDMI-equipped devices (two Blu-ray players and one Roku) to this switcher (it can accommodate five items) and plugged it into my LG HX350T 720p Front Projector - Black which has only one HDMI input and not only did this switcher recognize which unit was powered, it transmitted both picture and sound to the projector which in turn sent the sound to my amplifier/speakers.I first tried the unit while powering up only one unit at a time and the switcher worked automatically; when I powered up all three together, it was easy to use the included remote control to manually switch between them. (This was only a try-out; obviously most of the time I'll power up only one unit at a time.)Sources can also be changed manually via front panel controls so that use of the remote control is not mandatory.I highly recommend this little HDMI switcher to anyone who needs such an item. It is priced right, it is made right, and it works right. For what more could one ask?

Though it's certainly not the 'best' silent film ever made, WINGS, a World War I "war in the air" movie, is my personal favorite silent film. I have waited a VERY long time for the release of this wonderful new beautifully-tinted restoration - you can order it here: Wings [Blu-ray]. It is the best version ever released to the public and, most likely, the best version which will EVER be released to the public! (A DVD version, containing the same new restoration, is also being offered and it can be ordered here: Wings.) Until now, NO ONE (except someone old enough to have seen it in 1927-1929) has been able to view this film in essentially the manner intended by its creators.I believe that anyone and everyone who has purchased any home video discs for their personal enjoyment should buy this one too - and as soon as possible. This film truly demonstrates Hollywood at its best and shows clearly why Hollywood films matter so much to us. I think WINGS would be the cornerstone of any home movie library.The story is superb, the directing is superb, the acting is superb, and the aerial scenes - well, they are BY FAR the best and most exciting ever done in the entire history of the movies and they are the best that ever WILL be done. They have never been duplicated nor will they ever be. Why do I make such definitive statements about the flying sequences? Because the flying sequences in WINGS are all real - repeat: ALL REAL! And they sure look it! NO "trickery" can duplicate "real!" Please see below for further details.I first saw the film in 1969 at the George Eastman House in Rochester, NY during the fifth Cinecon (Cinecon is still going strong). We were told that this was the first public showing of the complete film in almost forty years (clips have been used in other Paramount Films, most notably during the beginning of The War of the Worlds (Special Collector's Edition)).Two years later, WINGS was shown at the Paramount Theater in New York City. I still have the original LIFE Magazine review of that showing. (The lines to get in went around the block!)In 1985 Paramount released a LaserDisc edition as well as a VHS tape. Until now, these two versions were the only officially authorized home video releases of WINGS, at least in the U.S.A. These editions featured a beautiful organ score newly composed by that master of silent film accompaniment, the late, great Gaylord Carter. Though originally WINGS was shown in tinted prints, this LaserDisc edition was in black-and-white only and, like all prints I had seen until now, it was made from the print which survived in the Cinmathque Franaise.In 2002-3, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences ("AMPAS") had a retrospective of all Best Picture winners up to that time. The program began with the second winner THE BROADWAY MELODY. AMPAS saved WINGS for last; it was shown two nights - May 15 and May 16, 2003. The Samuel Goldwyn Theater (cap. 1012) was sold out both nights. I know. My wife and I were there, having flown to Los Angeles especially for this showing - and we attended BOTH nights! (Note: WINGS did not actually win for Best Picture; that category was not instituted by the Academy until several years later. SUNRISE won for Best Artistic Achievement; WINGS won for Best Production.)This showing was of what was called a 'partially-restored' print; some tinting was in evidence, but not as much as that for which I had hoped. However it was the first time I had ever seen the film with any of its tints present. (None of the Handschiegl color process effects - see below - had been restored at that time.) This print too was derived from that Cinmathque Franaise print and was essentially a fifth-generation print. However, the music (and the recreated 1927 sound effects) played, with a live orchestra, was the original music which had been used at the first showings of the film. Gillian Anderson, a wonderful musicologist, had recreated the score (which had been arranged by J. S. Zamecnik, using some fairly well-known classical and popular music) and she conducted the orchestra. I had not thought that anything could match Gaylord Carter's score, but this one did, at least in my opinion. (Adrian Johnston had recreated the sound effects; they were so good that it was possible to distinguish the German airplane engines from the 'American' ones.)Recently, on September 6, 2011, the AMPAS had a special program featuring the newly-restored COLOR print of Georges Mlis' A TRIP TO THE MOON (1902). What a fantastic restoration!! (I am anxiously awaiting the release of this movie on home video; it has been announced by Flicker Alley - I have already ordered a copy - for release sometime in March 2012 [Amazon is now offering it here: A Trip to the Moon Restored [Blu-ray]). You can see a couple of very short clips from this new restoration in the movie "Hugo" [see it in 3D if possible].) My wife and I attended that program and, afterwards, I had the opportunity to speak with Mr. Tom Burton, head of the preservation department at Technicolor Los Angeles, who had been in charge of that color restoration project. He told me about the forthcoming release of this new Blu-ray (and DVD) edition of WINGS, of which he was also in charge.Mr. Burton told me that he and his team, working with the original tinting requirements (which miraculously survive in the Paramount library), would reproduce ALL of the original tints, including the Handschiegl color process effects (a stencil process used for machine-gun fire and flames from shot-down airplanes), and that this edition will look better than anything seen since WINGS' first release. He also told me (and these are his exact words) that I will be "blown away by the sound track."He was right! On both counts!The new Blu-ray and DVD will not feature Ms. Anderson's music reconstruction, however. J. S. Zamecnik's original 1927 score has been re-orchestrated and arranged by Dominik Hauser, another musicologist, along with some piano filler played by Frederick Hodges. In 1927, sound effects (machine guns, airplane engines, etc.) were performed behind the screen. Ben Burtt, a noted (and superb) sound engineer has recreated and augmented these effects for the new restoration.In addition, Gaylord Carter's score will be present on a second audio track (and this is very welcome). When one watches this track, note that the timings are different; this is due to the fact that this track begins immediately with the movie rather than, as on the first track, with the various Paramount logo montage (very beautiful, by the way) and does not include the intermission or the end restoration credits. As far as I can determine, you cannot switch between the audio tracks (at least on the Blu-ray); when you start Play, you must select one 'version' or the other.This film is being released as the first title in Paramount's 100th Anniversary retrospective and it is one of the 'crown jewels' in Paramount's oeuvre. Paramount has tried its best to ensure top quality for this restoration (Paramount claims the film has been restored frame-by-frame!) and, in my opinion, they have succeeded.I ordered my copy on November 15, 2011 immediately upon reading Paramount's press release (obviously sight unseen). This new edition, which I watched in its entirety last night [January 24, 2012] has been at least partially created from a duplicate negative, made from an original then-surviving nitrate print, back in the 1950s, an element not used previously (the original negative and all original nitrate prints are long-gone). In all versions I have seen prior to this one, certain scenes appear badly 'washed out' - this is due to fact that all of them have been derived from a print - and a print is NOT a negative (hence the best that can be derived from such a source is a fourth generation print, and that is if no additional work is done - not the case here). Most of these scenes have been at least somewhat corrected for this new restoration but in the scene near the end of the film where "Buddy" Rogers is reading a letter sent to Richard Arlen, there are open areas (where the building was evidently bombed out) in which you can see what's going on outside; this small portion of the scene is still badly 'washed out' and the out-of-the-building view only comes into sharp relief when the scene fades out. But that's the only truly noticeable 'washed out' scene and, as the 'washed-out' portion is only a small part of the background, it does not mar the actual scene in any way. (See below for two other unfortunate but "unfixable" flaws.)There is at least one 'cut' in all versions I have seen previously: I have been told that Clara Bow's topless scene has had several seconds removed. These frames supposedly exist (in the print owned by the Library of Congress and possibly some other sources). From what I can see in this new edition, the scene looks to be complete but I'll have to check further with some knowledgeable people. [See March 15, 2012 Update below.] (Not that it matters, but Clara Bow is extremely easy on the eyes! Though her role is relatively small [and, in reality, unimportant], she was cast in this film as box-office insurance. And, as in ALL of her films, her acting is superlative - there is no other word for it. Watch her eyes: they're with what she acted and, in my opinion, she was one of the very finest actresses ever to have made movies.)If you are unfamiliar with WINGS' plot, you could call it simple Hollywood Hokum - but, if it is, well, it's Hollywood Hokum at its very best, due to the superior and sincere acting of ALL of the cast, the magnificence of the cinematography, as well as the exemplary direction of William Wellman. [If you want to read a good book about this film and its director, I highly recommend The Man and His Wings: William A. Wellman and the Making of the First Best Picture written by William Wellman, Jr., his son (whom I had the great pleasure of meeting a couple of years ago).] Basically, the story is about two men in love with the same woman - but of course she loves only one of the men. Naturally there is another woman, the 'girl next door' in love with the man the first woman does not love - but he does not realize that he really loves her instead. When the United States enters WWI, both men join the Army Air Corps, the 'girl next door' joins the Women's Motor Corps, they're all sent 'over there' and --- well, I'll let you guess the rest.Spectacular - and I mean SPECTACULAR - aerial 'dogfight' scenes and some absolutely splendid direction and cinematography (including the first, to my knowledge, big 'moving-boom' scene ever done in the movies) make this a film not only memorable but eminently re-watchable (I myself have seen the film over 100 times - and that's no exaggeration!).When you see the two leading men, Charles "Buddy" Rogers and Richard Arlen, up in the air, they REALLY are up in the air! There are no - repeat NO - rear projection or other cinema 'tricks' being used. Both men learned to fly those planes (made of wood and fabric!) and they not only flew them (during their close-up scenes only, of course), they also had to turn on the battery-powered electric camera mounted on the airplane in front of them - and then they had to act while flying the plane! (Read their lips and you'll see some 'interesting' language!) They each logged about 100 flying hours during the making of this film.Most of the formation flying seen was done by U.S. Army pilots (the Army contributed vast amounts of men and matriel without which the film could not have been made).But the other pilots you see up with them in close-ups were Hollywood stunt pilots and they too were actually flying their planes during the filming (obviously!). All of the spectacular flying maneuvers were done by these men (the Army pilots could not have done them, nor were the Army pilots crazy enough to try!). These stunt pilots were some of the very best pilots who have ever lived. What they do in this movie is nothing short of amazing - and they too had to film their own close-up scenes while performing maneuvers which will literally make your jaw drop! For example, one stunt pilot sends his plane into a spiral dive, something which is particularly dangerous. And not only do you see this spiral dive in distant shots, you see it as he, playing "dead," is actually filming himself! There is no doubt about it - he is in a spiral dive! No one in his or her right mind would try this today in one of these old, unstable, and fragile biplanes - but THIS pilot did it for the film and you can see it!Do you think you'll see anything like this again in another movie? Put that thought right out of your head! This sort of thing has never been - and will never be - done again; insurance companies would NEVER allow it. But this is why the flying scenes in WINGS look absolutely real - they are!Frankly, WINGS is a terrific audience pleaser. It's an action/adventure movie which also appeals to women and it's a love story which also appeals to men. In over forty years of watching this film and showing it to many, many friends and acquaintances, I have met only one couple who did not enjoy it (they claim that they do not like 'older' films).This restoration is not 'perfect' - I think that there will never be a 'perfect' restoration of WINGS. Time and, I'm saddened to say, neglect have taken their toll. Essentially, what we are seeing here is a fifth generation print, like that which I saw in 2003. (It may even be further down the chain.) Thus there is an excessive amount of grain present which would have NEVER been seen in 1927, except possibly in the Magnascope sequence; Magnascope was a process in which the screen enlarged to four times its area - twice as wide and twice as high; it surely must have been something to see! Only a very few theaters could accommodate it (see below). This grain is very noticeable on the Blu-ray and I suspect that it will even be very noticeable on the DVD (I have not yet seen the DVD version). However, you will pay attention to it ONLY if you are critically looking for it. (Please note that, having seen this movie as many times as I have, I am quite familiar with it and, frankly, I WAS deliberately looking for flaws in the restoration so I could note them in this review. I can easily see the grain; now that you have been alerted, you may too if you choose to concentrate on it [it is very evident in some scenes, not so much in others, but it is always there] but I want to EMPHASIZE: it does NOT spoil the enjoyment. When you're watching the film for sheer pleasure, it will be easy to ignore.)Also, while there are some scenes filmed deliberately out-of-focus (some may think that's a flaw but it is not), there is at least one scene which looks slightly 'soft' - that is the scene in which El Brendel becomes nauseated and runs to an ambulance truck. I have never spotted this 'softness' before and it may be noticeable on the Blu-ray only because the Blu-ray is so sharp.As Tom Burton states in one of the supplements, we may never again see WINGS as it was on Day 1 in 1927.But this version is VERY close, probably as close as we'll get in any of our lifetimes: if you want an example, you need watch only from timing 00:38:00 to 00:50:45. This 12 minute sequence alone will clearly demonstrate the greatness of the film and the greatness of the restoration. By the way, the Magnascope sequence would have occurred at 00:41:34 to 00:42:25, less than one minute in length. (These timings are for the first video track which contains the new music score and sound effects. The timings are different on the track which contains Gaylord Carter's score.) You will see two intertitles ("On the high sea of heaven" and "The enemy!") which are one-fourth the normal size. These titles would have appeared normal size when shown with Magnascope. Unfortunately, that process will probably never be seen again. Even in the late '20s, only a very few theaters had the capability of accommodating it.The tinting, unlike that on some other prints I have seen on home video, is near perfect; the colors are not overblown and do not reduce sharpness in the image. They only enhance the viewing experience (as they did in 1927).And none - I repeat, NONE - of any visual flaws present (and they are all minor) spoils the enjoyment of the film, not even in the smallest way. Most people will not even notice them. Let me emphasize: any flaws present are ALL minor.As for the sound, it's spectacular. Is it authentic? Definitely not. Being that the sound effects in 1927 were performed "live" behind the screen, they would, of necessity, have been much more spare (as they were when I saw the film in 2003). And they certainly would not have been DTS stereo surround! However, we are not watching this film in 1927 - we are watching it today and Ben Burtt wanted to accommodate the sensibilities of today's audiences; I think he has succeeded admirably. Wait until you hear it (hopefully with the volume cranked up!). I also think that if they had had the capability back in 1927, those early sound engineers would have designed the sound similarly to the way Mr. Burtt has done. (As I mentioned, Tom Burton told be that I would be "blown away" by the soundtrack: I was!)The sound effects are used only on the first track; the second track, with Gaylord Carter's score, has just the organ music (and it sounds beautiful). So if for some reason the sound effects are not to your liking, you can always view the film with the organ score alone.The three supplements included on the Blu-ray (only one is included on the DVD and it turns out that that's a shame) are all very worthwhile and interesting (unlike most supplements on discs), though I wish someone had discussed the Magnascope process in some detail. Seeing A. C. Lyles in the supplements is always a particular joy for my wife and me. I wish the producers had allowed him to speak at greater length. He knows more about this film (and Paramount Pictures) than any other living person.Do I have any "druthers?" Yes. I wish Paramount had given this disc a deluxe packaging treatment (if you want to see great packaging for a Blu-ray/DVD edition, you need only look at certain of the Warner Home Video presentations). They should have made the DVD a 2-disc set so that they could have included all three of the supplements. Paramount does not even include a leaflet, much less a booklet, about the film and I think that such packaging (and printed information) should be standard for significant motion pictures such as this one released to home video. As this is the first disc in their 100th Anniversary Retrospective, I wish Paramount had designed a uniform type of packaging so that purchasers could buy a complete matched set. Wouldn't THAT have been something?I understand that Paramount, Amazon, and even Netflix seriously underestimated the demand for this film and they are now scrambling to replenish their stock. I'm not surprised; whenever WINGS has played anywhere, it's almost always a sell-out (as it was last week at the Academy, and as it was in 2003 - both nights - when my wife and I attended, and as it was in New York when we saw it a couple of years later).So, to sum up, I strongly recommend that ANYONE and EVERYONE who has even the slightest interest in movies (and who has the financial resources to do so) buy this disc - and buy it soon (either the Blu-ray or the DVD). You'll thank me for my recommendation. And at Amazon's price, I feel that it is truly a bargain.Thank you for reading my very lengthy comments. I apologize for the length but I hope that you found them to be somewhat interesting and I truly hope that everything I have written is accurate (if you find any errors of fact, please let me know in a comment).(As a personal aside, I wish that Sam Rubin had lived to see this restoration.)And if you do buy this new edition of Wings [Blu-ray] (or the DVD edition: Wings), I hope you enjoy the film as much as I do.==============================================================================================Update: March 15, 2012The following is just an FYI:As of this writing, my wife and I are attending the CINEFEST 32 in Liverpool, NY and I have spoken with some VERY knowledgeable people (including two people who were involved with preserving and restoring WINGS). These people have informed me that, as I suspected, this edition is NOT 'frame-complete.' Several seconds of Clara Bow's topless scene are not in this print nor are a couple of seconds of the male nudity. I understand that a Chinese "bootleg" DVD DOES have Clara Bow's entire nude scene but, of course, that DVD will not be of a restored print (and is B&W only, not the way this film should be seen).It's a pity that Paramount did not choose to make this restoration 'frame-complete' (I have been told several different reasons for the decision but I do not know which reason, if any, is correct).However, and it's a VERY BIG however, the fact is that these few seconds, which do not contribute to the story in any way, are missing do NOT - repeat DO NOT! - detract from the enjoyment of this film by adults and the fact that they are missing may make the film more appropriate for today's children.While I personally would have wished that EVERY FRAME shown in 1927 had been included, I continue to HIGHLY (as highly as possible) value this restoration and release and I STRONGLY recommend this Blu-ray or DVD to anyone and everyone.Thank you again for reading all of this and for considering my opinions.Lawrence H. Bulk

I am quite pleased with this little Kodak micro SD 4 GB Class 2 Flash Memory Card with SD Adapter KSDMI4GBPSBNAA, so much so that I just ordered a second one (it is my opinion that one should always carry a spare data card 'just in case').I use it in my Kodak Easyshare Touch M5370 16 MP Digital Camera with 5x Optical Zoom, HD Video Capture and 3.0-Inch Capacitive Touchscreen LCD (Blue) and it works perfectly. (I have had this camera, an excellent one by the way, for over a month and have used it extensively.)While the Micro-SD card is REALLY tiny in size (and one has to exercise care so that one does not break it or lose it), it is actually quite good. In this particular camera (16 MP), it can hold 749 pictures taken at the largest size (highest quality) or 29 minutes of 720p video (and much more time if taking video at VGA 640x480 resolution). I am amazed that something so small can hold so much.It comes with its own SD adapter so that it is easy and convenient to insert the card into the adapter and then insert the whole thing into computers which have a built-in SD slot (most of them do nowadays) to transfer the pictures.In fact, you can actually use this card in ANY camera which uses either 'regular' SD cards OR Micro SD cards. In the first case, if your camera uses 'regular' SD cards, you place the Micro SD card into the adapter and then insert the entire device into your camera and in the second case, if your camera uses Micro SD cards, you merely just use the Micro SD card itself. This makes for a very useful and versatile card and allows it to be used in ANY camera (or device) which uses any type of SD card.Thus there is nothing else necessary to buy and you can see that the low price for this entire device is comparable to other cards which may not include the adapter. This card is even supplied with a sturdy plastic case which holds both parts securely and conveniently.So for that particular Kodak camera I mentioned as well as for any other camera which takes a Micro SD card (or 'regular' SD cards), I give this one my highest recommendation.

In my opinion, this Epson WorkForce 845 Wireless Color Printer (C11CB92201) is a fantastic piece of equipment. It prints text documents beautifully - they're clear and sharp - and photographs look positively vibrant with accurate, vivid color.It prints FAST and it is very quiet. And you can load an entire ream of paper (500 sheets) into its two paper cassettes (250 per cassette). Or you could have, say, 4"x6" photo paper in one cassette and 8.5"x11" regular paper in the other. This is particularly convenient and is what I have done. That way, when printing, I can just "pick and choose" the cassette containing the paper to which I wish to print, there being no need to load and unload a cassette with the desired paper.It can also print two-sided and that feature works perfectly.We have an older Canon MP780 All-in-One which we have upstairs in our den. It's a very nice machine but it is not a wireless one. To print from a computer, we need to physically move the computer into the den and attach it, via USB cable, to this printer (which is, of course, an annoyance).Not so with this new wireless printer. My computer is downstairs (my wife's is in another room) and when I print via this unit, often by the time I get upstairs the document is ready. When I printed a photograph, I did get to the printer before the picture was complete, but it only took a few seconds more for completion. (And it prints FAR faster than does our Canon machine.)Well you might say, "So what? Lots of wireless printers do the same thing." And you'd be right. But, at least for me, here is the big difference:Like all printers, the Epson WorkForce 845 is compatible with the Microsoft Windows and Apple Mac computer operating systems. But we do not use either of those; we use Linux (currently I use Xubuntu and my wife uses Linux Mint). There is no mention of Linux in the Epson's documentation.After I ordered the printer from Amazon Vine (on Thursday, November 17, 2011), I went to the OpenPrinting Database which contains Linux drivers for every known compatible printer; I found the Epson WorkForce 845 listed there.I downloaded the driver and installed it to my computer. On Tuesday, November 22, the printer arrived. I unpacked it and set it up in our bedroom (I am keeping the Canon in our den for reasons I shall explain).But I'm afraid I was a bit intimidated about trying to set it up so I just left it there. The next day my wife was at the hair dresser's and I decided to try to configure the printer.Well, setting it up and connecting it to my network was as easy as could be. As soon as I started the configuration, the printer saw my network. All I had to do was to enter the Network Security Key and the toughest part about that was remembering my L...O...N...G network password to enter into the printer's database - but, once entered, the printer connected immediately. (The setup took me about ten minutes.)I then went downstairs and fired up my computer. I went into the Printing menu option, selected Add Printer, selected Network Printer, and there it was! I printed a Test Sheet and, before I could get upstairs, the sheet was printed and it was waiting for me! (The printer setup on my computer took less than two minutes!)In retrospect, I needn't have had any trepidations whatsoever!All that is why I am thrilled with this printer!Obviously, if you use Windows or Mac, you'll have no trouble setting it up. Complete and clear instructions are readily available (in the printed Quick Guide for Windows and online for Mac).But if you use Linux, you need have no fears. It sets up easily and works perfectly (and without reading any instructions at all!). Its touch screen interface is so intuitive that I'm certain that most people will have absolutely no difficulties in setting up and using this printer.Not only can you print from a computer, you can also print photographs directly from data cards (even Compact Flash ones) and you can even do some simple editing such as removing red-eye and/or cropping them via the nice-sized LCD screen (by the way, this is a touch screen LCD: you select the controls right on the LCD!). The LCD control panel tilts out easily if you prefer; this makes seeing the LCD much easier. And you ought to see the quality of the photographs! I had read that Epson printers make the very best quality (and longest-lasting) photos - and, while I can't comment on longevity, I CAN say that the pictures I printed are by far the best I've ever seen from a home printer!Plus you can also print from your Smart Phone or tablet computer (such as my Dell Streak 7 Wi-Fi Tablet. I went into the Android Marketplace and searched for Epson "apps." I found two; one is called EPSON Printer Finder and, when I installed it, not only did it immediately find this Epson printer, it also showed that there was a firmware update for it. I activated this update and ran into my bedroom where I keep the printer to see if anything was happening. Sure enough, the printer was upgrading itself (wirelessly, via the internet) and within a few minutes it was done - and everything went as smoothly as could be. The other "app" is called EPSON iPrint and is for the actual printing. Of course I downloaded and installed that one too and then printed a web page. It printed (two-sided, by the way, as I had configured) perfectly.I myself cannot use this machine as a FAX machine; its placement in our bedroom is too far away from the telephone connection. That's why I'm keeping our Canon; it is connected to our telephone line (though I do not FAX often - the last time I did was about a year ago).I copied a document with this new Epson machine and it came out looking just great. I have also scanned a photograph (you do NOT need to use a computer in order to scan; appropriate scanning software is incorporated into the unit and you can scan a photo directly to an inserted data card or to your computer via the front USB port). Not only does this all-in-one automatically crop the photo, it renders the colors very vibrantly. (There are selections for the type of document or photo and the quality desired in the machine's menu; these are amazingly easy to use.)But if you DO want to scan a document to your computer, well, it's as easy as can be. My computer's scanning program immediately recognized the machine and the document scanned perfectly.Is there one 'nit?' Of course! I wish this printer had a separate single-sheet paper feed as does our Canon. But that is the ONLY "druther" I have - and that is a VERY small 'nit.'I am totally pleased with this Epson model. The manufacturer is even thoughtful enough to pack the four necessary #127 ink cartridges in the package - and they are the high-capacity cartridges! No other printer I have ever purchased came with such high-capacity cartridges.Epson claims that its ink cartridges last much longer than those of competitors and that ink costs are much lower. At this time I cannot comment on this claim one way or the other but it seems to me that Epson's advertising claims appear to be less extravagant than some of its competitors (just my impression) so I believe them.I can't comment on the longevity of this unit; only with the passage of time will I be able to do that. But it is apparent that the printer is constructed with a great deal of integrity. Based on my initial impressions, I should think that this printer will last for a very long time.Obviously, I give this printer the highest recommendation possible and I thank you for reading this review.

My wife likes this Remington D3710 Ceramic Fast Finish Dual Fan Turbo Hair Dryer, 1875 Watts which we received a few days ago courtesy of Amazon Vine and it probably would be her hair dryer of choice were it not for the fact that she also owns this Remington Ac2015 Tstudio Salon Collection Pearl Ceramic Hair Dryer which she likes even better.The D3710 DOES seem to dry her hair a bit faster than the Ac2015 BUT - and this is important for her - she does not like the on/off switch on the new D3710.As a matter of fact, she detests the switch.She has baby-fine hair and she dries it in sections. She wraps a section around a brush, turns on the hair dryer, dries that section, and then turns off the dryer. She does this repeatedly until her hair is dried.This particular model has a three-position slider switch as opposed to the positive three-position "push-type" one on the Ac2015. She does not like slider switches at all; in her experience, such switches, used heavily, wear out quickly. (I tend to agree with her but we cannot - and should not - generalize, at least regarding this particular hair dryer.)She claims that this particular slider switch is awkward for her to use. She says that if someone were to dry their hair in one complete session (not turning the unit on and off continually), that person would probably be completely satisfied.But in her case, she finds this switch to be annoying, hence the deduction of one star. (You may feel totally differently.)So even though this one is slightly faster than the older one, it is the older Ac2015 to which she will be returning. She'll keep this D3710 as a spare.Please consider that her situation may be unique, not comparable to yours.As for the construction and quality of this hair dryer, she says it is first-rate. She also says that she is now a "Remington Hair Dryer Girl," having had nothing but positive experiences with this brand and nothing but disappointment with all other brands she has used previously. She has been using her Ac2015 for over a year now (on a daily basis - she even took it with her on our latest cross-country trip) and it has proven to be totally reliable. I should think that this newer model will be at least as reliable.With the caveat she mentions, she (and I) give this hair dryer a good recommendation.Thank you for reading this. I hope it has been of some help to you.

1:25 Mins==========IMPORTANT UPDATE February 9, 2012: It has just been announced that Kodak is exiting the digital camera business. Please see Comment #7 for further details. Nonetheless, because it is so good, I still highly recommend buying this camera.==========I am very pleased with this little Kodak Easyshare Touch M5370 Digital Camera (Blue) and I am certain than anyone buying one will be just as pleased.Ease of use is very important, in my opinion, in small cameras such as this which are meant for snapshots, both candid and posed. When taking such pictures, the user often does not have the time nor the inclination to play with camera settings. He or she just wants to turn the camera on and take the pictures (or videos) quickly - and have them turn out perfectly.That's what you will achieve with this camera 99% of the time - and that with just using the Smart Capture mode.Turning on is almost instantaneous and turning off is equally quick.You can see from my video that the camera adjusts to scenes with different light levels quickly and unobtrusively. Focus is automatic (of course) and very quick. (When taking video, sound is recorded even when zooming.)Not only do videos turn out perfectly, so do still pictures - and without any extraneous input from the photographer.Just turn it on and fire away.Of course this camera is primarily intended for stills. (I do not know of any way to add a still picture to this review; that's why I attached a video taken with the camera. At least you can see the quality of the images it produces.)(Regarding video, I might mention that, contrary to the printed instruction manual which shows an option of video at 1920 x 1080, and contrary to at least one review here which states that the camera takes 1080p video, it does NOT take video at this level. It has but two options: 720p and VGA video. With a 4 GB Micro-SDHC card, this translates to 29 minutes at 720p and 2 and a half hours at VGA level. My video was taken at 720p.)I very much like the touchscreen controls and I have to admit that I was somewhat apprehensive about them. I needn't have been. They are as easy to use as is possible and, as I indicated, you do not actually have to use them if you don't want to. Your pictures will almost always turn out just the way you want them.The colors produced are vivid and beautiful (as you can see in the video, taken on a Fall afternoon around 3:30 PM). Different color types are available and easily accessed for those who wish to modify the look of pictures; even black-and-white and sepia tone are offered.For those who are more advanced, there are options offered in-camera to crop a picture, adjust its color, and several other things besides. (I have not as yet used these options.) Videos, likewise, can be edited in-camera. These options are really nice to have and can prove very useful to many people. In other words, you can improve your photographic results without the need to buy expensive computer programs and your photographic knowledge can improve without outgrowing the camera.There are also several other settings, including a Program (programmable) setting, for those who wish to exercise more control of their pictures. This Program setting too is extremely easy to use.I REALLY like the facial-recognition feature and the ability to automatically (or manually) 'tag' pictures with the names of people. Not only does this feature allow identification of people when viewing the pictures on the camera's screen, the tags carry over when you download the pictures onto your computer. (I use a Linux viewing program called Gwenview and, when I view a picture tagged via this camera, the name(s) of the people are clearly displayed. I am sure that other image viewing programs available for Windows and Mac will do the same thing.)Now to the nitty-gritty. This camera has a Schneider-KREUZNACH lens which appears to be of good quality (this company has always had a good reputation). It features an optical zoom ratio of 5:1 (equivalent to a 28-140 mm lens on a 35 mm camera) which is adequate for most people and will not require the use of a tripod (as do lenses of large zoom ratios). By the way, if you do use a tripod, you will find that a tripod mount will not interfere with battery/Micro-SD card access.The lens is somewhat slow (f 3.9 - 5.7) which is about the norm for cameras of this class. It is unfortunate that it is not somewhat faster (allowing more light to be registered). With such a small camera and with so many mega-pixels (16) crowded into a tiny sensor, "noise" ("grain" in film image terminology) is inevitable under low-light conditions when pictures are taken without flash. While this "noise" is not inordinately obtrusive under normal household illumination, critical viewers will easily be able to spot it.The camera does have several flash options, all easily accessible from the main screen (even in Smart Capture mode); you can set the flash to Auto Flash, Always-on Flash (for use outdoors when you want fill-in flash), Auto-Red-Eye removal (pre-fires a small flash so the subject's pupils contract somewhat), or No Flash at all. (Even with Smart Capture, there are certain things that you yourself will have to "tell" the camera what you want.) Using flash will alleviate any "noise" problem indoors under low light.While the camera does have a small capacity built-in memory, you will definitely want to buy an optional Micro-SDHC card. I bought this Kodak micro SD 4 GB Class 2 Flash Memory Card with SD Adapter KSDMI4GBPSBNAA. This one is inexpensive and comes complete with an SD adapter, necessary to use to insert the card into most computers which have card readers. (I do not know why Kodak chose to use the Micro SD format which is much less widely used than the "plain" SD format; we have a Fujifilm FinePix T300 14 MP Digital Camera with Fujinon 10x Wide Angle Optical Zoom Lens (Black) which is just about the same size as this Kodak and it uses a normal SD card. The Micro-SD size is awfully small, especially for my fingers. But there it is.) 4 GB offers 749 pictures at the maximum quality (much more at lesser quality). That's a lot of pictures!I also bought this Kodak 1972736 Hard Camera Case (Black) from Amazon. (Right now it is selling for $2.99! Other colors are available but they cost $12.99. So I "settled" for black!) It is a very nice case offering good protection. It also has room for an extra Micro-SDHC card as well as a spare battery or two.Regarding spare batteries and external chargers: do NOT buy Kodak's offerings. They are too costly. Buy this 2Pcs Battery+Charger for Fuji NP-45 NP-45A instead. Not only do you get an external charger, you get not one but TWO spare batteries. PLEASE NOTE: The NP-45 battery is exactly the same as the Kodak Rechargeable Li-Ion Battery KLIC-7006 used in the camera. Just compare the prices for their battery and their charger.To protect the LCD screen I strongly recommend this 3x Kodak Easyshare M5370 Camera Premium Invisible Clear LCD Screen Protector Cover Guard Shield Protective Film Kit (3 Pieces). It is very inexpensive, it fits perfectly, and it is easy to apply. Plus, in the package, you get three shields; you can use the other two for any other appropriately-sized product you may have.As I use a variant of the Linux computer operating system and Kodak does not support this, I cannot comment on photo sharing. Frankly, I have no interest in that (I do not belong to Facebook, Twitter, or any other social network) but, knowing Kodak, I am sure that their sharing function works well and is easy to use. I'll refer you to other reviews here which may comment about this feature in much greater detail.To sum up, I like this little camera very much. The pictures produced by it are exemplary. No one need ever be embarrassed by their quality. The same applies to the video produced by it. I plan to carry it wherever I go; I have always wanted to do this (there have been several times when I wished I had a camera along when I saw something which would make a nice photo) but, until now, I did not have the means for doing so. (I do not have a "smart" cell phone and, in any case, most of the pictures I have seen produced with such cameras do not match the quality of a dedicated camera, at least in my opinion.) So this one will be with me always. It will not replace my "main" camera (a much more sophisticated model) but being so small and of such high quality, it may be available when my "main" one is not.Obviously I give it a very high recommendation. I thank you for reading this, for watching my video, and for considering my opinions.==========Update: December 6, 2011Courtesy of Amazon Vine, I now own both this  Fujifilm FinePix T300 14 MP Digital Camera with Fujinon 10x Wide Angle Optical Zoom Lens (Black) and this Kodak Easyshare Touch M5370 16 MP Digital Camera with 5x Optical Zoom, HD Video Capture and 3.0-Inch Capacitive Touchscreen LCD (Blue).The Fujifilm camera has many more possible adjustments than does the Kodak plus it has a 10:1 zoom lens as opposed to the Kodak's 5:1 lens but the Kodak is much the easier of the two to use.I have taken some pictures back-to-back with both and, at least in my opinion, pictures taken with both are nearly identical in quality.Since the Kodak is the easier to use, I have given it to my wife and I myself will use the Fujifilm model.But either would make a fine choice and I am very pleased with both of them.

This StarTech.com VGA2HDMIPRO Professional VGA to HDMI Audio Video Converter with Scaler is an expensive item but, at least in my and my wife's opinion, it is worth every penny.Last year we drove cross-country and visited relatives and friends. We had lots of home videos we wanted to show them but, as we had no means for playing our videos (stored on our netbook computer) on their televisions, all of us had to crowd around a 10-inch netbook screen.This unit to the rescue! I bought it several months ago and, due to inertia (there is no other word), I did not even try it until we arrived at a relative's house (more than half-way across the country) on our second cross-country driving trip.To make a long story short, hooking it up was as easy as could be (most necessary cables are packed with the unit but you will have to buy separately an AmazonBasics High-Speed HDMI Cable (6.5 Feet/2.0 Meters) - Supports Ethernet, 3D, and Audio Return [Newest Standard] or similar which I had done).Operating it is the proverbial piece of cake. Plug it into an AC outlet, attach the outputs from your computer (VGA and audio) to the inputs of this scaler, and finally attach whatever output(s) from the scaler you will use to your television set (in most cases, that will be only an HDMI cable). Menu options are straightforward and easy to adjust.The picture AND sound are carried over the HDMI cable; most newer televisions will support this (all of the ones with HDMI inputs we tried did) but, if the set accepts only the video via HDMI, you can use a TOSLINK (optical) digital sound output or a standard analog 3.5mm output.The picture and sound quality produced were positively first-rate. Believe me, NO ONE will find any cause for complaint! (Picture and sound were perfectly in sync.)The unit is very small in size and it, and the necessary cables (VGA, Analog Audio, TOSLINK, HDMI) and power supply take up little room in your suitcase. (The power supply comes complete with adapters which would allow use in several foreign countries; we did not take these adapters with us.)In addition to playing our videos via this scaler at our friends' houses, we also used it on the road at hotels which had HDMI capability. As well as our home videos on the computer, we also brought along a Western Digital My Passport Essential SE 1 TB USB 3.0/2.0 Ultra Portable External Hard Drive (Black) onto which I had copied thirty or so feature films so we would have something to watch in our hotel rooms (if what their cable channels offered was of little interest to us). In all cases the scaler worked perfectly. (Some of the hotels in which we stayed [especially those on our way out west] still had older analog televisions; at these hotels, we used this PC To TV Video Converter which, contrary to some reviews, worked perfectly also though, of course, the picture was not anywhere nearly as sharp as it was as when we were able to use this digital scaler on a more modern TV.)As I stated, this unit is expensive. And, within a couple of years, it probably won't even be necessary. I anticipate that late in 2012 or at the latest 2013 almost all computers will offer HDMI outputs. At that point, we will be able to connect our computers to any modern television using just one HDMI cable alone.But of course you'd have to buy one of those new computers at that time. In the mean time, if you have need for playing computer video through an HDMI-equipped television set (or projector) with the computer you already have, this unit certainly fills the bill.I am very happy with my little scaler unit and I highly recommend it to anyone who has need for such a product.Thank you for reading my review and for considering my opinions.

My wife and I (especially my wife) are very pleased with this lightweight Hoover Sprint QuickVac Bagless Upright - UH20040.We own several vacuum cleaners; our main ones are Eureka THE BOSS SmartVac Model 4870 Type GZ of which we've owned two units for a couple of years now. They are excellent vacuum cleaners and work very well indeed. Maintenance on them is minimal. They are, however, very heavy and that is the reason we bought two of them: one is for downstairs and one is for upstairs. (They were highly rated in "Consumer Reports" and cost about half - $150.00 - of what other comparably highly-rated machines did at the time.)We also own a couple of lightweight 'stick' vacuums: a Eureka Lightweight Easy Clean Upright Vacuum Cleaner and a Bissell FeatherWeight Vacuum, Bagless, 3106B (my wife slightly prefers the Bissell to the Eureka). We use these for light touch-up vacuuming and they are excellent for that purpose.But this new Hoover model almost combines the best of both worlds: it is lightweight (of course not as lightweight as the 'sticks') yet comparable in performance to our 'heavy-weight' Eureka 4870s.It is so easy to put together right out of the box (no instructions are necessary for assembly) and its use is straightforward. It is helpful and desirable, of course, to read the owner's manual but figuring out this unit is almost (but not quite) a 'no-brainer.'There is only one tool included with this machine and that's all you'll need. It is a most ingenious tool, combining a crevice tool and an upholstery tool in one compact unit. It has to be seen to be believed.Everything snaps in place and the machine exudes an air of confidence and of high quality. It has an unusual carry handle which can be used when moving the machine (rather than carrying it awkwardly with the 'main' handle, as is the necessary case with most vacuums).Using it on stairs is very easy, almost as easy as using a cannister vacuum.The power cord has to be wound carefully onto its nesting place otherwise it won't fit properly. But that is easy to do. The power cord's length is adequate for our house, as long or longer than all the other vacuums we own.My wife especially likes the foot-operated on/off switch.On first use, she exclaimed that the suction was amazing. She said she could not believe it. After she finished vacuuming our entire upstairs with it, she asked me what it sold for. I replied that currently Amazon was charging $70.00 and it listed for $80.00. She then stated very firmly, "That's a bargain!"Obviously, with it being so new for us, I cannot comment at this time on its longevity or ease of maintenance. Should anything untoward develop, I shall report it here.But there is one comment I can make: at least one reviewer here states that, to access the belt, one must remove seven (7) screws. That is, in fact, what the owner's manual states.But, if you look at the bottom of the vacuum, you will see a little chart showing the location of just six (6) screws; that is all that really need be removed. (Not that that makes a whole lot of difference.) I do recommend that you do as we do: remove the screws and put them in an egg carton. That way you are sure not to lose any of them. You will need a moderately long and thin Phillips-head ("crosshead") screwdriver to remove the screws but this should be easy. Such screwdrivers are readily available (if you don't already have one) at any hardware store (or even a dollar-store). (I have not tried removing the screws: it 'ain't' broke so why should I fix it?)I cannot say, at this time, if this machine will replace our 'big' Eurekas as my wife's main vacuum cleaner, but, so far, she is really enamored of it. (She does most of the vacuuming and she is 'in charge' of what we buy and use in such machines.)As I said at the beginning of this review, both I and my wife are very pleased with this vacuum cleaner. It's offers heavy-duty suction without the 'heavy-duty price' or 'heavy-duty weight.' If you buy one, I believe you will be pleased too.Thank you for reading this review and for considering my opinions.==================================================================================================================================Update: November 11, 2011We've had this vacuum cleaner for a month now and, if anything, my wife likes it even more than when we first received it. Since it arrived, she has used our 'big' Eurekas only once, much preferring to use this Hoover model which she regards as being lighter in weight, easier to maneuver, and superior in deep cleaning our rugs.Plus she says that, of all the vacuum cleaners we have ever owned, bag or bagless, this is by far the easiest and most convenient to clean.And its price is 'right.'

I'm going to go out on a limb and say that, in my opinion, this AmazonBasics 32 GB Class 10 SDHC Flash Memory Card is by far the best value in a 32 GB SDHC flash memory card available on the market at the present time.I took the one I received and placed it in my Fujifilm FinePix T300 14 MP Digital Camera with Fujinon 10x Wide Angle Optical Zoom Lens (Black), formatted it, and "fired away." The pictures 'wrote' to the card VERY quickly and, while I do not have any means for comparing one card's write/read speed against another (as some reviewers here have done), it seems to me that the speed this card offers is MUCH more than adequate for 'ordinary' camera users, such as myself and my wife.(According to Fujifilm, this camera should use only Fuji's own cards or SanDisk's; no other brands are recommended because Fujifilm has not tested them. Nonetheless, this AmazonBasics card works perfectly.)Class 10 cards, which write much faster than Class 4 or 6 cards, are recommended when taking video. As this camera does take nice video, the use of this new card in the camera will be an advantage. Class 10 speed is, I believe, currently the fastest available speed in a flash memory card.But the main advantage of such a large card is, of course, its capacity: with our camera, the 4 GB SD card we had previously been using can take 573 pictures. This one can take 4576(!) pictures, almost 8 times as many. This, I think, is a real advantage for those who need to take a large number of pictures without transferring them to a computer (situations in which, for one reason or another, such transference is difficult or not possible).Some might say (and they might be correct) that one takes a great chance taking a large number of pictures and leaving them on a card only (without transferring them to a computer); if the card 'goes bad,' you could lose all your pictures.This might be a very real concern.Nonetheless, I think that the concern is mitigated by one essential fact: this card carries the AmazonBasics label. I do not know who makes this card for AmazonBasics, but, if it is like all the other products under that brand which I have purchased, it will be produced with the highest standards of quality. I admit I am prejudiced: I have been buying various products sold under the AmazonBasics label almost since the beginning of the introduction of that brand and I have never been even slightly disappointed with any of them. NEVER! Rather, I have been extremely pleased with the quality AND THE PRICE (consequently the value) of all of them.Which brings me to the price of this card: look at it. You could buy a competing 32 GB SDHC card for about the same money - but it would probably be a Class 4 card. To buy a 32 GB Class 10 card, you are looking at much more money than Amazon charges for this one. This one does not cost much more than 'quality' (name-brand) cards of much lower capacities.So, for the reasons I list above, I highly recommend this flash memory card and I urge anyone interested in such a card to carefully consider this one.I thank you for reading this review and I thank you for considering my opinions.

It's hard to believe that this 2Pcs Battery+Charger for Fuji NP-45 NP-45A is being sold for so little. Not only can it charge the battery from a standard AC wall socket, it can also charge it in your car with its included DC adapter cable.To add icing to the cake, it ships with two (2) NP-45 batteries.All for less than $9.00!What a fantastic bargain!Now my Fujifilm FinePix T300 14 MP Digital Camera with Fujinon 10x Wide Angle Optical Zoom Lens (Black) came with the NP-45A battery. (Note the 'A' suffix.)What is the difference between the two? I can't find anything of great significance. It MAY be that the 'A' version runs a bit longer than does the 'regular' version but this is hard to pin down.In any case, if you look at the price of the 'A' version of the battery, you will find that it alone costs MUCH more than does this charger with its two batteries!So why buy just a replacement battery when you can, for far less, get a charger with two batteries? Even if the 'regular' battery offers slightly less running time than the 'A' version, by buying this product you will have TWO spare batteries PLUS your original battery, three in all. Plus a home/car charger to boot!The charger's two-prong AC plug folds into the charger's case, thus saving a great deal of room (and making carrying it much less awkward than when plug prongs stick out).It is obviously constructed with a great deal of integrity. I have charged both of the NP-45 batteries with it and it functions perfectly. I have not yet tried charging the NP-45A which came with my camera (it is already fully charged) but I see no reason that this charger won't charge it as well as the standard AC-only charger Fujifilm supplied. (I have not yet tried using the NP-45 batteries in the camera but I can see no reason for any concerns. If there is any problem, I shall report it here.)The NP-45/NP-45A batteries are used in a number of other cameras besides Fujifilm ones; obviously this charger and its batteries can be used with ANY camera which uses either of the batteries.Thus it is my opinion that you just can't go wrong with this product. Buying it is almost a no-brainer.I bought mine from BestDealUSA, an Amazon partner. Their base price is a bit higher than some of the other dealers, but their ridiculously low shipping charge more than makes up for it.Their packaging was fine, the product was as advertised, and the shipping was quick (I ordered it on July 26 and it arrived today, July 29, 2011. You can't get much better than that!).For anyone who needs (or wants) a spare charger for the NP-45/NP-45A battery, both for home and car, I highly recommend this one (as well as BestDealUSA).

The book is very informative. There is a big section in the beginning about all the ingredients, how they interact with each other. There is a detailed description with illustrations of different techniques used for preparing dough, and also why the author likes making up recipes using ratios as opposed to other methods. In recipes, dry ingredients are measured by weight ounces, not volume. Unfortunately, the liquid ingredients are measured by liquid ounces, i.e. volume. I hate volume measurements - how accurate is it when you measure off honey? What about all the honey that gets stick to the cup? I do prefer putting a mixing bowl on the kitchen scale, and weigh everything while adding it to the mix, using Tare function on my scale. So, off to the calculator and conversion tables, again. More precise and less measuring cups to wash. Please, please, authors, write your recipes with weight measurements!Each basic dough recipe is described in detail, with why and how and what to expect and hand drawn illustrations if there is a need for those so reader has the right idea of how to proceed. Then for every basic dough there is a section with recipes using this dough, some savory, some sweet. The variety is great, and there are suggestions for recipe variations, too. For each of the basic dough recipes, author suggest on how to make the dough by hand or using mixer of food processor, if it is possible. The recipes accompanied by photos, which I love.The book is very well written, and is very informative.

The ring looks very nice, although the clear cubic zirconia sparkles more than the reddish ones. The red is more like reddish orange color. The workmanship looks good, too, nothing is out of alignment and no snags. Although it looks about the same inner size as my other size 7 rings (17.3 mm diameter as advertised), it is wider, and fits more snug than narrower band rings and it leaves two indentation tracks on the skin, too, because underside is not solid, but hollow, as you can see on the pictures. It is also thicker due to having crystals all around, and it tends to hit the joint on my pinkie finger, which makes it a little uncomfortable at times. So, maybe order larger size if you are unsure. I am glad it is rhodium plated, since it means less tarnishing.

Love the dishcloths. They are generous size enough for dishwashing but can be used for drying, too, for general cleaning and for other small jobs. The black and gray cloths are textured, which helps with light scrubbing. The printed ones are smooth, and they are white on the back side. I love microfiber cloths, they are very soft and absorbent. As much as I like the printed designs, the black cloths are my favorite in the set. I don't like kitchen cotton towels and dishcloths, using microfiber ones make for better cleaning, and feel better in my hands.

The eggplant and sage colors are not as bright as I was hoping, Eggplant is quite too light to be of a real eggplant, sage is almost gray. But the colors do not bleed in the wash. Both kinds of dishtowels are reasonably thick, at least as thick as all of my other microfiber towels. The fabric is very soft, and they absorb a lot of liquid. Good both for washing and for drying (not at the same time, obviously). They do snag on too dry skin, just as other microfiber towels. The edges are serged, and the serging shortens in wash. I can pull them back to shape so they will lay flat, but I do not bother, it is not that bad. I fold them in four and store in a drawer, I like to have a bunch for many different jobs around the kitchen and around the house, too.

The millet is not of the best kind, so it does not give the very best results, but it is relatively clean with no rocks. I cook it in a rice cooker on brown rice setting with extra water, and often add some milk halfway. Milk and longer cooking time makes it creamier, but not as creamy as other millet varietals produce. The texture is still a bit too rough even after all tricks I could come up with. Anyway, it seems to be the best millet I could reliably find in USA.We mostly use it as a side dish or in soups. Do not forget to wash it before cooking, or you get dirty foam on top. I like smaller packages that can be reclosed after you remove some millet for cooking.

It feels heavy and seems like it was made of metal, unlike many other tools that are metal-colored plastic. I choose the tool because there was a height adjustment, but it turned out to be totally useless - the range of adjustment is so small, you have to have extra-thick band for it to fit on its highest setting - they did skimp on the screw height - in goes only halfway through the thickness of the tool, so it was clear that it was shortened for economy, not because of the design requirements. Anyway, it worked fine to remove links from my watch band with no problems, after we cut a credit card in a few layers to fit the band. It took five layers!

Seems to be original Brother cartridge. Just a note, Brother printers tell you that the cartridges are empty way before they actually are, but it is fairly easy to reset the counter so they will print again, a lot. Look up your printer model instructions on the net. I knew my printer is lying when all four cartridges started flashing empty at the same time - no way they all got used up the same! Seemed as expiration date was included.

good value for a bag full of space ships. We did get couple of ships that were defective (missing features) but overall it was good. My son liked to play with the big bunch of ships, making the whole flotilla, and we also gave away a lot of the ships at his birthday party.

the robots are fun to make, although my 6 years old needed help with a few of them, when the tabs did not want to get into the slots. The cardstock is shiny on one side, and it is printed on both sides. The directions are printed on each card, so the cards can be given as party favors and people will know what to do with them.There is an app that supposed to work with the robots, but it is not. It is supposed to scan the front of the package and then the robots would be moving on screen. It does not recognize the package (it does recognize the sample page provided on the website) But even if you get the sample page it does not do anything fun.

The machine can make a nice milkshake out of softened ice cream and milk. It makes the good texture. It cannot handle any kind of ice and hard frozen ice cream. It is all made of plastic, the thing itself, the beater and the glass. The glass is small, so it only can make one drink at a time. There markings on the outside of the glass, which makes them quite useless for the job, it is more of a decoration. When I put chunks of ice cream in there, the whole thing was shaking like crazy, and the glass was actually bending with the chunk moving around. The good thing about this machine is that it is quiet, it is so much quieter than by blender.

The book seems to be geared toward people who heard that coding is a lucrative field, and want a piece for themselves, but have no slightest idea of what it actually is. The book starts with description what coding is about, how we meet it in real world, where to start. It even gets with some examples of coding and what and how to learn to be able to find a job - going to college or or self-teaching and about other opportunities to learn. There is a lot to learn from the book. It is written in easy to understand language, as usual with the dummies books.

The watch is quite large, but is not huge. The clear crystals sparkle gently. It looks beautiful now. The watch has synthetic sapphire window, and it is gold plated stainless steel. I wonder how long the plating will last. The dial window is flat, I like it very much since it reduces glare. The clasp is very secure, it is actually too tight right now, I have to use quite a lot of force to open it. I hope it loosens up a bit, but no too much, of course. I can remove the watch with only one side of the clasp open, but it is a bit loose on my wrist. The clasp is practically invisible on the band.The watch was set to the correct date and Pacific time. It was easy to set it to my time zone. The little peg has two positions - first one is for date and the second one for for time.The color is reddish gold, it is much redder than my red gold rings, almost looks like copper. Very rich color.

The labels are class 2 certified, which means that they tested unprinted, blank labels to see if they wash or peel off from exposure to chemicals or weather. But the printing on the labels may or may not stay under the conditions depending on the printer  and inks you use. They did test those labels with different printers and inks, and you can see the list on their website (it is on the product page in fine print), although the list is awfully short. But if you do use the printers, you will get your printings on labels that can withstand marine environment, too.The labels fell like they are made out of plastic, not paper. There are perforations on the back that let you tear the backing away exposing thin strip of the sticky label, so it is easy to start removing it from there. I liked this feature very much. The quality of the print is quite good, and the print stays on the label, although I did not try to immerse it in ocean water because of the lack thereof.I tried to use the avery website to load my own images so I can print them, but it never worked - the images would not load there, I even tried different browsers to no avail. I used the website before with no problems, so I am not sure what was the matter now. I ended up downloading the template and using Word.

The beverage is quite sweet and tastes very good. Much better list of ingredients than in traditional colas. Serving size is one bottle 10 oz, so it is not huge, which I like - we really do not need even more sugar in our diets.
