The cola contains Kola Nut extract, anything with a word "nut" puts me on high alert, so I did a research, and it is not actually a nut, but a seed, so it is not related to tree nuts and is not likely to cause a reaction in people with tree nut allergy. What a relief!The bottles are safely packed in cardboard box with dividers and extra space on all sides. The caps look like regular metal caps, but they say "twist off", but I was not strong enough to do that, so I used the usual opener. The glass bottle top does have threads for twisting. My teenager did not have any problem opening the bottles.

The shampoo smells nicely, and the smell is not strong at all, very gentle. It is whitish in color, so it is easy to see how much of it left in the carpet cleaner. I use Hoover cleaner, it has separate container for the detergent and it mixes it by itself. I did make my carpet cleaner. I am not sure how it is supposed to renew carpets. Mine is overdue to be renewed, it is over 10 years old, tan, including carpeted dining room, so it gets dirty very fast. While the carpet does look much cleaner now, it is still not perfect, probably nothing can make it new again. There does not seem to be any residue left after the carpet has dried.

There is lots of strategies on writing good resumes in the book. It is written in easy to understand language, and has a lot of advice. There is a lot of discussion on what to say in your resume, and what is better to be left out, and what to do in particularly difficult situations like looking for work after layoffs, after long work in the same place, after sickness and even after being in prison (hope we will not need this advice!) and many more. There is a huge section with examples of resumes that highlight the previous advice. Some of it is quite obvious, but it is nice to have everything in one place.Overall, it is great resource for writing resumes.

All three kinds of chocolate may contain almonds. It does not say anything about it on amazon product page, but it is written on each of the chocolate bars included.The set comes in a sturdy corrugated cardboard box, with three of each chocolates plus the wrappers and stickers. The wrappers do look quite nice, they are printed on high quality paper, with deep saturated colors. Each of them has a place to write the names. The wrappers are very well done. They even printed instructions on how to wrap on each of the wrappers (to be covered by wrapping paper, of course). They include silver colored round stickers to close the wrappers. It looks quite nice when done.The chocolates themselves are the usual Hershey's chocolates, exactly as you expect them to be. Not gourmet chocolate, but still quite good. Each bar is easy to open.Everything came well protected. It is cold outside now, so this particulate box did not have a chance to get warm and melt, but I know from previous experience that Amazon ships chocolate on ice in the Summer, so there is no worry over it coming damaged.Overall, it is a good way to give some small gifts for many occasions.

The stain remover works very well. I have carpeted dining room, and the color of the carpet is light tan, so I am always fighting stains. The rug doctor seem to do excellent job here. I usually use Pets and Kids stuff, but it does not always work. There were couple of old stains that the Rug Doctor completely erased. And they did not come up later, as it happens sometimes. The cleaner has nice fresh floral smell, not offensive at all. It is quick and easy to use on small spots.

The fit is OK. But they feel like a board - you can almost stand the pants without the child inside. They are very stiff, and the stiffness did not wash off yet. On the other hand, they are completely wrinkle free. So, they might be acceptable for a special occasion, but only if your child can stand the stiffness.

The instructions are inside of the bottle - remove them first! The bottle has removable screw neck. It screws into the bottle, and then the cap screws into it. Remove the neck, and you will be able to get the instructions out. I am not sure why did they do it, since the instructions are also printed on the outside packaging.Otherwise, the bottle is quite nice. It is painted black, I am not sure how long it will stay black, though. It does keep water cold for a long time - After filling halfway with ice and then filling with water up to the top - 24 hrs later the water was still quite cool. Now, this is not how I usually use water bottles, but I just had to test their claim. I am quite disappointed about the removable neck. The attached cap suggested ease of use and no lost parts, but the neck piece has to be removed for washing and instructions say to store it separately. I guess it is so germs will not grow in there. But it means that it does have a part that might get lost. Half of the reason to have attached cap is gone. That middle piece is also quite hard to unscrew. It does mean that when I unscrew the top, the neck piece stays put, though, so I do not have to worry about that.

Sorry to say, but at some point I had to force myself to finish the book. But now I am glad I did. The overall idea is interesting, though it was hard to follow the journalistic investigations about unfamiliar (to me) Italian politics, and especially since it involved endless (unfamiliar and hard to pronounce) names and places. I am pretty sure I missed a lot in the book because of lack of proper cultural background.Anyway, the characters work to produce a newspaper that is never going to be published, but their investigations seem to be real.  They are scared that they dig too deep and might unearth something dangerous. But will the world care?

The bed was easy to assemble. It is made up of two narrow beds that you connect, so it is easy to carry upstairs separately, after you get it out of the box. It took only a few minutes to unfold and secure each of the beds, and then connect them with two bolts. There are illustrated instructions for all the steps. They also include brackets for attaching a headboard. We did not use them, though. We did the assembly together, but I am sure I would be able to do it myself with no problems. Putting the heavy mattress on top by myself might be a problem, but it is not the bed's fault, right?  The bed frame has rounded corners, and the corners are covered with plastic shields so you will not bump into metal. It is hard to see on the picture, but the cover has a rubbery strips at the two ends for helping the bed stay in place. The white middle is made of unwoven fabric. The cover fits quite tight around the bed, it is velcroed to the corner shields, and it is the width of the spring box, probably to give it traditional appearance, so you do still see what is underneath the bed, and it is in the way if you want to store anything under the bed because it is so tight. Bed skirt, anyone?Even though the bed is kind of foldable, it does not move or squeak when you climb on it and feels as solid as the old frame plus spring box. No sounds and it feels solid. We put thick spring mattress on it plus memory foam mattress pad, and it works great. It will be harder to move around the room because it does not have any wheels, but seeing we only did it once in the last 10 years to make more room for the crib, it should not be a big problem. The bed can be disassembled as easily.There is a 10 year warranty card included (does not pay for shipping) for residential use, 1 year for rentalThere is not weight limit mentioned anywhere.

This is my first Chromebook, and I wasn't sure what it is and how it works. Basically, it has Chrome OS instead of Windows, and you are supposed to do most of the things online. It does not work with usual Windows programs like Office and Photoshop or Firefox, but they do have their own google apps that do most of the things that you would expect, so it should be OK for many people if you only browse internet, check gmail and watch movies. But really, it does not allow any outside programs. Everything is done from Chrome browser, so you can see for yourself what can be done and how it works before buying a Chromebook by using Chrome browser, pretending it is the only thing installed on your computer, and seeing if it is enough for what you need. Maybe not installing a whole bunch of programs is a good thing - think about Windows running fast on a new computer, and slowing down after you load a bunch of software on it.The screen is nice and bright. The keyboard has lights all around keys, they do not shine through letters, but somehow the white letters are clearly seen in the dark. I really miss touchscreen here, but I was pleasantly surprised by the touchpad. It can move the pointer quite fast, and all the gestures with one, two or three finger touches make my life so much easier. Because it is not Windows computer, some of the control work differently, so they included a cheat sheet with shortcuts and useful tips, plus when you start the computer for the first time, there is a tour to learn the tricks. YOu can get to the tour later by clicking on question mark in the lower right corner. The keyboard is a bit different, too - no Windows button, obviously, no CapsLock button - yay. The power button located right next to backspace. It is the second laptop that has this "feature" and I just hate it when they do that. At least it does not turn off the computer - to do that you need to hold the button for a while. No F1-F12 buttons, too. No Print Screen, no Home, no End buttons, either. Bare minimum.The sound is good but not great. Loud enough for when you are close, but it is still too quiet for when you are not - I like to bring along a laptop with Netflix running when I am working on household tasks, and do have to bring a speaker with the laptop, the same as with my other laptop. It does sound a bit tinny when it is cranked all the way up.The laptop is quite lightweight for the size, and feels nice to the touch. Top is metal, but bottom is plastic, both textured (stickers will not stick), the touchpad feels textured, too. It gets hot quite soon - about an hour of netflix, and it is too hot to touch. They do have warnings about not touching it for a long periods of time, and using insulation if you plan keeping it on your lap.To sign in, you have to type gmail password. I hate it - mine is long and random to protect my information, and it is a pain to type it. Yes, I learned it by heart now, and you will, too. There is an option to sign in using your android phone - it is unlocked if your phone is unlocked and is within 100 ft. I did sign up for that, but I am not sure I like it - if you leave it on your desk, go to another room and start using your phone, people can get to your laptop and do whatever they want with it, so I would not leave this feature on if I did not trust people near me. It is easy to turn the feature off - go to settings in the lower right corner of your screen, and click on advanced settings on the bottom of the page - look for Smart Lock. You also need to have bluetooth turned on on both devices - another battery drain.Overall, if you do not need anything outside what Chrome can do, it is quite good, fast and nice machine. If you want freedom to use whatever programs you want, choose something else, or prepare to install another OS. This is what I will probably end up doing. I am giving it 4 stars for what it can and cannot do for being a Chromebook, without comparing it to Windows/whatever.

The cream works very well on moderately dry skin, helps make my hands feel soft and supple. It does have a smell, but it is not too strong to make me stop using it. It is not a cure for very dry skin, though. I have a patch of skin on my elbow that is very bad - flaking and cracking all the time, and the cream did not really do anything there.The cream absorbs well in the skin, and does not leave any unpleasant residue.

The elastic bandage is as comfortable as it can be - it is quite soft and squishy but can maintain its structure and shape during wear. I was a bit confused about how the clip would work from the description, but it was easy to figure out once it was in y hand. Basically, you wrap your leg or whatever place you wish to wrap, then attach the clip to the end and then stick the large velcro pad on the clip to the bandage. It lays flat and stays on without moving. Very easy. When you are done, roll the bandage and apply clip to hold the bandage rolled. Keeping it rolled also helps with wrinkles that appear during use.

I only owned the phone for a few days, and I like it very much so far. The screen is awesome, very bright and sharp. It makes great pictures, although I was surprised to find out that you do not need to unlock the phone to take pictures. I see possibility of pranks and unauthorized picture taking. The phone works so fast compared to my old not so smart smartphone, it is amazing how things are changing. The phone is lightweight, charges fast, and the battery last for quite long time. I signed up for MetroPCS, my main complaint is that I had to go the store to activate the phone. They would not accept the phone online (they only list ancient phones in their bring your own page, probably to discourage people from buying phones from other places). Do not buy sim card from the store - online and at Walmart it is $10, the MetroPCS guy wanted $25 for the card.

The 8 oz jar is huge. It is supposed to last long, as you only need a little bit each time, so they had to add a whole bunch of chemicals to keep it stable for long time, even after opening. The main ingredient after water is propylene glycol, and the next one is coconut oil, and then the list goes on with glyceryl stearate, mineral oil, stearic acid, cetyl esters,propylene glycol (again?) and a while bunch of other parabens and such. It has vitamin E, too. It says not to use on red or irritated skin, which effectively excluded the use on my face since I have rosacea. I used it on my hands. I didn't get any side effects there. It is a bit hard to spread over the skin, but then it mostly absorbs easily. I would not call it lightweight formula for sure, it is too viscous and feels greasy to the touch. It does make skin softer right away. My jar looks quite different from the one on the product page, but it is the same brand Vitamin World, and the list of ingredients is the same, too.

The book is very interesting, because it is not only about the recipes (which are good, too), but also about science of preparing meat. It describes in detail what chemical and physical processes happen after an animal was killed, and how to take advantage of it - how to treat each kind of animal to make sure it will yield the best results. Then, there is a big section for each kind of game - birds and animals, with pictures, short description on habitat, looks, what it eats and such. And then, of course, the recipes. There is a lot of different kinds, some only use basic ingredients, and some utilize more exotic and harder to find ones. Most of them quite easy, and then there are quite elaborate, too. Many of the recipes have full color beautiful pictures. At the end of the book, there is a section on marinades and sauces, and also a picture guide comparing different kinds of game, and some pictures on how to debone and cut the game, but those are quite tiny and do not have verbal description

I liked the book quite a lot. The language is smooth and easy to read. There is some science explaining how the future's space technology works, which sounds quite believable. There is an appendix at the end with notes on the science in the book, it was quite entertaining to read, too. And although I mostly enjoyed the story, I did not like the portrayal of Chinese as evil conniving beings that will rather kill than let Americans advance. Maybe I just want people to get along better in the future at last.There is a lot of action, especially towards the end. The good guys in the story a little bit too good, and the bad guys are a little bit too bad, but overall the book is quite interesting and enjoyable fast read.

This is really cute book. My six year old still likes lift the flap books and he was excited about this book. This book is not simply lift the flap - it is a paper action book - the tools can do their appropriate works. For example, a saw moves back and forth, and then you can move the cut piece away. Hammer hits the nail, and nail goes inside the wood piece. You move up a pencil and it marks the cut line.The pages are very thick, but they use a thinner card stock for the moving parts, so I do not think this book is very suitable for two year olds, as the amazon page suggests, they would simply tear the pieces apart in minutes. 4-6 year old is more appropriate age for this book, I think.

The paper itself is just regular run off the mill copy paper, it fits in the printer and works like any other, nothing to say about it. But the wrapper on the pack is just terrible and it asks for trouble. The huge paper stack is wrapped in one thin layer of paper. That is it. Not plastic, not laminated paper. The result - the wrapping paper is torn on all edges with paper exposed. My paper pack look even worse than the one of the other customer's pack - look at customer's pictures.. I am not returning it because I need the paper right now and cannot wait for reorder, but it is just not acceptable. I will think twice before ordering any hammermill products in the future.

This is a dense gray sponge with one side coated with scratchy coating. The coating feels like very fine sandpaper, and it works like it, too. I makes my sink shine with less effort than the usual scrub pads or magic eraser do. The coating is somewhat stiff, so if your sink has areas with fine pitting, like mine, it gets to look shiny with tiny darker dots in the most worn out areas - my sink is decades old..The scrubbing pad should not be used on appliances - those are polished and the finish will be destroyed.
I like the pasta's taste and texture. The shape is a tube, thicker than regular spaghetti. The taste is rich and creamy.My kids like this pasta, too.

I have Silhouette Cameo, I love the machine even though it is tricky to use sometimes. I was really curious what new possibilities will be open with the new Curio machine.First of all, it is not a replacement for Cameo, since it can only cut relatively small size materials, but Curio can cut much thicker materials (5 mm vs 8 mil, if I am not mistaken). The large size tray for Curio is going to be 8.5 by 12 inches, twice the size of the regular mat that comes with Curio. Even though the regular tray can be used for cutting 8.5 by 6 inches size designs, you can still insert letter size cardstock in it to make front of the card, for example, and leave the back intact. You do not have to cut the paper to put it through the cutter. It kind of makes up for small size.Curio cutting mat is rigid. With Silhouette I would peel of mat from the paper instead of paper from the mat, and this helped keep paper from curling, it is nearly impossible to do this trick with Curio. The mats along with the spacers attaches to the cutting tray, so it is entirely possible to remove the whole thing, make some adjustments, put it back in, and still cut in the same place, because the mat will be positioned exactly in the same place. That would be especially useful if you found some elements of design did not cut through, you can run it through the machine again and cut properly. That was impossible with Cameo. The mat and spacers attach to the machine with little clips, they do include some extra ones in the box. Hope they will be available for purchase, too, those are quite thin plastic, might break easily, but we will see.The cut and sketch features work on Curio about the same way as on Cameo, except now you need to also use spacers to compensate from media thickness. It cuts and sketches with the same precision as Cameo.Curio does not have the ratchet blade adjustment attached to the body of the machine unlike Cameo, which is a minor annoyance, but they made four tool holders on Curio, which I love. Another nice thing is due to the lack of desk space, I put Curio in front of Cameo, and Curio tray moves just above the Cameo's bed, so I can put them close to each other without fear that the Curio's cutting tray will hit the Cameo. Every inch counts, right?I love twin blade holders, it was fun to sketch a shape with a metallic gel pen and then cut the same shape, which made for the golden edges for the shape. It is much easier to to this with one go. The most important thing is not forget to mark the right tool holders for each step, or you will be getting cut instead of sketch, etc.The only other new thing I was able to try (the other do not have right accessories yet) is embossing. The machine comes with two embossing tips and embossing mat. You can use embossing mat for cutting, too, but it reduces its life. it means you can do cutting and embossing in one go so both your cutting and embossing will align. The bad news is that I was only able to emboss plain copy paper. 67 lb cardstock seems to be too thick for the machine and the images emboss very faintly and I cannot see almost anything on the other side. It has the same 210 gram cutting force, which is much lower than competitor's machines force. (http://smile.amazon.com/dp/B00O1YI3CI/ has 750 g cutting force, for example) I would not expect crispy embossing from Curio, unfortunately. I love doing hand embossing with a hand tool and metal stencils, and my hands always hurt after that, because it takes a lot of force to emboss crispy images on card stock, so I can see how lack of pressure might be problematic. Sorry, Silhouette, I am not going to buy your emboss and score paper for dollar a sheet.There is a score and emboss function, that is made to imitate the look of proper debossing by scoring (cutting very thin layer) and then debossing. It kind of looks like kind of debossing, because it does have sharp edge where the machine scored the paper, but it is still not perfect.That leaves us with yet unexplored stippling, etching and deep cutting, we will see how it works when the tools become available for purchase in a few weeks. Hope it will work, but I am not very optimistic because of the cutting pressure.The software for Curio is the same as for Cameo - Silhouette Studio. There is stippling and embossing parts in the software that will not work until you connect Curio. The software is quite powerful as it is (it is free on the website), or you can upgrade for more features and even purchase a plugin for Corel Draw, and now business edition available, too. I have Designers Edition, and I love all the possibilities, plus the ability to cut .svg files. Of course, the new machine meant new update for the software, and new bugs as well. The good news is that the customer service is answering questions very quickly via email, and there are forums and groups available throughout the net with all kinds of friendly advice and even free designs.Bottom line, for right now, before the etching and deep cut blade has become available, if I didn't have Silhouette, I would not go for Curio. I would have bought one of the more powerful machines, they cost less than Silhouette and Curio combined. If stippling, etching and deep cutting work as they should when they come out, and someone figures out the best settings to make embossing work for regular materials, than Curio might be the right choice in addition to Silhouette.

This is a simple toy. The pop gun is a bit confusing at first since there is no trigger in the trigger hole. It pops when you pull the barrel. The cork is made of foam and is attached to inside of the barrel, so it will not get lost, and you can pop it over and over again in a quick succession, almost like a machine gun.It is just the right size for my five year old. Lots of fun, and good protection from monsters that live under the bed.

The knife is quite sharp. It is easy to open and close. It locks open, but it does not lock closed. There is something that helps the blade to click closed, but there is no actual lock, so it is possible for a blade to come open when in the pocket if one of the cutouts gets snagged on something, although there is some resistance to help to prevent it. The blade sits there securely and feels quite solid. The knife looks beautiful, with satin finish. The clip is quite tight.

The color is mid-beige. It does even out the tone for the areas where I do not have much redness, but it does little for really red ares where my rosacea is most active. I usually get better results with green-tinted concealers for redness. This one also is quite dark, makes me look way too tanned. On the other hand, it does not seem to irritate my skin so far. It has nice consistency and goes on nicely. It is easy to spread over the skin, too.

This is well engineered printer. The set up is easy, except for having to type (long) wifi password using old  telephone-style input, where you have to press each button multiple times to scroll to the correct symbol. It connected to my wifi and printed the test page without any problems. The print quality is very good. I like how the whole thing is made - there are indentations on both sides so it is easy to carry the printer, loading cartridges with just one click (you can replace them one by one as needed), all the little details that you usually do not notice, but that make life easier.The printer can print 11x17 inches paper as well as A3 size, which is a little bit larger than 11x17. Both of the sizes can be borderless, too. The large size paper or any other media that you do not want to bend load from the back, and there are two trays in the front - one for regular paper, and the other one for photo paper. It takes 277 or 277XL ink cartridges (there are six of them). Make sure you have some space behind the printer for printing in large sizes. I have it on a rolling cart so the back is easy to reach, but I can move the whole thing away when not in use. The printer itself is large, too, but it is only one inch deeper and three inches wider than XP-820 printer that is for standard size prints. I expected for it to be larger. The 960 has a cable about one foot shorter than the 820 for some reason.The printer makes beautiful photos. I only used Epson brand papers so far, and always got great results. The photos look sharp and the colors are exactly as I wanted them to be.

I did not like the mask. The smell is nice, it is easy to apply. You are expected to wash it off in two minutes. My skin is very oily, and I have rosacea and I have great trouble finding anything that caters to both of the problems. Right now I am using Eucerin redness relief products, which are good for my rosacea, but my face is always too oily when I use those.Even though I washed my face with facial cleanser, the mask did not remove all the residual oil and I did not feel my skin becoming any smoother. I figured, it might need more time to become more effective, so I tried couple more times. but it did not get any better, but instead my rosacea flared up and I have redness and irritation all over my face. Looks like it is not something I would use in the future.

In the beginning of the book, there is a list of different vegetables and fruits and the best ways to prepare them for spiralizing, best settings, and how to treat them after, as well as size and weight references for each. Then there are four large chapters for gluten free, paleo, vegetarian or vegan, and raw food recipes. Each recipe takes a page or two, and they formatted it so you can see the whole recipe for two page recipes, you do not need to turn pages back and forth to read it, which is very good for busy cooks with flour on our hands. Only some of the recipes have pictures - full color and they are located in groups with no indications on the recipe pages themselves if there is a corresponding photo. Photos list the name of the dish and the page for the recipe, though.Many recipes were a big surprise for me, I would have never guessed you can combine those ingredients. Very intriguing. I mostly liked the combinations. I liked that there are some meat and chicken recipes, too, and many recipes look appealing to different tastes.

I got this book for my teenager since TI-84 is in his class requirements. There are instructions on how to use the calculator for any of the class assignments scattered inside of his textbooks, so it might be hard to find a specific piece of information. The book is a collection of all the techniques in one convenient place. The text is precise and easy to read, with screenshots for everything important. There is a nice reference section at the end, with SAT problems, skills list, and troubleshooting and error messages tables.

The dispenser looks like real wood, although it is plastic. I had to check twice, it is so like wood! They did wonderful job on the appearance. It is easy to unscrew the top, add water and oil and close it. The controls are a bit confusing, though. There is different color LED light inside, but in no way you can see it unless you look directly down from the top, so I am not sure why is it even here. It has light on the side that shows that the unit is on, and this light can be clearly seen. The oil diffuser works nicely, you can see thin stream of steam coming from the top, it looks beautiful. It diffuses essential oils with the steam, too, you will only need a few drops of oil in there for it to work. It is small size humidifier, and it will not work for large room, but it just perfect for sitting close to it and reading or doing needlework, or watching TV while enjoying nice smells.My main concern with the item is a safety - it is not UL listed, and there is no other safety certificate for it present anywhere on the unit. Granted, it itself is low voltage appliance, but you still plug it in the wall receptacle with 110V. Since there is no certificate shown, it is possible they might not have used correct materials for the job, but who knows. I would not leave it unattended for sure.I received the item for free.

I chose the shampoo because it says rosemary and mint on the bottle. Well, it does not smell like rosemary nor like mint. I am disappointed. It is OK as a shampoo, it lathers well, rinses well, and leaves the hair nice and clean. It does add some volume, too. My hair is oily, it cleans the hair well, but does not prevent hair from getting oily again.

I was using prescription Nasanex for quite some time, and switched to Nasacort recently per my doctor's advice. I am not taking it enough time to tell any difference in efficacy, but I like the spraying mechanism of Nasacort better, and it does not leave yucky aftertaste, unlike Nasonex. There is no fragrance added as with Flonase. No burning, too. SO far I like it much better.

This is a very nice reference. The pages are thick and laminated.For each application, there is a picture with numbers, and for each number there is reference code and short description, like the size or distance or what other key moments are there. There are room plans for different kinds of rooms, load calculations, formulas for Ohm's law, Voltage drops and power factor formula at the end. Tables for which cable or receptacle to use, schematics for different applications. Very concise guide with all the references to find more information. Great book is small enough to put in the tool box.

The cutter works well for cutting boxes. It is sharp as expected. The blades are removable and replaceable, but replacements are quite pricy at the moment. There are three positions for the blade - hidden inside, half retracted and fully retracted - it is the one pictured. When the blade is in the middle position, the thick housing obstructs view and it is hard to see the cutting area, which might lead to mistakes. I wish they made it more tapered so you could actually see what are you doing.

The surge protector has metal outer housing, the bottom that goes against the wall is plastic, as well as the outlets themselves, obviously. Metal is attached with screws to the base. On the back side, there are two holes for hanging the power strip to the wall, it only works vertically, but you can hang it with cord going up or down - your choice. It get confusing, though - there is warning on the under side saying "This power tap is not intended to be mounted on a desk or similar furnishing surface. Do not use with aquariums"The cord is thick and looks very sturdy. The cord length is about 3 ft - to reduce clutter choose the right length for your application.

The carver works, but to produce nice clean carved surface, your child will need to have some patience. It uses regular crayons that are sold everywhere - there is a paper stripper for regular size crayons as well as for the jumbo size. You put two caps on the crayon's ends and stick the crayon in the holder. Then you turn on the machine - the engraver end vibrates and carves the crayon while you move the handle part over the carving tiles. To produce clean image you will have to move over the tile several times. We put the carver on a large tray when kids are playing, so the crayon shavings would end up on the try and not on the carpet. They tried to make it as mess free as it can get with shavings collecting inside of the box, and raised edges, but some do find their way on the tray, too. There is exactly enough places to put the carving tiles on the machine. and you have to put them in the design space, too, if you want all of them attached. There are more tiles available for purchase, but there is no place to store them on the machine itself. All the other little attachments can be stored on the machine, too, which is just great.

The shampoo smells nicely, but the smell is very strong and it stays in your hair throughout the day. It lathers up nicely and seems to clean the hair as expected. The hair looks nice and healthy after drying. The bottle is large 22 oz, and lasts for a long time.

The curling iron is made of two parts that you are supposed to connect, and you can buy and connect different barrels. Unfortunately, mine broke when I was trying to connect the two pieces. The barrel part that goes inside cracked when I tried to lock it. Now there is a big crack along the part of the barrel that goes inside of the handle. It is all plastic in there, and apparently, it cracks way too easy. I called the company - they hung up after a few minutes of wait. I went online, and was able to write to them from there. It says I will receive a response within two business days, but they are still silent. To get warranty repair or replacement you need to have the serial number which is conveniently located on the outside of the box and nowhere else, so you can inadvertently throw it away and possibly be left without warranty. The website states that for warranty you have to have the silver sticker with the serial number still attached, they do not specify what is it supposed to be attached to, though. The website also states that if your product is going to be replaced under warranty, you should send it to them first (it does not say who will pay for it), and they will mail you another one withing three weeks.  I seriously dislike all this kinds of tricks.Aside from being broken now, the iron looks very attractive. The cable is long and swivels easily so it will not be tangled up with use. To exchange barrels, you most definitely have to wait until the one you were using cools down, which probably means you are not going to use two different barrels to make the same hairdo.

The iron heats up to the highest setting in just one minute. I gather it would be even faster for lower settings. The white outside is all plastic and so is the golden part. The cord is longer than usual, and it is really nice, I didn't realize how restrictive 6 ft cord feels until I tried the T3. The cord also swivels easily so I do not have to worry that it will tangle, and I do not have to fight with tangled up cord. The ceramic area is very smooth and it works perfectly, but it is on the smaller size, about 1 inch by 4 inches, so it is great for shorter hair, but it would be too little for longer hair that needs a lot of work.The iron looks very stylish. They include a heat proof mat, but it is quite small, and black, looks like it is made of dense felt. It looks OK on my very dark brown vanity, but it just not as pretty as the iron itself.I checked out the warranty on the iron, and they say for the warranty the iron has to be purchased from an authorized retailer, and it has to have a silver sticker with the serial number. The problem is that the sticker is located on the box, not on the iron itself, so if you throw the box away you might be in trouble if something goes wrong. It also looks like in case of warranty claim you will have to send the iron to them first before they will evaluate it and decide if they replace it, and it should take 3 weeks. I am not comfortable with this kind of customer care for such an expensive luxury product.

I like that the guide is organized by the grade, but it makes it somewhat repetitive. There is a wide variety of information, but it only has a few  sentences on each subject,so if you want to know more you will have to dig deeper. It is really small book, and the guide is very condensed. I wish they used less space on advertising themselves (what other students who's been there said and such) and gave more info on how things work. No real eye openers here, but still useful, especially to the young person. I liked the checklists for each stage, and a lot of references.

The capsules are quite big, but they feel slippery in my mouth and so they go down easy. The capsules are tasteless. I broke one of the capsules to see how it tastes inside, and it had a slight fishy taste, but not too bad. There is no aftertaste or burps, too. Keep in mind that you need to get 3 capsules for one dose, preferably with a meal.

The big colorful pieces are made of soft bendable plastic with rounded edges and dull colors. The white cube shaped pieces are made out of hard Lego-like plastic, and have sharp edges. They are cubes with five indentations in them, and one bump to connect to another cube. To add more ways to connect the cubes, they added two tiny connectors, less than half inch in size. Something tells me those would be lost in a flash, which will make it impossible to make some of the projects.The wheels do rotate, although not very well, but all the other rotating pieces hardly do - they do connect with round pieces, but the pieces fit so tightly they do not allow for easy movement. This greatly reduces the play with finished projects - who wants to play with helicopter if the rotors do not spin? The parts require quite an effort to connect with each other or to pull apart.Pieces can be stored in the box, but since they are so large, the finished and even half finished projects will not fit in there.The story in the book is not very inspiring, and does not make too much sense most of the time. The illustrations are the same quality as the artwork on the box, you be the judge. The suggested age is 3-6 years old, but the instructions have multiple pieces added in each step, which makes it highly unlikely for a three year old to be able to follow. Combined with hard to connect pieces it becomes a toy where a parent builds everything, and then kid plays with the result for a minute and walks away.The list price of $45 does seem to be high for this mediocre set. I guess they charge extra for using word "engineer". I bet if they added "STEM" they could have charged more.

When wet, the dishcloths are very soft and fluffy, and absorbs water very well. But they stain very easily, and since I do drink a lot of tea, the dishcloths became all spotted brown  in no time at all, and those stains stay. It takes forever to rinse off the soap from it, and it still stinks after it gets dry.Also, there is a paper sticker on the back of both dishcloths, and I didn't notice it at first, and wet it with the sticker on, and now the top of the paper washed off, and the stickiness stayed. The sticker came right off the other (dry) dishcloth with no residue, so make sure you do not repeat my mistake, and take it off right away.The size is just right, slightly large the the palm of my hand. The surface is soft (when wet) and is not scrubby.Overall, they are nice for light dishwashing, but they do look horrible after use, and feel stiff until they get wet again.

The shampoo has nice and fresh fruity smell. It lathers up nicely, and washes away easily, too. It leaves the hair squeaky clean. The hair looks shiny and feels soft. It does not seem to weigh the hair down. You only need a small amount of the shampoo, so the huge bottle will last for a long time. I like that there is no silicone in the shampoo. The ingredients list is quite short, but there is still some unpronounceable stuff on it.

The potting mix feels more like real soil than peat moss as it is often the case with potting soil. It drains well, but still can retain water for growth. I planted last year seeds with not much hope for them to take, but I got a nice germination and the plant grow nicely. I would not normally care if the potting mix for my flowers is organic or not, since we are not going to eat those, but I was pleasantly surprised by how my plants grow in there so far.

The beef jerky tastes differently from their regular kind of beef jerky, because it does not contain nitrites and other artificial preservatives and no MSG. Nitrites add distinct taste to cured meats. The texture is a bit different, too.Overall, I like it, although the texture is different from piece to piece, some of the pieces are a bit too stringy.

I received this mat nearly free for the purpose of this review.The mat is quite generous in size, and it is made of thin layer of silicone. It is limp and drapey. This mat is made for lining your work table when dealing with dough. It says right on the mat that it can withstand 230C (about 450F) so it is mostly safe to go in the oven, but it does not have rigid edges as other silicone mats designed specifically for the oven do. It is perfectly fine to line a cookie pan with it, though.The surface of the mat is a bit tacky, and it makes the mat to temporarily adhere to the table so it will not move while you are rolling the dough. I was able to stick it to the wall cabinet, and it stayed there for a few hours before it fell down, this is how sticky it it. On the other hand, the dough or other foods do not stick to it, so it is easy to clean. It rolls for storage, too.

The clamp adapter is convenient to use in hard to reach spaces for wires that are attached and possibly are live. It might be a bit bothersome to attach the flexible cable to the adapter if you have to do it many times in the row (insert and turn), but you can reach with it in very tight spaces and isolate and test one out of whole bunch of cables, and you can still see the readings on your handheld multimeter that you hold at your convenience thanks for long and flexible lead. Make sure your multimeter can accept banana plugs.

I gave this board game to my son for his birthday who just turned eight-years old.  It was the first thing he opened and immediately demanded to play it with grandpa (grandpa is always up for a good board game!).  After setting it up, grandpa and grandson were racing to find a path between a number and a symbol.Dominate is one of those very simple games that looks a lot more modern than it really is.  From a distance it looks a bit like Stratego, but its actually more like dominoes.  In essence, you roll two dice (one with a symbol, the other with a number), and then its up to players on each side (who cant see the others slides) to move the pieces around until theres a clear line between the number (1 through 6) and the symbols.The game looks complicated  the paths look like circuits!  but its actually pretty simple.  That doesnt make it easy by any stretch; shifting the tiles around can be frustrating, and my eight-year-old wasnt happy with it.  The challenge is that this is truly a head-to-head game thats timed, so its easy to get frustrated when playing against an adult.  It might be better to try to solve the puzzle in timed trials (vs. playing against another player) just to relieve some of the pressure.There's several randomizing factors at play.  For one, the placement of the tiles by each player is determined by the player -- smart players might try to make lines in the hopes they get lucky -- but the other randomizing factors largely cancel this out.  Then there's the dice, doubling the variance for the shape you need to connect to at one end and the number at the other.Additionally, there's the six shapes (titled "goal chips") themselves; the goal chips are also placed randomly at the beginning of the game.  When a player wins, he claims a goal chip.  This creates a bit of an issue with randomization as the game progresses, because you can roll a goal chip on the die that has already been won, in which case you need to roll again.  Not a big deal early in the game, but when there's just two goal chips left this means a lot of rerolling.Its a fun idea, but eight-year-olds might find it a bit frustrating at first and it seems to have limited replay value.

My son, who just turned eight, is a big fan of creating his own content  I blame Minecraft  and as a result frequently creates Minecraft comics.  His addiction to Minecraft and video games is considerable, so I suspect he considers creating comics a reasonable substitute when his screen time is limited.  Hes made several page comics on his own before, so this book was a natural next step for him.The kit comes with everything you need, including markers, a cover sheet, and 16 interior pages. Theres a form to ship it all off when youre ready (this may take a while) and advice on how to put it all together.Theres a pretty big age swing for this product (4 to 10 on Amazon, 4 to 8 in the description) and how your childs age will likely determine how they engage with it. The suggested steps to creating the book are a little basic (you mean you write down your ideas? AMAZING!), but thats likely for the younger kids.  On the other hand, my five-year-old daughter is still learning to read and write, so the graphics are more important than the lines on each page (six lines on one-third of each page). The only two completely blank pages are for the front and back.  Theres also the opportunity to include an About the Author section, complete with the kids picture.My son's response to the book was lukewarm. I recommended he and my daughter work together on it, but we'll see if we can get them to focus on it -- maybe dividing up the pages a little at a time with an overarching story where they fill in the blanks.This book reminds me a bit of those customized baseball cards featuring a picture of your child with relevant (often amusing) stats.  Or to put it another way, this is an adorable book as a giftfor someone else.  The thrill of seeing a published book is starting to wear off in this day and age of self-publishing, high-quality printing, and the constant stream of creativity my kids generate every week at school or camp. Relatives and family friends, on the other hand, will love having a snapshot in time from the kids.

Im a big fan of bagless vacuums. The Dyson we have changed our lives.  So when it was time to buy a vacuum for our basement/garage which is also my man cave and the kids playroom, we bought a cheap bagless vacuum.  It lasted a year. Simply put, any downstairs vacuum is on the front lines of a war against the dirty outside world (the garage door is frequently open). Enter the CH5040.This is a commercial vacuum, so its not out to impress anybody. The first thing you notice is its no-frills appearance; the second is that its basically a cloth bag on a tube. This is why the CH5040 is so light; its got very few solid components. The electronics are entirely located in the handle, which comes separately and you screw into the base.The CH5040 does two things: vacuum loudly and vacuum quietly.  This is a commercial vacuum meant to be used by a cleaning service who doesnt want to disturb the owners, but I find it useful to vacuum around my kids in the playroom who frequently complain about the noise. There wasnt a huge difference in suction power between the two modes, but presumably there has to be some loss of power in quiet mode or I assume Hoover would have just made it quiet all the time.I mentioned that its light and theres a good reason for that. Theres a handle on the back thats not just for hoisting the vacuum, but also lifting it horizontal so you can vacuum steps. You can try to do this with a typical vacuum but 1) they often dont lie nearly flat, 2) theyre way too heavy. I vacuumed the basement steps and this worked very well.There are a few issues with this vacuum holding it back from a full five stars though.  For one, it has a short cord and comes with an extension cord  presumably so that a cleaning person can use an extra-long cord if needed.  The problem is that this means the short plug sticking out of the vacuum frequently comes unplugged under significant pressure. I have several corded outdoor tools and they all come with a little loop to tie the cord so that this doesnt happen.  Its not a huge deal (you can just tie it in a knot, or tie it around the aforementioned handle), but its a design flaw that should have been accounted for.The other issue is that the on/off button is on the handle. Vigorous use virtually guarantees you will shut the CH5040 by accident once or twice. Ad this together with the cord coming loose and if you use this vacuum a lot it makes for a frustrating experience.Additionally, it doesnt have a wand, so this vacuum cant quite get everywhere (being light and liftable makes up for some of those places but not everywhere). And this is still a bagged vacuum, which means at some point you need to replace it.  But given the performance of the bagless vacuum before, Ill take my chances.

This graphic novel was written by the inimitable Craig Thompson, the multi-award winning artist and writer who churns out massive comic compilations and Space Dumplins is no different. Its a meaty tome filled with drama, adventure, and deep thoughts about our relationship with the environment  even if it happens to be a space environment that involves space logging and space whales.The main protagonist is Violet, a precocious girl whose life is turned upside-down when a space whale eats her school. All this eating causes an epidemic of whale diarrhea and vomit, which creates flooding in the space lanes and emergency evacuations.  Violet is caught between the dueling lifestyles of her lumberjack (spacejack?) father and her high fashion mother. Her parents have very real arguments about class and obligation that are surprisingly serious for a book suitable for all ages.When Violets dad disappears on a secret mission to deal with the space whales, she goes on an adventure to rescue him.  Along the way she enlists an evolved space chicken and an orange thing who claims he is the last of his race.  They form a Star Trek-like triumvirate of impetuous leadership, Spock-like logic, and hot-headed emotion. There are times when Thompson beats you over the head with precisely this point, and there are other times when Violet spouts philosophy that seems totally out of character for her. Also, the space chicken has biblical visions that seem to embrace astrology.Space Dumplins is an odd duck (or odd chicken, if you prefer).  Its gorgeously illustrated, with details that span multiple pages. Its chaotic, and occasionally so messy its not clear who is talking. It also ping pongs between heartfelt emotions and just being gross  I mean, who doesnt love graphic whale vivisection?In the end, this is a book about children reuniting with their parents, be it space whales, space chickens, space orange things, or space girls named Violet.  I read a chapter a night to my kids (it took a while) and they enjoyed it, but I have a few reservations about recommending it to everybody.

This is the beginning of vacation season for our family, so these packing cubes seemed like they might come in handy.  With a family of four, they ended up being a huge help.As you can imagine, packing one suitcase for two adults and two kids gets messy. We try to stay in suites, but this doesn't mitigate the fact that clothes get packed and unpacked inefficiently and sometimes just plain lost. These cubes are an excellent solution to the problem.They're durable, it's easy to see what's inside, and they're very lightweight.  My wife assigned a cube to each of us.  It provided a good limit to what we could put in the suitcase -- if it didn't fit in the cube, it didn't go with us! And with an easy handle and double zippers, it's easy to place and retrieve from luggage.Once we got there the real test began.  We tried to just place each cube in a drawer.  The depth was just a hair too much (to be fair, we really stuffed the cubes), but for a slightly deeper drawer it would work fine.  Then you basically live out of your cube. Alternately, you can use the cube for your dirty laundry and fill it up as your trip progresses.The cubes passed with flying colors, our clothes all stayed in their separate compartments, and nobody lost anything.  High marks for such a simple concept.

First things first: this is a pattern game. You set cards out in a 6 x 6 layout and then turn them over.  Get three different kinds of fish in a row (red, purple, and yellow, who are also all different sizes for easy identification) and you get to squish an opponent's fish.That brings up the second point that parents need to know: this is a Play-doh game. Oh, it's not "Play-doh" of course, it's "safe modeling fun dough," but the point being it's a clay modeling game.  That's the good news.  The bad news?  After making your beautiful fish creations, your kids will be smashing them all over the table.Each player gets barely enough clay to sculpt five fish, which sits on a flimsy piece of cardboard. This made a mess. Then whenever a kid gets three in a row, he or she gets to smash some other kid's fish.  This made them mad. Then we had to clean up the mess after the smashing and the inevitable complaining.  This made ME mad.On some visceral level it's fun to smash clay.  But not when it's someone else's clay, who may have spent five minutes putting it together.  The molds don't help -- the art makes it look like the fish are three-dimensional, but they're actually one-sided.  This makes sense; the only way you can efficiently crank out five fish quickly is by placing the clay under the mold and pressing down hard. These one-sided fish do not stand up well, so now you have to do additional sculpting to ensure they have a wide enough base. Mind you, this is work for clay fish that are doomed to be squished anyway.The more I test board games with my children from these board game companies I've never heard of, the more I question if anyone actually tests them with kids.  On the surface, the game seems fun: three-in-a-row plus Play-doh = awesome right? But in reality kids don't like their art projects smashed, and because there's really no rhyme or reason as to which player's fish gets smashed, they can easily gang up on a player.Nice idea in theory, not so great in practice.

My father is an architect, but I don't have an architectural bone in my body. My son, on the other hand, was drawing his own floor plans at four-years-old, so I thought this would be perfect for him.  What is even better however, is that you can use the tools to plot out building your own Minecraft house.My son, like many seven-year-old boys, is Minecraft-crazy.  He's really enjoys the blueprints and stencils. The stencils cover both larger building views (from the side) as well as a zoomed-in room view, which is where the Minecraft magic happens. The colored pencils and sketchbook are just gravy.That said, the extra stuff (the pencils, the sketch book) are really something you could get anywhere.  For the price, this feels like they're bundling content that's unnecessary.  You're better off providing a kid with a project -- in my case, asking my son to draw out the plans for his various Minecraft houses before he builds them in the game -- and then let their creativity range free.Who knows?  Maybe the boy will follow in his grandfather's steps...although I suspect the state of architecture will likely involve a lot more computer modeling and a lot less line drawing by then.

As an inexperienced camper, Im learning the hard way about carrying a sleeping bag, the importance of comfortable sleeping material. So far, Ive learned that I 1) do not sleep well on floors (like in Cub Scout sleepovers in museums), and 2) I dont like the restrictive nature of sleeping bags.  I feel like Im being swallowed up by some sleeping bag monster and it freaks me out.This sleeping pad addresses a few concerns.  For one, it doesnt get too warm (which is fine with me) so theres not this weird reflection of your body heat back at you from an inflated cushion.  For another, its light enough that you can carry it easily.  Lugging a sleeping bag alone is aggravating enough, this is a nice compromise between carrying an air bed and one of those awful flat mats that my son seems to have no problem sleeping on.That said, you cant just sleep on this thing without a cover.  You could theoretically sleep on it with just your sleeping bag, but since I kick everywhere thats not an option.  The sleeping mat actually has a use here  put it over this and it provides enough flat surface so you dont have dreams of falling through any of the holes.For the price, youre really paying for the fact that its so lightweight. And it achieves that in spades  at just 12 ounces and packed down to a 6 by 3 size thats about as encumbering as a full water bottle.  Your back will thank you!

Inspired by my success with giant spiders, I picked up a pack of party favor alligators to fill the role of packs of crocodiles and alligators in my Fifth Edition Dungeons & Dragons game. Crocodiles are large sized, so the Visejaw Crocodile is the nearest approximation at $8 each.  Or you could just buy this 12-pack of crocodiles for eight bucks (including shipping).The crocodiles, which you can buy from Amazon here, come in three poses: crocodile, crocodile with its mouth open, and alligator.  You can tell the difference because the alligator has a pointed snout.Like the giant spiders, you can get 12 of these critters for cheap or pay the same price for just one.  Overall I was happy with how they turned out.

One of the changes of the Fifth Edition of Dungeons & Dragons is that there is no longer a sliding scale for certain common monsters like monstrous spiders.  They have been returned to their "giant" status, and you can't very well have a giant spider that's tiny-sized, can you?  So now the only kind of giant spider is a large-sized spider, which made a lot of miniatures useless. A large monstrous spider miniature retails for $22 with shipping included. But I'm here to tell you that you can have 12 giant spiders for under five bucks.It doesn't help that giant spiders tend to come in packs. For the moment I'm leaving aside the medium-sized wolf spiders because I have plenty of those that fit the bill (specifically, the deathjump spider from D&D miniatures).The answer: party favors. Party favors are surprisingly well-sculpted and colorfully painted.  I ordered them for $4.49 and free shipping thanks to Amazon prime (you can order yours here). What you get is four different types of spiders, three of each: the flat-thorax huntsman spider, the hairy house spider, the smooth black widow spider, and the brown recluse. Mind you, I had to interpret what these spiders were meant to represent by the shape of each sculpt, so this list isn't necessarily accurate.  I based them all first and then painted them according to the type of spider I thought they should represent.Did it work? 12 giant spiders (four types, three each) would normally cost me $264 in D&D miniatures or even Reaper Bones' giant spider at $6 (shipping included).  Not bad for a toy!

My seven-year-old son isn't a big fan of bugs, so I thought this book might be a good opportunity to get him to think of bugs as good guys instead of horrible monsters to be squashed. We read a chapter together each night. The good news is this book is a seat-of-your pants ride that he begged me to keep reading after we finished a chapter.  The bad news is he still hates bugs.In short, Max finds a magical magnifying glass inside an old musty tome his mom bought him at an auction (his mom brings home things from the auction house where she works, like full suits of armor -- she's the coolest mom, ever).  When Max uses the magnifying glass to look at a map in the book, he is transported to Bug Island, a world where he's bug-sized.  He meets emperor scorpion Spike, which is a bit like befriending a great white shark.After determining that Max is not a lizard (the enemy, natch), Spike brings Max to the bug's leader, Barton, an enormous brown beetle. A volcanic eruption has caused a bridge to form between Bug Island and Reptile Island and the bad guys have begun to inviade. It turns out Max's superior brain might just be the edge the bug's need to fight off the dreaded General Komodo and his army.Because this was a review copy the pictures were not all finished, but my kids enjoyed looking at them anyway. Judging by the description the critters in the book are meant to look like the real thing, but some of the bug pictures seem more anthropomorphic than others.Author Jack Patton does a great job of balancing the fear of bugs -- particularly scorpions, tarantulas, and other venomous creepy crawlies -- with their utility.  No bug is cuddly in this book, but they're not bad guys either.  The bugs are divided into combat divisions by type, so the flying bugs have their own regiment, so do the army ants, the hornets, etc.  All of the bugs have entertaining personalities too, particularly the stuttering, shy trapdoor spider.Conversely, the bad guys are often referred to as reptiles when that's clearly not the case.  There are several amphibians in the mix, and Patton seems to remember this a little later when he starts referencing that Reptile Island's troops also included frogs and toads.  Still, that's a minor quibble in an otherwise very engaging battle between micro-fauna.At heart this Battle Bugs delivers on the title's promise: a war story that's light on casualties and big on fun. My five-year-old daughter (who isn't afraid of bugs) enjoyed it too.

It all started with Bratz. The trend that had overcome pop-culture, where divas with skinny waists and short skirts became celebrities, finally permeated little girls' toys in the awful monstrosities known as Bratz. The outcry was fast and loud, so the toy makers shifted gears.  Bratz begat Monster High, and Monster High begat Ever After High -- because fantasy versions of barely-there dressed dolls are a little more acceptable. In response, Hasbro "aged up" their My Little Pony line -- if Hollywood monsters could be fashionistas, why not ponies? -- with Equestria Girls, which is why we now have Twilight Sparkle in a skirt.To be fair, the two Equestria Girls movies have actually been pretty good.  But what's fascinating is how much Hasbro has touted the success of the Equestria Girls dolls despite the fact that they only have two movies in the entire franchise. It's clear that these dolls -- no matter what we adults think of them -- sell, and they sell well.Twilight Sparkle is indicative of the changes in the line.  The dolls have similar proportions to Bratz: long legs, short arms, tiny waists, big eyes. In Twilight Sparkle's case, this is a costume for a concert, which makes it marginally more acceptable than the Bratz characters who apparently wear their outfits for a night out (or who knows, every day?). Twilight has a similar color scheme to her pony counterpart.  But she also has a rainbow hairpiece that little girls can clip onto their own hair...or clueless dads who forget it's clipped to their back pants pocket... *cough*Anyway, this doll is surprisingly articulated.  She can sit and cross her legs easily, stands reasonably well, and comes with a few additional accessories (shoes, purse, and earrings -- the earrings are barely noticeable). My daughter enjoyed playing with the doll for her birthday, but Twilight Sparkle was no competition for the plush Anna doll she also received as a present.

This board game has a lot of things my kids like.  Dogs? Check! A pop-o-matic dice? Check! Checkers? Uh...Check!  By all accounts this should have been a huge hit. But instead it's a muddled mess of poor rules, aggravating game play, and no dogs whatsoever.Let's start with the dogs. This game is "dog-themed." Imagine if all the animated movie Lady and the Tramp featured nothing but dog bowls, paw prints, and bones and that's pretty much what you get with this board game. There are pictures of dogs on the box and some in the instructions and that's it.  It's just paw prints on the board, the pieces are dog bowls, and the queens are identified with flimsy foam bones.Speaking of the components, there's three: brown and red dog bowls, a bunch of white bones, and the pop-o-matic. The dog bowls are surprisingly sturdy components, which is totally unnecessary for a game of checkers. The materials should have been spent on creating the queens (Dog Bowl Kings, in this game), which are identified by the bones you place in the bowls.  The bone doesn't even fit all the in the bowl. This rapidly becomes a problem when you move a Dog Bowl King and the bone falls out.Besides the not-a-dog theme, there's two twists in how the game differs from checkers.  There's the pop-o-matic, which features three dice.  These dice have six sides with two possibilities, red bone or brown bone.  Depending on which dice you get, you move your piece and/or your player's piece as well!And now we come to the most confusing and aggravating part of the game: each turn, each player can move any piece on the board. Depending on the die roll, the player may not get to move any of his own pieces and only his opponent's and vice versa.The problem with these two innovations is how they interact with each other.  Early in the game there's not a lot of places to move (non-King dog bowls can only move forward, remember), which means you very quickly run out of options and forfeit your turn.  It also robs player's of agency, frustrating kids who dislike seeing their pieces moved by their opponent and get rapidly confused as to whose turn it is.The popper/"anyone moves" mechanic would actually be helpful during the final stages of the game, where opponents can circle each other forever as Dog Bowl Kings, but the game specifically prohibits this.Here's my recommendations to improve this game:1) Buy some plastic dogs to replace Dog Bowl Kings.  Everyone will be happy that they finally get to play a dog in a game with dogs plastered all over it. Also, you won't have to worry about losing the tiny bones.2) Don't use the popper until the first person gets a Dog Bowl King, and then apply the "player controls opponent's piece" rule to every piece, including the Kings. This helps speed up play rather than slow it down.Or you could just buy a cheap game of checkers, three dice (even is red, odd is brown), the aforementioned plastic dogs, and end up with a better dog-themed checkers game for under $10.

I resisted getting an electric toothbrush for years. Did I really need that hassle? However, my dentist finally talked me into it. It's not like she sells the toothbrushes, and she's the best dentist I've ever had, so I was willing to take her advice. Then it was kismet that this opportunity for an electric toothbrush became available.I use this toothbrush on the sensitive setting because my teeth are ridiculously prone to discomfort from hot and cold. This toothbrush has a lot of the bells and whistles many of them have, such as different settings and a little stutter when it's time to switch sides. My teeth don't exactly feel cleaner than they do after manually brushing (and my dentist warned me of this) but they feel cleaner longer after. My teeth don't feel quite as in need of a good brushing at night as they used to. I think that's probably the best endorsement of an electric toothbrush that I can give.I was concerned about constantly having to plug this toothbrush in, but it goes weeks without needing a recharge. The battery gauge light on the front of the unit lets you know when it's time to recharge. It also comes with a handy case, which keeps the entire works clean and enclosed (because we all know your toothbrush shouldn't be left exposed in the bathroom!). It's easy to change settings on the lighted display.Overall, it's a solid toothbrush that has made the chore of finally switching to an electric toothbrush a bit easier. The multiple settings make it worthwhile for people who have complicated dental problems.

I've been a big fan of GreenWorks since I switched from my old electric lawnmower to a dual-battery GreenWorks mower. Unfortunately here in the northeast it's been difficult to find anything to use it on because the entire outside has been covered in snow.  All of it. All the time.  Did I mention I'm sick of the snow?So it wasn't until the day after the first day of Spring that I had a chance to try this sucker out. And holy cow did it pass with flying colors.I of course didn't read the instructions at all as I assembled the thing.  I assembled it and pressed the button.  I was greeted by a beeping noise.At first I thought this was a sign that I had done something wrong, but then I realized it was a safety mechanism. That beeping?  That's the sound of awesome getting started.There's a double-click system to get the blower going, but once it starts to blow, it BLOWS. My son described the power of this blower as "violent" and I think that's apt.I've nicknamed this blower Voom, after the Cat in the Hat book:Then the Voom...It went VOOM!And, oh boy! What a VOOM!Now, don't ask me what Voom is.I never will know.But, boy! Let me tell youIt DOES clean up snow!Also, leaves, debris, and anything else not nailed down.

When I first saw "Night at the Museum" I thought it was stupid fun. That was eight years ago, if you can believe it, and the trilogy finally comes to a close with this final installment. As the passing of two key cast members demonstrates, the show really is over -- a decidedly adult conclusion to a kid-friendly franchise.Who hasn't thought about museums coming to life? It was only in the past decade, when the special effects could keep up with our imaginations, that the concept was brought to the screen in glorious (and often cheesy) CGI. And who better to shepherd a franchise than Ben Stiller as Larry Daley, channeling his bitter snark into a family-friendly loser who is just trying to raise his kid right.If you watch the first movie again...well, don't, because then you'll start to notice things -- the most egregious being the relentless characterization of Attila the Hun (Patrick Gallagher) as spouting gibberish.  But never you mind, because "Secret of the Tomb" is now refined family fare. The third part of the trilogy has filed off the sharp edges so that there's less monkey slapping and more hugging and kissing.To wit, the tablet of Ahkmenrah, responsible for animating all of the exhibits in the Museum of Natural History, is beginning to corrode. During a special exhibition in which the exhibits are "brought to life" (unbeknownst to the wealthy guests in attendance, who think they are merely special effects) the animating magic of the tablet goes haywire and the animated creatures go nuts, ruining the museum and leading to Dr. McPhee (Ricky Gervais) getting canned.  The whole party -- literally, the museum's exhibits seem to party every night -- comes to an abrupt end.But fear not! One flashback and some exposition later, we learn that former villain from the first film Cecil Fredericks (Dick Van Dyke, along with Bill Cobbs and recently passed Mickey Rooney ) is the link to the tablet's past. Fredericks directs Larry to the British Museum, where Ahkmenrah's parents (Ben Kingsley and Anjali Jay) hold the secret to restoring the tablet to its former glory.  This is of course an opportunity to animate and explore a whole new museum filled with its own quirks and wonders.As with all of the "Night at the Museum" movies, there are always jokes that just go on too long. Rebel Wilson as Tilly, the British security guard equivalent of Larry, spends far too much screen time desperately trying to be funny with nothing to do. There's an awkward thread about fathers and sons -- Larry's son Nicky wants to be a DJ instead of go to college -- that's supposed to parallel later events in the film but doesn't quite succeed.  And Stiller's brand of humor isn't for everybody.But there's some brilliant moments too, filled with action, intrigue, and a lot of coming-of-age hokum. The Neanderthal Laa that was modeled to look like Larry is an inspired joke and Sir Lancelot's (Dan Stevens) epic quest is heart wrenching when his hubris finally comes to grips with reality. Indeed, "Secret of the Tomb" embraces death, even if it's only because some gold prop started to corrode.In what can only be described as a bittersweet finale, Robin Williams as Theodore Roosevelt says goodbye to...well, to everything. Adults wept in the theater while kids wondered what the heck was going on. And suddenly what was a trifle of a kids film filled with stories about the wonders of history has become a sharp lesson about letting go of the past.Does this make the film better? Will people watching it years later still feel the same? Probably not.  But for now, in the present, everything is thrown in sharp relief by the last line ever spoken by Robin Williams as a wax figure in the form of Teddy Roosevelt:"Smile, my boy. It's sunrise."

It's easy to get jaded if you're a fan of horror films.  We've seen it all before: Slasher kills girl's family, girl meets slasher, slasher dies only to be resurrected in a sequel. "You're Next" is a refreshing twist on the tired slasher tropes.The first sign that "You're Next" is different is in how director Adam Wingard treats his characters. Five minutes in, we are invited to judge a relationship without understanding what's going on: an older man and a much younger woman having sex.  That early scene communicates volumes. Our camera perspective peering into the bedroom makes their lovemaking look more like violence. The girl is clearly unsatisfied. Padding out of the room while her lover takes a shower, she sets up a five-disc CD player of music on repeat that will be integral to the rest of the film. Then she dies.As our protagonists enter the next scene, driving up to a house nearby ad offhandedly explaining that the double homicide we just witnessed was a professor who left his wife for a college student. Do we feel better about their deaths as a result of their moral transgressions? While that question bounces around, we discover that our protagonists Crispian (A.J. Bowen) and Erin (Sharni Vinson) are in a similar relationship.  Do they deserve to die too?The rest of the film is a running battle between three men in masks wielding crossbows and a WASPy family reunion gone sour.  Erin and Crispian don't know each other that well, and the film cleverly juxtaposes the horrors of navigating a boyfriend's family with a slasher film. There's the frail mother, the overbearing father, the little sister who battles for attention, and the bullying older brother who is jealous of everyone else's happiness.  All of these family members come with their respective spouses, who are equally clueless and disengaged.  All the non-family members (Erin included) also look curiously fake -- Erin and Zee (Wendy Glenn) look like they're wearing wigs. In "You're Next" the killers aren't the only ones wearing masks.As the assault progresses, we get an explanation for why the bad guys do what they do, and "You're Next" gleefully wallows in the utter depravity of its villains. It throws the sins of the family in stark relief -- they're bad, but they're not murderers. Or are they?Erin certainly is. In a refreshing twist, we discover that Erin is no shrinking violet. She uses survival tactics worthy of any prepper compound.  There's something viscerally satisfying about her increasingly ferocious counterattack as each character's morals (or lack thereof) are brutally unmasked."You're Next" is filled with plot holes in service to the genre. Nobody seems to have any guns. The killers can barely see thanks to their ridiculous masks and they refuse to take them off when anonymity is no longer an issue. And the murder plot is flimsy at best. But "You're Next" isn't about realism.  It's about really, really hating your family. If you can't find the humor in that, this movie may not be right for you.

Just discovered Beck's fabulous "Girl" (I know, it takes me years to discover songs). I've seen a lot of controversy over whether this is a love song, or a serial killer's internal monologue, and a lot of theories in between. Here's what I think:  I saw her, yeah I saw her with her black tongue tied  Round the roses  Fist pounding on a vending machine  Toy diamond ring stuck on her finger  With a noose she can hang from the sun  And put it out with her dark sunglassesThe narrator sees a girl (noticably not a woman) pounding on a vending machine. She has a diamond ring on her finger, which he mocks, calling it a toy. Her marriage, it's clear, is something she's not mature enough to understand. He also feels she's either self-destructive of hopelessly naieve, and that although she wears dark sunglasses (cause she's that cool), she actually has a huge ego. Her ego's big enough that if she were to hang herself, she'd block the sun out. She's obviously into goth-type attitude/attire, as evidenced by her "black tongue tied" and "dark sunglasses." Judging from the tongue-tied, I'd guess she's a theater major or English major fond of spouting epithets that don't make her sound any smarter.  Walking crooked down the beach  She spits on the sand where their bones are bleaching  And I know I'm gonna steal her eyeAs she walks down the beach in a crooked line, a line that most people walk straight (and thus representative of her winding, indecisive life), she spits. Again, not a nice image for an object of affection, but more importantly she doesn't even know what's she spits on. Alternately, she's too oblivious to notice the bones of the creatures on the beach, as she's so wrapped up in herself.  She doesn't even know what's wrong  And I know I'm gonna make her die  Take her where her soul belongs  And I know I'm gonna steal her eye  Nothing that I wouldn't trySo "gonna make her die" -- does that mean Beck wants to kill this poor girl?I doubt it. It's more likely he's going to break her heart. He feels he's a real man, better to bring this girl into a real relationship than the stupid marriage she's locked into.
