This does a good job of getting in every nook and cranny.I admit I had to change my brushing technique. I used to brush aggressively with a regular toothbrush, pressing down hard and brushing fast in several different attitudes (horizontally, up-and-down and in a circular motion). This electric unit does the work for you. I had to slow down and let the brush linger on each tooth. The two-part brush head does the work for me. I also had to learn not to press down hard.I found the unit comfortable in the hand, easy to maneuver around in me mouth and easy to use. I did find the on-off switch difficult to engage without looking at it though.Did the "Truly Radiant" toothpaste give me a whiter smile in just five days? Sadly, no. In a week? Unfortunately, no. In a fortnight? Again, no. I have tried a number of different toothpastes that advertise whitening properties and none have every worked for me. I can report that we found the spinbrushes very effective, giving a good, efficient brushing and leaving our teeth as clean a feeling, if not more so, than any manual brush. It's a good set and I recommend it with four stars.

I have mixed feelings about this bathroom set. There are plusses and minuses to almost equal degree.Firstly, I like the color of the shower curtain. It replaced a mint green one and the prominent white and yellow combined with the blue-green really brightened up my bath. I really like the padded, blue-green mat. It's a micro fiber and really soaks up the water falling off one's form as one exits the shower. It's nicely padded and very soft on the feet. It has a rubberized bottom and holds water rather than it leaking through. In addition, it seems to dry quickly.Unfortunately, this set (that's the key word here - "set") does not come with the inner, water-proof curtain. I think if you're going to sell a set and you're going to swap out everything, you may as well start with a new waterproof, inner curtain too. I didn't like the hooks. They looked very light and flimsy. The wire they're made from is very thin. I could bend then with my fingers, for pete's sake!In short, I liked the colorful, bright curtain, the mat but didn't like the absence of a waterproof curtain and the flimsy, cheap hooks. Three stars.

Okay, I admit it. I have a sweet tooth...okay, more than one! If you like Starburst or Skittles, this is the cat's meow!Six packs of original Starbursts, three packs of Favorreds (the red ones! strawberry and cherry!) and three packs of Tropical flavors (there's even a kiwi-cherry...okay, that took some time to get used to). Starbursts are fruit-flavored chews - like taffy in consistency and individually wrapped within each pack which makes them suitable for a candy dish on the coffee table!Skittles are fruity candy in a hard, candy shell - think of fruity M&Ms instead of chocolate and you've got the picture. This pack contains eight packages of original flavor, four in Wildberry, three in Tropical and three in Sour - my new favorite!The only problem with this deal is that with so much in one package...one risks the temptation to eat too much in one sitting! No, I'm not kidding. Yes, five stars!

This Amazon Basics Surge protector seems like a good unit that does what it's supposed to do - protect your electric gadgets from power surges.I originally thought the unit felt very lightweight and flimsy. Well, except for the cord - the power cord is thick and heavy-duty. I can tell you that it does what it's supposed to do because I had a power surge. I live in a rural area and the power is sometimes tricky - if a bird lands on a powerline wrong, I lose power! Well, a couple days after I got this, we had a power outage and, when the power came back on, there was a surge.The light is out, meaning the breaker tripped. There was no damage to the gadgets plugged into this surge protector. The only bad thing is that I have to get another surge protector! No, I wouldn't hesitate to get another one of these. Though I still feel the unit is a little light weight, I have to give it four stars for its performance. Decent price too.

Clockwork Synergy silicone bands are excellent. Period.Bought two silicone bands for a new watch. The new watch came with a very nice leather band, but leather absorbs sweat - bad consequences follow. Silicone is easy to clean with an alcohol wipe. Not only that, but these bands by Clockwork Synergy are very flexible and comfortable. Additionally, they come with quick-change pins already installed, making it easy to install or remove to give your watch another look.The only thing I didn't love is the shade of green. I would have preferred a darker green or camo (Clockwork Synergy, are you listening?) in the 24mm size band. Well, I knew what I was getting when I ordered it. The other band I bought? Stiff as a board and uncomfortable! Didn't come with pins, much less quick-change pins! This band is excellent and I recommend it with five stars.

This is going to be a short review. The hardware (buckle and pin) is decent. The colors are vivid with the a camo pattern reminiscent of the British army DPM camo pattern. Unfortunately, the band itself is so stiff that I found it very uncomfortable. This is supposed to be silicone, but felt like a poly strap in it's stiffness. The band itself is thick and perhaps that contributes to the rigidity. I do not recommend this product and give it only two stars.

I have bought Purina chows for many years. As a boy, I remember Purina chows for cattle, sheep, barnyard fowl and the "checkerboard square" on the side of the coop silos. Though Purina Cat Chow Indoor formula has been the staple in this house, I thought I would try Purina Beyond Natural for the house felines.I really liked the switch from grains to more meat. Cats are predators and they eat meat. I looked at the ingredients and saw chicken meal, beef fat, and I also saw "No corn, wheat or soy. No poultry by-product meal. No added artificial colors, flavors or preservatives." I think this is a better product from the old checkerboard square, but how will the cats like it?The house kitties love it! I think it's more than just a change of pace. They actually eat more per day so I'm having to make sure they don't get fat! The stray we're feeding outside (but haven't managed the get to trust us enough to come inside just yet) isn't a good judge since he eats anything he can get without complaint!It does have pea protein, egg and canola meal as well as pea fiber and carrots for fiber and bulk. It also contains the necessary minerals cats need in their diets. I like this product and I think it's a step toward more authentic food for pets. My cats like it and I like what I see on the label. I and the cats recommend this product with five stars.

In Adrian Coombs-Hoar's "Eagles in the Dust", the author sets himself the task of re-evaluating the battle of Adrianople and it's effects on the Roman Empire. This battle between Germanic Goths and the late Roman Empire has been compared to Cannae as a disaster to the eastern Roman Empire in terms of number of troops lost. But, was it really a disaster for the empire?The author does a good job of "setting the stage", explaining the situation in the Roman Empire divided into eastern and western halves and each ruled by it's own emperor. Coombs-Hoar does a good job of showing the fractious nature of the empire in that there were no rules for succession and differing claimants to the throne fought it out, weakening the army and their own state.Likewise, the author does a decent job of showing the forces pushing from the steppes of Eurasia in the form of Huns that pushed Germanic tribes like the Goths west until the ran into the border of the Roman Empire. Likewise, he covers the incursions by "barbarians" into the empire and finally the Goths led by Fritigern being allowed to settle within the empire. We also read of the cruel treatment of the Goths by corrupt Roman officials that sparked violence.Where the book falls absolutely flat is in analysis of the battle itself. The author spends one chapter on the battle and most of that is an analysis of the route Emperor took and how many hours it required. The few paragraphs he spends on the battle are simply insufficient for a book focusing on the battle and its effects. The fact that he gives the reader a chapter on his opinion on its long-term effects, a good chapter on Roman armor, weapons and equipment in the late empire period, and a chapter on "what if's" does not make up for the almost nonexistent look at the battle itself.This book is only average and I would not recommend it to those looking for insight into this pivotal battle. Three stars.

The very first thing I noticed about the Gladiator starter pack was the quality of the components. This Gladiator product is a starter set that can be added to as your needs grow - or just as it is if that's all you need. It's meant to be a system by which you can hang or store items on the wall, whether rakes, screws, axes, or ???I opened the box and pulled out the wall piece and the boxes containing the storage components: three big, heavy-duty hooks, two small hooks and one plastic bin. The hooks are all nicely powder-coated with the biggest hooks having a non-slip neoprene coating that is soft and will grip your tools so as not to slide. They are very well made and finished. They are also very strong with good welds that won't let you (or your tools) down.Installation: Easy! But...WARNING...have all your prep done and tools collected! The battery for my cordless drill needed to be charged and I needed a new battery for my stud finder! You will need: drill (cordless ones are handier, but an AC plug-in drill will do fine), a stud finder, a pencil, tape measure, level and an appropriate drill bit (I used a 3/32 bit).The easy-to-follow instructions say it'll take you about 15 minutes and that's about what it took me. I found the studs on the side wall of the garage with my stud-finder. I recommend one that will also detect AC wiring - you don't want to drill into one of those! Even a rookie can follow the simple directions and get this done in the allotted time (but, remember, don't rush).Now, I'd done something like this using 2x4's and various size hooks (I used bicycle hooks for the bigger tools) and it worked great. But, I have to admit that this Gladiator product looks better and is only a little more expensive when all is said and done compared to my home-made project.This Gladiator Starter Pack is a good product, whether you're buying it as a stand-alone unit or with additional units in mind for the future. I found it easy to install and the product itself it high quality make. I recommend this with five stars.

The Jedi Council have decided on a course of action that was very un-Jedi - assassination. The Separatist war led by Count Dooku and General Grievous is causing so much death and misery that Mace Windu suggests a radical course of action - assign a Jedi master to kill Dooku in the hope the Separatist movement will collapse without their leader. Even stranger, they suggest this Jedi assassin team up with an unlikely partner.I will state at this point that I didn't really like the book. I think there were things that author Christie Golden did right like the action sequences, the tech, the vivid descriptions of differing worlds. But there were a number of things I really didn't like. Some of them were technical, while others involved the plot line.The author makes some technical errors that create a difficult read at times. Worst of all is the "head hopping" wherein the author goes from the inner thoughts of one character to the inner thoughts of another character without noting a change in perspective. This is sometimes done in the same paragraph with one sentence following another. Especially in the beginning, it makes it hard to understand exactly who's thinking what.I thought the author used too many "parallels" with the main Star Wars story line. I don't want to spoil things for someone who buys this book, but this story has aspects that are almost exactly like Episodes 1-6. I thought it was problematic from a number of angles such as if this happened before, shouldn't the Jedi been more aware of the possibility in another Jedi that could lead to disaster? I also thought - why couldn't the author think of something different than what we've already seen on screen?Probably the worst thing about the book is that is often felt more like a romance novel than anything else - something I really wasn't looking for and didn't want. Not only that, but I thought it was a poorly constructed one! The male character's responses are sometimes rather silly and seemed more like a star-struck teen than an experienced Jedi Master.In balance, I think most Star Wars fans will be disappointed to some degree with the "parallels" (and what they should have meant), the overt romance and the technical issues. Although I feel the author did some things right, she did some that didn't appeal to me at all and I can't give it more than three stars.

These old Disney films are such treasures! They're exceptionally well written, directed and acted. The color of these films are vibrant and beautiful! Walt Disney always created family-friendly films that had an innocence that has since been lost.This film, Johnny Tremain, is one of Disney's tributes to the founding of the country in the American Revolution. It focuses on Boston in the years immediately before the "shot heard round the world" as it involved the fictional character of Johnny Tremain, an apprentice silversmith, caught up in the events of the outbreak of war.Johnny's story is the story of the outbreak of war for the sake of liberty - a concept that made a common man like Johnny the equal of the wealthy noble. James Otis, Sam Adams, Paul Revere and the other leading lights of the Boston "Sons of Liberty" make their appearances as Johnny's life parallels that of the rise of a new country founded on liberty and freedom. Events such as the Boston Tea Party and the Battles of Lexington and Concord are played out from the perspective of the young Bostonian.The film isn't like movies of today with their special effects and gritty realism. No, this is a highly stylized, patriotic, perhaps simplistic account of events in a story focusing on the common man. There is an innocence in this film I find refreshing. The British leaders themselves are shown as men of honor doing their duty, dreading bloodshed with the colonists even as the Patriot leaders are men of conviction, willing to sacrifice their very lives for freedom and liberty.I enjoyed this window to a simpler time when Americans loved their country and didn't look for reasons to fault it. I enjoyed this film and recommend it to those interested with five stars.

The George Foreman GFO240S Indoor/Outdoor Electric Grill! It's as good as a charcoal or gas outdoor grill! Well, no, it really isn't.The George Foreman line of electric grills offers a quick, efficient way to cook various meats (I haven't tried fish, but I've tried the usual animals that walk on four legs and chicken) while being relatively (remember that word) easy to clean and drains excess fat away. It does not cook the meat using any kind of flame or charcoal and does not impart that delicious flavor that comes with traditional outdoor grills. If that's important to you, stop reading now. That does not mean you can't get good flavor, though.Looking at this unit, it comes unassembled. Not to worry, it is very easy to assemble with only two screws you will need a screwdriver for. That's it. On the negative side, it's not rock-steady when fully assembled on the pedestal - it's a just a little shaky. The large (240 sq. in.), ridged, heating surface is plenty big for lots of burgers, dogs, steaks, kabobs, fillets, etc. It's about the same size as the traditional size charcoal "kettle" grill. One of the things it does very well is even heating across the surface of the heating surface.I have a four-serving GF grill and use it mainly because I'm on an Atkins style diet, heavy in protein - which, for me translates as steaks, ham slices, chicken breasts, pork kabobs, burgers and dogs. The GR line of grills does a good job of cooking quickly and efficiently - even if it adds no taste to the meat. This product, unlike most of the smaller grills in the line, has only one heating surface - just like a "real" grill, so you need to turn the meat  over to cook both sides.While cooking, the excess fat will drain into a grease trap under the unit that is easy to reach and can be easily detached to empty. Since this product has a cover, moisture will condense on the underside of the cover. Unfortunately, it will then drip onto the ground (not necessarily a problem) or onto the countertop if used indoors without the pedestal (which IS a problem) and you will have a circular pool of water under the unit. I admit I was surprised by this.How does the food taste? Like cooking it in the oven, unfortunately. I used several marinades on the meat I grilled with the GFO240S. I used Allegro Hickory Smoke Marinade and A-1 NY Steakhouse Marinade I picked up at my local grocer. You may have a favorite or home-made marinade you use. Go for it! That's the key with a GF grill - be resourceful about imparting flavor in the absence of the smoky heat of the charcoal or gas grill.The aftermath: it cooked my top sirloin, flatiron and eye of round steaks as well as can be expected. I will warn you that the cooking surface is a little hotter than I expected based on my smaller GF grill. Lean toward less time per side when looking at the ranges specified on their generally-good cooking guide. For example, if the say 6-8 minutes per side for steaks (well done), lean toward the 6 minutes. It does impart the traditional black lines across the meat because of the ridged cooking surface (which also allows the liquified fat to drain away).Cleaning? Here's where that "relatively" comes in. The cooking surface has a non-stick coating which does make it easy to wipe off. Well, the problem is that you cannot immerse the cooking surface while washing it with mild detergent in warm water. For the smaller units that have twin heating surfaces that detach, they can be easily held in one hand above the sink while cleaning. No problem. This unit, however, it too big to be held easily or comfortable while cleaning. I felt like putting it up against a rock in the front yard and hosing it down!To be frank, you can make this work. If you don't want to mess with charcoal or gas or, to have for a backup in case it rains or for winter, this is an option as long as you do a little work to improve the flavor. But, for the most part, I didn't like this GF product that well. It does offer advantages but, the robustness of the unit, the water dripping from the cover, the cleaning problem and the lack of that "real" grill taste cause me to give this product three stars.

I have a new LG G4 and wanted to get a nice case for it. I liked the colors and the texrure - as far as I could see on the Amazon product page. The reality was very different than what I had expected.Firstly, this case is a hard plastic - not a softer, rubber-type material. I guess I was looking for something that was softer and would absorb impacts or drops. Why would you want a hard-plastic case that does not cushion the phone within? The little kick-stand is nice, but difficult to pull out into place.Frankly, if I had had the opportunity to touch this product, I would not have purchsed it. I cannot recommend this unit and give it only two stars.,

How could you go wrong with a trio of Ford measuring tapes? These are pretty good measuring tapes that will give good service...well, two out of three isn't bad.In this package, you get a 26', a 16' and a 10' unit. They're shaped like tires and have a no-slip coating all the way around the edge - like a tire. The belt clips are sufficient, but nothing special. Each has a convenient thumb button to hold the tape in place and lock. In addition, it has a lock underneath the unit - as you draw the tape out from an edge, just push down on it and it holds the tape in place! Works pretty good actually. The tape itself has a nylon coating on it and gives it a matte, non-reflective finish. I thought this was great since many tape measures have a more glossy finish that will reflect sunlight and obscure your vision.I take a star off because I think the 10-footer should be thin and compact enough to fit in a pocket. It's really too big and wide to easily fit in my pocket and the small unit has no advantage over having one of the larger ones. What's up with that? Also, the button on the bottom of the 10-footerwon't engage because of the curve on the bottom of the case. Badly thought out. It's a solid unit, but detracts from it's usefulness by its overall size and poor design.So, you get two measuring tapes that are top-notch and one that is less so. But, overall, I like them well enough to still give the 3-in-1 pack a nod at four stars.

Steven Decatur was one of America's early heroes and one of it's great tragedies. In this work, author Leonard Gutteridge lays out the story of Decatur's rise to fame and his early death on the "field of honor" in a pointless duel neither man wanted.The Author does a decent job of giving the reader the essentials of the life of the naval hero whose name graces many towns, townships and counties in the eastern US. The author gives us a matter-of-fact version of events. Strangely, he seems to focus more on mundane topics than on the battles and "action" if you will!The author spends a few pages on his naval battles whether against Barbary pirates or British ships during the War of 1812 as we Americans know it. I found myself wanting to read more about those very battles instead of the wrangling of egos that all-too-often overshadowed what mattered in the early US Navy. The author spends entire chapters on the angry letters that passed between Decatur and his killer, Barron. I thought the author gave us an account that was rather pedestrian in the end.I thought this book sold Decatur short as a naval hero and I think it only so-so as a biography. Three stars.

S.C. Gwynne has given us a wonderful story - all of it true. Gwynne gives us the story of a great commander who appeared out of nowhere to shine brightly indeed and then was suddenly gone. This is the story of "Stonewall" Jackson.The author writes wonderfully, giving us more than the dates, places, units and battles. The reader learns who this man was, how he lived, how he worshipped, how he loved, his sense of courage and duty. We learn about the poverty of his early life, his big break that sent him to West Point, his courage in combat in the war with Mexico as well as his life in the post-war army. We read about the instructor at VMI who was universally judged not only to be a failure as a teacher, but rather an oddball to boot!Jackson's life before the war and his meteoric rise to fame as a commander is well chronicled. All these things the author gives us. He also gives us a good idea of the man within. Jackson as the devout Christian, the loving husband, the tender and sentimental middle-aged man of his small town. The author does a fine job of setting up the reader for Jackson's appearance on the stage of war.The maneuvers, the marches, the feints as well as the battles are chronicled which shows the reader how Jackson could "mystify, mislead and surprise" his enemies. A battle was set up by maneuver and movement beforehand in order to put an enemy in the best position to be defeated. The Confederacy's disadvantages in this war were great as the agricultural South fought the more populous and industrial north. As a matter of fact, the author shows how the Confederate forces were poorly armed, equipped and supplied. Compared to the Union's soldiers, those wearing butternut brown or gray were hungry or ragged most of the time. That they performed as well as they did for as long as they did is tribute to their innate toughness.The reader will note the difference in command between North and South. The author's work makes it quite plain even to the novice that Lincoln's generals were often chosen by their political connections while those in the Confederacy were obviously more competent as warriors. I was struck by the fact that "Billy Yank" was usually as brave as "Johnny Reb", but often poorly led. I found it odd that, though the Union forces were more numerous and with better weapons and supplies, their commanders were usually more risk averse. On the other hand, Southern commanders such as Jackson were more daring, willing to risk great defeat to achieve great victory.Jackson was a commander who often led from the front, keeping close to the leading edge of battle. At Chancellorsville, Jackson met his end in the fading light in a crossfire between Union and Confederate forces. Here, at the high-tide of the Confederacy, Jackson fell. In one of history's "what ifs", men still conjecture on the course of the war is Jackson had not died.This is an excellent book that I cannot find even one criticism in. It is well researched, well written and is an enjoyable read on one of military history's towering figures. I heartily recommend this to Civil War, Military History, American history readers or readers of fine biographies. Five Stars.

I typically wait a month to review a watch. That way, I have a longer term view and have a better chance of seeing the strengths and weaknesses of a watch. In the case of this Akribos XXIV chronograph, my experience has been mostly good.I'd had this watch on one of my Amazon wish lists for a while before the opportunity arose to get it. I was impressed by the styling of the watch but wondered about the quality. The styling itself is very attractive and this timepiece was obviously meant as a dress watch. The light silver dial is nicely contrasted with cobalt or "blowtorch" blue markers with hands a shade darker blue. The reflection of light off the markers especially sets this watch off. There is lume on both dial and hour and minute hands - not great lume, but about what you'd expect on a watch in this price range. The mineral glass crystal is clear and a gentle tap with my fingernail tells me it's not thin.The band is mesh steel - something I don't have on any other watch in my collection - and it is attractive. It is easily adjustable, much more than a bracelet that requires a trip to the jeweler in most instances. I don't baby my watches and wear even dress watches to work in a warehouse. I did replace the mesh band with a silicone band making it easier to clean it of dirt and sweat.The watch itself performed very well and was four seconds fast for the month - very good for a quartz watch. The hands all align and hit the markers squarely. The chrono functions work properly, reset properly and it's accurate. The watch performs well and does what it's supposed to do without problems. The water resistance is 30m. Remember, that's water "resistance" and 30m doesn't mean you can dive to a water depth of 30m wearing this. A 30m water resistance essentially means you are covered if you get caught out in a sudden rain or splash some water on it while doing dishes.Perfect? No. For some reason, the designers of this watch decided to have the date represented with a date window (at four o'clock) as well as a dial (at six o'clock). Why do you have two different ways of looking at the same thing? Do they work? Yes. Does this duplication interfere with the function of the watch? No. It's just weird. It's a wasted space that could have been used for a day-of-week dial or a 1/10th second dial. Again, it doesn't hurt anything, it's just a wasted opportunity to include another function.As always, one must consider price in any conversation of watches. At this price, the watch is a good value for the money. It is attractive, accurate and gives the wearer a stopwatch function all at a good price. Despite the date duplication issue, it's a good watch and a good value that I recommend to those looking for a value dress watch with four stars.Added 10/10/2015 - After having this watch a while, one of the things I like is the 30-minute chrono dial. Unlike others I have, the hand on this Akribos's clicks one minute at a time. It's never in between the minute markers. It's on one or another and makes the dial much easier to read - an important point since these subdials are by necessity small.

I keep buying these silicone bands for the watches in my collection and new purchases and they never let me down in terms of quality or functionality.Silicone bands are waterproof, soft and flexible - easy on the arm and don't absorb sweat. There are other makers including some that make striped and colored bands like this one. These from Clockwork Synergy are the best I have found to date and have purchased several over the last 6 months for existing watches in my collection. This band is destined for a new watch I'm purchasing from Amazon.The colors don't bleed. On another manufacturer's bands like this I've bought in the past, the colors tend to bleed so a white looks like a light gray and red looks a little darker when paired with a blue or black stripe. Not the case with these bands. The contrasting colors are bright and vivid. What you see on the Amazon product page is what you get. The hardware is nicely polished stainless steel and certainly not cheap.The band already comes with spring bars or pins installed. Not just any spring bars, they're quick change bars - no tools needed. As soon as you get the old spring bars off, these go on easily - meaning that you can change looks as frequently as you want. The bars themselves are built into the bands so they won't spring away from you while you're trying to take them off/put them on.If you look at the underside of the half that has the holes the buckle pin goes through, the holes aren't just straight through. On the underside, it also has the holes drilled at an angle so the buckle pin just slides right in. That's attention to detail!These are the best silicone bands I've found and I recommend them with five stars.

A world where blight is destroying crops and turning the human race into a starving species with no hope of survival doesn't see the miracle that brought ex-astronaut Cooper to a hidden NASA facility.The story itself begins as a quest by a threatened mankind to find another home to replace the dying Earth. Along the way, the explorers face obstacles of time, distance and human frailty. An interesting premise that, as far as I am concerned, fell flat in it's execution. There are people who "get" certain types of movies. I am not one who "gets" this type. If you liked "2001: A Space Odyssey", this may be right up your alley. I found it tedious and boring interspersed with occasional excitement.I didn't really appreciate this film as much as others perhaps would. If you like films like "2001", you may like this, but I didn't. Just three stars.

I like the shirt. I like the design. The silk screening appears to be pretty good and should be long-lasting. That part, I like.But...the sizes are waaaaaaaaaay too small! I bought a size XL. I have been wearing XL shirts for a couple years and there is minor variation in shirt sizes. When I received the shirt, I tried it on immediately. Very tight around the middle. This is an XL..extra large! It's almost a tapered fit, for Pete's sake! I didn't return it for exchange because I had plans to go on a diet. I did and lost 15 lbs. Tried it on after that and still too tight! Too late for me to return.If you're going to buy this shirt, you'll need to adjust your sizing accordingly.

This LG G4 is one nice smartphone! It is very sophisticated, very fast, very good looking. There's only a couple things I don't like.I'm new to smartphones and I was surprised how easy this Android os machine was to set up. Basically, all I had to do is take my micro SIM card (if you have a non-smartphone like I had, you may have to go to an ATT retailer to get a new SIM chip) and put it into the slot in this phone. A lot of the setup is intuitive for the benefit of non-enthusiasts like myself. There's still a lot of sophistication for the more savvy user, though. I was able to set it up very easily. I set up my email (I use a gmail account) and social media such as Facebook in moments.The phone has a very nice, large display. The touch screen's sensitivity is just right (at least for me). You can set a number of interesting options - in my case, I choose to have the phone vibrate whenever I launch an app. You can change the volume or sound the results from your touch. As far as the app go, you get a good selefction of basic apps together with a number of ATT apps, including MyATT which I find useful. You have a couple different web browsers, email, calendar/planner, contacts, Google, Gmail, et al.The camera is very good (but not as good as my Canon Power Shot) and it does take better pictures than I expected. The phone has 32 Gig of storage. After taking away a chunk for the os and the apps, you have about 27-28 Gig for your use. Not enough? You can put a micro SD card in it to expand your storage.The power button is on the back, below the camera lenses, with the volume up above and volume down buttons below it. All other controls are on the touchscreen. It works well, is fast, has loads of storage for the average person. What don't I like about it? Well, nothing really. The one thing I don't like is common to all software and hardware today - no manual! Being from an earlier generation, I like to have a manual to read and find all the features. All you get is a little, folded pamphlet.In conclusion, this is a great phone that should serve one well. I recommend this phone with five stars.

I really like this George Foreman grill! If you want to grill some hamburgers or hot dogs, cook some steaks, kabobs or even a salmon or tuna steak, this will do the job. Not only will it do the job, but it will do it quickly and efficiently.The George Foreman grill (this is the 4-serving size) is essentially a top and bottom heating element covered by non-stick plates. You plug it in at which time a yellow preheat light comes on (the left hand light). Wait about 4-5 minutes and the right-hand light will come on and you are ready. You grasp the handle, lift it, place your meat on the bottom plate and close the cover back down again. There's no timer, so you have to keep track of the cook time. In the couple weeks I've had it, I've used it extensively as I'm on a modified Atkins diet with a lot of protein which translated into steaks, chops, burgers and fish that needed cooking.The guide that comes with it goes over unpacking, setting up, cleaning, cooking (and safety too). It gives you a pretty good idea of cooking times for various types of foods. I found it to be very accurate after a little experimentation - depending upon how you like your meat: rare, medium or well. It cooks meat very efficiently and gives it the classic burn lines we expect from a charcoal or gas grill. Do not expect you'll get the same taste though. Only fire will give you that smoky taste. But, it does a good job for what it is. The grill itself has a sliding hinge so it can accomodate very thick slices of meat. I have cooked inch-thick NY strip steaks with success using this grill.There are a couple things I didn't like, though. The non-stick plates which are held in place by clips and are easily removed cannot be immersed in water and must be washed with warm water. This means they have to be washed separately from your other dishes although you can put them in a dishwasher. The power cord is very short and I found I had to rearrange things on the countertops to accomodate this flaw.On the whole, this is a very good unit and has done everything I needed it to do. Despite some cleaning and power cord issues, I think it is a  very good indoor grill. I recommend this grill with four stars.

The Fieseler Fi-156 "Storch" - Stork in English - was a German aircraft designed in the mid-1930's as an army liaison aircraft. It served everywhere the German army did and even soldiered on after WWII in the Spanish air force.The book itself is a pictorial and has many fine vintage photos of the Storch in action. You get to see the Storch in the snows of Russia, the deserts of North Africa and everywhere in between. There are some good shots of battle damaged and crashed aircraft as well as shots that give you an idea of the STOL capabilities of this aircraft. There are pictures with auxiliary fuel tanks and bomb racks - obviously only the lightest of bombs. There were fairly good (though not great) line drawings of the aircraft's basic frame, wing construction and canopy.Additionally, there is some good text about the competition to supply the army with this type of aircraft in which the Fieseler design won. There were several manufacturers that tried to win the contract including an autogyro. There's a little about the engine used and also the Storch in postwar use. It's a fairly good book with a lot of good photos, but there were some that were simply filler. So, there you have it. It's a pretty good, though short, pictorial at a reasonable price. I recommend with four stars.

This is a nice, little hummingbird feeder. It has perches for four birds and holds a decent 16 ounces. It has a bee guard and you fill up the top with water - a feature called a "moat" - to keep ants out.I got it and it was easy to disassemble (to get the hook out of the bottom of the feeder) and will be  very easy to clean. As you can imagine, it's made of plastic, but seems very sturdy for all that. The bee guard is a good feature (dang, I hate those yellow jackets!) but it makes the hole deeper for the hummers to get to the nectar. They'll get used to it - the ones around my house did.I think this feeder is a good one for the money. Does what it's supposed to. Haven't had any problems with it. Five stars.

This is a very nice, well-made and efficient nail clipper, The plastic body/holder is very comfortable to grasp and makes it much easier to hold and accurately cut the nails. The clipper gives clean cuts and traps the clippings inside the unit, so they don't fly all over the place. Along the side of the plastic holder is a file built in. It's not the best, but it does work. It's made in Japan and seems well finished and works smoothly.The problem? It cost over twenty bucks! No matter of comfortable it is to hold, nicely it cuts or any other feature, it is simply over-priced. Three stars.

Gerhard Koop and Klaus-Peter Schmolke have given us a comprehensive record of the Deutschland-class warships of the German Navy before and during WWII. This is an exhaustive record of the German "pocket battleships" and covers almost everything.The good thing about this book is the plethora of data of every sort. I was surprised to read about the types of steel used in the armored belt and the rest of the ship - the carbon content, the nickel content, etc. The engines and electric generators are covered. The guns, primary armament, secondary armament, AAA guns, are discussed as well as the mounts. The radar, the range-finding equipment and other combat-related stuff is listed and discussed. The authors briefly give the reader the service life of these ships from construction to  destruction including prewar cruises, combat and even refits.The period photos, line drawings and sketches are numerous and excellent. There are pictures of the weapons, the spotter aircraft, every angle of the ships' exteriors as wel as good pictures of crew members in action and in their daily lives  working, relaxing and at mess. There are so many good things about this volume.The only bad thing about the book - and why it is a four-star instead of five-star book - is that the authors didn't really make it an enjoyable journey. The book is very much a reference work with no attempt to even make the war service of these ships sound interesting. It's a rewarding read, but a very dry one. Four stars.

There's very little I can say that hasn't been covered by other reviewers. But, I genuinely enjoyed this movie at a number of levels. It's a good basic story, good sci-fi and visually attractive. I found this prequel to the "Aliens" films worth my time.Archeologists Charlie Holloway and Elizabeth Shaw (played by Noomi Rapace and Logan Marshall-Green) see the same celestial representation in ancient representations all over the world - from those carved in stone in ancient Sumer and Egypt to cave paintings in the Scottish Highlands. All these representations hint at ancient visitation by extra-terrestrials. The two convince an aging industrialist to fund an expedition to the place these representations point to in the cosmos in order to find the origins of our species.The expedition includes an android (well played by Michael Fassbender) who, during the long voyage to the planet, becomes a skilled linguist in order to translate any written...or verbal communications they may find. The ship touches down and the team indeed does find a facility created by the "engineers" as the extra-terrestrials are called.There are several plot holes and acts that require one to suspend disbelief, but the story itself is about origins and the desire to find one's origins. The science part is reasonably believable and the plot takes a few very interesting twists. The film itself will shock, surprise and give one a shiver at times! The roles are well cast with the exception of one of the supporting characters and the cinematography is very good. I thought it was visually impressive.This is a good film in the "Aliens" series that I thought went beyond the usual horror-story-in-space and approached something higher, more sophisticated. I recommend this movie to those interested with four stars.

I've owned this Tommy Hilfiger watch for a month now and I can tell you that it's a good watch. It's not an outstanding watch by any measure, but it's a good one.Firstly, I think the 42mm case width is an excellent size, fitting virtually any man. It's big enough to fit into the new "big watch" style currently in vogue yet not big enough to exclude smaller wristed men like myself. I think the case is very nicely polished on top surfaces while having a brushed finish on the sides. The white dial with the red-white-blue Tommy Hilfiger colors is very nice.The watch movement itself was 15 seconds fast for the month - only average for a quartz watch. The Amazon page doesn't mention the place of manufacture for the movement so that probably means China. The faux, numbered diver bezel does not move and is obviously there purely for "decoration" and tends to detract from the watch in my opinion. The second hand is in a nicely contrasting red but does not hit the markers - not even close. I have more expensive watches that don't and cheaper watches that do but, as a watch buyer, I always look for it.The 50 meter water resistance should be sufficient for this casual/dress watch if you get caught out in the rain or splash some water on it while doing dishes. I would not recommend immersing this watch - it's not a diver's watch. The band is certainly sufficient and is comfortable silicone with two keepers, but nothing special. I bought a Navy Blue/Red striped premium silicone band from Clockwork Synergy - 22mm Premium 2 Piece Ss Silicone Striped Navy Blue / Red Interchangeable Replacement Watch Band Strap which looks much nicer to my eyes.It's a good and good-looking watch that has only a few things pulling it down to four stars like an average movement and some poor styling elements. But, it's a solid four star watch and I recommend it to Tommy Hilfiger fans.

There aren't many books focusing on the military vehicles in the background such as the supply trucks, the artillery tractors, the cranes, ambulances, busses, etc. This book hits that spot perfectly for the WWII German Wehrmacht.This book is a pictorial, but don't let that fool you. There's a lot of good info here beginning with the organization of the commissary units of the German army. There are tables of equipment for supply columns of every sort. The book then moves on to the types of trucks employed by the German army. They used trucks by many manufacturers such as Krupp, Daimler Benz, Magirus, MAN, Opel, Ford,...there's even a section on captured vehicles used by the Wehrmacht!Each section, organized around the manufacturer, gives the basics of the trucks the company sold to the German army. The text and captions under each picture give the specs on engine, weight capacity, suspension etc. There are a lot of good photos of each type of truck including manufacturer pics, prewar photos and pictures from wartime. The "Maultiers" or mules are covered with their Carden-Lloyd suspensions.This is a good volume running 207 pages in all showing the trucks used by the Wehrmacht. This is a good book on a rare topic not covered elsewhere in such a comprehensive fashion. I recommend it with five stars.

Quest for Solomon's Mines was, unfortunately, anything but. This NOVA production tries to make as much as possible out of the mythical "Solomon's mines" and really doesn't do a very good job.The fact of the matter is that neither the Bible nor any other ancient chronicle mentions Solomon having "mines". This appears to be something invented for fictional stories. The DVD does a decent job of looking at Solomon's generally-accepted time period and does find some mines in Sinai that may have been worked at about this time. There is no evidence that the mines looked at in this video had any connection to King Solomon.The video does a creditable job of looking at ancient mining and metallurgy, talking about the early metals and alloys such as bronze that were important at that time. There was a little about mining of precious metals and the dangers thereof to ancient miners.I have purchased other NOVA productions and found them very interesting and enjoyable. This is one of a minority that is not. I do not recommend it and award it only three stars.

I bought this for a nephew as a Christmas present. It was a hit with him and I'm glad I bought it. The graphics (on one side only) are vivid, have good colors and seem like very good silk screening to me. The size was right on for his age-size so I didn't have any fit problems with the shirt.The shirt itself was a standard-weight cotton tee. I looked it over pretty good and didn't see any bad seams of long threads hanging out. It seemed like a quality shirt with a well-applied graphic. As an aside, always turn these shirts inside-out when washing-drying. I thought this a good shirt for the price and I recommend it with five stars.

I bought this for a nephew as a Christmas present. It was a hit with him and I'm glad I bought it. The graphics (on one side only) are vivid, have good colors and seem like very good silk screening to me. The size was right on for his age-size so I didn't have any fit problems with the shirt.The shirt itself was a standard-weight cotton tee. I looked it over pretty good and didn't see any bad seams of long threads hanging out. It seemed like a quality shirt with a well-applied graphic. As an aside, always turn these shirts inside-out when washing-drying. I thought this a good shirt for the price and I recommend it with five stars.

This Schiffer title, Krupp At War, highlights Krupp trucks used by the Wehrmacht during WWII. For those unfamiliar with Schiffer, they produce short, pictorials roughly the same size as an Osprey New Vanguard with more period photos and less text. They are usually affordably priced (under $10 most of the time).This book highlights the Krupp "Protze" (which means "limber"), a 6x4 unarmored personnel carrier designed and built from the early 1930's on. These light trucks were utilized to tow light loads and weapons. It also was modified to carry a 20mm AAA gun. They were reasonably effective vehicles for the German army though they were no as effective off-road as a result of not having all-wheel-drive. This book also gives an account of other Krupp trucks used by the Germans.There is sufficient text to give the reader an idea of the suspension, engines, load and towing capacity as well as a brief life-cycle of the trucks involved. These are not in-depth treatments on any subject and only scratch the surface. However, these books are sometimes the only information available on subjects like this. There aren't many books on non-combat vehicles like trucks, unarmored half-tracks, motorcycles etc. and help to fill in gaps in your WWII library.This is a good little book for the price, remembering that it is only a pictorial overview of a subject. I recommend it to those interested with five stars.

Got this as a Christmas present for a nephew who likes to shoot his uncle's AK-47 (safely and under adult supervision). The tee is a standard-weight cotton t-shirt. It seemed of good quality with good seams, no errant threads. He's a teen so I bought an adult small size on the advice of his mother. Fit perfectly.The graphic of Mikhail Kalashnikov's design is silk-screened on and seems reasonably sharp and even. (Remember, turn shirts with silk-screened designs inside-out when washing and drying.) It was a big hit and he really liked it. The price was right, too. I recommend this shirt to those interested with five stars.

These are very nice Christmas crackers...as long as you understand all the prizes are nutcrackers! These seem to be very well made. They have all the usual items: a folded, paper crown, a little piece of paper with a joke or riddle and trivia, and a prize. These prizes are all miniature nutcracker ornaments. They seem to be of reasonably high quality and there are enough different styles that everyone has a different nutcracker. If you have more than six people, expect there to be some repeats.We've had Christmas crackers for many years now and these certainly rank with the best we've had. You can get better crackers but you'll pay more (rightly so) and these are certainly worth the price based upon my past experiences with crackers. I'd recommend these crackers with five stars.

This Schiffer title, Arado AR196, is dedicated to the WWII German seaplane used on numerous fronts wherever the German navy was to be found.This book is only 47 pages and only intended to be a brief introduction to the subject. As a pictorial, it serves model makers and WWII aviation buffs. The photos themselves are quite good and offer both factory and military views of the aircraft though there are no color plates. It does include line drawings of the AR196 also.The photos give the reader very good views of the aircraft on the water, on ship and in the air. There are pics of the AR196 on the catapults of the Prinz Eugen and the Gneisenau. One can imagine that the Graf Spee used its AR196 to find victims for its guns! There are also pictures of the AR196 being refueled, maintained, with wings folded, on the catapult, being recovered with the German "wake" employed on their ships.This is a good, short pictorial with brief, but effective, text. For the price and recognizing its limitations, this is a four star book.

The Perky-Pet 5151 is one big bird feeder! At twenty-three inches tall, this feeder holds plenty of your favorite type of feed - we use black oiler sunflower seeds.The feeder is very sturdy with the bottom feeder-unit and the top cap made of metal. The transparent tube is plastic, but seems thick enough to last quite a while. As you can imagine, it will hold a lot of feed! The only problem is that you will need something substantial to hang if from. A standard "shepherd's hook" won't do as the weight will pull it over. I found a steel hanger I could clamp onto the railing of my deck that is set at a 45 degree angle that's sturdy enough to handle the weight.How does it work? Very well as it will hold a lot of seed. There are enough perches for small or big birds. I can't tell you if the "break away" feature prevents squirrels from raiding it because I've never seen a squirrel on it.I can say that if you are looking for a sturdy, high-capacity bird feeder, you won't go wrong with this model.

The "teen in peril" genre is a classic; I remember reading the old Lois Duncan books when I was growing up (Killing Mr. Griffin, I Know What You Did Last Summer).  Kelley Armstrong takes on that genre with a fantastic twist:  the bad guys aren't just on the outside.  They're inside as well.Specifically:  Riley Vasquez is a survivor of a terrible trauma - a few months ago the parents she was babysitting for were gunned down on their way out the door, and Rile survived by hiding under the bed with their daughter.  Now she is grappling with PTSD, anxiety, guilt, shame, depression - plus she's still dealing with the death of her cop father eighteen months ago.  She's a bit of a mess, and her mom hopes that the therapy weekend camp with Riley, six other troubled teens, and two counselors,  will make a difference.  The "camp" takes place in a huge abandoned warehouse in a bad neighborhood, which seems strange enough.  But just a few hours into the session, armed invaders storm the camp.  The kids are being taken hostage because one of them is the son of a very rich man.  Riley tries to comfort the other teens - she knows from her dad, in the vast majority of hostage situations, no one is harmed.  But things quickly go awry and soon Riley and one other teen, Max, are scrambling through the warehouse, locked in, trying to evade the bad guys and figure out an escape plan.Yes.  Max.  Max is the wild card, for Riley and the reader.  He's one of the other therapy kids - the only one Riley had met before the weekend - and he's got a serious, permanent problem.  I'm not going to say what it is. But suffice it to say, it's a problem that means the demons Max and Riley is facing in the hallways are in many ways not nearly as scary as the demons that Max is facing inside his own brain.This is a great, thrilling read.  As other reviewers have said, there's a lot of plot twists.  Nothing - and no one - is as it seems on the surface.  Many things that seem disconnected are, in fact, all tangled up together.  And through it all is the constant thread of tension driven by Max's nervous grip on reality.  It's a novel about trust - trust in others, and trust in yourself.  It's a novel about bravery - what it means, who has it.  And ultimately, it's a novel about the uncertain future that awaits us all, and how to find a way to have hope and faith when literally nothing is for sure.  I really liked this book.

"The Rest Of Us Just Live Here" is a story of four college seniors just trying to make it to graduation, four weeks away, without their family imploding - or their high school exploding.  Michael (Mikey), the narrator, is coping with a flare up of his anxiety disorder while watching his sister Melinda continue her fight against anorexia.  Their mom can't be bothered, as she plots a run for Congress, and their father would be a good guy if he were ever sober.  Henna is Melinda's best friend and Mikey's long time crush; Mikey wants to let her know how he feels about her, but the arrival of new kid Nathan is impinging on his game.  And then there's his best friend, the huge gay guy Jared, who has secrets of his own.  Like the fact that his grandmother was a goddess and cats worship him.Oh, and yes, there's also some sort of Ultimate Good vs. Evil battle going on, which is kind of par for the course for this small town, which, like Sunnyvale and Forks, seems to attract evil.  Mikey and his tribe aren't the ones who fight evil - those are the indie kids - they're the bystanders just trying to get through to graduation, and could you guys please not blow up the high school at prom?  (Early in the book, Mikey reflects on the time that the "indie kids" fell in love with all the vampires and then killed them.)It's a lot of plot, and it's a big compliment to Patrick Ness that he balances it so gracefully.  The Good vs. Evil battle is presented in the introduction of each chapter, with a brief description of all the Big Things Happening ("Kerouac discovers the Messenger lies to him; he dies, alone") while the bulk of the chapter talks about what's going on with Mikey, Melinda, Henna and Jared.  It's a sweet conceit, and of course, as the book goes on, the two stories start to become more intwined.  The story that Mr. Ness is telling, of course, is that we're all heroes; and all our lives are important; and all the stakes are life and death.  No matter who we are or how we're described.Sometimes I thought the plot and setup was right on the verge of being too cute or convoluted.  And it's not territory that hasn't been explored before - the Buffyverse spent a lot of time on the "real people" and the notion that all lives are meaningful, and you don't need powers to be heroic.  But the characters here are so well drawn (even if they're archetypes, they work), and the writing so fun, that it all works.

In 1959, young couple Nat and Paul Collier move to Idaho Falls, where Paul, a military man, is going to serve as a caretaker of the CR-1 nuclear reactor.  It is the turn of the decade, and the beginning of a new era, but Nat and Paul - and the military families around them - are remnants of an old one.  Paul is assigned to the CR-1 reactor, and it becomes clear that this reactor is a metaphor symbol for Nat and Paul's marriage, and their broader community:  old, out of date, poorly tended, overlooked - and ready to explode.  We begin the novel with a flash forward to 1961, with the marriage in tatters and the reactor melting down; then quickly circle back to 1959, when Nat and Paul have first arrived, and begin the story of how this meltdown - marital and nuclear - came to be.I wasn't sure I was going to like this book. I have a bias against MFA graduates - they often seem to value pretty sentences over powerful stories - and I thought a detailed, fictional examination of a forgotten true story from 1961 might be a little slow.  Here's the news:  I was wrong, and happily so.  While the writing can be a little precious at times, for the most part, this is a great story that rockets along.  By page 15 I was hooked:  we had a great villain, a meaningful conflict, a sense of looming danger and dread, and a terrific, richly realized setting of small town military communities, right before the whole world imploded - figuratively and, if you were in Idaho Falls, literally.The story is told from alternating perspectives: Nat and Paul tell most of the story, but we also hear from Jeannie, the wife of the man tasked with supervising the reactor - the aforementioned villain of the piece.  Jeannie gives us the long-timers' view on life in this military community, where the wives and husbands all play very precise roles, with a carefully structured hierarchy;  Nat is the young wife who has an instinctive wish for a different way of life; and Paul the lifelong outsider who just wants stability, even as he finds the world around him crumbling.I guess it's not necessarily a subtle metaphor - the nuclear reactor melting down as the marriage does, and as the hierarchy does - but it works really well.  This was a great read.  It's not that there are huge plot twists, but more the sense of impending doom, while very well realized characters head towards disaster, and we can see it coming - but we can't make them get out of the way.  I really enjoyed reading it.  I will absolutely read whatever Ms. Brown writes next.

I picked up this novel hoping it would be another Rosie Project - an offbeat rom com with a smart point of view.  And in many ways, it was.  Mr. Donovan can write and the book flows along, easy to read - which really is a compliment.  An easy read is hard to pull off.  The lead characters - Richard, an aspiring screenwriter so broke he's had to cancel his Netflix subscription, and Elizabeth, a young law associate who works so hard that her colleagues call her "La Maquina" - the machine.  Richard and Elizabeth have a contrived non-cute-meet when they are set up by a mysterious benefactor (or is he?) who, through an intermediary, offers them half a million dollars, each, if they will spend two hours together once a week for a full calendar year.  No more information, no apparent connection between the two.  Of course they accept the deal.  And of course complications ensue, both romantic and suspenseful.The extremely contrived nature of the setup was a bit much to swallow. Maybe there's a way to write a scenario like this and have it seem believable, but here, it wasn't.  The Rosie Project had a contrivance at its heart - but the contrivance was rooted in character.  Here, it feels artificial and as the story went along, and the contrivance took more of a role, the book felt less authentic to me.  I wish the author hadn't felt compelled to use it, and had been willing to trust his writing, his comic voice, and his ability to create good characters.  All of those things are present.I still give it four stars - I want to be generous to new writers, and Mr. Donovan can write.  The characters are funny and believable, and I wish we had been able to see them in a more authentic environment.  I'd read his next book.  This one feels a little bit like a warm up.

The "literary historical fiction of the little-known side character" is a new sub-genre all its own - in Aviator's Wife, about the wife of Ernest Hemingway, and the upcoming Swans of Fifth Avenue about the women who surrounded Truman Capote, and in Ms. Cullen's previous book about Edgar Allen Poe's wife, there's a lot of work about the women who lived in the background of the "stars" of history.  In this case, the story is of Isabel, Mark Twain's beloved - and eventually discarded - secretary.  The mystery that this book seeks to reveal is: what truly happened to cause the rift?  How did she go from being his closest confidant to the woman he was determined to destroy?  What did she do - or what did she know - that caused him to turn on her so viciously?It's a good mystery.  And there's a number of factors that make it a great topic for a novel.  Mark Twain has always been a fantastic character to write about - colorful, smart, funny, deeply complicated - and all of that comes through here.  Plus, the time that is written about in this novel, near the end of his life, is a little-known period of his life.  Writing about this time allows the writer to explore all kinds of things - the impact his fame has had on him, the impact his choices have had on him, and who he has become at the end of his life.  It's not always a pretty picture.  But it is absolutely compelling.  And Isabel is a worthy counterpoint:  a woman raised to be rich and cultured, who circumstances have forced into a life of service, she is smarter than you think, and more complicated herself.This is the story of how Isabel gets sucked into the late-in-life Samuel Clemens' life, what it does for her - and to her - and who she becomes in the face of adversity.  It's a terrific read, bringing to life a very specific time and place.  I don't want to give away the plot secrets, but it's a read well worth your time.  I haven't read Mrs. Poe but I will read it now.  Well done.

Steven King has said that people love to read about work.  Melanie Benjamin takes us into the "work" of being a high society wife in Manhattan, an elusive "swan" in the 1950s: the capturing and catering of husbands, the curating of friendships, the cultivation of one's image and identity, the construction of beauty and style.  Of course, the story is told largely through the eyes of Truman Capote, the ultimate outsider turned insider turned exile.  Truman famously wormed his way into this ultimate elite club in the 1950s, gaining the trust and confidence of such elusive luminaries as William Paley (godfather of CBS), Lee Radziwill, Gloria Vanderbilt and - most of all - Babe Paley, Bill Paley's wife, the loveliest swan of all.  He learned their secrets, he studied their essence - and then he betrayed them all, writing a fabulously mean, gossipy tell-all piece in Esquire magazine.  When the story was published, one of its subjects famously killed herself; one died soon after; and none of them ever forgave or spoke to Truman again.Swans of Fifth Avenue is a behind-the-scenes look at this behind-the-scenes scandal; taking us from Truman's first arrival on the scene, as the original 'gay husband' to society wives, through to his pinnacle of success with the publication of In Cold Blood and his famous Black-and-White ball; and then on to his downfall and destruction.When the book began I thought "Oh, this is going to be WONDERFUL."  Ms. Benjamin does a terrific job setting the scene, introducing the swans and Truman, and establishing a juicy, elevated world that you know is destined to fall.  This is a fantastic idea for a novel, with great characters, and it is very well realized.  However, I do feel that in the end, it tries to do too much - and maybe falls a bit short.  The biggest problem might be the scope:  the story is told from alternating points of view; all the different swans, Truman, Bill Paley.  There is so much gossip, so much backstory, so much going on, and after a while, it starts to feel a little bit like we're just on the surface of it all.  I found myself looking forward to finishing the book so I could go online and research what really happened with each of the characters.  Which is a testament to how great the story is, but also that somehow, in the execution, it's just a bit lacking.  I didn't think that Ms. Benjamin had deep insight into any of the characters - we keep darting around from one to the next - and Truman himself, who could have run the show, keeps vanishing at different points.  It's like she didn't know what story she was telling, so she tried to tell all of them; and in so doing, maybe, didn't give them quite the justice they deserved.In the end, this lack of focus and depth kept it from being a great novel for me.  But for anyone who has a passing interest in Manhattan society, Truman Capote, and delicious scandals and gossip, this is a worthy, fun read.

Dominic looks like an ordinary man - a prosecutor, musician, and transplanted Englishman living in Texas.  But he's hollow inside - a man without a conscience or a soul, a man looking for an opportunity to test his own boundaries and see if they even exist.  When a friend tells him about a way to commit the "perfect crime", Dominic takes him up on it - and naturally, things go awry.  The story of the novel is about two mysteries:  will Dominic get away with it?  And how hollow is he, really?  Is there any soul in there at all?Other reviews have noted that there are no likable characters in the book; some are bothered by that, others not.  I always find it interesting - sometimes I can't stand a book with no one to root for; other times (as with Gone Girl) it works fine for me.  In this case, I didn't find it too problematic, because the book wasn't asking us to root for Dominic.  We were meant to see, from the inside, what psychopathy (or sociopathy) looks like and feels like.  And on that front, it did a really good job.  I felt like I was living inside a hollow man.  That's a tricky thing to pull off; how can you feel emotions for a character who feels none himself? If so much of why we read is to feel something, then how can we feel something for a character who doesn't?  I guess in some ways an exploration of emptiness is, itself, an emotional experience.  I enjoyed the book.  It did leave me feeling a little hollow, but maybe that was the point.

Jerry Grey, a famous writer of murder mysteries under a pseudonym, has Alzheimer's and periodically thinks he is a serial killer. As his mind shuffles in and out of lucidity, neither he nor the reader knows what he has imagined and what he has really done. Is Jerry telling the truth? Or lying? What is real and what is a story he made up? Why does he never see his wife, who he loves so much? And if it's all his imagination, why is he carrying an earring matching the one of a girl who was killed?The fun of this book is imagining Stephen King as a killer, since Jerry Grey feels very much like Stephen King, and even sounds a bit like him. We don't know when Jerry is telling the truth, and we're not sure when he knows either.  It's a fun thriller; the Alzheimer's twist goes right to the edge of being annoying, as Jerry constantly slides in and out of sanity, but ultimately Mr. Cleave pulls it off. Great read, really well done.

I had a really hard time getting into this book.  It has an opening that didn't work for me:  the aftermath of Caroline Jacobs having said the f-word to one of the other moms at a PTO meeting.  The room is reeling in shock from her having used such language, and the first chapter is reliving what led up to this horrible event, who said what and how finally Caroline erupted in rage, and now life as she knows it is completely undone.  This is the catalyst for the entire book - leading her on a quest of self discovery back to her childhood -  and it just didn't work for me. I myself haven't yelled the f-word in a meeting, but I've been in any number of meetings when other people did, or when people got emotional or lost their tempers (including me!), in meetings with much higher stakes than basically a bake sale brainstorm, and as the catalyst for a narrative, this just didn't work for me.  So I kept reading the beginning, saying "who cares?" and then putting it down.But...since I had promised to review the book, I forced myself to keep reading.  And there are good things in the rest of the book.  It's well written, the mother/daughter relationship between Caroline and her daughter is interesting, and her journey back to childhood to figure out why she is so meek and mild gets interesting as it goes.  Ultimately, the story is a bit deeper than the f-word outburst.  But there is also a bit of "much ado about nothing" - I don't get why saying the f-word in a PTO meeting is such a big deal, or why her bullying experience in adolescence is so traumatic (we've all been there in our own way).  It's a fun, light read, but it didn't do more than that for me.

In the opening sentence of this book, two men invade Rowena Cooper's kitchen as she is putting away groceries and she realizes instantly that her life is over.  Her thoughts race to her son Josh upstairs, listening to music in his bedroom, and her daughter Nell standing on the back porch, looking out at the woods and eating a chocolate peanut butter cup that she recently negotiated.  Rowena's life is indeed at is end... but the killing spree still has a ways to go.  Minutes later, the Cooper family is down to one living member - and as Nell flees from a killer through a vacant wood, I found myself putting the book facedown to catch my breath, and I was only mere pages in.This experience repeated itself throughout the novel:  I was desperate to know what would happen next, the tension was constant and unbearable, but I found myself constantly putting the book down so I could calm down.  Not since The Hunger Games have I read a book that moved so fast, with no break in the action at all.  The book starts out at a sprint and does not slow for 400 pages.  I finished it in less than a day, in just three sittings.The author does a great job setting up characters that we care about, putting them in peril, and constantly tightening the screws.  In addition to Nell racing through the woods, he introduces Chelsea, an English ex-pat who walks past an RV at just the wrong time and finds herself re-enacting Silence of the Lambs; Valerie, the cop who has lost her lover and nearly lost her mind pursuing these serial killers, and who finds herself falling apart just as the pieces of the case start to come together; and a hermit widower, a famous author grieving his wife who suddenly finds himself the only thing standing between Nell and an untimely death.  The story ricochets between these arcs and others, and it's a testament to the strength of the novel that no matter what character you're following, you're completely invested in their story.My only criticism of the book is the ending - the last 50 pages tip over from intense action to near-parody, as different characters get shot, rally, think they're about to die, rally again, crash in helicopters, get shot once more, rise up from the snow, etc.  It almost feels like an SNL parody ending, which is a bit of a shame - but ultimately, while it made the ending less effective, it didn't detract from my overall enjoyment of the book.I will make one other P.S. statement.  This is my first time reading this author (who is being published as a debut author under a pseudonym, an interesting marketing strategy to make an old mid-list writer seem new), and whenever I read an author for the first time, I am a bit nervous - can I trust them?  Are they making me fall in love with characters only so they can kill them all and make some point about how irredeemable life is, or the triumph of evil over good?  This author does kill characters we love.  But I didn't get a sense of darkness or despond from this book.  That's important to me - life doesn't always have a happy ending, but I can't stand authors whose life philosophy is despairing or hopeless.  If you happen to share that viewpoint, then at least in my opinion, this book is still safe to read.  Just make sure that you have set aside enough time once you get sucked in!

Sophie was barely out of her teens when she started feeling off - run down, achy, with night sweats.  One doctor after another couldn't figure out what was wrong, but everyone was stunned when she was finally diagnosed: a rare cancer that had spread extensively throughout her body.  The survival statistics were grim and suddenly Sophie was looking at more than a year of chemo, extended hospital stays, and a life that seemed to be shutting down just as it was starting to open up.Of course, Sophie survived her disease.  This book was written ten years after the diagnosis, drawn from a combination of the journal she kept at the time, and her reflections now, years later.  I find it a bit difficult to review a book like this, because how can you give a negative review to a young woman's bravery under incredibly difficult circumstances?  So let me be clear, I 'm not reviewing Sophie as a person.  She seems delightful and strong.  And she's a decent writer, also; the book flowed along.But... it didn't really resonate for me.  There are a number of "I survived my illness" memoirs on the market, and all writers have to find a way to make theirs stand out.  The angle here is the wigs that Sophie chose:  when she was feeling sickly and weak, she discovered that putting on different wigs gave her different kinds of courage.  One wig made her bold, one was practical, one encouraged her to dance, one made her feel like a sex kitten, etc.  It's a nice idea.  And I like the concept that you can "put on" courage when you need it most.  But - that's sort of a good essay; it doesn't really hold up as the frame for an entire book.  And I guess that's my criticism overall.  It feels like a good essay that was fluffed out to manuscript length; literally, especially in the second half of the book, we're just reading pages and pages of journal entries that don't do much more than record "here's something that happened today and here's how I felt about it."  By the second half of the book there were no new insights and no new developments, plot-wise.Thankfully and mercifully, Sophie's treatment was successful and without incident - this is a blessing for Sophie as a person, but it removes some story elements from the book.  Late in the book, she introduces a new character - a woman with a terminal diagnosis, who knows from the beginning that she will not survive the disease - and it's possible that this could have been an interesting arc, as Sophie moves towards life and another woman moves away; but this character comes in so late and has such a brief stay, that it feels like another way to make the book longer, as opposed to a meaningful story.  By the end, I was quickly shuffling through pages, as my interest had waned.So - I like Sophie.  I admire her courage and her humor, and she can write well.  But as a work of memoir, this did not resonate as well for me.

On her second night of college, Aspen Matis - a girl so sheltered that her mother literally dressed her every day of her life - was raped by a boy she had just met.  Because she invited him to "spend the night" after the rape (the sort of confused reaction that is more understood now than it was then), the college didn't acknowledge the rape.  Not only did they dismiss her claim, but they even moved her rapist into the dorm with her, forcing her to abscond to living in a hotel room that ended up being flooded by sewer waste.  No small surprise that a traumatized Aspen (then known as Debby) decided to flee school.  Always having loved to hike, the writer decides to cover the entire Pacific Coast Trail, from Mexico to Alaska, in hopes of reclaiming her sense of self, and perhaps finding an autonomy and courage that had always eluded her.I am a bit of a junkie for true-life adventure stories, I've read scores of them, from self-published ebooks to the high profile bestsellers, and Girl in the Woods is a solid addition to the field.  While the story itself is not particularly unique (girl has trauma and loses self, girl walks trail, girl finds herself and a husband to boot), Ms. Matis has a natural, easy style to her writing that makes the pages (and the miles) fly past.  I read the first half of the book in one sitting - after picking it up just to look at the first few pages - and finished the whole thing within a day.She brings to life so many aspects of thru-hiking:  the other thru-hikers who become your tribe (whether you like them or not), how you get accustomed to stepping over rattlesnakes as if they were sticks, surviving on parmesan cheese and chocolate frosting from a can, and the glorious experience of "trail angels" - such as the locals who left a recliner,  jugs of water and piles of fruit by the trail, for tired hikers to take a break.  You experience the stress of drinking water in which a dead mouse was floating (and drinking it slowly, as if that will make you less likely to get sick), and copying by hand the xeroxed "water report" that tells you exactly how to find water in a world that's going dry.  It's a great read.Unlike another reviewer, I did not find Ms. Matis unlikable - I found her deeply human, a young sheltered girl who keeps making mistakes, but in that way, she's like all of us.  And I appreciate her courage to tell the truth, even when she's being foolish.I do wish that the book was a little bit more about her finding her own independence, instead of using the trail to discover that boys do like her, and boys can be good, and here's a boy to marry!  But that's asking her to write a different story, not her own, which is unfair.Bottom line - if you like to read these kinds of books (and who doesn't?), then Girl in the Woods is a good choice.  Enjoy!

This book was sheer fun to read.  I'm a fan of the "behind the scenes" novel - the books that go deep into a specific world.
