These novels all follow a basic archetype: young person enters a high-stakes arena, learns the ropes, learns the cost of success, and emerges sadder but wiser.  There's been a number of good ones in recent years, in the worlds of  fashion (Devil Wears Prada), finance (Bond Girl), law (Partner Track), political journalism (The List).  It's a great, modern hero's journey archetype, and when it's done well, it's so much fun to read.Well, The Underwriting is done well.  There are some ways in which it follows the template to the letter:  it covers the incredibly high-stakes world of banking, specifically, the process of preparing an IPO for an internet startup.  The frame of the novel is a new location-based dating app, Hook, sort of Facebook meets Match.com, but entirely focused on "hooking up" and finding a sex partner, and Hook's path towards going public and possibly making a whole bunch of people a TREMENDOUS amount of money. If you want the bottom line, just know this:  it's a fantastic book, so much fun to read, not high literature, but filled with great characters (heroes and villains), fun plot twists, written with an ease and a snap that makes it fly by, and a (mostly) satisfying conclusion.  That's all you need to know!!  But if you want more perspective, I have a few more things to say...The Underwriting takes on the worlds of Manhattan and Silicon Valley, both old school traditional banking and internet startups.  We go behind the scenes into both of those universes; one of the biggest departures of The Underwriting, though, is instead of telling the story of one hero, The Underwriting takes on a whole cast of characters, with rotating POVs.  So we're not following one hero's journey, we're following more like five or six - and they're not all heroes.  Some of them are decidedly villainous, but what's so lovely, is that they all THINK they're heroes.  We've got Todd, the aspiring Master of The Universe who thinks he has the world on a string and is heading up the new venture deal; Tara, the young woman on the rise, who's working like hell to meet impossible standards but starting to think she might be doing it wrong; Nick, the wannabe who's never been quite good enough but having latched onto Hook, might finally have found the right rocket to ride; Juan, the programmer with a conscience who is stunned to realize he might be set up for riches now; Beau, the son of Big Money, who seems to be just along for the ride; Amanda, the paralegal who might be underestimated by everyone, including herself; Callum, the British high financier who might have a soul somewhere inside him; and on and on.  None of these characters are hugely deep or profound, but they are all a step above two dimensional.  As the book goes on, all that matters is this:  you find yourself rooting for the good guys and rooting against the bad guys.  And Ms. Miller does a great job of stringing you along.Oh, and did I mention, there's also a murder in the middle of this?The "Hook" dating app on which the entire plot is built is a great MacGuffin too - a location based dating app that essentially is all about letting you find the closest possible sex partner.  It's skeevy and sleazy and yes, someone ends up dead early on in the novel - possibly related to Hook.  And possibly related to some of the people who work at Hook. So mixed in with all the questions of how the IPO plays out, and the corporate intrigue, is the investigation of the young woman who was killed, and the gradual revelation that it might have something to do with Hook itself.This isn't great literature, sure.  But it's a great read.  My only complaint is an unnecessary extra twist at the end that was meant to be a shocking conclusion, but came across like playing games.  Other than that - so much fun, a great summer read, and I will definitely read Ms. Miller's next book.  Congrats!

My husband and I started getting back into backpacking a few years ago, and we've been using old gear.  When I had the opportunity to try a new, updated backpack I jumped at it - and will never go back.  This pack was incredible.  It makes me want to go backpacking more often!As others have said, one of my favorite features is the pockets.  I am constantly losing things in my purse, forget a huge backpack, and being able to assign different items to their own compartment, and know I can always find them there, is a huge timesaver.  I'm just over 5'6 and had no issues with fit at all; the waist strap sat perfectly with just a little bit of work and the shoulder straps as well.  I haven't taken this on a multi-day backpacking trip yet, but have used it for hiking and traveling, and it's worked perfectly.It's less heavy, and less rigid, than our old backpacks.  It's possible that for a multi-day hike (like an Outward Bound style trip) that it might not be quite rugged enough.  But on the upside, it is SO much more comfortable, that I'm almost tempted to take it on regular travel, as an alternative to a second suitcase or carryon. It's a little bit like a Goldilocks pack - it's bigger than a daypack, lighter/smaller than an expedition pack, but for regular hiking and traveling, I would say it's just right.

Dr. Grace Blades, the survivor of a devastating murder/suicide that killed both parents and led to a long cycle of foster homes, has channeled her horrific past into a productive life as a respected psychologist with a unique gift for helping people overcome traumatic experiences.  But beneath her healthy surface, she is still grappling with demons - the compulsion to put herself in dangerous situations, often with unknown men.  She thinks she has things mostly under control, until one morning a new patient comes into her office - and they both realize that he is the same man she had dangerous sex with the night before.  This is unsettling enough, and becomes even more so when that same man turns up dead the next day, and the police come to Grace, looking for answers.  And as Grace herself begins to investigate, she comes to realize that this man might not be the stranger she thought he was... that in fact, she might have met him for the first time a very long time ago, under very different circumstances than these.This is a nifty setup for a novel, and let me say, there is one thing about this book that is absolutely stellar: Grace herself.  She is one of my favorite characters in a very long time.  The story of her past, which unfolds in alternating chapters with the story of her present, is absolutely compelling.  You root for the young girl who is so terribly abused, who has to figure out how to build a life - and a self - with very little help from anyone else.  When Grace finally begins to find a bit of home, piece by piece, it is so incredibly moving.  Even more so because there's not a traditional happy ending at any point along the way; just a series of small victories and setbacks, hard work and fateful blessings, that are just incredibly moving.  I was riveted to the story of Grace's past, what happened to her and how she got to where she is when the book begins.The part of the book that worked slightly less well for me was the present day mystery/thriller.  The opening paragraph describes the setup, and it's a doozy.  Halfway through the book I would have given it five stars, no question.  But it got a bit bogged down in the present day story.  While the alternating chapters that deal with Grace's past are wonderful all the way through, the chapters that deal with the current mystery fell a bit short for me.  There is one nice reveal, but it's revealed early, and after that, there is very little plot development in the present day.  Grace literally drives around doing little things, and it almost feels like the present day story is biding time waiting for the more interesting backstory to play out.  I found myself starting to skim the present day chapters, getting a bit impatient; but the "who Grace is and how she got here" story is riveting all the way through.Bottom line, I definitely recommend this book.  I loved Grace, and rooted for her, and loved hearing her story.  The one downside is it got a bit sluggish about halfway through, in the present day chapters - but that being said, still very worth reading.  I'd read more Grace stories in a heartbeat.(P.S.  I also appreciated that this was a standalone.  I used to like the Alex Delaware novels, but fell behind a long time ago.  It was nice to be able to read something fresh from this author, who I've always enjoyed.)

I suspect that more people know the backstory of this manuscript than know about the actual story inside the pages.  The backstory:  book sells for $2 million after an intense auction featuring most of NYC's publishing elite; editors from around the industry describe it as the best thing they've read in years; the author describes it as his attempt to create a novel version of an HBO boxed set; this is the book that is the epitome of the best publishing has to offer.MAN I have been looking forward to reading this since 2013, when the auction was held.  I am such a sucker for big epic novels. I literally shrieked with excitement when I got hold of the manuscript.But...Look, in terms of the book itself, comparisons have been made to DeLillo and Pynchon and David Foster Wallace, and granted, I don't love any of those guys - so maybe this book was not for me right from the start.  And Mr. Hallberg can definitely write.  He has a way of creating a scene where you feel like you are actually right there, almost living it alongside the characters. The "HBO Box Set" comparison is apt.  He creates a very precise world of New York City in the 1970s that is so tangible you feel like you're watching it on TV, or in a movie theater, not reading it on a page.  It's seriously impressive.But....In many ways, this book is written like a checklist of "how to appeal to the stereotypical publishing literary elite."  It takes place in the 70s. There are rich people who reject their wealth and feel disenfranchised.  There are poor people scraggling for their place in the world.  There are older men having affairs with teenage girls.  There are obscure (fictitious) punk rock bands.  And drugs.  Many drugs.  Most important, everyone takes themselves VERY VERY seriously.  I don't think anyone in this book has a sense of humor.  It all feels like a book written for editors, and for publishing houses, not for readers.  There's craft here, but there's not much passion, or joy.  (I don't mean joy as in Pollyanna happiness.  I mean the sense of joy you get whenever you read a great story that the author is telling with energy and skill.)  And with each page that turned, my heart sank, a little bit.It's one thing to know the backstory of the book - the sale at auction, the huge advance, the industry buzz.  It's another thing to be more than 100 pages into the book and still more interested in how this book was published than in the story itself.  And no matter how long I read, I just couldn't get invested.  It all felt constructed, and forced.  I didn't care about the characters.  I wasn't interested in the story.  I found myself making up excuses to read something else, instead of getting back to this.It was a big disappointment.  I was almost disappointed in myself, for not loving it.  But I finally had to admit, 200 pages in, I just didn't want to keep going.  Like I said, I'm not a fan of DeLillo or Pynchon or David Foster Wallace's fiction (love his essays).  So I might not be the target audience.  And if you love those guys, then give this one a try.  But for me, the story inside the pages was never as good as the backstory, and I finally let it go.

There is something really lovable about this book.  Of course, it could be the story - a story so filled with American archetypes that it's hard to believe it's not made up.  It's almost a roster of the classic American narrative, all packaged into one neat story.1.  Rising Up By Your Bootstraps/Triumph of The Underdog.  Jesse Brown is an African American sharecropper's son who grows up tending to his younger brothers, clearing the swimming hole of snakes so they can cool down after a day in the fields, and reading books to better himself.  Through his mother's love and "devotion", he lifts himself to become the first African American carrier pilot, fighting for his country.2.  Bravery and Righteousness.  As if we don't know that Tom Hudner is a good guy, he is introduced in the first scene defending the honor of an overweight boy being picked on by bullies; Tom stands up to the bullies when all his friends are too scared, and when the bully backs down to shake his hand, Tom learns an Important Lesson about being willing to help others.  A lesson that (spoiler alert!) will come in handy when Jesse is shot down behind enemy lines.3.  Military Sacrifice.  It's interesting that this story is told about the "Forgotten War" - it's true, except for MASH, most people don't tend to think about the Korean War.  This book does a good job of bringing that conflict to life, especially the sacrifice and loss that its soldiers faced.  If nothing else, it is a fair and just reminder of the service these young men gave to their country, and the cruelty of how we have discarded them in history.4.  True Love and Friendship.  At its core, this is a book about relationships, and the "devotion" of people to one another.  We see it in the relationship between Jesse and his family, Jesse and his wife Daisy, and most importantly, Jesse and Tom.5.  Civil Rights.  Our treatment of African Americans has been called "America's original sin," and this book does a good job of showing that original sin in a very specific setting: the Korean War, and the servicemen there.  The friendship between the privileged white boy and the sharecropper's son can skirt the line between an archetype and a cliche - if it were a novel, I might find it a bit cliched, but honestly, it's so sincere that I went with it.6.  Survival.  Everyone loves a good survival narrative, me most of all, and this is a good one.  There's the long term survival of growing up poor in the South as a young black man, and the immediate survival of being shot down behind enemy lines.So yes - this book draws on all of those narratives at once, and ultimately it's irresistible.  This isn't to say that it is without flaws.  The writing can be a bit superficial, and the characters two dimensional:  the good guys are fully good, the bad guys are fully bad, it has sort of the flavor of an old time Spaghetti Western, with dialogue to match.  We are introduced to our hero Tom, as I mentioned, when he stands up to bullies, and the dialogue is quite literally along the lines of "We should do something about this," and "I'm not getting mixed up in this," etc.  And we're introduced to Jesse when he stands up to bullies who spit on him from a school bus.  Throughout the book, the dialogue and scenes just feel a bit like reruns of narratives we've heard before.  But - there is no denying their archetypal power, and ultimately, I found it irresistible.

I'm not sure why I ordered this book, but I'm glad I did.  It was a delightful little surprise.  The Seven Good Years is a series of very short vignettes that take place in the first seven years of Eigar Keret's sons' life - which also happens to mark the last seven years of his father's life.  Apparently, Mr. Keret is an accomplished fiction writer, but I confess I have not read any of his work before, so I went into this knowing nothing about him.  I came out surprised and touched and won over.  Each essay is very short - one to three pages - and touches on a small moment in time, like the moment of his son's birth that coincided with a terrorist attack, so the hospital staff was distracted tending to attack victims; or a brief reflection on why he enjoys plane travel.  The essays are so short that they feel lightweight, almost effortless; but there is craft and structure behind them, and interspersed throughout these tiny little musings are very big thoughts - about his father's illness and decline, about family responsibilities, about life itself.  But since he's writing about such tiny little moments, in such small snippets, it somehow feels both light and fresh.  The impact sneaks up on you.  This is a great book to read between other, heavier books; it's like sorbet with real nutritional value.

Jen Lancaster is a fascinating case study, from a psychological standpoint  - a deeply flawed but somehow still relatable woman who's chosen to record her life through a series of memoirs. Each memoir claims to have some sort of mission, some sort of self-discovery project attached, but with each book, the mission has become more and more flimsy, until at this point we're essentially just reading Jen's annual diary with a weak framing device.  I can't resist continuing to read her books, out of sheer curiosity to see how she evolves - she's like her own Housewives series, a comparison I think she would enjoy -  but I think my patience might finally have worn out.  Here's why.1.  The bucket list is lazy.  The entire point of this book is a bucket list, and she says the frame is to push herself to try new things.  First up on the agenda:  ride a bicycle.  I thought, well, that's aiming pretty low, in terms of pushing yourself - but she goes even LOWER, by deciding that instead of getting a bicycle, she will get a three-wheeled bike - an adult tricycle.  She tries to mine humor out of this (haha! see the adult woman trying to ride a tricycle and failing!), but it felt like weak humor.  And it's emblematic of the book in general.  These are the items on her bucket list:  take a trip to Rome (i.e. go on vacation), ride a bicycle (which becomes a tricycle because a bicycle is too hard), run a 5K (not a race - just a 5K - which she doesn't actually end up doing because again, too hard), lose some weight.  These are the easiest bucket list items I can imagine, and the minute any of them get hard, she quits:  the bicycle becomes a tricycle, the 5K race becomes a 10K walk with friends, the trip to Rome with a group becomes her own vacation with her husband.  There are SO MANY inspiring books on the market about people actually trying to do hard things, pushing themselves, overcoming obstacles - and none of that is here.  If something is hard, Jen gives up.  Weird lesson.2. The writing is lazy.  Jen's humor has always been right on the edge of "mean girl" territory.  When she was an underdog, either because she was poor (Bitter is the New Black) or heavy/insecure (Such A Pretty Fat), her cruel edge could read as a defense mechanism, and was understandable.  But now it just reads as nastiness.  I listened to this on audio book and at one point, she spent literally twenty minutes making fun of a family sitting beside her on an airplane.  It was sort of easy target humor (the dad is stupid, even though he's a neurosurgeon, the kids have sticky lollipop fingers, the skinny mom is obsessed with her phone), and it goes on forever.  It's just - not funny.  The observations are trite, and kind of mean, and don't advance anything.  Her trip to Rome is the "highlight" of the book, sort of the center of the narrative, and she spends probably an hour (again, audiobook) describing why she decided to fly first class, the experience of checking her luggage, the annoying people on her flight, what she did during her first class trip,  etc.  When she gets to Rome, it's an extremely ordinary narrative of eating good food and walking and seeing the Vatican - the sort of thing you can read in literally any random travel blog.  Her big insight?  People in Italy can eat Italian food and not get fat because they don't eat too much of it.  And Europeans enjoy their lives and don't rush around as much as Americans.  This is the kind of insight that anyone who has ever read one sentence of any person's trip to Italy will accomplish.  The funny just isn't funny.  At one point, I was listening to the book, and she described American energy as being akin to "a rapidly deflating balloon careening about".  I thought, huh, that's a good line.  And IN THE BOOK, her husband said "Oh, that's a good line," and she said, "Thanks.  Professional writer."  I sort of laughed, that when she actually had a good line in the book, she had to point it out to us, so we didn't miss it.  It's just the sort of weird self-consciousness that pervades the whole thing.3.  She's smug.  Again - this sounds mean.  I apologize for that, I do.  But it's just my honest reaction.  She spends a weird amount of time lecturing people on bad behavior in the book:  the family on the flight who take up too much time getting to their seats, parents who spend too much time on Instagram and not enough time enjoying their kids, people on social media who are mean to her, etc.  There's a big feeling of "I am better than everyone else."  Once upon a time, she had a sort of self-awareness about her flaws that made her somewhat relatable.  But as time has gone by, she seems to be less willing to be self-aware of her own weaknesses, and more intent on exposing those of other people.  I think she has been so rewarded for her mean girl schtick that at this point, she thinks it's delightful, and doesn't even see it when she's being cruel.Which begs the question - why do I keep buying her books, when I've found them lately to be so consistently disappointing?  I guess it's for the same reason I keep watching Housewives shows - there's this weird compulsion that I have to see what happens to her over time.  To see if she learns, if she develops, etc.  But this last book was SO boring, honestly, that maybe it is finally the one that will get me to change the channel.

Annie Holleran has known all her life that she has a secret - her Aunt Juna, a woman who fled from town in scandal years ago, is really her mother.  Her father is unknown but, she suspects, might be the man who's buried at the town crossroads, the victim of a public lynching some years back.  As the novel begins, it is the day of Annie's ascension - the day she becomes a woman - and when she goes to the well at night, following town tradition, to look into the water and see the face of her husband, Annie does not see the vision of her future.  But she does find a body; the body of the mother of the lynched man.  And all her family's secrets come bubbling to the surface once again.  Who are Annie's parents, really?  What sins did her Aunt Juna commit? Is Aunt Juna set to return - or was she herself killed, all those years ago?The novel flashes back and forth between Annie's story, set in 1952; and the story of her Aunt Juna and her mother, Sarah, in 1936.  It's a common enough device, and it works here pretty well.  In fact, for me personally, I would say "pretty well" about describes the book.  It checks off the boxes of a basic gothic Southern thriller.  Family mystery, good atmospherics, people with secrets, etc.  I guess maybe for me, the shortcoming is that it all just feels a little too "by the book" so to speak.  It's well written, but somehow, it didn't for me have a sense of originality or urgency.  It felt like many books I have read before, and will read again. I was skimming about two-thirds of the way through, just cruising to look for the ending resolution, not feeling too invested in the characters.So - if you like gothic suspense novels, then this is a good one.  But for me, just a little bit too ordinary to be memorable.

The idea of a professor falling for his student, and an ensuing love triangle, is not a new one. And in some ways, this novel doesn't break new ground: after Charlie, a new teacher at a prestigious prep school, falls for a young student but doesn't allow himself to cross that line, ten years pass - and then the student returns; now grown; and Charlie feels he can overcome their past, and even connects her to his charming half brother. But the past is never really past, and neither Holly nor Nick are exactly who Charlie thinks they are.This is an odd book, in some ways. It definitely has a literary style to it, in the writing, which is reflective and careful. But the events often veer towards melodrama, and the setup (as you might be able to tell from the paragraph above) is a bit convoluted.  It feels like a lot of work to deliver a pretty standard scenario. In the end, it's a nice classic execution of the classic boarding school coming of age novel.

A year after getting divorced from an addict and losing a baby (on the same day), Helen decides to take a three-week wilderness adventure course, to reboot her life.  (Maybe Helen read Wild.) She's irritated when her younger brother's best friend Jake announces that he's going to be on the course as well, and reluctantly agrees to road trip cross country with him, to the start of the adventure.  Much to her surprise, she finds herself falling for this much-younger man on the road trip, as he reveals hidden depths.  But a misunderstanding derails their closeness before it gets off the ground, and as the trip begins Helen has instructed Jake to pretend they're strangers.I was expecting this novel to be primarily a survival story, about Helen in the wilderness.  The beginning of the book plays up that this is not an Outward Bound course, but a really dangerous course where people often die.  (That seems unrealistic; no commercial outfitter could survive regularly killing their customers; but I'll suspend disbelief.)  In truth, it's more of a chick lit style romance novel, the story of Helen and Jake, in a wilderness setting.  After all the setup, I was a bit disappointed that there wasn't more of a "danger" element in the wilderness; it really was a basic Outward Bound course.  That's not necessarily a complaint, I love Outward Bound, and shoot, Wild didn't depend on Cheryl Strayed being in mortal peril.  It was just a bit of a setup that didn't pay off, and a tiny bit more of a romance read than I was expecting.  But thus endeth my complaints!  This book was just completely delightful to read.  Ms. Center has a terrific sense of humor and the book was genuinely funny.  The story races along like a sailboat under a stiff wind.  Some of the characters are two-dimensional, but others are really not - the trip leader, Beckett, develops nicely; Jake and Helen are strong; and Windy, a gorgeous California blonde studying to become a pet psychologist, makes the third leg of the romantic triangle and fills it out really well.  There's a bit of emotional depth from Windy's study of positive psychology and the neuroscience of practicing happiness, and Helen's journey to try that on herself is really touching and rings true.The last third of the book, possibly, is a bit cliched; I won't give spoilers, but let's just say that Ms. Center has studied romantic comedy conventions.  There's no "race you to the airport to declare my love" scene, but most of the other basics are well covered.  :)  But I won't hold that against her.  I loved this read; it was funny and sweet and offered a bit of emotional depth.  I read it in one sitting, late into the night.  Definitely recommended!

I don't usually read short stories, but I picked this up after seeing it on a list of anticipated books for the year.  I'm so glad I did!  It reads like an extra-smart romantic comedy, with a lot of sharp edges, but still funny and smooth.  Too often, to me at least, short stories read like class writing assignments - more about technique and craft than story, often they feel more like something to be admired than to be enjoyed. And in a short story, it is definitely more difficult to get emotionally invested in a character, or to feel a change.  But these stories resonate.  The leads are mostly a range of young women, with a recurring character who shows up in a number of pieces, who share the fact that they are looking for love and a place to belong, and struggling with it.  There's a woman in an unsatisfying relationship with a long time live-in lover, who wants to leave him at the same time her beloved dog is dying.  There's the woman having an affair with a married man, whose ex wife wants to meet.  There's the girl living with her platonic roommate who wishes - and sometimes pretends - that he were her actual boyfriend.  Each story is specific and insightful.  I enjoyed this very much.  Is it wrong that I now would like her to write a novel?

Claire is a forty-something mom of a teenager and a three year old.  After an accidental pregnancy that forced her to leave school and struggle through her twenties and thirties as a single mom, she finally has her life on track:  a great new (younger!) husband who adores her, a delightful toddler, and a good relationship with her older daughter - in college herself now - and her mother, who's always been there for her.  But even in the book's first scene, this delightful, hard-earned life is unraveling, because Claire has just found out that not only does she have early-onset Alzheimer's, but the disease is progressing far quicker than anyone ever expected.  She is already having a hard time connecting to Greg, her beloved husband.  And as she struggles with the progression of her disease, she also struggles with how to be a mom to her older daughter, who has a secret of her own, and her younger daughter, who still sees Claire as a really great playmate - but for how long?  And why does she feel strangely drawn to Ryan, the stranger who keeps cropping up in her life at unexpected times, and seems to understand her struggles better than anyone else?This book has received comparisons to JoJo Moyes' "Me Before You," and to Lisa Genova's "Still Alice."  The second comparison makes more sense, because it deals with the same core issue - a mid-life woman trying to cope as she watches her sense of self slip away.  I liked this book, but for me, it didn't quite have the emotional authenticity or resonance of Moyes' or Genova's work.  The characters are just a bit two-dimensional, the scenarios just a bit too neat.  The relationships between the three main women - Claire, her daughter Caitlin and her Mom - are well drawn, as are all three characters.  There is something so appealing about good, flawed people trying to take care of each other.  It is in many ways my favorite kind of story.  There are two weaknesses here that keep this book from standing out for me as really special.  First,  the relationship between Claire and Greg, which is supposed to be the heart of the story, is the weakest of all.  We don't know him as well, we don't know what their relationship was really like, so losing it doesn't feel as tragic as it is supposed to.  It also doesn't make much sense that Claire would forget Greg so quickly, and remember everyone else in her life. Second, is the handling of Claire's disease.  It feels a little bit like her disease symptoms come and go based on what the plot needs - whenever Caitlin needs Claire, suddenly Claire "comes back" and is fully herself again.  It almost is too sunny a view of the disease; as someone who lived with a loved one who went through a loss of self, I can say that the hardest part is that they don't "come back" when you need them most.  To have Claire able to function almost perfectly so often, but then unable to recognize her own husband at the same time, just doesn't feel real to me.And yes, there is a twist in the story, but I both saw it coming and found it unbelievable.  The twist hinges on Claire having a blind spot that there is not a shred of evidence that she really has, and it feels like something the author did so she could say "Look at my plot twist!"In sum, a sweet story, but lacking in the sort of emotional resonance and authenticity that the really best writers in this genre can deliver.

I admit it, I'm a bit of a junkie for the survival thriller: people lost or people being chased in high mountains, ideally with a storm coming in.  It's one of those genres I will read happily in most circumstances.  This is a really good entry in that genre: four people, a young man plotting suicide and three women on a joy trip, happen upon each other.  We know from the beginning that one of the group does not make it down; the book is being narrated by the young man, Wolf, telling the story to his son years and years later, explaining this great mystery of his past. It's really well done. The adventure scenes are well written, and the shifting relationships between the characters, and within Wolf himself, are also strong. It's a change of pace for Lori Lansen, who has written more traditional "literary" works in the past, to dip into this adventure style, but she acquits herself well. I really liked it.One odd note - the publisher compares it to Cheryl Strayed's "Wild," and Krakauer's "Into the Wild," which I found a bit cheesy - those are nonfiction accounts of true survival/spiritual growth stories, and this is, you know, a NOVEL. It's a different beast, so to speak, and the comparison feels a bit disingenuous. But I'm not going to hold it against the book!

Dana Catrell's neighbor and budding friend, Celia, is found brutally murdered one night.  At first we think Dana is just a good person shocked to see a friend die. But it quickly becomes more than that. Dana is bipolar and possibly off her meds; she can't quite remember what happened earlier that day, except that she remembers Celia calling Dana to her house to show her pictures of Dana's husband having an intimate lunch date with another woman. Why did Celia have those pictures? And, as Dana starts to investigate, why was Celia's number on her husband's phone? What was really going on between them? And what did Dana do about it?The unreliable narrator is a pretty common device since Gone Girl, and at first I regretted choosing yet another domestic unreliable narrator thriller to read. But this was a good one.  The writing is strong and the real device here was the question of Dana's husband: who is he, really? What did he do? So the unreliable narrator, and Dana's mental illness, is just one element that adds to the mystery, which itself is well done. I thought the writing was strong and it was exciting.  More than Gone Girl, it reminded me of the really good thriller from a few years back, Before I Go To Sleep.  Very much recommended and better than most of its peers.

Now that she's four years past her breast cancer, Daisy and her husband, Jack, are finally ready to reclaim their lives.  He's about to graduate from veterinary school, she's well into her graduate studies in psychology after delaying school when she was sick, she's happily renovating her fixer upper dream home, and they're even starting to think about a baby.  She barely pays attention to her four year cancer check up - but then the bottom falls out from under her.  The cancer is not only back, it's "everywhere" - it's not treatable - and she's going to die soon.So what does she do, in the time she has left?I picked up this book because I saw the comparisons to JoJo Moyes' "Me Before You," which is still one of the best reads I've had in the last several years.  I know there is a lot of "dying porn" literature out there - the whole Love Story genre of young women succumbing tragically; I don't actually like this genre so much, but the reviews made me think this one was like Moyes' book, a cut above.It was, and it wasn't.  This is a well written book, and Ms. Oakley has some talent.  I liked Daisy.  But there was a flaw at the premise, and for my taste, the writer ultimately couldn't resolve it.  The core issue here is that when Daisy and Jack first get the news, they go into denial.  That's probably realistic.  But it lasts for a long time - a very, vey long time - and ultimately, reading a book about a couple who are frittering away the last few months they have together just gets frustrating.  There is also a very strange sub-plot where Daisy first becomes determined to find Jack a new mate (I find this really unbelievable; they've been married for just a few years, and he's a handsome young veterinarian; I don't believe that she doesn't think he could find someone on his own) - and then it veers into a question of whether he is cheating on her.The book raises really difficult questions of what do you do when you just have a few months left to live, instead of your whole life - and then doesn't really have the nerve to answer them.  So, here's my final recommendation:  if you like this genre, the beautiful death genre, then pick up this book - it's well written and easy to read.  But if you're looking for a really standout book, or real insight into the hard questions of life and death, for me, those questions aren't really addressed here.

Lindy was the lovely neighborhood girl that all the boys - or at least this one boy, in particular - watched as she ran through their modest neighborhood of Baton Rouge, circa 1989.  She had long legs and a Schwinn bicycle, she liked to race the boys, and every night she went to track practice.  She was the magical girl of a magical youth.Until somebody raped her, and the magic stopped forever - for Lindy, for the children of the neighborhood, and for the boy who loved her from a polite distance, who narrates the story...who was one of the four suspects in her rape.My Sunshine Away will get rave reviews and it will deserve them.  It does a beautiful job evoking a very specific time and place - Baton Rouge, Louisiana, from 1989-1992.  You can feel the heat and smell the swamp rising behind the back yard, and hear the cicadas in the growing dark.  And through all the magic of gathering moss, you can feel the sense of dread, emanating most particularly from the Landry's house, the 300 pound, ominous psychiatrist who takes in a series of broken foster children and is himself the boogey man for the local children.I can imagine the book was pitched as To Kill A Mockingbird meets Gone Girl, and if it wasn't, it could have been - a coming of age story of innocence lost, set in a very specific Southern place, but instead of the innocent child narrator Scout, we have a possible Amy or Nick - an unreliable narrator who might be an observant child - and might be a rapist.  It's a great idea for a story, and this is a great writer.  But it didn't quite work all the way for me.  I think because Mr. Walsh wanted to play with the question of "did he or didn't he do it?" then we never get to know the protagonist in the same way we knew Scout.  It's a device that is tricky, because if he's innocent, it seems odd that he would write an entire book implicating himself as a possible predator; and if he's guilty, then it changes everything about the story.  For me, the structural requirements of the framing device - that we cannot know the truth until the very end -- keep the story from fully working.  This book is not about a mystery that the narrator himself is learning (as in To Kill A Mockingbird); it's about a secret that the narrator might be keeping.  And after a while it became a bit frustrating, and a bit unbelievable.  So it's not a home run for me.  But this is definitely a writer to watch, and I suspect many people are going to love this book.

I missed this book earlier this year, but picked it up after seeing it on a number of "best of year" lists.  I'm so glad I did!  It's beautifully written, short and poetic and almost like a stream of consciousness - but compulsively readable.  I kept stopping to read sentences out loud to my husband.  I admit, that nine times out of ten I won't like a book like this - I like narrative, and story; and this book is mostly impressions and ruminations, as a wife thinks back about her marriage.  But for some reason this book was incredibly easy to read and captivating.  I think that's because the sentences are simple, even as the ideas are profound - making it easy to read, and something you keep thinking about.  Totally recommended!

Annie Black is living the good life in San Francisco - a successful husband, a teenaged son and two younger daughters, an interesting career as a lighting designer. But as the book begins, we learn that it has all unraveled on her - her son was involved in life threatening automobile accident, his life hanging in the balance, and somehow Annie's past is responsible. The book is written as a letter, a confession, to her son, as she tries to explain what happened in her time as a young adult  in London so many years ago, and how that year in London has echoed through to his life today.There is much to like about this book - the milieu of London and San Francisco are well set up, and the writing is clean and tight; and the dilemma of past wrongs destroying your present is a universal one. But I couldn't connect with this book as I wanted to. For me, the characters didn't really pop - I didn't care enough about Annie to care what happened to her; her husband was very underdeveloped, and the son whose life is in the balance is not really a character either. I also thought that the whole framework - present day to past, teasing out the mystery - was so slow as to get frustrating. I found myself impatient with both Annie and her story.

This review is tricky to write.  I will just share my impressions, in order, as I used it.1.  Why is the key pocket BEHIND the phone pocket, instead of in the sleeve?  The way this works, the extra pocket (for keys, sports gels, etc.) is behind the phone pocket.  Meaning once you have tucked your stuff in there, you can't get at it again without taking the whole thing off.  This is still a bad design, I think, BUT it didn't bother me when I used it.  I thought it would make the armband uncomfortable, with the phone pressing against my key pressing into my arm.  It didn't.  HOWEVER, it did mean that you can't get into the extra pocket, so it's not a place you can put sports gels, etc.  Boo.  (Seriously, why didn't they put it on the armband alongside?  This makes no sense to me.  None at all.)2.  Man, this is tight.  I had to really wriggle my phone to get it in there, take it out of its case, etc.  I saw some reviewers say they worried about the phone breaking, and I can see that.  It actually made me kind of nervous to have my car key jammed so hard up against the phone and everything pushed to the breaking point.  But it worked fine, once in there.3. Hm.  Why isn't there a hole for my headphones?  There's a little flap at the top, which is meant to go down over both the phone and the back pocket, but without a hole for the headphone jack, the flap just sort of sits there, half open.  Meaning there is nothing to keep the phone and (more important) the key behind the phone from popping out.  Maybe that's why they had to make it so tight?  Why didn't they put a hole in the top for the headphones?  Why doesn't it seal?  This is weird.4. The phone actually works well through the sleeve.  Of all the sports armbands I've used, this is the best in terms of being able to operate the phone while it's in the sleeve.  Bonus points!!5.  The sleeve was comfortable to wear, stayed in place throughout, and nothing came out.  Excellent!Okay.  So the bottom line - I had three big reservations right up front, where I saw design flaws.  But it worked fine, in use.  I remain puzzled about the design decisions - after all this experience in the marketplace, why in the world would you advertise "a pocket for your keys and sports gels" but then put those things where you can't reach them?  Why would you make the fit so tight as to have people nervous about breaking their phones?  And why not create a slot for the headphones?  Weird. So if those problems don't bother you, especially if you feel like your phone fits in there okay, then I say this is a fine product.  But I also believe there will be better ones on the market.Update: After using it a few more times, the one other concern I have is about the key in the extra pocket. On my last few runs, I have had to push the key back down as it started to ride up and out of the pocket over the course of the run - and since there is no sealed top (see point 3 above), there was nothing to keep it in place. So I have to remember to watch the key and tuck it back in, which I don't like.  Otherwise it continues to work fine.

This book claims to offer a comprehensive behind-the-scenes look at the Sound of Music - from the origins of the real Von Trapp family, to the making of the movie, the marketing of the movie, and what has happened since.  It's written primarily from the point of view of the director, Robert Wise, and the writer of the movie, Ernest Lehman.  I love "behind the scenes" books and I love Sound of Music, so I expected to love this book.  But ultimately, I thought - eh.  Here's why.1.  There's not much new information here.  The main backstories - about Christopher Plummer hating his role on set, the critics' tearing it apart, the differences between the real Von Trapps and the movie Von Trapps, the casting of Julie Andrews -- all of that has been extensively covered before.  It honestly felt like this book was less new information and more old quotes and interviews repurposed for this book.  Think of a superfan going through all his old collection of Sound of Music memorabilia, and putting it together into one master file.  That's this book.  Now if you haven't read much about Sound of Music before, this might be new to you, and you might like having it all in one place.  If so, definitely get this book.2.  The new information is not as interesting.  This book spends a great deal of time with the below-the-line makers of the movie - the cinematographer, production designer, costume designer, etc.  I suspect this was to give something that hadn't been covered before.  But it wasn't that interesting, really - sort of like reading a bunch of Wikipedia entries for people who worked on the movie.  There isn't any true insight behind the scenes, even for those people.3. The sourcing is strange.  There's very little direct quotes for attribution, and honestly, it does make the book feel kind of amateurish - less like a genuine behind the scenes exploration or work of journalism, and more like a really detailed Wikipedia page written by a dedicated fan. It's fine to read, but just not that special.  I almost wonder how much original research was done for this book.4.  The good gossip has already been written about before.  Probably my favorite Sound of Music read was Charmian Carr's book Forever Liesl, which told the behind the scenes of the movie from her perspective.  Much of the good stuff from this book was found first there.  If you want a good, fun "what was it like to be part of Sound of Music," read her book.5.  The analysis is fine, but kind of obvious.  Like, yes, Sound of Music is so popular because it gives us a sense of faith and family, and reassures us that life can be good in difficult times.  I think I knew that already.Ultimately, if you don't know much about Sound of Music other than seeing the movie, and you want to read it all in one place, this book isn't bad.  It's easy to read and obviously written by someone who loved the show.  But if you're looking for something original, or insightful, this isn't that book.

At the age of 26-ish, Lena Dunham was the writer, director, producer and star of her own TV show, after having written, directed and starred in a well-reviewed independent film.  Like her or hate her, that's impressive. Yet when she gets the opportunity to tell her story, in her own words, this is what she talks about:- Why she gets naked in front of the camera- Her eating habits, including detailed food diaries- Her weird obsession with her sister- Her relationship with her therapists- Extensive depiction of her sex life, her sexual experiences, and yes, the rape-not-rape, Barry-not-Barry incidentThis is what she does NOT write about in this book:- How she developed her writing voice, how she learned to write- How she came to create her first film- How she pitched her show.- How she creates her show, how the show works, anything at all about the show OTHER THAN the experience of being naked- What it was like to create Tiny Furniture (I'm not sure the movie is ever mentioned)- How she became a director- How she developed her working relationships (none of her colleagues or costars are even IN this book)In Mindy Kaling's book (WHICH I LOVED), she writes extensively about how she became good at comedy, how hard she worked, the jobs she took before becoming successful, the little steps along the way that made her successful, and a huge, long, detailed section on what it was like to be part of building The Office. All of it hysterical, and filled with tiny, revealing details while keeping her private life private. Tina Fey did the same thing.  So did Amy Poehler.  So did Neil Patrick Harris, for that matter.  All of these people wrote their books understanding that we want to know - how did you get where you are?  How did it work for you?Lena apparently isn't interested in any of that - nothing about her work, nothing about her craft or developing it.  She writes ONLY about the most "shocking" parts of her life.  It's absolutely stunning to me, how many press conferences and interviews she gives in which she complains that no one wants to hear about her craft, and they only want to talk about her nudity, and that topic has been done to death - but then in her book, when it's her choice and her voice, she does the same thing.  She does have a way with words; she clearly can tell a story.  But for all of that, I've never gotten into Girls, and I was really disappointed with this book.  I wanted to hear how a young woman, at the age of 26, developed her craft and her voice to the point where she was writing, directing and starring in her own show.  I wanted to hear what it was like to run a set, to hire actors, to fight for your vision in an industry that doesn't encourage such things in young women (and what it was like to find people who support you, as she obviously did, as Amy, Tina, Mindy and Neil all did).  None of that is in this book.  Instead, she seems to go out of her way to write ONLY about things that will be shocking and "offensive" - going for shock value and reaction, rather than inspiring or exciting us. This book was written only to get attention and to maximize the "shock value" of her life.  Fine, that's her right to choose to write that kind of book, but then don't be shocked when you get negative attention and people are offended.  I have read Tina Fey, Mindy Kaling and Amy Poehler's books again and again, relishing their wisdom, their insight, their humor, and getting inspired by their accomplishments.  I will never touch this book again.

Books arent recipes, not the best ones anyway, but Emma Hoopers whimsical debut, Etta and Otto and Russell and James is filled with delightful ingredients.  A charming premise: equipped only with some chocolate, her good boots and, yes, a rifle, eighty two-year old Etta sets off on a two-thousand mile walk across Canada to fulfill her dream of seeing the sea; a slate of winsome, irascible characters (including a talking coyote); and a lovingly rendered sense of place.  For me, thats an irresistible mix and I set off with Etta on her journey fully expecting to relish this book.I did not but if there is any fault here, it lies with me.  When it comes to narrative, I am a traditionalist.  I like books with a beginning, a middle and an end.  Emma Hooper tells this story more impressionistically, changing locations and time periods so freely I sometimes was not sure where I was, or when.  I wanted to walk along with Etta on her journey across her homeland, to see what she saw, to share in her relationships, to experience her conflicts and savor her triumphs.  Instead I often felt lost.(On a related note, I dont love the trend of writing dialogue without quotation marks.  Why make the readers job harder?  Whats gained by that?)In fairness, Emma Hooper did not set out to tell just one tale, but four, the story of Etta and Otto and Russell and James, and their shared journey through life.  If you are a reader who does not mind deviating from the map, I suspect you will love taking this journey with them.

I got this book because I absolutely loved "What Alice Forgot" by Liane Moriarty, and this seemed very similar - a woman wakes up and finds that the last five years of her life have been rewritten. In Moriarty's book, Alice did not remember her life and everyone else did. In this book, Rachel remembers a life that no one else does - the last five years have just disappeared.Ms. Atkins does a really good job setting up the conflict and characters. Right from the beginning she introduces the main characters and their relationships in a way that draws you in - the rich boyfriend who might be bad news, the platonic best guy friend she's known since childhood - sure, a little cliche, but still effective. And that's how I would describe the book as well. I read a lot of these sort of female-suspense-thrillers and sometimes they can blend together. After reading too many stale ones in a row, I had taken a break, and this was a bit of a re-entry into the genre. I would put this in the upper third grouping of books like this.  It doesn't have the emotional resonance or narrative thrust of Liane Moriarty (my favorite writer in this category), but it's clean and well written. You care about the characters and the plot moves strong and confident, like a fast flowing river. After so many of these books where nothing happens, or where it runs out of steam at the end, it was nice to read one that was so confident and forceful throughout. I will definitely read her again and hope that she continues to develop.

I've been reading the shopaholic series for decades and what is there to say? If you have read them before, then you know just what you're getting: featherweight, wish fulfillment chick lit.  I enjoy them because they're fun. And Ms. Kinsella writes with energy and genuine wit, which makes the books enjoyable. They're repetitive, sure, and somewhat forgettable (I can't even see what I missed in the books I skipped) but the characters and situations are fun.  When you're having a bad day or just want to take a break, Becky will keep you company.

I had ambivalent feelings to David Nicholls' previous book, One Day - the unexpected ending was a pretty devastating blow.  As I was reading through this one, at first I thought I was reading a pretty ordinary, if well-written and humorous, depiction of a marriage. But once again, Mr. Nicholls was hiding an ace in his hand and he played it at just the right time.It's interesting how he lulls you into thinking you are reading a normal story of a disintegrating marriage and a last-chance family tour through Europe; just as with One Day, you thought you were reading a traditional romantic comedy.  Douglas is a somewhat hapless (or is he?) scientist, long married to the perfect (or is she?) Connie, a woman just slightly out of his league.  They have a son, Albie, who is sour in what seems at first to be a normal adolescent way, and a passing, painful reference to a daughter, died in infancy long ago.  Douglas is stunned when Connie asks for a divorce, and as he trails on a last family trip through Europe, the reader (that would be me) is lulled into thinking that this is a pretty ordinary story.  I started to lag about 85 pages in (it took me a while to go from page 76 to about page 100), and I might have stopped but for two factors:  the short, one-page chapters are easy to read, and sort of propel you along.  And the reviews were so good that I wanted to hang in there.So I did.  And yes - Mr. Nicholls was heading somewhere specific, somewhere unexpected.  I won't give anything away here, except to say that once again, as in his previous novel, I felt a bit upended by where the narrative took me.  So if you're reading this and wondering where it's going, trust the author.  He's got a destination firmly in mind.

I am a running-gear junkie. I own arm bands, fuel belts, camelbaks, handheld water bottles. I'm always searching for that elusive perfect running tool that will carry water, my phone, (ideally) some sports beans, won't slow me down or feel awkward.Spoiler alert: this isn't that.I thought that this might be a useful option. In theory, here's what I like about a handheld that includes phone and water: nothing bouncing on your waist. Everything easy to reach and see. (Phone armbands are frustrating for me because I can't see my pace without stopping and twisting the band around.) Both in one hand, so one hand is still free.And yes, those benefits do apply to this product. I will probably use it sometimes, but not as often as I'd hoped. Here are the downsides: an 8 oz water bottle is pretty small. That's good, because it's not too heavy, but it also honestly isn't much water for a long run. If I'm going 75 minutes or less I don't really need water, and if I go more than 90 minutes, I need more than 8 oz.  (my other handheld is 12 oz, and my waist belts hold two 10 oz bottles.) I guess this would be a good option for a 90 minute run.The other downside is that the phone plus water bottle is actually kind of awkward to set up. Getting the phone in place (I used an iPhone 5) requires some wriggling, and the earphones don't line up, so it does take some work to get the earbud in the phone and through the hole in the case. Then once it's in, you can't easily get it out, so it's in for the duration.  The water bottle slides in and out fine, with a nice flat back that makes it snug against the phone. I will say that filling it, both times so far, I've ended up with a wet cover on the phone - not a wet phone, but it makes me a bit nervous that so much water got on the sleeve itself.Other good things - it's comfortable on the hand (although I wish it had a thumb strap instead of just sliding across my palm), and the touchscreen on the phone works well through the cover, which has been a problem on other covers I've used.So - bottom line - I will use it sometimes, but probably not too often. The small size of the water bottle and the awkwardness of the phone fit make it not as useful as I would have hoped.  The search continues!

Ten months into their marriage, Don and Rosie are living in New York City.  If you read the Rosie Project (and you really must, before reading this one - it's a better book, and important backstory), then you know that Don is a uniquely socially awkward man, not technically diagnosed with Aspergers (and he hates that term), but someone who interprets all of life with his brain.  He's an assistant professor at Columbia, and she's in medical school.  He is happily adjusting his routines to new married life, but when Rosie tells him she is pregnant, all hell breaks loose.I guess the easiest way to review this book is this: it's like every sequel to every book or movie ever, except maybe Godfather 2.  It doesn't have the magical spark of the original, it feels a bit like a retread, the characters have faded somewhat --- but if you loved the people, you'll be glad enough to see them.  And yes, some of the humor was definitely funny. Don has a unique way of seeing the world.However, for me, Don's personality felt a bit more like schtick this time, less authentic. Rosie was much more of a cliche - the anxious pregnant woman - and I honestly forgot why they had fallen in love and were so perfect together. I absolutely loved the Rosie Project, and handed it out to everyone I know. With this one, I will say, "if you loved Rosie Project, sure, why not?" But I won't go out of my way to get people to read it.

I love this book.  What else is there to say?  Florence is a terrific character - quite literally, a bit of a character, a kind of grouchy, funny, smart woman who is "a bit of a pain in the neck."  She has that kind of terrific older-literary-New-York-City life that you see in Woody Allen movies, an intellectual writer with a complicated family.  She thinks she knows what the next stage of her life has in store for her.  She's wrong.  In good ways and bad ones.This book is incredibly easy to read, with short chapters and incredibly clean prose.  It feels like it's simply written, but I know how much work there is to make writing like this feel easy.  Brian Morton has always done a good job with older characters (I loved Starting Out In The Evening, which is still the best title for a novel about falling in love for the first time when older that I've ever heard), and this is his best book. (It reminds me of the work of Reynolds Price, especially his novel Kate Vaiden.) Florence has gotten some press, and some awards.  I hope it gets more.  I would love to see him become a breakthrough star.  He so deserves it.  This is the kind of book that is in danger of not always getting published - no obvious genre niche, not a young hip writer, not a flashy or timely topic - but it also the kind of book that reminds me of the joys of reading.

This was an easy read, like drinking a vanilla latte on a cool afternoon. It's the story of two women living in a rich New York suburb: Charlotte, the bored mother in the unhappy marriage, and Allison, the artist who was widowed ten years ago. The women become friends when Allison moves to town, but when Allison starts to become close with Charlotte's husband and sister as well, then their bonds start to fray.This book was easy to read, and a perfectly fine rendition of women's fiction, if nothing special. I thought the bored rich housewife milieu was well portrayed, and the choice to make Charlotte not always likable was a good one. But some of the psychology was off: it's assumed that no one would find it odd, for instance, that an estranged husband is having private dinners with his wife's new friend; and one character is presented one way for the first 75% of the book and then given a sudden and dramatic transformation that makes little sense. In the end, a good quick read, even if I doubt I will remember it.

After barely surviving the loss of her boyfriend the previous semester, Jam has been sent away to the Wooden Barn, a small private school in New England that's a halfway house between a psychiatric hospital and real life.  Her fellow students are all broken in some way, and Jam can barely bring herself to even attend classes, not even the Special Topics class to which she has been mysteriously accepted - without ever applying - a secretive class that is taught only occasionally, to select students.  There are five students in this semester's class, all of whom are reeling from their own recent tragedies: the gorgeous dancer, the superstar stud who's lost his way, the girl in the wheelchair, the boy with the hoodie.. and Jam. Their teacher, Mrs. Q, gives them each a journal to write in. And suddenly, in the writing, each student finds that the thing they lost is returned to them.  Each student revels and is brought back to life as they find their grief erased, their lost loves returned - but as the semester progresses, each student knows: when the semester is over, when the journals end, the loss will return. And will they be able to recover, to survive their grief, this time for good?I read this book in one day, in two sittings. It is a simple and clean story and it races forward with barely a wasted word, ratcheting up the tension with a surgeon's precision. The characters hover between archetype and stereotype a bit, but I didn't mind. Think of this as Breakfast Club meets the Bell Jar; five delinquents brought together for a brief interlude from the real world, hoping in that time to find a way to emerge from their bell jar of depression, loss and grief.  It's a very well told story with universal themes and a nice new way to tell them.It's not a perfect book - Ms. Wolitzer places a lot of weight on the mysterious day when Jam lost her love forever; the real story, revealed at the end, was a surprise, but in my mind, didn't quite hold up. I will day there's a twist, and an interesting one, which I didn't see coming. I wish I could discuss this book with a group; there's a lot going on here.  And if the ending didn't quite hold up, that's okay with me. I recommend the book very much.

Fantastic read. Absolutely thrilling, brilliantly plotted, fascinating three-dimensional characters (even the bad guy is real), terrifying storyline that feels way too plausible, great plot twists, unexpected actual character development along the way, and a startling infusion of heart and humanity by the end. And it moved like a rocket ship, full throttle all the way across.  I seriously loved every page. More, please!

This is a good, if not extraordinary, upscale ghost story. It combines elements of old style gothic reads like DuMaurier with the modern twist of a Lovely Bones: troubled families, a house with secrets, a young boy coming of age.  In terms of style and scope it reminded me of Searles' "Help for the Haunted"  --- much better written than the average piece of genre ghost fiction, but lacking a bit in narrative drive. The two narrating ghosts are the most original aspect of the story, and the most engaging.  Not groundbreaking, but a good read if you like smart, spooky sagas.

I am in awe of this writer.  Reading this book is like anthropology itself; it seems less written than witnessed, as if Ms. King somehow transported herself back to New Guinea in the years between the wars, and carefully recorded all that she found there. Most of the novel is narrated in the voice of Andrew Bankson, a young, unhappy anthropologist who, after a somewhat half-hearted suicide attempt fails, meets up with he married team of Fen and Nell - Fen a somewhat surly Australian who doesn't seem to like his wife very much, and Nell, the brilliant, interesting anthropologist.  The bidding relationship between Nell and Bankson is brilliantly told, primarily through long conversations where they share their experiences in the field. You can see them both coming to life before your eyes - and as they head deeper into th field, in search of a new tribe for Nell and Fen to study, you can sense disaster looming ever closer.  The writing is brilliant; I kept interrupting my husband to read passages out loud; the story is original and fascinating; and the narrative is pure adrenaline. My one complaint is just as other reviewers said - at about 250 pages, I wish it had gone on twice as long. I loved this world and did not want to leave it. This is the first book I have read by Lily King, and I am ready to read some more.

There have been a lot of reviews talking about plot and the overall writing quality, so I'm going to talk about one concern I had going into this book:  is it too dark?  That was the most common criticism I saw of the book, and I don't necessarily like grim reads (life is grim enough), so I was hesitant.  But here's where I came out:  nope, not too grim.Yes.  There is a darkness to the book.  How can there not be?  It takes place in a desolate, dying town in Montana during the end of the Carter years.  It involves groups of people who are ostracized from mainstream, affluent America:  the poor, the disenfranchised, and the desperate.  In many ways, I thought that was what the book was about:  what happens to good people, and not good people, in desperate circumstances.Yet, I didn't find the book hopeless.  Good people, like Pete the social worker, try to make a positive impact.  There is love and friendship, even if it doesn't turn out well.  Even the "worst" people have three dimensions to them.Ultimately, I really admired this book.  It wasn't easy to read.  I think of it as being like a really fine Scotch.  It has a strong taste.  You have to sip it, not swallow.  Every sentence was precise and crafted with a lot of care, but unlike a lot of "MFA Fiction," Fourth of July Creek also has a really strong narrative and storyline.  If you like light, easy reads only, then I wouldn't recommend this book.  If you want happy endings without compromise, I wouldn't recommend this book.  But if you want a gorgeously written novel that brings to life an often overlooked world and people, if you want truly fine writing wrapped around a compelling story, then here you go.  I will definitely be tracking Smith Henderson's work into the future.

Emily Shepard is a rebellious, hard-headed adolescent girl with behavioral issues.  She is also a highly empathetic, lonely, brave and loving young woman struggling to survive after her world literally blows apart. Orphaned in a nuclear plant explosion that her father may have caused, she has fled from the hatred and judgment of her old life, and finds herself adrift.  Befriending a young foster boy named Cameron could finally offer the connection back to life that Emily desperately needs - but it could also be the start of her final undoing.  Emily tells us her story in short narrative snippets, bouncing back and forth in time; the style could be disjointed but Emily's voice is so clear and each scene so vivid that it's easy to follow.  A compelling story about a brave girl in impossible circumstances.

This review is hard to write because the source of the novel is secrets and so much of the joy of it is finding them out for yourself. So, with no spoilers, let's just say this. Madeline is a hot headed, feisty, funny 40-year-old mom who hates her first husband and his hippy wife, and is NOT happy to find them sharing her youngest daughters new kindergarten class. Jane is a sweet single Mom with an adorable angelic boy named Ziggy, who is very sweet and hopefully NOT a bullying psychopath. Celeste is a gorgeous Mom of two twin boys, perfect boys, and Celeste is serenely leading a perfectly privileged life. The three women are united by chance on orientation day of kindergarten. By the end of the day, they have made a set of enemies. And by the end of the term, one of these women may have committed murder. But who was killed? And why? You'll have to read to find out.Lianne Moriarty is the master of the narrative hook, and she shows it here. We know from the start of the book that there has been a murder at the kindergarten's Trivia Night, and the novel is interspersed with testimony from minor characters giving their reactions to the murder, talking to the police, as Ms. Moriarty unwraps what happened to lead to the killing. Her thesis, of course, is that everyone has secrets - and what happens when we try desperately to keep them, and what happens when we start to share them, is the engine that drives this story.  There's a simple tension in desperately hoping that your favorite characters are neither the victim nor the villain - because we do not know who died or who killed - and a deeper tension in wanting to know how each mom's story will play out.  The author is brilliant at weaving together lots of different stories towards a shared climax, and there are quite enough twists along the way to keep you surprised. The final one-two punch of a reveal was VERY well done.Simply put: love the book, love the author, perfect summer read.

North of Siberia, there is a chain of uninhibited, frozen islands: Jeannette, Henrietta, and Bennett. This chain is known as the DeLong islands, after George Washington DeLong. This is the story of how those islands were discovered, why they got that name...and at what price.George DeLong was a young navy captain who became entranced with the Arctic on a disastrous voyage with the Juniata, during the years when all the world was inspired by the race to the North Pole.  He became determined to find his own ship, and take his own quest.  His path intersected with two incredible characters of the time.  First was James Bennett, the profligate millionaire playboy newspaper owner who once terrified New York City by inventing and publishing a story about escaped Central Park Zoo animals going on a killing spree, and whose engagement to a society girl was cancelled by her horrified family when he peed into their grand piano at a high society party.  Bennett, a lover of spectacle, liked inventing news more than reporting it - and became enchanted with the idea of sending his own party out to find the North Pole. Second was August Petermann, a world famous cartographer who rarely left his living room, had never traveled, but somehow had fashioned himself as one of the global authorities on the geography of the North Pole. Petermann was convinced that just past the polar ice pack was an open Polar Sea, with its own glorious continent, and he convinced Bennett to fund the search for it - and Bennett hired DeLong to do so.  What happens from there is as grand and terrible as you might expect, to quote the book's sub title.There have been lots of polar exploration stories, and I doubt any of them will ever touch one of the first, Lansing's Endurance and its story of Shackleton. There was a leanness to that story - a total focus on adventure - that this book is missing. Entranced by the characters of Bennett and Petermann - who, did I mention, also has suicidal tendencies? - Mr. Sides spends the first 150 pages of the book not on the ice, but with the founder and the cartographer who inspired its launch. They are great characters and I enjoyed reading about them, but it served to divide the book a bit, losing its focus.Once on the ice, Mr. Sides also does a great job with the characters on the boat - stalwart DeLong, recently married and desperately in love with his wife; Danenhower, the navigator, who had once been insitutionalized and whose ability to handle the journey is in question; Collins, whose love for newfangled gadgets like Edison's electric lights could be the boat's savior or his own undoing; etc. Theres even an extended cameo from famed naturalist John Muir. But the best character, by far, is Melville, the young engineer/mechanic who is related to Herman, nudged whose energy, resilience, intelligence and ingenuity just might be the one thing that saves them all in the end.Once the USS Jeanette becomes locked in ice, what drove a lot of the tension for me was the question: will DeLong make it home to his wife?  Mr. Sides sets up their romance well, and intersperses their ice journey with letters Emma writes to her husband, for the years of his absence. Seeing her hope become genuine, then forced, then with desperation creeping in, is genuinely touching and you can't help rooting for their reunion.Does it come? Well, I won't give that away.  But the story is very well told. I think Mr. Sides is better with characters than he is with narrative tension; the book moved like the boat itself, gradually through deep ice, lots of time to enjoy the view, but not the right vehicle for going fast. Until the last 100 pages, the story was pretty slow.  There was 150 pages of prep time, then another 150 pages of early journey and "trapped in ice". The energy of the characters - rather than action - kept me going.  It picked up at the end as the situation got more desperate, as the boat was finally crushed by ice and DeLong, Melville and the gang fought desperately to find their way to civilization from thousands of miles away.  A great story, very well told.

I read a review that described this book as a "slow moving Gothic thriller" and I can back that up - with just a bit too much on the"slow moving" bit.  It started off strong, with the classic boarding school set up:  the shy bookish poor girl connecting with the rich spoiled girl, drawn into their family, only to discover A Big Family Secret.  It does read a bit in the style of Wuthering Heights or Jane Eyre, which is fun - the family compound where most of the action takes place sets up a nice, specific setting; and the clues to Bad Things are sweetly old fashioned - locks on all the doors, crazy spinster aunties, things hidden in the attic.  For the first 100 pages, even though it was slow, I read with optimism, expecting that it would start to pick up.  But it didn't, at least not soon enough or quickly enough to hold my interest.  I started skimming around page 150, getting impatient, and eventually petered out.  I gave it my best shot, and there were things to like about the book.  But ultimately, I was a fish that the author hooked but couldn't reel in.  She just lost me.

The Secret Life of Violet Grant tells the story of Vivian, a modern girl right at the edge of the modern age, 1964, a budding journalist (a bit of a cliche, but okay) who receives a suitcase that was lost by her mysterious great-aunt Violet - WHO?!? - just before the outbreak of World War I.  The story is told in alternating chapters between Vivian, as she tries to solve the mystery of Violet and struggles with her romantic entanglement with the handsome Dr. Paul, a pediatric surgeon who might be too good to be true; and Violet, a female scientist in an age when women did not do such things, who has found herself married to a monster and looking for a way out.  But did that way out include murder?  And whatever happened to Violet and her secret lover, who is also not what he seems?There's a certain kind of book that used to be a staple of reading - the juicy saga.  They're often rooted in the past, with a strong and diverse set of characters, some near-soapy romantic elements, a bit of mystery or intrigue to drive the story forward, and a certain richness that elevates them above the traditional straight romance novel.  I LOVE these books and wish there were more like them still being written.  Kate Morton has been writing those books lately - Forgotten Garden and Secret Keeper are great examples - and now I can add Beatriz Williams to the list.  She's been on my radar for a while, but the Secret Life of Violet Grant is the first one of hers I've read.  Now I'm psyched to go back and read her previous two.  Based on this one, she just writes your basic great, old-fashioned story.  So simple in theory, but not often executed as well as this.

Marley is a teenaged girl painfully aware of how ordinary she is - a bit overweight, "funny but not too funny," friends but no good ones, possibly a good writer but nothing special. She has a troubled relationship with her father and a loving, if distant relationship with her mother. A few years ago she was sent to a psychiatrist for an unknown crisis, but everyone thinks she's better now. No one is paying her much mind. Until she runs.  Now everyone is looking for her, most of all her father.  Only her mother - the one person who loved Marley the most - seems hesitant to fling herself into the search, though it's nearly destroying her.Interestingly, the book answers the question "where did Marley go?" almost instantly, as both Marley and her mother Rachel narrate the book in alternating chapters.  This is a nice concept because it shows us why kids run, even "good" kids - and more than that, how kids delude themselves into believing the wrong people, and how runaway plans can unravel. I found the Marley bits of the book really compelling, as she slowly (too slowly) starts to realize what she has gotten herself into.  The Rachel parts of the book were weaker; too much fretting and waiting and stewing. It's hard to sympathize with a Mom who is so passive at a time like this, and Rachel's story dragged for me. But as a look into mother daughter relationships, and an exploration of the dangers of running for a better life, I thought it was strong. It did remind me a lot of Reconstructing Amelia.
