I liked the Amelia characters better; but this book had the advantage of letting us hope for a happy ending for Marley, which drove the narrative forward.

Given the reviews, both here and elsewhere, I thought I would like this book more.  There are three sort of interlocking plots about Clarissa, an admin at a college in England, and men who may be bad men.  There's the stalker Rafe, with whom she spent one night and who is now haunting her.  There's the court case she's currently serving as a juror on, about a hooker who was gang raped by some bad men, and in whose story Clarissa finds uncomfortable parallels.  And there's Charlie, another juror on the case, with whom Clarissa is starting up a new possible relationship even as things with Rafe escalate.  None of these stories were particularly entrancing - and Clarissa herself is pretty ordinary as a lead character -- but I kept reading in hopes they would intersect in some interesting way at the end, with a twist or something to make these seemingly ordinary plot lines more interesting.  To my mind, that didn't really happen.  In fact, I thought it had a fairly ordinary ending, one you might find in a basic horror movie.  If you enjoy women-in-peril or women-being-stalked stories, and you want to read one set in England, that's well written, then pick this one up.  If you're looking for something more interesting than that, there's better choices out there.

Peter Heller has given me everything I look for, everything I need, when I read fiction.  A vividly drawn cast of credible characters, a beautifully rendered sense of place (in this case, a place I happen to love, the American Southwest) and enough plot to keep the pages turning, all told in an agreeable voice.  Any book that delivers these essentials will always get four stars from me.But this is not a four star book.  Heller also follows Stephen Kings market-tested counsel and offers his readers an insiders glimpse of not one but two unique worlds: the passion and practice of an artist and the passion and practice of a fly fisherman. In this case, these worlds are joined in one person, Jim Stegner, painter, father, lover, and angler, a man whose talent is rivaled, driven and threatened by his demons.I will not give away plot points here but bad things happen, some of them to good but flawed people, some of them to bad people, some of them caused by people who want to be good but arent, really, at least not completely, but who are lucky enough to be loved, anyway.  Which is to say Peter Heller has not merely written a remarkable piece of fiction.  He has produced a work of art.  Five stars, hands down.

As a sophomore at Yale interning in a prestigious summer program, she should have it all, but Nicole is heartbroken. Her boyfriend just dumped her and she can't stop crying, even though her family's nickname for him was "lady legs." She is barely paying any attention to the stupid doctor's appointment she has to check off her list - until the doctor tells her, first, "don't kill the messenger" and second, "you're going blind." She doesn't have ten years left to live - but she does have ten years left to see.It's not that what happens afterwards is surprising: there is sorrow, and denial, and a rash of bad decisions, and bumping into things. Lots of bumping into things.  Ultimately there is true love, of many kinds, and courage, and acceptance. It's not the facts of the story that are surprising, but Nicole is a wonderful person with whom to spend some time. She is hysterically funny, first off.  She is self-deprecating and NOT self-pitying. She doesn't always handle her problems well, but she is relatable and engaging. The way she comes to terms with her hardships - and the way she ultimately realizes that everyone has hardships; blindness is hers - is poignant and feels authentic and earned.  I liked her very much and I enjoyed the time spent in her company.  A definite fun, light, worthwhile read.

Eileen Leary wants things. She grows up in a poor neighborhood with alcoholic, well-intentioned parents and she wants more. She marries a brilliant, kind scientist, and she wants more. A bigger house, a better standing, a child... Eileen wants. But instead, Eileen is about to find that instead of getting more, she is about to suffer a great loss, a loss that will last a lifetime.Many reviews - including the Publishers's Weekly blurb - spoil the "loss" and I wish they hadn't. Finding out why Eileen's family is unraveling is a central question of the book, and the great mystery of the middle third. I think I would have enjoyed it more not knowing.  Also, this is not a book with plot to spare.  This is a 640 page novel that reads like a poem, and I mean that in good ways and possibly in bad ones.  The sentences are gorgeous and beautifully crafted. There were three chapters that were so profound I literally turned back and read them again as soon as I had finished the first time. The book is emotionally insightful into the three principal characters of Eileen, her husband Ed, and their later-in-life son Connell. Most of the book is told from Eileen's point of view, although Connell gets a voice starting about halfway through. I wept at the end. It does feel that you have witnessed a life go by.That being said: this was not my personal favorite kind of book. The publisher compares it to Olive Kitteridge, or an Alice McDermott novel. Fair comparisons - meditations on often neglected women. But those books were 300 pages. This one is 640, with very little story to show for it. It could have been much shorter, in my opinion.  I'm more of a Dickens or Donna Tartt reader: I like my big sprawling novels to have big sprawling stories to go with them. This book doles out plot very slowly, measured like medicine, a spoonful at a time. Very little happens (which is why I wish the one big development were not spoiled; there aren't others). I'm the reader who hated Middlemarch, and this book is more of a Middlemarch than a Dickens book, in terms of style: poetic and thoughtful. So I can fully recommend it for its craft and skill and emotional acuity. But if you read for story, this might not be the first book you would choose.

Henry and Beth are happily married, he a farmer, she a mom, raising two young kids.  They'll probably always get by but it will probably never be easy.  They live in a small town, fighting a way of life that's sagging. The excitement in their life comes when their childhood friend comes to town; Lee, the rock star, marrying the Hollywood actress; Lee, the poet and good guy: Lee, who has everything the world thinks you could want but somewhere inside him, who wants what Henry and Beth has... and might be tempted to take it, if he gets a chance.This is a beautifully written book.  I felt like I knew the town of Little Wing, and the people are very crisply drawn - Henry and Beth and Lee and their friend Ronny, the rodeo clown with a head injury; and Kip, the businessman with a shaky moral compass.  Like small town life itself, it's a bit slow, like the river that meanders through town on a hot day.  I don't think I would say the book is surprising, or urgent.  I started skimming a bit at the end, when it became evident where everything was going, the same way you try to hurry up your boat at the end of a long float trip, you're ready to be done and on to the next thing.  But the book was written with love, and I suspect this writer has more (and better) books ahead of him.

I have vacationed in the Ozarks and so I was looking forward to this book - it's such a terrific location, full of history and a sort of built-in sense of mystery and wildness.  And this book delivered, for certain.  The characters are precise and well developed. It definitely reminded me of Winter's Bone (the movie) and Justified - almost too dark and grim, but the writing is beautiful and there is just the faintest promise of hope at the end.  There is such a surplus of regional crime fiction out there, and it's easy for a book to get lost in the shuffle, but this one is worth finding, and the author is worth watching.

I'm always interested in books that present a behind-the-scenes look at the publishing industry, and I always like a good thriller, so this book was right up my alley.  It took a few tries to get into it - the first few chapters were a bit cumbersome - but once I got going, I sped right through it.  The Accident stars Isabel, a literary agent with a sad past who receives an anonymous submission to a life changing manuscript: an expose of a powerful media magnate, submitted by an anonymous author.  The story is told from multiple points of view of different characters who interact with the book in the course of a day:  a down-on-his luck editor whose fortunes might change with this expose, a publisher about to lose his family business, an assistant on the rise, a producer, a rights negotiator, a CIA-type secret agent determined to prevent the book's release, and yes, the mysterious author himself.  All exciting and well done.  I give it four stars, not five, for a few reasons.  One, it didn't really stand out for me - other than the fun behind-the-scenes-of-publishing, it wasn't that different from the regular good thriller.  I could guess the plot twists in advance, and the biggest one of all was telegraphed, I thought, miles ahead of time.  Also, there are so MANY characters, that most of them are not as well developed as they could have been.  And the CIA element seemed shoehorned in - as if the stakes wouldn't be high enough unless the entire government were brought in; at some point, one character says that even the PRESIDENT might be trying to kill people to keep the book from being published, and that just was too much for me.  As if the author didn't trust us to be invested unless the Whole Free World was at stake.  And that never paid off.  But that being said - a fun read, well written, and particularly good if you're a book publishing junky.

This decades-long saga of three women begins when Grace, a timid young Chinese woman fleeing an abusive father, arrives in San Francisco with vague dreams of becoming a dancer at the World's Fair. She knows nothing of Hw to survive in the big city; fortunately she is quickly befriended by Helen, the daughter of a Chinatown magnate; and the two of them meet Ruby, a feisty young woman willing to do anything to get ahead. Of the three young girls, two find jobs dancing - and they all form a complicated, shifting, lifelong bond as secrets are hidden and revealed, tragedies unfold, hearts are broken and someone commits the deepest betrayal of all.Lisa See is carving out a great career, writing one strong book after another. She specializes in writing about Chinese women in the recent or distant historical past.  I still think Snow Flower is her best work; the story she was telling there was more unique than this one, another novel about women at home during WW2. Of course, the unique story of the Chinese and Japanese communities during this time makes this book more original, but it still felt just a bit expected. There is a boy, friendships betrayed, all well told but all just the slightest bit done before.  Plus, Ms See covers so much ground and so many characters that some elements of the story - the internment camps, for instance - are not as well developed. And the ending is a bit too neat, as one person "explains it all" just as the book comes to a close. That said, a great read, and definitely recommended.

Frank has a problem.  He recently had some incident happen to him - a car crash that was possibly a bit more than that.  He's lost his entire memory; he knows that he is a "terms and conditions" lawyer, the kind of guy who specializes in fine print, but he seems to have lost the big picture.  His wife is treading lightly around him, anxious and nervous and eager to please.  His brother and boss acts like everything is fine.  But is it?  As Frank tries to rebuild his life, he starts to sense that everything is not as it seems.  And that the people around him might be hiding some pretty big terms and conditions of their own.I liked this book, but not as much as I wanted to.  Frank's voice was funny, and the sense of place - a London corporate law firm - was really well established.  It took quite a while for the characters to come into focus; by the end, there are a few people we definitely like and some people we definitely don't, but I read for a long time without getting invested in anyone.  The revelation was not that surprising (or original), and the ending was wrapped up very quickly.  The biggest point of difference with this book was its format:  it is written like a law contract, filled with footnotes and footnotes to footnotes.  I love books that play with format, but in this case, it was quite literally difficult to read:  the gimmick is that footnote fonts keep getting smaller and that as a terms and conditions lawyer, Frank has learned to hide the most important facts in the smallest print.  But that gets in the way of reading this book - I quite literally struggled to read some of the fonts, as each footnote got progressively smaller in size.  It started to seem like a gimmick that was driven the story, instead of helping to tell the story.Mostly, in a comic novel like this, it's all about the voice.  And in this case, I thought it had its funny moments - Frank and his two brothers were popping by the end, with a neat dynamic -- but it wasn't as funny as some of the other comic novels I've read recently.  So, if you're looking for a fun read about corporate law, set in London, that gets better as it goes along, then check it out.  But maybe bring a magnifying glass.  :)

In the book "A Beautiful Mind," about the mathematician John Nash who struggled with schizophrenia, a friend said to him, when visiting him in the asylum, "You're a brilliant mathematician.  How can you possibly think that you are really hearing voices?" And John said, "Well, those are the same voices that gave me all my best ideas about math."  It's always been fascinating to me, the idea that our demons and our angels, our illness and our inspiration, can come from the same place - and what does that mean?  What I Had Before I Had You is an exploration of that question through the eyes of one family, over many generations:  a family that is struggling (secretly, in denial as much as possible) with the toll and turmoil of mental illness.I won't recount the plot, because many others have done that before.  But this novel did a wonderful job exploring that experience from the inside: the fear and frustration and the constant lurking presence of the disease, like sharks in the water.  It colors everything in life, and even if you try to ignore it (as the main character did) or deny it, the disease will take its toll.  And yet it can be hard to "treat" the illness because mental illness cannot be separated from the individual in the same way that cancer or heart disease can.  It's all wrapped up in your identity, and the toll of the disease on a family - to the point where it all unravels, in a thrilling story -- is very well told.  I ripped through this book quickly (it reminded me of early Kaye Gibbons, herself an author living with bipolar disorder) and I will definitely seek out more works from Ms. Cornwell in the future.

Eve is a typical suburban Mom who on the surface is living a very ordinary life: married to a good man from whom she is drifting apart, mothering a teenage girl whose secrets might be ordinary - or might be serious - but mostly, Eve's a mom raising a son who will die in just a few years; a son who is poisoned by sunlight and whose death warrant was signed years ago. So this family lives by the ticking of a clock; the daily tick of sunrise and the bigger tick of a life winding down when it's supposed to be starting up. Eve thinks her life couldn't get harder. But one day, in the space of a text message, Eve's fragile life takes another fatal blow. And as her community reels from its impact, we start to explore all the secrets that everyone is keeping - and what price they will pay for those secrets.Sounds like a great book doesn't it? And I wish I could rate this book higher - I don't like leaving critical reviews, especially for young authors, and I look for the best. But for me, after a nice setup and a good catalyzing event, the book slowed down to a crawl. It was as if the writer had thought of a great premise and created a compelling community, but then didn't know where to go. The plot is a waiting game, and reading becomes a waiting game as well, as all the characters passively wait for their secrets to be revealed. No one in the book does anything, really; days just unfold while we wait for something to happen. This is the second book I've read lately with this problem ("You Should Have Known" is the other) and it's a bad trend! Thrillers or mysteries in which the main characters are defined by their passive avoidance and denial of their circumstances do not make for good reads. And also as with You Should Have Known, there are no real plot twists: a set up, an event, 300 pages of waiting, and the end. Just not fun to read.Looking for the positive, I can see why this book was published -- nice setup and premise, nice first twist, decently written -- and I can see why some people would enjoy it.  Mothers might be able to imagine themselves in this situation, and think how far they would go to protect their own children. It might have extra resonance for a mom. But for me, it felt flat and I was restless as I read along, frustrated with the slow pace and what felt like an ordinary, predictable course to resolution.

Toni and her boyfriend Ryan have just been released from prison after serving 15 years for murdering her sister - a crime they did not commit. After trying hard to come to terms with her rage for the injustice of her sentence, and the betrayal of everyone from her life before, Toni mostly wants her life back, but discovers it's not that simple. She might be technically free, but the real killers are still out there. They know she has the truth. They tried to take her life from her years ago, and they're not about to let her have it back.Here's the best thing I can say about this book: I didn't want to do anything else while I was reading it. The setup is compelling, and the book has that kind of infuriating tension that comes when a character - in this case Toni - is dealing with a huge injustice and things keep going against her. You just want to race to the end to make sure it comes out okay.I also liked this book MUCH better than the earlier reviewers. I read a lot in this genre, and this one is a notch above. My favorites in this category are Lisa Gardner and Harlan Coben. For most of this book, Chevy Stevens hits that standard.  The premise is compelling and she tightens the screws until you can't stand the suspense. So it is a solid four stars and for those who like this kind of book, I really think you'll like this one.That said, it's not perfect. The bad guys are predictable and two dimensional; the tension comes not from "who done it" but "why" and "how will they get caught."  Under those criteria, I thought it was a little lacking in payoff. The vast majority of the book is spent in setup, and the payoff is pretty abrupt and lacking in the sort of twists and excitement that the best in the field can deliver.  So it's not perfect, but it was a great weekend read, and recommended for fans of this kind of book, for certain.

The concept of the unreliable narrator - and especially the unreliable narrator spouse - has been getting quite a workout lately, with Gone Girl kicking off a major sub-gene of literary thriller around this concept.  Headmaster's Wife is an above average entry in this sweepstakes: the first half of the novel is the headmaster, being interrogated by the police after picked up naked in Central Park, telling the story of what got him there. We know he is confessing to a crime - but what crime is it? We also suspect he is not telling the truth - so what is his real crime? As he confesses to an escalating series of sins (which I will not spoil here), we become more convinced that he is not telling us the full story. The first half of the book closes with a whopper of a reveal that I confess I did not anticipate in full; the second half of the book re-tells the same story, from a different perspective, with the assumption that this time we are getting the truth.I deliberately did not set out too many details in the description above because honestly, the way the novel is structured, to even reveal the names of major characters and their identities, is to spoil some of the surprises.The book was short and quick to read; it was cleanly structured and the author (himself the founder of a small liberal arts school in New England) knows the prep school setting intimately. There's a great sense of time and place. In the end, I was left just a bit disappointed: some of the characters who were most interesting never came into full view, and the device of recounting the entire story through memories gave it a sense of being a bit removed - like watching a party through a window, instead of being let in the door.  I just never felt fully connected.  But it was a lovely read with some nice surprises and twists along the way.

I won't revisit plot here, since I'm late to the game with this review. But I can speak as someone who read his prior book, and offer a comparison.I read A Land More Kind Than Home with huge expectations - the Cormac McCarthy/To Kill a Mockingbird comparisons were irresistible - and was a bit disappointed. That book felt a bit self conscious to me: the author trying too hard to hit on the classic "literary South" archetypes. So my expectations were a bit tempered with this one and hey! I liked it much better. Maybe Mr. Cash was more confident, or had less to prove, but this book just felt more relaxed to me somehow.  The themes are similar - young children and the parents who fail them, set in the hardscrabble South, where redemption and despair are in a constant dance.  But this book is more tightly plotted; whereas Land More Kind Than Home spent a lot of its time in portent and promises of events to come, like a guy trying to impress you on a first date, this book is more simple and benefits from it: Mr. Cash simply tells the story and trusts the story. I think he is going to write a Great American Novel one day, and I'm enjoying watching him work his way up to it.

Seriously.  I really loved this book.  From the very beginning, when Fanny is setting out across the ocean with her kids for some unknown reason, all the way through.  It's an incredibly generous work - generous with story (many things happen, which after reading too many passive books lately I am very grateful for!), generous with its characters (they're all interesting and well developed, even the bad guys, even the minor characters), generous with language - it's just lovely and sumptuous.  She does a terrific job of making you feel like you are there:  from the waiting platform in Belgium to France, the Samoan Islands, etc.  The theme of "unknown woman behind famous man" can seem a bit overdone lately (I know Ms. Horan is credited with starting it), but Fanny and RLS are such well developed characters that you don't care.  A terrific read.

I was so primed to love this book.  And there are things to like a lot about it.  It's a great premise -- Grace is a successful Manhattan psychologist with the perfect life and perfect husband writes a book criticizing women for not following their instincts in love, only to find out days before publication that her own husband, and her own life, are not what she thought at all.  In fact, nothing is as she thought at all: her instincts about everyone around her, from her best friend to her own husband, have been proven to be very truly wrong.Great premise, right?  And there's great writing in here, especially in the very clear depiction of the upper-middle-class Manhattan lifestyle, its perks and its perils.  But... I kept waiting for it to really get started.  And it never does.  This is a strangely passive book.  For one thing, all the interesting action takes place offstage: the murders, the murder investigation, the gossiping about Grace and her family, the gradual unraveling of the truth - all offstage.  Her husband, the ultimate villain of the piece, does not make an appearance - not in the present day, not even in flashbacks.  That's an incredibly strange choice, like having a Shakespearean drama where the villain is never seen.  We don't even see very basic conflicts such as Grace's circle turning on her.  Literally, Grace spends the vast majority of the book in denial of what is going on, just going about her life; and then when she realizes what happens, she flees town, never to return. It's a strangely passive book where almost everything interesting takes place in a different room from the one where the story is being told.

I picked this book up on a whim, after hearing about it on People.com, and it was just a delightful, unexpected treat, like a box of See's Candy left at the door.  It's the true story of Patience Bloom (how can this be her real name? but it is!), intellectual by day, secret lover of romance novels by night, who eventually finds her true calling as an editor at Harlequin - and finds the difference (and similarities) between romance love and real love.  Ms. Bloom's voice is easy and breezy but with a bit of an edge; she's humorous, but mostly at her own expense; she paints a vivid picture of growing up the daughter of incredibly smart parents and an overachieving brother, struggling to find her own way in the world, and, yes, to find real love and a true calling.  Her love for romance novels is a recurring theme, taking her through dark times in her life, and eventually leading her to her true calling: as an editor at Harlequin.  There is a bit of darkness in the book - a traumatic event from her 20s that is gradually unfurled, and a sad relationship with her distant father -- which makes it more real, and more textured.  I spent time in NYC in my 20s, and this book made me want to move back there.  While I don't love romance novels, I DO love reading, and I could relate to that part SO MUCH - the way books help us to escape our life, but also give us hope for it.  And the behind the scenes world at Harlequin was fascinating to me.  Honestly,  the book was just sheer fun:  I read it in one day, and didn't want to do anything else until I finished it.  I bought a copy for a friend in the hospital, promising it would cheer her up.  It will you, too!

Penn Cage's beloved father, Tom - Atticus Finch with a medical license - stands accused of murdering his old nurse, Viola Turner, an African American woman who has just returned to Natchez after fleeing from the murdering Double Eagles (a terrorist group who didn't think the KKK was extreme enough) during the 1960s.  Did Tom kill Viola?  If so, was it a mercy killing (she was dying of cancer), or something else?  What was Tom's relationship with Viola back in the 60s?  Did he father her son, Lincoln?  And how does all of this connect to a series of murders, beginning in the 1960s and stretching to the present day?  What is the truth - and how much is Penn willing to sacrifice to find it?I am a hard core Greg Iles fan, and I have been waiting for this book since the minute I finished Devil's Punchbowl in 2009.  That book ended on a cliffhanger, as Tom suffered a sudden heart attack and begged Penn to come to his side immediately, so Tom could reveal a long held secret.  Greg promised the follow up novel would follow within the year.  Flash forward five years - and a behind the scenes saga that itself could have been a novel itself, including his father's death, a near-fatal automobile crash for the author, a change in publishers - and finally, here it is. Natchez Burning is quite a high wire act:  it's both picking up a story that the author has been writing since Quiet Game, and starting a new trilogy that is supposed to take him to the next level, after a long absence. Possibly NO book could have lived up to the expectations placed on this one, by me, or by the new publishers, or the author himself.  And the weight of the expectations shows, as I will discuss.But first:  there is a phenomenal story in here - and a fantastic writer is telling it. SO much of this book lived up to my expectations.  It truly is epic in scope and ambition, and the stories that Greg Iles is telling are exciting, interesting, with great characters, terrific villains, lots of mystery, moral questions...all the good stuff.  When I finished the book, I handed it over to my husband and definitely encouraged him to read it, and I encourage others to read it as well.  It is just the kind of novel that I wish was being published all the time.But - it drags.  There's no other way to say it.  This book could have been at least 200 pages shorter and not lost a thing.  Other reviewers have noted it's a slow read, and it kind of is.  There are two very specific problems - one is minor, one is more frustrating.  The minor problem is repetition.  I noted that Tom Cage is "Atticus Finch with a medical license" - that's a great character summary.  It's probably in the book six times.  Tom describes himself that way; his son thinks of him that way on several occasions; other characters think of him that way.  This happens throughout the book - the core character issues are repeated over and over.  Penn's fiancee Caitlin is struggling with her own ambition versus her moral code.  She thinks about this struggle and reminds us of this struggle over and over and over and over.  Yes, we get it!!  You are struggling!!  I am not exaggerating when I say that there is probably a good 50 pages worth of content that is repeating the same character dilemmas over and over, as if we might not "get it" without the repetition.The second problem, and the more frustrating one to my mind, is that of ambition.  Greg Iles (and his publishers) want us to know this is an epic American novel.  (I think it may well be.)  So, literally, in the course of the novel, the characters repeatedly TELL US that this is an epic American story.  One scene after another of characters saying to each other, "Do you have any idea how big this is?  Do you have any idea how deep this goes?  Do you have any idea how powerful (this villain) is?"  The novel tries to cover American history from the 1960s to the present day, trying to link MLK and RFK and JFK and Katrina and slavery and J Edgar Hoover and American corporate and political corruption and investigative journalism and the history of the FBI - which is hard enough - but Iles is constantly interrupting his own story to make the point that this is a BIG STORY.  At one point, about 70% of the way through the novel, just as the momentum is really getting underway, there is a three page chapter where nothing happens except one of the main characters takes a moment to ruminate on HOW IMPORTANT this whole story is.  I'm not kidding when I say that there is probably another 50 pages of text that is devoted just to different characters talking about the epicness of the story that we are reading.  I found myself getting really frustrated with that and it ultimately affected my enjoyment of the book, hence four stars instead of five.My honest hope is that, now that the five-year-monkey is off his back, and the first novel of the trilogy is out, Greg Iles will be able to relax into just telling this story, and trusting the story.  It's a great one.  I really do think it has the potential to be an American epic, and I look forward to the next one.  Hope it's not five years away!(One other note - I was nervous about another cliffhanger ending, so for those who might share that concern - it wasn't too bad.  Yes, there was a cliffhanger, and it was bizarrely similar to the Devil's Punchbowl cliffhanger.  But enough was resolved that it felt fair, and I am not too traumatized waiting for the second book.  :)

A very delightful movie. Sort of like the romantic comedies of the 60's if they had been updated to reflect the 21st century.It is good enough to watch several times for the nuances of the characters.

Perhaps I'm "old school," and I sort of remember when one didn't do much with the American flag except fly it, and if it touched the ground, you burned it.  But, times change, and when I saw this "throw blanket," I asked to review it through the Vine Program at Amazon.com.This is an amazing blanket!  The colors are as rich as the pictures.  The "flag" side is sort of a brushed velour, very soft.  The "fluffy" side is as soft as, well, it's the softest stuff I've ever felt, and the fluff is about 3/8th's of an inch thick.One thing I've found about it is it keeps away drafts, but on warmer days, to me, it doesn't feel hot.  My wife's cold natured, and she likes it.  I'm sort of don't like to get too warm, and I like it.  I would recommend this as a very good item to have.I cannot wait for the 4th of July to put this across the bed when we have people over to the house.

I live in the Southeastern United States very close to the Tennessee River (a quarter mile at best), and there is a creek that flows into it across the street from my house.  No matter what the local street or parks department does with regards to mosquito control, we are going to have mosquitoes in my neighborhood.  I, also, have ADHD, even being 65, and with ADHD one usually has something that they hate, and for me, it is the itching from mosquito bites.Over the years, I have learned a lot about mosquitoes, and I'll get to that later, but let's talk about REPEL Sportsmen Dry Aerosol Spray.  I try not to use a lot of mosquito spray.  Namely, because it seems you have to use sprays with a higher amount of DEET to keep the mosquitoes away, and I'm concerned about the sprays I have been using (Off and Cutter sprays).  It seems when I use them, and their spray gets close to my Casio watches, and their plastic bands, the plastic gets "gummy," and I've even had the writing on one of the watches wipe completely off when I wiped the excess spray off of the watch.  I tried wearing long sleeve shirts and just spraying the shirts, but I still got stung.About three years ago, I visited a friend who has terrible allergies.  He's allergic to medicines, to foods, to odors.  Before I could visit, I had to wash all the clothes I was going to be wear down at his place, in the country no less, and bathe in a Hunters Soap Scent-A-Way 32 oz. Deodorizing Liquid Soap  for several days before I came.  When I got down there, it wasn't but a few minutes after sundown that I noticed something different.  The mosquitoes weren't attacking me.  I asked him if he did anything knowing I hate having mosquito bites.  He said he didn't, it was from my clothes not having any heavy scents that attracted the mosquitoes.  While the mosquitoes later that night did attack me, it was not like anything like back home.  When I got back home, I continued to use the soap, and it helps. There is nothing like talking to a neighbor, and you've put a little mosquito spray on, and additionally have not "scents" that attract the mosquitoes. Usually, it is the second night you're talking with them, and they are swatting at any and everything, and you are not having any issues, that you tell them your secret.With regards to REPEL's Sportsmen Dry Spray, it doesn't really spray on "dry," but the spray isn't quite as "greasy" as the other sprays I have used (both aerosols or out of a spray bottle).  Testing REPEL's Dry Aerosol Spray by spraying it on my Casio watch Casio Men's PAW1500-1V "Pathfinder" Multi-Function Digital Watch did not make my watch's plastic band or resin case have a "gummy" feeling like the other sprays, and the spray was easier to wipe off, afterwards, also.  I would highly recommend it for use.  The odor level is a lot less than the other sprays, and it seems, so far, to last for most of the day. I say "so far" because this year our weather decided to give us these last three weeks: snow for one week; ice storms for the second week; and rain this last week.  So, I haven't been out there in the yard as much as I normally would be t this time of year.  I did use it while washing the cars one night, in between rains, and I did not get bit.  With the DEET level at 25, that should hold off most bugsAround our neighborhood, mosquitoes tend to start coming-out of the "woodwork," to speak, when the temperature goes higher than 65 degrees Fahrenheit.  This last year though, I noticed a new mosquito in the neighborhood.  I saw a couple of Asian Tiger Mosquitoes.  Supposively, they carry several diseases, and maybe a new one that will affect us called the "Chikungunya Virus," that will affect one's bones and joints.If you hate mosquitoes, like I do, you have probably done all the things to limit their finding a "home" at your home: eliminating standing water, if you use mulch, or marble like I do, be sure there are no low places within your flower beds where water can collect under the mulch or rocks and breed mosquitoes.  Clean your gutters, or get those teflon-coated gutter guards that keep your gutters from having anything get into them and stopping them up.  Make sure all potted plants can drain any excess water from rain within a couple of hours.  Also, I found if you use a garden hose mosquito spray, be sure to spray the shady side of tree trunks, especially oak ones or any trees with thick bark.  Mosquitoes in our area, then to spend their days resting on these trunks.Like I said earlier, I am concerned about using a strong DEET spray, but I also know it is about the only thing that can work these days.  REPEL's Sportsmen Dry Aerosol Spray has shown me it is easier to use without damaging the plastic and resins on my watch, so I will be using it mainly in the early morning and late evening when mosquitoes tend to come-out to "feed."  By doing do, I will at least limit my use of the DEET 25 spray.  I gave this product 4 out of 5 stars, mainly not because it didn't work, but that it suggested it was "Dry" and wasn't.  If the manufacturer had said it was "dryer" than other sprays, I would have agreed with them on that point.

Recently, my television/Internet service was redone to make everything pass through WiFi.  Originally, about three-and-a-half years ago, I left the satellite television hook-up and went with AT&T's U-verse set-up of using WiFi for televisions (5) and Internet within the house.  The first installation had fiber optic coming into the house, then a hardwire between a downstairs modem and an upstairs modem.  I piggy-backed on it to provide an extra layer of WiFi using Apple's Airport Extreme downstairs and Apple's Airport Express upstairs because it gave me greater control of the WiFi, and it was faster.When the tech guy replaced the hard wire between a new upstairs and downstairs modem, he told me that I should expect to see higher data transfer speeds.  I'm not from Missouri, but I bit my lip, and didn't say, "Show me."  He did a good job, and the TV signal was even stronger, so I accepted it; however, the downloads of data were noticeably slower.  Not cable modem slower when all the kids in the neighborhood come home from school, but about a third slower (9 Mbps versus 15Mbps).So, when I got a chance to test NETGEAR's N300 Wi-Fi Router, I jumped at the chance.  Over the last 15 years, I used several different Wi-Fi Routers (NETGEAR, Belkin, and about 7 years ago I went with Apple Airport Extreme and Apple Airport Express), this NETGEAR N300 was the easiest to set-up.  Actually, after thinking back on all the different ones I've set-up, this one was almost "fun," and by that, I mean I just followed the five short steps on the instructions, and that was it.  No tweaking at all!  Those were:  1) Unplug the modem's power (it was just out of the box... already done), 2) Connect your modem by attaching a cable to the router's Internet port (I used a CAT5 I had to do this), 3) Power on the router with the adapter, 4) Connect a computer using Ethernet cable (I used the short CAT5 included to do this), 5) Log-in to the router (it said I should see NETGEAR's Genie display, I didn't, so I entered the URL www.routerlogin.net, and it found the N300 and connected it after I entered the password that was on the bottom of the N300).  You can, also, use WiFi to connect using the WiFi network name and password from the bottom on the N300.After doing this, I took the N300 and used the short CAT5 that was included to connect it to U-verse's WiFi.With my computer (Apple MacBook Pro) I downloaded the Genie app, and I was able to compare the signals of using my U-verse WiFi, the two Apple modems and the NETGEAR N300.  With up to 8 different computers and phones being used within my two story house, the signals can vary from moment-to-moment, but the signal strength of the NETGEAR was stronger (-13 dBm) versus U-verses (-39 dBm and -37 dBM).  The Apple units being the oldest were -59 dBM and -61 dBm.While I was upstairs in my bedroom, I went into VUDU and tested the download speed for movies, which I watch a lot, and while no one else was on their computers I got:  NETGEAR Download 17.70 Mbps Upload 1.82, U-Verse downstairs (the main WiFi) Download 15.51 Mbps Upload 1.79 Mbps, U-verse (upstairs extender) 14.08 Mbps Download 1.81 Mbps Upload.It may seem odd that the NETGEAR hooked-up to  U-Verse's WiFi modem would give me faster speeds, but five years ago, or maybe even longer than that, when I went with AT&T's satellite (DTV) and WiFi package the Apple Airports hooked-up to their WiFi modems were faster then, too.Besides the easy installation and faster speeds, I like three things about the NETGEAR N300:  1) the Genie.  It tells you about all your WiFi networks, 2) The ability to control use and times of use for computers and phones in your WiFi network (so your children won't be using the WiFi all the time for their games, and 3) It's price.  While I would imagine the new version of Apple's Airport Extreme would be a lot faster than the older Apple Extremes I am using, they cost about 6+ times more.I could not find anything about NETGEAR's N300 to complain about, and I can only recommend it.  I am very pleased that I have it as an extra layer of WiFi in my set-up as I feel the network is safer and, also, faster.

For the past year I have been taking cabinet making/carpentry courses at my local community college, so when I saw I had a chance to review under Amazon's Vine Program a tape-measure, which is something I use probably 30-40 times a day in class, I jumped at the opportunity.Overall, I give this tape measure only two stars.  One star is the lowest you can give a reviewed product, and I give it an extra star because it is heavy-duty.  Compared with the other tape measures out there, it is accurate, but please be advised that none of the markings on the tape measure less than an inch are marked.  Like most tape measures, the first 12 inches are divided into 32nds.  Additionally, it has a sliding tip, so the tape can be pushed against a piece you are measuring or attached around an end piece and still give an accurate measurement.  The tape is of a non-reflective, glare resistant, silver/grey color with black markings.  These are the positive points about this tape measure.On the negative side, the idea about having a graphite "lead" that slides-in at the opening area so as to mark a distance the tape is from the end is a good idea. If you enlarge the picture of the tape measure, you will see on the front side of the tape measure a red spring mechanism. You pull-up on it and lock it into place while you push one of the thin leads through a hole at the top.  Once you push the lead piece down, you release the red spring mechanism, and this keeps constant pressure pushing down on the lead.  The lead rubs against a scored metal wheel that rolls as you move the tape measure sideways across whatever you are wanting to mark.For example, let's say you need to cut a 4 foot x 8 foot piece of plywood in half (making two 4 x 4 pieces). The way you would use this to mark where you cut it would be for you to  pull the tape measure out four feet, less a little because the line where the lead will mark is located inside from the edge of the tape measure where the tape rolls up into the container.  At first, I thought one moved the tape measure sideways across the lumber leaving a solid line, but doing so, you actually only put down a semi-solid line (more about this later), and this causes you to use up the whole the lead piece in 9-12 inches.  So, I'm thinking, to save lead, you make a slight mark at one edge; then, a slight mark in the middle of the plywood; and, finally, a mark at the other edge.  Then, you take a straight edge and connect those three marks.  Next you do your sawing. Otherwise, you would use at least four of the pieces of leads to make a four foot line across the plywood.As for the "mark" the lead puts down, it is barely visible at times, and I ended-up having to press hard on the wood to get it to leave down a consistent mark, which if you are using soft wood or plywood, leaves a scored mark on the wood.  This isn't too bad of a mark by itself, but if I just wanted to go by a marked embedded by the metal scored wheel, I'd forget about using the lead.As for the package that claims you can make "1000+ Marks Per Load?"  Forget it.  In actuality, to do so must mean each mark must be like the tip of a pencil mark because after moving the tape measure sideways 10 inches, and leaving a faint pencil mark for those 10 inches, the lead is used up.  It is quicker and easier to use a traditional tape measure to do the marking, and a heavy-duty tape measure would cost about one-half the cost of the QuickDraw.Quite frankly, I don't know how this product is getting all the positive reviews (sometimes one can click on the reviewer and you find-out the only item they've ever reviewed on here is the one they are giving the "great" review about, which makes you wonder, sometimes not), but I'll leave that up to others to figure-out.Over the years I have mainly used a Stanley 25 foot Powerlock tape measure Stanley 33-425 Powerlock 25-Foot by 1-Inch Measuring Tape - Original, and I have even, on occasion, used Stanley's Fax Max, if I was needing it to have to stretch quite a distance Stanley 33-725 25-Feet FatMax Tape Measure, but when I started my cabinet making class 14 months ago, I noticed the Komelon 25 foot Tape Measure with the sliding, magnetic end Komelon 7125 Monster MagGrip 25-Foot Measuring Tape with Magnetic End.  Since I was going to be in a cabinet making class of 20 people, I thought it's ugly green color might help me keep it from "walking off," if you know what I mean.  So far so good.  I've used it thousands of times, dropped it way too many times, and it's still working fine, and its magnetic tip, while something I only use a couple of times a month, is useful to have, especially in the big box store's lumber area where they use metal stands for the lumber.  I can affix the tape measure tip against the metal end of the lumber stand, and then stretch the tape lengthwise to measure odd pieces to see exactly how long they are.Additionally, with my tape measure, I have it securely clipped to my belt and sometimes bib overalls pocket using a MagnoGrip 002-290 Tape Measure Holder MagnoGrip 002-290 Quick Snap Magnetic Tape Measure Holder.  This allows me to reach down, without looking, and bring-up my tape measure in a second, unlike if I had used the belt clip or the Tape Measure Holder I had previously used since the 1970's Custom Leathercraft 464 16-30 Top Grain Measuring Tape Holder. There have been a couple of times I absentmindedly didn't return the tape to the magnets, and the tape measure dropped, and I wish I'd gotten the MagnoGrip 002-320, MagnoGrip 002-320 Quick Snap Magnetic Tape Measure Holder, but I have found this holder to be a quick way to access ones tape measure, and speed is counts with most employers, and teachers.When one does these reviews for Amazon through their Vine Program, you always hope that the product is a great one; however, in this instance, I cannot recommend it.  I do hope I've given you enough alternatives, though.

There are two general types of cases for the iPhone 6 Plus: the padded wrap-around clip-case, like the Otterbox, that sometimes has a belt clip, and the Folio.  With the increase in size of the iPhone 6 Plus, the Folio-type, like this Belkin, makes more sense because it protects the iPhone, especially when it is dropped, and offers the user the ability to prop it up on its side to use and view.The Belkin case holder is curved and wraps around the edges of the iPhone, and by doing so, holds it securely.  The case has a cover that is magnetized, and when dropped, I found, would close and protect the iPhone.  A lot was made initially about the iPhone 6 Plus bending when it first came-out. While I didn't notice this as being a problem unless you put it in your back pocket and sat on it, the Belkin case gives the phone additional support.Overall, I thought the case looked very smart and business-like, although with the phone getting this large, it is more difficult to pocket it in ones trousers, but fits nicely in ones inside suit/sport coat pocket or front coat pocket.To me, this case is very good protection for ones iPhone 6 Plus.  It is not a total protection as you will still need to put a protective sheet over the screen to keep that from getting accidentally scratched, that's why I gave it four stars, but overall it is stylish and does the job if one is careful with it.

David Pogue has been putting together "Missing" manuals ever since, well, the manuals started going missing.  For some folks, these missing manuals were 'all right,' as they only looked at the manual as a last resort, and I have to admit, I was one of those, but as I get older, I find more and more folks asking me for advice on how to do things with their electronic devices and computers, that I neither want to do, nor even care about knowing they can be done, but wish I knew just to get my friends off my back.  David Pogue's manual's serve the purpose of being able to answer their questions, and occasionally mine, quickly and efficiently.  While similar in theory to the "Step-by-Step" series Microsoft started years ago as a means of, well, making more money, Pogue's books always seemed to cost less and have just the right number of words needed in order to communicate how a task was done.Even better, I see that this manual has color screen prints.  Having read through it, and researched several problems I, and others, encountered, I found the solutions easy to follow, and I found them, which is better than some books that seem to only lightly touch on the most obvious issues one might have.I highly recommend iPhone: The Missing Manual.  It says it is good for use with the 4S and newer model iPhones, but I found it slightly tilted for the 5 and above iPhones.
The large oversize calendar is well worth the price, but when they toss-in a copy of last year's Sports Illustrated Swimsuit DVD, this is a great buy.

In ALFRED HITCHCOCK: THE MAN WHO KNEW TOO MUCH, Michael Woods has penned an interesting short, 120+ pages, book on Hitchcock.  Unlike some books on the great director that often explore his quirks to the extent that you almost hate to go see another of his movies, this one is less thorough, but more enjoyable. The main parts are included, but you don't get the psychoanalysis of the director that makes other publications on Hitchcock drag.I had fun playing the Hitchcock movies while reading about them, and Mr. Woods analysis helped me enjoy the movies more, and understand them better.I would recommend this book to anyone who wants to get a better understanding of Hitchcock the man and the director.

Brain Trainer is an app my wife installed on her Kindle Paperwhite, and I bought it to put on my Kindle Fire.  While the apps look different in that her's has black and white images and my Fire shows them in color, the games it uses are the same so you can compare scores.  I could see one even competing with someone who cannot read, whether it be a child or someone from another country.Fun and challenging.  You can compete with others, or with the clock.  I'm glad my wife showed this to me.  Now, I just have to get faster......

I enjoyed Patricia Cornwell's latest Scarpetta novel, FLESH AND BLOOD.  It was fun to be reunited with old friends like Marino, Kay and Lucy.  From the beginning, each one of them has the feeling that something isn't quite right, but being crime fighters, they must have proof.  They can't go on their gut feelings.Marion "knows" that the sniper killing in Kay's neighborhood is related to the ones in New Jersey; Kay "knows" that Lucy has a problem with her partner, but isn't ready to talk, yet, or "spill the Boston beans."  Lucy "knows" that someone has been in her computer, but that cannot happen since Lucy is the top computer/crime prevention guru in the country.As Lucy traces strange E-mail messages and Tweets, the connections between all of these odd events seem to be connected on one way or another to Kay and cases at the Cambridge Forensic Center.  Benton has been working with Lucy on the computer traces and thinks someone is sabotaging Lucy's network.As the novel progresses, Cornwell, the author, feeds us the pieces of the puzzle, and we begin to put the coincidences together for the complete picture.  If you are a Scarpetta fan, you will be racking your brain for someone from a previous book to blame for all the problems.The ending isn't quite as exciting as the fight at the Crystal Carbon2 plant freezing room in THE BONE BED, but I would rate it in the top third of all the books.FLESH AND BLOOD: A SCARPETTA NOVEL  was delightful reading that I would gladly recommend to all her fans.
I really wanted the softer version. These looked like the Liberty bib overalls, but the fabric is a lighter weight.  They have held-up well washing them each week.

As a replacement battery, the LENMAR Replacement Battery for Samsung Galaxy S5 is very good.  In testing this one, while streaming video, music, posting on Facebook, I got between 14 and 15 hours of continued use the three times I used it (14.1, 15.0, 14.6 hours).  With the OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) battery, I got 17-18 hours use (17.2, 17.5 and 17.9) .  I know, sometimes, it is difficult finding the exact original battery, so this would make a great substitute.One thing I noticed, though, is that while Samsung has a list price of $29.99, you can find it here on Amazon, in Non-Retail Packaging for much less, Samsung OEM 2800 mAh Standard Battery for Samsung Galaxy S5 - Non-Retail Packaging - Black, but be wary as those do not seem to come with any warranty, and the LENMAR has a one-year warranty, which makes me think something might be amiss for OEM lower priced items, like gray market merchandise.  While I have no knowledge of this, you may want to research anything you buy further before purchasing.Another thing, though, the OEM battery clearly states "This battery is equipped with an NFC antenna, allowing your handset to communicate with other devices and accessories equipped with NFC technology."  Neither the lower priced Non-Retail battery, listed above, nor the LENMAR say they have NFC capability, even though the product number for Non-Retail is the same as for the Retail model.  I hope I didn't make this more confusing than it needs to be, but, to me, NFC is something good to have as it allows payments from your phone, printing directly to printers, and other capabilities.All-in-all, for it's price, and with its one-year warranty, the LENMAR Replacement Battery for Samsung Galaxy S5 is a good buy if NFC capabilities is not a priority for you.

Have you ever bought someone something, and you seem to get "stuck" with solving all the problems they have with it afterwards?  Seven years ago, I bought my step-daughter a Honda Element, EX version.  Along the roof rack, skirts below the doors, along the front fenders and bumper and rear fender and bumper are heavy black vinyl areas.  Over the years, I've used Armour All-type liquids and even tire-black stuff to keep it looking "newish."  Most work for around three weeks before the vinyl starts fading back to the soft black, almost dark gray color.Turtle Wax Premium Trim Coating Kit is not like any of those products.  If you have ever had a diesel vehicle and changed the oil yourself, you know what a mess that is, with the oil changing from a rich, thick oil, to a black, thin liquid that discolors your skin wherever it touches you.  This Turtle Wax Premium Trim Coating is very much like that thin liquid your diesel oil becomes.To put it on, you use a  rectangular sponge applicator, much like that provided to re-blacken your tires.  Do yourself a favor, and buy yourself a thick pair of kitchen gloves to apply the liquid, it just might keep it off your hands, but forget those "gloves" Turtle Wax provides with the product.  Getting the dirty liquid off your hands afterwards will take some Goop or scrubing with Lava soap.  I sprayed some WD-40 on my hands, and it seemed to help, if you have an adversion to getting your hands dirty.  I would especially recommend you spray the WD-40 underneath your nails, as those areas were the hardest to clean.Turtle Wax recommends you cut the applicator sponge in half if you want to be meticulous in your application of the coating, but I found if you take the "black" watery liquid and run it around the sponge just inside the outside edge, it allows you to apply the coating right-up-to-the edge of the vinyl plastic.I have only had the coating on the trim for a week, and only time will tell if one can go "up to a year" before reapplying, so I'll be updating this review later, but the coating does it's job.  It does "rub" off the first couple of days, but after it initially dries, it looses any shine, but it retains a dark, black hue that reminds you of how the vehicle looked when you first bought it.On the Element, there is a lot of trim to coat.  For me, it took about 1/3rd of the bottle to coat everything.  If it lasts six months or longer, I would say it is worth the cost and the effort.  Hopefully, by the time a reapplication of the coating is needed, my stepdaughter will desire to do this by herself.

As someone who had to endure waking-up at all hours in the past to listen to "Just a Minute" over the shortwave, WELCOME TO JUST A MINUTE! A CELEBRATION OF BRITAIN'S BEST-LOVED RADIO COMEDY is a utterly delightful book that provides fans with a complete and thorough history of the program.  Unfortunately, in 2005 or so, the BBC decided to stop broadcasting the show over shortwave, and one was forced to listen to it, when available, by a computer.  While this was disappointing, as you didn't get the feeling of listening to it as it was being broadcast,If you have ever listened to the broadcast, or are just a fan of British humor, you will enjoy reading about the show, as it gives a rich history of how the BBC has evolved over the years.Nicholas Parsons begins by telling the development of the concept of the show by Ian Messiter from a previous show Mr. Messiter developed titled "One Minute Please!"No part in the development of the show is spared as we are given whole sections of the BBC's style-type guide, called "The Little Green Book," in-house reviews of those first programs, and the thoughts behind the "tweaking" of the program as it is changed to its current format. The reader learns why changes were made, and the book truly gives one insight into the creative process at the BBC, which for me was fascinating.Included in the book are whole sections discussing the panelist's thoughts on the program and throughout are pages in which most of the panelists who have appeared on the show are discussed, with many of their appearances on the program detailed in word-for-word exchanges. Years ago, I found somewhere on the Internet a site devoted to episodes of "Just a Minute" listed as mp3 files. Playing those individual audio program files as I read the exchanges in the book added another dimension to my reading.  Another way I have found to listen to the show is through a phone app called TuneIn Radio.  One just searches for "Just a Minute," and it plays non-stop.The book progresses on a linear time-line through the 47 years, with each decade in which the program has been broadcast being a separate section. Each decade includes a remembrance written by one of the panelists, and I found each of these fascinating.In the preface Mr. Parsons writes, "These are the people, who throughout 47 years and counting, have propelled "Just a Minute" forward with panache and style," it is clearly evident that it is his panache and style that has made "Just a Minute" the comedic institution it is.(Just a minor disclosure. In the UK version of this book, on page 428, there is a "George McAdams" referenced. That is me. I still am upset that one must have a computer or telephone to listen to "Just a Minute," and it is no longer on shortwave, even though shortwave broadcasts to the States have been curtailed, also, but life goes on.)

The problem I found with the iPhones, 4S and earlier, and our iPods, that data cables develop shorts after a month or two, and you have to replace them.  I thought with the solid thick cable this would last longer than the other cables you can find that look like what Apple used to supply with you phones and iPods, but was I wrong.  I bought two of these because I liked the way they looked; however, one lasted three weeks, and the second only lasted a little longer than one week.Save you money, and get something better.

At our house we don't buy a lot of vacuum cleaners.  Other than a shop vac that I use in the garage, we have purchased two in 20 years.  We bought a Kirby G4 in 1995 and a Eureka Pet Smart Model in 2007.  Both have good qualities, and have a function in our home.  With the Kirby, you have an easy to use vacuum that is self-powered, but it doesn't get up as much stuff as the Eureka.  The Eureka is a heavy vacuum and isn't self-powered, but it does a good job getting the carpets clean. It's hand attachment has given us more problems than it is worth.  My wife has complaints about both vacuums, so I jumped at the chance to test this Hoover Windtunnel 3 Pro.  When I tested the Kirby against the Eureka, I would use one, and then vacuum again with the other.  The Eureka showed it picked-up dirt and dust that the Kirby left, but it was a pain to push around.The Hoover Windtunnel 3 Pro has four rug settings and a hardwood setting.  The first thing I noticed is it's very light.  I was concerned that it might not get up as much dirt and lint from the You can activate the brush feature or not for all settings.  When you have it set to the hardwood floor setting, it does a good job getting-up 95% of the dirt and dust, and you get the rest by running over the area from one side of the room to the other, instead of up-and-down.  On thin carpets, it is not difficult to push the Hoover without the brushes turning.  If you have the brushes turning, you actually need to have the brush height set to 3 or 4, out of 4, to have the vacuum pull the vacuum, and you just have to guide it.  With it set at 1 or 2, you have to exert more to get the vacuum going, and it pulls you across the carpet.  Pulling it back isn't difficult.The Hoover had many of the same features that the Eureka has, but you could tell more forethought went into it.  The Eureka hand head would often clog-up  and have long hair tangle-up the brush.  It had a way of opening it up, but it was easy to put it back together wrong.  The Hoover has easy to snap open head and it was easy to remove any long hairs.  The Hoover Windtunnel also had a "lock" mechanism on the hose that kept it in place, which I found better than most vacuums.On the negative side, I noticed when you had the brush height set to 3 or 4, there was an odor that seems like the belts are slipping.  Even after a number of days use, this was as odor that you would still have, and it took a while to dissipate after you finished vacuuming.  After three months of using this vacuum, the odor is no longer present.  Besides the power brush hand attachment, the Hoover only comes with a crevice tool that is more of a crevice "pointer," instead of the universal crevice tool most vacuums have come with since the 1950's, and what I thought was the world's smallest brush attachment.  It was pathetic.As for the value of being bagless. I liked seeing the dust come into the dirt chamber.  I found it pretty easy to clean; however, there is additional care needed for the user, so I'm thinking what you gained, you lost something else.  After three months of use, I found the "bagless" feature not as enduring.  In fact, it make cleaning the chamber-out thoroughly almost a necessity.  You can take the chamber off, rinse it out, then let it dry overnight, and its not too bad.  Since it is bagless, you have a HEPA filter, which needs to be backflushed every four thorough vacuuming of the house.I do find myself using the Hoover more because of its light weight.  Would I buy this vacuum if I needed one?  No, although I liked some of its features.  I would look at another Hoover with more advanced features because we tend to keep vacuums for 10-20 years, if not longer.  If it was easier to clean and had a better attachment, I would have given the Hoover Windtunnel 3 Pro five stars rating.

Bear with me on this review because I have been dealing with protector shields for almost 12 years.  I have been using smartphones since the early 2000's, starting with the Samsung SCH-i730, followed by an AT&T Tilt, a Samsung Jack 2, iPhones 3, 4, and 4S.  From the very beginning I had trouble with the screens needing protection, and I started using the clear plastic shields one could buy for your photo iPods to keep the screens from getting scratched.  Most of those you cut with scissors to a fairly "close" size, and they adhered with an adhesive that was thick and gummy.  The plastic was thicker than that of the MIcra Digital Anti-Glare Screen Protector, which was nice because you could poke it quite a bit without it getting scratched.  On the negative side, if you got any bubbles under the plastic, you had to work the plastic for several days to get all the bubbles out, and even then, somehow they reappeared.With my iPods, I started buying Otterbox cases to protect them from the beginning, and when I went to the iPhones, I continued to buy their Defender cases, OtterBox Defender Series Case and Holster for iPhone 4/4S  - Retail Packaging - Black, but I found I had a new problem.  The Otterbox case had its own plastic shield, which initially seemed nice, but given that the case wasn't waterproof, it only offered a little help, at least, until the areas where your favorite apps were picked-up scratches on their shield.What I have done, now, has been to remove Otterbox's plastic shield, after it's one year warranty has expired, and placed my own screen protector.  In the past I had to find one that fit, and I ran into a problem.  If the shield was too thick, it was harder to swipe and punch-in your selection or choice.  It seems that the thickness reduced the conductivity of your finger pressure for swiping and double punching.  If the plastic was too thin, it streaked or scratched easier.I have used several different brands of screen protectors, and when I saw I could test the Micra Digital Anti-Glare Screen Protector for my iPhone 4S, I jumped at the chance.  I found these protectors to be cut exactly the size you need; I found them to reduce the glare more than some of the other screen protectors and much better than just the Otterbox by itself.This year I went back to school to take cabinet making, and having to place stripes and other templates exactly right on furniture, I found these screen protectors easy to install. I, also, found the picture instructions included with the protectors lacking, so I will expand them below to make it, hopefully, easier to install.1) Start with a clean surface on your phone, no matter whatever type of phone you are using.  If there are any smudges on your iPhone, you will have to deal with smudges after installation. Use a clean, cotton, lint-free cloth like you'd use on your furniture for dusting to get it smudge-free.  Do not spray anything like Windex that has ammonia on it.  If your phone is so grimy you need to use a glass cleaner, use an ammonia-free cleaner by first putting just a little on your cloth, and then apply it to the GLASS surfaces. DO NOT APPLY any of it to your switch or volume buttons.2)  Next, take one of the screen protectors, and without removing the thin plastic shield that go over the sticky side of the protector, practice curling it up like it shows on the very inadequate picture instructions supplied with the protectors. Place the phone on a surface that will not scratch the surface of the phone, yet, it will not allow the phone easily to slide about.  I know that sounds impossible, but this will help.  Just curl-up the protector a couple of times, press it down on an invisible line that goes up-and-down the center of the from from the bottom to the top.  I used the "Home" button at the bottom as your guide because it is easier to center it there.  One time, I actually placed the index finger tip of my other hand on the "Home" button, and held the protector down as I moved it up to the top of the phone, but it only worked easily one time for me.3)  Once you are comfortable after a couple of test runs, peel off the thin plastic that covers the sticky side of the screen protector.  If you run your finger up the middle of the curved protector, then, press the protector down from the middle to the outside of the protector, most of your bubbles will vanish.I found these screen shields did help reduce glare.  Adjust the brightness of your screen to where you can see it best in the type of light you view your phone's screen the most. Remember, though, the brighter you have the screen, the more battery energy you will be using.I recommend these screen protectors.  You may have to change them every-so-often, but given their responsiveness to your touch, I cannot find much about them not to recommend.Two other tricks for iPhones and, actually any phones.  First, my stepdaughter has issues with getting electronic stuff wet.  Start saving those silica packets that often come in medicine bottles and put them aside in an air-proof bottle.  If they drop their phone or iPod in water, first dry it off ASAP] if it has a battery you can remove, remove it; next place it in a Zip-Lock freezer bag along with all the silica packets you have; leave it for at least 12 hours if barely gotten wet, longer if it got really soaked.  I revived several electronic devices, iPods, a Samsung Jack, etc. by doing this.  I did not immediately give them back the device they almost ruined.  I went let them have several days of doing without to help teach them the severity of their carelessness.  Second, with the iPhone 4, she started having problems with the On-Off switch at the top not working.  It was only after it stopped working, did she tell me about it.  I was able to restore it using a contact cleaner like Hosa Cable D5S6 Deoxit Contact Cleaner Spray that I bought from Radio Shack, and you can get here at Amazon.  Had she told me she was having a problem with it when it first occurred, the cleaner could have fixed it immediately.  Since she didn't, It took working with it for a couple of days.

When I first saw Kernel Season's Bacon Cheddar Popcorn Seasoning flavor available on our grocery shelf, I passed.  This past year I decided to give it a try and found it an excellent topping for a baked or microwaved potato or even as an addition to sour cream, regular or low-fat, to make a tasty dip.As with all Kernel Season's products, I have found after a couple of weeks they tend to "clump-up."  No matter if you use something (ice pick or knife) to break the seasoning up, again, it tends to have lost some of its zest.  Bacon Cheddar actually "clumps" up faster, but if after opening the seasoning, you put it in the refrigerator, you will find it keeps fresh longer, which is, I guess, what they may have meant when they said "store in a cool, dry place."

MLB Slammin' Sluggers Baseball Game is just that, a game for "slamming sluggers."  I am old enough to remember the metal baseball game we played as kids in the late 1950's, and this one is so much better.  The game requires a certain amount of skill from the person who fields both the pitcher and fielders, and the person doing the hitting.  The player controlling the pitching, can guess which way the batter will hit the ball based on how fast they pitch the metal ball towards the batter. With a magnetic field between the pitcher's mound and home plate, the ball, if pitched slow enough, the metal ball can curve, but throw the metal ball too slow, and it might never reach the batter.  For me, hitting with the batter's bat was harder than I thought it would be, but once you get into a groove, it does get easier.The game is fun for adults with children tendencies, and children older than 8 or so because the plastic players show they've got to be handled with care, or the pegs on the bottoms of the player's feet will lose their grooves and the players will start falling over.  Children younger 7 and younger might not be able to handle the plastic players careful enough to avoid breaking something.While one could find a number of things to complain about with this game, the major one for me was the lack of instructions on putting everything together.  So, keep the box handy, you are going to need it.  The instructions on playing the game are just a tad better, but eventually you'll be able to figure it out.Would I buy this game for my children or other children, "Yes," if they were into baseball. If they aren't into baseball, this game will not get them excited about baseball, and I wouldn't.

This is the third D-Link Wi-Fi camera I have reviewed for Amazon, and the most complicated of the three.  The other two I have reviewed are the D-Link Wireless and D-Link HD Pan and Tilt.Like the other two the Baby Cam has natural and infrared lighting settings and an iPhone app that fairly easy to set-up, but like the other two it lacks instructions to tell you what the heck you can do with it.  While the other two camera basically just gave you a picture of what was happening on the other end, the Baby Cam, with its music, two way conversation and other settings, needs give you more info.  I can understand why it doesn't, because like most "apps," instructions are only good until the next update of the app.  However, it sure does make life difficult, especially, if you had an issue with your settings, and you have to do a "reinstall."  For this reason, I am uploading a number of pictures that show the various settings as of September 1, 2014.  Other than those, pictures, though, here are some comments on the installation:If you have used D-Line cameras before, and the "D-Link Lite" app, you cannot use the same D-Link account for the "Baby Cam."  It was only after I got almost through the install because this became apparent.  If you do not have a D-Link account already active, the normal installation instructions are almost foolproof.  For an iPhone, the instructions will take you through setting-up a Wi-Fi link between the camera and your Baby Cam's Wi-Fi, be sure to look past the blank pages and get the passcode and MAC address on the little folder they provide.  You don't need the MAC address at first, but you may need to use it if the app doesn't work.  If you do have a D-Link account already, you need to be prepared with a different E-mail address to set-up a separate D-Link account.  This is because the Baby Cam shares so much more information.  On the down side, some Wi-Fi out in the general public areas, like restaurants, hospitals, etc., might not be fast enough to support the interchange of data with the Baby Cam.After you have linked the phone with the Baby Cam, it will have you link your Baby Cam with your Wi-Fi network, so you can view your Baby Cam's picture away from your home or the proximity of the Baby Cam.The installation, I've installed this camera 6 or 7 times, is generally correct, and it will give you settings that will work; however, if the settings get screwed-up, save yourself some time and just "reset the default" settings.  Any adjustment you do, isn't really shown that you've achieved it.  Several times, I kept making adjustments, and I had no idea if I had adjusted anything.  If you do have a reinstall, do not be alarmed if you do not have to reenter your passcode, as it seems to have kept this, no matter if you perform a "hard" reset or not.In summation, if you already have a D-Link camera or a D-Link account, you will have to establish a different account, using a different E-mail address when you install the Baby Cam, and just follow the iPhone's app instructions.  They tend to be fine.  If your play with the settings, don't try to reverse your adjustments, because you cannot tell if they settings worked or not.  Just reset camera to "Default Settings," and give it another shot.  I will post pictures with notes over the next two days.  Do I like the Baby Cam, "Yes," even though I do not have any children.  I plan to use mine to communicate with my wife while she's using her computer at home.

Thinkware's F550 Dashboard Camera is an excellent piece of equipment.  Solidly made, it attaches to the front windshield behind the rearview mirror easily with its easy-on, easy-off slide clip.  I was concerned that it might interfere with the reception of my AM/FM radio, but I couldn't hear any interference as the power cable is quite thick, and my radio seemed to pick-up the same stations.  I did not like the way you had to run the power cord from the power plug around the windshield.  Quite frankly, in the car it looks a little tacky, but after a while you forget it is there.They supply you with 16 GB micro-size memory card for use with the camera and a larger SD size shell for inserting the micro card for reading in most computers.  Along with this micro memory card is a little "reader" for getting the micro card in and out, that, I guess, is useful if you are clumsy with your hands, and you have big fingers. I didn't need it, but I could see where someone might.When you are installing the Dashboard Camera, it seems like it is going in backwards, but that's because one is attaching it to the slope of the windshield with the bulk of the camera to the side of the lens.  You want to attached the mount first to the camera and then both to the windshield because it is easier to handle them.  After first cleaning the inside of my windshield, I made two "x's" with a dry marker to show where I wanted the bottom corners to be, THEN I took the protective tape from the back of the mount and attached the adhesive side of the mount to the windshield.
