In my windshield, I have a built-in antennae for AM/FM reception, so I had to make sure the camera was attached in a manner where the wires for the antennae were not obstructing the view of the camera lens.  The buttons to turn on the unit and adjust the volume of microphone and speaker are separated by a manual record button that is a totally different size button, which is very helpful so you don't press the wrong one because it is almost impossible to tell what button is for what from more than 2 feet away.  The camera rotates easily, yet, it is clearly notched so that it will not rotate on its own.  If your vehicle sometimes handles a heavy load and you have weak rear springs, you may need to adjust the camera angle when you have a heavy load.I haven't done anything that has automatically turned-on the unit, but I will try to post something that shows what the picture will look like.  Given that the unit turns itself on when there is a jarring movement, we'll just have to wait and see if it does.  You might want to make a mental note about what to say or not say if you are in an accident, since it will record sound, too.Overall, if I lived in a city environment where it could be expected that I would be in an accident, I would probably have one of these, but off-hand, I think these are best mounted in business vehicles, especially if you have a driver who has already had an accident.  I will say that having this unit in my car along with my radar detector, my vehicle is beginning to take on the appearance of an unmarked police unit.

Each Barbie doll seem to try to find a niche, and this one brings out the creativity and resourcefulness in children.  With Barbie Sparkle Studio Doll, my girls found no problem using the stencils and glitter, although they did think the multilingual instructions could have been printed on a larger sheet of paper so they would have been easier to follow.  The two-piece turquoise blouse/skirt set was more difficult to put glitter on for them.This Barbie doesn't bend at the elbows or knees, but they seem to accept that certain Barbie dolls won't bend, and they liked it as it was.  It has kept them busy for hours, and they found it to be something they could play with it without getting bored, which to me is a big plus.All-and-all, it would make a welcome addition to any Barbie collection.

Electric shaving is something one either likes or dislikes.  The Remington R3 Power Series Rotary Shaver is a nice entry level shaver for a young man, or a good "travel" shaver to have for trips, when you don't want to unhook your regular shaver for short trips.  Using Afta pre-shave gave me a close shave without any mess.  The R3 goes over a week between charges, and its pop-up trimmer does a good job on the sideburns.I would not hesitate recommending it to anyone looking for a starter razor or wanting to "test" electric shaving before buying a more expensive model.

When I look for Anti-Virus protection in a business application, I look for three main qualities:  1)  It has to provide great Anti-Virus Protection and update itself regularly., 2)  It has to let me monitor the other computers; telling me the others on the system are running their preventative maintenance programs regularly, and 3) Provide answers to me when there is a problem.I have been using Norton's 360 (PC) and Internet Security (Mac) for my computers for several years, using the Multi-Device package in which you can protect up to 5 PCs, Macs or Android devices.  I thought, with my 8 computers, this Small Business version would be a good package to review, since it seemed so similar to what I was doing now.  Unfortunately, downloading the program for a Mac proved to be a problem, as the instal program would download as a zip. It would next expand, only never to be found.  I kept getting the message that it could not download the support packages, "check your Internet connect and try again later."  (I uploaded this message as a customer image).I thought I might have an issue with my still having Internet Security on the Mac, so I deleted Internet Security, after all a fellow reviewer stated installing this version removed their current version and install this one.  That wasn't the issue as I continued to received the same "cannot download the support packages..."  So, I tried to reinstall my former "Multi-Device" software only to be informed that the Operating System I use, Maverick, which is the latest version, is not supported by my previously used software, even though it has only been installed for 10 months.Historically, I tend to restore my computer every-so-often to get rid of all the clutter, and that includes reinstalling my Norton's, but this time when I reinstalled it using the same Key, it used another of my licenses.Something tells me Norton's is having problems with Apple's updated Operating System, and I cannot recommend this package if you use Macs, like I do.It would be helpful if Norton could post some detailed installation instructions, but given that the "support packages" aren't being installed, I guess we're sort of floating out there on our own.  BTW, Norton has updated how your account information is shown.  It used to show your first installation, the number of installs you had from that package, and clicking on a link would list those installs, and how many installs you had left.  Now, you have to click on "Renew" to get your computer installations and their install dates (you won't be renewed automatically if your automatic renewal switch isn't turned-on, though).Windows Vista made me an Apple customer, if more companies follow Norton's approach, I may have to change and go back to using Windows.  Given that 75% of my computers are Apple products, I cannot recommend this to Apple users.UPDATE (September 4, 2014):  I still have had problems installing the this software on Apple computers; however, when Norton's 360 Multi-Device began expiring on my other computers, you could use the "Product Key" to install this program.  When you did so, it uninstalled Norton's 360 and installed Norton's Anti-Virus, which is not quite the same complete program.  During the install of Norton's Anti-Virus, the account I set-up for its installation showed two previous attempts (an Apple and a PC installation attempt) to install it just using the instructions provided by the Norton's Small Business package had installed, even though they hadn't, thus leaving this 10 device package only usable on 8 computers even using this workaround.  Two days after I uninstalled Norton's 360 and installed Norton Small Business 0 10 Device, a box popped-up and asked me to name this computer.  Then, another box asked me to Set-up Norton Management.  When I used the account E-mail address and password I used to establish the Norton account for this installation, which was different from my other Norton Account, it told me this account does not include an N360 subscription.  I'm thinking this problem goes deeper than just a problem with Macs. I'll check on the Window's installations and see what happened.

I have a number of tool sets, mainly because they are usually reasonably priced when sold as a set and have the tools I need to take care of most "fix-it" jobs around the house.  When I say I have a number of tool sets, I have three (Allied, Channel Lock, and Crescent). Of the three, I usually grabbed the Allied set when someone says, "I need you to fix my ___ ," and I'm not sure which tools I will need.  I grab it because it has a little bit of everything, unfortunately, it has issues, which is why I chose to review Stanley's 210-piece Mixed Tool Set.First off, the Stanley Tool Set has a case unlike any I've ever seen.  With a "turn it this way it's lock, this way it's open" lock on the front of the case.  Gone are the clips that Allied and Crescent used to hold their case together, of which one of the four clips has fallen-off on each of those two sets.  This lock works, even when dropped from a three-foot height, which is about where one would be carrying it when taking it somewhere.  When those clips come undone, the case springs open and your nicely arranged tools get scattered.Opening the case, you see there is a place for everything, and everything is in its place.  The Stanley folks obviously looked at other tool cases before designing theirs because the means of holding-in the pieces isn't just to "snap" them into place, but, in the instance of the sockets, you have a "bulge" that sticks up on the bottom of the socket holder that makes your sockets held-in on three sides.  This reduces the chances your sockets will pop-out.  When I opened-up the case the first time the only tools displaced from their places were two screwdrivers, and I'm sure the USPS put the case through a challenging test before I received it.  Additional testing showed only one of the screwdrivers and the drywall cutter prone to being knocked loose by rough handling of the case.The second thing I noticed is that it has a good selection of tools.  For whatever reason, the other tool sets seemed to leave out one tool or another: would you believe that the Crescent set was the only one of the three that didn't have an adjustable "Crescent" wrench included?  There are sets of both standard and mm size hex wrenches, and they are enclosed in a thick plastic pouch designed to hold them.  Another thing is the Stanley tool set appears to have their Stanley tools in it.  Most of them are stamped with their product number.  So, you're getting Stanley quality, even if it is made in China.The third thing I noticed was the Stanley set had three ratchets (1/2. 1/4 and 1/8 inch sizes), where most only had two (Crescent had three).  That said, I did feel that Stanley should have had two additional pieces in their set: it did not have a 1/4 to 1/8th inch socket adapter, and it only had one 1/4 inch four-inch extension, but maybe that's just because of the type of fix-it jobs I do.  On the positive side, more times than not, I've needed that small ratchet for working in tight places than the longer extension, and I'm glad Stanley has it.On the negative side, I noticed the "spinner," that's the drive nut screwdriver-type driver, had to take an adapter to connect the drive nuts and while I realize you could use a ratchet somehow to duplicate it in some cases, although driving bits would be difficult.  That said, just remember: while the holder for the adapter is rigid, you want to be sure not to misplace it.On the description of the contents of the Tool Kit, it lists four ratchets, but there are only three ratchets provided.  I checked with Stanley Customer Service (800-262-2161), and they said it must be a typo of some sorts as only three are in it.On the positive side, the Stanley Tool Kit does have a 6-inch Adjustable Wrench, a 16-foot tape, a no nonsense pair of needle-nose pliers, 8 wrenches and a nice mix of both standard and mm size sockets.  Customer Service reminded me to tell you that all of the contents, except for the case, have a life-time warranty.  For socket replacement warranties, you can call them.  For hand tool replacement, just E-mail them (google for the address).As for me, now that I have STANLEY'S 210-Piece MIXED TOOL SET, I'm going to take my 1/4 to 1/8-inch adapter and 1/4-inch four inch extension from my Allied set, put it in a Ziplock sandwich bag where the hex wrenches are stored, and sell my old tool kits "As Is" the next time I have a yard sale.

When one has children, or even people we mentor, we look for ways in which we can positively influence their lives and keep them on the positive track towards improving their lives.  Let's face it, life is not getting any easier, and as I look back on my 60 plus years, I sometimes see the problem may seem to be the same, but the solutions, or steps needed for a solution, are more demand and complex.  Knowledge of almost everything is replicating itself faster than we can keep up with it.  In NOTHING CHANGES UNTIL YOU DO, Mike Robbins uses what in the 1970's we would have called a "Zen" approach to look inwardly at solving life's problems in a way so that when we analyze and solve our problems, we'll do so in a way that will help us not repeat them.In addressing problems he and others have faced, Mr. Robbins pulls no punches, unlike some authors who seemingly have never made any mistakes, or at least admitted to making any mistakes.  Robbins addresses how it is easy for us to think we can go through life mistake free, but let's face it, if you ever stick your neck out, you will sometimes get it chopped off.  How one recovers is, in essence, this book, and in explaining this, through personal examples, he adds a layer of human compassion we should always try to maintain for ourselves and others.As I read it, I couldn't help but think of my father, who passed away almost 20 years ago.  Sometimes I think to myself, what I wouldn't give just to have one more week, even one more day, with my father to milk him for the wisdom that I know he had to achieve to get to his place in life.  With NOTHING CHANGES UNTIL YOU DO, I found the closest thing, so far, to duplicating some of that wisdom.  There were times in reading this book I felt my eyes swell-up, I found it that moving.  Other times, I smiled, as I came across something he learned that I had.All-in-all, I found this an excellent book to help anyone find themselves and develop their abilities to deal with life.

As the author, Talayah Stovall, states, LIGHT BULB MOMENTS are those times in ones life when you are doing something, or trying to figure something out, when, suddenly, an idea comes to mind that give you an idea.  In her book, she goes through how she thought of different ideas or solutions to situations she encountered.  Some of these were serious situations, some minor in nature, but all showed how we should use them in solving problems we encounter, or may encounter, in our lives.I liked Ms. Stovall writing style and found her to be a gifted writer; however, I wish she had taken what were mostly vignettes or anecdotes and shown the reader how one builds on them to solve a problem.  An example of this is the story about how her grandfather, as he got older kept wanting to return to his Arkansas roots, and would try to break out of the house and start walking to Arkansas, 800 miles away.  After they had locked all the doors to the house and gates from the yard, grandfather found he could put two blocks, one on their side of the fence, the other on their neighbor's side of the fence, and using those, he could easily climb over the fence and make his escape.  Where did he find the blocks?  Well, they were in his neighbor's yard, and to get those blocks,  he went over the fence and brought back one to put it in their yard.  With this story, her point was how, sometimes, the "blocks" that keep us from achieving our goals are sometimes already accomplished, but we are too focused on a result, rather than the steps to achieve our goal.  This is a commendable lesson, but I wish she had taken this thought further and said something like, "When we look to achieve a goal, we must first think of the steps needed, and decide if they are obtainable; next we need to...etc."There are some "Light Bulb Moments" where she does this, but for me, they were too few and, as they say, too far between.  All-in-all, it is not a bad book; it is just that it could have been a better one, and for that, I've given it just four stars.  People who like her writing, will enjoy this book.  Others, like me, may wish she had expanded her premise further.

Sofia is a about a little girl, a commoner, until her mom marries the king and ... She's whisked off to the castle where she learns that looking like a princess is more difficult than it seems, and thus is the back story of Princess Sofia, featured on Disney Junior Channel.With Sophia the First's Royal Prep Character Collection, you get a very durable plastic collection of the young majesties of the Royal Prep (Princesses Maya, Jun, Clio, Hildegard, Vivian and Amber, along with Prince James), their fairy headmistresses (Flora, Fauna and Merryweather), and Mimimus the horse, Clover the Rabbit, and Crackle the Dragon.  A total of 13 friends.This collection, the most extensive one sold, will give your child and their friends hours of fun as they are able to build upon the television series into new adventures that are only limited by your child's, and her friends', imagination. Through the interactions of the characters, and extension of Sofia's television stories, children learn how to interact with each other.The actual pieces are flexible and highly detailed.  Like most small toys, I would not recommend you buy this if your child and their friends is under the age of three or haven't learned not to put toys in their mouths.  Of all the characters in the collection, Clover the Rabbit is the smallest.  If your child follows the Princess Sofia series, this collection is a great way to start their collection, as it provides Sofia and her friends, and you avoid "piece meal" purchases that often end up costing more.

With Marvel's "Guardians of the Galaxy" movie just around the corner, you knew there was going to be some serious marketing of toys.  While I was confused about the "raccoon" shown in the previews, my younger friends have assured me Rocket Raccoon was the "real deal," and this action figure lives up to all its advertised to be.This is a fun toy, and while I won't say exactly how old I am, I had fun, and the kids I know had fun, too.  I tried to post a video that shows Rocket in action, but only photos can be uploaded, and I'm not quite ready to start posing video reviews.If there's anything I might say about the toy is that when it "blasts" away at its target and talks in a "mean" voice way, it really shakes.  The toy does balance, but most of the guys held it with one hand, while pressing the weapon making him talk (no profanity or even rough language, just rough sounding).The toy held-up well, but I wonder how it would do if I dropped it a lot.  That said, this is a fantastic toy, buy it while you can still find them.

UPDATED:  Our family has used Kernel Season's seasonings on our popcorn for 7 or 8 years, and we were mainly a Nacho Cheddar family, but one day, while at the concessions counter at the theater, my stepdaughter asked if I was going to get any seasoning for the popcorn, and I took out my 2.85 oz. bottle of Nacho Cheddar.  Two guys behind the counter said, "Wow, you've come prepared!"  Then, one suggested I try White Cheddar seasoning, and the other agreed, so we tried it.As expected, Kernel Season's White Cheddar was much milder in flavor, but it was noticeable enhancement to our popcorn, and we all like it.  I especially like how it did not seem to compete with the flavor of the Coke I was drinking when I went from eating popcorn to drinking Coke.  I still like "Nacho Cheddar" the best, but "White Cheddar" comes in a very close second.I would warn you, though, this is an 8.5 ounce bottle, and it is about three times larger than the one you find in your grocery store, so if you don't use it often, or live in a place with high humidity, be prepared for it to harden before you get anywhere near finishing the bottle.  Once it hardens, even if you break it up again with an ice pick, it won't have the same mellow flavor.Update:  One aspect about using Kernel Season's products is that after a couple of weeks they tend to "clump-up."  No matter if you use something (ice pick or knife) to break the seasoning up, again, it tends to have lost some of its zest.  If, after opening the seasoning you put it in the refrigerator, you will find it keeps fresh longer, which is, I guess, what they may have meant when they said "store in a cool, dry place."

UPDATED:  Our family has been using Kernel Season's seasoning for 7 or 8 years, and of the different flavors (White Cheddar, Ranch, Caramel, Bacon and Cheddar Cheese and the Garlic one) we like the Nacho Cheddar one the best.  Before the movie theaters started selling it at the concession stands, we would sneak into the theater some to sprinkle on our popcorn at the movies.  Nacho Cheddar's flavor is lively, without spoiling the flavor of ones soft drink.  With the name "Nacho Cheddar, you'd think it would have a strong "Mexican food" type flavor, but it is just a hint of spice in it, with most of the flavor being "cheddar."  Even if you don't like Mexican food, you will probably like Nacho cheddar if you like the taste of a mild cheddar cheese.If you find several flavors in your grocery store, I'd recommend you try Nacho Cheddar first.Update:  One aspect about using Kernel Season's products is that after a couple of weeks they tend to "clump-up."  No matter if you use something (ice pick or knife) to break the seasoning up, again, it tends to have lost some of its zest.  If after opening the seasoning you put it in the refrigerator, you will find it keeps fresh longer, which is, I guess, what they may have meant when they said "store in a cool, dry place."

One of the nicer aspects of the Internet is that we often come into contact with someone from the other side of the world, and we get to know them, without sometimes knowing them.  Such was the case of one of Sam Smith's band members, whom I have exchanged correspondence with via an iPhone app for almost two years.  After a while, I got this note from him last year asking me, "Did you see me on the "Grams" the other night?'  At first I was puzzled, and after a exchange or two, I found-out he was in the band that played with Adele when she was on the Grammy Awards.  A month or so later, I saw him, again, with her when she sang on the Oscars, and was awarded the Oscar for "Skyfall," the theme from the latest James Bond movie.Last fall, or so, he started telling me about Sam Smith, and how Sam was such an exceptional singer. In December 2013,  I received a video link to the album trailer for "In the Lonely Hour," (Sam Smith - In The Lonely Hour (Album Trailer)) which sent me to YouTube where I saw an exceptional, though short, two minute video of Sam singing and recording the songs.  This fellow is an exceptional talent, with a voice that is as clear and resonate as any you have ever heard.  Since then, I've been aware of his playing in venues all over Europe, but I was truly surprised when his USA tour sold-out in days, and he was mostly playing large venues of more than 2,000!Given that I had seen him perform on videos songs such as "Nirvana" at Abbey Road, and "Lay Me Down" (Live) at Mercury Lounge, I halfway knew what to expect when I received the CD on the day it was released; however, I wondered if his strong stage presence would translate over to strictly audio.  After listening several times to each track, I can see where this debut album is going to be one that everyone will be remembering for many years to come.What is so nice about it is that Sam's voice isn't one of those "one trick ponies" that you get tired on hearing after a couple of plays  There is enough variety between the soulful tunes like "Stay with Me" and "Make it to Me," to the dance-like rhythms of "Money on my Mind" and "La La La," to almost demand repeated replays just to hear him hit a certain note or two.If there is one major theme of "In the Lonely Hour," it is the lover's angst and pain heard in the words and voice as he sings "Leave Your Lover," "I'm Not the Only One," "Like I Can," and "Life Support."  Before hearing this album, for me, there was only one genuine sad moment in a movie or record that could always tug at my heartstrings, and that was the scene at the end of the movie "Casablanca," where Rick is saying good-bye to Ilsa.  For me, this record has become the one to listen to when I think of a love I lost, or one that never quite got going, or one, well, that just hurt.  Sam Smith has somehow, without knowing me, captured the pains I have felt.  And while not all of the feelings, at the time they occurred, were good feelings, I've learned over time that they are to be cherished as much as the pleasant one, because they show you not only the depths you sometime have reached in your life; they, also, show you how you've rebounded and are actually stronger for having gone through them.

When most people think of Bob Hope and the Golden age, they think of his "Road" movies that he made with being Crosby, and while those are consistently good, this collection of 10 movies actually show him at his best with a variety of wonderful leading ladies, namely Martha Raye ("Give me a Sailor," "Never Say Die"),  Paulette Goddard, ("The Cat and the Canary," "The Ghost Breakers," and "Nothing But the Truth"), Jane Russell ("The Paleface") and Lucille Ball ("Sorrowfull Jones").With each movie, you can almost hear the movie executive thinking, "Establish a pretense and let Hope run with it," e.g. "Hope and others in haunted house await the reading of an eccentric relative's will," for "The Ghost Breakers."Several of the movies, like "The Ghost Breakers" will seem familar because the plots have been used often, but seldom were those made since as funny.These movies are Bob Hope at his best when he was "king"  of radio. If I was to rate the movies individually, I'd give 8 of them a 4 out of 4 Star rating and 2 of them a 3 out of 4 Star rating, but which got which might change, depending on my mood the day I watched them.If you are a Bob Hope fan, or know one, this collection of movies is one you, or they, will really enjoy.

UPDATED: I love popcorn, and have experimented popping it and doctoring it up for variety.  One trick I used back in the 1980's was sprinkling some Hidden Valley Ranch Dressing Mix.  I had taken the Ranch Dressing Mix and added it to sour cream to make a dip (since then Hidden Valley has developed a dip mix Hidden Valley, The Original Ranch Dip Mix, 1 Oz, and one day I decided to sprinkle it on my popcorn.  Most of my friends liked it, and while I liked the taste, I thought it was a little "gritty."With Kernel Season's Ranch Seasoning, the "gritty" issue I experienced has been solved.  Kernal Season's Ranch Seasoning has a "ranch" flavor that is mild enough not to overpower your senses, and it left a pleasant after taste in ones mouth.I have used various Kernel Season's seasonings for at least six, maybe more, years, and I found their latest updated container easy to use.  Over the years, I have found the seasoning, if you don't use it regularly, will start clumping, but that might be more my living in an area that has high humidity.  I have used at least five different flavors (Nacho, White Cheddar, Ranch, Carmel, and Butter) over the years, and Kernel Season's Ranch Seasoning is one of my favorites.  I did find it not as tasty when I drank Coca-Cola, as it seemed to flavors conflicted with each other, but this could just be my individual taste buds kicking it.  However, I still use it from time-to-time and always have it for family to use when we have a "movie" night, though.Update:  One aspect about using Kernel Season's products is that after a couple of weeks they tend to "clump-up."  No matter if you use something (ice pick or knife) to break the seasoning up, again, it tends to have lost some of its zest.  If after opening the seasoning you put it in the refrigerator, you will find it keeps fresh longer, which is, I guess, what they may have meant when they said "store in a cool, dry place."

I have a nice size home that was built in the middle 1970's that has limestone on the bottom story and with heavy-gauge grey siding outside the second story, that I have been cleaning every so often, especially the gable end on the north side of the house.I enjoy experimenting with processes, and have used various methods and products to clean the siding over the 14 years I have owned the house.  Before I tell you about this product, let me stated what I've used before to clean the siding on my house.  I started with just spraying the housed with brass nozzle Gilmour Solid Brass Water Jet Nozzle 06BJ, but I found after four to six months, I had to spray the house off, again.  So, I used a pressure washer, and that seemed to keep the house, mainly the north side mold-free for 8 months.  Windex once had a cleaner you could attach to your hose and spray on the siding, but it kept the siding clean only as long as the pressure washer, and you had to use a pressure washer to get it really clean before your first application if you wanted it to work best, so it had no benefit.  When I told the guy at the hardware store about my experiments, he told me I should be using a product like Jomax  Zinsser - Jomax House Cleaner & Mildew Killer Jomax Mildew Cleaner 1 Gal.: 647-60101 - jomax mildew cleaner 1 gal..  Applying Jomax by using a tank sprayer and spraying a mixture of bleach, water and Jomax on the siding and using the brass nozzle on the hose to rinse it off gave me a year-and-a-half to two years of mold-free siding before I had to use it, again, and that's reapplying when it just started having that "grey" powder on the siding, not full-fledged mold.Given my history, when I saw Amazon was letting us test KRUD KUTTER HS01 GREEN PRESSURE WASHING CONCENTRATE HOUSING AND SIDING CLEANER, I thought I'd try in out.  While the proof in a siding cleaner will come in how long it keeps my siding clean and mold-free (I will update this review to show how long it lasted or if any issues developed), I was not very impressed with it from the "get-go" because the instructions mentioned putting it into a siphon-type sprayer, which I didn't have, but it sounded like it was similar to their KRUD KUTTER HOUSE WASH hose attachment KRUD KUTTER HW32H House Wash, 32-Ounce.  Adding it to ones pressure washer, I have a Simpson 3200, Simpson PS3228-S PowerShot 3200 PSI 2.8 GPM Honda GX200 Engine Gas Pressure Washer and spraying was easy enough.  KRUD KUTTER had similar instructions as the Jomax: spray nearby bushes with water to protect them from overspray, spray area with water first, spray the area with the KRUD KUTTER, wait three to five minutes and rinse.Since it uses no bleach, it had less odor than the Jomax, but because just using a pressure washer would clean the siding itself, I couldn't tell if the KRUD CUTTER did a better job.  Cost-wise, I had to use more KRUD KUTTER than I expected to use.  Living down south near a cheek and a river, this summer will be a good test of this product, which I will report later, but based on what I have encountered using it this time, I am sticking with my Jomax for now.

Thirteen years ago, I had Lasik corrective eye surgery which gave me 20-20 distance vision.  At the time, I, also, got a pair of  prescription glasses for reading, which since then has been replaced many times over with simple readers.  After retiring, I decided I wanted to learn to work with wood, so I am taking a cabinet making class at the local community college, where we are required to wear safety glasses when working in the shop.Soon I found my work was being slowed down by having to change to my "readers" every time I needed to read something or work on something up close.  I had found 3M's safety glasses to be a good fit for work with sidewalk trimmers, etc., and I even wore them in the shop.  So, I gave these a shot, choosing the 2.0 magnification because I wanted to be able to look at things clearly, yet, not have to hold things too close to my face.These safety glasses are terrific!  And, after using them for over two months, I have found them to be comfortable with the soft rubber cushions across the top of the glasses and behind the ears; I have actually found them to be clear as my "glass" readers, if not clearer;  and, they stay attached to the padded cord I use to hang them around my neck.If I wouldn't get weird looks, I'd wear them all the time, but you know being married, I can't always do what I'd like to do.Since my "glass" readers tend to last only a month at best, I bought a second pair, but even though I've lost one pair of "glass" readers and broken a second pair of "glass" readers since I've have been using these safety glasses, my safety glasses are as good as the day I bought them.  I would suggest you rinse them regularly with clean water and wipe them dry using a clean cotton handkerchief.

In the world of shaving, it tends to come down to Schick and Gillette to develop better razors.  Over the years, I have tested the two brands on almost a weekly basis, but when I saw the Amazon Vine program offering several Schick razors for testing, I offered my stepdaughter, a 30-something who has temporarily, I hope, been residing at home a chance to be a tester.  This might seem a little different, but several years ago, when she and I were shopping together, and I needed a new razor, I ended-up buying her, at her request, the Schick Quartro Trimmer Schick Quattro Trimmer for Women.  Since I saw she still had the other razor in her shower, I asked if she might want to test one of the newer Schick razors for women.  She jumped at the chance.First of all, she liked the soft green color.  It didn't stick-out mounted on her bone-colored tub enclosure, but it was different enough that she could easily find it if any leftover soap got in her eyes.  She said it wasn't heavy, but it wasn't so lightweight that you could nick yourself.  She said the soft rubber handle was easy to grip and control, and made it easier to shave places like the back of ones legs.  The skin guards, or whatever you'd call the extra soft rubber around the razor blades, did not drag when using regular body soap.  Overall, she found it to be a great razor, with only one grip, and let me tell you, if she can complain about something, she will.  The bracket for holding the razor to the wall of the shower, with a suction cup, that came with her razor wasn't the easiest thing to put the razor in, but that is really rather trivial, as she found the razor the easiest she has ever used, especially shaving under her arms. She said the cushioned head prevented nicks, and the handle was designed to make it easy to manipulate all shaving areas.The proof of the test came when I found her previous Shick Quartro shaver in the bathroom trash can.  Don't tell her, but I tested the shaver for closeness by shaving one-half of my face with it and the other-half with a Schick Hydro 5 Power Razon Schick Hydro 5 Power Select Razor, and after a day, I found the side shaved with her Schick Hydro Silk Sensitive Razor had less noticeable stubble.  And, thus ends, what I hope will be the last women's razor test I will ever do with my stepdaughter.

In my software filing cabinet, I have Access 1.0 on 3.5 inch floppy disks, and along the way I upgraded with Office Professional so I would have it; however, almost 10 years ago, I stopped using Access and went back to just using Excel for developing management solutions. It was because it wasn't worth the effort, both in developing the database and getting others used to using it.With Filemaker Pro 13, one has a program that is easier to use; it allows you to present the data easily; and most of all, it can work cross many platforms.  I, also, like that you can vary access, no pun intended, to data.Like that original copy of Access, it is pricy, but in this instance, you get what you paid for.

The Hot Wheels Workshop Track Builder Starter Set is a great center piece for any Hot Wheels set-up as you can have five cars start from the central tower.One aspect about the "Starter Set" is that it is a starter set, and you need to purchase some other Hot Wheels Builder Stunts and accessories to get full enjoyment of the set-up.  This is probably why Mattel sent with the Starter Set a number of Builder Stunt set-ups for me to try.  Of the ones they included in addition to the TRack Builder Starter Set,  the Hot Wheels Track Builder Deluxe Quick Kick Loop Stunt Set  and Hot Wheels Track Builder Crossroad Crash Stunt Pack seemed to generate the most excitement when added to this set-up.  So, plan on spending around $50-60 more if you don't already have some Hot Wheels cars and accessories.  BTW, one reviewer mentioned there were 5 cars included in his set. In the one I had, and it was sealed tight, there was only one car included.The set-up takes-up a fair amount of space so allow at least a 5 x 7 foot area for it.  The track is easy to set-up, but it is far more difficult to break-down, but this is good, because you don't have to worry about it coming apart like these tracks did when I was growing-up.  Be sure to allow your youngsters additional time to put these tracks away.  You should, also, have an 8 gallon plastic container to store the pieces because there is no way you will be able to get all the pieces back into the box after taking them out.Overall, it's a great set and reasonably priced for what you get.

In the stores it is easy to find the yellow highlighters mixed in with four or five other colors, but I only wanted the "yellow" ones, and this price is normal.  Additionally, I have found the "retractable" highlighters last longer mainly because I don't lose the cap.
The perfect inserts for my Rolfs Passport Wallet. You'll need these as the Rolfs wallet will last you a couple of decades, but "plastic" seldom does.
I bought this for my wife and it was a perfect match, in color and leather texture, to her Coach leather satchel.

Without a doubt, this is one remarkable book.  As a former contract officer who handled over 1200 kitchen and bathroom renovations, a public administrator who has overseen the human resources for agencies that had from 8 to over 80 employees, and as someone who is currently learning to build kitchen cabinets and bathroom vanities, I cannot think of anything this book does not address with regards to starting and running a kitchen and bath renovation or installation business.  I know this is a very strong statement to make, and as a former public administrator, I learned to never use the words "always, never or anything" in describing anything because just as soon as you do, something comes along and bites you on the posterior, but in this case, I have met an instance where the word "anything" can be used, and I won't lose any sleep at night.KITCHEN AND BATH BUSINESS AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT, WITH WEBSITE addresses the following, and this is not a complete list:The how's and why's of starting a business, from do you have the creativity, the energy or the finances to do it, to do you have the temperament to deal with the customers.  This is all written about in detailed articles and expansive questionnaires.What kind of staff and employees do you need and what will be their roles.  How to develop job descriptions, how to hire, and how to develop your staff and employees.How to get the word about your company "out there," whether it be advertising, web presence, word of mouth, collaboration with other contractors, etc.How to set-up your inventory, keep tabs of inventory and determine your cost basis.How to estimate jobs and deal with potential customer's expectations, and not make promises you cannot keep.How to design installations, install cabinets, conduct inspections of installations (including what problems to look for during those inspections, and how to address those problems) and deal with customer complaints.How to turn completed jobs into future jobs.Oh, and how to be run a safe operation and what one must do to comply with OSHA.There is plenty of information in this manual for anyone starting or running any business, much less a kitchen and bath business.  I noticed that the companion book Kitchen & Bath Residential Construction and Systems (NKBA Professional Resource Library) is also available, and while I haven't read it, I would imagine it would be excellent, too.  I cannot recommend this book any higher than I am doing so here.  While there is information that someone doing a home renovation or designing a kitchen or bath could use, a book like The Essential Kitchen Design Guide would probably be better to read.

So you find yourself, maybe like I did, upset with Windows and buying a Mac.  I did so several years ago, when Vista was their Operation System (O/S), and my first Apple O/S was Tiger.  Since then, I've faithfully updated my Apple O/S through Leopard, Snow Leopard, Lion, Mountain Lion and, now, Maverick.  Suddenly, in looking at the tasks I used to do, there seems to be new steps that I'm not aware of, and just a glance at iTunes shows Apple's done a number on it where it doesn't look anything like it ever did.  As it turns out, the changes have been steadily coming, and I was contently doing the things I always did, for the most part, not realizing Apple's world has passed me by.TEACH YOURSELF VISUALLY OS X MAVERICKS is an excellent book it that it takes one through each step of the process in doing something.  It is, almost, impossible to not do it correctly.  I say "impossible" because I'm sure I'll get impatient and jump a step in anticipation, but the steps are there, and they are easy to follow.This book is also for you if are one who has just bought your first Apple Mac and need someone holding your hands through the process.  It is not a book to tell you how to do everything, but it will get you more than started on using a Mac to its full potential.  Realizing just how behind I am, I have bought a second book, OS X Mavericks on Demand, by Steve Johnson, as a companion piece, and I read them side-by-side as I learn how to do tasks, whether for the first time or a refresher course.  This is not a trouble-shooting book, as those then to be more technical, and have less pictures.  This is a book on how to maximize the updated features that have come with Maverick and the iLife and iWork programs.If you are giving someone their first Mac, or are like myself, slightly behind in your Apple skills, this is a very good book to buy, and you will find you will reach for it first before any other book on Maverick.

We have a "glass top" cooking range, and I needed to get a skillet with a porcelain-type bottom to prevent any marks on the range's top.  I thought this might be a great product, especially after I received it, but even after following the instructions "to the letter" and even hand washing it after it had cooled down, the skillet's exterior began flaking off.  I have posted a picture that shows what the flaking looked like.There is no way I could recommend this skillet, or any of their similar products, I am just thankful Amazon is taking it back and refunding my money.

The sinuses in our family seem to run 24/7, and with this condition a sore throat soon follows.  When checking the throat of a loved one, you want to make sure you use a sterile tongue depressor and have them say, "Ah," as that causes another inch of the throat to rise-up and be seen when you are using a flashlight to view their throats.  These depressors are "OK," but I found them difficult to separate their paper covers because the glue holding the two covers together extended to the end of each cover.  Other than that, I found these to be clean and sterile.

For the price of a couple of extra dollars, you get not only a charming calendar to help you keep track of your days, but, also, a DVD of the previous year's calendar shoot, which usually sells for around $20.  This is a bargain too good to pass-up.

The title of Galadrielle Allman's biography of her father, Duane Allman, is taken from Scott Boyer's song "Please Be With Me," which was recorded by the group Cowboy, with Duane Allman providing the slide guitar accompaniment, is so appropriate for this book of remembrances that chronicle the mostly ups, and a few downs, of the genius of Duane Allman.  For anyone who has ever heard the silky tones of what his slide guitar sounds like, you soon begin to realize that at some point in his life, the gods of music touched Duane's heart and fingers, and they freed musical tones to be channeled through to a guitar for the rest of the world to hear and be in awe.This is an extraordinary book, and one immediately recognizes it will be one as Galadrielle Allman begins it with these first sentences:  "My father is killed in the first paragraph of every article ever written about him.  His life story is told backwards, always beginning at the end: in the road, his motorcycle down, his body broken. People linger over the wreckage as if it says something meaningful about his life."Galadrielle was two years old when her father died, and while one may ask, how can a two year old write a biography about someone she could not have possibly remembered much about, you soon realize she does have her memories, and more importantly, she has chronicled her father's life from others remembrances to give an almost "no holes barred" recount of her father's life.  As you read her book, she recounts circumstances in Duane's life that went into making him the musical artist he was, whether it be how he took time to visit and write an injured friend or how attending a military prep helped in his developing as a band leader.The book details the shock Galadrielle feels when she learns she is not Duane's only child, a secret she learns from someone who was writing a book about the band.  While Galadrielle's words detail the hurt she felt at first when she first learns of her half-sister, she, also, expresses a sadness for her after she learns her half-sister was born deaf because her mother contracted rubella during her pregnancy, as she writes, referring to the memories she has of her father versus those her half-sister never had, "Stranger still, all I have of him, which never felt like enough to satisfy my need for him--the stories I have gathered, the relationships with our extended family, and even my name--suddenly feels like a great wealth of riches that she does not share, and I feel ashamed of that.  Most of all, I am wounded by the thought that she cannot hear his music."As one reads through PLEASE BE WITH ME, one gets a true feeling of what it is like developing a band, and just how difficult it was.  There is very little of Duane's life that isn't documented in this book: from the birth of Galadrielle to her parents break-up, from Duane's lifting spirit, to sometimes dark moods.  With regards to the Duane's collaboration with other artists, such as Boz Scaggs, Delaney & Bonnie, Eric Clapton, et. al., she recounts the how those came about, and how that collaboration made their music better.If there is a weakness in this book, it is that the stories are just that, and at times the stories seem to run together, but for the most part, the book, when Galadrielle is writing strictly from her feelings, you feel a certain poetry expressed in her sentences, for example, her description of Macon, Georgia, is, "Macon is beautiful in the spring, white magnolia blossoms hanging heavily in the trees, fallen pink cherry petals swirling on the cobblestone streets, and new grass growing in so green it hurts to look right at it."  Having been raised in the South, I immediately recognize her description, having seen it in so many Southern cities.I began this book by referring to the song, "Please Be with Me," that was written by Scott Boyer and sung by the group Cowboy.  If you ever wondered just what it was about Duane Allman's playing that added to a song, do a search on YouTube, first of "please be with me duane allman," and then of "please be with me eric clapton," and note the differences in the way the music was played.  This is not a knock on Eric Clapton, for I view him as one of the greatest guitarists there ever was, but a comparison of the two song reveals the gifts Duane Allman brought to the songs he played on.  Also, speaking of Eric Clapton, if you ever get a chance, listen to the jams that Eric Clapton and Duane Allman on the extended version of the album "Layla and other Assorted Love Songs" by Derek and the Dominos.  Those recordings will show you how two great guitarists can feed off of each other.During this past year, the documentary "Muscle Shoals" was released, and this book provides wonderful stories about the recording sessions Duane had at FAME Studios In Muscle Shoals and Muscle Shoals Sound Studios in Sheffield.  Being a resident of the Shoals area, I knew some of these stories, and I am glad to read of other stories I hadn't heard before.  Which brings me to two personal remembrances of Duane Allman.  The first being the only time I ever heard the Allman Brothers play live.At the time, I was attending school at the University of Alabama in Birmingham, UAB, and I was on the Entertainment Committee at the school.  It seemed there was a promoter that the Allman Brothers owed a concert, but he couldn't find a place to stage it, and he proposed having the Entertainment Committee sponsor it.  This was in 1970, just before "Idlewild South," a name for a cabin they used back then.  The Entertainment Committee rented the Oporto National Guard Armory near Eastwood Mall in Birmingham, and we were treated to three-and-a-half hours of great music as they played all of the tunes from their first album, "The Allman Brothers," plus all of their upcoming album, "Idlewild South." The band was on a stage elevated five or so feet off of the concrete floor of the armory, and the band, with its two drummers, two lead guitarists, bass player and Greg Allman's massive B3 Hammond and amplifiers, took-up a third of the back wall.  The place was packed, with only the local Fire Marshall stopping the people wanting to pay their $7.00 to get in to hear them.  The band played so tight, yet they, also, seemed to be jamming at times, that before we knew it, it was 11:30, and the Fire Marshall literally turned on the house lights and made everyone start leaving, or I think, we'd have been there for a couple of more hours, as the band seemed to be feeding off of the positive energy of the crowd.My second remembrance isn't really a remembrance, rather it was an experience I had while taking a tour of the Hard Rock Cafe's Vault in London, England.  My wife and I are very proud of the musical heritage of "The Shoals," as most everyone calls the area in which we live, and as we went through the tour, we started telling stories about some of the artists who had recorded at the old Muscle Shoals Sound Studio on 3614 Jackson Highway, Duane, Bob Dylan, Lynyrd Skynyrd, etc.  It wasn't long before we had as many folks listening to us talk as the tour guide had.  So, he walks up to me carry this Fender Strat, and says to me, "Here, this is the Strat Duane Allman played on for the tune "Layla" with Derrick and the Dominos.  It's number 19, you play it while I give the tour," and with that, I held this really sweet instrument whose strings played so perfectly up and down the fret board.  It was an experience I will never forget.This book isn't for everyone, I know, but for those who love Duane Allman's music, who want to know what the Allman Brothers Band went through in their development, or even a large part of what the music scene was like during the late 1960's and early 1970's, Galadrielle Allman's PLEASE BE WITH ME: A SONG FOR MY FATHER, DUANE ALLMAN will be a book you will enjoy reading.NOTE: This review was based upon an advanced copy I received through Amazon's Vine Program.  It is anticipated that the book will be available for purchase in early March 2014.  There could be some changes in the book when it is finally published, but, if there are, it is expected that those will probably be minor.  I was asked how I received an advance copy, and I replied:As a member of Amazon's "Vine Program," Vine reviewers receive an E-mail of products Amazon thinks we would like to review. Usually, the items they notify us are of items similar to what we have shown an interest in or have reviewed in the past. A week after we receive the first E-mail, we receive a second one listing all the products people in the program have not chosen. Most of the books I have reviewed have just been published or are on the verge of being published. Ms. Allman's biography of her father, Duane, was offered to Vine members almost two months before it is being published. It is a "pre-published proof," which means it may still be edited some, but for the most part, only minor grammatical corrections will be made to it before it is published.

In the late 1970's, Disco music was still be played, and the Beach Boy's, with "Here comes the Night" ventured into Disco, producing a very harmonic, and long, disco song.  It's not great, but it's not trash either, and it makes a great conversation piece.

I have been reading Twentieth Century European history for over thirty years.  I knew that Churchill had played an important role in that history.  The great pleasure of reading "The Last Lion" was to learn that his influence was even greater than I had realized.  This is an immensely enjoyable  book with first rate narration.  Highly recommended!

These black and white photos were taken at the turn of the Twenty First Century.  Yet there is something so classic about Herzog's images they look like they could have been made fifty or seventy five years ago.  Her images capture something so timeless that at their core they capture man's fascination with the size, strength and speed of bulls.  It is this primal fascination that pushes some men to fight them and others to watch.  In "Tauromaquia", Herzog beautifully documents all of the splendid horror and brutality that is at the heart of bull fighting.  Bull fighting is not for everybody but if you love it, "Tauromaquia" is for you.  Finally, purchase the hardback because the paperback edition is printed in a small format.  Highly recommended!

Daniel Alarcon left Peru as a young child and settled with his family in Birmingham, Alabama.  He experienced Peru's war years while on summer vacations and through family stories.  Like others who experienced the war, it left a deep impression on him.  In one form or another, this experience of war informs Alarcon's first three novels."At Night We Walk in Circles" follows the well worn structure of the travel narrative.  Three friends/actors leave the capitol city to travel up into the mountains to recreate a legendary theatrical tour from the war years.  At its core, this narrative is a trip back into time and memory in an attempt to deal with a war time trauma.  Alarcon is a gifted writer and it was a pleasure to follow him on this journey.  But I must confess, the point of the journey alluded me.  "At Night We Walk in Circles" is a good novel but not as strong as the first two.

There is something deeply human about wanting to be close to the physical remains of a loved one.  Unfortunately, modern warfare has evolved so that some of the dead are so physically mangled that they are no longer identifiable.  As a result, grieving families do not have an individual grave they can connect with their loved one.  After the Great War, the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier arose as a symbolic touchstone for a grieving nation to connect with the missing and unidentifiable casualties of the War.  The "Unknown Solider" movement with its concurrent rituals began in England and France and soon spread throughout the world.  These Tombs continue to resonate into the Twenty First Century.Please note that "The Unknown Soldier" was written for a middle school audience.  This book works really well for its intended audience.  If you are looking for a more sophisticated approach, you will have to look elsewhere.

John Pohl makes a very good argument for reading his book in the very first paragraph.  He notes, " Traditionally, Late Medeival European History focuses on the Hundred Years War, followed by England's War of the Roses and the Swiss Wars against Burgundy and the Empire.  Attention shifts to Spain only after 1492, with the fall of Granada and the first explorations and conquests in the Americas.  This may leave the reader with a sense of astonishment that seemingly from nowhere the 'Catholic Monarchs' Fernando and Isabel were able to lay the foundation for the world's first global empire."  That introductory paragraph nails it.  Why were the Spanish able to create an immense global empire in such short order?With Osprey, you never know what you are going to get.  The quality of their book's authors range from bumbling enthusiasts to pedantic professors and every once in a while you will find an author who can really write.  Fortunately, "Armies of Castille and Aragon" is one of Osprey's better endeavors.  Professor John Pohl cannot only write clear prose but also has the gift of simplifying complex history.  In a short forty seven pages, Pohl beautifully answers the question he posits in the introductory paragraph.  This short book was a joy to read and I highly recommend it.

A true American classic.  It is as elegant and functional as when the Open Road was introduced in the 1940's.  When you reach that point in your life when you feel a little bit silly walking around in a baseball cap, take the leap and purchase your first Stetson.  A better hat for a gentleman of a certain age does not exist.  Highly recommended!

I would recommend the audio cd only for people with prior study of the Peloponnesian War.  This is an ancient text and without the proper background, it will be difficult to listen to because so many of the references are obscure.  The best overall study of the Peloponnesian War is Donald Kagan's book.  He dedicated his career to the deep study of this conflict and his book is a modern masterpiece.  Reading Kagan is great preparation for taking on Thucydides.  I would next recommend "The Landmark Edition of Thucydides".  It is by far the best edition to read.  Its many footnotes and scholarly essays are absolutely first rate.  Listening to Thucydides is a pleasure with the right preparation.  Highly recommended!

If your primary interest is in learning the history of the Peloponnesian War, I would recommend Donald Kagan's masterful book on the subject.  Kagan dedicated his career to the study of the war and his book is a modern masterpiece.  I had the good fortune to read Kagan before reading the "The Landmark Thucydides."  It made the whole experience much more enjoyable.  I understood what was going on and did not have to spend so much time with the Landmark footnotes.If you want to take the big leap and take on Thucydides, the Landmark Edition is a must.  While not as strong as Kagan, the introduction and scholar essays are first class and go a long way to making Thucydides approachable to the modern reader.  However, what takes The Landmark Edition to another level is the footnotes and maps.  If you have the patience and take the time to really study the text, you can really develop a deep understanding of Thucydides.Finally, Robert Strassler is a real hero.  Let us hope that he is able to produce more Landmark Editions.  In my book, Strassler has covered himself with glory and has done the reading public a great service.  Highly recommended!

Steven Pressfield has carved himself a place as a genre writer of historical fiction set in the ancient world.  "The Afghan Campaign" follows the travails of an ordinary soldier during Alexander the Great's conquest of Afghanistan.  Pressfield's conceit is that warfare in Afghanistan has not changed in over two thousand years.  "The Afghan Campaign" is a genre novel and as such works beautifully.  The modern reader learns a little history, follows an exciting plot and is reinforced in the widely held view that Afghanistan is an especially wild and barbarous place.  "The Afghan Campaign" is not great literature but succeeds within the constraints of its genre.  My wife has her Chick Lit and this type of genre book is my equivalent guilty pleasure.  Recommended.

Claudio Linati (1790-1832) was an Italian painter and lithographer who moved to Mexico in 1825.  He is best known for his book "Costumes Civils, militaires et religieux du Mexico published in Belgium in 1828.  The book is a collection of lithographs and descriptions produced by Linati in the mid 1820's.  The lithographs are fascinating because they show ever day life in the years immediately following the War of Independence from Spain.  Linati's wonderfully detailed images show a wide variety of races, social classes and professions."Trajes Civiles, Militares Y Religiosos de Mexico" is a Spanish language 1957 reprint of the original 1828 edition.  This book is a nearly sixty year old and was a high quality publication for its time.  This is a well produced book and will be of great interest for all those interested in the material culture of the early Mexican Republic.  I cannot wait until Linati's book is once again published with Twenty First Century production values.  Highly recommended!

Soon after war was declared against Germany, Jose de la Luz Saenz volunteered to join the U.S. Army.  Saenz was a teacher and family man from South Texas.  He volunteered instead of waiting to be drafted because he wanted to show his patriotism and commitment to the country of his birth.  During the Great War, Saenz kept a diary which he published in Spanish in1933.Saenz' diary can be read on many different levels.  At its core, Saenz' diary is a chronicle of his life as a front line American soldier fighting in the trenches of France.  As an educated school teacher, Private Saenz was given the opportunity to work in his battalion's headquarters unit where he  served as a French language translator.  Although he was in a support unit, Saenz was up close to the fighting and experienced war in all of its random brutality.  Jose de la Luz Saenz was a good writer and did a solid job of recounting his wartime experiences. The Great War produced many great first person narratives.  As a diary, Saenz' work is good but not great.The real value of Saenz' diary is as a political text.  In 1917, Saenz was a member of Texas' very small Mexican American middle class.  At that time, living conditions for Mexicans and Mexican Americans were especially difficult.  The society was openly racist and very violent.  Saenz saw military service during war as the catalyst that would change how Mexican people were treated in Texas.  Taking up arms in service of the United States was a political action which would allow veterans and their families to assert that they were United States citizens with all the corresponding rights.  These political themes run throughout Saenz' diary and that is what makes it such an interesting book.The Great War changed conditions for Mexican Americans in Texas.  It was Saenz and his generation of middle class war veterans who would go on to start the League of United Latin American Citizens.  This organization was the first statewide Mexican American political organization in Texas.  It would soon grow into other states and begin the fight for Mexican American civil rights.  With Saenz' diary, the reader can read about the seeds that led to these changes.  This is fascinating book and I highly recommend it.

By their very nature, bande desinee albums are visually rich.  I purchase them for their striking  images and not necessarily for their stories.  Fortunately, Pierre Veys' story is as strong as it can be within the constraints of the genre.  But what makes this album are the beautifully detailed images of the illustrator Carlos Puerta.  His images have a photorealistic quality to them that I found very pleasing.  His coloring of the images is also first rate.  This is the first Carlos Puerta  bande desinee that I have read.  I will be searching out his other works.  Highly recommended!

"The Great War-The Persuasive Power of Photography" was published in conjunction with a 2014 show at the National Gallery of Canada.  The purpose of the book is to present a broad survey of Great War photography.  To do this, the author developed broad categories into which photos could be placed.  These categories range from personal portraits and amateur photo albums to more mundane categories like propaganda photos, unit portraits and battlefield reconnaissance.  There is also an interesting section on French stereoscopic photography. The intent of this book is to cast a very wide net.  The images that accompany the text are fascinating in their ordinariness.  The curators of this exhibit valued breadth over the beauty of the individual images.  As a reviewer, I have a definite bias towards the humanistic depiction of war.  I look for images that reveal the humanity of the subjects.  I did not give this book five stars because too many of the images are quotidian in nature.

Osprey Publishing has a problem with quality control.  When you purchase an Osprey book, you never know whether you are getting a small gem or a dry desiccated dud.  I am pleased to report that "Pylos and Sphacteria" is one of those little gems.  I am currently reading Thucydides and have just finished the section on the Spartan disaster at Pylos.  Even with the help of the beautifully detailed Robert Strassler edition, many of the details of the battle were not clear to me.Like many Osprey authors, William Shepherd loves his subject.  With a sure hand, he reconstructs this 2,400 year old battle.  His photographs of Pylos and Sphacteria bring the story to life in a way the written word cannot do.  In addition, the veteran illustrator Peter Dennis lends his formidable skills to this endeavor.  I only hope Shepherd took advantage of his trip to Pylos to write a future Osprey campaign book on the battle of Navarino Bay.  Highly recommended!

Over the years, I have read a number of Inspector Maiget novels.  Whenever I pick up a new Maigret novel, I know that it will be a great read.  Most will be five stars and the disappointing ones will be four stars. Georges Simenon had a successful formula and his readers knew that he could deliver that trademark formula novel after mystery novel.  One of the pleasures of "The Late Monsieur Gallet" (1931) is that it is Simenon's third Maigret novel.  It is a pleasure to see Jules Maigret near the start of his career.  All of Simenon's narrative mastery is present from the very beginning.  As should be expected, "The Late Monsier Gallet" delivers.  Highly recommended!

I have read many books of Greek mythology and history to my children and "Heroes, Gods and Monsters" has to be one of the best.  There is a reason why a book first published in 1966 is continually republished.  Bernard Evslin has the narrative gift.  I would recommend purchasing the audio cd.  Like the author, the actor reading the book is also gifted.  The Greek myths began as spoken word presentations.  I believe the best way to present these myths to young children is through the audio cd.  The marriage of great text and gifted actor is magical.  Highly recommended.

A dystopian novel set in Colorado where my childhood neighborhood is mentioned, how could I not love it?  "The Dog Stars" is not high art or even middlebrow pap.  It is just plain old summer fun.  Heller knows his audience and hits a home run.  Recommended.

John D. Clare's "Living History" series is one best history series for children that I have ever come across.  Clare's approach is to find re-enactors and use them to illustrate his texts.  The re-enactors take their hobbies seriously and their attention to period detail is extraordinary.  This is the type of series that could only have been produced in England.  They have the historical buildings that they can use as backdrops for the re-enactors.  This marriage of strong written text and great period photos cannot be beat.  Highly recommended!

"The Italian Renaissance" is part of the Living History Series.  This series marries a well written text with detailed photographs of period re-enactors.  The quality of the photos are absolutely first rate.  A great deal of time and expense was spent in recreating images of the Italian Renaissance.  This emphasis on recreating past history allows the reader to step back in time and imagine themselves in the photos.An earlier reviewer claims an anti-Catholic bias in the text.  I think this is unfair.  The Roman Papacy reached both great heights and lows during the Renaissance.  But note, this book covers much more than the Roman Catholic church.  There are great sections on the arts and science of the time.  I have read a lot of history books with my children and the "The Italian Renaissance" is one of the best books that we have read.  This is a great book and I highly recommend it.

"The Voyages of Christopher Columbus" is part of the Living History Series.  The Editor of this series thought the best way to bring history to life was to photograph historical re-enactors.  I think this is great approach because it allows children to step back in time and imagine themselves in the photos.  A strong text accompanies the well shot photos.  This is a great book that will be enjoyed by both children and parents alike.  Highly recommended!

"The Stanford Law Chronicles" was a must purchase for me.  Like the author, I am a Mexican American graduate of Stanford Law School.  I finished only a few years ahead of him and know many of the people of whom he writes.  My wife is even mentioned in the book.  It is from this close vantage that I review this book.As a tenured sociology professor with a strong activist commitment to social justice, Alfredo Mirande was not a typical first year Stanford law student.  Not only was he much older but Mirande was a lot more accomplished that the typical twenty four year old law student.  From the very beginning, Mirande viewed himself as a participant observer in the law school experience.  This informed distance made his experience different from that of the average student.As a sociologist, Mirande was interested in  how Stanford Law School formed students to enter into America's legal and business elites.  Throughout his three years at Stanford, Mirande was both an insider and an outsider.  By joining the law review and clerking for a judge, Mirande followed the path of an ambitious law student.  Yet at the same time,  his formation as an activist Chicano professor would never allow him to fully embrace that experience.  Like many other students, Mirande felt that combination of alienation and boredom which is so typical of the law school experience.The value of "The Stanford Law Chronicles" can be seen in at least two levels.  First, as a sociological study on the formation of American elites.  Second and I think more importantly, "The Stanford Law Chronicles" is a rare autobiography from a Mexican American intellectual.  There are many books on the formation of elites but Mexican American autobiographies are scarce.  Alfredo Mirande is a gifted writer and it is as an autobiography that "The Stanford Law Chronicles" will be read in coming years.

Like many people, I have followed the course of Israeli history through the daily newspapers.  As a result, I see Israel through the prism of current events.  The best thing about "My Promised Land" is that it puts the history of Israel into its proper context.  By tracing the history of Israel, I was able to develop a more organic understanding of how the country has developed.  Ari Shavit is an excellent writer and a truly gifted guide.  Highly recommended!

The initial stumbling block with "I, Juan de Pareja" is that a slave and Spanish renaissance painter can have a warm and caring personal relationship.  It is not an unreasonable to question whether a slave  can ever have a good relationship with the person who owns him.  But if you can cross this initial barrier, you will find "I, Juan de Pareja" to a good read.  The book is well written and filled with rich period details.  My nine year old daughter and I both enjoyed the book.  The book works only if you can suspend a certain amount of disbelief.

Born in 1913 in the Department of Cuzco, Julio Benavente Diaz was the greatest charangista of his generation.  He became a school teacher and spent long periods of time in the remote villages of his region where he collected old Quechua songs and melodies.  He was typical of the Latin American musicians/intellectuals of the post-war years who sought to make folk music respectable to the middle and professional classes.  They did this by taking rural music and transforming it something that represented the spirit of the nation and its people."Peru-Perou: Charango & Songs from Cuzco" was recorded in Paris in 1985.  This was towards to the end of Julio Benavente Diaz' career.  The album consists of just him and his charango.  There is no folklorico group backing him up.  What makes this album great is that it is just one man with his instrument and his voice.  Some of the Quechua songs are really stunning.  If you love the Andean aesthetic, this album is a must purchase.  Highly recommended!

I must be upfront and admit that I cannot read French very well.  I purchased this book for the pictures of knights and castles.  "Les Chevaliers Teutoniques" is a photo history of the medieval Teutonic religious order.  Many of the photos were taken at the surviving Teutonic castles in Poland.  From an architectural point of view, these photos go beyond the post card images that are usually presented of the castles.  Of more interest are the photos of medieval re-enactors.  Towards the end of the book is a nice series of photos showing a battle reenactment.  If you like professional photos of knight re-enactors this book is a must purchase.  Recommended.

Robert Dawson is a serious architectural photographer.  Using different size formats he has been able to produce some very beautiful photographs of American public libraries.  Unfortunately, the medium sized format of this book does not give his photos the proper space to be best exhibited.  His work would have been better presented in a larger "coffee table" sized book.At its heart, "The Public Library" is a study of a building type.  Public libraries run from the very elaborate to the most humble building types.  It is fascinating the see such variance.  It just goes to remind me the reader that the United States is continent sized and that libraries can be so different from community to community.

"Knights in Armor" is part of the Living History series.  The central conceit of this series is to bring history to life by using modern day re-enactors.  This is an English series and they generally do a good job of placing the re-enactors in appropriate historical settings.  Unfortunately at times, they photoshop re-enactors into shots.  Besides that, these is a very good series of books.  There is nothing like seeing the material culture of the time to make history come to life.  This book is appropriate for kids from 9 to 12.  Highly recommended.

1968 had to be one of the most interesting years of the Twentieth Century!  There was war in Vietnam, racial unrest in the United States, student revolts around the world and a Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia.  As would be expected, the photographers of Magnum were there to cover all these major historical events.  This must have been the last year that most photojournalism was still done in black and white.  If you love that up close and powerful Magnum aesthetic, this book is a must purchase.  My only caution is to purchase a high quality used book.  The book was not well bound and the spines are fragile on the two copies that I own.  Aside from this, "1968 Magnum Throughout the World" is  a great book.  Highly recommended!

Over the last century, thousands of books and articles have been written about the beginning of the Great War.  Many of those books center on playing the blame game.  They focus on one country and compile dossiers of evidence to support their argument that one country or another shares the greatest responsibility for starting the war.  Christopher Clark escapes this trope by concentrating on "how" the war began as opposed to "why" it began.  By concentrating on the discrete acts that led to war he avoids the trap of laying responsibility on any one person or country.  Ultimately, I think this is a wiser approach in trying to understand the origins of this catastrophe.  Highly recommended!

Lawrence and the Arab Revolts covers the totality of the Arab revolts from Libya to Yemen.  It is a good book if you are looking for information on the more obscure corners of the Arab Revolt.  However, most people are interested in T.E. Lawrence and the struggle in the Hejaz.  Osprey's "Arab Revolt" by David Murphy does a much better job of covering that topic.  Another good title is Osprey's "Meggido 1918" which chronicles Allenby's campaign in northern Palestine and Syria.

The author Martin Windrow and the illustrator Angus McBride are very well known in the adult military history world.  Combined they must have produced several hundred books.  "The Viking Warrior" was written for elementary school age children.  The book is well written and will be enjoyed by both children and parents alike.  However, what really makes this book are the great illustrations by Angus McBride.  He was a gifted illustrator and his images really bring history to life.  Highly recommended!

Arguably, Tyler Hicks is the greatest photojournalist of his generation.  Like all the greats, Hicks is a person of great personal bravery combined with a strong artistic vision.  "Histories are Mirrors" begins with the destruction of the Trade Towers and follows the response through the invasions of Afghanistan and Iraq.  During those three years, Hicks was everywhere and was able to flow freely between friends and foes.  Like all the great photojournalists, Hicks was always very close to the action and consequently able to document the horrors of war at its most intimate and terrifying.  By necessity, all of HIck's photos are in color.  Although many of the images are beautifully composed the fact they are in color also robs them of their ability to one become truly iconic.  There is something about black and white photography that raises war photography to a higher level.  But having said that, there is no doubt that "Histories are Mirrors" is a great book.  Highly recommended!

I think I am typical of the people who read Osprey books.  I have a college degree and have been reading military history for many years.  I am interested in Byzantine history but by no means am I an academic familiar with the Byzantine and Saljuk politics of the Eleventh Century.  To tell that story for an Osprey audience a great deal of explanation is needed.  The greatest problem with "Manzikert 1071" is that Nicolle loses track of his intended audience.  He predisposes that his audience has more knowledge than we do.  In turn, I found Nicolle's book to be obscure and not especially enjoyable to read.  If this were not bad enough, Christa Hook's illustrations are not up to the usual high Osprey standards.  Not recommended.

I have been a casual reader of architecture books for the past twenty years.  I believe I know most of the iconic buildings and their architects.  The pleasure of "Architects From A to Z" is that while the really famous architects are included there are also included a number of lesser known architects and their best buildings.  This was a exciting to me.  Paul Cattermole's work is an excellent reference source for learning about new architects.
