I have reading about World War II for over forty years.  in my mind, it is a black and white war.  Therefore, it is always shocking to see color photos of the conflict.  Color photos have a way of making that time come alive for me.  "Britain at War in Colour" is a novelty book.  It is interesting to see the photos and the descriptions that go with them.  But the photos are not especially well organized and most of the images are rather ordinary.  It is an interesting book but it is not one that I will look at more than once.

The best thing about this book are the illustrations by John James.  His richly detailed drawings are a delight.  His images are able to draw both child and adult into the story of Jerusalem's Temple.  The history of Herod's construction of the Temple up to its destruction by the Romans is a complicated story. Jacqueline Morley wrote this book for elementary school age children and therefore had to reduce a complex story down to a level that a young child can grasp.I would recommend Peter Connolly's "The Holy Land" for more mature readers.  Like John James, Peter Connolly is a gifted illustrator.  However, Connolly's style is aimed at more sophisticated audience.  Connolly's "The Holy Land" does a good job of tracking the story of the Temple as it was related by the Judeo/Roman historian Titus Flavius Josephus.

Peter Connolly wrote ancient history books for both children and adults.  Well a precocious middle schooler can read the "The Holy Land" I am not sure that a young person would necessarily enjoy the book.  "The Holy Land" closely tracks the "Jewish War" written by Romano/Jewish historian Titus Flavius Josephus.  This book chronicles the rise of Herod and concludes with the destruction of Temple in Jerusalem.  It is an important but nevertheless intricate story that many younger children may find too complex.  Nevertheless, the younger reader will enjoy Peter Connolly's beautifully detailed illustrations.However, as an adult, "The Holy Land" is a great book.  I have never read Josephus and Connolly's book has whetted my appetite to give it a shot.  The "Holy Land" does a wonderful job of putting Jesus Christ in his historical context.Finally, there are two other versions of this book with different titles.  "The Holy Land" is the same book as "Jews in the Time of Jesus" and "A History of the Jewish People during the Time of Jesus."

The editors of this book had a great idea in mining the National Archives for interesting photos of the Vietnam War.  Each branch of the US Military had combat photographers who literally shot millions of photos during the War.  From such a large body of work, the editors should have been able to find more high quality photographs.  I would estimate 15% of the photos are high quality images of the conflict  The rest are rather mundane shots.  The ordinariness of these photos illustrates the difference between the high quality work of professional photojournalists and the average work of young combat photographers.  Finally, the book was printed on low quality paper and the photos are not well cropped or printed.  All and all, this book is a disappointment.  If you are looking for better books, check out the works of David Douglas Duncan, Larry Burrows or Associated Press' compilation of Vietnam Photos.

First the bad news.  This audio cd version of "Good Soldier Svejk" is an abridgement.  Usually, I hate abridgements because editors cut out so much that I find it difficult to follow the story line.  Fortunately, the episodic nature of "The Good Soldier Svejk" lends itself to an abridgement. However, what really makes this audio cd is David Horovitch's narration.  He is a classically trained British actor who can easily avail himself of Great Britain's many regional and class accents.  This wide array of accents fits perfectly into Svejk's ethnically diverse Austro-Hungarian Empire.  "The Good Soldier Svejk" is a work of comic genius.  Fortunately, David Horovitch has the timing and comic talent to bring Svejk's world alive.  Highly recommended!

The Associated Press sent its first reporters to Vietnam soon after the French military returned to the country in 1945.  During the next thirty years what started out as a distant colonial war grew into the principle military struggle of the Cold War.  The whole time, the Associated Press was on the ground writing stories and taking photos.  To do this, the AP hired and cultivated the best photojournalists of the era."Vietnam: The Real War" is a photographic history of the conflict.  Most of the photos come from AP's archive but when necessary the editors have included photos from non-AP sources.  The text lightly covers the history of the war.  Its real strength is telling the stories of the AP photographers and journalists.  These are the stories of the intrepid journalists who brought the war to the world's newspapers and magazines.The "Golden Age" of photographic journalism is often seen as having taken place during the Spanish Civil War and Second World War.  A whole cottage industry has arisen to chronicle the works of the great Magnum photographers, Robert Capa, David Seymour and George Rodgers.  The photographic history of the  Korean and Vietnam wars have never generated the same interest among historians and authors.  Perhaps this is because of our nation's more troubled relationship with these conflicts.  Neither the Korean nor the Vietnam War were ever considered "Good Wars" fought by a "Greatest Generation."It is unfortunate that the great photojournalists of the Vietnam War never received the recognition they were due.  "Vietnam: The Read War" is a collection of extraordinary photographs that move way beyond merely documenting the horrors of war.  There are beautifully composed images that leave the world of illustration and  enter the realm of fine art.  Those images say as much about the insanity of war as any work by Goya.  This is a great book that will be enjoyed by people interested in both history and photography.  Highly recommended!

I have spent years searching out and reading ancient history books to my children.  The Usborne Greek and Roman histories are the best single volume histories of their respective periods.  What makes the Usborne books so good is that they jam a lot of information into their relatively thick books.  The print is small and the accompanying illustrations are really well done.  It is this marriage of written detail and plentify illustrations that makes this book work.  If you are interested in still even more detail, make sure to check out any of Peter Connolly's great ancient history books.

When P.G. Wodehouse created the Jeeves and Wooster characters he knew he had a winning combination.  "Jeeves and the Mating Season" is like every other book in the series.  They all follow the same successful formula.  There is plenty of hijinks and mad cap humor. Looking back over the decades, all of the books have for me blended into one pleasant haze.  I have discovered that listening to a Jeeves and Wooster book is better than reading it.  I know there is some dispute but I believe Jonathan is the best narrator for the series.  He has the great character voices and a fantastic sense of comic timing.  For timing, I would put him up there with Jack Benny. With Jonathon Cecil narrating, the plot becomes unimportant.  The whole series has become a nice blur and Cecil's narration is that extra touch that brings me back year after year.  Highly recommended!

"The Roman Legionary" is a picture book geared at children 8-11 years of age.  The illustrations are by Gerry Embleton.  He is an illustrator and reenactor who has made a career ilustrating Osprey military history guide books.  He is one of the finest illustrators working in historical non-fiction.  Martin Windrow is an author who has also made his career by writing Osprey guidebooks.  The text is well written but ultimatley limited because this is a picture book geared towards young children.  If you are looking for something more substantive, check out "The Legionary" by Peter Connolly.

"The Door in the Wall" is a well done story of a crippled boy coming to grips with his new disability.  As ofther reviewers have noted, there is a problem with archaic English which is used when characters speak.  If you have a child who is patient enough to work his or her way through the unfamiliar words, this a good book. If you have a child who is easily distracted by the unfamiliar, this book will not work.

For many years, I have been a fan of the Alan Furst/Eric Ambler approach to World War Two thriller/spy novels.  Their approach is to tell the story of ordinary people working in the obscure corners where spies practice their craft.  I enjoy seeing how the "small people" react to the calamitous events of their day.  Phillip Kerr takes a very different approach.  He places his hero Bernie Gunther at big events (Katyn Woods Massacre) where he intereacts with real people (Goebbels).  Kerr does not have a problem with throwing in a beautiful woman for Gunther's love interest and some creepy Nazis and Soviets as the bad guys.  Kerr boldly takes the maximalist approach to writing a World War Two thriller. Half way through the novel, I thought there was no way that Kerr can pull this off.  There is just too much going on.  To my surprise, he did pull it off.  "A Man Without Breath" is a big, sprawling and thoroughly enjoyable book.  I am not sure that it will be a classic like "A Coffin for Dimitrios" or "Red Gold" but it is a good read.

The scholarship that took place at Library at Alexandria is one of those accomplishments that encompasses both the Greek and Roman civilizations. The scientific advances of the ancient world are often times inadequately addressed in the histories written for children.  "The Library of Alexandria" does a great job of explaining the scientific breakthroughs of individual ancient scholars.  This perspective adds to the usual tales of emperors and conquerors that so dominate the study of ancient history.  What keeps me from giving this book five stars are the mundane illustrations that acccompany the book.  To my eye, the illustrations are flat and are not grounded in a strong understanding of perspective.  This is too bad.  Historical illustration is its own field and the publishers of this book should have invested in a better illustrator.

Over the years, I have searched out and read a large number of children's books on ancient history.  For me, the best books need to be clearly written and well illustrated.  There are a lot of great books out there but if I had to purchase only one book on the ancient Greeks, it would be the Usobrne Internet linked "Greeks".  The book comprehensively covers the basics of ancient Greek history.  But what really makes the book are the large numnber of detailed illustrations.  Every page is covered with intricate illustrations that allow children to better imagine what life was like over two thousand years ago.  This is a great book and I highly recommend it.  I hope it inspires both children and adults to look deeper into ancient history.

"The Insurgents" is a book about ideas and how armies adapt and learn.  When countries go to war, they go to war with the armies and doctrines they have been forged over many years.  However, wars are dynamic by their very nature.  Sometimes, a nation's war strategy may start out well but over time the war can go in other directions and there may be a need for a course correction.  "The Insurgents" is the story of how the United States military became a learning institution and found new strategies and tactics to deal with the realities on the ground.Fred Kaplan tells the story of this course correction through the lense of David Patraeus and the group of intellectuals he assembled around him.  General Patraeus was the key American commander of the Iraqi War and the adoption of counter-insurgency doctrine the most important development of the war.  The final judgement as to the effectiveness and importance of the counter-insurgency doctrine will be made in the coming years.  "The Insurgents" is one of the first volleys in what will become a historical debate.As a first draft of history, "The Insurgents" is a success. Fred Kaplan understands the value of ideas and the role they play in the shaping of wars.  I have been reading military history for forty years and this is the first book that spends more time on soldier's academic pedigrees than it does on descriptions of combat.  If this book has a weakness, it is in Kaplan's focus on the shaping of doctrine as oppossed to the implementation of doctrine.  My sense is that future historians will spend more time in determing whether or not the counter-insurgency strategy actually worked.  These future historians will leave the world of ideas and examine the gritty details of how counter-insurgency doctrine actually worked.

Like countless numbers of young people, I first became interested in the construction of cathedrals through David Macaulay's iconic children's book "Cathedral". His beautifully detailed illustrations brought medieval construction techniques to life. As an adult, I still love Macaulay's work but as a children's book, it can only carry you so far. Malcolm Hislop's "How to Buid a Cathedral" takes medieval construction to a much higher level.  Hislop uses scores of richly detailed illustrations to explain the building technologies of the Middle Ages. In preparing this book, Hislop was able to draw upon beautifully detailed line drawings from Nineteenth Century sources.  The other great virture of this book is that Hislop writes for the general public.  This is a great book that is reasonably priced.  Highly recommended!

First and foremost, "My Face to the Wind" is a girl's adventure story.  The heroine begins the story in a terrible state.  Her father has just died and she is all alone in a small Nebraska pioneer settlement.  How will the protagonist survive and move forward?  All the classic elements of an adventure story.  What takes this story into the realm of historical fiction is its 1880's Nebraska setting.  Although I am no historical expert on pioneer life, the details felt right.  But remember this book is more girl's adventure story than a careful recreation of pioneer life. "My Face to the Wind" is well written and both my nine year old daughter and myself enjoyed the book.  Recommended.

Peter Connolly (1935-2012)wrote and illustrated many books on the ancient world.  A few of his books were written for adults but most of them were geared towards the young adult market.  His greatest gifts were as an illustrator and experimental archaeologist. Connolly was fascinated with the material culture of the ancient world.  His great contribution was in taking degraded archaeological findings and re-animating them through his illustrations.  Connolly's richly detailed illustrations brought ancient history to life."The Greek Armies" is divided into two sections.  On the top of most pages is a condensed narrative of the Persian Wars, Peloponnesian War and Alexander's conquest of the Persian Empire.  The bottom parts of the page focus on the material culture and technologies of the Greek armies.  It is in this bottom section of the page that Peter Connolly's genius really shines.  "The Greek Armies" has beautifully rendered illustations of such ordinary things has helmets, shields, spears, triremes, catapults and siege engines.I read this book to my ten year old son because he has a budding interest in ancient history.  As an adult, what I really appreciated was Peter Connolly's visual recreation of the ancient Greek world.  "The Greek Armies" is an book that can fascinate both child and parent alike.  Highly recommended!

The end of the Roman Republic is a story that has fascinated people for over two thousand years.  Most contemporary histories focus on the struggle between the two "great men" of the era, Caesar and Pompey.  Cicero, Cato, Hortensus, Crassus and Cataline are usually just supporting actors in their struggle.  Goodman and Soni hit upon a great idea in shifting the focus by placing Cato at the center of their narrative.  The value of placing Cato at the center is that his contribution to creating the crisis becomes clearer."Rome's Last Citizen" is great example of high quality popular history geared towards the reading public.  It is well written and thought provoking.  Some of the negative reviews of this book place too high a burden on Goodman and Soni.  They judge a popular history by the standards one uses to judge an academic history.  Some of these reviews are pedantic in nature and are more geared to showing off the reviewers esoteric knowledge than they are to informing a potential reader of this book. I thought this was a first rate book and I highly recommend it.

Roger Lancelyn Green had a great idea in creating a meta-world where all of the great Greek heroes interact as contemporaries.  This idea works because the ancient Greeks saw their heroes as living in an organic "Heroic Age".  It is a compelling idea but it is poorly executed.  This book fails because Lancelyn Green must jam in all of the heroes and their many adventures into a short children's book.  Jason, Perseus, Theseus and Heracles deserve their own books in which their many adventures can be properly told.  These ancient stories are foundational texts for Western Literature.  It is a real diservice to young children for all these stories to be bundled into a truncated text.

I grew up in Colorado in the 1970's.  I loved local history but I could find very little published about the Mexican contribution to the settlement of the State.  I knew this history had to exist but that it would take effort to find it.  Fortunately, in the last forty years a number of excellent books have been published that have explored the contributions of the Spanish and Mexicans to the settlement of Colorado.In the late 1850's, Mariano Medina (born Taos in 1812) a former trapper and mountain guide settled on the banks of the Big Thompson River.  Medina was the first non-Indian to settle in what is today Loveland, Colorado.  He built a toll bridge and trading post.  Medina was a good businessman and became one of the wealthiest citizens of the area.  What really made Medina stand out was his colorful character.  A good friend of Kit Carson and other well known mountain men, Medina was a local legend.  Zethyl Gates a Loveland librarian was able to mine the local newspapers and legal records to create a biographical sketch of Mariano Medina.  "Mariano Medina" is a good read and a must purchase for people interested in Colorado History. Recommended.

It is a special kid who is interested in the intricacies of Greek Hoplite warfare.  If you are like me and happen to have one, "The Greek Hoplite" by Martin Windrow is a must purchase.  It is well written and the illustrations are first rate.  A good used copy can be picked up for under ten dollars.  If you like this book, Martin Windrow produced a number of good books in the "Soldier Through the Ages" series.  My guess is if your child likes Greek Hoplite, he will also be interested in Roman legionaires, Vikings and Medievil knights.  Highly recommended!

As children move towards middle school, there are fewer beautifully illustrated history books.  The emphasis moves from teaching through images to more written word narratives.  I think this is too bad.  Images are powerful and help children place themsevles into historical events."The Greeks" by Roy Burrell is a general history of ancient Greece aimed at children ages 10-14.  Burrell is a competent writer with a good command of the history of ancient Greece.  However, what really makes this book are the beautiful illustrations by Peter Connolly.  Until his death in 2012, Peter Connolly was the foremost illustrator of the ancient world.  Connolly had a love of ancient material culture.  His passion was taking archaeological finds and through illustration bringing them back to their original forms.  I have spent years tracking down used Peter Connolly books.  His illustrations are a great way for childrens and adults to place themselves into the past.  Recommended.

In the Nineteenth Century, France was at the center of the Western architectural world.  The best architects and artists travelled and studied in France.  The most fortunate ones were able to study at the Ecole des Beaux Arts.  When they returned home, they brought back with them French architectural styles.  Beaux-Art influenced buildings can be found from New York to Buenos Aires."Architecture in France 1800-1900" is a broad based survey of the architecture produced during this period.  What makes this book such a joy is that Bertrand Lemoine chronicles a wide variety of building types.  His interests extend beyond the major public buildings to more obscure buildings such as factories and park pavillions.  The scope and range of his interests is truly impressive. Fortunately, his text is well translated and is easy to follow.  Having finished this book, I only wished that it had been longer.  A comprehensive survey of French Nineteenth Century buildings would require numerous volumes.  Until such a work is published, "Architecture in France 1800-1900" is the book to own.  Highly recommended!

I started this book because I was interested in learning about how the writings of Ancient world were recovered and used to inspire the Renaissance.  Exploring Epicurean philosophy was less important.  I thoroughly enjoyed Greenblatt's description of how the Roman texts were recovered.  But to my surprise, I found Greenblatt's take on the spread of Epirucrean philosophy to be the more interesting of the two subjects.  I'm not sure whether "De rerum natura" was as influential as Greenblatt makes it out to be.  Neverhtless, Lucretius' poem feels very modern and from today's vantage point, the work still seems fresh and relevant.

In the 1980's, Giovanni Caselli produced a series of short historical vignettes for children entitled "The Everyday Life Series".  Each well illustrated book examines the daily life of ordinary people through the ages. It was a series aimed towards young children of 7-10 years of age. I have read number of these books to my children and we have enjoyed them all."A Boston Trader" tells of the visit of two farm children to their uncle's prosperous home in Boston.  Their uncle is a rich merchant in the Boston of 1730's.  They have an opportunity to explore Boston's busy port and watch the preparations for an important ball.  The story is well written and the illustrations are well done.  This is a good book which can be purchased used at a very reasonable price.

Carl Rochling and Richard Knotel were two of the finest illustrators of the Nineteenth Century.  They specialized in historical scenes.  In the late 1890's, they collaborated on two illustrated biographies, "Der Alte Fritz" and "Die Konigin Luise".  Fortunately, "Der Alte Fritz" has been republished a few times.  It is a great book and can be purchased at a reasonable price.  However, I am not aware of any reprints of "Die Konigin Luise".  If you are interested in this book, you will probably have to purchase the 1896 original.  If you can afford it, "Die Konigin Luise" is a great find.  The book's fifty illustrations of Queen Luise's life are absolutely first rate.  She was a Prussian hero from the Napoleonic Wars and the great love the German people had for her is reflected in these beautifully crafted illustrations.  Highly recommended!
Best thing ever! Keeps my water cold for about 2 days!
Had to return this, wasn't as bright as I was hoping it would be.

Wonderful guide to procrastination and time management! I'm in college right now and its really hard to be very diligent... This guide helped me and I'm sticking to some of the tips this book provided! Very concise and straight to the point. I thought this book was a quick read, so I didn't get bored. Looking forward to being successful!

Very great bundle! Its a good read. I learned a lot and definitely will keep a lot of tips in mind. There were some parts that I didn't understand, but majority of the bundle was very straight forward in helping you succeed. Some of the content in here was very unique and I thought was well worth the money I spent to purchase this. If you're on the path to entrepreneurship or business, then I think this would give you a good start.

Great bundle so far! I haven't finished it all, but went through a few stories already, and have been really impressed with the quality of them. They're all very unique and loved the storylines. The characters have been very detailed and believable. Will update if my thoughts on this changed...

Short, but a fun read! This was definitely a great life lesson for the youngsters! Didn't know what to expect going into this book, but it was well worth it. Being that its short, its easy for my kids to read through the book without getting bored or wander off.

Great short story! I enjoyed this variation very much. Particularly liked the Darcy & Bingley interactions and Wickham was a rascal! Definitely worth a read if you want to go about your day with a smile.

Before this book, my anxiety was pretty off the charts. Although, its still there, this book had calmed me down significantly. I think this book provided a lot of insights and helped me through tough times. If it wasn't for Juls Madel, not sure where I'd be like right now.

What a great guide! this book was very resourceful and I definitely recommend this to every parent! Very clear and easy to understand, the author knew what she was talking about. This was a short read, but very effective! Worth the purchase.

This was a very fun read, I definitely got into trying to figure out who would survive this crazy maze. The author kept me very engaged with lots of plot twists that would surprise you till the end. The experience in this book was beyond what I had ever read, it kinda felt like a movie... Definitely wouldn't mind watching this on a big screen. Hopefully I'll see more of this author.

Thank you for writing this! This was very helpful! Before reading this, I didn't know what I was doing... this book helped me clear up a lot of questions I had! The information in this book saved my life! On my way to better money management!

Been a big fan of Taylor Swift... Saw her concert recently and loved her performance! I really liked this book as it was very informative and made me love Taylor even more! I discovered a lot of cool interesting facts about her and the inspiration behind her songs! Very fascinating read!

Great book! Been looking for something like this. There were a lot of good tips and tricks on flipping houses for profit. This comprehensive guide was very helpful. Although, this isn't the only book I'm using, I've also looked at others, however, still a good read. If you're really trying to do this to make money, all it takes is dedication! Don't wait, learn the tips from Brent Driscoll!

very exhilarating and thrilling read! Taking place in the author's home town, this book left me chills... Katherine is a fantastic writer! Her style is very unique and gifted. She knows how to keep you engaged throughout the book with very interesting plot twists. Breath and Release had me guessing the entire time! Wait until you get to the ending!Loved this story, and the characters, which kept me at the edge of my seat!

Great addition to the novel, X. Brought a lot of new thoughts to my attention. Sometimes I get carried away and drift off reading long novels, so this was a good added read. Pretty short, so I got through with it fast. Overall, if you need a quick read for a book report or something, this is perfect as it give you the sense of whats going on.

This book was great! I received lot of value from this book. Got this book when it was free! But definitely still worth the money. The value the author presented in this book will make up for the chump change you're spending... If you finally want to become debt free, then this is the perfect starting point! It does take dedication, but what doesn't? There's no easy way out, just read it improve!

Very thrilling read! Kept me on my toes throughout the book. Very fast paced and lots of twists that kept you wondering what would happen next. I think that was one of the pluses of this author. He really knew how to keep me engaged in the story. The characters were portrayed very well and I thought was very believable. Really enjoyed this one. Would look forward to the next installment!

Hands down the best dating book out there. Not only is it funny and easy to read, but the tips are amazing. I could see myself in a few of these scenarios and now know what I should do differently. Trust me, it will only help you.
An awesome beginning to a new series. A well written original story, with fully developed believable characters, that leaves you hooked and wanting more.

A motivational read. Short, but very concise and to the point. This 10 week plan is definitely going to shape my way of life! Much needed read and Kristi Patric Carter J.D. has helped me in many ways already!

These two authors have been helping entrepreneurs start successful businesses for a combined 40 years. It's great to have this in-the-trenches book from experts who have been there. I highly recommend this book for anyone who wants to get an easy-to-read, comprehensive guide to starting and growing a great business.

Very enjoyable epic fantasy trilogy, like Lord Of The Rings but very different story. The characters were interesting, with lots of development, particularly in books 2 and 3. I think Delin the knight was my favorite character, but I liked Ifferon too. The action scenes were amazing, especially in the 3rd book when they fight Agon. I also enjoyed the writing style, it was very poetic and beautiful. The tension and twists kept things moving and I was sad to turn the last page. I hope the author writes more books like these.

Very short, but very good. Collection of poems, with lots of emotions. I warn you though, this book is for those that have an acquired taste in poetry. If you're not into poetry, then this might be hard to get into... great reads, loved it!

Great characters, great plot. Loved the humor from Hunter Murphy. This was a truly unique read that I was recommended by a great friend of mine. This was a feel-good type of novel, and I definitely hope you consider picking up this book too.
entertaining read, just get it... great for passing time. Loved the unique story.

great read! very entertaining and engaging! The main character, Xenophon, seeks his revenge! Lots of great scenes leading up to the main plot. The author's becoming one of my favorites. I definitely recommend this!

I am the proud parent of a brand new baby girl. We received a bunch of great gifts from family and friends, but honestly I only use about half of it. Thats why this book caught my attention, because Im more of the simplistic type, and dont think I need all the clever gadgets out there to raise a child. I want my kid to be outside and enjoy nature instead of being cooped up in the house playing video games all day. This book offers some great advice to help you get your child on the right track from the start. I liked it, you should check it out too.

Ive been married going on 7 years now and I have to admit, things are getting a little stale. Between a busy work day and my kids schedules, finding quality time for my mate has been quite the challenge.  I was searching for ways that I could spice things up a bit and I came across this book.  I especially liked the chapters on trying new adventures and getting flirty because thats what I would like more of with my mate. This book has some great tips and advice if youre trying to get that spark back in your relationship, I highly recommend it.

Wow! This book was amazing! If you're like me who enjoys vampire stories, then this is a book you'll have to get! Its not your typical vampire story, but Christian Masters done a great job in putting a twist to it! He definitely kept me engaged and made me want more! loved this!

Like a lot of people, I struggle with my weight, so Im always searching for new things to try to get rid of this belly fat. I accidentally stumbled across this book and I enjoyed the information that is offered on the benefits of red wine. I always heard that wine can be good for you in moderation. Since I like to sometimes enjoy a glass of wine after a long day at work, this book gave a more in depth explanation of all of the benefits. Im curious to find out if I will lose any weight, we shall see.
currently on this diet crave... great book. lots of good ingredients. wish there was more!
Very enlightening read! Really liked this book. I'm glad I was able to pick this book up! Definitely recommend this! Very short read, but very comprehensive.

Definitely an interesting read! Didn't know what to expect, just got it for kicks and giggles because of the title, but it was pretty entertaining from the beginning. Really enjoyed it throughout the book. I definitely would recommend this book.
Lots of useful information. I'm in the process of dieting and a lot of the content provided in here have already helped me. Very comprehensive, just need dedication!

Looking for ideas? Then you don't have to look any further. If you don't know what it is, well, its a good idea to pick this book up... Brief: making money without doing anything...This book is well written and a good guide to your richness! Just gotta do the work
cool short read for my kids. They all loved the story. Enjoyed it with the family!

I'm always finding ways to improve, and this book was just what I needed to get my assertiveness to the next level. The title is very fitting because the things that I learned from this book is pretty powerful (no pun intended). I really noticed a big difference in my life and my relationships with my friends and family. The tools presented in this book is well worth the purchase.

Was having trouble writing, but after picking this book up, I noticed a big improvement. Very easy to read and comprehend. I didn't improve right away, it does take time, but if you really want it, you'll get there.

Fantastic read! A movie to be made, definitely! This was a long read, but really worth it... took me longer than normal, but I felt that it was really fast paced and lots of great surprises here and there. The author's writing had really kept me engaged. I felt that the story would develop better too as you read...Overall, I loved the storyline, and very easy to read.

Great book! Short, but sweet. This was a good read under a nice sunny day. I felt that this was a feel-good book with a good adventure. The book was entertaining and the author's writing was unique which kept me engaged throughout the entire time.Wonderful!
Very helpful! There were a lot of good pointers that I was able to use on my studying... The book was straight forward and no fluff was involved. I couldn't been happier with my purchase.
This was a very lovely and enjoyable read.  I thought this was a feel-good type, and has been one of my favorite books in the summer.

Wow, this book has allowed me to put so many things into perspective. First off we lie and we do it so often that we don't even realize we are doing it anymore. We lie to our friends, family members and co workers ALL THE TIME! We do it to fit in and to be more accepted by others it's a natural defense mechanism. We want to be liked and we want to make a good impression and when we don't feel, "Good Enough," we lie... This book has taught me to understand my self worth, to recognize the lies I say to others to feel better about myself, and lastly to understand in my core that I am not defined by any of it! I am whole and perfect as I am without the need to saturate my spirit with who I should be and what I should be doing. A lie is mere clothes that we wear and we are not define by any of it! Very freeing book, so glad I found it!
Rocked my world ;)

I love fantasy stories! This book was definitely worth the long read. Its 300+ pages of thrill seeking adventure! Can't wait for the next installments! I really enjoyed the plot, definitely unique and very creative. Lots of surprises too, which made it even more enticing and kept me on the edge of my seat!

Strengths: Awesome plot, quick read, beautiful illustrations, great references to the original book, hilarious characters, snappy dialogue, hidden references for political junkies.Weaknesses: Slow start, could use more about Pinocchios wife, overly sentimental at times, simplistic view of congress.Great book! Kind of a sequel to The Adventures of Pinocchio, this takes place in modern day America and picks up with an adult Pinocchio working for a company called The Kronos Group, a powerful D.C. lobby firm headed by a Jack Abramoff-type character, Charles Stevens. Pinocchio is married, has a young son, and lives near his father, Geppepto, who is portrayed as a doddering old man with one foot in the grave. It seems that Pinocchio has forgotten that he was once a puppet, and he resents Geppeptos telling stories about his youth to his son, Albero. Otherwise, Pinocchio is shown as a true innocent who doesn't fully understand Washington, or politics in general for that matter.The book is told from the perspective of a newspaper reporter, Max Wiggs, who wrote an article that accidentally launched Pinocchio to fame by playing up his absolute honesty. Later, its alluded to that Pinocchio cant lie, and the reason it isnt revealed until midway through the book in a hilarious way. Pinocchio, his head swimming with thoughts of fame and power, becomes disenfranchised from his family, even going so far as to throw Geppepto into a nursing home (The Weeping Pines Retirement Center Ha!). But slowly, Pinocchio starts to realize that Geppepto may have been telling the truth when he learns that he can talk to animals and trees. Everything comes crashing down when he tells a complete lie while giving testimony to congress and he transforms into a puppet once again. Panicked, he sets out to cure himself and learns he has to find a fairy and a cricket, only to learn the fairy is an ugly, womanizing, drunken old man, and the talking cricket is a slimy cockroach with thousands of children.At this point, the book takes an unexpected turn, going from a somewhat predictable story about a good man corrupted by power to something else altogether. Reading the last half is like watching an action movie  well paced, exciting, and with a really unexpected twist at the end.The writing is super strong, with memorable witticisms that remind me of Oscar Wildes short stories. That being said, the pacing could be better. The first hundred pages or so, while funny, is slow. But once Pinocchio becomes a puppet again, the story just takes off. The book is dripping with subtext and carries a lot of themes  parenthood, marriage, even Greek mythology (and for us political junkies, the author loads up the story with easter eggs that I think the average reader wont get - look for the plaque on the secretarys desk). The animal characters, in my opinion, are actually representations of humanity. They are cruel, racist, fearful, in other words, the worst of us. The remind me of the barnyard in George Orwells Animal Farm, another great satirical work.I do wish I could have learned more about Pinocchios wife. In the end, she remains a somewhat flat character. Overall, however, the characters are very true to life, the dialogue is fun, and the book is an enjoyable quick read.I had trouble with this review because, honestly, there is just so much going on in this book. Somehow, the author has managed to build a rich, colorful, new world out of characters weve all known for years. This book is something entirely new, and I hope a lot of readers enjoy it! Well done!
I enjoyed this short read. Some interesting twists in the plot that kept me intrigued throughout the book. I was able to read this through on a quick airplane ride.

My friends are movie fanatics, and I decided to pick this book up so I can keep up with simple conversations... I never want to be an outcast.. The stuff in here is pretty raw and interesting. I think my friends would look twice when I start coming up with some cool critics of my own ;)

Enjoyable spy techno-thriller set in the near future. There's a lot of depth to this story and some interesting perspectives on AI and political power plays that could end up happening. Probably one of my favorite reads this year.

This is a summary of the popular book between the world and me. I thought this book sufficed my needs. Needed something quick for a book report, and I used this book to quickly put together something. Thanks!

I really enjoyed this book, it definitely surpassed my expectations. This fantasy novel was really thrilling and I loved the details in each character. The arthur knew how to keep me engaged throughout the book. Definitely a fun read and I can see this turning into a blockbuster movie!

Lots of useful information! I definitely needed this book. If something happens, then this book would be the only book I'd turn to. I really like how this survival book has a broad range of different scenarios. Valuable knowledge.

Awesome book! An adventure that will be reminded for awhile! Loved the book. It was fun and entertaining. There were a lot of surprises and full of action, I couldn't put the book down. Left me in awe till the end!

Awesome bundle! Lots of great stories. I'm only 1/3 of the way, but I'm already liking what I've read. Each story is very unique and very enticing...Looking forward to more! I'll update if my opinion changes!

Very simple and straight forward book to getting you to be completely stress free. I learned a lot and i was able take deep breaths when stressful times arises and become more relaxed, especially during my high stress work hours.

For a while now, people have been telling me that I need to write a book of all the stories Ive told over the years. Problem is...I dont write. Im terrible at it. I have no clue how to do it at all. Granted, Im not all the way done with this book, but from what I can tell its going to help me out quite a bit.

I don't like most Kindle Ebooks these days, they seem to be drawn out longer than needed full of "filler information" rather than useful information. I don't normally leave reviews but I had to on this one. Short and to the point with helpful information, just how I like it. 5 stars.

I bought this book after reading an article about it being awarded Editor's Choice from the Historical Novel Society. At under a buck I figured it was worth a shot, and if it wasn't that great, I still had an award winning book on my Kindle to pretend I read. Not that anyone casually browses through my Kindle, but you know what I mean. Fake bragging rights, if you will. Fair trade for a dollar.What I ended up with was a great read. Mount of Hope is written in the spirit of classical fiction without all the loquaciousness. The Victorian dialogue, descriptions, and flavor are on every page in a most natural and fluid representation of the time. The story of the Julia/Alfred/Amelia triangle is clean, entertaining and clever, with a good balance of gravity and humor. I thoroughly enjoyed this tidy little book and am glad to have stumbled across it.

All I can say is, WOW. This book was a short, but enjoyable read and it was very well-written with steamy scenes that I could picture vividly in my mind. (Possible spoiler alert) I liked the banter between Clarice and Maverick in the second story and I would love to see what happened to those two after this book ended.Overall a great short read and I'm curious to see what the author comes out with next.

I generally dont read romance novels because theyre cheesy and somewhat boring, BUT The Eyes and Ears of Love exceeded my expectation indefinitely. This book is A-mazing! It wraps your mind around the daily crap and tragedies people go through in life. Two college kids happen to fall in love in the process and guess what? Theyre not perfect!!! This isnt a fairytale story, its REALISITC! Danielle C.R. Smith is young, but shes already got it all figured out how to write a phenomenal story. I really hope Danielle writes a second book because I want more of Dorothy and Bentleys life. I'm addicted.

I needed help, and this book was just what I needed... This guide was brilliant! Very short, simple and easy to understand. The style of the writing was very easy to comprehend, especially since I've been really disorganized, my reading needs to be fast paced and straight to the point.

I rarely find interview skills really informative, but this one surprised me... It was very easy to understand and has helped me gain my confidence in my interviews. The author knows her stuff and if this book helped me, it certainly can help anyone else!

Quick and short read, definitely a unique twist in the whole "twilight-esque" genre... The characters were very believable and very detailed to the point where I was able to clearly imagine the scenes, which made it a romantic evening ;)Great story line too! Really enjoyed this one

I love the cover art, whoever drew the main character did a good job. Later in the book you'll find yourself wondering what Tetris (the main character) looks like with his transformation. The description in the book is pretty graphic but I like the fact that the cover visualizes that a bit more. This book is full of twists and turns, the story is tight the way I like it, and the language is vivid and succinct. There are a lot of idiosyncrasies in there that I think depends on who's reading you may find that brilliant or complicated. At times it feels like a mind-fck (all the Barry Hanshaw excerpts pretty much) but I like it.

I'm learning python and this book really helped me out a lot! I had a lot of issues, but the concepts presented in this book really helped me understand. Although, this wouldn't be the only book you need, but its a supplement to other resourceful tools.

Fantastic read! Very sexy and unique! I thought there were a lot of good points in this novel that kept me turning pages. It was really intriguing and the romance felt very real. The author was very great at writing out the characters details and the scenes, made the story feel surreal!

Kate is an average girl trying to make her mark in the movie business. Heath is the hottest English actor on the Hollywood scene. Their instant connection makes waves on set, and in their beds. Will Hollywood tear them apart or bring them closer together? Find out in the debut novel from Romance writer Casey Monroe!
What a great book! Aziz is a great writer and truly unique. This book had me turning pages and was very detailed that left me in awe at the end.  I really enjoyed this read.

Lots of great information in this book. Most books I've read are really short, but this one had an extensive overview of Ketogenic dieting, for unique and cool dieting plan. If you're looking for a way to slim your belly, then I'd suggest reading this book. Very comprehensive and straight forward. All it takes is dedication and focus!

Wing Chun is a really cool boxing style! This book will tell you what you need to know about it! It has everything a beginner would need. If you're midly interested in boxing at all, then you should definitely check this book out!

In Writing Wizardry, Maity Schrechengost shares 70 mini lessons for better writing. This is a newer and expanded version of the earlier book which contained 60 mini lessons.Each lesson, presented on a page or two, contain a brief commentary, with non-example, followed by one or more examples, tips for teachers and additional resources.In a lesson on giving characters personality, the non-example is "Tommy is sad"; and the example is "Tears filled Tommy's eyes as he bit his lip to keep from crying."The lessons include using strong verbs, active voice, showing vs. telling, adding detail, focusing, setting the scene, creating exciting leads, grabbing readers' attention, creating satisfying endings, building bridges, writing for the reader, adding variety, bringing characters to life, using symbols, allusions, alliterations, and much more.

In Writing Wizardry, Maity Schrechengost shares 60 mini lessons for better writing.Each lesson, presented on a page or two, contain a brief commentary, with non-example (example of poor writing), followed by several examples, tips for teachers and additional resources.In a lesson for using strong verbs, the non-example is "Danny ate his lunch"; and few examples are "Danny gobbled his lunch" and "Danny nibbled at his lunch."The lessons include using strong verbs, active voice, showing vs. telling, adding detail, focusing, setting the scene, creating exciting leads, grabbing readers' attention, creating satisfying endings, building bridges, writing for the reader, adding variety, bringing characters to life, using symbols, allusions, alliterations, and much more.

In the Show or Tell, James Thayer explores the difference between telling and showing through numerous examples.To transform "telling" into "showing", Thayer suggests you ask "Where is the evidence?".For example, "His arm itched" is telling.  To show that his arm itched, you provide the evidence - "He scratched his arm."Thayer suggests situations where it may be appropriate to use telling instead of showing or perhaps use both.He also provides numerous examples of telling vs. showing when describing personality, emotions, reactions, aches and pains, character descriptions, and weather.He concludes this 41-page booklet by suggesting games for developing your show vs. tell muscles.

Guaranteed Solutions contains golden nuggets of spiritual insight and the appropriate spiritual practice, the essence of which is "live in the present moment, fully conscious, fully aware, centered in your being".The book appears to be a transcript of Nithyananda's talks, and each chapter contains several short stories, designed to entertain as well as illustrate the point he is trying to make.  Here's one of them:"A 90-year old man used to sit every day at the beach from morning to evening, watching the people going by.Another man who noticed this went up to him and asked him, "What do you actually do sitting here everyday?"The old man replied, "I am searching for a woman to be my wife."The man was simply shocked at this replay and asked him, "why did you not search in your youth?"The old man replied, "I have been searching since I was 30 years old."The man was astonished and asked him, "What sort of a woman are you searching for?"He replied, "I am searching for a perfect woman.""And you haven't found one?" the man asked."I found one woman who matched what I had in mind but it didn't work out well with her", replied the old man.The man asked why.The old man replied, "She was searching for a perfect man."Some chapters also contain spiritual practices and meditations scooped from different sources from Kularnava Tantra, to a variation of Christian (Pentecostal) practice of speaking in tongues.  Some meditations, like Darkness meditation technique taken from Vedanta, contain warning "One should not do this meditation without the presence of an ordained teacher of Life Bliss Foundation".The book also contains questions from participants and Nithyananda's answers.  Many of the questions, answers and examples in this book may appeal particularly to people who are accustomed to the way of life in India.Few quotes from this book:"Spirituality is always all encompassing.  Drop your notions of "I am this" or "I am that".  Keep your life open.  This is the basis of spirituality.""Be very clear that all miseries arise because of self-contradictions.  You yourself are not fully clear about what you want to do and so you are unable to do it.""Again and again, scan your mind and see what it is that gives you joy.  Then, start following it.""To drop an addiction, flood it with awareness.  It will transform in the right way.""Learn to be with yourself.  When you become a meditator, you will slowly understand that you don't need t depend on relationships to make you happy. ... You need to have relationship with yourself first.""When you see the world as something, that something is You.""Every problem is pregnant with the solution. All you need to do is look at the problem with deep awareness, and the solution will stand out."

While some information in this book is a bit dated and it was primarily focused on direct marketing, Dan Kennedy also shares timeless principles of writing sales letters that can be applied even today no matter what kind of sales letters you are writing.Getting to know your target audience will never become outdated, and the suggestions he shares from his past experience are quite thorough.  He mentions that in order to get into the mind of his readers, in this instance dentists,  he'd read every industry publication every month, visit websites that host discussions forums for dentists, subscribe to email groups where only dentists communicate back and forth, attend industry functions, conventions, seminars, trade shows, he'd play prospect, and routine mastermind with dentists.He then shares a step-by-step process he used to write a copy, very detailed with various examples.  He shares a fill-in-the-blank headlines with examples, different ways to attract attention and to overcome barriers, how to re-write and then he offers an extensive check-list with 35 points to check your copy.Yes he does have a plug for his website and services which I find appropriate in this book, and he also has a plug for few other tools like mike Capuzzi's CopyDoodles.He then suggests re-writing for passion, and editing for clarity, and how to test your copy.At the end of the book you'll find additional resources.

Having first read Jack Chapman's book for writing Headlines, which he wrote after this book, I must say that I prefer the book for writing Headlines simply because he shares lots of examples in that book.In this first 52-page booklet on Copywriting, he shares an overview of different elements of copywriting, without offering specific examples, except for sharing several types of headlines.It reads mainly like an introduction to copywriting or a brief review for those who are familiar with copywriting but need a reminder of all the elements that the copy should include., and how to go about doing research and writing, how to manage your time, and so on.

In this 71-page Copywriting Wizardry Booklet, Jack Chapman shares different kinds of headlines, providing examples as well as commentary for each headline.Headlines are presented in a fill in the blank format, e.g.Warning [Some Sign(s)] That [Blank]followed by examples like:10 Warning Signs That You Chose the Wrong Wifeor a question like:Warning - bleeding gums - a sure sign of gum disease?Among different types of headlines are the ever popular How To headlines, headlines that elicit shock (The Shocking Truth about  ...) , headlines based on lack of knowledge (3 little known facts  that could affect your [blank], headlines directed to specific audiences, headlines promising peace of mind, alleviating problems, offering guidelines, headlines that offer x number of ways to solve a problem, headlines that offer x number of steps to solve a problem, and many others.it is a good resource to start your creative juices flowing.

I have just finished reading several books which read as if the authors were just brainstorming ideas, never organizing the information or editing the book, so when I started to read this book, I was pleasantly surprised and relieved that Mike Shreeve truly gave a thought to this book, took the time to organize the information so that it makes sense and his professionalism and expertise shine through.This book is designed to help people who may know little or close to nothing about copywriting, people who run their own small businesses and those who would like to develop the copywriting skills. It is not an exhaustive book on copywriting, but it is very good book to get you started.Mike gives you the tips in this book to practice just the way those who have become successful professional copywriters practice.You will find the common mistakes that people make when creating a sales letter and how to avoid them.You will then learn the basics of copywriting.  Here Mike has outlines six steps for you to follow.Next you will learn 3 things that you can do that will dramatically improve your copywriting and help you to master it in the shortest period of time.  This steps truly are the steps that any great copywriter has followed.And while the secret to becoming a great copywriter is "practice, practice, practice", if you're in a rush to put together a decent sales letter, Mike shares a template you can use, guiding you step-by-step through writing a headline, body copy, all the way to the best ways to ask for call for action.

This 52-page booklet reads like one long sales letter for Nithyananda's meditation classes.The problem is your karma, and the proposed solution is - sign up for Nithyananda's meditation classes.This book is part of Nithyananda's why series.As such,  the question is:  Why do you have karma?The answer is "Because your thoughts, words, and actions keep creating it."What can you do to be free of karma? - Life from pure consciousness.You won't find the answer to how to do that in this book,  but you'll get the hint " as long as you think, you keep creating karma."Again, you won't find any guidelines how to stop thinking, but if you turn to chapter "Hands on Technique to Live Beyond Karma", you'll find that the entire chapter is an advertisement for Nithyananda's Live Bliss Meditation classes.  The ad says if you sign up to be initiated you will receive a mala (necklace), bracelet and a spiritual name by Nithyananda, and a meditation booklet personally signed by Nithyananda.

This book is written in a form of letters from a caring father, Gary Halbert, who is serving time in Boron prison to his son, Bond Halbert.Through these letters Gary is giving advice to Bond related to general health, well-being and conduct in life, as well as to direct marketing and copywriting.  The letters also contain brief descriptions of incidents from prison life.  Bond says he left them in this book, so that the reader would have an idea under what kind of conditions Gary wrote these letters.Gary walks his talk and is trying to teach his son through examples from his own life.Among those suggestions for well-being is the advice to run for half an hour or for an hour each day, or for that matter to engage in some form of physical exercise, not just for the sake of exercising the body, but because neuro-science has indeed proven that if you move your body, your brain works better, which would then influence your ability to think and come up with better ideas for direct marketing and copywriting.His next suggestion relates to eating fruits and fasting at least one day a week. Again, the idea is that if you have a healthy body, you'll be able to be more productive in your direct marketing and copywriting attempts.Gary then shares wonderful insights for direct marketing and copywriting, though in sporadic fashion, as they occur to him and sometimes he's not sure what should he mention next.  In other words, they were written for Bond, who was at the time of writing these letters 16 years old and who also mentioned in the book that his father has been taking him to various direct-marketing and copywriting events or seminars since he was 9 years old.Even though these letters were written in the 80's, many of those insights are timeless, like different tips and tricks on how to attract attention, stimulate interest and desire, and call for action; how to go about getting the leads, to write simple and to read your copy aloud several times until it reads smoothly.Gary would mention what to do and what not to do - for example that you should first find the hot market, and then the product, rather than the other way around.And he'd describe the general process of developing and testing direct marketing packages, for example to start with 5,000 letters, and depending on response increase it to 50,000 or more.Since these letters were written in the 80's, Bond has added his commentary underneath each letter in an attempt to correlate those principles to internet marketing.I got the book in a kindle format, which may differ from the paperback.  The edition of the book I purchased contains typos and grammar errors in the commentary, which makes you feel like eating a super delicious apple and finding a worm inside.

If you like the books and teachings of Ramana Maharshi and Nisargadatta Maharaj, and if you enjoy reading books related to advaita, non-duality, here's a gem of a book, with teachings by Wu Hsin, intended to help you realize your true nature.The realization is not an intellectual process, so it is not enough to just read the book.  But the words in this book are like seeds which if you nurture through constant contemplation, will give birth to the experience of the true nature.Wu Hsin talks about the same thing from many different perspectives, so that if you're having difficulty getting it one way, another way may perfectly resonate with you.Here are few pointers from this book:"Wu Hsin's instructions will not lead you to anywhere.  They lead you toward the place that you have never departed from.""Truth does not require your agreement, merely your recognition.""There is nothing to learn, however, there is much to unlearn.""All that is needed is to relinquish one's erroneous beliefs.""To be free from the obsession with "What's next?" is all instruction necessary.  You are waiting for the arrival of something that is already present.""Enlightenment is the return to that point of view that was operative prior to the arising of self-consciousness.  It is unitive in its very nature.""I am is the ultimate fact.  "What am I?" is the ultimate question.""What you strive for is what you imagine you must strive for.  With the cessation of striving, what needs to arrive, arrives.""What is experienced is the content of consciousness.""You want to escape your prison,but you haven't discerned that the thinking you're in prison is the prison.""Remove the attention from what is personal and what reveals itself is The Source, without which neither light no darkness could be cognized.""You emit the world and its activities without doing anything.""There is never a problem in the outside world.  All problems are in the mind.""If you really want to end the searching, you must return the way you came.""Consciousness can well exist, all alone, without phenomena.  But, phenomena, can never exist without Consciousness.""Here is the secret:  Thought obscures happiness.""Recede from concepts into perception; then recede from perception into Being.""The truth doesn't set you free.  The truth reveals that you've always been free.""We are already looking from that which we are looking for.  In that sense, we really need not go anywhere."

This is the first book in Dr. Yang's Qigong series and it provides an overview of Qigong for health and martial arts. Like his other books, this one begins with the history of qigong, and the general principles of qigong.  This one also deals with popular martial arts styles of qigong.Following the introduction, the book is divided in sections on Wai Dan Qigong (external cultivation), Nei Dan Qigong (internal cultivation), Qigong for Health, and Martial Arts Applications.The external cultivation includes illustrated Da Mo's Yi Jin Jing, Open Palm Sequence, Moving Forms, Ba Duan Jin (Eight Pieces of Brocade), and Still yoga-like stretching exercises.  Some of these you may be able to do, at least as far as physical movement is involved, by just following the illustrations and descriptions, while for others you may be better off if you either watch them on a video or participate in a live instruction.The internal cultivation includes the Small Circulation (Microcosmic Orbit) , Grand Circulation, Qi Enhancement and Transport Training, and Chi Self-Massage after the exercises.  While the information provided may serve as an overview, you may want to cross-reference it with other works, perhaps Mantak Chia's.  In this book Dr. Yang is making it seem much harder to do than it truly is and you'll encounter all kinds of warnings if you do it improperly, and Mantak Chia teaches some preparatory exercises that make the circulation a breeze.  Also for some reason, Dr. Yang's has misplaced Ming Men, the Door of Life, and keeps referring to it as if it were the point behind the heart, when in fact, Ming Men is the point between the kidneys.In the Health section, Dr. Yang shares an overview of qigong healing modalities like health diagnosis, acupuncture and massage, using taiji balls and six healing sounds - not enough to get you to do them yourself for a healing, but more to get an idea of modalities that you may want to explore further.In Martial Arts section the focus is mainly on cavity press or chin-na, which Dr. Yang's explains in much greater detail in his related books and an excellent video.While this book may not be perfect on its own, I still do recommend it for the avalanche of good information.  Just do cross-reference it with other related books and videos.  I do recommend just about all books and videos by Dr. Yang Jwing Ming, as well as most of those by Mantak Chia.  Dr. Yang's work though seems to gravitate toward martial arts, and Mantak Chia's toward taoist spiritual alchemy, but many basic practices overlap and they wonderfully complement each other.  There are other good others, but these two seem to be among the most prolific authors.

These videos are superb.  Robert Peng exudes inner peace and balance as he guides you through qigong - exercises for cultivating inner power, harmony and wisdom. He speaks with a resonant, hypnotic voice. The video has just perfect special effects to help you with visualization.You will learn how to project energy through your fingers with a Sword Finger technique, how to create a qi ball, how to build the energy in your lower, middle and upper dan tian, how to balance the energy through the central meridian.  You will learn an amazingly beautiful Lotus meditation, and much more.While you can use these videos on their own, you can get even more out of them if you also read the Master Key book.  If you get the book in a digital format, you'll find there links which will take you to the SoundTrue website where you can view the video clips.  I have purchased these videos through the links in the book, where they are available in downloadable format.  You can also view video samples on youtube.

While I can attest to the effectiveness of the Eight Pieces of Brocade, when done properly, I was expecting this books to have more information specific to the exercises themselves.This is a small book of 112 pages, and only 20% of this book is dedicated to the actual Eight Pieces of Brocade, half of that to sitting exercises, and half to standing exercises, that's about 10 pages for each, and since illustrations take about half a page, you'll get the bare minimum of guidance for the exercise.As Dr. Yang says, he wrote the book to be used together with the videos. Although you can get the gist of the exercises from the illustrations and the right-up and you may be able to perform them to some point even using this book, and you may get the benefit from the purely physical movement, there is no specific guidance for coordinating breathing with the movements, nor the visualizations that help you to get the most of the exercises, nor a key instruction regarding a simple thing you must do get the energy circulating.Also, for some reason when talking to Middle Dan Tian, Dr. Yang keeps saying several times that it is in the solar plexus region, and sometimes that it is at the heart center.  And the kidney point, the Door of Life, which is called Ming Men, he has renamed here Jing Men.  Acupuncture charts depict Jing Men as a point on the side of the ribcage.The first chapter of this book, which is about 30% of the book deals with the history of Qigong, second part of the book, again about 30% deals with the theory of Qigong, and the last 20% of the book is the glossary.While Dr. Yang emphasizes that he believes that the theory of Qigong is more important than the actual form of the exercise, and while I respect all the hard work he invested in translating the works and sharing the information with the west, he also added that he found it difficult to translate some Chinese concepts into English and at times his choice of English words doesn't help to make the meaning any clearer.  At times the writing style seems somewhat erratic, as if Dr. Yang was just jotting down his thoughts on paper, and feel that further editing might have helped to organize and present the information in a way that would be easier to comprehend.I have read books by Mantak Chia, Bruce Frantzis, Eva Wong, Thomas Cleary, Robert Peng and others, and have found these writers to present the information in a clear and easy-to-understand way.  Again, I do greatly appreciate Dr. Yang's life-work, but have found this book to have, perhaps a lot of information that may be interesting, but not necessarily helpful for the Eight Pieces of Brocade, and I have found some information which would've been more helpful for the Eight Pieces of Brocade missing.

The Master Key: Qigong Secrets for Vitality, Love, and Wisdom is beautifully written.Through the first five chapters, Robert describes his journey, meeting his teacher Xiao Yao when he was 8 years old, and practicing 2 - 4 hours a day, first martial arts, and then qigong for healing, while cultivating inner balance and developing spiritual awareness.In the course of his training, he says that he learned hundreds of Qigong practices, and in this book he shares several foundational practices. Through the following 11 chapters, Robert guides you to the process of awakening qi power, using a sword finger, creating a qi ball, empowering three dantiens (lower, middle, and upper), balancing the three dantiens, empowering the central meridian, lotus meditation, and connecting universe exercise.The qigong exercises are illustrated, and there are links to brief videos at SoundsTrue website.  While these videos are helpful, they seem to be designed more to give you a preview of what you may expect from the DVDs you can get to get more out of the exercises.Having also purchased the Master Key videos through the SoundsTrue website, just as this book, they are truly professionally created.  Robert has a resonant, hypnotic voice and through the video he radiates calm, balanced energy and both the videos and this book are at the same time informative, instructional and enjoyable.The slant of qigong practice presented in this book is primarily on creating inner balance, and becoming spiritually centered in the process, and then transforming inner imbalances and fostering healing through manipulation of energy, as well as through spiritual awareness.Robert has dedicated a good chunk of this book to the cultivation of spiritual awareness, and here he shares a simple practice for experiencing Awakened Awareness.Through the last three chapters, Robert shares guidelines for practicing the exercises; explores how energetic imbalances affect relationships and intimacy, and how you can create a healthier, more balanced relationships by first cultivating inner balance; and has a chapter on the evolution of the self-aware universe.The practices involving the balancing and empowerment of three dantiens and the central meridian are called the Four Golden Wheels, and the practices presented in this book are summed up by Xiao Yao:"Awaken the Four Golden Wheels. Become wiser, more loving, and more capable of taking action in the face of the unknown.  Remain centered, balanced, and in a state of open flow.  When the four wheels are turning smoothly, you find yourself in the right place, at the right time, doing the right thing, with the right people.  A clearing appears before you.  This path is your destiny, and with every step you take you are happy and the whole world rejoices."

The talks with Ramana Maharshi in this book are presented in question and answer format. In the introduction, it says that 68% of these talks are the same as the ones presented in the book "Talks with Ramana Maharshi".The talks are presented through chapters, with various headings like "The Mind", "The Ultimate as Reality", "The Ultimate as Truth", and a number of the talks are repeated verbatim under different chapters.The talks consist of similar questions asked by people who have not experienced the Self, and Ramana's attempt to put in words that which can only be known through experience.Ramana thus points over and over again, that the experience of the Self is a natural experience, that the person gets to experience it through self-enquiry by tracing his thoughts back to the Source, the Self, which results not in a verbal answer to self-enquiry, but in experience of the Self, and once experienced, all that is left is to practice abiding in the Self.In this practice, the thoughts arising out of ego, the bodily identification, begin to dissolve.  In the beginning the practice requires conscious effort.  Eventually, it becomes effortless, natural expression of the Self.A person asks, "What is this Self?Ramana answers, "Know the Self and God is known.  Of all the definitions of God none is so well put as the Biblical "I am that I AM" in Exodus III.  But none is so direct as the  - "I AM" - The Absolute Is.  It is Self, God.Another one says, "Convince me of the existence of God."Ramana answers, Realization of the Self amounts to such conviction."Yet another asks, "How is "I-I consciousness felt?"Ramana answers, "As an unbroken awareness of "I".  It is simply consciousness.  You are that even now.  There will be no mistaking it, when pure."Q. "How is God to be seen?"A. Within.  If the mind is turned inward, God manifests as the inner consciousness.Q. "What is liberation?"A."It is to know you were not born.  Be still and know that I am God.  To be still is not to think.  You have lost hold of yourself.  Turn inward.  If the mind's source is sought, it will vanish leaving the Self behind.""Self is beyond knowledge and ignorance.  It is Self-luminous.""Self lies beyond [hearing or seeing] - all alone as pure Consciousness.""The consciousness within, purged of the mind, is felt as God.""The Self is here and now and alone.  It is not new and something to be acquired.  It is natural and permanent."Q. "How to get rid of fear?"A.  "All fear is nothing more than thoughts.  If there is only one there cannot be a second (to be afraid of).  To think that there is something outside ourselves is the cause of fear, but if firmly rooted in our own reality, then there will be no fear, no doubt, no undesirable qualities, as all the latter are centered about the ego.""We talk of attaining the Self, of reaching God with time.  There is nothing to attain.  We are already Self-Existent.  Nor will there ever be a time when we shall be nearer to God than now.  We are now ever blissful, Self-Existent, the Infinite.  Our consciousness is unbroken, continuous, and eternal.""There is only one Self and it is fully conscious now and ever.  There is neither past, present nor future for it, since it is out of time. Without the Infinite Power, God, the true Self, this incense would not burn, this world would not exist.  This Self is in all forms.  It alone gives them reality.  Hence the Illumined One finds himself in all others, for he has found Unity and no longer perceives multiplicity."

No book will ever reveal the secrets of the absolute.  That can only be discovered through direct experience, and in that sense whoever seeks to know God by reading the book, and through intellectual understanding will always find something missing, no matter what book he reads.Patanjali Yoga Sutras point the way.  They are divided in four chapters.  The first chapter defines the goal - samadhi - the absorption into undifferentiated consciousness, and gives an idea of what it means to practice and experience yoga. The second chapter describes the practices which help to overcome the obstacles to full spiritual realization.  The third chapter gives insight into different abilities that may arise through dedicated practice of yoga.  And the fourth chapter describes the states of consciousness preceding the Self-realization and indications of the full spiritual liberation.The essence of the entire practice is - to know God, hold only God in your conscious awareness.Different commentators of Patanjali Yoga Sutra share different insights, so reading different version of Patanjali Yoga Sutra is helpful.  Some commentaries may be clearer than others, and this one is very good, insofar that it uses simple language.

Sri Yukteswar wrote The Holy Science at the request of Mahavatar Babaji with the purpose of bridging Eastern and Western Spirituality.  However, even though this book has verses from the Bible, its flavor is distinctly Eastern.The introduction to the book explores the calculation of yugas,, and stating the the object of this book is to point out the harmony underlying the various religions, and to help in binding them together.The book is divided into 4 Chapters: The Gospel, The Goal, The Procedure, The Revelation - according to the four stages in the development of knowledge.  The highest aim of religion is Atmajnanam, Self-knowledge.The first section of the book deals with Veda and the Gospel, and seeks to establish fundamental truths of creation and to describe the evolution and involution of the world.The book is written in the form of sutras with commentaries, e.g.Sutra 1: Parambrahma (Spirit or God) is infinite, complete, without start or end.  It is one, undividable Being."The Eternal Father, God, Swami Parambrahma, is the only Real Substance, Sat, and is all in all in the universe.Now, instead of adding characteristics of God as mentioned in the verses of the Gospel (as in "God is Light" or "God is Love"), Sri Yukteswar quotes the verses,"Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen.""Then said Jesus unto them, When ye have lifted up the son of man, then shall ye know that I am he."adding that God is incomprehensible by man of this material world (by human consciousness), and can only be comprehensible if a man lifts himself above the creation of Darkness or Maya.Sutra 2: In Parambrahma is the source of all knowing and love, the root of all power and joy.Sutra 3: Parambrahma emanates creation, inert Nature (Prakriti) to emerge.  From Om (Pranava, the Word, the manifestation of the Omnipresent Force) come Kala, Time, Desa, Space, and Anu, the Atom (the vibratory structure of creation)."Sutra 4:  "The fundament of creation is Anu or the Atoms.  Together they are called Maya or the Lord's veil of projection; each individual Anu is called Avidya, Ignorance."Atoms are the throne of Spirit the Creator.
