They are called en masse Maya, the Darkness, as they keep the Spiritual Light out of comprehension, and each of them separately is called Avidya, the Ignorance, as it makes man ignorant even of his own Self.He then compares these 4 ideas which gave rise to all confusions, to the 4 bests mentioned in the chapter of Revelations of the Bible."And in the midst of the throne, and round about the throne, were four beasts full of eyes before and behind."The Holy Ghost, being the manifestation of the Omniscient Nature of the Eternal Father, God, is no other substance than God Himself, and so these reflections of spiritual rays are called the Sons of God - Abhasa Chaiitanya or Purusha."In him was life, and the life was the light of men.  And the light shines in the darkness, and the darkness comprehends it not."This now continues with exploration of the nature of the Ahamkara with 5 different bodies, different senses, different objects of the senses, and so on, followed by exploration of 14 spheres - seven swargas or lokas and seven patalas, five koshas or sheaths of Purusha, and different kingdoms from animal to angelic.On the 2nd birth he says "Through his luminous body, man, believing in the existence of the true Light - the Life of this universe - becomes baptized or absorbed in the holy stream of the sound.  The baptism is, so to speak, the second birth of man and is called Bhakti Yoga, without which man can never comprehend the real internal world, the kingdom of God."Emancipation (Kaivalya) is obtained when one realizes the oneness of his Self with the Universal Self, the Supreme Reality.""When all the developments of Ignorance are withdrawn, the heart, being perfectly clear and purified, no longer merely reflects the Spiritual Light but actively manifests the same, and thus being consecrated and anointed, man becomes Sannyasi, free, or Christ the Savior.""Liberation is stabilization of Purusha (jiva, soul) in its real Self.""Residing in Self is liberation.  When man raises himself above the idea of creation of this Darkness, Maya, and passes completely out of its influence, he becomes liberated from bondage and is placed in his real Self, the Eternal Spirit.""Then there is cessation of all pain and the attainment of the ultimate aim (true fulfillment, God-realization).""Liberation is salvation.  On attaining this liberation, man becomes saved from all his troubles, and all the desires of his heart are fulfilled, so the ultimate aim of his life is accomplished.""I have said, Ye are gods;and all of you are children of the most High."

Together with verses from the Bible that inspire faith, Joseph Murphy shares inspiring stories."All things whatsoever ye shall ask in prayer, believe that ye receive them, and ye shall receive them."Believe means to live in the state of being it."Believe that you have it now, and ye shall have it"."Call things that be not, as though they were, and the unseen becomes seen."Murphy also shares tips for the practice of the presence of God.The first step is to realize that God is the Only Power.  Your whole world will change as you really begin to see God in everything and everyone. If you say and believe God is the only Presence, the only Power, Infinitely Good, Perfect, Boundless Love, and Limitless Life, your whole life will be transformed."The real Name of God, insofar as you are concerned is your concept or your belief about God.You practice the presence of God when you choose to hold in your consciousness only the eternal truths and perceive that which is eternal in everyone and everything in your life.Murphy has chosen to portray the nature of faith beautifully through the Song of Solomon, where your lover is the Invisible Presence within you - the Almighty Power which created the Universe.As you go to sleep every night, clothe yourself with the garment of love, peace, and joy.  Love gives birth to all things.  Your tomorrows are determined by your concept of yourself as you fall asleep in the arms of your Love (your ideal).

The recommendation in this book is based on the author's experience, which may be described as forcibly induced kundalini experience, but it has nothing to do with Self-Realization.  He is confusing varieties of kundalini, psychic and spiritual experiences with Self-Realization.  In spite of sharing the quotes from Ramana Maharshi's books, the author unfortunately doesn't have any comprehension of what Self-Realization is.  Thus the value of his critique of the methods used by yogis and Self-Realized beings and his assertion that you can become a Self-Realized Being using his method is pointless.The author describes his experience as the energy shooting up his spine, exploding in a shower of brilliant light, and him feeling like a marionette at the mercy of energy contorting his body violently, where he would've felt frightened except for a benevolent presence and experience of intensely erotic sensuality.In the experience of Self-Realization, you experience yourself as One Eternal Self, as pure undifferentiated luminous consciousness.  You don't see the Light - You  experience yourself as the Light.  There is no benevolence presence.  You are IT - the absolute changeless reality.  Your human consciousness dissolves in the infinite consciousness. Whatever you knew as your human self, the body, the mind - doesn't exist.  The only thing that exists is Pure Light.  You are the Limitless Formless Light - the entire creation contained within it, not in form, but as pure potential.Having the experience ultimately entails holding in your mind and heart only that which is eternal, allowing everything else to dissolve. Some may have the experience instantly through total surrender, others practice techniques that get them to dissolve human consciousness over time.  Having an experience of the Eternal Self, is only the beginning.  The journey is not complete until the experience becomes stabilized.  A Self-Realized being lives moment to moment from this undifferentiated consciousness.While the author states in some parts of his book that the experience he had was inconsequential, that it happened spontaneously without any cause, thus claiming no practice is necessary, and no practice will get you there - at the same time he states that here is the practice he followed and which he recommends as a 21 day practice:1. Month-long bicycle tour2. Substandard, calorie-restricted diet3. Sleep Deprivation4. Sexual Abstinence5. Hatha Yoga and Tai Chi Chuan (he also claims these do not work)6. Daily practice of deep relaxation before sleep and immediately upon awakening7. Sleep disturbance: being prematurely drawn up out of sleep by light of the seeing sun.8. Brainwave entrainmentThe author's recommended practice of forced deprivation from bodily needs can indeed induce all kinds of psycho-spiritual experiences, but where it takes you will ultimately depend on where your mind and heart are.  If your mind and heart are fixed on the Immortal Self, and during the practice you are placing all that you know yourself to be, your mind, your heart, your body into the hands of your Immortal Self, having nothing else in your consciousness, you may very well experience the Self.However, if your mind is fixed on bodily needs, and you're feeling deprived, these will seek fulfillment through your dreams - a man hungry for food may dream of food, a man hungry for sex will dream of sex, which is why the author has concluded that spiritual practice induces sexual dreams.  The author's summary of the chapter on Kundalini and Dreams ends with his conclusion that self-realization is about having stronger erections and enhanced sexual experiences.  The author also shares his insights on autoerotic asphyxiation - if that's what you're looking for this may be the right book for you.  Self-Realized Being does not have dreams, because he is fully conscious, even while his body sleeps.Self-Realization is an experience of Liberation from human identity, consciousness and experience, not about orgasmic pleasure. Immortal Bliss and Peace and Ultimate Freedom come from realization and experience that I AM not this body - I AM The Immortal Light - and apart from that nothing exists.  So, in the experience of Self-Realization that is all that you experience Light and nothing but the Light - the Immortal Reality - and that is the truth that sets you free.

This is a small book and you can read it in a couple of hours, so you can't expect ti to equal the Bible - however, the author has accomplished what he set out to accomplish and in that sense it is very well done.For each of the 66 books of the Bible, the author has quoted the author, the date when it was approximately written, summary of that book in 10 words or less.He then shared details in a paragraph or two, followed by quotable quotes, what's unique and unusual, and ultimately the moral lesson, under the heading "So what?"" that book attempts to convey.At the beginning of the book, the author writes, the ultimate message of the whole Bible is that God loves you."Beloved, let us love one another, for love is of God ... God is love. (1 John 4:7-8)Quotable Quotes:"God said unto Moses, I AM THAT I AM: and he said, Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel, I AM  hath sent me unto you." (Exodus, 3:14)"Ye shall be holy, for I (god) am holy. " (Leviticus 11:44)"The Lord is long-suffering, and of great mercy, forgiving iniquity and transgression." (Numbers 14:18)"Hear, O Israel:  The Lord our God is One Lord.' (Deuteronomy 6:4)"Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thine heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy might." (Deuteronomy 6:5)"Man shall not live by bread alone,but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God." (Deuteronomy 8:3)"Be strong and of a good courage, be not afraid, neither be though dismayed, for the Lord thy God is with thee whithersoever thou goest." (Joshua 1:9)"Create in me a clean heart, O God, and renew a right spirit within me. (Psalms 51:10)"Trust in the Lord with all thine heart, and lean not unto thine own understanding." (Proverbs 3:5)"The Lord thy God in the midst of thee is mighty: he will save, he will rejoice over thee with joy. (3:17)"Ye are the light of the world." (Matthew 5:14)"Ye shall receive power, after the Holy Ghost is come upon you." (Acts 1:8)"The fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, long-suffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, meekness, temperance." (Gal. 5:22)"Worry about nothing, but in every thing by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God." (4:6)"Pray without ceasing." (1 Thess5:17)"f any would not work, neither should he eat." (2 Thess 3:10)"True believers, Jude says, reflect God's love and show compassion." (Jude 1:23)So what?Troubles that people experience as punishment are not intended to hurt people but to bring them back to God, to urge them to return to Love. (2 Chronicles)Trouble isn't necessary a sign of sin in a person's life.  It may be something God allows to draw us closer to Him. (Job)When we find ourselves in bad situations, it may be so we can accomplish something good - like Esther did. (Ester)"God loves everyone - even the enemies of his chosen people" (Jonah)

This is a very well written book about praying with Biblical excerpts. It reads more like a dissertation about praying, rather than being a collection of prayers.  It also has sections that may be more useful for pastors and ministers rather people who are just praying on their own.The book is balanced with many common sense tips and helpful insights from the author.The author begins by saying "I discovered that prayer is not a religious exercise - it is a human necessity." and I fully agree wit it.He continues, "I discovered that prayer is the secret weapon ... It is like a missile that can be fired toward any spot on earth, travel undetected at the speed of thought and hit its target every time."For what can we pray?  Bible encourages us to pray about everything.  "If you abide in Me, and My words abide in you, you will ask what you desire, and it shall be done for you.""Worry about nothing, says Paul, and pray about everything" (Philippians 4:6)At times, the author shares quotes by other authors, like Dr. Curtis Mitchell,  "Prayer is set forth as the chief task of the believer.  It is his responsibility to ask.  it is God's responsibility to accomplish."The author emphasizes that we are urged to ask for what want and while we may ask for anything, he suggests that what we ask should be in accord with God's will.  He also points out that the more godly our lives are, the more powerful will our prayers be, and that while our prayers are answered immediately, they will be delivered in the "fullness of time", when the time is right.I the chapter on Why God answers prayers, the author quotes "And whatever you ask in My name, that will I do, that the Father may be glorified in the Son." (John 14:13)In the chapter on fasting, he mentioned few verses from the Bible where Peter, James and John attempted unsuccessfully to cast the demon out of the boy.  After Jesus arrived on the scene and delivered the boy, his disciples asked Him privately, "Why could we not cast him out?"  And He said to them, "This kind can come out by nothing but prayer and fasting." (Mark 9:28, 29)The author then shares different kinds of fasting mentioned in the bible, lasting 3, 5, 7, 21, or 40 days, some being complete abstinence from food and water, most being water or liquid fasts, and some being abstinence from some kinds of food, but not all.On account of intercession, the author says "We are never more like Christ than when we are praying for others."  He goes at great length to describe what the prayer is and isn't and how to go about praying.  The author also recommends that the reader reads as many other books on praying as he can.

Claim Your Anointing is a collection of interviews with people who are using their gifts ministering to people all over the world.The interviews are excerpted from previously published books Shifting Shadows or Supernatural Power and Supernatural Anointing.The book begins by a quote from Randy Clark "be careful of limiting God.  There are different anointings for different seasons of time, for what you care called to do. It is not like there is one anointing."The interviews presented in the book are  "You are so much more than you know" by Julia Loren, "The Price to pay for the anointing" by Randy Clark, "Claiming the anointing of the Holy Spirit" by Bill Johnson, "Claiming the Anointing of a true prophet" by Graham Cooke, "Claiming the anointing for strategic warfare" by Mahesh Chavda, 'Claiming the anointing for miracles of healing" by David Hogan, "Claiming the anointing to reconcile nations" by Myles Weiss, "Claiming the anointing of love to change the world" by Heidi Baker, "Claiming the anointing of power for kissings" by Leif Hetland, "Claiming the anointing to reach your sacred destiny" by John Paul Jackson and Paul Keith Davis.Julia Loren says "As you read about the various gifts, callings and anointings, listen to the voice of the Holy Spirit whispering, "This is you! This is you!".  Through the interviews you get a glimpse into different anointings, and the interviews are supposed to help you discover how you may use your talents and abilities in service to others and thus life your life abundantly, meaningfully and joyfully."The anointing is God's love saturating your life and overflowing to others. If you want more of the anointing, you are, in reality, asking for more of God's love.  Love releases the gifts in greater measure than you ever dreamed could happen through you.  ... The supernatural charisma gifts, or graces, from the Holy Spirit are simply tools, which are always given by God to serve others.The gifts are yours to express but given by God alone and to God alone, belongs the glory.  They are born out of God's love for you and are released out of love for God.""Do you want to know who the happiest people are?  Not the rich, nor the most gifted.  The happiest people are those who find their purpose in life and release their gifts in such a way that they discover they are living a meaningful existence.  The happiest people on earth are those who are living in the flow of grace - releasing God's favor and gifts to others. ... Claiming your anointing will not make you happy.  Releasing the anointing will ... if it is done to the glory of God and not to your own desire for glory."

The book contains the author's choice of selection of verses from the Bible.  The author has divided the book in different sections like Overcoming Negative Thinking, Protection through Proclamations, Financial and Physical Needs, Health and Strength, Guidance, Protection and Preservation, Testing and Trials, Mental and Emotional Stability, and so on.  Some verses are repeated 3 or 4 times in different section.Here are sample verses:Three of my mightiest weapons areproclamation, thanksgiving, and praise.Behold the manner of lovethe Father has bestowed upon us,that we should be calledchildren of God!And we are.Therefore the world does not know us,because it did not know Him,Beloved, now we are children of God,and it has not yet been revealedwhat we shall be,but we know that when He is revealed,we shall be like Him,for we shall see Him as He is.And everyone who has this hope in Himpurifies himself, just as He is pure.We have known and believedthe love that God has for us.God is love, and he who abides in loveabides in God, and God in him.This is our prayer:that the God may give to usa spirit of wisdom and revelationin the knowledge of Him,the eyes of our understanding being enlightened ...Bless The Lord, O my soul,and all that is within me,bless His holy name,Bless the Lord, O my soul,and forget not all his benefits;Who forgiveth all thine iniquities;who healeth all thy diseases;Who redeemeth thy life from destruction;who crowneth thee with lovingkindnessand tender mercies;Who satisfieth thy mouth with good things;so that thy youth is renewed like the eagle's.Finally brethren,whatsoever things are true,whatsoever things are noble,whatsoever things are just,whatsoever things are pure,whatsoever things are lovely,whatsoever things are of good report,if there is any virtue,and if there is anything praiseworthy,we meditate on these things.

In this book Don shares his views and experiences with deliverance.He says that he wished to be able to do more for people than he seemed able to, so he prayed from deep in his heart to be a deliverer and to lead people out of bondage.  He prayed to be the God's instrument of freedom.  In time, he was lead to help those who felt oppressed and who couldn't help themselves.He shares possible reasons why someone may get under the oppressive influence - the main one being some kind of unforgiveness. Thus in deliverance, the first things he asks the person to do is to forgive anyone and anything that may need forgiveness in his life.He points out that in order for someone to become oppressed, there must be some permission granted by the person, there must be a "gate" or doorway of opportunity.  Among these permissions he lists generational curses, traumatic experiences, weakness of mind or body, pain, spoken curses, feelings of fear, anger, shame, guilt, addictions, activities where the person doesn't seem to be able to exercise control, seven deadly sins, involvement in varieties of occult activities.While he lists involvement in different practices and activities as possible entranceways, making his viewpoint sound extremist, perhaps it would be more accurate to focus on one's state of mind and heart during those activities rather than on activity itself.  If someone spills hot water on himself while cooking in a moment he had an upsetting thought, it wouldn't make much sense to conclude that one got possessed by demons (if you'd choose to attribute burning accident to a demon) because of cooking activity, but rather to an upsetting thought.Scripture says "He who doesn't love doesn't know God, for God is love" (1 John 4:8); ""God is love, and he who remains in love remains in God, and God remains in him" (1 John 4:16); "Above all these things, walk in love, which is the bond of perfection" (Col 3:14). The one walking in love bears the fruits of love, and one walking in fear bears the fruits of fear, "therefore by their fruits you shall know them" (Matthew 7:20) "The fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faith." (Galatians 5:22)  These verses may offer a better guideline as to what state of mind may be more conducive to attract dismal influences in one's life - Are you filled with worry or with peace? Are you filled with thoughts and feelings of condemnation or do you walk in love? Like attracts like.The author says that in his experience virtually anything that a doctor calls a "disorder" may be caused by demons.  He lists then things that demons don't like - the name of Jesus Christ, the anointing oil, praise music, the word "holy", the name Jehovah causes them to fear and tremble.In clearing the person from oppressive influence, Don would ask the oppressed individual to first forgive whatever needs forgiveness, to repent whatever he may have done wrong and to renounce the activity and the association with whatever created the opening for such influence.  He'd also ask the oppressive influence for its identity, how it gained entrance to the person and when commanding it to leave he'd command it also to "retrieve very seed that had been planted, uproot everything that had been planted, clean up the mess completely and go into the abyss."People portrayed through case histories in this book come from all walks of life, though all of them are Christians and among them is also "a Baptist Deacon with demons".Don's mother, various inmates, and little children.  He says that "when ministering to children, parents must first go through the deliverance process in order to break any legal permissions that demons might have to the child's life through a generational curse."Again he points out that whatever influences or spirits affect our lives, they can only must have our consent, and permission is granted in many ways through each person's life.  That includes demons, evil spirits, devils, spirits of infirmity principalities, powers, as well as godly influences.  He quotes from Revelation 3:20 where jesus says "I stand at the door and knock" - because He too must have our permission to enter our lives.  We give permission through the thoughts and emotions we entertain, and through activities in which we participate.He quotes from Proverbs 25:28 "He that hath no rule [self control] over his own spirit is like a city that is broken down, and without walls."As preventative measures, among other things he suggests, "When negative thoughts come, you must rebuke them and replace them with positive thoughts", trust God daily to help you make correct choices, pray throughout the day.

This book has a healthy suggestion for prevention of Alzheimer's based on scientific research studies and covering nutrition, physical exercise, mental exercise through continuous learning, cultivating social networks, and spiritual practice.Here are several tips from the book:NUTRITIONOne study showed that people who drank fresh fruit and vegetable juices more than three times a week were 76% less likely to develop Alzheimer's disease than those who drank juices less than once a week. The study showed the protective benefits of juice appeared to be particularly enhanced in people who had a genetic marker linked to an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease known as ApoE-4.In one study scientists in Germany found that increased physical activity was associated with a lower incidence of dementia. Those who exercised at least three times a week were half as likely to have developed dementia as those who reported no physical activity.In a study at Loma Linda University, a study group found that a daily glass of pomegranate juice could halve the build-up of harmful proteins linked to Alzheimer's disease.Men and women who reported eating fish at least once a week had a 60 % lower risk of getting Alzheimer's compared to those who rarely or almost never ate fish.A study on the effect of blood caffeine levels found tat older adults who drank the equivalent of 3 - 4 cups of coffee per day were protected from developing Alzheimer's.The researchers found that people who drank more than 2 cups of green tea per day had a 50 % lower incidence of cognitive impairment. EGCG is an antioxidant found in green tea that researchers frequently study for its health benefits.  The researchers used EGCG to effectively untangle the proteins causing Alzheimer's and restore the pristine state of brain tissue.People with diabetes - especially type 2 diabetes - are at higher risk of eventually developing Alzheimer's disease. Taking steps to prevent or control diabetes may help reduce the risk of Alzheimer's disease.  Alzheimer's is being called Diabetes Type 3 by some researchers.  Researchers found that insulin is not just produced in the pancreas, but also in the brain.  And they discovered that insulin and its growth factors, which are necessary for the survival of brain cells, contribute to the progression of Alzheimer's.In Alzheimer's patients portions of their brain start to atrophy, or starve, leading to impaired functioning and eventual loss of memory, speech, movement and personality. In effect, the brain can begin to atrophy from starvation if it becomes insulin resistant and loses its ability to convert glucose to energy.  Ketone bodies may restore and renew neuron and nerve function in the brain after the damage has set in.  They are found in coconut oil.  A bit over two tablespoons of coconut oil (35 ml or 7 level teaspoons) would supply with equivalent of 20 grams of MCT which is indicated as either a preventative measure against degenerative neurological diseases, or as a treatment for already established case.PHYSICAL EXERCISEThose who exercised at least twice a week in middle age were 50 % less likely to develop Alzheimer's disease in old age.  Population studies have suggested that exercise which raises your heart rate for at least 30 minutes several times a week can lower your risk of Alzheimer's.  Physical activity appears to inhibit Alzheimer's like brain changes, slowing the development of a key feature of the disease. A lack of exercise affects Alzheimer's disease in a profound way.Resistance training is particularly beneficial for improving the cognitive abilities of older adults.  Those who weight lift experience the greatest improvement.Exercise not only prevents the normal shrinkage (atrophy) from occurring, but also stimulates neurogenesis - the formation of new brain cells and connections!  So, not only can you keep your brain from shrinking, but you can make it even bigger and stronger.INTELLECTUAL STIMULATION and MUSICIntellectually stimulating careers and hobbies, like learning a new language, playing a musical instrument or doing crossword puzzles or word games, build extra brainpower.It is important to challenge your brain, as in memory recall, learning or doing something new.  Find what's interesting to you, master it and move on to the next challenge.Learning different languages and musical instrument training may reduce the effects of mental decline associated with aging.  Studies showed that bilinguals experience onset symptoms of dementia years later than monolinguists.Sustaining musical activity during advanced age may enhance thinking ability, neutralizing any negative impact of age and even lack of education.  Musicians scored higher on tests of mental acuity, visual-spatial judgment, verbal memory and recall, and motor dexterity.The mental process required to play a musical instrument may work in the same way as juggling a dual languages to strengthen the connections in your brain over time.RELAXATIONDeep breathing, relaxation, stress reduction, laughter - help to protect from Alzheimer's.SPIRITUALITYNegative or "toxic" thoughts affect our mental, emotional and physical health.  Thinking and feeling anger, fear and frustration, causes DNA to change shape according to thoughts and the associated feelings.  The study showed that the poor quality of the DNA codes was reversed with feelings of love, joy, appreciation and gratitude!Un-forgiveness may be the most damaging toxic thoughts, according to the neuroscientist Dr. Leaf.  We can literally protect our brain and heart by extending forgiveness.

The author shares many good points and wonderful stories, and for them I'd highly recommend this book. And then the author also shares some of his personal opinions,  which weren't my cup of tea, but perhaps you find them agreeable.Most of this book I found awesome.  The author points out beautifully that prayer and intercession should be all about friendship, relationship and partnering with God, that what we pray should be motivated and arise out of love for God - not out of motivation to get something, nor out of feeling of obligation or sacrifice, but out of love - and under the guidance of God's love, looking at the world through the eyes of love.  We are the instruments through which love and power of God express, and we should be a pure channels through which that love flows.The author is also pointing out that while some things may happen of their own accord and we don't have to ask for them, that we are instructed to pray and ask for what we want.He shares many stories from the Scripture, as well as from his experience and from other people's experiences, and the stories themselves are worth getting this book.  There are stories about problems that people had simply because they didn't ask that those problems be solved.  There are also stories where even though people were told that the problem was solved in spirit, they still had to ask for it before they experienced it.Praying and asking may take different forms.  In this book, the author has offered prayers after each chapter, and they are a good starting point.  The stories the author shared also have examples of what people prayed for to resolve the problematic issue and the miraculous results their prayers produced. You'll find all kinds of wonderful stories of miraculous healings and of protection - truly inspiring.

The Business Communication book guides you through a 3 x 3 Writing Process.The first, prewriting phase of the process involves analyzing the purpose of the message, the best way to deliver the message, profiling the audience and anticipating the response, then adapting the message to the anticipated response.The second, writing, phase involves gathering information through research, organizing the information, and composing the first draft.The third, revising, phase, involves editing the message so that the message is clear, conversational, concise and readable, proofreading it, and evaluating it to determine whether the message would achieve the purpose fir which it is intended.Following the above structure, the author then covers the guidelines for writing emails and memos, routine letters and goodwill messages, persuasive and sales messages, delivering bad news, how to write recommendations, how to write informational reports, how to write formal proposals, how to write a business plan and how to write presentations.

In Animal Spirit Guides, the author shares the possible meanings of encountering a specific animal, when you may want to call the animal, and what you may traits the power animal may encourage within you, in terms of your thinking process, emotions, and behavior.In the introduction to the book he shares the tips on how to use the information in this book, how to honor your guides and animals, how you may get the messages from spirit guides (through visual, auditory, kinesthetic or cognitive channels), how to interpret and understand the messages you receive.In the first part of the book, the author covers around 230 different animals. In the second part of the book, you'll find tips on what power animal you may want to call to help you in particular situation.  Here you'll find animals sorted by those that may help you when you need to experience more abundance, or greater self acceptance, or new ideas and possibilities, when you need to take action, or to become more flexible, what animals may help you with different kinds of healing, with creative expression, with learning different things, with expanding awareness of different realities, communication skills, conflict resolution, detachment, releasing suppressed emotions, and this extensive list goes on.This quite resourceful book ends with the Guided Meditation Journey, and additional resources and websites for further exploration.

In the first half of the book the author dedicates on average about a page or two to each of the 27 nakshatras, consisting of the name, meaning, symbol, deity, main stars associated with the nakshatra, and the short description, ranging from few paragraphs to 3 - 4 pages.In the second half of the book the author offers one paragraph summaries of each nakshatra on a separate page .The author draws commentaries from Vedas, Puranas, Brahma Samhita, Vedanta Sutra, Mahabharata, Srimad Bhagavatam.

About half of this booklet has tips for writing an essay in 8 hours, and another half has 20 tips to get better grades.  Whether it takes you 8 hours or more or less may depend on whether you have gathered all the information you need, but the tips themselves are solid, down-to-earth, practical and you're bound to find them helpful.The authors shares tips on how to go about researching the information you need to write the essay, how to plan your essay, how to structure your essay; what to put in the introduction, body, and conclusion of the essay, how to present a balanced argument and how to include quotations and supporting evidence.He also helps with tips on how to cut down the time you write by focusing on what is essential and will score you the most points, and not waste time on minor points.If you're stranded for time, or don't like to read books with lots of fluff, then this book with tips may be all the information you need to get going.

If you have a tendency to remain silent when you need to speak and then when you've had it you speak because you feel angry or hurt, this book can help you to develop the ability to speak up and express yourself appropriately, without being mean.While the book contains examples of "power phrases" your particular situation may demand that you say what you need somewhat differently.  However, you can still use the ideas presented in this book and these power phrases as guidelines.You may look upon these power phrases as a place to begin.  The way some of these phrases are structured may be familiar to you if you have read books dealing with assertiveness, some may inspire you to try something else.Personally I sometimes suffer from the "foot in the mouth" disease, saying things I later find myself wishing I worded differently and this book has helped me to remind myself to stop, focus on the issue, and then consider what may be the most appropriate way to express what I desire to communicate.

If you'd like to learn evolutionary astrology, this book is a great place to begin.The author guides you through learning elements of astrology, just like you would learn to speak a foreign language - first going over the signs, planets, and houses, then aspects and finally putting it all together through interpretation.The difference between "fortune-telling" astrology and evolutionary astrology is that instead of merely using adjectives and telling you that you're like this or like that and that your fate is sealed, in evolutionary astrology your path is open.  It is up to you how you choose the energies expressing through you.  Having better understanding of the interplay of energies within you, you can make better conscious choices which will help you to grow, to evolve, and get the most out of your life.As you read through different elements, you get better insight into what different energies are trying to teach you, what strategies and resources it has available, and how that energy may manifest through it's shadow, when you attempt to repress it.While exploring the energies expressing through you, you learn how to successfully navigate through different areas of your life.

While his youtube videos are decent, this book reads as if it were written at the speed of Light, without anyone checking for spelling, grammatical errors, and whether the sentences made sense in English.  I really wanted to read this book, but I kept on re-reading sentences that made no sense, trying to make sense out of them, and then I wondered how many errors may be hiding which I wouldn't be able to recognize because the information is new to me.That Mercury and Saturn are "neutered", Pisces is spelled as "Piscies", Aquarius as "Aquirus", Sagittarius as "Saggitarious" - may be minor issues, as you can still grasp the meaning.When you read "any planets that comes in his aspect will reap the benefices", or "K.N. Rao in India revived this method, which to this day has about 90-95% accuracy in perdition", you may find yourself re-reading the sentence until your brain comes up with the words that would make more sense in the context and replace "perdition" with "prediction" and "benefices" with the "benefits" (and fix the grammar while you're at it).When you read "If Saturn aspects a planet while sitting in Taurus ascendant", you may wonder what is sitting in Taurus ascendant - Saturn or the other planet.Due to so many errors, when you come upon a chart depicting the "happy" or "sad" placements of the planets in different houses, and the houses are numbered, you may again wonder whether those numbers are correct or do they also contain errors.I'll be happy to re-read this book and review the contents of the book, when the author takes the time to proof-read it.  On youtube he seems passionate about teaching astrology and I hope he shares his passion through his writing in a readable format.  While I may not agree with everything he is teaching (I still find the outer planets - Pluto, Neptune, and Uranus very influential -  while he considers them meaningless), I am still interested in what he has to say.

I had some concerns when I purchased this item, as some reviewers said they hear static noise. I had no such issues. This cordless set has been working very well for me.  I find the sound quality to be good.  It is small, light and super-convenient to carry around.  The item being small, it naturally has very small buttons. I haven't found any comparable products, which is why I purchased it, in spite of the initial concern about static.

The book is very well written, to the point, covering different aspects of crisis negotiation, with stories depicting how different interventions turned out, what was helpful and what seems to escalate the problem - and what would be recommended dialogue and action.Some of the essential skills listed for resolving the crisis are active listening skills, emotion labelling, paraphrasing, asking open-ended questions, reflecting / mirroring, using "I" statements, and minimal encouragers.The author covers suicide interventions, hostage negotiations, dealing with people who are demonstrating abnormal psychology  - antisocial or borderline psychology disorder, schizophrenia, or major depressive episode, as well as those who may be under the influence of drugs or alcohol.

The author compares effective communication with martial arts, particularly judo, and illustrates his points through police stories, which makes the book both useful and interesting to read.Throughout the book are interspersed quotes from Sun-tzu, like "To win one hundred victories in one hundred battles is not the highest skill.  To subdue the enemy without fighting is the highest skill."He distinguishes between 3 kinds of people: the nice, the difficult and the wimp.  The nice people will do what you ask them the first time you ask them.  They like to cooperate.  Difficult people will not do what you tell them the first time you ask.  It is their nature that makes them say "Why? What for?"He adds that the 4 most popular questions Americans would ask are "Why?", "Who do you think you are to tell me what to do?", "Where do you get your authority?", and "What's in it for me?"And wimps are the ones who sound like nice people, but are closet difficult people.  To your face they say "Oh yes," "I agree," "You're right", but later they get you in the back.  Wimps hate authority, but they don't have the guts to challenge you.  They want revenge because they feel the need to even the score.The first principle of physical judo is to not resist your opponent.  Instead, move with him and redirect his energy - and the communication skills presented in the book follow the same pattern.The author mentions 11 things never to say to anyone (some of these statements may be more applicable to policemen on duty): "Come here!", "You wouldn't understand", "Because those are the rules", "It's none of your business", "What do you want me to do about it?", "Calm down!", "What's your problem?" "You never ..." or "You always ...", "Im not going to say thing again", "I'm doing this for your own good", "Why don't you be reasonable?" He does clearly suggest what you may want to say or do instead, and also what you may want to say or do when someone else says those things to you.The bottom line of communication that reduces conflict and tension is empathy - as in standing in another's shoes and understanding where he's coming from - and communicating with the person in a way that he can relate to.  The communication warrior's real service is staying calm in the midst of conflict, deflecting verbal abuse, and offering empathy in the face of antagonism.  If you cannot empathize with people, you don't stand a chance of getting them to listen to you.The author points out that we deal with people "under the influence" nearly everyday.  If it's not alcohol or drugs, it's frustration, fear, impatience, lack of self-worth, defensiveness, and a host of other influences - and that when we react instead of respond to the challenge, we run the risk of giving the greatest speech we'll ever live to regret, by saying the first thing that naturally comes to our lips.Instead, like a samurai, we must first center ourselves - because if we cannot keep a still center, we cannot stay in control of ourselves or the situation.  In this centered state we remain open, flexible, impartial, not biased.To deflect antagonistic behavior, the author shares a selection of "strip phrases", where you let the other person verbally vent, followed by requesting what you need the person to do, as in "'Preciate that, sir, but let me see your license, please."The next technique is "paraphrasing" by saying "Let me be sure I understand you.  Let me be sure we're on the same wavelength." and then stating back what the person said, using his key words - as different words have different meaning to different people.The goal of persuasion and the essence of Verbal Judo is to generate voluntary compliance. To execute it, the author suggests a 5 step process:1. Ask the person what you want him to doIf he doesn't comply2. Set Context by explaining why do you want him to do what you ask of himIf he doesn't comply3. Present Options and point out the consequences of each option, then let him chooseIf he doesn't comply4. Confirm their choice by asking "Is there anything I can say or do at this time to earn your cooperation? I'd sure like to think there is."And if he still doesn't comply5. Act out the consequences of the choice the person madeThe rest of the book teaches specific skills that help you to improve your ability to communicate and persuade. They begin with knowing yourself and the person you're talking to, using the language and the model of the world of the person you're talking to.The author then shares five basic tools to generate voluntary compliance - listen, empathize, ask, paraphrase, and summarize.You will also find examples of steps to solve domestic disputes, how to effectively criticize, how to obtain compliance through praise.The author has provided examples both from police stories and those related to civilian issues.

When I got this book I assumed that it contained suggestions from psychological perspective.  I wish it said on the cover of the book that it is based on the author's interpretation of the teachings of Jesus, which I feel leaves something to be desired.The book contains the mixture of good ideas for setting healthy boundaries mixed with a heavy doses of "it's Satan's fault" or "Satan will make you think this" "this is what Jesus or God meant" when he said such and such and this is what he wants you to do. If you want to know what God wants you to do or what Jesus wants you to do, why not ask God or Jesus or read the Bible and follow in the footsteps of Jesus.In one part of the book she quotes Jesus saying "You should love God with all your heart, mind, body and soul", and again appropriately points out that love is the essence of the Bible.  In the Bible it also says that "who says that he loves God and doesn't love his neighbor (a fellow human beings) is a liar". In another part she quotes Proverbs "Above all else, guard your heart, for everything you do flows from it" - but this time not in the spirit of love which is the essence of the Bible, but in the spirit of fear.  The guarding of heart is from fear and from lack of faith - because he who loves God with all his heart, mind, body and soul, would be filled with love and faith, and would have no fear in his heart.She again quotes what the scripture teaches about love: "Love is patient, love is kind.  It does not envy, it does not boast, it is not proud.  It does not dishonor others, it is not self-seeking, it is not easily angered, it keeps no record of wrongs.  Love does not delight in evil but rejoices with the truth.  It always protects, always trusts, always hopes, always perseveres." So, if you go by the Scripture, if you truly love, love will keep you safe.  It says in the bible that "love fulfills the law" - that is if you love your neighbor as yourself, if you perceive God or Jesus in everyone and everything - would you really put the boundaries between you and them?Again she quotes from the Bible "The Lord our God, the Lord is One.  Love the Lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul and with all your strength" - If the Lord is one - and there is nothing else but God, and one walks with the consciousness, with awareness of that One being all there is, present in everything one beholds and one loves it, what is there one should protect oneself from, other than his own erroneous perception?Along those bits where she claims that it's Satan fault that something happened or that Satan will make you think or do something, she elsewhere writes (appropriately) that you should take responsibility for your life.  And alongside the bits where she is mind-reading and interpreting what God or Jesus meant, in other parts of the book, she (appropriately) says that unless we have walked in someone's shoes, we have no idea where they are coming from.  I would have considered this book more valuable if the author stuck to what she has experienced walking in her shoes as obviously her own challenges with setting boundaries prompted her to learn more about setting healthy boundaries, to practice it and to share some of her experiences.Likewise she quotes from the book "Experiencing God" by Henry Blackbaby "Don't try to second-guess Him (God)" ... God's ways and thoughts are so different from yours ..." This books is full of contradictory ideas - where the author would quote a spiritual idea rooted in love and oneness, and then interpret it from the fear-based-perception which makes it challenging to keep reading the book due to incongruence.Much of this book contains excerpts from the Bible, which the author is attempting to interpret through her eyes, based on her current understanding and experience; and excerpts from the books of other authors related to setting boundaries, like "Living Successfully with Screwed Up People" by Elizabeth Brown, "A Woman's Passionate Pursuit of God" by Karol Ladd, "Boundaries: When to Say Yes, When to Say No To Take Control of Your Life" by Drs. Henry Cloud and John Townsend, "Dealing with the CrazyMakers in Your Life" by Dr. David Hawkins, "Handling Difficult People" by John Townsend, "Being Christian" by Steve Arterburn, "The Hole in Our Gospel" by Richard Stearns, quotes by Dr. Laura Schlessinger, and segments by psychologist Bernis Riley.  The numerous excerpts make you feel as if you're reading a collection of other people's books, rather than the author's book.The essence of this book is the author's six step system for creating healthy boundaries, which in itself is helpful.She calls it Sanity and the six steps are:1. Stop Your Own Negative Behavior and Destructive Patterns2. Assemble a Support Group3. Nip Excuses in the Bud4. Implement Rules and Boundaries5. Trust Your Instincts6. Yield Everything to God

Just reading this book was a soothing experience, as the book not only inspires the practice of patience but also oozes with gentleness and loving kindness.Patience is a skill to be developed and as Easwaran points out it may be hard and uncomfortable in the beginning, but we can all begin just where we are and then keep on stretching and expanding it.This is a small book and perhaps it has more inspiring examples rather than techniques that tell you how to go about practicing patience.  Tips for practicing patience are interspersed throughout the book and if you're looking for more specific techniques then you are more likely to find those in books related to the practice of mindfulness meditation.In this book Easwaran draws upon Indian culture and customs and perhaps it will most appeal to people who do enjoy Easwaran's work and those who love reading stories rooted in Indian culture.

I got this book initially when it came out - almost few decades ago, and I got it now again in digital format.The authors give the overview of nootropics, vitamins and herbal supplements that boost mental performance.  Some of the popular nootropics are varieties of racetams, like piracetam, aniracetam, oxyracetam and pramiracetam, and pyroglutamate or pyroglutamic acid which has similar chemical constitution to piracetam; centrophenoxine, hydergine, deprenyl, vinpocetine.It is important to take racetams with choline and/or lecithin, and it is also important to take anti-oxidants while taking these kinds of brain-boosters.  It becomes somewhat of an art, deciding what you should take when and in what quantity when you start mixing different supplements because they react with each other, and they also react with your own bio-chemistry.Some of these smart drugs require that you take B vitamins, particularly B5.  Vitamins A, C, and E may help to offset the free radicals that are released in the process.The authors mention that centrophenoxine and DMAE have a similar chemical constitution, though I think you may have to try each one of them to discover whether you get the same effect.Among the herbs for brain, the authors mentioned Gingko together with a story that it's the oldest plant on earth and that it almost became extinct but was saved few thousand years ago by Chinese monks, who found it beneficial for the brain.  The authors then mention Fo-ti-tiend and Gotu kola and point that these two have similar chemical constitution.  The authors also mention Royal Jelly and Ginseng, which contribute to the overall wellbeing, being rich in nutrients that help to energize the body and nourish the brain.They also mention the adverse effect of heavy metals on brain function, and how during autopsies of people suffering form Alzheimer's, it was discovered that they had very high amounts of aluminum of their brains.  Think about all the food you may be consuming from cans.  So, taking supplements that help to cleanse your body from heavy metals, may improve your brain function.Some amino acids are mentioned for boosting the brain, like glutamine, and others for detoxifying the body like glutathione, methionine and cysteine.The authors have provided interesting excerpts from different publications and among other things have mentioned how the autopsies showed that the brain tends to shrink and in very old people it would shrink even one third of its normal size.  The smaller space makes it harder for the information to travel, much like the traffic gets stuck on a congested highway.  Brain nutrients and exercise help to keep the brain expanded and functioning well into old age.At the time this book was written most of the nootropics were hard to get, so the authors share helpful information on different channels through which one may acquire them.  These days, most of these supplements are easily available right here on amazon.

This is the first Phillips Sonicare product I've used and I was immediately blown away. Prior to using this product I was using the less expensive battery operated type tooth brush. There is no comparison between the two types. The Phillips Sonicare is much more quiet, less bulky and much more efficient. I could tell the difference immediately when I first used it. My teeth felt so clean. The feeling was similar to the one you have after visiting the dentist and getting the plaque removed. It is just a great addition to your self help needs for maintaining a nice set of teeth and gums. The brushing is characterized by the speed with which the bristles turn. One might think that this might hurt your gums but nothing could be further from the truth. It is vigorous but gentle on your gums. I absolutely love his product and will never go back to the old style, let alone brushing manually; it is just so much more efficient. If you are looking for a new tooth brush definitely buy this one because you won't be let down; it is an outstanding product.

I'll be brief and just say that these are a very nice pair of shoes. There are several things I take into consideration when buying shoes. First and foremost is the fit and comfort; always tricky when ordering online. These shoes passed with flying colors. I normally use a size 11 and this fit true to my size They look narrow and smaller than size 11 but after putting them on they felt super comfy. They immediately felt like a pair of shoes that had been broken in and used for some time. I think the material gives and the support contours to the individual shape of your foot. It passed the first criteria with flying colors. Next I look for style, something that looks good or anyway to my liking. I don't think I would make this an everyday shoe to wear out and about everyday ; that's just my preference as I have many other shoes or boots that I prefer for going out. Instead I have delegated these comfy shoes to the wear around the house indoors; almost like a slipper but more versatile for that unexpected outdoor venture. I also have another use for them which is a driving shoe. They are perfect for getting into the classic 56 Chevy and going for a spin on a sunny afternoon. The heel is contoured perfectly so it is padded and supports your foot when in the driving position. They are classy looking for a casual shoe and think you will be pleased with these shoes as an addition to your collection of shoes. I have not walked extensively in them so I cannot attest to the comfort or support after miles of walking. However for use as I've described they are perfect. They are  a very lightweight and good looking shoe that I think you would be pleased with. I recommend these shoes for your feet; you'll hardly know you have shoes on.

I ordered this product through the Vine Program and was a little skeptical about whether it would actually do the job as described. My yard has mulch  everywhere in controlled path ways and around certain trees. Besides this I have made several other pathways made from stone and small pebbles or lava rock. Every year there is a problem with rain washing the mulch or stones away where I need to place them in the proper area again. High winds create the same problem this product was applied during the holidays and since it has rained and we.ve had high Santa Ana winds. So far so good. The Mulchlock has been a blessing as after application I have not needed to moved the mulch or stones back into place. Granted it hasn't been very long so we'll see how it holds up through summer when high winds return again . I felt it was relatively easy to apply and the adjustable spray was very convenient for not wasting the spay. The opaque color is really barely noticeable and looks pretty natural. If you're looking for something to contain your landscape this product will do the trick. I recommend this for making your life easier and having time to use that hammock instead of raking your mulch back into place or resetting your pebble pathway. It works so go for it.

I'm not one to use creams but was afforded the opportunity to try out this product through the Amazon Vine program. I tried it out but honestly couldn't get into the discipline of applying the cream regularly. I did like the feel of it and the resulting feeling on my skin. I gave this cream to my wife to use and she raves about it. She loves the texture and non sticky feeling on the skin. It is absorbed readily, especially if your skin is dry. If I would have continued using it no doubt it would probably be gone by now with my alligator skin! The product is made from  natural ingredients mostly so it is very nice to the touch. The cream is very nice smelling and according to my wife the smell is divine. It does smell very nice I might add. It is non greasy which is a plus. She loves it so I love it. If it makes her happy it makes my life easier. Get this product for your wife and you can be a happy camper too. Recommended for help with dry skin.

If you are a fan of the Robert Rodriguez's "Mariachi" Trilogy films than you will love this disc. It is not just for fans of "Mariachi" the film but for anyone that loves genre bending Spanish guitar or just cool Spanish music. Most of the guitar work is original and electrifying with a frenetic pace. It is cutting edge flamenco inspired if anything, but not Mariachi music. This is not, let me say it again, this is not Mariachi music by any means. I have a library full of music that is Mariachi and believe me this is not Mariachi de Tecalitlan El Mejor Mariachi Del Mundo or anything like it. The song by Chingon, love the name which also happens to be the name of my favorite breakfast sandwich up the coast in Carlsbad at Mas Fina Cantina, " Malaguena Salerosa" is a case in point. It is a hot number reinterpreted on an old Spanish theme. All the music is amazing, conjuring images of Rodriguez's film and old Mexico. As the title says it is music from the movie and inspired from Rodriquez's trilogy, El Mariachi, who was a character, the main protagonist.  The DVD is also very good and informative but unfortunately ii is much too short. I really did like the DVD but I would have just liked more behind the scenes and more footage of the concerts. All in all it is a disc worth adding to your library, just don't file it under Mariachi music, unless you have a sub category for film than it would be El Mariachi. Did I say this is not Mariachi music? This is a highly entertaining CD/DVD combo and worth having, como se dice en Mexico, vale la pena.

First off understand where I'm coming from. I'm not really big into hip hop although I have accumulated various artists and songs into my library over the years. That said I really liked this disc; you might even say I love it/ her voice. She commands attention with authority. Being a bilingual person I do understand and am fluent in Spanish. However, hip hop is a language unto itself that requires good listening skills to keep up with the rapid- fire rap. So do I get all her lyrics? Si y no/yes and no. Honestly some of it goes over my head but that doesn't matter as the music is way cool. I first heard Ana Tijoux while watching an episode of "Breaking Bad" and thought who is that? The song was so catchy and cool I had to find out. Thanks to my fave music app, Shazam, I found out immediately and almost as quickly ordered the disc through Amazon. I was blown away with the talent and diversity of her style. Like a good sauce she is both sweet and spicy, angry and seductive resulting in the best of both; yin and yang if you will. Her accompanying musicians and rappers compliment her quite well. The reggae beat on some tracks is infectious adding to her world beat charms. On "Oulala" she raps in French and I get don't understand but it doesn't matter because it's the universal language of music; good music that traverses boundaries and language barriers for a memorable musical experience.  This makes her at least trilingual as she raps in English as well. The Chilean artist born in France to parents who were exiles from the Pinochet regime might explain her unique view of the world. She incorporates a variety of musical styles and uses the production values of incorporating the use of various elements of electronic mixing of beats and voices. Her music is mixture of jazzy world beat styles, combining elements of R&B into the musical stew that doesn't shy away from political themes. Ana Tijoux music is interlaced with intricate rhymes that pull you in and won't let go until the song is over; then another song begins demanding more and once she has her musical tentacles in you you're in for the duration. I bought this album because I fell in love with the song "1977" on "Breaking Bad." I recently found out that it is a album that you can add to your library if you are a Prime Member at Amazon. If you are go for it. I recently added another disc of hers to my Prime Library and look forward to giving it some attention. If you're looking for something different to listen to, whether you speak Spanish or not, than this disc will not disappoint; she is fresh and deserves attention. Buy it , you'll like it; you may even love it like me.

George Benson has one of the most unique voices in his own right that incorporates smooth jazz vocals  and scat singing; all while playing Wes Montgomeryesque guitar. On this jazz based album he all but abandons his own particular style to channel the sweetness of the late, great, Nat King Cole. On many songs he sounds very much like the velvet, smooth voice of Nat King Cole but with a twist at times; he performs his scat vocals to give some songs his own interpretation while his vocals remain true to NKC. This is more than a tribute CD. It goes above and beyond tribute. There are times while listening to this disc that I would swear it was NKC singing if I didn't know better.The familiar songs are all well done and to numerous to mention individually. Some of my favorites and standouts from this disc are the classic "Route 66"  and "Straighten Up and Fly right" from the lesser known jazz period of Nat King Cole. If you like these songs you might check out songs from his trio period The Best of the Nat King Cole Trio: The Vocal Classics (1942-46),  BTW, there are many good NKC discs available covering all periods of his career. For an overview you may want to start with  The Very Best Of Nat King Cole. "Nature Boy" is another easy choice as this song has been interpreted by George Benson before. It is a song that warms the heart with the message of love. Several of his more well known songs like "Unforgettable" and "Mona Lisa" are here but with a twist; the George Benson twist. On the signature NKC song "Unforgettable" Benson pairs with jazz giant Wynton Marsalis to create a very outstanding rendition. "Mona Lisa" closes out the disc with Benson playing guitar that has a Latin flavor while he invokes his inner NKC and belts out a beautiful version accompanied by a lush string arrangement. This is truly a tribute disc; it is evident that Benson honors the tradition established by NKC and wants to honor it. If you're a fan of either artist you will really enjoy this disc. Recommended for nostalgic day or nights where timeless music permeates the air, for a truly "Unforgettable" musical experience.

I love the different taste of these energy bars. There is a flood of bars available on the market usually with one thing in common. Much of what is available is bland tasting to overly sweet, with a consistency and taste of gooey straw. Thankfully there is a product available that breaks the mold and after one bite makes you go MmmMmm that's tasty and much different than your average bar. The mix of sweet and hot, an old concept for food but maybe new to energy bars, is absolutely delicious. The heat is not overbearing but rather blended beautifully. You take a bite and you want another bite and then another, all the while trying to distinguish what is the spicy taste that beautifully off balances the  traditional sweet taste. One problem, the bar quickly disappears; a couple of nice sized bits and it's gone. After the initial tasting of this bar I had to have another. The bars are small and not filling at all. The nuts give the bar a nice crunch and texture that compliments the spice and sweet taste. They are perfect for a snack on the go or for that snack between meals that probably will suffice for a meal until you can have something more filling. I have tucked these into my jersey while out cycling and they are great for a bite and quick energy when you're pounding the pedals. I imagine they are good for any endurance event when you don't have the time or means to feed your body. The real selling factor is the delicious taste combination, sweet and spicy that makes you go MmmMmm, so different and so good. Recommended for those like a little spice with their sweetness.

This is a good addition for your grooming needs. If you or your man is like me it is always good to have a variety of tools to tame the facial hair. The size of the scissors and comb might be of concern to some men. I'm average size with large hands and my fingers barely fit into the small area designed for the thumb and finger. If you are a big man or you're buying for someone who is you might take this fact into consideration. Extra large fingers or fat fingers will fit uncomfortably. Otherwise this is a nice compact set designed for home or travel. The scissors are very sharp and cut the hair with precision. Nothing worse than dull scissors that pull your hair or worse yet don't cut at all. These are precision scissors that should give years of use with proper care. The comb is a little cheesy as it is very small; I guess that is the desired design for the mustache. Personally I prefer I larger comb when grooming the facial hair. Although it is sold as a mustache set I found that it works perfectly well with my beard. I've used it for fine tuning after trimming my beard with an electric trimmer with a length attachment. All in all this is a nice set to have in your army of facial hair grooming tools. Recommended for fans of Movember or  the bearded one's.

I'll keep this review simple and leave the spec and other details to those so inclined. I've had mine for about six months and find it to be outstanding. It is light, nice looking and extremely practical. I love the ability to fold it and have it set up to allow you to view the screen in different upright positions. It is the perfect protection for my tablet with sleek simple style. If you have a Verizon tablet this works perfectly. Highly recommended for your tablet protection and viewing pleasure.

I love traditional Christmas music nut also have room in my musical tastes for variations on a theme. This disc is anything but traditional. It is very cool collection of songs, some traditional mostly not that are either old school jazzy or rhythm and blues. With songs entitled "Be Bop Santa Claus,"  "Christmas Night in Harlem," " Dig that Crazy Santa Claus," and other off beat titles, well. you get the picture, this might not be for everyone. You won't find " I'm Dreaming of a White Christmas" on this disc. This is music from a by gone era, even before my time. Good music withstands the test of time. There is lots of scat singing and horn blowing where even the most recognized songs are so different that it is hard to equate the two. My absolute favorite song on this disc is" Zat You, Santa Claus"? by Louis Armstrong. It is a classic. If you've never heard this song it is worth a listen. Highly recommended for a change of pace when it comes to Christmas music.

I love this app for getting news paper accounts from different sources. I have this on my tablet and phone but noticed the Kindle app is different. There are not as many newspapers, otherwise it is good. For that reason I give it 4 rather than 5 stars.

If you like to keep up with events across the USA and  globe than this an app for you. You can watch whatever you like on your TV and have this on your device nearby to catch up on events or topics , For example, last night when The Ferguson Grand Jury decision was announced I was able to check out what was going on while continuing to watch a movie. The same features you've come to enjoy on CNN at home is now available on the go. Recommended for people that want their news everywhere and whenever,

I have this app on all my devices and my Kindle is no exception. I was very pleased to get this app as sometimes some apps are not compatible with the Kindle. If you love sports on the go than you need this app. One of the things I like about it that I get more ESPN channels than I get on my TV. This is especially cool because I can watch soccer matches, college football etc. When their is a conflict with simultaneous programming this app is perfect to watch several games at once. Overall it is outstanding for the sports enthusiast. I don't know how I managed to keep up with all my sports. Get it, it's a great app!

There are almost two thousand reviews of this product currently as of this review. Basically it has all been said both positive and negative so there is not much to say that hasn't been said already, there are even video demos. That said I will keep it simple. I am not one to use a French Press with regularity. It is more of a treat for me. I've used this French Press on several occasions for both tea and coffee and found it produces a rich tasting cup of hot brew. It is easy to use, simple in fact. I was recently involved in an accident and even while going through rehabilitation I managed to use it, in spite of the nerve damage in my hand. The quality of material used is top notch. The protective design serves it's purpose and looks good to. I have had other French Press's throughout the years of lesser quality and invariably something happens, usually the glass breaking or screen tearing. I don't think this will be the case with this product as it seems durable so far. As I said I don't usually use a French Press so with proper care this product should provide years of lasting enjoyment. If you're looking for a French Press that is a quality product I would recommend this one by Idylc Homes. I definitely would recommend this French Press for the novice or connoisseur coffee lover. This would make a great gift for anyone who appreciates a good cup of coffee or tea.

Like many others I liked The Shadow of the Wind more than this, the second book in the series. This is not to say that I was disappointed in any way as I was not expecting a better book, but rather a book that compels and demands my attention as the first book did. I liked it very much for all the same reasons as Shadow. The intriguing, beautifully written imagery, Barcelona in a different time and place returned to darkness and characters reborn with a running theme of a story within a story, a book within a book coming to life from the Cemetery of Forgotten Books for a mysterious epic journey. The writing is magical and as a reader I got lost in the language easily. This in turn created a problem for me because it seems the more I read and enjoyed the book, again lost in the language, the less I seemed to understand. This is not the case as I was reading but rather after a reading session, I would say to myself, what the heck just happened? It is as though I had been transported, as a reader, to within a world of awe or quite possibly awakening from a dream and asking myself if it was real or a dream ? I thoroughly enjoy Zafron's use of language and look forward to reading the final installment in the series which I recently began. Undoubtedly  many answers will be revealed that were left unanswered in this book.  Recommended for anyone that enjoys mysterious, dark  Gothic places in a superb writing style.

If you like music that transcends boundaries , both musically and internationally than this disc is for you. Italian Daniele Gaudi or as he is known,  Gaudi is a man on a mission. A musician ,songwriter,  singer, Record Producer and composer formerly known as the  Dub Alchemist for good reason . He incorporates Dub into his world music with elements of electronica, break beat  and reggae. Although using those labels to describe the music would be a simplification, his music is simply, quite profound. The titles alone make statements of profundity, like the song does on  "And the Earth Said: Oh My God!." The experimental results are breathtaking mysterious sojourns around the planet, to inner and outer space and back. I personally prefer the songs that have a little more structure but he is the Mad Master Moog, as he was once known. The spacey  tune  in " Chant Thermique"  starts out slowly, droning along and turns to silence, then suddenly MLK's famous speech " I Have a Dream" comes through for a startling effect. "Ayahuasca Deep Fall" has a Indian vibe, complete with Earthy beats and chants that is happiness in a groove. "Theremystical"  begins with a man giving a lecture on an instrument that plays without even touching. It to develops into a dance groove where the lecture voice returns off and on during the duration just to be sure you're paying attention. Gaudi returns to his roots in a song entitles "Dub It' which is pretty basic Dub music. One of my favorite songs is when Gaudi pairs with the Spanish group Ojos de Brujo on the song made famous by them entitled "Babylon Flamenco." The song remains recognizable to the original but is reworked by Gaudi, for a remix of sorts. This is a magical release that belongs in your musical library, especially if you like world music that is innovative. I would definitely recommend this disc. He has released many CD's but this is as good as any place to jump in. Actually I'm quite surprised it has never been reviewed here at Amazon as it is widely considered one of his best. Recommended for adventurous listeners of world groove music without boundaries or limitations, file under, Electronica all over the map, where the  globe is just the beginning.

This disc is a mixture of flamenco fusion and pure Flamenco, depending on the artist featured. The disc is a good bargain as you get plenty of music for the price. There are 18 diverse tracks with all different artists which makes for an excellent disc with a lot of variety. The commonality is Flamenco in all it's various forms. There is up tempo, as in the song "Almeria", where it hits a light dance groove and down tempo fusion like "Sangre Andaluza" where you get a short dreamy visit to Spain. "Morning" is a track that lies somewhere between down and up tempo.  the track features soft female voices that creates an otherworldly result. "En Mis Suenos,"or "In My Dreams", in English, is a very cool jazzy, Flamenco mix that transcends a pigeon hole description other than to say it is good vibes. Artist David Amaya displays the pure Flamenco guitar and vocals on "Cancherito" that is a knock out tune complete with handclaps and sorrowful singing. This song will stimulate the imagination to see dancing gitanos or gypsy's by the fire or in a caf. This is a nice disc to play at night , enjoy a glass of Tempranillo , maybe with someone, and let the mind wander. The music on this disc can be pure but it is mostly a hybrid or fusion of Flamenco. Recommended for those that would like an auditory journey to the Iberian peninsula via the Flamenco Fusion.

Being a long time fan of Bob Marley I take great pride in listening to his offspring carry on the tradition. I had the pleasure of seeing Bob Marley live in a small amphitheater in San Diego many moons ago. I have seen Ziggy several ties throughout the years. I now want to see Stephen Marley. I love his music, it is an evolution of his roots, maintaining the past allowing for creative liberty to integrate the contemporary vibes all around us. When I close my eyes I hear Bob Marley. Both Ziggy and Stephen sound remarkably like their father. As the saying, goes the apple does not fall from the tree. The pure essence of Bob Marley's vibe comes through loud and clear. I can visualize him with eyes closed, arms stretched out over his head imparting his spirit on the talents of his sons, creating a lasing message going beyond his years in the flesh. I play this CD over and over, anytime of the day or night, it just makes you feel good. It takes me back, I go fast forward to the present and smile. It's the Rastaman Vibration again, he live on. Get this disc, it is a new Rastaman Vibration for a new generation.

If a little blood and guts details depicted during an era where the government of Argentina made this the norm than move on, this book is not for you. If on the other hand, you can tolerate scenes that involve massacres of groups and slaughter of individuals, set in a time capsule during one of Argentina's darkest periods, where violations of human rights was as ordinary as having a cup of mate, than read this French author's noir thriller. Strange characters are revealed early on, living in he underworld of Buenos Aires, where freaks run the risk of ultimate savagery and even death. Missing persons and even missing  families is a way of life where the government and it's cronies have taken liberty to do as they please, leaving atrocities in the aftermath. Enter Jana a Mapuche  Indian who pairs with  private investigator Calderon to find out what happened to Jana's best friend Miguel, who is in reality a transvestite prostitute known as Paula. The search for Paula leads Calderon and Jana on a dangerous path seeking justice. The book is a grisly thriller, full of mystery and intrigue set to the historical background of Argentina's time of los desaparecidos, the missing ones. This is an excellent read that will have you turning the pages, looking for answers and what answers the sleuths will uncover in their adventure to find Paula. Recommended for those interested in Latin American history and politics, specifically Argentina's, and a good dark mystery.

This is a short disc consisting of only five songs. The songs are probably familiar to those that already are aware of the fine music of Chambao. The difference with this is that the familiar songs are acoustic. The song "Chambao," which if it wasn't cool enough in it's original form is even more  down tempo and even more chill.
