Both assume that Scripture contains no errors and that predictive prophecy is possible. Further, that prophecy in Scripture is accurate, not imaginary.Is it an easy read? No. This is a primarily academic book. Theres no fluffy moments or pictures, and there is a need for a basic grasp of Biblical interpretations principles.If youre into the quick-pop prophecy, trying to line up current events and popular figures with Biblical passages, then this wont help you with that. In fact, it will probably knock that idea flat. Which would be healthy.I heartily recommend this for pastors and those interested in deeper study in the prophecy sections of the Bible. The authors have done a good job explaining the presuppositions and viewpoints so that the reader knows their angle, and then presenting additional ideas beyond their own. I do not agree with some of their conclusions, but their process is helpful.I received a copy of this book in exchange for the review.

Works on our 3 indoor/outdoor cats.We did not have a flea problem before we started using the PetArmor brand, but we also have not seen the fleas or ticks come in. It is possible for cats to have a severe reaction to the medication here, so watch for that.Otherwise, the cats are generally irritated at the inconvenience of being medicated. But they get over it.

1. It is exactly as described: 4 outlets, 2 USB ports. It has a 3 ft cord. That's about 6 inches shorter than I really needed on my desk, but I'll cope.2. The cord is thick, but that tells me well-insulated. (Hopefully I'm not wrong.)3. The safety on the outlets is fine.4. 4 outlets are enough, as my old 6-outlet had two slots taken up with USB adapters.5. Here's the main drawback: USB charging is slow compared to my Kindle charger, for example. And it's hard to nail down the stats---this points out it is a "2.1A" while the Kindle charger is "9 Watts." Those two metrics don't compare, so it's hard to know why the Woods item is so much slower. But charging a Kindle from dead, a Galaxy S5 Active from 20%, both take about twice as long here as with the Kindle 9W charager.So do with that what you will--there may be some devices (Fire TVStick, for example) that need a higher amperage than this. But otherwise it's fine.

Useful? Yes.Necessary? Probably not.However: for those starting in 9th grade and wanting to make sure they don't miss major opportunities for college prep, this pocket guide has some good pointers. I would DEFINITELY recommend this (or something similar, but I don't know of anything this concise) as an option for homeschoolers who won't have a guidance counselor or school announcements to remind you about tests and scholarships.The information is organized by grade, and is in a handy checklist format. It's also not overly wordy. You'll need to do additional research on the ideas, tests, and scholarships presented. But this will give you an organized starting point.

These towels:1. Absorbent. What's the point of a towel that doesn't absorb?2. Frayed a bit in the laundry. Apparently, not intended for a whole lot of washing.3. Colorfastness holds up well.4. Feel and seem durable in use. Strange, that they haven't fallen apart in use, but don't seem to hold as well in the washing machine.Are they worth it? They're not bad. And they do dry well. Just don't seem to have a long-lasting life.

Ignorance is bliss.Unless you're trying to figure out what to do with this beanpot. What do I mean?Included in the box: 1 Bean pot. 1 Recipe book.NOT included? Use/care guide. After looking it up on the manufacturer website, I see the Q/A warns that it's oven safe to 325 degrees. For a pot that is supposed to be stove top and oven safe, something in the box that warned of a limit of 325 degree would have been good. Also, the box points out that it's safe to use on an induction cooktop. My induction burner? There's nothing about it that will work with clay. It just sits there. Perfectly safe. Perfectly useless.Now, having sought out some guidelines on how to use a beanpot, I'm pleased with this one. It cleans easily, holds heat well. I like it.Is it worth putting in your kitchen? I think so, it's useful for beans as well as some casseroles and soups. Plus, it looks like a cauldron so you can fill it with candy at Halloween. :)

My college minor was speech, and I work where I make public presentations on a weekly basis. So I'm no stranger to speaking in public.Michael Port's work in "Steal the Show" is especially helpful for learning how to get started in presenting public presentations. While he does addresses material presentation, I would suggest that you will want additional guidance on doing the research and writing for your presentation, then apply the principles of Steal the Show as you edit and prepare the public side.Port has taken some of the principles of good acting and applies them here to "everyday life" situations of speaking and presenting. I think he's chosen some good material, especially about developing an aura of certainty in your work.I also find valuable the guidance about knowing what you want, generally, and how your speaking opportunities attempt to fill that in by filling in the small blocks.All in, is it worth it? I think so. There's a good amount of practical material here and you will benefit from it.

Comfy.Durable.What else do you need to know?1. The color has held up to being worn, washed, worn, washed.2. Size is true to what you would expect.3. Length is good for me.4. Pockets have good depth? Does that matter? I suppose...

Make sure your printer can handle the smaller paper size. The stickers on half-sheet size pages, not full-sheet size.That was problematic on the first printer I tried these on, but switching from my Canon to my Epson solved it. (Note: I was, most likely, just doing something wrong on my printer.)Now, these are a great size for attaching to candies like: individual Reese's Peanut Butter Cups; Dove chocolates; The mid-size York Peppermint patties.I do NOT recommend trying to put these on M&Ms. They're too big for even the Peanut M&M's--plus the candy coating sticks really bad. ;)Overall, great for that "extra touch" for a special celebration.

The NIV Zondervan Study Bible, the hardcover of which looks like the picture, is a replacement product for the NIV Study Bible that I had in college. At the moment, its available in hardcover. For those who arent interested in reading it as a Bible, it therefore works well to break your toes when you drop it. This thing is heavynearly 3000 pages.Without dwelling on the New International Version as a translation (Im not a big fan of the 2011 revision of the NIV), let us take the features under consideration first. On the surface, an obvious helpful feature is full-color printing throughout the Study Bible. This not only allows pictures throughout, which is a great, but allows something else nice. The study note section is shaded in light tan while the Biblical text is on white paper.The inspired text is therefore clearly separated from the ideas of the note writers. I like that. A lot. The note authorsa smorgasbord of evangelical scholars from the US and the UKgenerally hold to a high view of Scripture. They come from a range of the evangelical world, from Baptists to Presbyterians and a few more.I will not claim to have evaluated every note throughout the text, but I have yet to find one that is problematic. Passages that have major theological disputes about them (like Hebrews 6) follow the normal Study Bible pattern of providing most of the main views. Thats not a bad thing.Further, each book is given a full introduction, addressing authorship, date, etc., the basics that are typically covered in an Intro type class. Overall, the information helps one study the Scriptures better.If you are in the market for a study Bible, this one would make a good purchase. Id prefer the notes and content coupled with the New American Standard, but the notes are worth it as a reference Bible. And, it is too bulky for taking it everywhereId go for it on the shelf.The purchase of the hardcover does gain free digital access through the Olive Tree Bible App. Im still getting used to the app, so I wont comment on how well it works. Its better than nothing, but theres always a learning curve with such things.I did receive a free Bible for my review.

We had the opportunity to snack these bars down during a hospital wait, so they were meal replacements.1. A bit on the sweet side for the taste. Probably to cut back against the tartness of the fruit.2. Good crunch while still being chewy and edible.3. Nutritionally, pretty good. Obviously, not what you want to eat a complete diet of, but for a day where "lunch" is something you catch between and betwixt, well worth it.4. While these weren't filling, they were adequate for several hours.5. Held up well in travel.I'll be keeping a few of these on hand for travel days. They are healthier than candy bars, and just sweet enough to avoid the candy bars.

First of all, it's a cute box. While it's not as sturdy as a plastic file crate, it's better looking.Now, onwards:1. Fits in a file drawer. This is true and helpful. You can organize files into boxes rather than using hanging file folders and arrange the boxes in file drawers Then just pull out the boxes you need.2. Sits on a shelf. I wouldn't do this for too long as cardboard is, well, cardboard, but you can organize these onto a shelf for the same purpose--plus being labeled on 4 sides is helpful.3. It has a single divider that helps keep files standing up.Beyond that? Well, that's about it. It's a box that holds file folders. It's prettier than a plain box. It would work for some sizes of magazine as well. It's handy, if a bit pricey.

We have real, simple bows that the kids use in the backyard. We have the NERF bow that shoots regular NERFs. Our family is no stranger to pull-back the string and let if fly equipment.But for some reason, we can't get the arrows on this bow to go more than about 30 feet. It just doesn't quite fit right, maybe, in the hand. We have lucked up and gotten a good launch off, but there's just been no consistency to the results.The spinning quiver is kind of a neat idea, but I also don't see it working out with the high-speed that is suggested. Overall, it's just not working out for uus.

This is my first "non-major" brand smartphone, though I did carry a torch for Blackberry far too long into the modern era. By the time I went to Motorola and Samsung, the old Berry was "non-major," too.So, how does the BLU stack up?1. Call quality. This matters most, because IT'S STILL A PHONE! I live just outside of Little Rock, AR, and it works fine out here. I have no dead spaces that my Samsung didn't have. Certainly the BLU didn't work well in the storm shelter, but...and since this is a phone first, that matters most. Does it work? It did, on AT&T.2. Interface. Let's be honest: it's not the most interesting interface, nor has there been a lot of pre-setup with it. I'm okay with that, and it's working fine.3. Included apps: I'm still looking, but I'm not finding much in the way of bloatware. (Let's not talk about how much bloatware AT&T puts on a branded phone....ok, let's: too dang much.)4. Battery life: yes, it really does last a long time. As in 3 days of "normal" use for me: a few calls here and there, keeping up with data via WiFi, and a round of World Golf Tour a day.5. Screen: huge. Just huge. And responsive.6. Durability: well, it held up decently with the "knock-it-off-the-desk" test. But I decline to intentionally give it the "dropped in the street" test.7. The camera isn't great, but I'm a lousy cameraman anyway. Plus, there was something not right with my previous phone's camera, so it's no worse.In all, if you're looking for a backup phone or want to try something different, this one's a good test. Beats paying 4 times as much for a brand name.

1. I love the ink system, and so far it's worked quite well. Looking at Epson's website, looks like refill ink will be inexpensive. We've got a bit of a shift from the "cheap printer, we'll make money on ink" mindset.2. I'm not a fan of having to use a cable to set up a wireless printer. If you have to use the USB to set it up, then it's not wireless. Now, I know the "WPS" setup should work, but I couldn't get it to do so. So, I had to move the printer over to computer and plug it in to start with. Now, it's fine. (Plus, those cables aren't that expensive. Throw one in the box.)3. On that note, I know 6 buttons and 3 lights is a simple interface, but I've gotten used to knowing a little more from the printer itself.4. I'd like to have a paper tray instead of a load-from-the-back only printer. It takes up a little less space on the desk that way.5. But the ink should last a long time, and that's a big deal.6. Additionally, now that it's set up, I can print from both PCs and my cell phone. That's very helpful.7. Be careful after you've got it set up and primed. You have liquid ink at one end of this thing, and the "seal" isn't much for holding back the ink spills. And woe be unto you if you mix up the colors. Get too much Cyan in the Magenta, and your next call is for a new printer.In all, I think I'd aim for the next model for the front-dash controls, but this one is working as promised. Just be careful filling the ink...that stuff stains.

I'm not sure quite what to say about the file frame.It holds files as it claims, it holds them well. It assembled easily, but I'll admit to not paying a lot of attention to the directions.Additionally, it does fit well in a normal file-size drawer, but I'm finding it much more useful in a rolling crate that didn't come with hanging file angles, so that's providing a great deal of support and structure.I like it, but I'm just not sure of its universal usefulness.

Soft and absorbent. I think the price premium is for the eco-friendly nature of the recycled cotton.As to how they work: absorbency is fine, which is the main thing you need in a towel, right?Then there's the bath mat, which is pretty good at staying where you put it on the bathroom floor.Wash cloth is fine, all in all the set cleans easily and works well.

I did not know what to expect with The Letter for the King, so I can't go with "exceeds expectations."I will instead go with: a book that needs to be read by many. Recognizing that this is a work of both translation and authorship, I'll be commenting on the book as one work. Why? I don't read the original language--or even know it---so I can't say if the translating was "perfect." I can say this: the writing is excellent.The story opens with the classic conflict of the duty of rule-keeping with the duty of honor-keeping. Young Tiuri must choose between those rival responsibilities, and then take the consequences.What are those consequences? A journey of adventure, danger, and peril. A journey that offers no certainty of reward nor success, yet one that must be undertaken.How will Tiuri respond?The pacing of the story is not nearly as fast as many modern books. That increases the appeal for me as I pass it to my son to read. I think it will help stretch the long-horizon attention span. The chapters are short enough to read on and off throughout the day, but the story stretches the memory and the reading skills.The moral of the story, and the morals of the story, encapsulate lessons that need to be learned and practiced. I was more than impressed with Dragt's work and look forward to more

Some books I read for learning. Some I read because Im assigned or offered reviews. Some, though, I just happily snag for free because it saves me the money of buying them. These are the fun reads, the ones I would like to spend far more time on than I have the chance to.Oswald: The Return of the King by Edoardo Albert falls into this last category. I first met Alberts writing in Edwin: High King of Britain and have since greatly enjoyed his non-fiction related works on early Britain. I guess one could say I am a fan.Oswald follows on the heels of Edwin, as Britain remains in the turmoil of the post Roman Era. Its an imaginative tale, obviously not entirely historically accurate. After all, there arent exactly newspapers from the time laying around to be read.Still, Albert spins the tale well. The characters become people you actually care about, even though you recognize the reality of the environment. And that reality? People are going to die. Its a bloody time, a violent timeand a time of all sorts of other perils.The tale of Oswin and his choice between the monastery and the throne is not one most people are familiar with. It likely reflects the choice several people faced throughout the years of the Dark and Medieval Ages.Albert not only provides a gripping story for the reader, but he also presents several helps. The first is a list of characters so that the reader can keep them straight. Second is a detailed historical note providing the facts behind the story.Overall, this story doesnt make a family-friendly movie, but it is a fascinating piece of history. Its also an engaging read for those who want to know more about a generally overlooked time frame.Is it worth the reading? I would recommend Edwin first, just to set the stage, but yes. Its also well-worth having a copy around.I received a copy of this book in exchange for the review.

What is an Evangelical Christian? Other than Not a Catholic or an Episcopalian, that is?Trying to nail that answer down first, and then examining the history of what fits with Evangelical Christianity is the opening challenge of this book. After that, Evangelicals around the World addresses the global spread of this sector of Christianity. In short, there is no small task here, even for 400+ pages of densely spaced writing.Before we talk too much about content, let me make this observation: this book is nicely printed. Its full-color throughout, enabling the illustrations, maps, and graphs to pop out well. It also features footnotes! Academic-type works are harmed by endnotes, so I love to see footnotes.Now, to content: the work opens with 200 events in history that illustrate the depth and breadth of Evangelicalism. This is followed by an attempt to define evangelical in broad enough terms to include many groups while still showing a restriction to its meaning. This chapter does well in the attempt, and I will not reproduce it here. The authors did well by using both what it is and what it isnt to line out the definition.From there, we see a development of Evangelical interaction with other Christian groups. One could take issue with which groups are counted as Christianscertainly some Evangelicals wouldbut the authors are mainly working on mainstream views here.Then we see summaries of doctrines that Evangelicals agree on, with good notations on what range of opinions exists even in these areas. Rightly, the defining characteristics are the belief that the Bible is true and Jesus sent us to carry the message. How that bounds out is where there is much discussion!Finally, the book wraps with a region-by-region look at international Christianity. This section serves as a helpful introduction, though international situations can be so fluid that some of this data will be obsolete soon. Still, the snapshot of where things stand right NOW is a valuable reminder that America is not the center of the Christian world.In all, I think this is a valuable book on current church status and an encouragement that the Gospel keeps going forth. Its not the first book you should read every day, but if your church wants to learn where things are, its a good help and start. I would also commend it to homeschoolers to couple, as a reference, with geographylearn about the church in each area as well.Free book from Booklook Bloggers.

Very effective at keeping drinks cold. It's also very good about not sweating and getting moisture everywhere.Other good: slightly textured grip surface. This just feels better in the hand than a straight-up cup usually does. Also, even with the metal inner surface, this does NOT leave a drink with a metallic taste.I would side with the reviewer who suggests the base-ring could be better executed. I know it helps with stacking, but it's a bit uneven and so makes me nervous about tipping the glass over. Otherwise, though, I'm a fan.

First, cost: these are about in line with where I've seen most K-cups lately. Some are less expensive, but not by much.Second, flavor: this splits in two directions.Flavored coffees: great flavors. I'm really fond of the Vanilla Dream. The Choconut is good as well, but I'm not a huge coconut fan. So, it tastes like it should, which is good if you like it. Smooth tastes, easy to drink.The coffee-flavored-coffees: these are not bitter (or at least, not more bitter than they ought to be). They're right in line with the expectation, and yes "Da Bomb" kept me awake. Longer than I wanted it to. But there's nothing particularly awesome about these. They're right about average.As a different provider, it's fine. But I wouldn't pay extra for this over some other brand. Although I would snag a box of Vanilla Dream.

Honestly, I didn't quite know what to expect with The Theater of War. By the time I was done, I felt almost guilty for peeking into some of the personal moments that were shared by Doerries in this work.First, a look at what we have here: Doerries stages 'readings' of Classical Greek plays for veterans groups and other specific groups like those facing terminal illness. From that point he leads discussions about how the plays inform or address the issues being dealt with by those groups.Second, a look at the impact: this book probably has the most raw emotion I've read in a long, long time. We see people finally finding the vocabulary to express what they feel, to address what they face. It's powerful.It's powerful to see how the ancient world can inform the modern one. One of the best lessons in here is that one can address the difficulties of war separate from the politics of getting into it in the first place.Doerries' work reminds me that there is wisdom for now found in the old words.

As much as I disliked the Trapper Keepers of this year's line, I really liked this binder/file folder system. It's been swiped by my high school student to organize her writing class with a major project, but before she took it, I noticed:1. Closure is secure. It clips, it holds.2. Stout 3-ring binder. I wouldn't jam the "380 sheets" in it, but I buy that as capacity.3. Included file organization, like a filing cabinet. Small enough to carry with you, it helps with organizing various papers for projects.4. Outer pocket for electronic device or small books...it's carrying a Kindle Keyboard now.5. Small pocket for pens.It's got a shoulder strap, but that's not really much help.Is it worth the money? Not for every class, but for a major project-type class, probably so. It fits well in the backpack she already had, so it's a winner for us.

Lock: Excellent.App: Okey-dokey :)BE AWARE THAT THIS NEEDS AN EXISTING DEADBOLT INSTALLATION TO BE USED. OTHERWISE, YOU'LL NEED TO GET THE BOLT, OUTER LOCK, ETC....Installing the OKIDOKEYS unit on an existing deadbolt is really quite easy. The instructions are clear, the system works well. Additionally, battery life is quite good. It is a tad sensitive on those doors which have settled with the house, where the deadbolt throw space isn't perfectly lined up. If you are used to lifting/pushing/pulling your door a hair to throw your dead bolt, then you will have a little extra work to do.All of the lock features work well, including the door sensor. The add-on magnetic door sensor does take a bit more work, but it's worth it.My one dislike comes from the app. The basic features are fine, but the app needs to allow one to shut down the "location-based" services. I don't typically leave location on for my phone because of battery life (and paranoia, my tin-foil hat doesn't cover my phone). But the OKIDOKEYS app asks for location every time it's opened. And several times while it is open.I don't want my door to auto-unlock when I get close to it...that might let the space aliens in! So the app should allow the user to just decline location in the settings and not have to keep canceling the "Turn on location!" reminders.Other than that, I think this is a good one. Do-it-yourself friendly, with clear install instructions and easy setup.

Remember being kids and begging your parents for a Trapper Keeper? I do. Dad: "It's too flimsy and you're just paying for the name and the characters on it!" "But I want the...." (nope, not telling you what characters.)Fast forward 30 years. I snag this Trapper Keeper for my son, Star Wars fan that he is.Guess what?It's flimsy, not going to hold papers well, and you're just paying for the name and the Star Wars. Let's take it apart, piece by piece:1. The vinyl folds and the snap closure. It's a great snap. So great, that you're going to start tearing the folded vinyl that connects the closing flap over just to get it open.2. Inner pockets: not strong enough to hold much.3. No folders included...back in the dark ages, Trapper Keepers did come with Trappers. Not anymore.Good? Decent metal 3-ring closure.But overall?Not worth it.

Today's Book is Questions Jesus Asks. This is a follow-up to Israel Wayne's Questions God Asks, published last year. Wayne is a preacher and teacher in the United States.Now, on to this particular book. Essentially, this is an accessible theology book framed around the Scriptures that record Jesus Himself asking questions. It's a different approach than the standard formula of defining a topic and then going to the text for answers. It strengthens the reader's interest by using this approach.First, Wayne addresses the big question: Who is Jesus? Why does that matter? From this understanding of the nature of Christ, he goes on to address the other questions.A moment here to take a brief dip into the idea of all Scripture as the Word of God. Wayne is not presenting that "red-letters" are more important than other letters by focusing on the questions Jesus asked. Instead, he is using these questions as an organizational tool for exploring all of Scripture.The topics covered run from Christology to Eschatology, but all without being obscure or bizarre. Further, Wayne speaks plainly to the audience and without an edge of superiority.I found this a helpful book for learning theology by going through a different path, one that helps the reader stay focused. Additionally, I would commend the idea of using this book alongside reading the text as narrative, for a few excursions into what deeper things we can learn from the moments in the story the questions are asked.I did receive a free copy of this book in exchange for the review.

Not everything we do has to be deadly serious. One of the main people I rely on to keep me laughing is Tim Hawkins. And, for the first time ever, Tim has written a book!As a fan, I knew what to expect. This a short-chapter paperback that mainly holds Tims comedy in written form. The stories and jokes are funny, and considering Ive got most of them memorized, I can even hear Hawkins as one of the thousand voices in my head as I read this book. (Whether thats good or bad, my pshrink wont say!)While this predictability is an asset to the tome, Diary of a Jackwagon contains a few things I had never heard. Much of it is backstory either of Hawkins life or the longer version of humor that doesnt fit in a video presentation. These parts were the better parts of the book, mostly due to their freshness.Honestly, though, what are we expecting? Its funny, its Tim-clean, and its worth $10 to have something fun to read from time to time. It takes almost no extra brain power to read, but it also doesnt numb you to the realities of life.All-in-all, its exactly what you would expect. Unless for some reason you think Tim Hawkins is a stage name for D.A. Carson or Dan Wallace (heavy-duty Biblical scholar dudes). In which case, you might have thought there was depth. There isnt.Just good clean fun.Free book from Booklook. It was worth every penny.

Let me be upfront: I am not a professional-level saxophone player. I played in high school and still enjoy playing, for fun and not audiences, 20 years later. Hopefully some expert will give you an expert look. Here's an amateur view:1. Packaging: reeds are individually packaged in protective plastic. Having bought cheap ones before that weren't, I like that.2. Fit: they fit fine.3. Tone: there was a bit of improvement. If I were better, I think it would have been even more noticeable.4. Durability: these have held up well through several hours of play, and several setups and take aparts.5. Splinters: what can I say, sometimes I've bought cheap reeds! There are no splinters to be had here.

24 rounds of Nerf annoyance!Setting aside the difficulty of storing this Nerfer because of the side cylinders, I love it. It shoots straight, does not require batteries, and the rotating cylinder design is different from anything I've seen.Further, it's easy to load all the chambers without having to prime the weapon.The only thing that seems useless is the "Slam-fire" mode. Essentially, hold the trigger while pumping the weapon's charging handle. It's not any quicker than normal shooting if you're not really slow. And it's not going to speed you up if you're uncoordinated.The cocking lever is a little weak in the connection. Make sure you screw that in tight. Otherwise, it's a great Nerfer for those battery-free days.

Effective as a long-range Nerfer, the RotoFury shoots from one end of a basketball court to the other. And for safety reasons, should only be used against people past the half-court line.Now, on to the product: 1. there should be a way to release the cylinder lock so you can spin it and load it. The need to cock the Nerfer just to get the last dart in the cylinder is annoying. Plus having to work your way around loading it instead of loading from one point.2. It does shoot fairly accurately. Obviously, the longer distances are less accurate. It's a foam dart, not a guided missile. Still, 7/10 into the box from 75 feet. (from leaning on a table at one free-throw line, aiming at a box on a table on the far out-of-bounds line)3. The darts whistle better than my old MEGA darts did. Not sure why, they just do.4. It's still incredibly loud on firing. That's got to be a large spring involved.5. Rate of fire is as fast as you can cock and shoot with the pull-back handle.6. If you hit someone within 20 feet of you, it's going to hurt.7. This isn't the first Nerfer you should get, but it's a great one in the arsenal.

The first time I heard someone mention special needs children in church, it was accompanied by a long list of Dont ever do XXXX again! The commandments to the church were accompanied by a list of things to instruct parents of other kids to never do at church and to make sure their children never did. In short, it made ministry with special needs children sound like a lugging a burden through a minefield, where survival was the only hope.As a pastor, thats not the approach that seemed best to me at the time.It still seems like a terrible approach. After all, Gods people are not all of one shape, size, and ability group. If we cannot flourish as the church by welcoming all people, then we have something wrong. Then I was offered Every Child Welcome through Kregel Academic and Ministry for review. Given how hard it was to pick one book to start with, I viewed this as a godsend for learning better first steps.I was right. Katie Wetherbee and Jolene Philo, both long-term educators, present a concise look at how all children can be welcomed and celebrated in church. Rather than presenting a burdensome batch of do/donts, they give strategies to try out.Some of these strategies are genericafter all, Wetherbee and Philo dont know who youre ministering towhich is fine. Given that many readers of Every Child Welcome are, like me, not qualified to make highly specific diagnoses, we should be looking at broadly usable ideas. From there, the more specific strategies recommended come into play.The most valuable information here is what should be the most obvious. The authors give some clear guidelines about how to communicate about childrens behavior which helps keep it edifying and private as appropriate. If your church leadership hasnt learned yet to keep behavior challenges off of social media, you need to teach that lesson right quick. For all ages. (And yes, I must admit to having failed at that in younger dumber years.)Further, Every Child Welcome provides resources for further study. Its a great intro work, and ideal for a pastor who wants to launch a church in the right direction, not just making a separate space for special needs kids but enfolding all of Gods people in the church.Free book from Kregel Academic in exchange for the review.

1. Easy to install. I don't think it gets much easier for a do-it-yourself. Install the base plate, slide the light on.2. No wiring! YAY!!3. It's not super-easy to install to brick/masonry because I don't have a good drill for that. But if you do....mine's on a wood wall.4. The one thing I'm not a fan of is how heavy it gets with 4 D batteries. I know that's a toss up with longevity and effectiveness, but man this thing is not light...it just is a light5. Sensor works well.6. Illumination is excellent.7. We're using on a stairwell, and it provides good light up and down. It also can be aimed, with a touch of effort, to sense movement at the top and bottom of the stairs. There's about 6 steps, for what that's worth.

Todays book delves into Colonial America and looks at two figures that are not typically portrayed together: George Whitefield and Benjamin Franklin. While I am not quite certain that Ill grant Randy Petersens subtitle of The Surprising Friendship that Invented America, I still find The Printer and the Preacher a great read. Heres why:First, Petersen opens with some of Franklin and Whitefields interactions rather than burying those into chronological order. This leaps the reader ahead a few decades and sets up why one would want to read the rest of the book.Second, while there is some prior knowledge of American Colonial History is helpful, its not critical. Petersen provides many of the background events needed to understand what was going on in the world of Whitefield and Franklin. We should know what happened in those times, but keeping it all straight is easier with the reminders.Third, I greatly appreciated the admission of things not known throughout this book. While there is enough ambiguity admitted to for the overall premise to be questioned, at least Petersen is not foisting a false certainty about the relationship between the two.Fourth, there is no attempt to posthumously baptize Franklin. The man went through his life unwilling to be counted a born-again Christian and any biography dealing with his life should admit that. Too many Christian-oriented books on the founding era of the United States attempt to classify all the Founding Fathers as strong, right-wing Christians, which they werent. Honesty is a good sign for a biography.Overall, this work is not without its flaws. For example, there are several places where there is no evidence that Whitefield and Franklin met. Its possible they did or didnt, and ones view of their relationship will decide how that silence is interpreted. Naturally, Petersen presents them as likely having interacted. It helps the story, but its not certain.At its core, though, this is a story of two men with conflicting viewpoints working together. They benefited professionally and personally, and in turn two nations reaped spiritual and temporal rewards. Its a great story, one that sheds light on a model worth learning.Free book in exchange for the review. Review originally appeared on my personal blog.

It's hard to figure how to really review the Amazon Echo. Here's why: I got it, expecting a WiFi enabled music player with a few other novelty perks. Which, given the deal I got was going to be just fine.So, we set up the Echo. The voice commands use an activation word, default setting is "Alexa." You give commands either by pushing the button on the remote and speaking them or by simply saying where the Echo hears you "Alexa, ...." (fill in the command). In our house, that got the Echo named "Alexa."First, to the intended usage: music. The music quality and streaming is excellent. Over the past few years, I've managed to get all of the music we own uploaded onto our Amazon Music account, so this is like having voice access to 100s of CDs at once. The Prime Music library is a good addition, though I've found it most useful to work those songs in through the Amazon Music App into playlists...sound quality is good, it fills the room well.I do wish there was finer control of the volume of music. 3 is often just a shade too quiet, 4 is too loud, and the voice system can't do "3.5."Second, though, we found a myriad of uses for Alexa that we didn't really expect. But when we recently moved and went a week, we realized a few things:1. Kitchen timer. Talk about simple--rather than punching buttons, you just call out for a timer. It would be nice to set dual timers, but the one is great.2. Calendar/weather updates. The daily briefing feature is far more useful than I expected.3. Ease of use for all things. Including that my kids love to ask for a joke...though the jokes are corny to the extreme.In all, I think it's a good purchase. There are a few limitations, like the volume control, that keep me from just going complete fanboy and five-starring this, but I think the Echo is well worth the purchase.

Reading a few other reviews, I think I'm finding a positive in what some find as a drawback1. Layout: you have a 2 page layout of the month. This has squares that are about 2 inches square on it, to do the month at a glance. Then each week gets a 2 page spread, with 8 lined sections. 1 for each day, plus a spare "notes" section.This is great for planning and recording what has happened.2. It's boring. There's no fancy lettering, pretty graphics, even much in terms of color. It's just straightforward. I like that, but some will find it visually flat.3. Cover: thicker cardboard, which the wire-bound style doesn't turn as easily. On the upside, it doesn't tear up in the backpack.For me, as a straightforward planner/calendar, this hits all the right notes. It's a bit pricey, and of course it's huge for portability/on-the-go use, but that's part of deciding if this style is right for you. It delivers on its promises.

Expectations matter---even though this is a color printer with a good resolution, I didn't expect perfect picture printing. And I didn't get perfect pictures, though they were good enough for what I needed.I did get great colors on basic images for work reports and printouts. Speed was good, and so far the cartridges are trucking well through their announced lifespan.Setup: I set this up strictly via wi-fi, which went seamlessly. Downloaded software direct from HP rather than using the CD. In my recent experience, installing from a CD results in "Checking for Updates" and a complete download anyway. Might as well cut out the middle man. So, download, install, print--worked fine.Also works fine doing Wi-Fi direct from my Samsung. Touch to print/NFC worked fine.Noise level is fine, not too intrusive.I'm not a fan of the price of cartridges but what are you going to do? That's how you can get the printer at an affordable price.In all, worth it if you need color. Primarily for printing reports/brochures in color, not pictures although pictures aren't bad. If you're a picture person, you might stick with a b/w Laser for mass jobs and look elsewhere for color.But to put out one machine? This one works.

It's a good fantasy series. Why?1. The characters develop well--the good guys are good underneath but not perfect. The bad guys are clearly the bad guys.2. Plot-wise, you've got a few hard to believe moments but it's fantasy.3. Even with the fantasy elements, Treskillard has a pretty clear picture of good and evil. He's done well (for what I know) dealing with the history and Druids as even-handedly as possible.4. I do NOT recommend starting on this book but on book 1 of the series.5. Be prepared--the story does not wrap-up and instead leads to another series.6. I'll be acquiring the prior volumes and handing them off to my middle-schooler.7. A good read.

Looking past my wondering WHY I would ever need this product, let's just take a look at whether or not it does what it should.1. Does it light up? Yes, it does.2. Can you control it with a mobile device via Bluetooth? Yes, you can. This is subject to all the limitations and issues related to Bluetooth connection, doubly so if your light fixture is not close to you.3. Does the programming work? Yes, it does. Assuming your phone is near to the light bulb when your timer/alarm should happen. Or that no one switches off, manually, the power to the fixture.The limitation of wireless connectivity is the real problem here. Sometimes, your phone isn't quite connecting. Sometimes, you're just a shade too far away. Sometimes there's interference.In short, unless you are right up close to the light, you aren't really getting the benefits of the light bulb. If you could send a program to the bulb, rather than have it dependent on the phone/app for operation, I think this would be better. But overall, I can't get it to just run the schedule without making sure I leave my cell phone close enough for the wireless to connect.Perhaps if you did the whole house in iLumi bulbs for the Mesh effect to work...but that's a stout outlay.

I am fan and user of Bible software. Most Bible programs can do the concordance search way quicker than anyone with a print concordance.Except those results are sometimes too comprehensive--if you're using one Bible, do you need the extra info from fourteen translations?What is a concordance? This is an index of every word used in the NIV translation of the Bible. For example, how many times (and where) does the NIV use the word "Father?" or "Rabbit?" You turn to the word, see the heading info and you can see how many and where.So, the hardcover has value. Additionally, it's easier to show someone else what you are doing by working through the hardcover concordance.Now, to this one:1. Exhaustive--and exhausting to lug about. I'm fairly certain they got everything here. I had the 2nd edition, and it was pretty close to right on. This one has a better digital database to build on, so most everything is there.2. The use of the G/K numbering system is helpful. You can actually use the numbers to find the Greek or Hebrew word and then find that number keyed to several of the major lexical works in that language. It is no substitute for learning the languages, but it's helpful.3. I don't know why they compare to Strong's, since Strong's is a concordance of the KJV. Still, it's quite handy.4. An additional use of the numbering system illustrates the difficulties of translation: one word like "love" may translate several original language words. By seeing the differing numbers, you can link up the different words for study.5. If all else fails, this is an excellent self-defense tool.I find the NIV Exhaustive Concordance better than my NASB Concordance--which is a pill, since I prefer NASB as a translation. Still, this is a great study tool for serious Bible students even if you prefer a different translation.

This one goes down as "so-so" in the Nerf blaster department.The Good: quiet approach and attack. You can sneak up on anyone with this...if you want to. Plus, broken down to just the core blaster it's easy to pocket. The add-ons are alright, the shoulder stock is the most useful.The Bad: one shot at a time. True, you can stick 6 Nerfs through slots in the stock. You can also carry them behind your ears like pencils and be just as fast. The one-pull, one-shot, then reload/rearm sequence makes this more like bringing a flintlock pistol to the fight. Make sure that's what you're up against--if someone comes with a full auto Nerf, you're toast.The Ugly: the add-on barrel is just flat useless. So is the weird squared config to use the belt clip.Is this a total waste? No, but unless you're putting together duels at 10 paces, you are going to need more firepower.

I'm in the middle of a work relocation, so there's all sorts of stuff I should be doing.Instead, I snagged the review offer of Pirate Hunters and blew three days reading it rather than doing any useful work. I was fascinated by the story of salvage and recovery, including the behind-the-scenes personal issues. But then I got into the story of the Pirate Bannister and the sea life.It was fascinating. I would certainly not wanted to run afoul of the pirates of that era, but reading up was fun.Further, seeing just how hard it is to bring history up from the depths was informative. In all, this is a great read for history buffs or pirate fans.

"If you want to lead the orchestra, you must turn your back on the crowd" is something I read in some leadership book somewhere...Now, we have a leadership book from an orchestra conductor. Except it's not about turning your back on the crowd. That's apparently a fundamental assumption of leadership that needs no book.Instead, Talgam brings out some ideas that I, having been a band nerd in high school, had not considered regarding music, leadership, and orchestras. You see, a high school band director is certified in 'instructional music," meaning he/she can teach (and therefore play) nearly every instrument in the group. Perhaps he's better at some (Mr. B was great on brass but only good on flutes) than others but one would not argue with him about the basics of any instrument.An orchestra conductor at the pro level, though, may have no real idea about how to play some of the instruments. He may have always been a string player and can't get a piccolo to do anything. Instead, it is his/her role to take the disjointed parts and bring them together into a whole. To take the lines and create the picture.From this, Talgam builds a picture of leadership. He does not present that a person should lead without knowing *anything* but stresses the ability of a leader to guide without knowing the details of every area being led. Consider how this applies--does a ship captain know the finer points of boiler maintenance? Or does the jumbo jet pilot change the oil in the plane? Likewise, an most organizations, insistence that the leader be more competent in everything than anyone in their departments is a recipe for failure.That does not excuse, though, the leader from respecting the knowledge of those being led. Talgam's guidance here will be lost in those workplaces where the "leader" is considered beyond question or always right. The value here is for those who want to lead or structure organizations where the leader works together with others to accomplish the goals. Where the leader is comfortable with his ignorance being filled in by those being led, without failing to guide to the big picture.Definitely worth a read.

The Roger and Suzanne mysteries are always good and have particularly liked the two that have a plot centering around the 'dog world'. The first was show dogs, which was familiar to me and this book goes on with AKC field trials, something that has been developed since I was involved personally with show dogs. Again, very accurate portrayal of dogs, their training and their personalities plus a very realistic look at dog show people as well. Personal dog show experience makes the author add realism to the storyline without error and as always, good, solid mystery plot and returning series characters.

I've been waiting impatiently for this book to come out, finished it in one sitting and am bitterly disappointed. Each of the first two books were excellent, ones that I've kept to re-read. Good characterization and interesting characters, interesting plotlines, good action sequences. Each book had it's own main character, but the initial core group of characters remained. with a complete story to each book, beginning, middle, end.The writing and storyline in this third book remains excellent, as does the characterization. Unfortunately the author has apparently decided to serialize this series with no warning and there is no ending of even a minor plotline, with a major overall story continuing on to a new book, an abrupt, middle of a battle cliffhanger ending. My personal opinion is that any serialized book should carry a notation to that effect, not be unleashed on an unsuspecting reader. If a cliffhanger ending is announced in the information and I choose to read the book anyway, it is my choice. If the author shocks me with it unexpectedly, my annoyance is going to be expressed.

Interesting characters, excellent writing, very *authentic* feel to the action and the dog handling and very accurate presentation of the issues with PTSD ... however, I read for entertainment and I do not find the death of dogs entertaining. Three books in the series, a dog dies in the last two books and a quick check of Book 4 indicates it happens there as well. I'm done.
Great characters, accurate depiction of tracking/search/military dogs and lots of action. Excellent series so far.

Like it with reservations. Still great characters, excellent writing, vivid action scenes and still the very accurate 'feel' to the PTSD episodes but I read for entertainment and I do not find the death of a dog entertaining. Will try the next one, but if the trend continues, I'm done with the series.

I've been waiting for this ever since I finished the second book in this series. Really like the characters, the passion the main character has for old buildings comes through clearly, at an emotional level and while I do not feel the same attraction, I can understand it from the viewpoint of my own passions. While I am not familiar with the area, or with urban settings in general, the writing comes through with total credibility and the plot revolving around the current issues of illegal immigrants is definitely interesting and reads as accurately presented. Like the first two books of this series, this is one I will keep and re-read.I still like the first book of the series the best of the three. I am definitely a character driven reader and the first book spent more time with character developing and there was more interaction with the supporting cast of characters. If I have a criticism of this book, it is primarily that I wanted to know more about some of the new characters introduced. For example, Charlie appeared only briefly, a major character primarily because of her absence, but I wanted to know more about her. Characters prominent in the first book only had 'walk-on' appearances which I found somewhat disappointing.My last criticism is that this book definitely ended in a cliff-hanger, which is usually  a major problem for me as I have an irrational dislike for them. In this case, I found it something I could live with because this plot and storyline was completely wrapped up and the 'cliff hanger' was a matter of just paragraphs at the very end and just a suggestion as to at least some of the storyline for what will be the next book in this series. I vind I can live with that and I will just hope that any future cliff-hangers do not go beyond this level.

This was a free download and I liked it enough that I've purchased the next in the series, which doesn't happen too often with me. I like science fiction and the sci-fi/futuristic setting was done well. Enjoy mysteries and the police procedural/mystery plot was handled well. Good character development and while I find many 'cozy mysteries' simply too silly to be entertaining, this was cozy more in the way of slower pacing, more character interaction and a lack of graphic violence.The biggest downside for me with this book was the recurrent reference to the Christian orientation and beliefs of the main character when it had nothing to do with the plot or storyline. It was handled with a fairly light touch, but was still intrusive at times.

My second book by this author and very different, but found it just as entertaining. Storyline wrapped around a very authentic medical and battlefield medical background, the reader is given a very personal view of life in a war zone and the damage it does to everyone involved. My only criticism, a minor one, was that the ending seemed a bit abrupt, a 'tie all the loose ends' with a happy-ever-after bow, and seemed a bit contrived.

Archaeological thriller that blends prehistory with a WWII storyline, touched off by a the discovery of a hidden medieval book in the wall of an old monastery. Good plot and an interesting storyline, although I found the ending, involving a mysterious covert government group somewhat underdeveloped and vaguely unsatisfying.

Very readable and well crafted police procedural/mystery. Romance line wasn't terribly overdone (although I skipped some of that), characters were interesting and I enjoyed the classical musical setting/background. Seemed a little short, I'd have personally preferred a little less romance and a little more character development.

Bought this immediately after reading the first book in this series and liked this one even more than the first. Very good blending of an old small town 'mystery' which turns out to be a murder and current events, with a nice touch of paranormal thanks to a psychic librarian.Very well done and a series I expect to continue.

This was a free download, an entertaining small town police procedural, good characterization and easily read storyline. Marketed as a cozy but seems to be a little on the side of standard small town police procedural more than a cozy, which is actually a preference for me as I end up dropping a lot of cozies because they are just too silly. The only criticism I had (thanks to my own law enforcement background) was the handling of murder scene evidence, a bit distracting but not impossibleI liked this well enough to immediately purchase the next in the series, which isn't something which I do often.
Entertaining urban fantasy read, a bit on the dark side. Good characterization though a little uneven, overall.
Fairly standard covert/government ops group novel, interesting plot line, fast action and good cast of characters. Plot was a bit of a stretch of the imagination, but overall and entertaining read.
A fun collection, interesting characters with well-planned storylines. Very entertaining.

Very much liked the original "Rune Breaker" series so was very glad to see a new book with the same characters. Like the characters and their development continues to be interesting. The book ... at 137 pages ... is short, obviously just a segment of the next series and somewhat of a cliffhanger, which I absolutely do not like but I did expect it so can't complain too much. However, there really isn't much of a storyline within the book, it's more of an introduction to the coming series and did find it somewhat of a disappointment on that basis. I can deal with 'part of a series' but prefer at least something of an actual story, beginning, middle, end, even with one of a series.

Obviously written by an author with police experience, this is one of the most realistic looks at actual on-the-street police work I've read. The plot was well developed, writing professional although I did find the characters less well developed and 'individual' than I usually prefer. This book's strength is, for me, not in the story but in the very realistic view of the life of police officers dealing with the issues in city law enforcement today, which is something more people need to look at, I think. This is not a particularly light read, or overly pro-police but a somewhat gritty look into the life of a group of police officers, though it avoids the worst of the graphic crime scene descriptions.

Good addition to the series. Interesting plot, excellent description of the locale and the usual good characterizations. I enjoy the descriptions and history of the area, which are always presented in a way that doesn't intrude on the storyline and particularly like the ongoing characters, who are mature, sensible and have no issues, which seems to not be case in many mysteries now.

Readable, but too many subplots and what might have been the main plot wasn't developed enough to bring the rest of the story together. Interesting storylines in the subplots, some excellent disaster scenes but a lot more character development would have given it more 'storyline'.

Very much an action/mystery storyline that made an interesting read and particularly interesting for the off-beat euthanasia angle. The subject the plot revolved around, euthanasia, is of particular interest to me and attracted me initially, but I found the book entertaining and very readable.

Readable police procedural story with the plot revolving around a serial killer. Some strong characterizations although I found some of the police department interactions a little strange and the mild romantic interest a bit of a stretch. I did find the ending a surprise but also a bit unrealistic.

Readable mystery that was borderline between okay and liked it. The biggest problem for me was that part of the plot was structured around a scam involving dogs that isn't possible now because of DNA typing and the storyline was current timing. I'd have liked the book more if I wasn't involved myself with purebred dogs and AKC registration and didn't know that part of the plot was impossible.
The usual fast action and good storyline I expect from this series, along with the usual excellent characterization. Definitely another  keep to re-read for me.

Read this immediately after the first book in the series. Good action sequences, good characterization but overall not quite as impressed with this one, but it is definitely personal opinion. Didn't care for the very cliche trick of the main character losing his wife, bringing him available for a new job and the government developed/monster program was more graphically bloody and required a bit more suspension of belief than I was capable of at times. Entertaining, not quite up to the standard of the first book but would definitely read a third book if/when the series continues.

Pretty standard A/A plotline, special forces, secret government projects, etc. but entertaining. Interesting characters, good action sequences and an interesting touch in 'government projects gone wrong'. The storyline moved well, the action sequences were vivid and overall definitely not boring.

I liked this well enough to be thinking it would end up being a 'keep to re-read' which doesn't happen too often with me. A lot of things to like, characters, interesting world and storyline although the plot was pretty standard. That was until the last 10 pages or so, as it ended as an absolute cliffhanger, just as the characters were stepping forward into a major battle.Cliffhanger endings are a personal major issue for me, hate them. Won't be re-reading, won't be reading any more of what is apparently going to be a series.

After the introductory free novella, I was really looking forward to this full length book in the series. More character development, if a little slow, more background/scene setting than action but I didn't really have any major issues for the most part.Until the ending. Classic, definite cliffhanger ending. For various personal reasons, I do not handle cliffhanger endings. I expect a book to have a beginning, middle and end and although a series can certainly have threads to the next book in the series, I expect the major issues in each book to be solved. The old movie theater serial type 'closing' with the female lead tied to the train track with the train in the background annoys me tremendously.Decent writing, reasonable storyline, interesting characters for those readers who are not put off by cliffhanger endings. I'm not one of those readers and will not be continuing with this series.

Excellent storytelling, much better than average military sci-fi, good character development for the type of plot, good dialogue. I gave his first book a rare 5-star review and this second book is another one. Of the two books (quite different) I liked the humor in the first book better, but I have to admit this is the only criticism I can really make.Pretty standard military sci-fi but interesting characters, well written action sequences, a realistically high body count without getting too far into the splashy gore descriptions, a good touch of political underhandedness.An author versatile enough that I'm looking forward to see where he goes with his next book although I would be delighted for a second book continuing with either set of characters.

Free download novella, very standard plot involving a covert group of non-humans/magic users gathered to protect normal humans, but the characters are interesting enough and the storyline promising enough I'm going on with the first book in the series.

Fun, although did not read as smoothly as it could have. The main characters are relatively well developed and the battle scenes read well, but the love/sex scenes felt awkward. This is one of those series I would continue with if my local library had them, but I don't think this will become a "keep to re-read" for me, so I doubt if I will purchase the next one.
Excellent second book in this series. Good characterization, good progression, very good battle sequences. Hope the third book is out soon.

Looks like it will be a series and I'd definitely try another. A bit slow paced, could have been more tightly edited, but very good characterization, interesting plotline and while I am not familiar with the setting or the details of the trucking industry, it had an authentic feel.

Very slow start and the entire book seemed to have difficulty deciding if it was "contemporary fiction" about a family moving to a foreign country and the wife having to adjust to being a full time housewife/mother after having a career ... or a spy novel. Slow pace, definitely not action/adventure. I think part of my problem with the book was that I never really did 'connect' with the characters.

Very readable police procedural with the bomb squad the focus and the plot brought in the issues involving military veterans and PTSD very believably. Reasonably good characterization, relatively straightforward plot line although I would have preferred a different ending. Would read more in this series.
I think maybe, for me, this was a little too short to have the character development and depth I prefer. Fast, furious and fun but it left me with a vague sense of feeling that something was missing.

The setting and characters were, as always, flawless but this isn't going to be one of my favorites of the series. Walt's reluctance to get on the plane and continue with the "unoffical" investigation seemed unrealistic. Also, the plot involved the return of a rather stereotypical "evil genius" from a previous book, which I really would hope does not carry on through more books. One book was good. Book two, a stretch. If there is a book three, I suspect that for me, third try will not be a charm.
An entertaining, fun fantasy,  definitely suitable for a YA readership and somewhat simplistic, with deft touches of humor that make it a quick, light read for adults.

Not a bad plot, but more tangents than necessary, which made it somewhat confusing. Many of the characters were very stereotyped. I read a lot of mysteries, very few romances and I suspect this might appeal more to romance readers who like mysteries than someone like me who is primarily a mystery reader.

Interesting plot line and well developed characters but the reader does have to seriously suspend belief to manage the heavily slanted political scenario in the storyline.There were parts of the book that I enjoyed very much, those that read like a well crafted techno-thriller. I did have to resort to skimming the sections which were the platforms for the political rants and social commentary.

Second of the series, entertaining read and interesting storyline.  In some ways a followup from the first in the series but I did find the ending abrupt and a bit strange.I would like to have seen more character development in this second book and less of the romance, which got a little intrusive at times and I still find the lead male character very indistinct, he seems as if he is there only for the romantic interest rather than a real personality on his own.I have some issues with what I personally term the "Bluebeard's Castle Syndrome' ... female character going alone, without backup into dark tunnels, unlighted alleyways, open buildings.  That tends to annoy me and it's been an issue in both books.With the way this book ended, I will likely read the next book in the next series to see how the author intends to continue, but depending on that and if some of the issues I've had with the first two books are not resolved, I probably won't continue after that.

Futuristic police procedural with a heavy romance touch. Interesting plot concept revolving around a test group for high-tech imaging implant, relatively well developed characters and  good secondary supporting characters.The description of the crime scenes is somewhat graphic and grim and I did tend to skim through those.  A little heavy on the romance for my personal taste, with a 'triangle' which isn't one of my favorite themes but will be reading more of this series unless the romance takes over the police/procedural storyline.

Well written and researched police procedural with a plot centered around British racing. As a lifetime horse person, I find very few books written with a background in the equine 'industries' that are accurate.Primarily police procedural the series seems to focus on deaths related to various sports with a likeable main character and an understated partnership/romance with a female officer that works well. I particularly appreciate the fact that there are the main characters are not taking up a third of the book with their alcohol, drug or relationship problems but are presented as sane, sensible detectives intent on doing their job.

Entertaining, with good character development and an interesting plotline.  A bit of the slower pacing which often seems somewhat characteristic of British mysteries and something I enjoy. Plotline was somewhat unusual, revolving around a question of accident/murder with a rockclimbing fall and I found the ending unexpected.

Second book of the series and if possible, liked this even better than the first, which I also gave a 5-star rating to.The author hits all my 'like' buttons and misses all the dislike buttons. His lead detective is a single mother but manages both personal life and professional duties in a sensible, straightforward manner, no drinking binges, no angst. The police department and supporting characters are presented with normal personality conflicts but no huge political or personal animosity, no "detective against the world" scenarios.Plot line in this book is interesting, touching on money laundering, terrorists and counter-terrorism tactics, perhaps a bit of a suspension of belief is necessary but it is handled with a smooth storyline that makes an entertaining read.Just wish the author wrote more in this series faster.

Just plain fun read, undemanding, fast action, the good guys win and the bad guys lose big time. An excellent addition to a series I've enjoyed. Quick read, lots of action and in this case an interesting plot twist with the usual male leads the 'victims' amd the supporting female characters taking the lead.
Found it difficult to follow in places, jumping from one scene to another and different time frames and people. Also seemed to have problems deciding at times whether it was a romance or a thriller.
Kindle format for the first of a series first published in 1995. Typical British police procedural, good characterization, rather slow progression, well written.
Good paranormal/police procedural with a 'ghost' as one of the main characters I found very interesting and a bit different from the usual.

Got the book because of the link to horses and rodeo and that part was well done, no real errors with that, which was a definite plus and pretty unusual. Would have liked the book better with about 2/3 less graphically descriptive sex scenes and a lot more storyline.

The plot, although predictable, worked for me for the most part. Must admit I'm a character-driven reader however and the characters never quite got past the 'okay' stage for me. Interesting main characters with lots of potential that never quite managed to click. More romance than I prefer, less action and a very flat ending.

I tend to like British mysteries and the plotline worked for me, but have to admit I'm a character-driven reader and I found it difficult to 'connect' to any of the main characters. I also found the dialogue rather stilted and awkward for the most part. I suspect a good editor could have improved this book considerably.
Enjoyed the feel of the NM setting, good characterization although I found the plot line a bit of a stretch of the imagination.

The background of Lexington and the Thoroughbred farms and industry was very well done and accurate and as a lifetime horseperson, this kept me reading.Otherwise, it seemed as if there were too many diverse plotlines, some of which seemed as if they were simply pieces of family history rather than a part of a main plot or storyline.

Fairly standard plot, farm girl sent to military camp for unknown reasons in a society where women are not expected to go outside their role.The storyline was interesting enough but I found the difficulties the main character found herself in to be annoying. I realize that she was supposed to be naive and find socializing difficult but she allowed herself to do things that were basically stupid and illegal for reasons I found unbelievable.Those inconsistencies were followed by an absolutely unanticipated cliffhanger ending, no indication this was Book I of a series. Since this is a particular pet peeve for me, I dropped the rating another star to indicate my dislike of this fact.

I've been a big fan of this series so far and was really looking forward to the new book but have to say I was a bit disappointed. I've enjoyed the somewhat leisurely pacing of the series and the slight "Victorian" flavor of the setting, but this seemed to be overly slow and a bit short on the plotting.

Entertaining storyline, interesting characters and good characterization for the most part. Would have preferred minimizing the sex scenes ... I prefer my imagination for scenes like that rather than graphic detail ... but a couple of humorous scenes made up for that. I can skim the sex scenes but I'm still snickering every time I think of the vampire-staking scene in this one.

Another good addition to the series, again seems as if the author is headed more to light/traditional mystery now than cozy mystery but remains excellent, with great characters and wonderful sense of area and people.
As good as the others, characters excellent, humorous touches, perhaps a bit more to the 'mystery' and a little less cozy.

A wonderful 'cozy' for those readers, like myself, who actually like a fun, light read but tend to avoid most of the 'cozy mystery' reads because of impossible characters and plots. After 15 years living in rural KY, I have *met* many of the characters inhabiting the pages of this series and the background and interactions are highly amusing (and not all that much exaggerated!).

Will be definitely be following this series. I like cozy mysteries but find most of them with characters that are absolutely ridiculous and silly and plots that are way beyond my ability to believe. This one has good, solid characters, female police chief in a small southern town, good supporting characters and the crimes are handled with a light touch even when they include murder. Author is definitely familiar with what she writes as well, as even though exaggerated for effect, after living in KY for 15 years, I have *met* many of her characters personally.
Liked this much better than the first book in the series. Main character has fewer issues and the plotline here, with causes linked to the past in WW II, held my interest very well.

Somewhat grim for my personal taste, but readable. I tend to find the flawed ex-cop somewhat of a overused character and most of them seem to follow the same patterns. Would liked to have seen a little more 'improvement' and a somewhat lighter feel to the storyline.
Good, solidly plotted and written private detective/mystery. Fast read, interesting characters and good plot twists that keep the reader involved.

The second book in the Drifting Isle Chronicles series. Same setting/location and world but different characters. Interesting plotline but did not like the characters as well as in the first book and did not find them as well defined.

Quick, easy read, with a minimum of YA angst and an interesting high-tech plot. As an adult reader, I'd have liked more mystery/thriller tension but for a younger readership it was probably right on target. Good characterization and a good feel for the 'humanization' of the A.I. character as well.

But not a lot of 'space', more military-on-the-ground. Strong female main character, reasonably good plotting and good action sequences. However, I found the conclusion of the plot rather contrived and lacking the emotional 'punch' that should have been a part of the situation.
Pretty standard 'battle for earth' military/sci-fi storyline. Good battlefield scenes, not as much character development as I prefer, even the interaction of the main characters seemed a bit lacking.

Good blend of urban fantasy/steampunk/detective with interesting characters and fairly good character development. Not something I couldn't put down, but it was an entertaining read and one I liked well enough to put the other books in the series on my TBR list.
Entertaining, well written and well crafted detective/mystery. Good character development, harsh portrayal of the forced immigrant/prostitute situation without excessive graphic detail.

The combination of Native American and Celtic mythologies worked well, loved the main character and the writing was beautiful. Unfortunately, for me, it seemed as if the author was almost deliberately trying to be obscure in some cases.As I read further, it became more apparent that some of these situations were in part, foundations for further storylines for future volumes in this series, something that was not made clear in the synopsis or title. While I do read a number of trilogies and/or series, I prefer that I know that this is the case in advance and that each separate volume does, in fact, have a very traditional framework of beginning, middle and end.

As good as any first book of a fantasy series I've read recently. Excellent characterization, great storyline, good action sequences. If the rest of the series holds up to the promise of this first book, it's going to be a series I keep to re-read.There were editing errors, but that is something I can overlook, especially for particularly good character development and a relatively unique world setting. Also avoids the 'cliffhanger' endings so prevalent and annoying with many series, so although the storyline obviously continues, there is the feel of a segment ending.

Promising fantasy, interesting characters, well presented evil characters. Biggest flaws for me were too much "tell" rather than show, giving some parts a bit of a history book feel and the character development felt a little flat at times.

Exceptional, the best of the series so far, I think. A return to the plotline based in old family history/secrets which the author does exceptionally well. Excellent characterization, well presented storyline which is fairly easy to follow even through the multiple characters and generations.

Second of the series, readable storyline but a drop into what I term "Bluebeard's Wife syndrome" and what seemed a weaker motivation for the plot framework kept it from being as good as the first book. The characters carried this book for me, although stupid actions to move the plot along annoy me.Liked it, but if it had been the first of the series, not sure I'd continue. I suspect this book may be a symptom of what I often find ... great first book, not as good with the second ... and additional books can go either way.
Well constructed and readable but a bit grim/bleak for my personal taste and 'unfinished' endings are definitely not something that work for me.

Well written, good progressive storyline, interesting characters. While not familiar with London, the location had an authentic feel without being intrusive, good character development although I was not always comfortable with all of the actions of the main character as a therapist.

Good characterization, somewhat leisurely to read, not a lot of action but also good construction with a rather complicated family-involved plot that could have been confusing but was handled nicely with a very organized and readable storyline.No graphic details and the characters were all sensible adults that did not involve themselves in stretch-of-the-imagination plot quirks ... a big plus factor for me.

Entertaining, with good detail and good characterization and a tightly written storyline. I've read one of the later novel length books and enjoyed that as well, this was a good novella, just enough detail and story.

Entertaining enough to keep me reading and I enjoyed the interaction between the two main characters, but the editing was particularly bad (and I'm not a person that is normally too aware of that) and I found most of the female characters rather oddly angry/aggressive.

My first read in this series and I found it well written, good action sequences and a good sense of place and atmosphere. Very entertaining, quick read with good character development for the type of book.

**Pros**StylishComfortableGorgeous colorsTons of compliments**Cons**Length of thumb holeI normally wear a size small, but I ordered a medium because I have monkey arms and I wanted it to fit the length of my arms. Plus, if it was a little baggy it would be okay. I am completely pleased with it. It's a little baggy, but stylishly so.I chose the wine color and am so glad I did. It's gorgeous. This is a great fall and winter shirt and would even make a great Christmas outfit. The pocket is tilted to the side for aesthetic purposes and has a cute striped design that matches the ends of the sleeves. The shirt is extremely soft and comfortable. It's slightly thin, but not see through.The only thing I noticed wasn't right with the shirt is the thumb holes on the sleeves weren't in the same spot on the shirt. You'll have to look closely in my pictures of the sleeves. The first picture is just the sleeve length. The second picture is the thumb holes, one is about two inches down from the end of the sleeve, the other hole is about four inches down from the end of the sleeve.
