Will the Antichrist never quit dogging us?This is a fascinating peek into Americas obsession with the Antichrist, from the time of our founding as a nation until today. While the Bible speaks of antichrists in only two short booksFirst and Second Johnand while these passages refer only to people who have already lived, fundamentalist churches 2,000 years later still anticipate the arrival of a demonic force akin to Revelations Beast of the Sea. This Antichrist may take the form of an organization, like the Catholic Church, or a person, like Mussolini, depending upon whoever is in the news at the time. In latter times, the Antichrist has been discovered in computers, bar codes, rock music and the Susan B. Anthony coin.Fuller is an oft-published professor of religious studies at Bradley University, and his writing style is precise and engaging. He carries us through dozens of Americas apocalyptic enemies, so-named the Antichrist by vigilant stalkers of the Beast, going clear back to King George III in 1777. Yankees, Masons, liberals, communists, Catholics, unions, feminists, socialists, modernists, few people have escaped demonization by various clergy in the cosmic war of good versus evil. Popes, world leaders, diplomats and too-liberal preachers are identified by name. Just wars are fought under the banner of God, spurred by apocalyptic lyrics such as the Battle Hymn of the Republic. Entire nations are portrayed as evil empires, even from the presidential pulpit, compared to the Gog of Ezekiel and Revelation. Charles Taylor solved the sinister mystery of Gog: Gromkyo, Ogarkov and Gorbachev, with that birthmark on the latters head surely disclosing his beastly identity.Beware anyone preaching tolerance, advocating pluralism, striving for universal brotherhood, saving the whales, or hoping for world peace. Fuller rightfully observes in the final line of his book that this relentless obsession with the Antichrist appears to have done more to forestall than to signal the realization of the Kingdom of God on earth.Written before the turn of the century, Fullers book surely struck a chord with readers mystified by the manic draw of the millennium end. At the time, over half of adult Americans expected the imminent return of Jesus, accompanied by the fulfillment of cataclysmic biblical prophecies including the appearance of Revelations Beast. The whole obsession would be comical to me, had it died before my own lifetime, but when Fuller got to the 70s the tone turned somber. I remember the panic over communism, the demonization of Kissinger,  and Gorbachevs antichristic delusion that peace was possible. I remember counting the letters in Ronald Wilson Reagan to reach 666. I remember when Greece became the tenth member of the EEC, completing the ten horns of Revelations beast. Had the rediculousness ended with the printing of 2001 calendars, I could write it all off as the nonsense of a prior age, but it hasnt. Our newest president has far and wide been the subject of this same religious madness.The Antichrist may never fade away, but thank goodness for reasonable studies like this one to help us understand and cope with this odd cultural phenomenon in the United States. A must read.Oxford University Press,  1995, 232 pagesISBN: 0-19-508244-3

The firstborn of thy sons shalt thou give unto me. Exodus 22:29Did Israel at one time offer child sacrifice to God? If so, when and how did they overcome this barbaric ritual?Levenson takes seriously the hints throughout the Bible that Israelites once condoned child sacrifice to Yahweh, though he doubts its practice was widespread. The firstborn belonged to God, and the most pious parents considered the most appropriate means of giving him to God was in sacrifice. Levenson argues that the phrase beloved son (yahid) seems to have been, at least on occasion, a technical term for the son sacrificed as a burnt offering. This practice was roundly condemned by the prophets Jeremiah and Ezekiel, and in time worshipers began to understand that God would accept animal sacrifice in place of ones favored son. The story of Abraham and Isaac is a key example.Sibling rivalry is a common Old Testament theme, reinforced often by the outward favoring by the parents of one son over another. One would imagine the beloved son to be the firstborn, with all the privileges that go with that station, but the Bible breaks the rules often. Abel over Cain, Isaac over Ishmael, Jacob over Esau, Joseph, David, the list goes on. The beloved son is not only favored by parents but God-chosen, and belongs to God  either in sacrifice or by atonement.This theme of the sacrificial death of the beloved son was never purged from the Judaic mindset, even to the point of believing Abraham did put the knife to Isaac. Many midrashic interpretations of the sacrifice of Isaac refer to his blood being spilled. Perhaps all of his blood, depending upon which midrashic commentary you read.Intelligent, deeply researched, and reasonable, this is a look at just about every beloved son in the Bible except the one you expect: Jesus. It goes without saying that Jesus is the ultimate beloved son, but he gets only a brief nod here and there. Still, this book will inevitably make you think differently about what the death of Jesus meant. There is a bit of New Testament theology thrown in, but the focus is really the development of a theme through the Old Testament  the theme of giving the one you love most to God.

Surprisingly, this book provides precisely what the title promises. Its in three parts:I. Can we do without religion?II. Does God exist?III. Can there be an atheist spirituality?In Part I, Andre argues that humanity survives on the same moral, spiritual, and cultural values that religion cultivates, but that religion itself is unnecessary. Religion doesnt provide the basis for our morals, but rather our morals provide the basis for religion. We do have a foundational need for our spiritual well-being, but Andre shows these basic needs to be communion, fidelity, and love  of which atheists can partake without entering a church building.Part II you may skip with no feelings of regret. Its a rehash of various arguments against God, and refutations of the common arguments for God, and there is not enough depth nor originality here to bother with.Part III makes up for the lazy part II, by exposing both the smallness and the awesomeness of our being. Just staring at the stars is a religious experience. Sensing nature in all its immensity helps the spirit break free, at least partially, of the tiny prison of the self. What a relief, when the ego is driven away and nothing remains but the All, the enormous thereness of being!Why would you need a God? The universe suffices. Why would you need a church? The world suffices. Why would you need faith? Experience suffices. Says Andre, the certainty that you cannot fall out of the universe, the sense of being at one with the All  never have I experienced anything more powerful, more delightful, more overwhelming and more soothing.It turns out that atheist spirituality is as experiential and meaningful as promised, but the training course may be more cerebral than fulfilling. You have to dive below the surface or get trapped in a head bubble, trying to oppose sophistry with rationalism and nihilism with humanism or some such similar commandment. I suppose thats a struggle with any worthwhile philosophy.Fun book, written with wit and intelligence, and which does indeed titillate your spiritual side without looking to God.

I doubt anybody needs an introduction to Saint Augustine, the 4th century Bishop of Hippo. Augustine preached for perhaps 30 years and authored over 100 titles. But if you want a quick overview of his life and spiritual growth, without getting bogged down in theological discussion, this is a friendly little book. This is my first Armchair Theologians book, and Im impressed.Cooper follows the lead of Augustines most famous work, Confessions, most of which is autobiographical, to tell the story of his life. Augustines other most famous work, his massive City of God, gets a brief nod in the final chapter. I found that Cooper provided a proper balance to the influences and motivations of Augustines life: his closeness with his mother, his relationships and later determined abstinence, his foray into Manicheism, and his resultant theology of grace. A proper perspective helps overcome the shallow perception that Augustine was wracked with guilt over what he considered a terribly sinful life. Augustine did indeed condemn his youthful actions, but they hardly ranked very high on the sin scale, and he comes across in this book as much more reasonable, merely cognizant of his shortcomings.This is not to say his denunciation of Manicheism and acceptance of Christianity was an easy one. He quickly grasped the untruths of astrology and other competing life views, and saw Christianity as the one true way, but was unwilling. One day, before feeling any strong conviction toward Christianity and feeling unfulfilled, he picked up a Bible and it opened to this passage:Not in revelry and drunkenness, not in chambering and shamelessness, not in strife and envying, but put on the Lord Jesus Christ and make no provision for the flesh Romans 13:1314He needed to read no further. His past ways were put behind him, and he found the strength to overcome his sinful naturemost of which amounted to a youthful lust for women. Augustines reputation as one who condemned the evils of sex (that whole original sin thing, you know) is somewhat deserved, but to be fair he was a product of his Christian times. The connection between Christianity and a preference for the virginal or celibate life was not something he or his generation manufactured. Christian asceticism traces its origins to the practices of Jesus and Paul, who were themselves both celibates. By Augustines time, this strain of religiosity was in full bloom, and he strove to overcome his slavery to lust.The majority of Coopers book, then, is of the formative years of Augustines journey, with little attention given to his time as Bishop of Hippo. Fun and engrossing, this is an easy book to recommend.This book was provided for review by Logos Bible Software and read on their mobile e-book software.

Gordon Dyes new book (which is only part 1 of a 4-part series) is meant to help us think humbly but responsibly. Some questions we have no justification to pretend certainty about. His playground for the topic is religion, which is a perfect arena, since we all think we know all about God.Dyes point is that we dont. Not really. And suppositions compound, so that as we add assumptions on top of assumptions, the probability of accuracy continues to decrease. Yet religious people tend to define certainty in a way that questioning the possibility of error threatens their religious beliefs.So Dye introduces what he calls a certainty notation early in the book, and from that point on, he labels each of his suppositions/projections/claims with his level level of certainty. These notations are (without getting into details):C1 = possibleC2 = probableC3 = extremely probableC4 = certainC5 = true by definitionBrilliant! I wish all religious writers would do the same. This methodology definitely reinforces the concept of absence of certainty. Of course, Dyes level of certainty often differed from mine; what he feels certain about at the level of C3 or C4 I would measure a C1 or C2. Im a more practiced agnostic than he, ha.The point, however, is that C1 through C3no matter how probableshould be categorized in our brain separately from the known facts. That way, when we build upon the foundations of our assumptions, we know which foundations are shaky. Dye uses this approach to discuss the authority of scripture, the need for an afterlife if God is fair, the appropriateness of exclusivity, and the concept of good and evil, among other things.I admit, I kept waiting for Gordon to get to the point. Cant we use these techniques to answer some of the big questions about God? Can we at least decide on the odds of whether theres life after death? No, sorry, Gordon never goes there; he merely uses God as a basis for conversation, beginning with assumptions about His existence, approachability and moral fiber in order to provide practice of thinking without certainty. Dyes most significant conclusion so far is that pluralism is logical. If this book sets the groundwork for more in-depth exercises in later books, then maybe well attack the harder questions later.This book (part 1) is a bit slow, spending an inordinate amount of time on definitions and ideas, so Im hoping for more engrossing discussion from of the next three books.

In case you misread the subtitle, thats physicists, not psychics!Ive seen them myself: arguments from modern physics that prove the existence of the Spirit (or some metaphysical phenomenon that justifies our spirituality or transcendentalism). Ive seen the opposite, too: arguments from modern physics that debunk spirituality.So Wilbers book should be a hit. What do our best mindsthe people who actually understand the physics of Quantum Theory, Relativity, and morehave to say on the topic? Youll recognize a lot of the names in this book: Einstein, Schroedinger, Heisenberg, Bohr, Eddington, Pauli, Plank and more. This is a collection of essays by these men, with brief editing and an introduction by Ken Wilber.Wilber culls the writings of these great minds to uncover their opinions, and discovers that they are virtually unanimous in the opinion that modern science can offer no support for mysticism in any variety. And yet they are all mystics of one sort or another! They simply do not believe modern physics can fully describe the universe we live in. Modern physics isnt in opposition to spirituality, it is simply indifferent to it. Eddington explains: We have learnt that the exploration of the external world by the methods of physical science leads not to a concrete reality but to a shadow world of symbols, beneath which those methods are unadapted for penetrating.If I had to choose a favorite essay, it would be In the Mind of Some Eternal Spirit by Sir James Jeans. Science is not yet in contact with ultimate reality, Jeans insists, and this is no surprise. Any meaning that the universe as a whole may have, would entirely transcend our terrestrial experience and so be totally unintelligible to us. The universe is a mathematical construct butand dont eschew the profundity of this claimthe mathematics enters the universe from above instead of from below. Jeans pictures the universe as consisting of pure thought. While Jeans may be the most daring of the bunch, the dualism of mind and matter is nevertheless a common theme.Fascinating book which starts a bit slow (after a great introduction) and builds from there.

Caution to readers of this review: As a liberal Christian who promotes liberal Christian books, I am a wolf in sheeps clothing who will be held accountable by God for deceiving Christians. That is Laura Daviss reckoning, who calls for Christians to rightly discern doctrine by making sure it aligns with scripture.Dont worry, I didnt just offend my new acquaintance. Davis actively promotes stringent intolerance as a Godly virtue, and couldnt have picked a better book of the Bible for her foundation: that intolerant book of Revelation. Had she been writing about Johns Gospel, I could not have given it four stars. Her stance is quite consistent with the scriptures she reviews, and I appreciate that. Still, I doubt she realized my deep liberal stance before passing her book to me for review, nor did I realize her deep conservative stance when I requested it.He Who Has an Ear covers the seven letters to the seven churches in chapters 2 and 3 of Revelation, and Davis provides a thorough exposition. I also have studied these letters, and the history of the cities to which they are addressed, so I can vouch for her accuracy and depth of research. Not so much for her Greek translation of words like apoktein. The writing is interesting and engaging, so I enjoyed the book.Davis then goes a step further and considers the impact of these letters, their promises and warnings, to todays world. They were all written to churches which no longer exist, but might the letters have more relevance than we think 2,000 years later? Do you see your own church in any of them? (Yes, Laura, I do  I grew up in the church at Ephesus.) If so, the warnings of Jesus should be carefully heeded.One place where I felt Daviss treatment didnt quite jibe with Revelation was her assumption that the gospel is about going to heaven. That the book of life is a list of people going to heaven. As best I can tell, Revelation doesnt say anything at all about going to heaven, and instead suggests the afterlife will be lived on earth.Then Laura begins chapter twelve with the words I dont think this chapter is going to win me any friends. Its her Wolves in Sheeps Clothing List, where she lists the worst offenders by name. This chapter, too, is quite within the spirit of Revelations letters, where John of Patmos invokes the authority of God to condemn both churches and individuals: Balaam, Jezebel, the Nicolaitans. Lauras list of baddies includes Joel Osteen, Kenneth Copeland, Benny Hinn, Rob Bell, and lots more.I confess that I can find nothing very Christlike in a prosperity gospel (that would be folks like Joel Osteen), but Id also be remiss if I didnt challenge Daviss conservative Bible understanding, since she makes it such a personal matter. Davis is fascinated that Rob Bell ignores all mentions of hell in the Bible, and wonders how he reconciles scriptures like Matthew 10:28, Matthew 23:33, Mark 9:43, Revelation 20:15. The answer is, Bell probably reads all of these in the context of first-century idioms and events as Bible scholars should, and recognizes that none of them really have anything to do with the doctrine of eternal punishment. Laura, if you really do want to know why many scholars read scripture differently than you do, Id enjoy chatting with you about it.Davis finally closes her book with precisely the promise made over and over to Revelations audience 2,000 years ago: Jesus is coming soon. A perfect ending. Her book is well-organized, thoughtful, and thought-provoking in a conservative way.

I really enjoyed this one. I asked for a review copy because I had previously devoured Steve Greggs Revelation: Four Views. This guy is an engrossing writer who gets right to the heart of the matter. While Gregg doesnt entirely mask his own opinion, he does manage to fairly represent several alternative views with these books, and this time around he gives voice to the following opinions about hell:  Traditionalists, who stick with the common view of everlasting conscious torment.  Conditionalists, who argue for annihilation of the sinful. The wages of sin is death.  Restorationalists, who insist that hell is a place of rehabilitation. Everyone will eventually find their way to heaven.Universalists, at least those who reason that for God to be victorious no one could find themselves in hell, are not strongly represented in the book. Hell is too real in scripture to dismiss.Its important to emphasize that all three views are solidly founded in scripture. Lots and lots of scriptural references are provided for each view, and all views have thoughtful, scholarly supporters.Wed all like to know the ultimate truth about hell, but I just dont think the scriptures are in total harmony in this matter. Thats where this study led me, though I doubt thats where Gregg meant to lead. The more I study topics like this, the harder it is to believe in Biblical Inerrancy. I remain baffled as to why otherwise thoughtful Bible scholars rage against the obvious  that doctrinal differences in the Bible are a natural result of differing opinions among the Bibles writers.Nevertheless, this is a book to make you think, and to make you appreciate the richness of the Bible even as it examines the most frightening topic known to man.

Coffee with Jesus isnt your everyday comic book. You think its easy putting words on the lips of Jesus, while avoiding the sacrilegious? I get the feeling that Wilkie toned it down just a little to take the edge off. He could have been much more pointed. Yet it really is as amusing as it is serious how Jesus pokes holes in our religiosity, just sipping coffee and offering advice. Jesus gentle sarcasm hits the mark time after time.Its a great book, but I have to point out a couple negatives. The print is small, and the same artwork is repeated throughout. Im guessing there are maybe a dozen unique frames throughout the book, which differ only in the words printed underneath the character drawings.  Whenever Joe, the Pastor, turns to look to the right, the part in his hair magically shifts to his left side  the wonders of mirror imaging. Obviously, youre not buying the book for physical humor or captivating artwork. This format works well for a daily publication; not so much for a book, where the repetitiveness may begin to wear on you.Artwork aside, though, youll fall in love with the personalities and their many character flaws. How like you and me they are, and how patient Jesus is with each of them! Definitely a feel-good book, whether or not Wilkie meant it to be!

This is an introductory philosophy text, complete with worksheets, focusing primarily on the subject of the nature of truth and how we know something to be true. What makes this text unique is that it chooses Christianity for its playground.Do not assume an argument will be presented justifying Christian belief. Apologetics is not the focus at all. The exercises and examples often relate to Christian thinking, but youll find little resolution. In fact, the discussion seems to meander around several philosophy topics without ever zeroing in on any solid answers. The point is to introduce the philosophy of examining truth.Along the way, youll discuss what is means to believe, the nature of religious belief, how God is experienced, providence, cause and effect, dualism, even miracles and the afterlife. Finally, Vick touches on the friction between science and faith, and the role of both. Its an appropriate finish, and the book closes with an enigmatic discovery: One cannot reasonably claim that knowledge results only from one kind of experience, or only from one method of understanding the world. In other words, science and faith should cooperate in the search for truth.My favorite section was a discussion of self-deception. Is such a thing even possible? This topic borders on the psychological. Does anyone ever really hold contradictory beliefs, or does one simply refuse to acknowledge the contradiction?I cant say this book is what I expected, but I did enjoy the study!

And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his purpose. Romans 8:28If ever there was a testament to the comfort of believing in God, this book is it. I cannot share all of Pamelas beliefs (which are too conservative for my taste), but I rejoice in the comfort her God brings into her life, through good times and bad. I cant help but award it five stars: warm, honest and heart-felt, this book is certain inspiration to believers.Pamela tells of outgrowing the solemn way that was a burden to her in her childhood, into a full trust in the boundary-crossing grace of God. She grew up in the same Christian sect as I did, which she calls the One True Way to highlight its exclusiveness. No single belief system is right for everyone, and this one simply could not satisfy Pams spiritual needs. She found the church meetings suppressive and joyless. While she was still a child, a close friend died in an accident, who was outside the exclusive boundaries of the sect. Was this friend going to heaven or not? Pamela was distraught, until one day, God gently pointed out Proverbs 20:11 (Even a child is known by his acts) and Genesis 18:25 (Should not the judge of all the earth do right?) Gods love was greater than she had ever been taught. Still, the emotional turmoil of leaving behind the religious tradition she had been born into was very strong. Telling her parents of her change in beliefs was the hardest thing she ever did.Choose this day whom you will serve. Put away the gods that your fathers served beyond the river and in Egypt and serve the LordJoshua 24:14-15Also hard was the first time Pamela attended another church. All such churches had been condemned by her former belief system. But had she never made the transition away from exclusivism, she would never have been able to draw strength from the God of grace for the greater test around the corner. Her husband contracted cancer, and began slowly wasting away.Romans 8:28 became Pamelas rainbow in a world of pain. The end result of the long, cancerous journey with her Godly husband is this book, about the goodness of God.Definitely recommended.

The Christian canon refers to that set of scriptures, complete and bounded, that we accept as scripture. Modern Bible scholars often examine the development of the canon from an extrinsic model, noting that the canon was formed over the course of several centuries as the church fathers selected their favorites. Many argue that Irenaeus, in the late second century, was the first to feel the need for an authoritative canon. But what if the selection of accepted writings was more intrinsic  that is, guided from within, rather than from without? What if the New Testament writers themselves understood that they were writing Scripture, and their work was quickly recognized and adopted as such, perhaps with Gods guidance?Kruger doesnt deny the extrinsic claims, that the canon was fluid and argued over for centuries. He simply highlights the evidence that our New Testament writers were knowingly writing Scripture, and our earliest Scripture readers knew it. This Kruger does by critically examining five tenets of the extrinsic model to see if they really do hold water. The five tenets he questions, in five chapters, are:1. We must make a sharp distinction between Scripture and canon.2. There was nothing in earliest Christianity that might have led to a canon.3. Early Christians were averse to written documents.4. The New Testament authors were unaware of their own authority.5. The New Testament books were first regarded as Scripture at the end of the second century.Kruger hits his stride at about chapter three, and it gets stronger from there. So if you find the book winding up a little slowly, I promise itll be slinging fast balls by the end. Krugers research is convincing and well-argued, with generous footnotes. At the very least, this book will make you a believer in the passion and conviction of the New Testament writers, even as they sought to remain anonymous, letting the gospel message speak for itself on its own authority.

Can a downer be a positive reading experience?This is a book that needs to be read, even though its not enjoyable. Its about how to relate positively to those who are going through hard times. How to be a friend in love. Its written from a Christian perspective by an Episcopal priest, but it does not pretend that faith solves all the hard problems.Schmidts younger brother Dave was struck with cancer, and endured seven years of the disease before succumbing to death. Sometimes life just sucks. Hoping for a handy guidebook about what to do in such situations, maybe a collection of pick-me-up promises like God wont give you more than you can endure or at least a cant-fail casserole recipe to bake for a suffering friend, I read all the way through to the end before I finally accepted that I was not going to be given any Biblical solutions for coping or helping another cope. This is just down-to-earth advice on how to validate and share the pain of another. As Schmidt would say, ditch the stained-glass language and learn to walk wounded.And yes, it WAS a frustrating read for me, most of the way. If Im going to endure a downer of a book, cant it just teach me to dispense a little Hallmark wisdom and send me on my way?Perhaps the best advice I gleaned from the first nine chapters (by reading between the lines) is this: When times get tough, go befriend a couple of recovering alcoholics. They understand struggle and neither coddle you nor make light of your pain.Schmidts message finally sank in as I neared the end of the book, with these three strange words: Availability is incarnational. Its really not as cryptic a message as it sounds. After stressing that Jesus interface with humanity was in the fleshincarnationaland after stressing that sincere love is sharing a genuine presence, making oneself available, the advice finally hit home. Theres lots of other advice in the book, of course, this just happens to be the message that finally penetrated for me. The simple secret of dealing with anothers grief, for both your own benefit and that of your friend, is this: Availability is incarnational.

Im a fan of Robert Cornwalls writing. Its hard to overrate brevity, common sense, and simple honesty. Last year, one of his books made my Top Ten for 2012: See Faith in the Public Square.In this book, Cornwall tackles the sticky subject of evolution. He writes as a theologian, not a scientist, but as one who recognizes his limited expertise and therefore respects and appreciates the contribution of scientists. Cornwall believes evolution is true not only because our greatest minds have offered convincing explanations, but because they have made great strides in medicine by building atop this biological knowledge. Cornwall believes the war between science and religion harms both sides, and that truth can best be approached by leaving the experts on each side to do their jobs without interference.Cornwall is not alone in this opinion. A few years back, Dr. Michael Zimmerman penned a letter encouraging the compatibility of religion and science, and this letter has now garnered over 10,000 clergy signatures. Evolution Sunday was born, marking the closest Sunday to the birthday of Charles Darwin (February 12th), and at last count nearly 600 churches celebrated this day by using their worship service to address the issue, declaring that evolutionary science and faith are compatible.Worshiping with Charles Darwin is a series of non-technical sermons and essays to that end. Many of the points and themes repeat in multiple sermons/essays, so theres a bit of redundancy, yet I believe this book fills an important niche, with the theologian side of the war respectfully reaching out to make peace.

This beautiful full-color book highlights the major personalities in Christian development over the last 2,000 years  from A.D. 64 to 2009.Its a short book, so I confess I felt a little frustrated at the lack of depth. The book takes on a little too big a topic for 188 pages of text, and religion is a topic where oversimplifying by bouncing along the surface can distort as much as elucidate. Therefore, to get the full benefit of the book, treat it like an instruction course and take advantage of the internet research suggestions peppered throughout the text. But for my money (for a lot more money, Im sure) Id love to have 600 pages between the covers of this one.One other minor frustration: Jones is a Southern Baptist whose subtle preaching permeates the book. For example, Deism is at least twice referred to as a false doctrine. This is probably just a personal issue, but I find it easier to trust a scholar who does a better job of hiding his own religious bias.With my complaints out of the way, let me say that I thoroughly enjoyed reading the text! Its a fun read, full of tidbits from history and helpful explanations of Christian terms. Every Christian should know at least the basics of Church history, and I definitely recommend this book as an entertaining stepping stone to whet your appetite for further in-depth reading.

Are you into graphic novels? I've never considered them my thing, always picturing such texts as little more than a comic book. So I was surprised to enjoy this one as much as I did.A graphic novel attempts to communicate on a different level, with penetrating images. The artistic lines and colors, at least in this book, are vibrant, stark, evocative, powerful ... this is a visual journey with a serious tone.Messiah: Origin is the beginning of the gospel story, from the birth of Jesus through the ministry of John the Baptist. I presume it's the first publication of a series. What sets this "novel" apart is that it contains no words except as translated directly from the Greek of the New Testament. It is a narrative harmony of the four Gospels, translated by Mark Arey, a Greek Orthodox clergyman, arranged in story form by Matt Dorff, and illustrated by Kai Carpenter ... an effective partnership.Definitely recommended as an enjoyable and moving story, though anticlimactic ... I do wish I had more of the story of Jesus to read.

I received a sample for an honest review, and promptly gave it to my significant other to try it out. :) She enjoyed it as a skin moisturizer. It comes in a cold-pressed tub but quickly turns to liquid as it contacts your skin. A little greasy at first, but quickly absorbs into the skin. Great smell if you love coconut; I do. We haven't yet tried it as a cooking aid, though it actually tastes good!
Soft and smooth - once you get them properly adjusted for the size of the strap, you will hardly notice them. They turn the day into night.

I wanted just two of these (one for work, one for home) but it was less expensive to buy four.These are AMAZING. They telescope like an old-fashioned radio antenna (simple pull/push), but do not terminate in a thin and flimsy final extension.  The final extension is plenty heavy to do the job without significant flexing.I was concerned that the antenna-like structure would tend to bend/collapse when put under stress, but this has not been the case. I can easily extend/collapse the scratcher by hand, but I have not been able to affect it by normal use.
Fresh and aromatic.  Helped me prepare an Ethiopian dish for the first time - it came out GREAT.
One of my top ten all-time movies.  My family agrees.

Sous vide is a completely new and revolutionary (and FANTASTIC) way of cooking. But the best chefs in the world would not have the faintest idea how to cook this way without some expert instruction.DO NOT try sous vide at home without expert instruction. You WILL NOT succeed. You won't even get close! You will try to apply your knowledge of traditional cooking, and you will DESTROY everything you attempt to cook.You need an expert!  And Jason Logsdon is an expert. He breaks down the entire process and explains how everything works. And he finishes with an extensive index of time/temperature guides to every type of food you can imagine (and several that I've never even heard of).

The very first sentence set the tone for the book. LEARN SPANISH, YOU DUMB ANGLICAN GRINGO. The first FOUR chapters were devoted to this theme, including a Spanish language primer. OK, I get it. Would you PLEASE tell me something about living in Loja that doesn't involve the importance of learning Spanish, or the syntax of the language?The middle chapters of this thin book did finally talk about living in Loja. But I found almost nothing that I did not already know by reading just a little bit on expat blogs and forums. The author is young, but most interested readers are probably retirees (like me). The author brought very little with her to Ecuador. We are interested in bringing 40-foot containers chock full of high-end stuff (how do we do that? What are the customs rules?)  How do we apply for permanent residency?  Can we bring a car? Do we pay Ecuadorian tax on our retirement income?The final chapters were devoted to places OTHER THAN Loja.If you are an Anglican gringo and are interested in Loja then you probably already know more than this book will tell you. I say that because you have already done your research (Loja is kinda off the gringo radar). Get a book about living in one of the larger cities, and beat yourself over the head with a LEARN SPANISH stick, and you will know how to live like a local in Loja.

Sharp and effective even at the very tips. Easily cuts through fish and chicken bones. I'm not so sure about the utility of the other "functions" compared to dedicated tools. I can't imagine myself ever using these scissors as a screwdriver (???) or a peeler.  But I don't care about that. I bought scissors, and these are great scissors. And they come apart (only when I want them to) for perfect cleaning. There is no such thing as a pair of "kitchen scissors" that don't come apart.

WOAH.  I tried my first Ethiopian recipe. It called for this unfamiliar spice. OK, fine - I bought these seeds.The moment I cut open the package, I knew this was something different.  Pungent.  Aromatic.  And then I put a few pods into my spice grinder.WOAH.  This is LEGAL?

ARE YOU KIDDING ME? Where has this been all my life???We typically cook with time.  We use a heat source much hotter than we want the food to be. Nobody wants a casserole to actually reach 375 degrees. We all know what happens if it does.We want it to maybe get to 150-160, and then take it out of the overheated oven. Timing is critical to avoid undercooking or overcooking.With sous vide, you cook with temperature, not time. You use a water bath at a precisely controlled temperature.  This is the temperature that you want your food to achieve (all the way through). So you CANNOT overcook your food, because it will never get hotter than the bath. You CANNOT undercook your food if you leave it in the bath for the minimum time. So your food is PERFECT every time.Your idea of "perfect" might not be the same as mine.  Expect to do a bit of experimentation at first. If you cook above 130 degrees (F) then your food will never be unsafe - it is considered Pasteurized, and free from any harmful bacteria or parasites (131 degrees is the perfect mid-rare steak, BTW). Once you find YOUR ideal temperature, you can reproduce it EVERY SINGLE TIME without fail.Tough cuts of meat (typically smoked, in BBQ) such as beef brisket, pork shoulder roast (Boston butt), and ribs will be THE MOST TENDER THING YOU HAVE EVER EATEN.  Rib meat literally FALLS OFF THE BONE (try sous vide baby back ribs - pure heaven). Forget about slicing a sous vide pot roast - it crumbles beneath a knife. The cheapest cuts of meat become tender delicacies that your family can't eat fast enough.This is a revolutionary approach to cooking that is NOTHING like regular cooking.  DO NOT TRY THIS AT HOME without some expert guidance.  I am indebted to expert author Jason Logsdon for his book, "Modernist Cooking Made Easy: Sous Vide: The Authoritative Guide to Low Temperature Precision Cooking" which I highly recommend. You will learn about the importance (and the method) of searing certain meats to achieve the Maillard reaction (the same reaction that makes golden bread crust so tasty).I created my own sous vide bath "appliance" using an Igloo 12-Quart Quantum Cooler. The lid has two molded cup holders. I used a 2.5" hole saw to drill a hole in one of the holder depressions. This is a perfect fit for the Anova cooker (the black part must be able to "breathe"). The insulated walls of the cooler make this HIGHLY energy efficient and help maintain the precision temperature.AND HERE'S A FREE BONUS FOR READING THIS FAR: a scientist (me) weighs in on two "confrontational" sous vide topics:1) Sear meat BEFORE you sous vide it, not afterward. The scientific rationale:  We don't want to impart any more heat into the meat than necessary to achieve the tasty Mallard reaction.  We want to impart heat only onto the surface, not into the core. It is TRUE that searing cold meat will impart MORE heat into the core (since the thermal gradient is higher, which accelerates heat transfer). However, this heat should fall well below our intended target temperature, so it does not affect the outcome.  HOWEVER, if you prepare the perfect mid-rare steak at 131 degrees and THEN sear it, you will impart SOME additional heat into the core that you do NOT want.  SOME of the meat (near the surface) will exceed the target temperature, and become overcooked.2) You DO NOT need to get the bath to your target temperature BEFORE you begin cooking. You should always start out with fresh hot tap water in your bath. This will already be 120-130 degrees (F). It is ALREADY significantly hotter than whatever you are putting in the bath. Heat transfer begins immediately.  It might take a few minutes more for the bath temperature to stabilize at your target, but the food has been heated the whole time.

It costs $35 for me to rent a steamer for 5 hours, or $50 for a full day.  This thing pays for itself quickly, as steaming bathroom wallpaper is a difficult thing to do. We did an hour or two a day, and it took two weeks just to strip the wallpaper.  And I highly recommend the three-headed Zinsser 2976 PaperTiger Scoring Tool, which will give better coverage in less time with less effort.AND IT COMES WITH A NARROW HEAD.  That is NOWHERE in the product description, but it was in the box!

These are finely-ground chips for use in a tool like The Smoking Gun.  These are not what you would want to use in your backyard BBQ.  I really like the variety.  And, since the wood reservoir of a Smoking Gun is about the size of a thimble, this set will last me a LONG time.I wish the assortment included peach, which is killer-good on pork.  Peach would be better than maple (a much more limited smoking wood).  But I won't deduct a star for not including it.
Well designed and easy to use (if you know how to use a slide rule).

I believe this is the only printed text of the title essay, Christian Reunion.  And, since it is now out-of-print, you better get your used copy while the gettin' is good.I bought the book specifically for this essay.  Lewis is a traditional Anglican, and this essay reads like an open letter to Catholics describing the obstacles to reunion of the two faiths.  Spoiler: he is not optimistic.  He presents no "master plan."In typical Lewis fashion, he deals with the topic at a high level, and does not get mired in minutiae.As a Catholic who was formerly Anglican, I have experienced both worlds.  Lewis treats both the Anglican and the Catholic viewpoints correctly and fairly.The essay is only a few pages long, but it is a very worthwhile read.

This is some Italian tribute band.  This album is available to me through Amazon Prime Music, so I listened to a couple of my favorite DS songs, Telegraph Road and Brothers in Arms.  I don't know why these are marked [EXPLICIT] - they are straight covers.  The playing of the instruments is outstanding, but the singer doesn't enunciate his words very well and he's difficult to understand.  If I didn't already know the lyrics then I would have missed half of them.

This is a sturdy cabinet. The heavy-gauge steel door is recessed (with close tolerances) when locked, making it more difficult to pry open.I give it two stars because the locks are crap.  I was able to pick BOTH locks in about ten minutes with no lockpicking skills other than what I learned in a 15-minute YouTube video. I had access to a pair of needle-nose pliers, a paperclip, a hairpin (yes, a hairpin), a hammer, and a hard surface to suffice for an anvil. I was able to fashion a tension wrench and a rake and pick both locks.  These are the ONLY locks I have EVER tried to pick, and they both yielded in less than five minutes each.  With some practice, I could probably pick both locks in a half-minute or less.Why put crap locks on a good cabinet?  A simple barrel-lock would have completely defeated me (and most anyone else).

Are you KIDDING me?  THREE universal stainless BBQ pipes that perfectly fit my big Smoke Hollow grille for ELEVEN DOLLARS with free Prime shipping?  My local "discount" hardware store wanted eighteen dollars EACH for the exact same product. They work perfectly.I can't spend my money fast enough. I've ordered two spare sets. I'm good for 20 years.
A faithful Brown Scapular.

I have TWO problems with Chromecast.The first is that it DOES NOT CAST everything on my Android phone.  It supports a FEW apps. Umm, scuse me, but myracast casts EVERYTHING. It's more expensive, but it does EVERYTHING.Second, Chromecast is REALLY crappy when I source it from my Sony receiver. There are LOTS of "snowflakes" and a solid bottom bar of static. It works just great if I connect it directly to one of my TV's HDMI ports, but this completely bypasses my awesome 7.2 surround-sound receiver/speaker system and forces me to turn up the volume in my dinky TV speakers.
I have feet issues (from DVT, not diabetes). I could not discern that this lotion did anything whatsoever to alleviate this.
Twisted Veins HDMI cables are da bomb!  These short cables are PERFECT for hooking up the backplane on my HDMI center.
Perfect to hook up my Sony 5-CD player to my receiver.  Heavy cables but not too long as to create a mess in my backplane.
Not OEM, but works just as well.
Not OEM, but works just as well.
It works fine, and was OK for my needs, but why not include a ground terminal? That seems like a pretty significant oversight.  And it would just be a pass-thru.

These filters work great, but are WAY overpriced.  Here's how to filter your Cat Mate bowl without paying an arm and a leg:The filters have a blue plastic housing that easily snaps apart with a small screwdriver.  If you open it up, you will see that the innards consist of a fibrous filter fabric and some activated charcoal pellets.You can change out these innards for pennies instead of dollars.The fibrous filter fabric can be replaced by HVAC vent register filters (4 x 12), which can be found on Amazon for $3.50 (with Prime shipping) for a dozen.  These filters are exactly the correct width, but are (obviously) too long, so they need to be cut.  You can try scissors, but I could not get satisfactory results.  Instead I used a guillotine paper trimmer with a stop-guard, and was able to quickly and easily create many perfectly sized filters.  A dozen register filters will produce 72 fibrous filters (each register filter will produce six Cat Mate filters).The Cat Mate filters use a pellet form of activated charcoal behind the fibrous filter (pellets are "tubes" of activated charcoal, usually more than a half-inch long).  I believe this is a very ineffective filter, especially at such a shallow filter depth (typically just one pellet deep).  Water (and crud) will tend to flow BETWEEN the inevitable gaps between the pellets.  I prefer Marineland GRANULAR activated charcoal, which provides a more dense surface area.I award two stars (instead of one) because these filters do work.  I recommend that you buy at least three of these (one of which came with your Cat Mate bowl).

These are small, flimsy plastic lanterns, but they produce a lot of LED light and are easy on batteries.I got them for "emergency lighting" when the power goes out.  They are ideal for this purpose.I would not want to take them backpacking or camping, because I don't think they would survive in my pack. But I won't deduct a star because that's not what I intended to do with them.  I'm just warning others who might have something else in mind.

I was excited to see a three-port switch (with remote control) at such an affordable price.But I have had nothing but problems.Only port-1 is reliable.  Port-2 is completely non-functional.  Port-3 works less than half the time (when it doesn't work, I see old-fashioned static followed by a blank screen, and this cycle repeats forever).What good is a three-port switch if only one port works?

These things are insane - and not in a good way.The taste is revolting.  They leave your mouth with a numb sensation (which actually provides some relief from the revolting flavor).They exacerbate whatever stress I was encountering.  I still have the stress, but now I have a foul taste and a numb mouth to go along with it.

ANYTHING by Dr. Damian Conway, by default, gets five stars.  He's probably the most brilliant person I've ever met (at OSCON).I'm a Computer Scientist trained decades ago in procedural programming methods. Dr. Conway gave me the best insight into object oriented programming that I have ever encountered.

Finally - a sling that supports my HAND as well as my forearm.  I wear a sling occasionally when I over-stress my right shoulder, which I dislocated a few years back. Sometimes it just needs a day or two of rest.But other slings failed to support my arm below the wrist.  My hand would just flop around unless I used my muscles to secure it - some of the same muscles that I was trying to rest.See the guy in the picture?  That could be me.  I'm a "full size" 6-foot man with long arms, and this sling extends almost to my fingertips.  FINALLY.

The were "clean" but I don't care for the pellet form.  They are said to be "prewashed" and, indeed, I did not find any carbon residue when I washed them.But some pellets were more than an inch long.  This is like a lot of sticks - they form a lattice structure that water can pass AROUND, not THROUGH.  I think this form is not as effective as granular carbon.  I switched to Marineland granular carbon.

I have circulation issues in my lower extremities (DVT, not diabetes).  This causes a thickening of the skin on my feet.  This little gizmo is AMAZING. You can actually SEE the thing in action (puffs of "white smoke" prove that it is doing its job).The stone is pumice (a common exfoliant).  Pumice will readily grind dry skin, but has little effect on healthy soft skin. I see reviews where people complain that the stone doesn't last very long.  Those people must have cast-iron feet, if they regularly wear down a VOLCANIC ROCK.This thing is about the same price as a nice pedicure.  But you only need to buy it once.

I got the pump, filled it up and plugged it in.  Wow, what a racket!  Well, it's in a bathroom that is rarely used.A week later, I rinsed it out, removing the upper part for the first time (it just lifts off).  And there's the filter - WRAPPED IN PLASTIC.  I removed the plastic wrap and now the pump is barely audible (and the flow is obviously improved).My cats were skeptical at first (especially considering the noise), but grew to accept it (even with the noise) after a few days.  They prefer drinking from the upper tiers (especially the middle one) where the water is moving more and is shallow.  Other fountains don't have such tiers (even units costing significantly more).I was able to make it even quieter by placing a rubber pad (an old mouse pad) under it.  Now I can barely hear it.The intake holes (those dark spots below the waterline on the right side of the photo) are small enough to keep most things out (even most hairs) and, of course, nothing is getting past the filter.Despite being on the bottom end of the price range, this is a superior fountain (once you UNWRAP THE FILTER!)

Good board, but get the GigaByte GA-970A-D3P instead. The boards are identical in every way, except the GA-970A-D3P has more advanced multimedia capability on the riser (an optical OUT and additional audio jacks).  And, at the time of this writing, the GA-970A-D3P does more but is five dollars less, and Prime shipping is available.  I deducted a star because this board is not as good of a value as a less-expensive model by the same fine manufacturer.Both boards offer plenty of expansion slots and memory slots.  Plenty of USB capacity - six 2.0 and two 3.0 ports on the riser, and there are standard pin-headers for both USB 2.0 (six extra ports) and USB 3.0 (two extra ports) for either extra slot plates (not included, but widely available for a low price) or ports built into a case.  So, overall, the board supports 12 USB 2.0 and four USB 3.0 connectors - impressive.Good placement of main power connectors clears even the largest of heatsink fans (such as my huge Cooler Master Hyper T4 120-mm fan CPU cooler). A large fan will hang over the memory banks, so modules with tall heat spreaders might interfere (my Corsair XMS3 4GB (2x2GB) DDR3 modules fit with about 2mm to spare, but I can't install or swap them with the heatsink installed, so plug in your memory before you mount your heatsink).Support for six SATA ports and easy-to-use BIOS (including multiple boot device selection - hit F12) is really nice.  Plenty of fan support (1 CPU, three case fans).  FWIW, I am using this board for an OpenSUSE 11.2 Linux server, and SUSE sees all the components just fine (including the built-in LAN).

I liked every flavor except the chili lime shrimp (way too heavy on fake tasting chili seasoning).  The noodles are the same in every package; the difference is the artificial flavoring powder that is added during preparation.  It's a quick, inexpensive, and satisfying meal, but with little nutritional value (negligible vitamins and minerals).The front of the package warns, "See nutrition label for sodium content."  And I saw that the average content was around 960 mg per serving (about 40% of USRDA).  That didn't sound too bad.  EXCEPT, upon closer examination, I see that a "serving" is half a pack.  If you eat a whole pack (and, who doesn't?) with the entire seasoning package, you are getting DOUBLE that amount - almost the entire sodium allotment for a whole day.  The directions "helpfully" point out that you can reduce the sodium by "simply" using less of the seasoning packet (the noodles themselves have very little sodium, and very little flavor).  Well, of course, less seasoning means less flavor.  I used about half of the seasoning, which gave it a little flavor, but still fairly bland.  And, instead of enjoying it like a soup, with the broth, I used a fork and drained the noodles and discarded the leftover broth.It would be SO easy to package the spices and salt separately.  This would give consumers complete control over the sodium content without sacrificing the seasoning and flavor.  That would have won five stars and a glowing review.  But the high sodium and, especially, the deceptive packaging are problematic.

OK, this is strange - I wanted to review the Pepp sticks and the Turkey sticks separately, but the same review shows up on both products.  So I will combine the review:The Pepp sticks are good, but I recommend the Old Wisconsin Turkey Sticks instead.  The taste is VERY similar, but the turkey sticks have half the fat and significantly less sodium (250 mg, compared to 320 mg).The product description says "No refrigeration required" but the package says (in bold lettering) "Refrigerate after opening."  So the "no refrigeration" applies only to the unopened package.  However, I don't follow the label, and a package will last me about ten days (sealed and stored at room temperature at my desk) and I have not had a problem with mold or other spoilage.  That's just my experience - your results may vary, and don't blame me if you get food poisoning.FYI, if you like these, then I DO NOT recommend the Old Wisconsin Beef Sticks, which are rather bland.NOTE - the package is not resealable.  You will need to supply your own ziplock bag or something to keep them sealed and fresh.My five-star review applies to the Turkey Sticks for being almost as flavorful as the Pepp but with much less fat and sodium.

Clear lenses, lightweight, comfortable, and a SCREAMING good value (with Prime shipping!).  The hinges and not spring-loaded but they are stiff, so the glasses stay put just fine.  My head is larger than average (I always buy the XL size hat) but these fit just fine.  The vinyl nose pads can be bent to fit whatever shape nose bridge you have (but they work fine out of the package for me).  I have no problem wearing these for hours at a time - the lens is just the right size to allow comfortable extended reading but not so large that it's difficult to look over the lens at a more distant object, or to alternate between close-up and farther-away.  And they are quite stylish!
My wife loved these whimsical decorations.  She put them in a large potted plant.  We don't inflict them upon our neighbors.

Essential for USB drives, which are getting smaller and smaller, and are easily misplaced or overlooked without a colorful strap.  It's impractical to label most USB drives, so the different colors help me tell them apart.  Great for small cameras, cellphones, etc.  They are well made, but I don't think I would trust them with something particularly heavy, such as a full-size SLR camera or camcorder.  FYI, the small wrist lanyards are fixed and the larger neck lanyards are detachable.

Really tight compression (which is good), but I bought the largest size and I wear a size 10 shoe.  If my foot were larger, the socks would probably feel too tight.  The graduated compression makes them comfortable to wear for a few hours at a time, but I wouldn't want to wear these for more than three or four hours without taking a break.  They are heavy and durable and look pretty snazzy.  The heavily reinforced heel should contribute to the durability of the product.They're great for people with DVTs (blood clots) which can cause the feet to swell.  But I would recommend a different approach for plantar fasciitis. PF is caused by the Achilles tendon (which runs down the calf) being too tight.  The Achilles tendon (AT) is anchored to the ankle bone, which also anchors the plantar fascia (the thing that hurts).  The AT is much stronger than the PF, so the ankle is pulled backwards and upwards, stretching the PF and causing heel/arch pain.  These socks will lift and support the PF, countering the pull of the AT, which will give relief from heel pain, but it's just treating the symptom (pain) and not treating the problem (the overly-tight AT).  The preferred approach for PT is to stretch out the Achilles tendon to relieve pressure on the ankle.  This is simple to do - if you have stairs nearby, stand on a step and hold the handrail (if you don't have stairs, make do with something you can stand on like s step).  Stand on the front part of your foot, allowing your arch and ankle to hang over the edge.  Slowly allow your heel to drop down and hold it there for three or four minutes.  Do not bounce up and down - keep steady pressure.  This will stretch the Achilles tendon (you will feel a mild burning sensation in your calf).  Discontinue or reduce pressure if you feel pain or burning at the back of your ankle (which tells you you're overdoing it).  Do this two or three times a day and you should experience relief.

Well, they are exactly what they say.  I used them for an electric bike conversion project (48 volt) and they work great.  They would be fine for any other DC application, such as golf carts (also typically 48 volts).
My wife and I both have this phone, and we both love it.

OK, maybe I just don't know how to use a double boiler.  I got this pot for a particular recipe.  As I understand it, you put some water in the lower pot, which boils, creating steam, which imparts indirect heat to the upper pot, which holds whatever food you are preparing.  This indirect heat prevents overheating (or very localized heating) for the food in the upper pot.But the two pots fit SO CLOSELY together that DISASTER is the ONLY possible outcome.  The steam builds pressure in the lower pot, but cannot escape, so it forces the upper pot off.  At best, the upper pot is merely displaced, while steam and water pour over the sides of the lower pot.  At worst, the upper pot comes completely off and lands on its side, spilling whatever was in it (this is more likely if the contents of the upper pot were heavier).I'm thinking that the only way to salvage this purchase is to drill some holes in the side of the lower pot, near the bottom of the upper pot, to allow steam to escape.I look at other Amazon reviews, which do not mention this obvious problem, so maybe I don't know how to properly use this pot.  Hopefully someone can enlighten me, before I start drilling holes.

I got this as a whimsical gift for my teenage daughter - she LOVES it.  It's a lot of fun for a small price.The "white light" setting is heavily skewed towards the blue spectrum.  I would not want to read by this bulb.  But it's fun to play with, and the remote is intuitive and entertaining.

I loaned my original adapter to my son (a United States Marine) who shortly thereafter was deployed to the Middle East, taking my adapter with him.  This replacement works perfectly for my 1-TB Seagate external USB hard drive.

I have chronic DVTs in both legs, and I have had this condition for years, so I know exactly what my symptoms are.  This was recommended by a friend (a woman).  I have found no benefit whatsoever after more than three months of use.Maybe this is supposed to help varicose veins (which I do not have - this is mostly a problem for mothers).  It does nothing for my DVT.
Good, sturdy basket.  The illustration is NOT proportional to the size - go by the measurements, which are accurate.  Easily holds a heavy 12-volt lead-acid battery for my electric bike conversion.

Great value.  Doesn't try to do too much (no clock, for example, meaning no daylight saving time hassles).At first I was a bit disconcerted because the outdoor and indoor readings were five degrees apart, even though the outdoor sensor was in the same room.  The directions say to allow an hour for the sensors to settle out (they are slow to react, which is what you want - so that a brief breeze doesn't swing the scale).  After an hour, the readings were 0.4 degrees F different, which is within the tolerance of the instrument (+/-1 degree).

I don't know if this really helps me.  I'm on prescription BP meds, and I take this as well.  My BP is managed in an acceptable range.  How much does the CoQ10 contribute to that?  I have no idea.  But I don't want to go off of it as a test.  The risk of taking this is low, but the risk of coming off of it could be high.
I really don't know if this helps me or not.  I seem to do better when I take it, but that could just be a placebo effect.  But a placebo effect IS an effect.

Editor Alicia von Stamwitz provides a brief introduction to The Spirit of Saint Francis in which she characterizes both Pope Francis and Francis of Assisi. She emphasizes the pope's optimism, courage, and "playful sense of humor reminiscent of the beloved saint."The book is divided into 10 chapters, each containing roughly 18 titled, single-page quotations. Chapter themes reflect major principles of Franciscan spirituality such as discover true joy, do not forget the poor, and choose simplicity and humility. Quotations are taken from official Vatican texts of Pope Francis's homilies, speeches, tweets, audiences, prayers, daily meditations, and writing. The source is provided for each.In one entry, the pope outlines his "ideal" prayer practice, which includes Lauds, lectio divina, Mass, work, lunch, siesta, Vespers, Office of Readings, afternoon work, Adoration, rosary followed by dinner. "And then I'm done." After presenting this schedule, the pope refers to a member of the staff: "I look at Sandro's face and he laughs and says: `But you don't do this!'" Francis agrees.Tweets from @Pontifex are sprinkled throughout the book; for example:* Your sins are great? Just tell the Lord: forgive me, help me to get up again, change my heart!"* To be friends with God means to pray with simplicity, like children talking to their parents.* Every Christian can witness to God in the workplace, not only with words, but above all with an honest life.The editor points out the care taken in choosing and arranging the material while reminding readers that no single approach to using the book is better than another. "Let your experience and curiosity be your guide," she writes. "Trust it, trust yourself, and trust that the message you most need to hear will find you."

In his latest book, Psychologist Robert J. Wicks addresses spiritual resilience, which he defines as "bouncing back in a way that deeper knowledge of both God and self may result." Wicks is best known for his work in integrating psychology and spirituality. His practice is focused on those in the helping professions, including ministry.The central tenet of this work, intended for the general population, is "Be clear and be not afraid for you are loved by God." The book is presented as 30 points meant to build greater responsiveness to God and closer solidarity with others. The points are laid out as "days," each beginning with a short phrase and ending with a suggestion or question.The first 14 days, grouped under the heading Spiritual Strength: A Psychological Resource during Difficult Times, address faith, prayer, and spirituality in times of crisis and loss. The next eight days, under the heading Uncovering and Addressing the Enemies of a Healthy Spiritual Psychological Perspective, relate to self-esteem problems; negativity; and anxieties due to inordinate fear of failure, doubt, and change. The final six days, headed Reaching Out...without Being Pulled Down, tackle the issue of preventing burn-out in the process of extending ourselves to others.All three parts of the book have at least one day dedicated to silence and solitude, emphasizing the importance of prayer and listening to God. Other overarching themes include opening our hearts to contemplation and greater appreciation of true simplicity. Wicks offers truly useful insights for everyday seekers in a down-to-earth format based on his own experience and writings of numerous teachers and healers throughout the ages.

Sacred Silence opens with Phyllis Zagano's observation that we need to "select among the great kaleidoscope of choices life puts before us in such a way as to fulfill our legitimate desires without disrupting our own or others' lives." She suggests that the stillness and silence of Lent can help us decide what we need and want. Instead of the typical approach of doing better at something or not doing something at all, she recommends that we practice silence with an open heart before the Lord.Each daily reflection begins with a title, list of Old and New Testament readings, and short quote from the gospel. Next comes a meditation on the gospel that may include a personal example, proposed activity, or simply a deeper look at the passage. The reflection ends with "A Grace for Today," a one-line original prayer.The following points from Wednesday of Holy Week, titled Spy Wednesday, show how it all fits together. The passage from Matthew (26:14-25) addresses Judas's betrayal of Jesus. Zagano recognizes three internal storms: (1) the disciples are confused and frightened, (2) Jesus is devastated, (3) Judas is troubled and will become more disturbed by his action. In our own lives, we experience these same reactions when tempted to sin. "Evil so often masquerades as some good," writes Zagano, and "Every sin moves us, each and all, further away from life in Christ." The Grace for Today: Lord, help me understand the nature of sin."

Introducing his latest book, Pat McCloskey, O.F.M., explains that the phrase "Peace and Good" is the greeting Francis of Assisi offered to everyone he met. The daily meditations McCloskey presents are based on writings by and about Francis grouped into 12 topics reflecting Franciscan themes. The monthly format consists of a two-page introduction followed by a page for each day with three sections: (1) a meditation on the theme, (2) Living as Francis Did, and (3) Growing with Francis. These last two, containing only a few lines, connect the teachings of Francis to our own lives.For example, the March section opens with the observation that most popular conversion stories are based on a specific event, such as Francis embracing a leper for the first time. However, McCloskey writes, the encounter with that leper and several other dramatic events in Francis' story were an integral part of a lifelong faith journey.The March 18 meditation, Step by Step, is a letter from Francis in which he asks God to grant "that we may do for your sake alone what we know you want us to do, and always what pleases you." Under Living as Francis Did, McCloskey reminds us the interior enlightenment Francis describes takes time. "The ante keeps going up, so to speak. We are tempted to tell God that we have done enough, that God should count on someone else for whatever may leave our consciences unsettled."The March 30 meditation, Do It, features an incident in which Francis was flooded by "a very great sweetness" that renewed his spirit, seemingly changing him into another man. Under Living as Francis Did, McCloskey addresses this change in Francis: "He retained his original DNA and fingerprints, but his heart became ever new and young."Pat McCloskey, O.F.M., a priest since 1975, is a Friar Minor of the Province of St. John the Baptist, headquartered in Cincinnati, Ohio. He serves as Franciscan editor of St. Anthony Messenger where he writes articles, editorials, and the monthly column "Ask a Franciscan." He has also written five books and contributed to several others. He holds graduate degrees in ministry, theology, and Franciscan studies.

The Joyful Sprit of Padre Pio is the fourth book Patricia Treece has written on this southern Italian priest who was canonized in 2002. (Note: Having little knowledge of Pio's life, I found it helpful to search out a dedicated biography on the web to give greater context to "Joyful Spirit." At the same time, I knew going in that that Treece wasn't writing a bio, as such, but  offering witness to "neither Pio's perfection nor to his ordinary spiritual gifts so much as to the richness of his love..." This book may go beyond the author's specific goal and encourage those unfamiliar with Pio to investigate further.)That aside, Joyful Spirit is rich in detail, starting with background on the ongoing controversy over his stigmata. (On her web site, the author reports that Pio was the first Catholic priest to experience the stigmata.) In the intro to this book, Treece describes efforts to expose Pio as being "a fake mystic with self-created stigmata wounds. Other analysts, including Catholics who do not believe he is a phony, nevertheless reduce Pio to a very pious soul with a limited neurosis that made him bleed." Equally inexplicable, and therefore open to speculation by some, were Pio's ability to survive on little sleep and nourishment, "odors of sanctity" that sometimes announced his unseen presence, and visible bilocations.Treece concludes that all these factors fall away in light of the Church's rigorous procedures for determining sainthood and examples of everyday occurrences in Pio's life. The Joyful Spirit is presented in eight chapters, each consisting of roughly 25-30 titled meditations made up of stories, letters, and prayers by and about Padre Pio.

Marcellino D'Ambrosio opens 40 Days, 40 Ways by describing the scriptural basis for Lent from Noah on the ark through the temptation of Jesus in the desert (Luke 4:1-13). The 40 days between Ash Wednesday and Holy Saturday are "training days," he explains. The six Sundays of Lent, always exempt from fasting, are mini-celebrations of Christ's resurrection. This distinction underlies the 40 Days, 40 Ways format. Each Sunday is devoted to a general meditation, but content for the weekdays consists of life-changing actions that can lead to a fuller discipleship.D'Ambrosio provides guidance for using the book to best advantage. Before Lent begins, read the Table of Contents, with its specific daily goals (for example, Day 12: Read a portion of Scripture every day). Praying for guidance from the Holy Spirit, choose up to three items that seem both important and realistic, then read the pages about those activities and commit to following the practice faithfully throughout Lent. Next, commit to reading the appropriate pages every day and trying to carry out the practice at least on that day if not on a more regular basis.Though the activities are presented in random order, I found myself fitting them under the following four themes: prayer and scripture, worship, reaching out, and learning. These are fluid and often overlap. For example, we learn about the works of mercy on Day 10. The action for Day 23 is reach out to the least important, least popular, most ignored..... Day 28: Visit someone lonely in the neighborhood, the hospital, or prison. Day 32: Pray regularly for those whose rights and dignity are trampled and for those responsible for their pain. Look for a way to help. Day 35: Learn the Prayer of Abandonment of Blessed Charles de Foucauld. Surrender your possessions, your future, and your life to God as you slowly pray it daily.

For thirty years Margrit Banta has worked as a pastoral minister, caring for terminally ill and dying patients and their families and friends. In "What Do I Say?" she shares what she has learned from that experience. Though she writes of general medical, legal, and religious issues it is always from the perspective of a layman. One example that mirrors an incident in my own family is that of recognizing the physical signs of impending death. When Margrit was a teen, her mother was taken to the hospital in the terminal stage of cancer. In what turned out to be the last visit between the two, Margrit missed the signs and engaged her mom in talk of recipes and routine daily activities. Shortly after Margrit left, her mother died. In the chapter titled "Approaching the Arms of Angels," Banta explains the most common physical signs of near-death from terminal illness or advanced age. She then describes two specific incidents of witnessing a peaceful death.Throughout the book Banta stresses the importance of attentive, impartial listening whatever our situation and relationship with the person. Separate chapters on unresolved issues and reviewing life suggest ways in which one might help by taking and transcribing notes, recording spoken words, and helping craft a letter. Banta also addresses religious issues such as wavering faith and psychological areas including denial by the patient and family members and friends. The chapter on final arrangements touches on DNR orders, living wills, hospice services, funeral arrangements, and after-death demands regarding notifications, insurance, and distribution of personal items. The last chapter, a discussion on praying with the patient, consists of six pages of appropriate prayers and a list of psalms.All this in a pocket-sized, 53-page book.

The Spiritual Genius of Thomas Merton is an updated version of The Human Journey: Thomas Merton, Symbol of a Century (1982). "Human Journey" is considered to be the seminal work of author Anthony T. Padovano, a professor of literature and philosophy. Padovano is also an internationally recognized authority on Merton, and as such, he goes well beyond a simple biography. From the preface: "This book will sketch the life of Merton in its elusiveness and assertiveness...deal with his faith and his writing...his mysticism and secularity, the psychological pressures that shaped his life and the myths that influenced his century."In Chapter 6, Cargo Cults and Ghost Dances, Padovano's background in literature shines through. The longest chapter in the book, it focuses on Merton's poetry, in particular "Original Child Bomb" and "The Geography of Lograire." Padovano explains that Child Bomb is about the detonation of the first atomic bomb over Hiroshima. He points out that Merton "weaves into the account the language of the Christian myth that was used by America in the process of creating and delivering this `child'" and explores myths underlying our attitude toward war. This section is rich in historical information. The myth of cargo cults, we learn, is an amalgam of the creation and Cain-Abel story. Padovano devotes 30 pages to The Geography of Lograire, characterizing it as one of the most important of Merton's books, written when he was "ready to enter into a comprehensive stage of his development."My hope is that this brief review will encourage readers to broaden their knowledge and understanding of Thomas Merton, his life, work, and the culture in which he lived. Anthony Padovano has laid it out in imminently readable style.

Joyful Witness is the sixth book by Randy Hain, a nationally known business consultant who converted to Catholicism in 2006. In "Witness" he celebrates more than a dozen ordinary Catholics, unsung heroes who are "shining examples to us of how to be a joyful witness for Christ." The idea for the book grew from Hain's experiences during work-related travel and involvement in Church ministry. Those featured have rejected the secular culture in favor of serving Christ. Hain discovered common traits of humility, selflessness, and self-sacrifice across the spectrum. His subjects radiate peace and joy as they participate in parish and community activities.In each chapter Hain provides a summary of the individual's faith journey, a short description of practical lessons, and questions for reflection. Examples:Keri Davison, a home schooler, runs a family business that develops and distributes resources for other parents. The chapter on her family story closes with three ways to pass the Catholic faith to our children: (1) complete trust in God will be rewarded, (2) we must rely on God and our own efforts, and (3) integrate the practice of our Catholic faith into everything we do.Manny Garcia-Tunon is a founding member of the Catholic Association of Latino Leaders. From his story Hain draws four actions to help us live our faith 24/7: (1) practice prayer and discernment (2) stay connected to family, community, and fellowship, (3) seek out the Blessed Mother, and (4) radiate joy, humility, and the light of Christ.Hain's collection of unsung heroes also includes religious educators, artists, pro-life activists, and media professionals. With its standalone chapters, this work would be an excellent resource for parish ministers, retreat leaders, and faith sharing groups as well as individuals.

Richard Fragomeni's Let Us Adore Him presents Advent meditations focused on Communion antiphons. The meditations for each day from the First Sunday of Advent through Christmas consist of a title; a list of readings for Year A, B, and C; the antiphon; a meditation; and a suggested practice. The same format is applied to feasts during the remainder of the Christmas season.The antiphons, which do not always mirror the theme of the readings, are like a conversation. "Some days we talk to God, other days God talks to us,"  Fragomeni writes. He sees the antiphons, with their "joy of the heart" as a unique perspective on the Advent and Christmas season.Within that structure Fragomeni adds special features such as saints whose feast days are celebrated in Advent and three consecutive days on "the power of three." On Monday of the Second Week the antiphon leads us to reflect on three comings of Christ: birth, the end of time, and Holy Communion. The next day we explore three crowns God offers to us: crown of royalty in baptism, crown of champions, and the crown of thorns.
