The third day addresses three ways of seeing: eyes of the body, eyes of the mind, and the eye of the heart.Let Us Adore Him becomes a special Advent resource with the inclusion of meditations on the Communion Antiphons, a liturgical element unfamiliar to many of the faithful.

Change our Hearts, Daily Meditations for Lent is a pocket-sized book formatted in roughly two-page reflections for each day from Ash Wednesday through Easter Sunday. All three readings are cited, and the Sundays include readings for Cycle A, B, and C. The reflections focus on the readings and their connection to our daily lives. Entries end with a suggested practice or original prayer. Themes include the traditional prayer, fasting, and almsgiving, but also emphasize baptismal promises for those already baptized and those preparing for the sacraments of initiation.Some samplesPrayer: "...May my hunger, and the gift of my goods, fill my neighbor's belly so that my neighbor may know that you are a God who wants their needs met more than you desire my noisy prayers."Practice: "...Do you believe in God the Father Almighty, Creator of heaven and earth? What does that mean to you?"Rory Cooney is a parish liturgy director and songwriter. His book of Lenten meditations is suitable for individuals and groups devoted to furthering their spiritual development during this season.

In his recent book "John XXIII a Short Biography," Kerry Walters recounts the life and times of the son of Italian sharecroppers who served as a priest and bishop for more than 50 years before being chosen pope. In just eight chapters, covering 55 pages, Walters tells the story of a humble, holy, and forward-thinking, man whose career had been thought lackluster by many.The book's early chapters center on Giuseppe Roncalli's story from his birth in 1881, through ordination and various ministries to 1958, when he became pope. Those years encompassed two world wars and the reign of five different popes: Leo XIII, Pius X, Benedict XV, Pius XI, and Pius XII. Walters does an excellent job of describing ways in which these forces shaped Roncalli and how he negotiated quietly and effectively among them to advance an agenda of openness, peace, and social justice.The final chapters focus on Roncalli's brief papacy. Walters makes it clear that Roncalli was chosen by a power-hungry curia as "a good stopgap pontiff who would do nothing and then conveniently die." They were right about his lifespan--he died just short of his five-year anniversary as pope-- but they were mistaken about the legacy he would leave. One of the first acts of the new pope was to convene the Second Vatican Council. He also intervened with U.S. and Soviet leaders during the Cuban Missile Crisis and wrote eight encyclicals on such topics as Christian unity and economic and social justice.

I am beyond best sellers, so always look for "literary fiction" from an earlier time in Kindle store. The author was familiar to me, so I took a chance. This took a little while to get into, but turned out to be really smart and absorbing.

My original head for this handle continues to serve well, but I have to wash it before using it to clean the crown moldings and doorway tops. Now I will reserve the replacement for that task!  As for it's "fitting" the frame, I, too, had a problem at first.  Solved it by working a little harder and stretching out the material in all directions. I'm really glad I found this.

In his latest work Ray Guarendi, Ph.D., tackles the subject of anger. As the examples below show, he uses a common-sense approach based on years of experience as a counselor and parent (he is the father of 10). The book contains more than 22 short chapters on contrasting opinions involving the nature of anger (Problem or Disorder, Emotion or Thought, Trait or State) and its expression (Vent or Contain, Forgive or Feel Bad).Some examples:In the Right or Wrong chapter, Guarendi examines assertiveness training, a "quasi-therapy" that claims emotional benefits to those who assert their rights firmly in social relationships. Under certain circumstances, such assertiveness can result in pushy and even obnoxious behavior, Guarendi writes. He suggests that sometimes the parties involved would better let the issue pass. Turning to Matthew 5:39, he recalls the counsel of Jesus to "turn the other cheek." The psychologist points out that setting aside some "rights" can be emotionally healthy while pursuing them may lead to distress and prolonged irritation. In summary, he emphasizes the importance of discerning whether anger is a choice or a right and, more importantly, how asserting that right will affect me and others. Anger, he says, is almost always a choice, not a right.Guarendi also questions the conventional wisdom that venting anger is a healthy way to release pressure. He cautions that venting is more likely to agitate than pacify the venter and can lead to guilt, shame, embarrassment, and regret. He suggests two ways to relieve frustration, the difference between what we want and what is: (1) align reality with our desires or (2) align our desires more closely with reality. Lowering expectations is often a good choice, he writes. Adult children living with parents is another popular topic Guarendi addresses. After a few examples, he offers two choices for parents based on their goals. If parents have no intention of taking definite action they need to "be quiet," that is, stop commenting, nagging, and pleading. If, however, parents decide to take action, they are advised to bring the reality in line with their own expectations. For example, stop doling out money and acting like a maid.

Each entry in Joseph Girzones Stories of Jesus begins with a passage from Scripture, primarily from John and Luke. The selections were chosen for their dual emphasis on the human and divine qualities of Jesus. Following each of the 40 readings, Girzone presents his creative interpretation of the event based on his theological training and historical research. His process is in some ways like that of a screenwriter adapting a book for the movies, fleshing out the characters and adding dialogue and clues to motivation. All 40 reflections end with original prayers.Luke 8:1-3 is the reading for day 12, titled The Strange Group Who Followed Jesus. Girzone reviews the crew traveling with Jesus as coarse and uneducated fishermen, a mixture of women representing the well-to-do and politically connected, and Mary Magdalene, whose reputation was built around her being possessed of seven devils. Girzone points out that in the absence of motels or the like where they could stay, the company camped outdoors together. Needless to say, the itinerant teacher was widely criticized. Yet, through it all, Jesus just kept moving on in his own merry way. The message for us today is that Jesus was comfortable with every sort of person, and his teaching sets us free.The authors goal of presenting Jesus as a companion for people of all ages and spiritual leanings is the basis for his present ministry. Joseph Girzone was born in 1930, joined the Carmelite Order in 1948, and was ordained as a Catholic priest in 1955. After poor health forced him to retire from the active priesthood in 1981, he turned to writing as a second career. He is best known for a nine-book series on Joshua, a modern day version of Jesus. The books have sold millions of copies and been translated into several languages.

In his latest book, Daniel P. Horan, O.F.M., shares his reflections on the last words of Jesus in terms of what they might mean to us today, highlighting ways in which Christian discipleship depends on sharing in the passion of Christ. Two major themes are the reconciliation of love and suffering and understanding the place of these two elements in our lives.Horan presents the seven sayings in separate chapters, each consisting of four segments: (1) an extended passage from scripture (2) refection on how the saying might speak to today's Christians, (3) reflection questions, and (4) an original prayer.The reflections all connect Christ's Last Words with Catholic social teaching and the Franciscan view of the Passion of Jesus (for example, loving and suffering are two sides of the same coin, and the Cross is entwined with the Incarnation).The book grew out of an invitation Horan received to be the 2011 preacher for a Good Friday talk at a large Manhattan parish. The topic was the Seven Last Words of Christ. While the young priest was aware of the traditional service, he had never witnessed it himself, so he considered carefully before agreeing. Once he signed on he embraced reflection on the seven last words as his Lenten practice, allowing them to permeate all his activities. Through that experience and further research, Horan concluded that the words of Jesus as he parted this life "should be the founding words of my life."Daniel P. Horan, O.F.M., entered the Order of Friars Minor in 2005, professed vows in 2007, and was ordained a priest in 2012. He has written numerous articles and several books including Dating God: Live and Love in the Way of St. Francis.

Joe McHughs vocation is helping others grow through spiritual direction, workshops, and retreats. He learned his craft as a Jesuit priest of 20 years and continues to reach out to others through Spiritual Direction Twin Cities and the spiritual direction program at Southern Methodist University. He has written for National Catholic Reporter and America magazine and is the author of the recently released book Startled by God: Wisdom from Unexpected Places. McHugh defines spiritual direction as reflecting and praying with another to uncover God in our everyday experiences. The structure he favors centers on how God is active in our lives, the meaning of that activity, and ways we might respond.The book features more than 30 short vignettes, many of which show God turning up unexpectedly in the lives of those who are open to faith, hope, and love. The stories are grouped under three headings: (1) What? Dilemmas of Perspective; (2) So What? Dilemmas of Discipleship, and (3) Now What? Dilemmas of Discernment. McHugh offers specific exercises at the end of many entries and suggests that readers construct their own activities for others. He recommends not just reading through the book for information, but using it with another person or a group, an approach that will demonstrate the special presence of Jesus among those who gather in his name.In an early story, McHugh explains that he suffers from binocularity, (using only one eye at a time) and relates this physical condition to the spiritual. He notes that some see only grace or guilt, but not both; likewise death or resurrection, loss or gain, and self-giving or self-fulfillment. Instead of this one-sided view, he writes, we need to see ourselves as God sees us: a loved sinner. He encourages those prone to either/or thinking to pray frequently for healing and to meditate on Scripture passages in which Jesus opens the eyes of the blind.

In the 1980s and '90s, Fr. Mitch Pacwa, S.J., a student of the Holy Land, joined three pilgrimages to the ancient sites. Within a few years, the Jesuit was adding information to the guides presentation and eventually was permitted to lead his own groups. By 2012 he had led 58 trips to Israel, 10 to both Jordan and Egypt, 5 to both Greece and Turkey, and 2 to Lebanon. With this armchair pilgrimage, Pacwa hopes that readers, both those who have traveled to the Holy Land and those who have not, find an opportunity to pray more and come closer to our Savior, Jesus Christ.The Holy Land, an Armchair Pilgrimage contains biblical texts associated with key shrines and sites, photos and art, mediations, and prayers. By structuring the book geographically Pacwa provides readers with an experience similar to that of an actual pilgrimage. Some of the featured sites, such as The Church of the Nativity, lend especially to that outcome. This chapter opens with a photo of the church and brief historical background. The next pages take us inside the church with photos and a description of the visitors experience from adult visitors must bend down to avoid bumping their heads on the wide stone lintel to public expression of prayer is not permitted as you wait in the long, disorganized line. The same feel of being there continues through The Cave of the Nativity. This page features photos of pilgrims descending into the cave and the silver star marking the spot where Christ was born. The chapter closes with history, scripture, and photos related to the chapels of St. Joseph and The Holy Innocents and St. Jerome.In addition to the rich text and full color artwork, Pacwa provides lists of illustrations, scripture citations, and a subject matter index. Through and through, The Holy Land, An Armchair Pilgrimage is a treasure.

Whether it is used for reference or daily reflection, by individuals, faith-sharing groups, or catechists, this classic is a valuable resource for anyone seeking the path to sainthood.The editor of the seventh edition of Saint of the Day reminds us that the holiness of the saints, Gods holiness, is something we all share. Their lives were indeed conditioned by the culture and history of their own day; their expression of holiness is partly different from what it would be in the twenty-first century. But the essence is the same: They received Gods gift with joy. They call us to do likewise... writes Leonard Foley, O.F.M.Though most of the dated entries feature lives of saints and blesseds, others are devoted to solemnities of Jesus not assigned a specific Sunday or holy day, feasts of Mary, and celebrations commemorating the dedication of important churches. The Sunday after I first picked up the new edition of Saint of the Day I heard a homily on the Dedication of St. John Lateran. The priest did a great job explaining the history and reminding us of church as building as well as people as Church. I found the Saint of the Day entry essentially the same, but appreciated the opportunity to be able to reflect more fully on what I had heard at Mass.As for individual saints, Fr. Foley explains that the earliest stories were written to memorialize martyrs on their anniversaries. In addition to these historical accounts, legends grew up around certain saints. After the presentation of facts on St. George (D. 303?), Foley writes that the story of a slain dragon, rescued princess, and conversion of Libya is a twelfth-century Italian fable. In the comment section, he reminds us that Americans somehow need Paul Bunyan in addition to historical heroes.Each entry consists of brief background, a comment linking the feast to our own life, and relevant quotations from scripture and the saint or another spiritual writer. The book closes with an index of alphabetical titles of feasts and the dates they are celebrated.

In the prologue to "Thirsting for God," Editor Angelo D. Scolozzi writes of his relationship with Mother Teresa, which began in Calcutta in 1976. "By her words and example during my twenty-one years of association with her, she showed me the royal way of the cross...encouraged me to do heroic acts of total surrender, loving trust, and acceptance." Scolozzi describes this book as a kind of yearlong spiritual diary made up of reflections, meditations, prayers, and his personal recollections of Mother Teresa. The material is drawn from numerous sources including a manuscript the senior sisters of her congregation developed incorporating Mother Teresa's first teachings. Scolozzi ponders the reaction to today's readers as her spiritual reality unfolds before them.For a taste of this work, let's look at a series of five consecutive entries filling two pages. (1) "Be faithful to little things, for in them lies our strength." Teresa saw opportunities for "little practices of love" as gifts from God on which we may build lives of holiness. (2) Practicing small, daily acts of penance draws us to God and God to us, and earns us the grace to overcome our faults. (3) Allowing Jesus to pray in and through us enables us to act out of love for others. (4) Praying and living the "Our Father" teaches holiness: "Everything is there: God, myself, my neighbor." (5) In the name of Jesus we pray for grace to love God above all and to make our hearts meek and humble like the heart of Jesus.

Sr. Wendy Beckett is known worldwide for her documentaries on art history shown on the BBC and PBS. Her new book on "The Art of Mary," features fourteen full-color reproductions of world-class art works related to the mother of Jesus. Most are from the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries and many are icons. Each full-page reproduction is accompanied by three pages of text on the history of the piece, a description of certain of its elements, and a personal reflection.In providing background Beckett includes several legends as well as factual information. For example, some believe that the Annunciation as described in Scripture was not Gabriel's first appearance before Mary, and that the reason wine ran out at the marriage feast at Cana is that Jesus brought along his apostles. Many of the reflections end in an observation about our own lives. For example, Mary's accepting God's plan "is essentially about trust in God and letting him do as he pleases with us," and "Joy comes from the deep, unshakable happiness of faith in Our Lord."Beckett's treatment of the Russian icon "The Mother of God as the Burning Bush" is a good example of the detail she provides. After describing the large, central portion of this complex image, she points out smaller symbols such as a ladder, symbolizing the incarnation as a connection between heaven and earth, and a tiny representation of Christ the high priest celebrating the Eucharist on the altar of his tomb in Jerusalem. "The icon is telling us that the Church contains Jesus, just as Mary did, and this complex imagery is held in her heart," writes Beckett.This book, quick to read, beautiful to ponder, would make a lovely gift.

Patrick Madrid introduces his new book, On a Mission, by describing St. Paul as one whose apostolic zeal irritated others because proclaiming and testifying to Jesus Christ made others uncomfortable. Paul's fervor, Madrid writes, was based on a personal encounter with Christ rather than on intellectual, scientific knowledge. All Christians are called to act with this kind of fervor for bringing others to the Church.Madrid uses St. Francis de Sales (1567-1622) as his primary model, with additional lessons from St. Francis of Assisi, St. Francis Xavier, Pope Francis I, and twentieth century apologist Frank Sheed. From these men, and others, Madrid says he has learned that anyone who is willing can become a channel of God's grace to others simply by saying "yes" to God and neighbor with a loving heart.The first chapter, What an Apostle Looks Like, is devoted to the story of Francis de Sales, who is credited with "re-evangelizing" the people of the Chablais region of France after the Catholic Church had lost influence in favor of John Calvin's brand of Protestantism. Madrid enumerates the steps de Sales took, the struggles he overcame, and his success in converting nearly 60,000 former Protestants on Calvin's turf.Here, and throughout the book Madrid reiterates the qualities of an "apostolic heart" marked by a wellspring of charity,  burning love for Christ and neighbor, and  "willingness to live and speak the truth courageously yet humbly in a world that resists the truth," based on deep knowledge of the teachings of Jesus and the Church.He offers a specific program for gaining that knowledge beginning with spending at least 10 minutes daily reading a chapter from the Gospels and three paragraphs from the Catechism of the Catholic Church. He recommends several Internet sites, additional publications, CDs, and Catholic radio programs including his own show Right Here, Right Now.

Fr. Ronald Rolheiser, president of the Oblate School of Theology in San Antonio, Texas, is an internationally known lecturer and writer. The author of a 2010 article on Rolheiser for National Catholic Reporter had this to say about him: "Few Catholic authors have that kind of cradle-to-grave appeal, across the widest possible spectrum of political and theological outlooks and life experiences."His latest book, Prayer, Our Deepest Longing, bears out that observation. In the 32 reflections on prayer Rolheiser covers topics using examples from daily life, Scripture, and contemporary culture ranging from Zorba the Greek to the cartoon Ziggy. Scripture references are sometimes familiar, sometimes enlightening, depending on the reader. For example, in writing about the Good Shepherd, Rolheiser explains that sheep were so attuned to their master's voice they would not follow even a very good imitator. He also explains the phrase "He descended into hell" from the Apostle's Creed in a way unfamiliar to me.The material is organized into six chapters addressing prayer issues such as common struggles, hearing God's voice, and developing a mature prayer life.Rolheiser's intention for this book is to provide "a healthy combination" of consolation and challenge to help readers overcome struggles with prayer  "so that it no longer feels as though you are simply doing some drab duty, wasting precious time, talking to a  wall, entertaining yet another daydream, or simply rehashing your heartaches and headaches."The reflections may be read in any order, he writes, then echoes a non-negotiable rule from great spiritual masters: You have to show up for prayer and you have to show up regularly.

Author Sister Wendy Beckett, now in her eighties, joined the Sisters of Notre Dame de Namur in 1946, continued her studies, taught, and translated Medieval Latin manuscripts for a number of years. In the late 1970s, in declining health, Sr. Wendy was permitted to leave her order for a hermit's life of prayer. For two hours a day, she studies and writes about art, a subject that has fascinated her from childhood. The proceeds of her work, including very popular TV documentaries, are donated to the Carmelite community on whose property she lives. Most recently she has written a series of three new books: the art of Christmas, the Saints, and Mary. Like the others, Sr. Wendy on the Art of Christmas is arranged around 14 works. Each entry consists of a reproduction and three pages of text on historical background of the piece and the story it represents; the work, itself; and a reflection for today.I've chosen "The Census at Bethlehem" by Pieter Brueghel as an example. Beckett begins her presentation on this sixteenth century painting with a reflection on current secular Advent preparations. Advent is intended as a time of prayer, she writes, but we are often overtaken by activities related to the commercial side of Christmas. She asks us to spend a little time every day acknowledging our need to receive the transforming grace of Jesus.Turning to the painting, she provides the cultural background in which "The Census at Bethlehem" was created. The Netherlands was in turmoil during the period in which Brueghel lived in Flanders. In this work he connected the upheaval in his own time with the political events leading up to the birth of Jesus. Thus, Joseph and Mary are embedded into a noisy, confusing scene depicting Flemish peasants in contemporary clothing milling about among brick buildings, gathering provisions, wood, and beer while children play in the snow. Beckett ties together the reflection by pointing out that for Mary and Joseph the approach to Christmas was filled with anxiety, yet they thought only of Jesus. "In all this, we can unite with them," she writes.

Did you ever spend a day with someone who came back with three or four really funny "bits" based on his observation of things you barely noticed? Lino Rulli is that guy. Like Cosby, he's a master storyteller; like Seinfeld, he sees everything as "material." Before you object to my comparing Rulli to these comedic greats, remember that "Saint" suggests he merits canonization--sort of. Rulli, host of "The Catholic Guy" on SeriusXM Radio, is really saying that canonized saints often have led lives of such great holiness that the rest of us can become discouraged.In elementary school he discovered he could get a laugh, and that was one road to popularity for an insecure kid with few other obvious gifts. Unless you count his family--a wacky, but much loved bunch--and his friends--where does one find these characters? Again, it's his eye for the amusing and his ability to craft great stories and one-liners. That's the humorist part. In addition, Rulli is a cradle Catholic with a master's degree in theology who is fully dedicated to discovering and accepting the call God issues to us all--sanctity.In his chapter on the corporal works of mercy, Lino is at his best in balancing the serious and the funny. He presents the works in checklist form, each with an account of his own performance. While pointing out that he seldom sees anyone naked and doubts that there's much opportunity to "give drink to the thirsty" in our culture, he also tells a wonderful story about feeding the hungry. It took place during Lent when he was honoring the season by giving at least $10 a day to folks he met on the street who seemed needy. Rulli had $20, needed dinner, but wanted to donate to a man begging for spare change. He explained the situation, asking the man if he had $10 "change." Lino ended up taking the guy along to a deli and buying him $10 worth of food. In addition to "feeding the hungry," Rulli also takes credit for his stint in prison ministry, but disavows burying the dead as illegal.

The content and presentation of From the Back of the Pews to the Head of the Class is exceptional. Information on interviewees; pull quotes; and an index all are "value added" to the story subtitled "The remarkable Accomplishments of a Segregated Catholic High School in the Deep South." The school, Most Pure Heart of Mary (HOM), opened in Mobile, Alabama, in 1917 and closed in 1968.Older alumni represented in the book generally speak with delight. Larietta Hall, a 1944 graduate, talks about The Holy Ghost nuns, who had the students performing Irish jigs at the all-black, Heart of Mary school." The nuns got pictures of Irish dancing costumes, and my mother sewed them...I knew nothing about Ireland." Others from that time said they were unperturbed by "Coloreds Only" signs. In many cases, they were satisfied with and thankful for the lives they were living--close-knit family and community, comparatively well off, good education. One interviewee said he had peeked into a white-only restaurant. Noting the elegant setting, he came away feeling he'd gained some interesting information, but it had little effect on him.Fr. John George Harfmann, SSJ, who was assigned to HOM as an associate pastor in 1964, was unprepared for the brand of racism in the Deep South. The newly ordained priest came from Brooklyn, and studied in Washington, D.C. "I had never seen face-to-face segregation the way it was in Mobile in those days," he said. He described his first "head-on collision with white and black" as he tried to visit a parishioner in the local hospital.Alums from the 1950s and 60s spoke highly of their education at HOM, but also about segregation, and the Church's complicity in it. Some recalled parishioners, staff, and even students who were instrumental in raising awareness and supporting civil rights legislation. Several former HOM students shared their initial views on the effects of desegregation in their community--not always favorable-- and their overall impressions of growing up as back-of-the-pews Catholics in a back-of-the bus society.

Franciscan Priest Richard Rohr is the author of more than 20 books and numerous articles, an internationally known speaker, and founding director of the Center for Action and Contemplations (CAC) in Albuquerque, New Mexico. Those with more than a passing knowledge of Rohr's history may be aware that, at age 70, he is cutting back on his travels in favor of a long-held dream of opening the "Living School for Action and Contemplation" at CAC. The curriculum will be based on seven central themes Rohr developed over the years: methodology, foundation, frame, ecumenical, transformation, process, and goal. In his latest book, "Yes/And!" Rohr organizes excerpts and adaptations from his previous works under these seven themes. A deep understanding of the themes isn't essential to appreciating the 366 titled  reflections, most of which cover only one page.The book is suitable for individual or group use, and lends to either straight-through reading or browsing. The range of topics is extensive. A few examples:"In the inspired documents of Vatican II, I found my best teacher in putting together Scripture, Tradition, and Experience in a quite reasonable (rational) way.""Jesus, you could say, came to show us how to suffer, how to carry `the legitimate pain of being human,' as Jung called it.""Substance addictions are merely the most visible form of addiction, but actually we are all addicted to our own habitual way of doing anything, our own defenses, and most especially our patterned way of thinking or how we process our reality.""In recent years and elections, one might have thought that homosexuality and abortion were the new litmus tests of authentic Christianity....They never were the criteria of proper membership for the first two thousand years, but they reflect very recent culture wars instead."In the end, Rohr writes that he is most excited when a conference participant says "Richard, you did not tell me anything new. Somehow I always knew this would be the case, and you just gave me the courage to believe it."

The Road of Hope is a collection of teachings written by an imprisoned Vietnamese archbishop to his people. Francis Xavier Nguyen Van Thuan (1928-2002) was ordained a priest in 1953. Subsequently he served as a pastor, studied canon law in Rome, served as a seminary professor in the archdiocese of Hue, and was consecrated as bishop of Nha Trang in 1967. During the following eight years he took on additional duties that included traveling widely to support peaceful solutions to the Vietnamese conflict and solicit aid for reconstruction. In 1975, after the communist takeover, he was arrested as he journeyed to Saigon for a new assignment as an archbishop.In the introduction to The Road of Hope Translator John Peter Pham describes the communist persecution of priests and religious who were deported to "re-education camps," as Church property was seized. In March of 1976, Pham writes, the Archbishop was deported to North Vietnam along with 2000 other prisoners. For the next 13 years he was confined to prisons and camps, spending the bulk of that time in isolation. For a period in 1975, Van Thuan was placed under house arrest. "Realizing that this 'respite' would be brief and that the Church, bereft of its shepherds, was facing a period of possibly years of persecution, the Archbishop took up his pen," writes Pham. The plan was to write a few messages to encourage and offer spiritual counsel to his flock. Over time, the messages formed a manuscript, and pages were smuggled to the outside and assembled as 1001 reflections, which were printed clandestinely and disseminated widely despite government efforts to interfere. Van Thuan was eventually able to edit the manuscript himself following his expulsion from Vietnam.As for the content of this book, the 1001 messages are grouped under headings such as duty, interior life, the apostle, ordinary work, and a life of hope. Most of us are familiar with the themes here, but the way this priest from this background presents them is extraordinary, yet simple and specific.

Author Melanie Rigney researched more than 700 saints and blesseds using nearly two dozen books and countless websites before settling on the 366 individuals to feature in her latest book, Sisterhood of Saints. The only introductory material appears in the preface, where Rigney highlights the variety of backgrounds, personalities, and activities these women represent, emphasizing that "in short, they are women just like you and me." What she learned, and hopes to pass on to readers, is that their love of God is the uniting trait of the sisterhood, regardless of when and where they lived.Single-page daily reflections, designed for busy women, consist of a short synopsis of the life of the subject, a paragraph about its relevance to our daily lives, a "snippet" from Scripture or the woman's writings, and a challenge. I'll choose Margaret the Barefooted (1325-1395) as an example. Margaret, showing her solidarity with beggars, went barefoot while begging alms for them, at the same time suffering disapproval and verbal abuse from her husband. Rigney takes this lesson from the story: "The importance of putting ourselves in someone else's situation, and at least offering a smile and perhaps a friendly word."In writing my review, I noticed one drawback to Sisterhood of Saints: no index, no discernible order to the entries. After deciding to feature Margaret the Barefooted, I had to page through to find her again. The content rates five stars, but lack of searchability caused me to award only three.

What better way to prepare for Christmas than to experience the infancy gospels of Matthew and Luke through the eyes of a first century Jew? Author Edward Sri provides that opportunity in his latest book, The Advent of Christ: Scripture Reflections to Prepare for Christmas.Week One reviews Luke's story of the birth of John the Baptist and Matthew's references to the Book of Genesis through three titles for the child: Jesus, Christ, and Emmanuel. Sri shows the connection between Old Testament and New inherent in these titles. For example, he explains that the Hebrew name "Jesus" (God saves) is significant because ancient Jews blamed Israel's sin for loss of the Promised Land and exile from God. The child Jesus, would not only free the Jews from the oppression of the Roman forces, but also restore their relationship with God. The author also points out that "Jesus" is a form of the name "Joshua." Joshua led the Chosen People into the Promised Land. Thus, Jesus can be seen as the new Joshua, who will lead the people out of spiritual exile.Week Two continues the story of Zechariah and introduces St. Joseph with an interesting parallel to Joseph the patriarch from the book of Genesis. Week Three focuses on Mary, and Week Four "the joys and sorrows of the Holy Family" as they travel from Nazareth to Bethlehem. A final section on Christmas covers Christmas Eve through the Feast of the Epiphany.Each section begins with a short preview and each day opens with a passage from Scripture and closes with a reflection question and prayer.This resource is suitable for individual and group use during Advent in all of the church's liturgical cycles.

Loved this show when it aired, really disappointed it didn't last. I could watch it over and over for the rest of my life. If you like Aaron Sorkin--West Wing and Sports Night-- rapid-fire patter, this is it!

The Miraculous Medal by Donna-Marie Cooper O'Boyle is all about miracles. The backdrop is the story of Catherine Labour (1806-1876). As a young girl, Catherine saw St. Vincent de Paul in a dream and discerned his call to her to join the Sisters of Charity. She was accepted into the order in 1830. In her days as a novice, Catherine had visions of St. Vincent's heart, Jesus visible in the Blessed Sacrament, and Christ the King, all of which she confided to her confessor. Later she had dreams and visions in which Mary prophesied and gave instructions regarding reforms needed in the religious communities founded by St. Vincent de Paul. Mary also charged Sr. Labour with having a medal cast, with specific directions on the design.As Catherine worked to see the mission fulfilled, numerous miracles related to the "Miraculous Medal" occurred.  In a chapter titled "Modern-Day Transforming Miracles," the author shares stories from people to whom she has given Miraculous Medals. "These encounters and stories happen on ordinary days during run-of-the-mill circumstances, but with the Blessed Mother's grace these moments are transformed into extraordinary occurrences," she writes. "Only God, the Blessed Mother, the angels, and the saints know for sure how these miracles come about." Subheadings throughout the 50-page chapter include Resuscitated Twenty-Eight Times, Peace Overshadowed Her, Wine Store Owner Celebrates a New Birthday, Spouses in Surgery and Transformed Hearts, Two Delivery Guys, and Faithful in China.Cooper O'Boyle provides a complete package here: the history of the medal, miraculous encounters to the present day, and a section on devotions to Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal.

Greg Willits presents the nuts and bolts of "The New Evangelization" from a wealth of experience. He is director of Evangelization and Family Life Ministries for the Archdiocese of Denver. He is also deeply involved in Catholic media, notably Twitter, Facebook, and The New Evangelizers web site.The New Evangelization and You is based on Church documents and Scripture, all cited in chapter-by-chapter notes. To complement these formal sources, Willits includes sidebars called "New Evangelizers in Action" in each of the book's 12 chapters. These stories feature ordinary individuals modeling elements of the New Evangelization: (1) renewed spiritual devotion and efforts in catechesis, (2) living our faith, and (3) sharing our faith with others.Willits also describes his personal insights on the New Evangelization. He tells about annual fishing trips with his brother, emphasizing the planning and knowledge that lead to success in catching striped bass. The same kind of preparation is required for evangelization (fishing for men). In this case the task is sharing faith and drawing others to Christ, even if we feel unprepared. Willits points out that our efforts must not be limited to only "the big fish," that is, those who are extremely skeptical or hostile. "We oftentimes get caught up with converting all the atheists and non-Christians we know," he writes, "but what about the small fish in your life? In the New Evangelization, that's one of the most important questions you can ask."

No wrong wayThe Catholic Update Guide to the Bible does a bang-up job of presenting the library-like book as a piece, summarizing the books of the Old Testament and explaining the New Testament with gospel comparisons and an overview of the book of Acts.In the final chapter, editor Mary Carol Kendzia gives concrete suggestions on how to approach reading, praying, and studying the Bible. First, there's no one way that works for everyone, and even the several experts whose work she draws on emphasize different methods. The message is stay flexible and incorporate the information from the first three chapters when considering guidelines like the following:* Don't start at the beginning and plow through.* Start with the New Testament, familiar gospels, or Acts.* Read sections, and read aloud--that's the way the stories were first encountered.* Read the introductions and footnotes.* Reflect on passages.* Imagine yourself as part of the story.* Always invoke the Holy Spirit.

In "A Quick Look at Heaven and Hell a View Unlike Any We Might Imagine" Tom Molnar covers a good bit of ground in a mere 43 pages. He opens with a survey of ways scientific findings have influenced ideas about afterlife from the days of Copernicus through the 1966 Time Magazine cover story "Is God Dead?"Other topics address images of heaven and hell through history, possible criteria for God's judgment, what heaven might be like, and the form of those who attain heaven. Citing several Bible passages, he writes, "God, of course, has no difficulty in resurrecting a body intact." The question is what would we look like? Glorified and immortal versions of ourselves at the time of death? All resurrected at a past or future age, such as 33 to commemorate the age at which Jesus died? "Personally I tend to think our bodies will be resurrected at our body's earliest fully mature age," Molnar writes. "Babies will likely come to heaven fully matured, and the elderly will again see the full bloom of youth."Turning to hell, Molnar explores scripture, reported visions by saints and others, and near-death experiences. Heavenly near-death experiences are familiar to many, but those of hell are less so. Molnar describes reported end-of-life visions of hell with words like "moans and screams of those tormented...beasts in the shape of grotesque animals...huge worms appear(ing) to emerge from their bodies...utter sense of despair and loss."In conclusion Molnar reminds us that each of us is called to be with God in heaven, and we have ample information on how to make that happen.

In "Raising God-First Kids..." Barbara Curtis introduces her 1980 self as "a single mother living in Marin County, California, with two daughters, Samantha Sunshine and Jasmine Moondance--both part of my hippie heritage." She wanted something more for her girls than the kind of chaotic upbringing she had endured, yet had no clue how to provide it. In turning to Alcoholics Anonymous for help with her addiction, she was able to replace non-belief with acceptance of a Higher Power. It was in AA that she met Tripp, whose background was similar to hers. The two married, and their first son was conceived shortly afterward.When their second son was born following a complicated pregnancy, the couple decided to forgo using birth control, agreeing that their spiritual purpose was "to continue raising a healthy family." Within eighteen months, their third son was born and their marriage was failing apart.Out of desperation, the couple attended a marriage conference that led to committing their lives to Jesus and embracing evangelical Christianity. Barbara abandoned her support for abortion in favor of pro-life advocacy. By 1993, Barbara and Tripp were raising nine children, and had made the decision to home school them. Barbara began offering home-schooling workshops, incorporating her Montessori training, and eventually wrote several books on the topic for evangelical publishers. She had also become an advocate for children with disabilities following the birth of her son Jonny, who has Down Syndrome. Tripp and Barbara eventually adopted three boys with Down Syndrome, bringing the number of their children to an even dozen. In 2005, Barbara began blogging in hopes of sharing ideas with other moms. At the same time, she accepted invitations to speak before pro-life groups, usually made up of Catholics and evangelicals. Through these events, she became aware of what she saw as hypocrisy among the evangelicals because they purported to be pro-life yet condoned birth control. There followed a moment in which Barbara recognized that the Catholic Church offered authentic and consistent teaching on these matters. In 2007 she, Tripp, and six of their children converted.Raising God-First Kids in a Me-First World is the tale of this extraordinary family told with honesty and humility in the hope that it will provide inspiration and support to others. Barbara Curtis died suddenly in 2012. She was 64.

Joan Mueller has written this book for those wanting to know more about St. Clare, who is sometimes considered only in light of her relationship with Francis of Assisi. Though a follower of Francis, Clare "has much to say for herself," writes Mueller. "Clare knew confused times, war, and poverty, and lived her life with simplicity and joy. In difficult days, she reaches across the centuries to guide us yet again." In this book, Mueller, a Poor Clare sister and internationally respected scholar, brings Clare to us in a personal, modern-day telling.One of my favorite literary devices is mixing current language with historical information, and Mueller does it here with gusto. In the introduction she writes of objections from some churchmen over canonizing Francis "this street guy with his grungy followers." She describes Clare as no "pushover or "vagabond." In the eyes of her uncle, Clare was a "mutilated wreck" no one would want to marry after she allowed Francis to cut her hair. In a quest to force Clare to return home, Uncle Monaldo both tried to "keep his cool" and "cooled his heels."Rather than simply recite the events, Mueller portrays the drama of Uncle's subsequent violent actions aimed at dragging (by the hair) Clare's younger sister away from the protection of the nuns with whom she was sheltered. That same dramatic effect also contributes to the reality of Clare's story. For example, when she and Francis first meet, "Francis found himself fidgeting, his hands sweating a bit," as he waited for Clare to appear.The final chapters of the book describe the daily life of Clare and Francis and their followers, development of their religious orders, Clare's death, and testimonies of those interviewed during the process of her canonization.

Like others in The Catholic Update Guide series, this overview of the New Evangelization is based on material from Franciscan Media and edited by Carol Kendzia. The first two chapters address development of Church teaching on evangelization, with special emphasis on evangelization as the mission of all the faithful, not just Church leaders.The third and final chapter "Go Out into the World," focuses on the how-to. Kendzia states that we are called to present an inviting image to the world. "We must be a collective sign of God's goodness, openness, and acceptance to all men and women." She turns to the writings of Henry Libersat, author of 16 books and an ordained permanent deacon, for specific ideas, among them thinking about "how to tell your story." He suggests we look at our lives before we came to know the Lord, describe the feelings that arose when we experienced God's love, and identify ways that experience changed us. Most importantly, we need to share our story as a conversation, not a homily or a lesson.Each chapter ends with reflection questions, and back matter includes a 10-point evangelization checklist and information on sources and contributors. Catholic Update Guide to the New Evangelization is a concise overview of the New Evangelization and what it calls Catholics to do.

In 1999, Elizabeth Bookser Barkley's husband Scott was diagnosed with an aggressive form of brain cancer. After several months of treatment he died, at age 53, leaving three teen-aged daughters and his wife of 23 years. Her book, Life after Death, offers an intimate look at what is involved in facing such a loss. It addresses general challenges for the widowed including financial planning; immediate and long-term decisions; dating; and caring for spiritual, physical, and emotional health.Each chapter ends with reflection points, information on a role model, and an original prayer. Most of the role models appear to be personal acquaintances of the author, but three are known more widely: Saint Elizabeth Ann Seton, Jane de Chantal, and Vice President Joe Biden, whose wife and daughter were killed in a car accident just after he was elected to the U.S. senate.The author's own experiences and those of numerous others are embedded in each chapter along with a wealth of resources to help the widowed  "begin to understand that there is nothing wrong with you for being despondent or feeling physically ill in the weeks or months after your loss," regardless of what others may say.On the spiritual side, Barkley shares the importance of prayer and ritual in her own healing. For example, she found inspiration to begin praying the psalms based on the writings of Scripture scholar Walter Brueggemann. In the book she devotes four or five pages to her approach and the results.All in all, Life after Death provides an effective balance of data, personal stories, resources, and prayer. The subtitle "Practical Help for the Widowed" says it all.

These were all the rage when I was in school, but they faded out of style. Looks like ACCO/Mead is hoping to make them big again by appealing to parents, who ostensibly grew up when Trapper Keepers were in fashion.Ironically, this Trapper Keeper does not have any Trappers, which are basically dividers with pockets. But the front & rear covers have a pocket apiece.The Star Wars Pattern looks great. I really like it. The R2D2 and Vader Patterns are a bit over the top, but look more period-correct.I note a few improvements over the Trapper Keepers I recall from my childhood:(1) Narrower: My old Trapper Keepers were wider and were difficult to fit into some backpacks. These are only a quarter inch wider than a typical 3-ring binder.(2) Softer vinyl. My old Trapper Keepers were already cracking and tearing before they even left the shelves. This vinyl is very pliable and looks like it might last a good while longer than the older ones.(3) Steel rings. My old Trapper Keepers has plastic rings that slid when you pulled a tab. These have the common round-rings with release tabs you find on most 3-ring binders(4) Snap closure. My old Trapper Keepers had velcro. They made a lot of noise. Snap should be much quieter. However, the snap on this particular Trapper Keeper appears to be damaged and will not close at all.But at the end of the day, none of these improvements make Trapper Keepers any more practical. Standard 3-ring binders are every bit as good and cost much less. You can get the kind with clear sides and put whatever graphics your prefer in there.And keep in mind there are much better alternatives. Just as an example, this binder is constructed with nylon (far more durable than vinyl), zippered on all sides, has pockets and organizers inside, and costs roughly the same. But I'll admit it's not as nice to look at as this Trapper Keeper.It really boils down to how nostalgic you are? If you really miss the 70s-90s and need a Star Wars themed Trapper Keeper, go for it. It's better than the old Trapper Keeper in many ways. But if you're looking for a practical binder for Back-To-School, look elsewhere.

You have to keep in mind that this is for younger children, not for older fans of the show. Collectors will be disappointed. It feels cheap. It doesn't look great. But on the bright side, for the collectors, it stands upright very stably and the arms are somewhat posable; shoulders and elbows twist. No other part is posable. Most of the details are painted, not stickers, which I appreciated as a parent. Paper stickers tend to get wet and tear off. And truthfully, it looks pretty good in both robot and truck form.Part of what attracted me to Transformers as a child was the challenge of transforming from a robot to a vehicle and back. It was basically a puzzle, frustrating at first, but a lot of fun once you've figured it out. This does away with it completely. It transforms in very few movements, not 1 like they claim, but very few.The 1-Step refers to main action of turning Optimus from a robot into a truck. You'll still need to straighten out the rear wheel-set, put his arms at his side, and pivot the hood, etc. Maximum, approx. 5 movements to go from one form to the other. Very simple, which makes it great for introducing Transformers to younger children. Even my 1 year old is intrigued. I'm sure she'd lose interest if I showed her an older Transformer with a dozen steps or more.BOTTOM LINE: This is for young children. Keep that in mind before you give this a negative review. Yes, it's cheap and boringly simple, but the target audience (children) will probably enjoy this. Mine does.

Most Green Toys are excellent, and this is no exception. They're durable and attractive. They don't contain BPA, phthalates, PVC or external coatings which are potentially toxic.The block colors seem to vary from set to set. For instance, our triangle pieces are green, the 2x4 blocks are yellow, 2x2 are blue, 2x1 are orange. In the set pictured, the triangles are yellow, 2x4 are blue, 2x2 are orange, 2x1 are green. That doesn't bother me. These aren't Legos and my baby and I aren't building anything elaborate. More on that later.The hues are pretty organic, which I appreciate. No wild neon colors. The green is a deep leafy color. The orange looks like carrots. The yellow resembles spaghetti squash. It's probably wishful thinking, but I hope the colors encourage my children to eat more vegetables.As another reviewer pointed out, though they look like big Lego or Duplo, they barely stick together at all. I believe that's intentional. I recall when I was younger, Lego pieces would stick together so well I'd resort to using my teeth to get them apart, which probably isn't healthy. But also consider, younger children that haven't developed fine motor skills will enjoy knocking these over more than they'll enjoy assembling them. In the case of our 1 year old, she enjoys knocking over my creations as fast as I can build them. The sound of the pieces colliding make a satisfying plonk.But keep in mind, as with all toys, appeal will vary from child to child based on their development, age, personality, etc.

The box and photos do a pretty poor job of selling this game. I don't think many people will be attracted to this if it were sitting on a shelf. That's a shame, because with the right group, this has the potential to be a lot of fun. If it weren't given to me, I doubt I would've even noticed it.There are a lot of checks & balances which serve as equalizers to level the playing field. The objective is to mold something neither too accurate, nor too vague.In theory, it seems like this should be a fair game. In practice, the game favors mediocre sculptors. Better sculptors will find it difficult to "dial back" their dohdle.The packaging is suggestive of a fast-paced guessing game with players shouting guesses, but it's actually pretty thoughtful and calculating.Overall, this was a fun game to share with adults over drinks. Not as much fun for smaller children. It's not my favorite game on the shelf, but it has its moments.

As the other positive reviews will attest, this is a HUGE bang-for-the-buck rangefinder.It's comparable to units well-north of its price-tag.The accuracy is pretty good when aimed at something relatively large and reflective.Naturally, it gets dicier if the object is sloped, dark, and/or very distant.For most of my applications, this works just fine.Tip for golfers, the pin is usually often too thin to pick up.Try aiming it at something broader that's approximately equidistant, like a tree or a rock.If you're aiming uphill, you'll just have to try your best to lase the flag.

It's hard to judge the "whiteness" from a computer screen.I would say "Sailcloth" is an ivory cream color.The sheets are an ideal medium between soft (t-shirt) and crisp (hospital linens).They're not initially as cool to the touch as dense Egyptian cotton sheets, but they stay cooler longer.

This is way better than I expected. It's a perfect fit on my HP Chromebook 14". The handles are a high-quality webbing. The body is like that EVA material used in luggage. The sides are pretty shallow and do not bother my wrists when typing. The exterior fabric is pretty coarse and has great traction against your pants when you're working off your lap. Not as helpful on a smooth table, but it's not slick so it won't slide around.There's one handle on either side of the case which make it very easy to quickly open the Chromebook by the handles.There's enough room behind the screen to stash the AC adapter and 7" tablet, Android of course. ;-)I use my Chromebook much more now that it has some protection and convenient carry handles. I only wish it were available in other patterns and/or colors. This black diamond pattern is pretty boring.

A hall-of-famer has already reviewed this, so I'll just add a few extra thoughts.It uses AAA batteries, which is far more convenient than button-cells. And they're accessible via a very simple trap-door. That's an under appreciated feature. Some tools require tools to disassemble and change batteries.I verified the tire pressure gauge against my most trusted dial-type pressure gauge. That's close enough for me. The digital readout is very easy to read.The red light is indeed a throw-back to the old days of reading maps by red-light to preserve night-vision. It's mostly useless for anything else. It's very dim and red light does not cast light well. If you have a light interior, you might be able to find a few things on your seats or dash, but for a dark interior like mine, the red-light is effectively useless. Same under the hood. It's not bright enough to illuminate anything. Doesn't hurt to have the feature though. You should have a map in the glove-box anyway, just in case your vehicle and phone lose GPS. They're free from AAA, weigh nothing, take up nearly zero space, and make excellent kindling in a pinch. :-)The white light, is just fine though. It's just bright enough to get the job done. It's a color is much cooler than an incandescent AA Maglite, but the intensity is nearly par. It casts a wide irregular beam out a few feet. Very efficient for inside the car, trunk, or under the hood. A little more light might be welcome, but isn't necessary.I have not tested this exact glass-breaker or seat-belt cutter, but I have tested similar ones at a pick-apart/u-pull. I concluded that hardness and point are the two most crucial factors. A steel glass-breaker requires a lot of energy because of how soft it is. They're very pointy when new, but after the test, all were blunted. Steel hardness varies with type, but carbide tips are far harder than any steel can ever be. The pointy ones will shatter glass with just a tap. Blunted carbide tips fall somewhere in between, depending on how rounded the tip is. This tool has a blunted carbide tip which isn't too rounded, so I expect it to require a confident swing, but should have no trouble.The breaker folds away, which is nice, but considering the blunted tip, probably not necessary. It's one less thing to snag and it does take up a little less space this way, and I appreciate that.Seat belt cutters were tested at the same pick-apart/u-pull yard and with various scraps of webbing. The conclusion was that this style of cutter with a shrouded razor blade works, but not well. They snag part-way through and required a lot of jerking. Perhaps the adrenaline of the moment will help you muscle through, but consider the awkward positioning of a shoulder belt across your chest. Righties in the driver's seat have a tough time since the angle of the belt is parallel to the direction of pull with your strong hand. Lefties are better off. The reverse is true of the passenger side. The best seat belt cutters were the gut-hook style made from higher-end knife steels no less than 420HC, but I've yet to see this style paired with a carbide glass-breaker at a reasonable price.BOTTOM LINE: The seat belt cutter could be better, but the other 4 features are great. For the price, I can't ask for a better multi-tool for auto-emergencies. The only tool that comes to mind that may be better than this is a Benchmade Triage which costs 8x as much and doesn't have lights or a tire-pressure gauge.

I'm hesitant to give utilitarian products more than 4-stars, because it's really hard to love a device that only does what it's supposed to. I only give the 5th star when it exceeds expectations. So please understand, 4 is the best score I could give this thing.So far, it's holding together and it's putting out plenty of moisture. That's all I can ask for. It's not showing any signs of slowing down or falling apart. By now, cheaper humidifiers start to creak and complain, but this hardy plastic unit is holding together.I keep feeding it distilled water, so it doesn't put out the notorious white dust. I've tried filtered water, but it's a bit dustier.I really appreciate that it's compact, unobstrusive, and not unsightly. My previous unit used a plastic water bottle, and as much as I appreciate the green-factor of recycling used water bottles, it looked pretty silly on my desk.

It's a tiny bottle of product. 4oz is about the size of a tube of toothpaste.But a little goes a long way. I only need a pea-sized drop of product for a whole head of hair. You may need more if you have longer hair.The hold is very light. Hard to describe how light. You won't be getting spikes, if that's what you're after.I found the best use for it was to tame frizz and stray hairs.The downside is that it makes your hair feel just a tiny bit caked and greasy, which is kind of uncomfortable. To me, it feels as though I haven't showered all day.The smell's not overpowering or unpleasant. I didn't mind it at all, but I wouldn't wish it to be any stronger.

I remember the analog version of this from decades ago, back when Radio Shack was not only in-business, but doing well. Back then, before prolific internet, this was conceived to carry a phone signal from one room with a phone jack to a room without a phone jack. Sending an analog signal over active noisy mains cables meant a lot of static on your phone calls, if it worked at all. Those units were $50 in '80s money, which is around $120 in 2015 money. In fact, I can still find them on Amazon: InstaJack, EasyJack, Etc.I tell you this to emphasize my trepidation when testing this. I expected the digital signal to fare better, but I never dreamed it would be crystal clear. Well lo and behold, it is. I have one end connected to my router and the other connected to a VOiP box. I detect zero static. It sounds exactly as clear as before when my VOiP was connected directly to the router. Even international calls are clear (said in my best infomercial voice).You may be thinking, VOiP isn't a bandwidth hog. How would a Gaming PC handle on this? Surely a powerful machine would overwhelm this hokey connection. Unfortunately, I've left my gaming days behind, so I don't have a L337 machine to test that, but I do have a HTPC and I couldn't detect any lag while streaming video. This thing is rated for 500Mbps, and thanks to modern packet-switching, it should handle all common household tasks. I don't recommend adding a router to this. Then you might really start testing the limits.

I've always preferred a spiral notebook for class and work. The ability to open 360 was great for crowded desks. But I would always destroy the spiral from repeatedly taking the notebook in and out of my bag. The spiral would snag on something or a few rings would bend out of place, and would ruin that ability to open flat. This notebook seems to have solved the problem by shrouding the rings with cloth. It prevents snagging and is still able to open flat.The pen holder is handy.The dividers are movable and the pockets hold a fair amount of paper. The little tabs that hold the dividers in place may get worn out or tear if moved too often.After a few days of use, I prefer this over 3-ring binders, composition notebooks, and stenographers pads, though the steno pad is a close 2nd.

At first, it made a lot of sense. It was clearly lighter and seemed better padded than the standard oblong fender. The rectangular shape fits well in storage. All features touted on the packaging.But after using it only a few days, I can see this is not going to survive as long as the standard fenders. The vinyl is rubs hard against the dock and is already showing signs of wear. I suspect it will last me a year or two, but I'll be in the market for new ones relatively soon.As for it being more storable, I leave my fenders hanging over the side, so storage really isn't much of a concern.I'd take away more stars, but for the price, I expect to get decent use out of it.

This griddle has SO many great applications. Aside from the usual griddle foods (pancake, eggs, bacon), you can cook also cook proteins that stick or fall through (fish, loose-packed burgers, tofu, vegetables, veggie patties, kabobs), and even bake to some extent (pizza, flatbread). And all of the food still catches that smoky charcoal flavor. There is some loss of flavor though, but it still tastes much better than when we use a frying pan in the house.But the application that really excites me, though I don't think it's advertised for this, is slow-roast BBQ. Get a low fire going, add a chip-pack if you want more smoke, and just forget about it for a few hours. I've tried this before straight on the grill, using a charcoal tray to one side and the meat on the other. There isn't enough charcoal to keep the heat consistent for hours. But if you lay out a good amount of charcoal, the direct heat dries and toasts the underside of the meat, not to mention the messy collagen/fat drippings all over your coals.This keeps the underside from drying and the trap catches all the drippings. The only caveat is that the smoked meat must be smaller than the griddle. That's fine for brisket and shoulders, but ribs need trimming. That's okay though, just chop off a few and freeze it for boiling stock later.

This is a lot of watch for the money, which I guess isn't saying very much considering the price. There's a lot of style-infringement and the execution is pretty decent, even if the materials aren't great. The watch itself (hands, case, bezel, face, etc) are styled after Rolex. Search for Submariner to compare. The band is styled after Maratac's Zulu straps. Together, they give the watch a diver's look, which I find very attractive. Unfortunately, according to the manual, it's only water resistant to 10 meters and should not be immersed. That means no swimming, much less diving.The second hand jumps precisely from hash-mark to hash-mark. It's not mistimed like many watches I've seen in this price range.The bezel sounds a bit cheap when you turn it. The clicks sound light/thin. But the serration on the bezel is positive and it turns pretty smoothly. The timing marks on the bezel are a joke, so you won't actually need to crank it often.The band looks like a Maratac Zulu, but it isn't. It's a pretty decent knock-off though. The hardware is thick steel, much like a real Maratac. The holes are precisely fused. The nylon is fairly rigid.It arrived in an oversized cardboard box with minimal padding and a folded 8.5"x11" sheet of paper they call a manual. It explains how to set the time, states that the bezel only turns counterclockwise, describes cleaning/maintenance/warranty. All very intuitive things that almost don't even warrant publishing.The manual suggests which "setting" to use with various grillables, e.g., NY Strip setting can also apply to Lamb Chops, Pork Chops, Beef Filets, Flat Irons. Take those suggestions with a grain of salt because the watch does not know the temperature or thickness of what I'm grilling. If my grill iss fired up to 600 and I'm grilling a 1/4" slider, that burger will be crispy in the recommended 12 minutes.Additional things I'm curious to know:(1) Who made the movement? Amazon says Seiko, but nowhere else is that published. The case only says Japanese movement.(2) I know at this price, the crystal isn't going to be Gorilla or sapphire, but is it plain glass or at least a mineral crystal? For the price, I think mineral is a reasonable expectation.Really, what you have is a sharp looking watch that steals design points from other good looking pieces, all done in a BBQ theme. Notice, it even says Sauce Resistant. It's not exactly the most durable watch, but it comes at a very reasonable price. I haven't had this long, but I do love this watch. I will revise my review if the timepiece becomes inaccurate or otherwise unduly breaks, but I'm expecting this to keep on ticking with average use. You could do much worse this price. I rate this over any Fossil, Casio, Seiko, Timex, for the same price.

It works on my lighter pieces with lightweight frames and plexiglass. I wouldn't trust it to hold up heavy wood frames with large glass. It's not the hook & loop I'm worried about, it's the adhesive backing. It may get stronger with time as it melds with the wall material, but in the mean time, it doesn't inspire much confidence.I'll update my review if the adhesive bond improves over time as I suspect. Until then, I do like it, so it get 4 stars. It will earn a fifth star if it really holds the claimed 3lbs in the future. Conversely, it will lose a star if I see no improvement and will lose 2 stars if the bond worsens.

This is a pretty decent diaper pail. The biggest selling point for us is that it uses plain trash bags which we buy in bulk anyway. Another advantage is the steel body which we're told will not absorb smells the way plastic does. And a benefit they don't mention is that the construction is hefty enough that it's more difficult to knock over than tall skinny cans like a Diaper Genie.Speaking of the Genie, we believe the Ubbi is superior. Even though we can get the refills fairly cheap via Costco and the Commissary, it's still pricier and less convenient compared to a big ol' box of Costco kitchen bags. And then there's the additional heft and stability mentioned earlier. The Genie is better at trapping smells in the bag during use as long as you're not squeamish about shoving your hand into a pail full of old diapers. Our plastic Genie hasn't absorbed much smell.Compared to our other pail, the Baby Trend Diaper Champ Deluxe, it's a draw. The Champ is plastic but wide and hefty. It's quite stable. It uses a sort of giant ball-valve to trap smells in the bag when tossing fresh ones. The Ubbi has no provision for trapping smells while open. Every time you toss one in, you get a whiff of stinky old diapers, but you learn to be quick about it. The Champ's plastic HAS absorbed some stink, but it's really not that noticeable, but I suppose this is one area where the Ubbi wins. So it's kind of a wash.But in the end, you can't help the smell. In all 3 cases, when you go to empty the pail, you get a big helping of days-old #1 & #2.Given a choice between the 3, I'd recommend the Champ overall because, as I said, it's a draw in performance, but it costs less than half the Ubbi! Next runner up is the Ubbi, despite the price. The Genie's easy to topple and the bags are annoying. Once we've used up all the bags, it's going to be donated or tossed.

I've read some of the other reviews and I share some points I agree with:(1) There's nothing in here that should relieve itch, not even oatmeal.(2) It's a pretty decent body wash.If nothing else, this will suffice as a body wash, but you could buy another body wash for less.HOWEVER, I found that this actually works on me. I am not typically very itchy, but I do get some irritation after being in the sun for a while, especially when mowing the lawn. I develop a mild itch over every exposed body part. Showering with this immediately relieves the itch. Just as an experiment, I showered with this as a prophylactic and it worked; I wasn't itchy after mowing the yards.Judging by how my skin feels after using this, my theory is that it leaves a behind a film that keeps the skin hydrated and seals out irritants. This actually felt a little bothersome at first, a bit like sunscreen, but it wasn't unbearable.Another excellent use for this is to relieve those funny itches you cannot find. You know the ones where you end up scratching head-to-toe with no relief. Just jump in the shower with this and I'm relieved.

I love it. I've been wearing it for days and it hasn't faded, tainted, discolored, or caused any irritation. And it really sparkles nicely. The chain is very thin, but strong enough to hold up to the occasional tug from Baby. The details around the edge came as a pleasant surprise. There are 11 tiny diamond settings. They're very cute. I can't believe they didn't show them off in the photos. I tried to take a photo, but I can't seem to do them justice. Come on Amazon, you'd sell a lot more of these if you'd show off how pretty the sides are.

The film actually does resemble stained glass from 5 feet away. They're pretty convincing. The privacy is excellent. And because of the nature of the pattern, it's more forgiving to mistakes. I used a pattern called "paper" by the same manufacturer and because it was monotone and homogenous, you could very plainly see the bubbles and the edges peeling. It took 3 or 4 tries to get it right. This one went on in just one shot and I'm happy. The colors make our front entrance just a bit more fun.Many of the reviews are excellent. You should read them for great tips on how to ensure success.In a nutshell:(1) Cut film to size(2) Clean glass with Windex or similar(3) Scrape away stray paint(4) Spray glass with water. Plain water worked just fine for me.(5) Apply film carefully(6) Squegee to remove water and bubbles out from under the film(7) Let dry

Very much like a K-Cup for gardeners. It makes it super-duper easy to start a garden. Each cup is filled with plenty of seeds to effectively guarantee that at least ONE plant will sprout from each cup. I didn't have a single dud. What more can I ask for.I do have 1 small complaint though. One pod opened, presumably in transit, and spilled everywhere. I was able to collect most of the seeds and put it back in the cup, but some were lost completely. Just keep that in mind if you're ordering online (via Amazon of course) but, consider visiting a brick&mortar for this type of product.

First things first, to reap the FULL benefit of this 802.11ac wi-fi dongle, you must have a 802.11ac router. However, it will work with just about any wifi router on the market, albeit not at top speed.I do not have an 802.11ac router. In fact, I don't even have a 802.11n router anymore (long sad story). I'm running a plain ol' FiOS router which I believe is only 802.11b. This dongle found the network quickly and easily and stays connected, but it's not any faster than my previous dongle because the router is the limiting factor.But to that end, I want to stress how incredibly simple it was to set up. (1) Plug the dongle into your USB port (2) Insert CD into your optical drive and let it autorun (3) Select the driver-only or driver+utility for the T2UH (4) Wait for installation to finish (5) Connect to your network.The hardest part in the entire process is remembering your network name and password, but even if you've forgotten, TP-Link has you covered. If you're the forgetful type, I hope you have a router with WPS configuration. If you do, you can simply press the WPS button on your router and then press & hold the WPS button on the dongle. Hold it until the connection is established, and you're done. Easy peasy.If you're looking for an inexpensive, reliable, easy-to-use dongle to connect your device to your wifi network, you can't do much better than the T2UH. I confirm that this works well on my Windows 8.1 and Windows 7 machines.
Super easy to use. Brought my deer-damaged fir trees back from the brink. I'm hoping one more application will make my trees full again.

This is very well constructed and relatively light too. I'm not the least bit concerned in the quality/robustness department.It does have a considerable amount of battery life and worked just fine outdoors in the relatively harsh 2015 winter. However, I received this late in the season and was unable to take this to the mountains where the super cold conditions tend to suck the life out of batteries.However, I'm a little annoyed with it's incompatibility with the standard waterproof GoPro housing. Falling snow or powder kicked up by other skiers/boarders/wind will stick and melt. This puts the camera at some risk. More importantly, the waterproof enclosure adds a moderate amount of shock-protection, which I appreciate as a clumsy all-mountain rider. Without it, I don't feel confident taking my GoPro on the slopes.I considered the following 2 options:1. Use the pole with the waterproof housing and forgo the USB connection. That basically makes it an overpriced selfie-stick.2. Modify the waterproof housing to allow for the USB connection. That makes it no-longer water-proof, but sufficiently water & shock resistant for use in the snow.And ultimately opted for #2 and bought another waterproof housing. All in all, I'd say it was worth it.

The material and the stitches held up to the chain of winter blasts we received. Genuinely surprised by how good this is for the price. I bet it would even hold up as luggage, at least for one flight anyway. The construction is unquestionably solid.And the most important detail of all, it fits 6 of my 3" thick patio cushions with room to spare. I could probably squeeze 9 in there with very little effort. If I owned 9 cushions, I'd try it, but I'm just eyeballin' for now.Once it warms up, I'll bring the cushions out, and put the Classic Accessories patio furniture covers into this duffel.

Canister vacuums have more or less been completely replaced by uprights in the average American household. And in the last decade, we've all gone from bagged uprights, to bagless uprights. And with good reason. For most of us, a bagless upright maneuvers quickly and easily, takes up very little space, and weighs less. All great qualities, considering the landscape of the average suburban American home (taller and narrower to cram more homes in smaller spaces). So why would anyone take 2 steps back in vacuum technology to buy an old-school bagged canister vacuum?PROSAs far as aesthetics go, this thing is hands-down the prettiest vacuum I've ever seen. Dysons are attractive in a somewhat industrial and functional way, but this Miele has curves and real steel tones in an almost art-deco way.It's also the most solidly built vacuum I've seen since the old Dirt-Devil canister vacuum from back in the day. The steel neck is robust, heavy even. And the plastic halves click shut like something you'd find on a car than the usual cheap clackiness you find on Dysons and Rubbermaids. It's hard to explain, but this feels like a serious piece of equipment where the Dyson and Eurekas I own feel toyish. It makes vacuuming feel like you're accomplishing something, like you're actually working, rather than performing a chore. It's just an oddly satisfying feeling.This is the most quiet vacuum I've ever witnessed by a large margin. Even with the brush-roll on, you can carry on a conversation. Not sure why you'd want to, but you could. Naturally, you'd have to talk over it a bit, but you won't be shouting like when I use the Eureka.This (relative) silence belies its power. It's very capable of sucking up dust and crumbs. It doesn't choke on anything either. I don't have the tools to quantify the suction, but my calibrated arm-technique, it feels as strong as the Dyson, but over larger area.And about that brush-roll. It's electrically driven and it has way more torque than the pneumatic ones that rely on the suction to drive impellers and gears. Instead, this one just chugs along, sucking up long hairs with nary a hiccup.CONSBut, like all bagged canister vacuums from back in the day, it has the same flaws. You feel like you're dragging a small carry-on bag everywhere you go. The convenient handle makes it easier to transport, but it's still not as convenient as an all-in-one upright design.Replacing the tiny bags are simple, but not nearly as simple as pulling the trigger on the Dyson's trap door.
