On the bright side, you don't get a dust cloud when you change bags. The bags aren't cheap. There's no good way to reprocess them either, I tried.The air filter on the canister is nominal. It'll probably catch stray dust that escapes the bag, but nothing more. Miele sells a HEPA filter that looks like it'll be more effective at air filtration.It doesn't store as well as an upright. Uprights stand on their own and have a small footprint. The canister can sit up and it takes up less space that way, but the handle and vacuum head are big and cannot stand on their own. It's currently propped in the corner of a hall closet. Honestly, that's no worse than an upright, after all, they'd be standing in the same corner. But where this affects me is in between cleanings. For instance, let's say I vacuumed the dining room and want to straighten out the cushions before I vacuum the living room. I have to put the handle on the floor because it would slide down the wall if I propped it up. Also, sometimes, I leave the vacuum out in the middle of the room as a reminder to vacuum that day. While its inability to stand on its own is a very small nuisance to me, I imagine this will be a much bigger issue for folks with bad backs.TL;DR This is an excellent quality product that unfortunately doesn't suit the modern American home. But if you can put up with the quirks, it's really a great vacuum and deserves your consideration.

There are many excellent uses for this body wash. Naturally, the first is for Baby. Our daughter has mild eczema and this doesn't seem to make it any worse. Other soaps make it flare up. Her skin feels softer during the wash too, so it seems to be pretty effective. I wish it were a miracle cure for her skin, but I'll take minor victories.What works for Baby, also works for Mom & Dad. Skin feels noticeably smoother after a shower, but it's a small bottle and we went through it really quickly once the adults started using it.M. Lafferman suggested using it for shaving. I have sensitive skin so I'm always on the lookout for a new product that takes the pain out of shaving. I've used hair conditioner in lieu of shaving cream with excellent results, so I knew he was probably right, and I just had to try. Lo and behold, it's better than conditioner, but not quite as good as Lubriderm. My Fusion cartridges glide over the skin with very little effort. It barely even tugs at the skin. I don't even need toner or balm afterwards. Best of all, it cleans right up. The Fusion with its tight blade spacing is notorious for collecting stubbly gunk between the blades. It washed right out with water. Normally, I'd have to tap pretty hard to get it clean.Just an observation, but this stuff is roughly 60 cents per ounce. It goes a long way on Baby, and with her skin condition, we'll buy her more. As for the grown-ups, we'll go back to normal body-washes which are around 20 cents per ounce. As great as it felt, it didn't feel 3x as good as Olay, for instance. Call me cheap. I admit it.Fun fact, calendula are also known as pot marigolds, not to be mistaken for other types of marigolds. It is believed to have a soothing effect on skin and muscles.

Snuffles is legendary where I'm from (grew up 5 miles from the Gund plant in NJ). If you love Snuffles and you love Pandas, this is a no-brainer.Snuffles is super plush. The beans in the butt help it sit upright well. My Snuffles is very soft and floppy. She has the most lovable expression. My baby daughter took to her immediately. It is now her favorite nap-time pal.Even though it says to hand-wash, I put her in the washing machine anyway. No damage and she hang-dried very well. I'll machine-wash her again the next time she gets all slobbered up.

It's soft and transfers makeup smoothly and evenly. You can brush or dab. The manufacturer's videos recommend dabbing. Worked both ways for me. I've only used an arched all-purpose face brush from Lancome before, so I'm far from an expert. This Kabuki brush works as well, maybe a little better than my old Lancome brush.My husband says it looks like a tiny shaving cream brush and has threatened to use it. I thought about letting him, but I like it too much to let him ruin it. :-)

Feels very smooth on the skin and absorbs quickly.Great part of a toner-essence-lotion regimen.Inadequate on its own for folks with dry-ish skin like me.That said, I think this is a little too expensive.It's been good while it lasted, but I will not buy more.

It has a good heft without being heavy, and the tamping surfaces are very flat. It's better than I expected for the price and would have earned 5 stars if not for a small flaw.The flash (defined below) is too prominent. It interferes with the sides of the filter cup which is very slightly tapered. The cup has marks for double and quadruple shots. Because of the flash, the tamper will not reach the double shot mark. Basically, I can only make quadruple shots.Considering that it would drive up the price if they took the time to debur each tamper or improve their cast, I'd leave this product as-is. It's a solid 4.5-star product.If you're in the market for this size tamper, I recommend this. If the flash bothers you, you can do what I did and hand-finish it yourself. It's just aluminum, so you can knock down the flash with a steel file.From Wikipedia: Flash, also known as flashing, is excess material attached to a molded, forged, or cast product, which must usually be removed. This is typically caused by leakage of the material between the two surfaces of a mold (beginning along the parting line[1]) or between the base material and the mold (in the case of overmolding). Molding flash is seen when the optimized parameter on cull height is not calibrated.[citation needed] Proper design of mold parting surfaces can reduce or eliminate flash.

Fits my largish face comfortably. Construction quality was pretty decent; above average for over-the-counter frames, but below average compared to proper prescription frames. I'd say it was appropriate for the price. The trifocal design takes a lot of squinting and time to acclimate. In a month of casual use, I failed. The intent is to minimize how often you adjust the position of your glasses, but I found myself adjusting them more often. Ultimately, I gave up and went back to regular cheap-o readers.That's not to say you may not be more successful. They just weren't working out for me. Don't let my personal failure deter you from trying.

This review is for the N300. It's not the easiest to set up, nor is it the prettiest. Had it been, it would've earned a full 5-stars. 4-stars is a good rating, equivalent to "I like it." I simply can't say "I love it" which would be a 5-star rating.The instructions were not what I'd call clearly written. 5-star instructions are immediately intelligible to an average user. If I weren't already experienced in setting up wireless networks, I might have struggled with the instructions that were provided. That said, it's not a difficult device to set up. You plug in a power outlet within range of your desired network. Connect your personal computer to the booster via wifi or the provided patch cable. Then, use the provided address to access the setup menu. There, you can see the networks within range. Connect the booster to your desired network. Wait while it saves. Once it restarts, you can unplug and relocate the booster anywhere within range of your network. Sound easy? Great, you'll have no trouble. Was that hard to follow? The instructions are worse.When everything else in the tech-world is so stylish and even $10 gadgets get the full industrial-design treatment, you can't bring a brick with antennas to market. Just look at the TP-Link AC750 sold on the same page. It may not be your cup of tea, but they put a lot of effort into making it easy on the eyes. The N300 looks like a brick-phone from the 80's. It would look right at home with an Apple II desktop computer. But the bigger issue isn't simply that it's ugly. It's brickiness means it sticks far out of the wall. If you plug a wall-wart into this, it'll stick out twice as far. For this reason, I put it in a low-traffic area where my family won't kick it by accident.But I DO appreciate the concept, and if you need a wifi booster in a home that doesn't have enough available power outlets, I DO recommend this. After all, despite my whining about its looks and setup instructions, it works quite well, at least for now.

A lot of great reviews have been written about this radio already. If you haven't yet, I recommend you read the most helpful positive & critical reviews.There's not much I can add, so I'll try my best.Mine says "Grundig Edition" across the top. It's nice to see the legendary manufacturer's name on the radio, but it's only a name. Eton licenses the name in the US. The radio was designed & developed by Eton. Still, it was a pleasant surprise.Assembled in China. That doesn't bother me, but it does to some, so I'll mention it. It might explain some quality-control issues other reviewers have had, but my radio works just fine.Came with a really handy nylon pouch. It's not the prettiest, but the radio slides in and out smoothly and keeps some dust and moisture out. I could do without the large bright white Eton logo, but at least it's easy to identify. If this radio catches on like I imagine, there may be nicer pouches on the market soon. Maybe leather? Belt loops?My opinion on the sound-quality is that it's pretty good for what it is. The mono speaker does a decent job, but for better quality, you need to use headphones. It's not perfectly balanced, but I don't expect hi-fi sound from a tiny inexpensive transistor radio. It's more than good enough for hours of casual listening.It has every feature I could ask for in a radio except NOAA's National Weather Service. This would've been perfect if it just added that one feature.I don't miss the solar and/or crank features found on other Eton radios because this is supposed to be lightweight, compact, and portable. Adding solar makes it bigger to accommodate the surface area of a 3v panel, adds a nominal amount of weight & bulk, and makes it more fragile. The crank & dynamo would also add unwanted weight & bulk.I think the size is perfect as-is. It's similar in size to an iPhone 4, but weighs considerably less. It's barely noticeable in a pocket. I've added it to my EDC. A radio is an often forgotten EDC item. When a power grid crashes, it tends to take cell and cable out with it. Radio, OTA HDTV, and satellite may be the only sources of information at such a time, and of the 3, only the radio is portable. Remember to use lithium batteries for longer life and less weight.

So far, this is turning out to be another excellent product from OXO. In one of the photos, you see the feet. They're just tall enough, stout enough, and spaced enough to allow plenty of drainage. Other mats I've used were too low and used many tiny feet. This lead to food getting stuck under the mat. I'm talking about common things like rice, getting hung up under the mat. I'd have to lift the mat and spray it down after every load of dishes.The design on this allows most food to drain away without getting stuck. I don't have to lift the mat unless something stringy gets under there, like tough noodles or stringy vegetables. This is much easier than before.The taller feet also provide more cushion. You can toss a dish in the sink pretty carefree. It will just bounce on the mat. On cheaper mats, the dish bottoms out and I could hear a thunk as the plate connects with the steel.It doesn't use suction cups, like some other premium mats I've tried, which is good. Food likes to get trapped around those cups too. And lifting it off to clean is much harder when they're anchored down with suction cups. That's why I made the decision, that if I have to release trapped food regardless, I may as well use something that's easier to lift.As much as I like it (4-stars), I don't love it (5-stars), because it isn't very attractive. It's a very utilitarian look. It's not even the usual 2-tone black & white OXO likes to use, not that it would've been an improvement. I think they were shooting for a neutral tone, but what they achieved is just dull grey. Are aesthetics really worth a full star? For many, the kitchen is the star of the house and everything in it needs to look good, so for those folks, yes it's easily worth a full star. It's more like a half-star for me, but since that's not an option, I give it 4-stars

I only give 5-stars to things that go above & beyond expectation. Hard to do that with wipers, but these Bosch Insight blades accomplished that.As usual, removing the crusty old blades is the hardest part of the process. Once they're off, installing fresh blades are generally simple affairs.Once you pop the trap-door open, these go on like any other blade. Then, when you close the trap-door, they provide an additional positive lock. You can't remove them without opening the trap-door. I've never had a blade fall off before, but this still gives me peace-of-mind, which I appreciate. And that's the "value added" aspect that earns the 5th star.As a wiper, it's as good as the pair that came with my Subaru, which is to say, perfectly. Blade swings, water wipes off. No hiccups. There seems to be a bit more tension than factory, which I appreciate. I think that helps wipe away water more completely.

I like the simplicity of  installation.(1) Find appropriate screws(2) Find studs(3) Align between studs(4) Drive screws into studsIt's a sturdy plastic panel that gets the job done. Reminds me of the Race Deck garage flooring tiles.I like that you don't need to pre-install mounting spacers or lug huge cumbersome sheets of pegboard around.Black plastic finish looks pretty professional. Better than a cheap wood pegboard.But, that ease of installation robs you of the freedom to mount this wherever you need. You MUST hang between studs and that may not be the best location for you.Maybe if you plan to use this with very light tools, you can just use anchors in your drywall, but I would advise against that.All in all, I'd call it a wash. Just keep in mind the issue about mounting between studs. If that doesn't bother you, I'd have no qualms of recommending this to you.Project idea: This might look really good if you finish an entire garage wall (corner-to-corner, ceiling-to-floor) with these tiles. The tough plastic would protect your walls and you could mount just about anything anywhere on that wall. The dark plastic finish would look pretty macho too. You'd have to trim the edge pieces to fit. Just a thought.

After reading other reviews, I've come to the conclusion that this product is particular about the type of mulch used.The most common complaint has been that the glue is too thin to hold their mulch in place. They spray more, and it turns white. Some have complained of it turning white even with a light application.My experience was nearly identical. The product looks like very runny glue. Upon first application, it didn't hold my mulch and it was starting to get a bit frosty. I applied a second coat later, and it became much more frosty. Could even be considered pretty in the winter, but not year-round.I will not be using this product again.

They do exactly what they're supposed to, so I like them. There's not enough of any 1 hook for me to finish my work bench, but it gives me a taste of everything, so I can buy more of the hooks I'll actually need.I didn't verify whether they hold up to the claimed 20 lbs, but I don't see any reason they wouldn't. They're solid thick-gauged steel, not like the cheap off-brand stuff.One thing to note is that this is for 1/4" pegboard, either plastic or particleboard. Just as a test, I tried it on my tool chest which has 1/8" steel walls. They fit a lot looser and the straight ones hung at a slightly downward angle, which makes them basically useless since everything will slide/roll off.

My usual wax is IBIZ. This is a thicker, but smoother product. It goes on really easily. Comes off just as easily. Leaves a great shiny finish. I'm not sure whether this will hold up to the elements quite as well as IBIZ, but considering how much cheaper & easier this is, I'd rather apply this more frequently than use IBIZ less frequently. Does that make sense?Coupled with Chemical Guys' EcoSmart-RU, this is a really easy way to keep your car looking like new.

On the Amazon product page, this novel is described as:"-a cozy mystery with a dark side-some laughs, gasps, and a little murder-a heroine you'd like to take out for coffee or join for a beer on the beach-fun, smart, beautifully messy characters-contemporary mystery, romance and suspense"And in this case, Sea Devil is a story that actually delivers all it is said to be. ;-)I thoroughly enjoyed Sea-Devil from start to the exciting finish. It is a cozy mystery/romance with substance.Many of the chapters start with a description of a sea creature that is then used as a metaphor in the pages to follow; I thought that added a lot to the story overall and added a nice, original touch.The characters are well-developed, I especially liked Sam Tegue, the main character's boyfriend. All were believable for the most part although I did think some of the actions of the dysfunctional family members that Delilah had were just a tad "over the top".Example: SPOILER ALERT!!! When Uncle Clark just can't wait to publish that naughty photo of Delilah from the past in his newspaper, knowing it will be devastating to her and was of minor relevance to the current situation that the police were investigating. Then in other parts of the book, he is kind and generous to Delilah. I know a LOT about crazy families, I've met more than my share over the years, but I thought in some respects their nastiness and then rebound civility and in some cases kindness, didn't ring true at times. But this was a minor complaint I had with the book and definitely did not detract from enjoying it overall.This is a long novel (over 400 pages) for the kind of story that it is; again I appreciated this. I dislike novellas and novels that are too short and hover at 200 pages or less. IMO, not long enough to really develop most stories worth telling.LOTS of twists and turns and the author keeps the reader guessing right up until the last few pages, how the whole story will unfold. I appreciate that. Too many cozies are of the "cookie cutter" variety, with the same old, same old plot, with only minor variations for each story. Definitely not the case with Sea Devil.I will definitely be checking out more books from Jessica Sherry. She did a better than average job writing this one and the characters in this book could certainly be used effectively in a series worth reading.

I had heard so much about this series and I liked that it was set in a small town, centering on the life of a priest and friends living there; sounded different and refreshing.I started with book one: AT HOME IN MITFORD and got as far as page 3 and that was enough for me.Starting off with his secretary hitting a friendly but homeless dog TWICE, is not my idea of a fun or enjoyable read. So much for Christianity!!!This surprised and annoyed me so much that I gave up at that point. I just didn't have any interest beyond that scene.I hate animal cruelty in any shape or form and in this supposedly light and uplifting novel, there was no place for it.Won't be checking out any further books in this series either. Too many other choices out there.

I'm always looking for ways to get more done in a day and to be less distracted along the way.I was attracted to this book by its title and also the many positive reviews written about it, at Amazon.com.Although it's obvious that a lot of work went into writing this book, it didn't appeal to me overall. Seemed to be a lot of the same things I had read elsewhere about prioritizing lists of things to do each day. And with the added suggestion to drop things from those lists if they weren't REALLY important for a person to actually complete.How would that realistically work for most people? I know that in my case, I often have things on my "to do" list that I'm not all that excited or crazy about BUT for whatever reason, eventually they still need to be addressed. Things like: paying bills, going for groceries, dentist appts....not thrilling by any means but still, in the real world, they have to get done. Wouldn't call them "10s" though, by any means.OK, but not a book I'd personally refer to or keep on my kindle. I have read a lot better motivational and organizational books.In my case, what seems to work best is not making the daily "to do" list TOO long but rather picking a realistic amount of things to actually complete or get a large part of them completed, that day. That DOES give me a sense of accomplishment and spurs me on.

I was attracted to the cover, title and theme of this book so decided to give it a go. For the most part, I really enjoyed: The Sea Les Traveled.It is rather a unique story about a man who actually DOES run away from home and sail off into the sunset, finding adventure, romance and lots of abundance along the way, often in very unexpected places and ways.The description of sailing on the high seas in a large sailboat were interesting and were an eye-opener too. Not for the faint of heart or the weak of muscle, that's for sure.I did find parts of the story rather far-fetched but as the author states at the beginning of the book, parts were embellished and changed but apparently most of it did happen.I thought the author and his friends did a LOT of drinking, morning, noon and night...that part seemed a bit much, considering the long and early start of days on-board and quite unhealthy too.Overall though, an enjoyable ride along with Les, Essie and Long John...I wish I could have been there!!!Will check out other books from this author too.Geraldine Helen Hartman, author of: Third Chapter, Second Chance, a midlife romance

Sharon Butala is one of my favorite Canadian authors. Her writing style always appeals to me and her story topics are original and engaging.Although I'm not a big fan of short stories, I decided to give this one a try. It was (as is usual for her) a unique and compelling read.It's also a story that's come to mind many times, after reading it. Atmospheric and memorable reading.I'm taking off one star as I would have preferred a full length novella or novel, with this same theme. I think this definitely could have been a longer story and for me, that would have added to the overall enjoyment of reading it.

As I wrote about in my own book:Laughing AT the Grim Reaper! Gems of Wisdom for Aging Well,Ive had (MORE THAN) my share of sleepless nights, over the years. :-(Particularly annoying for me has been waking up in the middle of the night (around 3 AM) which is also a time referred to as:The Hour of the Wolf.Tossing, turning, wide awake but tiredthinking all kinds of crazy, annoying and at times, very disturbing thoughts. Where some of them came from, I have no idea. But enough to keep me awake and to interrupt sleep in a most unpleasant way.The sleepless night situation HAS improved in the past couple of years as I have been making a real effort to go to sleep in a calm, relaxed frame of mind and when I DO wake up, in the middle of the night now, there are a lot fewer negative thoughts that come to mind.But now, when it does happens, I replace these thoughts with positive ones. Good things I choose and WANT to dwell on,its worth the effort and it really has helped.I happened to be browsing over at Amazon one day recently and did a search for Hour of the Wolf as I had seen the  Ingmar Bergman movie of the same name, many years ago in Toronto and wondered if it was still available. A strange, surreal and original story that I never completely forgot.And the term hour of the wolf is one that has always stayed with me, particularly on sleepless nights when I wake up during the period between 3-5AM  AKA, the hour of the wolf.When I did that search at Amazon, this Kindle book: Taming the Hour of the Wolf, also came up and I am SO glad I checked it out too. Its a wonderful book! :-)Written in a personable, engaging style and filled with 144 affirmations that readers can refer to, again and again, when the Hour of the Wolf strikes a discordant note.I am a true believer in the power of positive thoughts and particularly affirmations.The ones that the author shares in this book are divided into categories including:Sleeplessness, Negativity & Doubt, Procrastination, Abundance and several others.By choosing a particular category, you are then given a list of useful and calming affirmations to help still the mind and replace negative, upsetting thoughts, particularly during the Hour of the Wolf.I think most people at some time or other grapple with sleepless nights. Its not fun, its frustrating and getting back to sleep can be so difficult attimes.By keeping this book: Taming the Hour of the Wolf, close at hand on a bedside table perhaps, there is help only a click or page turn away.The Kindle version (which is the one I have) is nicely formatted, with full page nature photos to begin each new category.  And at less than a $1. for the Kindle version right now, a real bargain for a reference guide that I know I will be referring to, again and again. Especially when the hour of the wolf takes a turn for the worse and I need some positive thoughts to help to calm my mind and get back to sleep.If you also struggle with ongoing or even occasional sleepless nights, check this one out.Also shared at: mypoeticpath. wordpress.com  and myreallifereviews  .com (spaces removed)HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!*****NOTE to Author: I would appreciate you getting in touch via email if possible as I have a couple of questions re: this kindle book, thanks. Contact info at my blogs.

This soap has an ok ingredient list but it goes downhill steadily from there.First of all, the bars are SO big that they are hard to grip when taking a shower. Yes, there is such a thing as a bar of soap being too big and this one is.Then there is the slime factor. After only a couple of uses, this soap gets all slimy and gooey, no matter how often you empty out the soap dish.The smell of this soap is hard to describe, it IS nauseating as another reviewer mentioned, not pleasant at all. I don't like heavily scented products of any kind but for this one, it's a case of it being a very weird, 'earthy' smell that lingers on the skin afterwards.I now use Dr. Bonner's unscented soap bars and have been very happy with their products. No slime or weird smell either

A sun-drenched beach read that had me wanting to visit the locales in this story from chapter 1, right up to the exciting and original ending.I really liked the main character Nina, a woman on a mission to start fresh in sunny Florida, where she soon makes friends, finds adventure and a new home, far away from the troubles she left behind in her old life.Loved Danish most of all, what a character. And Pansy, I'd like to have her for a pal, what a sweetie!! ;-)The only thing I couldn't really picture was what a CAY actually looks like. I'm going to have to do more reading about those from landlocked BC Canada. ;-)I will definitely be checking out more books by this author; I'm glad I gave Sunbaked a try! .Geraldine Helen Hartman, author of: Third Chapter, Second Chance (a midlife romance)

I use this lotion throughout the day, particularly on my hands and arms.It has a just right consistency, not too thick but not watery.Absorbs quickly and completely, leaving a lovely, fresh scent that not only smells nice but lifts my spirits a bit too, with each application!I keep this one handy, right beside the soap dish, as a quick pick me up after washing my hands.  it!!!

Usually, I am NOT a fan of any kind of body/after bath oil type product. Too messy, too greasy,dont absorb BUT, when it comes to Weleda Body Oils, that is not the case. I love their body oils, the Evening Primrose Oil in particular.It has a light, delicate scent, it really moisturizes, a LITTLE goes a long way and best of all, it absorbs quickly and completely, making application a breeze.I feel pampered and special when I use Weleda Evening Primrose Body Oil. ;-) And dont we all need more pampering in our lives?

This book was a bit entertaining but in terms of concrete suggestions for freedom businesses, I found it lacking.Too basic and general overall to be much help to someone looking for actual suggestions what types of businesses to consider.

This was an OK guide but not great. The various places the author chose to write about in general terms were a good starting point, but in terms of actual requirements to MOVE and not just visit, nothing specific. I would have appreciated knowing more about actual visa requirements, etc...not just "touristy" type info. that could be gleaned elsewhere online.

These were a GOOD surprise! I didn't really know what to expect from a snack made with buckwheat but these are tasty, filling, not too sweet and have a nice cocoa kick to them too.Nutritionally, a lot better than most sweet snacks available and all organic ingredients too, that for me is so important.Will definitely buy these again and try some of the other flavors too.I love the organic spelt lemon cookies this company sells too. Give them a try if you like simple cookies with a good lemony zing!!! :-)Recommended!Geraldine Helen Hartman, award winning cookbook author

I received this brush in a padded envelope that was slashed open at the top, right across.The brush itself was not very impressive either. Seemed too rough and cheaply made. And I wouldn't use anything like this, that arrived in an open package.I've read a lot about dry brushing but my concern continues to be how to keep the brush itself clean and hygienic, use after use. Any suggestions? I'm still going to look for a dry brush to use but this isn't for me.Sent a request for a refund, hopefully it won't be a big long hassle getting one. :-(

These crackers are not good. They have a stale, flat "flavor" and the prominent taste is the spelt flour (first ingredient). Not what I expected or wanted. A few seeds thrown on top do not redeem these, nutritionally or taste-wise.I'm going back to Mary's Gone Crackers and Late July brands for my next cracker purchases.I thought I'd try something new this time but these were not a good choice.Geraldine Helen Hartman, award-winning cookbook author and avid product reviewere

Not happy with this holder at all!First of all, the one I received is green NOT clear. That was a surprise. Don't know if this was just a shipping error but I definitely expected a clear one with no color.The plastic has several  long, deep scratches in it and the holder isn't very stable with the cookbooks I tried in it.Returning for a refund. This is a dud, IMO. Back to my search for the perfect cookbook holder. :-(Geraldine Helen Hartman, award winning cookbook author.

A very interesting and in depth personal story about life in Belize.I've been fascinated by this part of the world for many years. For the most part, up until reading this book, I had only read stories about the idyllic, tropical setting, friendly people, cheap cost of living....none of the downside aspects of what this "paradise" can also is all about.I was particularly shocked and saddened to read that there are a lot of Belize residents who are not eco-conscious AT ALL and routinely burn all types of garbage etc...and also about how much animal cruelty there exists there too. Very upsetting.I do wonder though, why the author still lives there, given the MANY negatives he writes about in this book about Belize. I certainly don't have any interest in visiting or living there, after reading his story.

This dvd collection exceeded my expectations! What a bargain.I particularly liked Dishonored Lady and Nancy Drew, Reporter.If you love the golden oldies and film noir type movies, don't miss this collection. I'm planning to check out more of the Mystery Classics too. Great prices, great old movies...what's not to love.And as far as film quality, for the age of these movies, it's definitely acceptable.Highly recommended!!!

...not as good as I expected it to be, based on the many glowing editorial reviews about this book and its author,Roy Rowan.As a couple of other reviewers have mentioned here, it toggled between a self-help book and memoir and that was a bit distracting.I also would have preferred a more optimistic tone overall. I didn't enjoy reading all the (sometimes gory) details about his two experiences with cancer and the MANY pages of war stories.I think this book would appeal to people who have lived some of the same experiences as this author, living abroad extensively and/or as an international reporter. For me, it just wasn't all that interesting.I gave up before I finished and will be passing this one along to our local free box at the library.

I enjoyed this movie but I would say it was good, not great. Thought it dragged a bit, towards the end I was getting a bit restless to see the ending and wrap it up.This is not a movie that I'd watch more than once and my favs, I certainly do.I had heard about this scandal years ago and had watched the Jokers Wild with Barry after his long exile from tv so it was interesting to see the background of his career before his lucrative comeback.

If you love film noir like I do, don't miss this gem of a movie. Barbara Stanwyck and Burt Lancaster are both terrific and the story has some unexpected twists and turns to keep things interesting from beginning to end.SPOILER ALERT..I particularly liked the scenes set on Staten Island, mysterious and added so much to the intrigue and suspense. I also liked that Burt's character actually did have some initial strong feelings for his wife, not just the usual gold digger type of tale.Loved it all, the story, lead actors, supporting cast (yes that is William Conrad much thinner!) the sets, the clothes...one of my fav movies in one of my fav genres. Can't wait to view it again.

If you like a true rose scent and a better than average soap ingredient list, you may want to give this one a try. It's also exfoliating, with plenty of tiny granules throughout to give your skin a good cleansing.I actually prefer Dr. Woods unscented organic soap bar but gave this kind a try, to see if it would lighten dark spots as described. I just started using it so can't vouch for that so far but it is a good soap overall, that I do know. :-)PS: After trying this soap for a few days, I can now vouch for its lightening powers, it definitely does! I wash my hands a lot throughout the day and after a couple of days, I could actually note a difference between my arms (tanned) and my hands looking lighter!

For the most part, I really enjoyed this book. It provides a lot of general information for anyone considering a move to Ecuador, particularly retiring there. I enjoyed the author's personal stories about their various adventures and experiences as they settled in, albeit for only a short time, as they left after the first 8 months due to medical concerns (but still loving Ecuador at that point in time!)Definitely worth checking out if you are considering the expat life in South America.Ecuador certainly seems to offer a lot for a small amount of cash and not too much hassle to make it a reality. :-)Geraldine Helen Hartman, author of: Laughing AT the Grim Reaper! Gems of Wisdom for Aging Well

This guide provides a good overview of what the chakras are and how they impact every area of our life on a daily basis, depending on if they are balanced or not.After reading this book I felt like I had a much better understanding of the chakras and how I can achieve a better balance in life by working to keep them clear and to allow good energy to flow freely. I do think implementing this complete program successfully would take longer than a week and it would definitely take discipline and a committment of time. But as the author points out throughout this guide, the rewards are numerous and can be life changing. And even if you decide to only work on small changes and steps in this regard , its all good.Geraldine Helen Hartman author of: Laughing at the Grim Reaper! Gems of Wisdom for Aging Well

There are some good tips and reminders in this guide how to live life to the fullest every day.I liked the conversational tone throughout this book, like a visit with a wise and caring friend.Although I didn't personally note any ideas that I hadn't already been aware of , still helpful to be reminded of these life-enhancing suggestions nonetheless.We all want to live happier, more meaningful lives and on a daily basis. If you've been going through challenges or a tough period in life and need to get back on a more positive track, this guide is certainly worth checking out.Geraldine Helen Hartman author of: Laughing at the Grim Reaper! Gems of Wisdom For Aging Well

I liked some aspects of this story but not everything.The good: liked the choice of the 1950s and the "noir" type feel to the story. Henry was a believable main character and for the most part like-able. Lots of twists and turns to keep things interesting and to keep the reader guessing how things would eventually turn out. I also (unlike several other readers) DID like the time travel closet, I thought it was a rather unique idea to add to a detective story.Loved the cover too, just perfect!What I didn't like, some of the plot is kind of far-fetched. SPOILER!!!! Henry allows Luna to go back to her home in the woods and to stay for hours at a time at a hotel, when the bad guys are hot on their trail, that didn't ring true. Another thing I wondered about was when Henry was told to be at the docks at 11 and then it's actually midnight when the meeting begins. What happened there? Did they keep him waiting or was it a mistake by the author, about the different times mentioned in the book for this meeting?I would have liked a LOT more 50s related references in the story re: cars, clothes, food, music, slang...that always adds to these kinds of nostalgic stories, in a big way. Not much that made it uniquely 50s fare.I think I may check out more books by this author, based on this experience but it will have to wait till I catch up with my Kindle backlog. I have a LOT of books on my Fire, just trying to find the time to read them! ;-)

These are a healthier choice than regular potato chips and quite tasty too. I'm taking off one star as I'd prefer an organic ingredient list, even if the cost did have to go up a bit.I also think the sodium content could be reduced without any significant loss in taste. I thought they were just a bit too salty and the sodium content is quite high for a healthier type of snack that this is.OK but could be even better.Geraldine Helen Hartman author of the Groovy Green Kitchen series

I read this short novel in one afternoon and for the most part, really enjoyed it.An original and entertaining "starting over" tale about a woman in midlife who ends up dumped by her husband of over 20 years for a younger woman aka Fast Tracker, when she didn't see any of the signs that it was going to happen to her. The British humor in this book really appealed to me as did the redemptive aspects  of the story as well.I'm taking off one star as I would have enjoyed more of a focus on Imogen's present day life and the steps she took to carry on as a newly divorced woman and not so many stories about past jobs, experiences...I found the present day passages much funnier and kept me wanting to read more. The flashbacks definitely not as much.Overall though, I'm glad I whiled away a hot afternoon here in BC, reading this book.Geraldine Helen Hartman author of :Third Chapter, Second Chance

Although I'm a huge fan of both Edward G. and Bogie's work, I don't think this is one of their better onscreen roles together. Yes, it has it's moments, but for me the chemistry just wasn't as strong this time as it was in films like Key Largo. In that film, both of these stars were in top form.OK but not one of my 40s fav films. And those, I have a LOT of! ;-)

I've only used Veggie Dude a couple of times but so far, so good. Cleaned a bunch of carrots and a large turnip today, very well. Much more thorough than the previous veg brush I had. Nice firm bristles, easy to clean, soooo cute and reasonably priced too. I also like "the Dude" standing ready on the counter. He makes me smile while I cook. I'll update my review if I have any breakage issues later on, as some other reviewers have mentioned. But so far, I love my Veggie Dude!! I hope he's cleaning my veggies for a long time to come.Geraldine Helen Hartman, award-winning cookbook author

In spite of not being a big fan of Cary Grant, I loved this movie! In other films from the 40s and 50s that I've seen him in, he often appears rather blase and one dimensional, more there for "eye candy" than playing a role authentically. Not the case in Notorious, he was wonderful and perfect for the role of Devlin. And as usual, Ingrid Bergman was perfection and oh so beautiful too. The chemistry between them was tangible. I also loved Claude Rains, again perfect for the role he played.This movie has it all, suspense, intrigue, romance, great settings, beautiful costumes...I was sorry to see it end but I DID like the ending. It kept the viewer guessing almost right to the end, what would eventually happen.This is a golden age film classic you won't want to miss! They don't make them like that anymore, what a shame!!!

This story sounded so intriguing and I thought it would be a book that I would enjoy from start to finish. Unfortunately, it fell well short of my expectations, especially considering all the good reviews I had read about it previously.I thought the time frame of going back and forth between past and present, with so many characters, and how quickly these transitions were made, took away from what could have been a better book overall. It seemed choppy and disjointed. The idea for the story was great, but the way it was presented did not hold my interest past the first few chapters. I had had enough by that point, couldn't bother reading any further.

Richard Burton (as usual) is great in this film. Joan Collins is a surprise, in a good way. She really was believable as a nun and that's the kind of part I couldn't previously have imagined her playing. A long way from her usual sexy, sultry roles.This is a sad story and at times far-fetched. Some parts re: race are offensive too. But given the time it is set in, that probably was the norm. Still worthwhile and rather a unique story too, if you usually enjoy movies made in the 50s. I'm also wondering if it might have been loosely based on a real story.If you are a fan of Richard Burton and/or Joan Collins, you'll want to give this one a look.

Wow, a lot of great reviews for this book but unfortunately, it wasn't for me.I found the main character kind of silly and childish right off the bat. The story seemed too predictable right from the start as well.Still looking for a few great beach reads for this summer with a little more "meat" to them and not so quirky or ultra-light. Someone over 40 as the main character would be nice too. Any suggestions???

I've read and utilized a lot of books about creating kindle books over the past few years. Some were good, some OK and some just plain bad.I'd say this one was OK but nothing really new for me, personally.The title definitely is catchy and I'm sure the concept of completing a kindle book in 4 hours would appeal to many readers.If you are just starting out with your own kindle writing journey, this might be an OK book to consider. For me, it was just a re-hash of things I already know.

I liked the main character in this story initially and the setting was intriguing. The story seemed to be one I'd enjoy to the end, Unfortunately, I got bored quite quickly and gave up after the first couple of chapters.The dialogue seemed contrived and there was too much emphasis on small details, at times.I just didn't care enough to continue to read, to see what would happen next. Great cover though, loved that and the title.

I love reading cozy mysteries that revolve around any kind of food theme. Although this book fits that criteria and the writing is good, it wasn't my "cup of tea" overall.I couldn't relate to the main character. Definitely for the 20-30 something crowd. I'm older than that but thought I'd give it a try anyways. ;-)Loved the cover, that captured my attention initially.

I love reading stories based in Vegas but this one just wasn't for me.As another reviewer put it so well here, this is kind of like reading a stand-up comedy routine, as a novel.On the plus side, the writing is good but it's a quirky kind of humor that either you'd really enjoy or find kind of boring after the first few pages. For me, it got boring.OK but not what I was expecting.

I am really impressed by this soap! Excellent ingredient list (almost all organic), generous sized bar and triple milled so it doesn't melt down too quickly in the soap dish like so many natural soaps. Leaves skin clean but it's not drying. A good price too, considering the quality of ingredients and the size of the bar.Will definitely be buying this product again.

I was blown away by the quality of this tote bag! It is just beautiful.So well made, nice sturdy fabric, GENEROUS size, lots of pockets and zippers. The zipper pulls etc...are also top notch.This is exactly as pictured. (I got the pink butterfly one). For the price, this would be very hard to top.I had been looking for a nice year round tote for a LONG time and I'm so glad I found this one. I plan to buy at least one more, in a different print.If this was in a boutique, I'm sure it would be selling for at least $60 or more.Buy it, you won't be sorry. :-)Geraldine Helen Hartman, author and avid product reviewer

REVIEW OF PRODUCT: I eyed this shirt for a while before buying it. I took in other reviews, followed the vendor's measurement guidelines and ordered according to their recommendation. I like the style, but in holding it up, it was clear that top was way too large. I did not try it on so I cannot comment on the cut or feel of the top (see explanation below). The black color appears somewhat faded and slightly brown in places, may be a flaw in the dye, but might indicate the product was pre-owned. Pre-ownership may also explain discrepancy in sizing as other reviews cite the product stretches significantly with wear.EXPLANATION AS TO WHY I DID NOT TRY ON THIS PRODUCT: To be clear, I had every intention of trying the top on and in other circumstances I'd have done so, but I was too grossed out to attempt it. Fresh out of the packaging the top was streaked with either dust or deodorant and the back sported what appeared to be human hair and dandruff. This was not a factor in my review as it doesn't describe the product itself, but I feel my review would be suspect and dishonest if I implied I tried on the shirt and/or didn't offer plausible explanation on my admission of not trying it out. The color and size of the product left me suspicious that the item I received was pre-owned/worn and the state of the product I received appears to support that impression.

*** I received this product free of charge in exchange for an honest and unbiased review. ***Pros: Generally speaking I like the design of this product. The grip opened easily, held my phone securely, and the swivel head made it easy to align the phone to my line of vision.Cons: That said, the base is a little bulky and that made it difficult to position the mount in the 5-inch square of the lower corner of the windshield as required by law. I was also frustrated that the suction didnt hold in the heat of my afternoon commute, causing me to reinstall the mount at each of my three stops between work and home.

I've a problem with Elizabeth Chadwick. Well, not personally, I've a problem reading her work. I pick it up intending to read one chapter, but somewhere between points a and b, I fall through the damned pages and lose all sense of time and responsibility. I should have started the laundry two hours ago, but what was I doing instead? Tramping around the Welsh Marches.Am I sorry? Not in the least. Okay, maybe a little. I'll be scrambling to find clean clothes come morning, but I'm quite pleased with the time I spent on this book. Chadwick's ability to blend fact and fiction is brilliant and while I don't feel The Leopard Unleashed is her strongest effort, I admire much of the content and greatly enjoyed the narrative's direction and tone.Guyon trumps both, but I admit I like Renard more than Adam. I had difficulty warming to the latter when reading The Running Vixen, but Renard's easy-going manner, modest tastes, and perceptive nature intrigued me almost instantly. I wish Chadwick had written more from his perspective, I think there was a lot of untapped potential in his character, but I liked what she offered and thought his personality and disposition engaging just the same.That said, I think Elene the strongest of the three heroines. She's a contented homemaker, but shrewd, intelligent, and capable. She's insecure, but I think her struggles intensely realistic and I liked how Chadwick was able to showcase her emotions without sacrificing Elene's integrity. Her gentle inexperience makes an interesting contrast to Olwen's bold proclivities, but she's intensely empathetic and I found much to appreciate in her quiet strength and intense loyalties.I wasn't particularly fond of Olwen, but that has more to do with the structure and development of her character than her personality. She's shamelessly bold and conniving, but I think she'd have read better if the reader had been privy to more of her scheming. She disappears for several chapters of the narrative and is reintroduced in an entirely new situation and I would have liked to see her rationalizing that transition. The incident with Ranulf's would have been equally interesting, as would her seduction of Owain. All this happens 'off screen' and while I recognize the intent, I felt the approach left her somewhat fractured and arbitrary. Like Renard, I liked what was offered, but I think more could have been done with her character and role.The supporting cast didn't interest me as much as they did in earlier novels. Ranulf of Chester was more a more convincing antagonist that Walter de Lacey, but I struggled to understand the origin of the animosity he harbored against Renard. Judith and Guyon make brief appearances, but their roles aren't as significant as Miles' in The Running Vixen. Henry felt underdeveloped in my eyes which made his emotional trials difficult to fathom. Hamo was superfluous in my opinion and while Stephen made an impression, he paled next to predecessors William II and Henry I. I truly enjoyed Chadwick's interpretation of Antioch and the Battle of Lincoln, but I felt the absence of Raymond of Poitiers and Empress Matilda. Both are mentioned, but neither enjoys face time with the reader. Owain Gwynedd interacts with Ranulf toward the end of the novel, but it is a cameo appearance, one that left several unanswered questions in its wake.There is a lot going on towards the end of the novel and while I appreciated the action, I felt the final chapters rushed and slightly awkward. It isn't like Chadwick to leave loose ends, but I felt there was a lot of unresolved drama in this particular volume and that put a slight damper on my appreciation of the novel's strengths. I loved the book and would definitely recommend it, but I wish there'd been more to it as it doesn't offer the closure one expects at the end of a series.

I got excited about Marci Jefferson's Enchantress of Paris the moment I learned its release date. I'd fallen in love with Girl on the Golden Coin: A Novel of Frances Stuart in 2013 and had high hopes for the author's sophomore release. I knew nothing about Marie Mancini or Cardinal Mazarin, but I was excited at the prospect and eagerly anticipated watching the unfamiliar story unfold under Jefferson's pen.Did the book live up to my expectations? Yes and no. There were a lot of things I loved about the story, but I'd be lying if I didn't admit the time I spent with this particular narrative left mixed impressions in its wake.Like many of my fellow reviewers, I fell for Jefferson's heroine. Marie is intelligent, passionate, romantic, and tenacious, but my favorite aspect of her being is that she is vulnerable. This is a seventeenth century woman, but the flaws Jefferson incorporated in her characterization make Louis' mistress empathetic, engaging and relatable.I've not spent much time on fictional accounts of the Sun King, but I thought Jefferson's interpretation of Louis XIV equally noteworthy. Young and idealistic, he is portrayed as a monarch still growing into the duties and responsibilities of his position. He is unsure of himself and easily manipulated, but his growing confidence endears him to the reader and gives them reason to overlook, or at least accept, his personal shortcomings.I enjoyed the politics Jefferson folded into the narrative as well as the social drama experienced by her cast. I felt the multiple allegiances, rivalries and ambitions depicted within these pages authentically convoluted and appreciated the effort that went into crafting such a tangled web of pretension and purpose. I also thought the novel convincingly atmospheric and savored the descriptive details scattered throughout Marie's story.That said, there were several elements I thought might have been stronger if they'd been more fully developed. I liked the ambiguity of the magic depicted within these pages, but I was disappointed at how thoroughly the theme faded as the story progressed. Marie's maid Morena fascinated me, but her character arc ultimately felt incomplete, unfinished and fragmentary in my eyes.Olympia, Hortense and Marianne boasted similar potential, but despite their fascinating and controversial legacies, the trials of Marie's sisters go virtually unacknowledged. Don't misunderstand, I truly adore the story as written, but I couldn't help wishing she'd spotlighted the girls as Perinot did Marguerite and Eleanor in Sister Queens or Quinn did Cornelia, Lollia, Diana, and Marcella in Daughters of Rome.Do I regret the time I spent on Enchantress of Paris? Hardly. Jefferson is a gifted storyteller and I adore the fiction she crafted. I believe more could have been done with the material, but I've no complaints of what appears within these pages and look forward to her next release.

The Kindle Unlimited catalog is chock full of titles. I've browsed it a couple of times and bookmarked more than a few promising pieces, among them, Clare Flynn's Kurinji Flowers. None of my friends had read it, but the premise sounded different and I loved the idea of a WWII story set in a nontraditional locale so I threw caution to the wind and checked it out.Fortune, it's said, favors the bold and my daring was justly rewarded. I felt certain aspects of the novel could have been stronger, but I genuinely appreciated a lot of Flynn's ideas and admired much of the material she incorporated into Ginny's story. The social structure of the British, its contrast to that of the natives, and the inevitable struggle between the two was particularly noteworthy. I felt the relationship between Ginny and her mother struck a very intriguing note and I liked the subtle way that politics influenced events as the story progressed.Not to downplay Ginny, but I was fascinated by three of Flynn's male characters. Hector is a flat out brilliant addition to the piece. His character arc really appealed to me and I felt Flynn's treatment of his trials both appropriate to the period and sensitive to the subject matter. Rupert is a disgusting example of humanity, but such individuals do exist and despite my distaste, I admit a certain appreciation for Flynn's depiction of his depraved personality. I genuinely disliked him and right or wrong, my lack indifference speaks to a penetrating characterization and that is something I feel all authors should strive for. Tony rounds out the trio and though I felt his dialogue annoyingly reminiscent of Phil in Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day, I felt his emotional journey the most engaging of the narrative. He is arrogant, but weak, sheltered and naive. He strives to fulfill society's expectations, but he is woefully ill-prepared to do so. I might be alone here, but I liked seeing so much emotional conflict and individual struggle in a male character. I personally thought it a refreshing change of pace and lent a certain authenticity to him and his role.Thematically, I liked what Flynn presented, but I'm not ashamed to say I felt there was too much going on. There is a lot of great concept material within these pages, but the various concepts compete for the reader's attention and I don't think any is explored as thoroughly as it could have been. Looking back, I certainly appreciate where the story went, but I can't help wishing Flynn hadn't tried to fit many underlying motifs into a single piece. Not to sound picky, but I honing in and really developing one or two of these ideas would have been more satisfying on the reader's end.That said, I've no regrets over the time I spent with Kurinji Flowers. I found the novel original and thought-provoking and look forward to reading more of Flynn's work.

I've read Elizabeth Chadwick's The Wild Hunt three times now and I love it as much today as I did when I first discovered it. As a teen, I was seduced by the romance between Guyon and Judith, but as an adult I find myself draw to the characters, atmosphere, politics, history and emotional conflict. Romance aside, there is a certain timelessness to the narrative that appeals on a variety of levels.Guyon's relationship with Judith might sound odd to some, but the pairing of a twenty-eight year old to a maid of sixteen was quite acceptable in the twelfth century and I like that Chadwick didn't shy from exploring the intricacies of that age gap. The novel spans four years and the emotions she illustrates in both hero and heroine are intensely authentic. The relationship ebbs and flows, it changes as the characters grow together and that really worked for me.Guyon's relationship Rhosyn is equally intriguing. Chadwick's treatment of the Welshwoman in downright captivating. On the surface, she is Judith's rival, a pebble in the boot of the Lady's marriage, but as a reader I couldn't help respecting Rhosyn's position and spirit. She is honest to herself, kind, generous, gentle, sensitive, accepting, practical and realistic. I liked that. Too often, authors paint the other woman in extreme shades, but I felt Chadwick's approach thought-provoking and appreciate how she handled Guyon's conflicting emotional allegiances without physical infidelity or blatant stereotyping.Several members of the supporting cast also caught my eye. The author had no cause to develop them as she did, but conflicts each faced over the course of the story added much to the fabric of the narrative. Eluned's childish infatuation and jealousy, Rhys' sense of possession and developing understanding of the world and Alicia's struggle for happiness both during and after her marriage pulled me further into the story. Each has an individual journey and I liked how their struggles played into the main story line.Chadwick's book marked my first introduction to the Welsh March Wars, but I've learned a lot about them over the years and revisiting the novel only heightens my admiration for her handling of the material. Most who read the book will remember the character drama, but the power struggle between Guyon and the other marcher lords is rather interesting if you've an interest in period politics. The novel touches on the death of William II and ascension of Henry I, but Chadwick's focus is definitely on the border violence that characterized the age.Atmospherically, I love this piece. There are a couple of words, treadmill for example, that stand out like sore thumbs, but for the most part the language and descriptions feel genuine to the era. Chadwick obviously understands the period and the lifestyles of those who lived in it. Folk remedies such as moldy bread are prominently depicted, but no one feigns to know why the treatment is effective and there are no undue hints that the concoction of bacteria on the aging crusts is in fact penicillin.Bottom line, The Wild Hunt is a wonderful book. Brilliant in both historic detail and fictional drama. Highly recommended.

I've no nostalgic memories of Elizabeth Chadwick's The Running Vixen. I've read The Wild Hunt three times, but the second installment of 'The Ravenstow Trilogy' enjoyed limited international release and was next to impossible to find when I first discovered the series in the late nineties. Fortunately for me, the book was reprinted in 2009 and I was afforded a cost-effective means of indulging my interest.Though not specifically illustrated, I love Chadwick's mention of The White Ship and the crisis it created for Henry I. The book itself documents events between 1026 and 1028, but it is chock full of references to The Anarchy and the events that led to it. William le Clito, Geoffrey of Anjou and Hugh de Mortimer enjoy small, but noteworthy roles and I liked how their inclusion added to the political drama that played out in the background of the novel. I was further impressed with how Chadwick made the bureaucratic unrest relevant in the eyes of her fictional cast. Miles' grandson and namesake drowning alongside William Adelin, Adam serving as royal escort for Empress Matilda, and Guyon's personal support of Stephen of Blois weren't exactly pertinent to Adam and Heulwen's story, but such details spoke to the author's deep appreciation for the facts on which her story is based and her dedication in recreating this time and place for her audience.As far as the narrative is concerned, I wont deny feeling The Running Vixen took a long time to find its feet. Chadwick's books usually draw me in immediately, but I was a good seventy pages into this installment before I fell into the story and I think that had a lot to do with the relationship between Heulwen and Adam. Unlike their predecessors, Adam and Heulwen have history. They are at a turning point in their association while the reader is playing catch-up. Chadwick handled the situation well, but as stated, development took a little longer than I'd anticipated. In comparing the book to its predecessor, there is also a notable shift in both style and tone. It's not bad by any mean, but it is very different.I found Heulwen fascinating, especially as the story progressed. She has many original attributes, but I noted traits reminiscent of both mother and stepmother in her demeanor. I made no secret of my appreciation for Rhosyn in my review of The Wild Hunt and maybe I'm alone in this, but I thought Heulwen's tendency to seek solace away from the confines of the keep a nice nod to her mother's aversion to stone walls. Her married life is challenging, but Chadwick managed to make her demons very different from Judith's which is why I feel the story works. The author picked up where she left off, but took things a completely new direction to explore entirely new subject matter.Guyon is a tough act to follow, but I think despite the odds, Chadwick managed to do a lot of interesting things with Adam. I thought his struggle to balance his own merit against his father's legacy inspired and feel it brought an interesting dynamic to his role, especially toward the end of the novel when his insight serves a poignant and tender purpose. I also liked that for all the skill in his sword arm, he finds himself at something of a disadvantage with Heulwen. It's not something I've noted often in medieval fiction, but I found the intimate role reversal both striking and original.Miles caught my eye in book one of the series, but he shines in book two. Despite his pride, the aging patriarch is openly devoted to his family and I liked how Chadwick utilized him to further his granddaughter's story. Rhodri has a lot going on under the surface and while I wasn't particularly fond of him, I wont deny appreciating how the author's presentation challenged me to think about him from different angles. As far as antagonists go, I felt Warrin de Mortimer stronger than Walter de Lacey. He's isn't likable or sympathetic, but he isn't one dimensional either and I liked the idea of villain with layers.The Running Vixen is heavily romantic, but it is also clever and engaging. It's a little slow in places, but it is a solid sequel to The Wild Hunt and something I'd definitely recommend to fans of medieval fiction.

I owe my discovery of Richard Rashke's Escape from Sobibor to my father. He introduced me to the death camp in one of our notorious late night discussions and his account of operations within the compound and the subsequent uprising that took place there were so captivating that I took it upon myself to learn more about the remarkably obscure chapter of Operation Reinhard.Rashke's was the first title Google turned up and thanks to Open Library, it was also freely available for download. I felt providence was on my side and I checked it out thinking myself well-prepared for the material it promised to address. A WWII junkie, I'd studied AuschwitzBirkenau, Treblinka, Theresienstadt and Ravensbrck in some detail and couldn't imagine the accounts of this camp being much different. It took only a few pages for me to realize how wrong that assumption had been.Broken into three sections, the book is extraordinarily comprehensive. It covers the prisoners, their lives before transportation, life and death behind Sobibor's barbed wire, the soldiers, their duties, the planning phase of the uprising, the execution of the mass escape and the events that followed in the surrounding forests.I spent almost a month wading through the accounts Rashke painstaking recorded within these pages, but I don't regret a minute of it. I put the book aside several times to process and consider events as I discovered them, but the publication was never far from my mind. Fact is it dominated my imagination and challenged my perception in ways I hadn't expected when I first cracked it open. It put my brain into overdrive and I liked the depth and dimension it brought to the subject matter.Exceedingly intense, the book itself is a brilliant blend of historic detail and raw human emotion. Poignant, powerful, unapologetic and ofttimes overwhelming, Escape From Sobibor is easily the best Holocaust book I've had fortune to pick up. A highly recommended and unique volume that deserves a place in every WWII library collection.

I discovered Nathan Dylan Goodwin's The Orange Lilies while browsing the Kindle Unlimited catalog. None of my Goodreads contacts had read the novella and the Amazon reviews weren't particularly detailed, but the premise held promise and I decided to give it shot.Before I get too far ahead of myself, I want to make a couple of things perfectly clear. The Orange Lilies is book 2.5 of Goodwin's Forensic Genealogist series, but it can be read as a standalone. I know because it's the first I picked up. It's also a bit of a slow starter so don't toss it aside if you aren't captivated by the end of chapter one. Here again folks, I'm speaking from experience.Despite being a mere one hundred pages in length, the book is filled with several wonderful characters. Charlie, Nellie, Margaret and Morton in particular struck a chord with me. They each enjoy relatively modest face time with the reader, but they feel fresh and original nonetheless.Goodwin's descriptions of the Western front are brilliant. The author worked far more detail into the piece than I'd expected and I was quite impressed with his realistic portrayal life at the front. From the mud and blood to the mental fatigue and gallows humor of those struggling to survive the trenches, these scenes demonstrated both Goodwin's skill and dedication to authenticity.The modern day story line is equally captivating. The multi-generational mystery of family secrets took longer for me to appreciate, but as the pieces fell into place, I recognized a growing fascination with the puzzle that represents Morton's personal history.Highly recommended to fans of both historic and contemporary fiction.

Ellen Feldman's Next to Love was a recommended read. Heather, the voice behind The Maiden's Court, suggested it at the Historical Novel Society Conference in Denver and I tracked down a copy soon after returning home. I wasn't at all familiar with it, but her rending of the plot had me sold sight unseen.She mentioned the trials of life on the home front, but was very clear that the story focused on post-war America as well. She mentioned that one of the heroines struggled to understand her husbands PTSD and that another was defined by her husbands death. She went on, but my mind was already racing. I flashed on that scene in A League of Their Own, the one in the locker room where the Peaches apprehensively watch Jimmy Dugan walk the telegram down the line. The audience breathes a sigh of relief for Dottie Hinson, but what happened to Betty Horn? How did she weather the years without George? It wasnt something Id ever considered, but I couldn't argue the potential in the story of a war widow.At this point youre probably wondering if the book lived up to Heathers praise and/or my imaginings and Im happy to report, it did. I think Babe, Millie and Grace make very interesting protagonists and I liked watching their lives and personalities change with each passing year. I also liked style and tone of Feldmans writing and found it very easy to slip into the world she created within these pages.My only complaint is the structure of post-war chapters. I didnt like the sudden shifts to narrators in the supporting cast. Sporadic intervals with Naomi, Claude, King, Jack, Al, Mac and Amy felt awkward in the context of the story and made it difficult to remain focused on the central trio. The erratic timeline caused further confusion and often forced me to stop and rearrange events in my head to make sense of the order in which they took place. I liked how Feldman used multiple perspectives to explore various themes, but I can'd help feeling her execution imprudent and that the latter chapters of the novel suffered as a result.Obviously I'd have liked a stronger ending, but I cant say I felt the time I spent with Next to Love wasted. The presentation was disappointing, but I greatly enjoyed the plot and look forward to reading Feldman again somewhere down the road.

The premise of Praveen Asthanas The Woman in the Movie Star Dress looked vaguely interesting when I skimmed the description, but my main interest in the book was that it wasnt historic fiction. Id just come off a heavy hitting period piece and I was looking for a break. I mean no offense, but I didnt expect much of this piece and was entirely unprepared when it captured my imagination hook, line, and sinker.Im a voracious reader, but when I dont have my nose in a book, I greatly enjoy movies which probably explains my enthusiasm for the myriad of motion picture references in The Woman in the Movie Star Dress. The title garment is the striking red number worn by Marilyn Monroe in Niagara, but the story also refers films such as When Harry Met Sally, Roman Holiday, Before Sunset, Witness for the Prosecution, Alien, Silence of the Lambs, Double Indemnity, To Kill a Mockingbird, and Casablanca. There are others, but what Im getting at is how Asthanas allusions draw readers into the narrative by playing on the emotional connections we make to films and those who star in them. Its an interesting tactic, but it works beautifully beginning to end.Another thing I loved about this book is how deliciously atmospheric it felt. I reveled in the authenticity of scenes at Griffith Park, onboard the Queen Mary and inside the chapel at Mission San Juan Capistrano. I grinned over the authors illustration of the street performers that occupy the cement outside Grauman's Chinese Theatre and sympathized with Genevieves frustration with traffic on the five. It isnt often that one sees their corner of the world through the eyes of a storyteller, but I cant help feeling Asthana interpretation genuine.As to Genevieve, well, Asthanas leading lady took some getting used to, but she grew on me as the story progressed and I felt quite connected to her when all was said and done. Shes an emotionally complex character and I liked that a lot. The same can be said of much of the cast now that I stop and think about it. Renzo and Todd are just as distinct and not just from one another. Theyve a unique quality about them, something real and relatable.Conceptually intriguing and dramatically dark, The Woman in the Movie Star Dressed proved an absolute pleasure. Brilliantly imaged and thoroughly addicting.

I owe my introduction to The Graham Saga to Amy Bruno at Historical Fiction Virtual Book Tours. Anna Belfrage was not a name Id known before receiving an invitation to review the authors sophomore release and while I remember thinking Like Chaff in the Wind looked vaguely interesting, I also remember wrestling down a significant amount of skepticism. I never expected to fall in love with the world Belfrage created, to connect with her characters or become thoroughly captivated by their experiences, but that is exactly what happened.To make a long story short, I loved the book and inhaled installments three through seven as soon as they were published. That said, it wasnt until early 2015 that I decided to backtrack. Book one had taunted me for two years and I didnt feel right tackling the series finale without knowing where Alex and Matthews journey began. My timing couldnt have been better as the action in To Catch a Falling Star is closely related to plot points introduced in A Rip in the Veil. Linked as they are, I couldnt help feeling the two served as beautiful bookends to the series and while I feel book one the most challenging in terms of content, my understanding of the how the novels progress allowed me to appreciate the intent and purpose of the novel in a way that is probably much different from those who approached the books chronologically.First and foremost, I want to note A Rip in the Veil is historically lighter than the rest of the series. Dont misunderstand, there is plenty of period detail in these thirty-seven chapters, but Belfrages focus is in developing the relationship between hero and heroine. On a macro level this makes perfect sense as their partnership is the cornerstone of the series and requires solid development. The same can be said of the attention Belfrage pays time nodes, their nature and function, but I can see where fans of historic fiction may feel those elements received too much emphasis when considering the novel as a standalone. To this, all I can say is push forward before passing judgement. Trust me on this, it makes a lot of sense of the stories progress.The book is character heavy and frequently shifts between a number of narrators. Some may find this a little overwhelming, but I personally loved the movement and perspective Belfrages alternating POV afforded. I appreciated the insecurities the author established in both Alex and Matthew and how she wasnt afraid to showcase lovers with flaws, quirks and personal demons. I also appreciated the care Belfrage took in crafting her antagonist and while I cant say Ive much affection for Hector Olivares, I can admit him exceedingly well-developed, he is an adversary with layers of rage and a personal vendetta as deep and complex as the centuries it spans.In sum, I loved the book as much as I did its successors. I could kick myself for waiting so long to read it, but thats neither here nor there. A permanent part of my library, I cant recommend the book or series highly enough. Thoroughly enjoyable, fun and imaginative.

My purchase of Gwendolyn Womacks The Memory Painter was something of a surprise. I mean no offense, but when push comes to shove Im a bit of a penny pincher and rarely buy books blindly. Truth is, Id not heard of this piece before spotting the striking yellow cover at the Historical Novel Society Conference bookstore and was entirely unfamiliar with the author. I queried a handful of my peers and while they agreed the book looked promising, no one had read it and I wasnt entirely convinced I wanted to be the first to plunge into a debut. Historically speaking, such ventures seldom ended in my favor, but something about the description sparked my curiosity and refused to let go. I debated a while, but ultimately caved to indecision and acquired the title.Ill be honest, things did not start well. I spent the first three chapters wondering what Id gotten myself into, but all that changed in chapter four. The plot started coming together and the story began to find its feet. The rush, however, was short-lived and by the end of chapter eleven, I felt I could confidently predict how things would turn out. Chapters twelve through thirty-nine didnt leave much of an impression, the drama was diverting enough, but predictable in my eyes. The pacing intensified in chapter forty and the curve-ball in chapter forty-five found me cheering Womacks creativity, but the moment was all too brief as the novel concluded only three chapters later.Did I like the story? Yes, looking back at the plot, I think The Memory Painter a fun crossover piece. There isnt as much history as Id hoped, but I enjoyed the elements Womack wove into the narrative. I think the author could have done more with the emotional relationship between Bryan and Linz, but the pair proved enjoyable protagonists nonetheless. I found Finn and Conrad incredibly interesting, but youll have to read the book to understand why. As far as supporting characters are concerned, I liked Barbara, but felt Claudette, Martin and Layla underdeveloped in comparison which bothered me as I felt their roles should have placed them on more equal footing.Ideally, Id have loved a historical note. Something that explained how and why the author chose the historic figures that appear throughout the piece. Personally, Id have loved to know why certain figures, Louis Le Vau and Pedro Damiano for example, were less prominent than Origenes Adamantius and Alexander Pushkin. Id also have liked a slightly stronger finish. I appreciate that Womacks conclusion is meant to lead into a follow-up, but the final notes of the narrative felt rushed and awkward just the same.Would I recommend The Memory Painter? As usual, that would depend on the reader. Diehard historic fiction fans might find the book a difficult sell, but the book incorporates exciting elements of both thrillers and science fiction and should prove quite entertaining to those with varied tastes and open minds.

Ive a confession folks, so I hope you dont mind if start there and get it off my chest. I was over the moon when I received my copy of Anna Belfrages To Catch a Falling Star, but a part of my didnt want to read it. Ive loved each and every installment of the Graham Saga, but I wasnt ready to say goodbye. Truth be told, Im still not.That said I think this installment of the series is my favorite.
