Patricia Bracewell's Shadow on the Crown marked my first encounter with Emma of Normandy. The historic record is sketchy at best, so it isn't as if there's a lot of information for those looking to learn more about her, but even the basics were new to me. Naturally this blank slate mentality made it difficult to discern where fact met fiction, but it also made reading the book a unique experience as I was able to really lose myself in the narrative.Bracewell's interpretation of Emma is wonderfully dynamic. She is passionate, resilient and astute, but there is a vulnerability in her make-up that rounds out her character and draws on the reader's sympathies. I found the fire and spirit Bracewell folded into Elgiva of Northampton equally fascinating and enjoyed watching the two vie for power in thelred's court.I admit Bracewell's depiction of the Anglo-Saxon king didn't make much of an impression on me, but his eldest son is another story entirely. Little is known about Athelstan and his siblings, but the romantic arc she constructed for thelred's sixteen year old heir was highly satisfying and speaks volumes about the author who imagined it.Finally, I thought the world these individuals inhabited beautifully developed. Though the novel is character driven, the reader is afforded a thorough understanding of the period, the lifestyle of the court, and the political stage on which Emma's story takes place. I personally believe atmosphere an essential factor in any fiction and can't help but appreciate the effort and research Bracewell put into crafting such an authentic setting.Impossible to put down, Shadow on the Crown captivated my imagination from the start and left me itching to see how things will unfold in future installments of the trilogy.

My nose for World War II lit led me to Lan Fang's Potions and Paper Cranes, but my appreciation for the novel has nothing to with global events of the period. Shocking as it sounds, it was Fang's depiction of individual experiences that captured my imagination.The main story shifts points of view between Sulis, Sujono and Matsumi, something I liked as the role of each character alters with each narrative voice. It is an approach few could manage, but I felt Fang handled it beautifully. Another thing I liked was contrast in Fang's approach to Chinese, Indonesian and Japanese culture and how those influences might have interacted during the uncertainty brought on by the larger conflict.A deeply intuitive tale, Potions and Paper Cranes is a naked assessment of human nature, a haunting narrative that touches something in the reader's soul and shakes them to the core.

I stumbled over Eugen Ketterl's The Emperor Francis Joseph I: An Intimate Study by his Valet in the bibliography of another resource. I believe it was The Emperor & the Actress: The Love Story of Emperor Franz Josef & Katharina Schratt by Joan Haslip, but don't quote me on that. It took me months to track down a copy. There are few available in the United States and most belong to University collections, but thanks to the efforts of my local librarian I was able to get my hands on the rare volume.I personally found the biography interesting for a couple of reasons, but the one that stands out in my mind is Ketterl's tone and command of prose. The text is clear, straightforward and unpretentious. He talks about his insecurities and fears as he does his strengths and personal triumphs. He has nothing to prove and isn't nearly as self-righteous as Marie Larisch or H.R.H. Princess Stephanie of Belgium, Frstin of Lonyay & Ex-Crown Princess of Austria-Hungary.Ketterl's position gave him a unique perspective on the Emperor and those he associated with. The pages dedicated to Emperor Franz Josef's meeting with President Roosevelt was particularly interesting to me, as were his description of the valet's duties and muted critique of the Emperor's love life. The picture he paints is that of a simple man with modest needs, a flawed and compassionate individual who struggled to balance his nature against the duties and responsibilities of his station. It is a sympathetic view that lacks the pomp of most biographies and while I certainly think it bias, I can't help but admire Ketterl's attempt to characterize the Franz Josef he knew and so obviously respected.A rare firsthand account of the Emperor by someone who followed his daily movements, I feel Ketterl's work essential to anyone looking to understand the man who ruled Austria for nearly sixty-eight years. I caution, however, that it be taken with a grain of salt in acknowledgment of Ketterl's relationship with the Emperor and his tenancy to trade in gossip when discussing events and affiliations to which he did not bear witness.

Fiona Carnarvon's Lady Catherine, the Earl, and the Real Downton Abbey fell into my lap. My mother had learned of and recommended the book's predecessor after I'd turned her onto the television series, but I hadn't found time to pick it up. That said, my curiosity had been sparked, so it wasn't all that surprising when I jumped at the opportunity to review book two. Unfortunately, my optimistic expectations crumbled when face to face with reality.To be clear, I don't think Lady Catherine, the Earl, and the Real Downton Abbey a bad book. There is a lot of great information for those whose knowledge of the period begins and ends with the British costume drama, but being slightly more acquainted with the details, I can't say I found the text particularly enlightening. I appreciate getting to know Catherine Wendell, Lord Porchester, and the events that marked their lives, but in looking at the bigger picture, I confess I found myself bored and disinterested.I found Carvarvon's prose dry and often felt the narration formulaic. As much as I hate admitting it, I had to fight my way through this one and on completion can't say I'm inclined to rush into Lady Almina and the Real Downton Abbey: The Lost Legacy of Highclere Castle.

I felt I'd come late to the party when I picked up Susan Spann's Blade of the Samurai. Every review said her sophomore release was better than her debut and there I was jumping into book two, one eyebrow raised, wondering what the hell everyone was going on about. I'd never heard of the author, wasn't familiar with the series, was slightly wary of all the praise, and wasn't feeling it as I moved through the first few chapters.I don't know if it's because I was unfamiliar with the cast, was still getting to know Spann's voice or that I'm just a stubborn skeptic, but I struggled to get into this book and was half-convinced I'd be penning a lukewarm commentary when Spann threw a curve ball I didn't see coming.Moving forward after that was an entirely different experience. Spann had caught me off guard and in so doing, engaged my interest. The general levity of the narrative was still difficult for me to digest, but the mystery at the heart of the novel more than made up for it. Shrewd, sophisticated and imaginative, Spann constructs a riddle that keeps her audience on their toes.From a historical perspective, there is a lot of interesting detail, particularly that pertaining to the samurai code and the Jesuit missionaries operating in Japan during the sixteenth century. There are also some rather lovely representations of Japanese architecture if ambiance is something you look for in literature.In hindsight I wish I'd read the books in order as there are several elements that seem to build on concepts from the previous installment, but I can't say I regret the time spent with Blade of the Samurai. I ultimately enjoyed the story a great deal and would definitely recommend to anyone with an interest in culture based fiction.

Unravelled, M.K. Tod's debut novel, made quite an impression when I read it last year. Moving and emotionally authentic it was unlike any wartime romance I'd yet encountered and if I'm honest, it set an expectation that was unusually high for an newly published author. Naturally, I was both excited and nervous about tackling the follow-up, but Lies Told in Silence proved just as eloquent and emotive as its predecessor.Written as a complimentary stand-alone, Lies Told is Silence incorporates faces and events familiar to those who've read Unravelled, but the story is in no way dependent on Tod's original publication so one needn't worry over reading the books in any particular order. That said, I personally enjoyed picking out those details that connect the two and appreciate the effort Tod put into crafting continuity despite the varied motifs and themes of each piece.A multi-generational story, Tod's chronicle of a French family during the chaos of WWI intrigued me for a number of reasons. First and foremost, I liked seeing the war from the perspective of those who bore witness to the destruction of their homeland rather than those who sought glory in its defense. I also enjoyed the contrast Tod created not only between the male and female characters, but among the different age groups represented within the narrative.Historically speaking, Tod offers a wonderfully detailed glimpse of the period, but as with Unravelled, I felt her understanding of what it means to be human amid the terror and torment of such hostilities outshone the fact-based elements of the book. Set against the backdrop of war, Tod writes of lives transformed by combat and the vitality of those left standing when the dust finally settles. Her books make wonderful war stories, but she is in her element writing of those caught on the tides of battle.

I have mixed feelings about Anna Castle's Murder by Misrule. On one hand I found it entertaining in an amusing sort of way, but on the other, I must admit the story didn't grab me the way I'd hoped it would.Castle's characters are a diverse collection of individuals. The socially awkward and disgraced Bacon, the rogue Tom Clarady, the pretentious Stephen Delabere, the stately Allen Trumpington and the earnest Benjamin Whitt make a well-rounded team and though somewhat predictable, I found I enjoyed following their exploits.There are several scenes that boast great tension and intrigue, but that sense of suspense often waned between key points in the narrative. It isn't a bad story, but I think I might had appreciated it more if the momentum established in the early chapters had been maintained through the final page.A humorous tale, Murder by Misrule is brimming with levity and mirth. A lighter historical the book is sure to enchant those looking for airy and upbeat fiction.

In terms of a wartime romance, Cara Langston's Battle Hymns is exactly what I expected. I'll be the first to admit there is a certain predictability to the plot, but I found Langston's treatment of the material and the themes she incorporates into the story balanced the more typical elements of the narrative, ultimately transforming it into something both memorable and moving.Charlotte in particular stands out to me. A volunteer nurse, she joins the war effort in order to keep busy, but discovers a tangible passion for the profession. This personal journey, her growing self-awareness, wasn't something I'd anticipated, but I really liked the contrast it brought to the larger story. Like a phoenix, Charlotte finds strength and rises from the ashes of the conflict in a beautiful display of fortitude and perseverance.Parallel to John and Will, Charlotte carries wounds that will never truly heal, but here again Langston managed to surprise me. Set in an age before PTSD was understood or really even acknowledged, the author took great pains to illustrate how varied the disorder can be. I've seen authors struggle with this, too often defining the condition by the extremes, which is why I sincerely appreciated Langston's more intuitive handling of the material.Peppered with authentic detail, Battle Hymns is an eloquent historical that offers rare insight to the intimacies of lives touched by conflict. A poignant debut that holds much promise for Langston's future efforts.

Victoria Dougherty's The Bone Church is not an easy read. It hits the ground running and never lets up. Paired with decidedly heavy material and themes, the narrative is more than a little challenging, but that said, it is easily one of the best historical thrillers I've had fortune to come across.Those who follow me know the WWII references in the description are what drew me to this piece, but it was Dougherty's application of history, how she utilized and built her fiction around it that captivated my attention. Both storylines are sculpted from verified truths making it difficult to determine where fact meets fiction. The resulting seamlessness enhances the tension within the narrative and generates such excitement that the novel is practically impossible to put down.Dougherty's treatment of Magdalena and Felix also stood out to me. It would have been easy to paint these characters in bleakly sympathetic tones, but Dougherty didn't go that route. There is an authenticity to this couple. They are trapped and hunted, but there is a tenacious intensity in their make-up that draws admiration rather than pity. An edginess in their story that plays on the reader's emotions in a way that is both inspired and unexpected.A deliciously dark and addicting foray into a world of mistrust, betrayal, paranoia and deceit, The Bone Church was a wholly unexpected pleasure. Yes, I had to work for it and familiarize myself with previously unknown chapters of historic detail, but when push comes to shove, I can't say I regret a moment spent with this piece.

No you aren't imagining it. That is a five star rating up there. I understand it's a bit of a shock, but books like The Devil in the Marshalsea don't come along every day and even I give credit where due.Hard as it might be to believe, this one sucked me from the start. Author Antonia Hodgson hits the ground running, setting a blistering pace that kept me engaged to the final page, but momentum was far from the deciding factor in my opinion of her work. She also took full advantage of London's disreputable history, creating a chilling and deliciously authentic picture of lower class life in eighteenth-century England.The story itself is part social commentary and part good old fashioned fiction, but the deft complexity of the novel's construction make it impossible to determine where one ends and the other begins. It's layered, but in such a way that one is hardly aware of its elaborate intricacies.The heavy themes and details were balanced by an array of well-defined and distinctly original characters. These individuals were both captivating and memorable despite their questionable virtues and served as a nice counterpoint to the grit of Tom's surroundings and the heightened tension of his situation.I could gush all day, but there's really no substitute for firsthand experience. A clever tale of debauchery, villainy and corruption, The Devil in the Marshalsea isn't to be missed.

It is a truth universally acknowledged that once one has fallen for Pride and Prejudice, one will be inexplicably drawn to spin-offs and re-tellings of Jane Austen's classic and I am no exception. Every so often I'll find a title with just enough promise to tempt my interest and away I'll go. Such was the case with Reina M. Williams' Most Truly.What I liked most about the piece is that Williams did not try emulate Austen too closely. Naturally there are similarities, but she didn't suppress her individual voice in an attempt to mimic her predecessor which is something I personally found very appealing. All too often I find authors of adaptations force a false note into their style, story or characters, but I liked that Williams wasn't afraid to highlight her own technique and spirit.Another thing that appealed to me was the shifting point of view. Rotating between James and Kitty allowed the reader to see both sides of the equation and though Most Truly is a short, I think Williams' approach exceedingly well-plotted and executed.A light romance, Most Truly sets the bar for the Love at Pemberley series. An enjoyable period piece for any fan of Austen based fiction.

I've a confession to make folks. As much as I hate to admit it, I had no idea who Sylvia Brooke was prior to picking up Philip Eade's biography and to be entirely honest, I couldn't've found Sarawak on a map if my life depended on it. I knew nothing about this volume except that it sounded interesting.Flying blind, I had no idea what to expect in terms of subject matter and was pleasantly surprised by the colorful eccentricities of Sylvia, her friends and relations. Eade's depiction of her dysfunctional home life, unconventional lifestyle and colorful personality illuminate much of her character and make a lasting impression on the reader.That said, I found Eade's writing difficult to appreciate. The material is entertaining, but his prose is both dry and plodding. The most engaging passages are quotes lifted directly from family journals and/or correspondence, a fact which made the book quite difficult to get lost in. I was also irritated by Eade's tendency to recap every detail of his extensive research as his inability to streamline his findings made navigating the text rather tedious.When all is said and done, Sylvia, Queen of the Headhunters proves an interesting biography, but the format and style fail to deliver the engaging and richly provocative story its cover suggests. Not a waste of time, but not any way essential.

I had a lot of fun reading Henri de Weindel's Behind the Scenes at the Court of Vienna. The book itself is not a particularly accurate volume, but it is amusing for its exploration of contemporary gossip.A French editorialist, the most important thing to remember in looking at this piece is that Weindel collaborated with an unnamed source some sixteen years after the death of Empress Elisabeth. Best taken with a healthy measure of salt, much of his work contradicts firsthand accounts of the royal court as well as the investigative records pertaining to Crown Prince Rudolf and the affair at Mayerling.Weindel paints a sympathetic portrait of both Empress Elisabeth and Crown Princess Stephanie which I found interesting as the two were so famously incompatible. The author is far less gracious toward Franz Josef, Crown Prince Rudolf and the Archduke Franz Ferdinand, but his conclusions are still fairly interesting when considered in context.Akin to a grocery store tabloid, Behind the Scenes at the Court of Vienna is not something I'd recommend to those unfamiliar with the Hapsburgs, but it is noteworthy for its depiction of popular opinion regarding the Imperial household immediately prior to the assassinations in Sarajevo.

Want to know something funny? I don't really want to write this review. I don't want to write it because once I put down my thoughts, I'll have to say goodbye and Melanie Dobson's Chateau of Secrets is the kind of story I hate to let go of.I suppose the most amazing thing about the novel is that both story lines - Chloe's in the present and Gisle's during WWII - are equally compelling. Maybe I've been unlucky, but this is practically unheard of in my experience. More often than not one period will read much stronger than the other and I end up skimming whole chapters to pick up the more interesting half of the narrative, but that didn't happen here. The stories complement one another, but are unique enough to be appreciated in their own right.Religion plays a noticeable role in the story, but it flows naturally and is applied to the characters in very realistic ways. I abhor preachy fiction with a passion and was stunned at how effectively Dobson was able to utilize faith as a primary theme without pontificating.Riley's story was a little much and I wasn't convinced Austin would have exited as quickly as he did, but these are minor quibbles at best. Thoroughly engaging and entirely unpredictable, Chateau of Secrets isn't to be missed.
This is a fine compilation of Michael Nesmith's solo material from 1970 to 1973.  If you're interested in hearing his post-Monkees work, this would be a good place to start.

Del Rey Books had the rights to adapt the Star Trek animated series into book form.  The earliest books in the series adapted three episodes per book.  After the sixth book, they realized that there were only four episodes left to adapt.  What could they do?  They could have switched to two episodes per book and gotten two more books out of the series.  But that's not what they did.  Instead, they chose to adapt ONE episode per book and get four more books out of the series.  So, how do turn a 30 minute TV episode into a 180 page novel.  Well, in the case of this particular book, you adapt the TV episode in the first third of the book and then tell a completely unrelated story in the last two-thirds of the book.  Or I should say that the new story seems unrelated to the TV story, but the author does manage to tie them together in the last chapter.  In the TV part of the story, the crew of the Enterprise ages backwards when the enter the anti-matter universe.  In the new material, the Enterprise and a Klingon warship come into conflict over a man who allegedly invented a doomsday weapon.  It's enjoyable enough if you're a Star Trek fan.
Another good album by Madonna.  Songs about relationships and sex,  Long live the Icon.

This is another fine album by Jerry Lee Lewis, the last surviving member of The Million Dollar Quartet.  It doesn't lean as heavily on musical "guests" as his previous album, although there are some here.  Keith Richards, Ronnie Wood, Neil Young, Robbie Robertson and Shelby Lynn lend a hand, but are not advertised on the album cover.  Rock, country, blues, The Killer can still take any song and make it a Jerry Lee Lewis song.

Another album by William Shatner?  Well, why not?  Unfortunately, this is probably the least enjoyable of his albums.  It's not funny (intentionally or otherwise) and it isn't completely successful as a serious album.  The fault probably lies with the production.  It's rather monotonous, despite having different guest musicians on every track.  Better luck next time, Bill.

Roky Erickson was the leader of The 13th Floor Elevators in the 1960's.  This was his first album after the group broke up.  He trades the psychedelic sounds of The 13th Floor Elevators for a hard rock sound here.  The album has a lot of songs inspired by monster movies.  Not all of the lyrics make sense to me, but I suppose they make sense to Roky.  It's actually a great, unique album with a lot of songs that would be cool to play at your Halloween party.

I had never heard of Antiseen, but I saw that this was "a collection of wrestling songs and, being an old time wrestling fan, I was intrigued.  It turns out that Antiseen is a punk band.  The wrestling songs here are compiled from previously released Antiseen recordings, with the exception of a newly recorded cover of The Freebirds theme song, "Badstreet USA".  It's a fun album if you like wrestling and punk rock.  It's only 24 minutes long, but that's about the right length for this sort of thing.

This autobiography of Roy Campanella was published in 1959.  It's quite good in covering Campy's boyhood, life in baseball and life in the year after he had the accident that left him a quadriplegic.  Roy comes across as a great guy and quite inspirational in dealing with his tragedy.  However, there is no mention of his feud with Jackie Robinson.  Also, Campy writes in glowing terms about his wife Ruthe, but she left him the year after the book was published, so she must not have dealt with his handicap as well as he portrays.  Campy writes about his adopted son David being arrested, but says that he learned his lesson and will stay out of trouble from now on.  Well, he was wrong about that, because David was arrested several more times and died of a drug overdose.  Good book, though.

This is a excellent compilation of Halloween themed rock and roll or novelty songs from the 1960's and a few from the late 1950's.  Most of these records are obscure, but some of them showed up on other Halloween compilations before this.  The sound quality is very good, considering that many of the songs are from tiny record labels where the master tapes couldn't possibly still exist.  Not all of the songs are good, of course, but it's still a lot of fun for fans of this type of material.  I wish that there were liner notes, but I suppose that in many cases very little is known about the performers anyway.

Al Schacht was the original "Clown Prince of Baseball", years before Max Patkin assumed that title.  Schacht started out as a pitcher, before transitioning to coach.  While working as a coach, he would entertain the crowd with comedic antics.  Eventually, he retired from coaching to become a full time baseball clown.  Most of the book is comedic stories about his antics is baseball.  That's fine, but it would be nice to read some serious comments about things like his feud with Nick Altrock.
Kim Fowley was Frankenstein and the All-Star Monster Band.  It's a Halloween themed novelty album.  The music is new wave.  I wanted to like this album, but it's not actually that good.

After Elvis got out of the army, their was an attempt to turn him into a "serious" actor.  Flaming Star was one of his serious films.  Unfortunately, his lightweight movies like Blue Hawaii did a lot better than his serious movies, so that pretty much killed off Elvis' ambitions to be taken seriously as an actor.  Since Flaming Star is NOT a musical, their were only four songs recorded for it (or five songs, if you consider "Flaming Star" and "Black Star" to be different songs, which they are not). "Flaming Star" and "Summer Kisses, Winter Tears" are very good songs and the other two songs are silly novelty songs.  This is a 75 minute CD, so there is a LOT of bonus material, all of which is alternate takes of the four songs.  The alternate takes are fun, because you can hear Elvis laughing and clowning around.  He especially has a hard time getting through the novelty songs without laughing.  Of course, the price of this CD will keep anyone except for hardcore Elvis fans from buying it.

Bob Dylan sings pop standards here.  All of these songs were previously recorded by Frank Sinatra, who was arguably the best interpreter of this kind of material.  Dylan doesn't perform any of Sinatra's signature songs, wisely avoiding comparisons.  Some people don't like Dylan because he doesn't have a beautiful voice, but he does get to the emotional core of the songs.  An enjoyable album if you do happen to like Dylan.
It's no Green Eggs And Ham, but it's cute.

This is a collection of "Nguyen Charlie" comic strips that were originally publishing in Stars and Stripes during the Vietnam War.  It is, as far as I know, the only comic strip that was actually ABOUT the Vietnam War during the conflict.  Nguyen Charlie is drawn somewhat stereotypically, but he doesn't really come acoss much worse than the American soldiers in the strip.  I confess that I didn't find the strips to be all that funny, but perhaps I just don't "get it" because I wasn't a soldier in the Vietnam War.

This collection of Dobie Gillis short stories preceded the famous TV series by several years.  Most of the stories were written in the 1940's.  There is no continuity from story to story.  Dobie is a college student at the University of Minnesota in every story, but his major changes from story to story and other details are different, like what his father does for a living,  He is also in love with a different girl in every story, and yes, these are girls, not women.  Their ages range from 16 to 19.  The main thing to know about these stories is that they are quite funny, with most of them ending with a humorous surprise.  By the way, Max Shulman also wrote a novel about Dobie Gillis called "I Was a Teen-Age Dwarf".

This is the book that originated the "Belvedere" character, later seen in three movies and a sitcom.  I haven't seen the movies, but this Belvedere is quite different than TV's Mr. Belvedere.  This Belvedere is a self-centered, self-proclaimed "genius" .  The book takes place during World War II.  Babysitters are hard to come by, with most women working in plants for the war effort.  Tacey King has the idea to take out an ad in a literary magazine, looking for an aspiring novelist to live with her family and help out a little around the house, but leaving a lot of time to write.  Lynn Belvedere answers the ad and turns out to be a man, much to Tacey's surprise.  Hilarity ensues, needless to say.  The book is surprisingly adult, with the occasional curse word and sexual situation, not to mention a character who is implied to be possibly homosexual.  This is an enjoyable read.
This was the second children's album by Trout Fishing in America.  It's a good album, but I wish it was a little funnier.

This is a compilation of Jewish themed comedy songs.  The songs are funny to me, even though I'm not Jewish.  I should note that four new recordings were made for this album.  They were produced by Richard Foos, one half of "The Rhino Brothers", the founders of Rhino Records.  Two of these songs are re-recordings of novelty songs from the early days of Rhino Records, back when Rhino released a lot of Jewish themed novelty records.

In 1966, the same year that Batman was all the rage on TV, Superman was on the Broadway stage.  I was born in 1967, so I never saw the Broadway show, but based on the cast album, it was a pretty good show.  For whatever reason, the show wasn't a hit and ran for less than four months.  Perhaps the problem was that the lead character wasn't Superman himself, but rather a heretofore unmentioned Daily Planet columnist named Max Mencken.  Oh well, the cast album is enjoyable anyway.

This is the third box in ERB's series about Venus.  In the previous books in the series, Earthling Carson Napier accidentally landed on Venus while attempting to travel to Mars (don't ask).  This being Burroughs, he naturally wins the love of a native princess.  Of course, they become separated for a time in this book and Carson goes through adventures before being reunited with her.  The most interesting part of this book is that Burroughs satirizes the Nazis with a Venusian political group called the "Zanis" (get it?).  Fans of ERB will enjoy this book.

This is the first album by the talented actor John Lithgow, and it's a children's album.  John knows that children like novelty songs, so most of the songs here are novelty songs.  He performs the songs in a charming style, which will appeal to little kids and big kids like me.

In the mid-1960's, five American GIs stationed in Germany formed a garage band.  After they got out of the army, the band stayed in Germany and cut an album.  The music on the album has been described as "avant-garde garage rock", which is accurate.  If you are a fan of sixties garage bands, this is a must hear.

This is a "traditional pop" album by Tony Bennett and Lady Gaga.  Obviously, Tony Bennett is one of the biggest legends of this kind of music.  Less Obviously, Lady Gaga does a great job of singing these kind of songs, too.  When the two of them sing together, it is utterly charming.  This is a very good album.

I wanted this second volume Hanna-Barbera Classics for a long time.  But it was only available as part of the "Pic-A-Nic Basker" with Hanna-Barbera Classics Volume One and a sound effects CD.  I already had Volume One and I didn't want the sound effects, so I couldn't see buying the box set to get just the one CD.  Finally, a few months ago, I found a reasonably priced copy of Volume Two.  Most of the CD is taken up by "underscore" music (which is to say background music) from The Flintstones, Top Cat, The Jetsons and Jonny Quest.  These were prime time shows, so they had higher budgets than the Saturday morning shows and thus could spend more money on original music scores (the Saturday morning shows often recycled music).  The CD does end with the theme songs from ten other cartoons.  The music is rather enjoyable if you a fan of these shows.

This book prints highlights from over twenty years worth of journals kept by Charlton Heston.  "Chuck" writes in the intro that most of his entries about playing tennis have been cut, but there is still too much tennis for my taste.  What is interesting is reading Heston's thoughts about the movies he made at the time that he made them.  It is quite clear that he took the "craft" of acting very seriously.  He actually come across as a good guy, despite what some people might like to think.  He also wasn't as conservative as people think, having participated in the March on Washington.

This was the third book of letters from "Ted L. Nancy" to businesses and the responses that he received.  Many of his letters are so absurd that they are laugh out loud funny.  Most of the respondents actually took him seriously, although at least one response got that it was a joke.  Funny stuff, if you like this sort of thing.

This book collects material originally published in Love and Rockets Vol. II # 11-19.  That is to say, the Jaime Hernandez material, not the Gilbert Hernandez material.  Roughly the first half of the book is about Hopey Glass as she makes a career change to teaching assistant.  The second half of the book is about Ray Dominguez, as he becomes involved with the unstable stripper Vivian.  Oh, and there are aIso a few strips about a young tomboy called Angel.  I haven't read Love & Rockets in several years, so I was a bit confused about what was going on, but I still enjoyed it.

This is a "sequel" to Jose Canseco's previous book, the best selling Juiced.  Most of this book is about the reactions to the first book.  It's interesting enough, but obviously not as explosive as the first book.  He does add a few new names to the list of "juicers" from the previous book.  Of course, history shows us that Jose told the truth, despite what some people thought at the time.
Good book, pretty funny.  It's a little dated, though, even if it is just ten years later.  Probably seemed funnier when it first came out.

The basic idea of this book is that "Ted L. Nancy" wrote ridiculous letters to various corporations.  This book prints the letters and the responses that the corporations sent back to him.  Amazingly, only one responder seemingly got that it was a joke.  Most of the letters he sent out are so nutty, it's hard to believe that anyone took them seriously.  Funny stuff.

This is a novel for young people that was published in 1928.  It is about Ernie Powers, a sophomore at "State College".  Ernie has a secret desire to be a baseball pitcher, but is pathologically shy and lacks confidence.  When Ernie gets in a snowball fight, his throwing arm catches the eye of Ruth Harding, the most popular girl in school (and possibly the only girl in school; we never meet another coed).  Ruth encourages Ernie to come out of his shell and try out for the baseball team.  That's enough information about the plot.  This is an enjoyable enough story that is a product of its time.

This is a book, written in 1955, that teaches boys how to play baseball.  Despite being 60 years old, the teachings here still apply today.  Of course, it is always preferable to learn how to play from a good coach, rather than a book.

This biography of Branch Rickey came out a year after he died.  It was written by the man who previously was Satchel Paige's ghostwriter.  It was written for children (10 and up), but it does a good job of conveying Rickey's life story.  Today, Rickey is best known as the man who brought Jackie Robinson to MLB and broke the color line, but that part of his life isn't given any more coverage than the rest of it (although the book does open with Rickey's first meeting with Robinson).  Truly, Branch Rickey lead a life to remember.

This is a collection of science fiction short stories, by various authors, originally published in 1969.  It seems to be intended for younger readers, although not all of the stories read as though they were specifically written for youngsters.  The stories were originally published in science fiction magazines between 1946 and 1966.  All of the stories are good, although I enjoyed some more than others.
A very good collection of short stories by various writers.

This novel for boys by Curtis Bishop is one of several that he wrote about Little League Baseball.  I don't know if the books have recurring characters, but several of them seem to take place in the author's hometown of Austin (as this one does).  In this book, Carlos, a refugee from Fidel Castro's Cuba, joins the Giants of the Austin Little League.  Will Curtis adjust to living in America?  Will Carlos and his father be allowed to stay in Austin?  Will the Giants win the championship?  Actually, you don't find out the answer to the last question, because the book ends in the middle of the season.  This is an enjoyable enough book for boys, although possibly too dated for the boys of today.

Full disclosure: I was a Kickstarter backer of this book.  Like the first book, it offers suggestions for enjoyably bad movies to watch with your friends.  There are less movies this time, but the write ups are longer.  There are some good ideas here that I will definitely be watching on future movie nights.

This is a well researched book about William Moulton Marston and the women in his life, both real and fictional.  Marston was a fascinating character; a self-promoter, a polygamist, a feminist, an inventor, a psychologist, a comic book writer.  Equal time is also given to Marston's wife Elizabeth Holloway Marston and his lover Olive Byrne.  The author does a great job in showing how specific incidents in Marston's life are reflected in his Wonder Woman stories,

This is exactly what it says it is; a book with 50+ suggestions for movies to watch at a Bad Movie Night.  It does a solid job of giving information about entertaining bad movies, some well known and some obscure.  There could be more films from prior to 1980, though.  Since the author lives in my hometown of Bethel, CT., I would like to extend an open invitation for him to attend one of my Bad Movie Nights.

This volume of Marvel Masterworks reprints The Defenders comics from August 1973 to October 1974.  The most prominent storyline here is "The Avengers/Defenders War".  Yes, The Avengers issues of the crossover are included.  Also included is the battle with The Squadron Sinister, where Nighthawk defects from The Squadron and joins The Defenders (as a replacement for The Sub-Mariner).  Oh, and Professor X gets The Defenders to help him battle Magneto and the Brotherhood of Evil Mutants, during the time when The X-Men didn't have their own comic book.  These are fun comics that are nostalgic to me, since I was a seven year old fanboy when these issue came out.

This book reprints the Robin comics from Star Spangled Comics #87 to #105.  As other reviewers have pointed out, the production quality here is much lower than it was in Robin Archives Vol. 1.  The stories were NOT recolored with fresh, vibrant colors like the first volume had.  Instead, we get the faded colors from sixty year old comic books.  That's disappointing, but if you can get past that, the stories are pretty fun.  From issues #88 to #95, the strip essential became a "Batman and Robin" strip, in an apparent attempt to increase circulation.  With #96, Tomahawk (a Revolutionary War hero) took over the cover of the comic and Robin went back to solo adventures (with some flimsy excuse for why Batman wasn't involved).  Fun comics, but it would be nice if the stories had decent coloring.

This edition of Marvel Masterworks reprints the first ten issues of Adam Warlock's solo series, plus the three issues of Incredible Hulk that wrapped up the storyline.  Warlock debuted in Fantastic Four as "Him" and was finally given a real name when Roy Thomas gave him his own series.  As Thomas admits in his introduction, he was inspired by Jesus Christ Superstar to create a messianic superhero.  He wanted Warlock to be the only superhero on the planet, so he had the High Evolutionary create "Counter-Earth" on the far side of the Sun.  The High Evolutionary's evil creation the Man-Beast took the Satanic role in the series.  It was an enjoyable series that was canceled prematurely.

This big book reprints the entire John Carter, Warlord of Mars series published by Marvel Comics.  That's 28 monthly issues and three annuals.  This series is surprisingly good.  That can be largely attributed to two of the best comics writers of their generation, Marv Wolfman and Chris Claremont.  Wolfman started the series off with a ten part story and Claremont topped that with a twelve part story.  The artwork is good, too, with Gil Kane drawing more issues than anyone else.  Something worth noting is that Frank Miller's first Marvel work was in John Carter #18, although he hadn't developed his own style yet and his artwork looked pretty much like everyone elses.  This is a fun series for people who are fans of Edgar Rice Burroughs' Barsoom series.

Five of the surviving Beach Boys reunited to record a new album for their 50th anniversary.  It's a good album, although not quite as good as their "classic" albums.  But how could it be?  It does sound like a Beach Boys album, and if this is the last studio album from them, it would be a fitting coda to their career.

As far as I know, this is the second album released by Chuck Barris.  The first one was an instrumental album of theme songs from his tv shows.  This is his first album as a vocalist.  Unfortunately, he isn't that good of a singer.  He probably would have been gonged on The Gong Show.  His voice isn't terrible, it's just nothing special.  However, the band on the album, lead by Gong Show bandleader Milton DeLugg, is quite good.  The songs are pretty short, with 16 songs packed into 38 minutes.  Most of the songs are standards, but of course Chuck also does his biggest hit as a songwriter, "Palisades Park".  This is a fun enough album if you are a Chuck Barris fan.  If you aren't a fan, this album won't turn you into one.

During the recording sessions for Ghost On The Canvas, Glen Campbell recorded new vocals for some of his most popular songs as well as a few other songs.  Some time later, new instrumentation was added to his vocals and this album is the result.  While this album isn't as great as Ghost On The Canvas, it's still great in it's own right.  Glen's voice isn't as strong as it used to be, but the "catch" in his voice just makes the songs more touching.  The vulnerability in his voice and the sparce instrumentation bring out the melancholia in "Rhinestone Cowboy" like never before.  God bless Glen Campbell.

This is a deluxe edition CD of the soundtrack to Stay Away, Joe.  This is the first CD exclusively devoted to that movie, since there were only five songs recorded for the movie, which would have made for a really short CD.  There were two recording sessions for the soundtrack.  The first session was in October of 1967, where three songs were recorded.  It was decided that the movie needed one more song, so another session was scheduled for January of 1968.  Two songs were recorded for possible inclusion in the film, plus two other songs that had nothing to do with the movie.  That makes a total of seven songs, which would be a very short "album".  But have no fear, there are a ton of bonus track incuded here, all of which are alternate takes.  These alternate takes are among the most interesting of Elvis' career, because Elvis was in a "mood" during the sessions.  He curses on most of the alternate takes, and jokes around a lot.  As for the quality of the songs, "U.S. Male" is one of his best songs of the late 1960's, and the other songs are good, which one exception.  That exception is "Dominic", which is one of the worst songs that Elvis ever recorded and Elvis asked that it never be released on a record (oops).  This is a fun CD, but the price and the duplication of songs makes it only of interest to hardcore Elvis fans.

This album was assembled by a producer named Pink Bob.  He got Tiny Tim to come to his recording studio on two dates.  Tiny sang and played his ukulele, and Pink later overdubbed other instruments onto the tracks (a band called The Sediments provided the instrumentation).  Actually, only half the songs here are from the Pink Bob sessions; he licensed the rest of the songs from other people.  The first song is an Elvis related novelty song produced by Stuart Hersh.  There are three songs from the still unreleased album celebrating Tiny's marriage to Miss Sue.  Three of the songs were written and produced by Mike Nerlino; I assume these are from the 1970's, because two of them are disco songs.  The final song is a bizarre remix of a Tiny Tim song fragment that Eugene Chadbourne somehow stretched out to almost seven minutes.  The different sources for the songs give the CD diversity, which actually works in it's favor.  This is a fun album which shows that Tiny Tim was more than just "Tiptoe Thru The Tulips".

The Monkees Present was The Monkees third album of 1969, including the original version of The Monkees Greatest Hits.  It included four tracks each from Micky, David and Michael.  Unfortunately, they didn't choose the four BEST tracks from each of them (in my opinion).  Two of Davy songs are actually leftovers from More Of The Monkees and don't belong on the album.  This three CD (and one 45) Deluxe Edition features a whole of songs that were considered from the album but ultimately left off of it (including some more leftovers from More Of The Monkees).  Most of these songs are included in multiple mixes.  There are even some backing tracks which they never got around to recording vocals for, most of which aren't that great to listen to.  This collection is clearly only for Monkees obsessives, because no one else would want to hear FIVE different mixes of "Mommy and Daddy" (actually SIX different mixes if you include the 45).

Clive Barker's Hell Priest, the demon or angel from the higher planes of pain and pleasure, the Cenobite known vulgarly as Pinhead has an ambitious vision.  As he pursues that vision, he attempts to recruit a detective gifted with a sensitivity for evil, and covered with tattoos that help him find his way when he opposes demons and ghosts, Harry D'Amour.  Pinhead wants D'Amour to be his chronicler, the observer who records Pinheads ascent to greater power in Hell and beyond.  Needless to say, D'Amour gives the demon an unequivocal 'no', but still gets drawn into battles and journeys on earth and in hell.I enjoyed the story immensely.  The characters were well developed, the plot moved quickly, and the elements of the story connected well.  By any standard, this was an excellent horror/fantasy story.  But the style wasn't quite what I had expected.The language and story were a departure from Barker's earlier style.  Compared to the book that introduced the Cenobites, Hellbound Heart, or the story that introduced D'Amour, The Last Illusion, Scarlet Gospels seemed less vibrant and less developed.  The descriptions were good, but lacked the intensity and visceral character of the earlier books.  The plot seemed more linear.  At one point, Barker was listing descriptors and ended with 'et cetera', which seemed very out of character. It read like a Barker story transcribed by a mentally and emotionally healthier person.  The book was good, and I enjoyed it, but the feel of it was unexpected, having read many books by Barker.A great horror novel, despite being a departure from Barker's usual style.Edward M. Van Court

Take an M&M, make them pastel colors, use first rate dark chocolate, and make the candy shell mint rather than bland sugar.  That is a mint lentil.  Like an M&M, but better in every way.Now pack them in a five pound bag rather than the customary 8 oz or smaller.  Of course you want to try them before you take the plunge, but if you have the taste for mint lentils, stop with the amateur hour already and go for broke with the five pound bag.E.M. Van Court

Every student of American history (at least those who stayed awake) knows the story of George Washington attacking the Hessians on Christmas Eve.The author of this work was an officer of those Hessians.  Ewald articulates the needs of a conventional force using unconventional tactics to oppose an insurgency.  Just like the Marine Corps' 1940 Small Wars Manual, many books about the US-Vietnam war, a plethora of current articles about Iraq and Afghanistan, and a host of other works.For the contemporary counterinsurgent, Ewald provides a sense of continuity, a sense that you are not alone, and others have shared the challenges you face.  To be fair, there is little said that hasn't been said elsewhere, but that someone described an experience you share in in 1785, 230 years ago, is proof that you are not alone, that others have shared in the trials through the ages.  On the other hand, sometimes historical perspective can offer insights that did not emerge from more recent works, like the 1940 Small Wars Manual.For a student of light infantry tactics, Ewald provides two things.  First, he provides examples of early dispersed tactics using precision small arms, tactics that required initiative, discipline, and dynamic leadership while breaking with Napoleonic tactics in every way. Second, he commiserates with the junior officer who sees a need for change while facing senior leaders who cannot see beyond their comfort zone in obsolescent concepts.  The struggle is real, and goes back centuries, brother.  Don't surrender, and don't back down.For students of the American Revolution, Ewald provides a perspective seldom voiced, that of neither the Colonials nor the British, but a British 'military contractor'.  We hear the voices of American patriots, and occasionally our French allies (since the war conveniently served their interests), and once in a while we hear the thoughts of Brits who were defeated by a pack of Colonials, but the German mercenaries are seldom, if ever heard from.  The bitterness at defeat by a bunch of untrained an poorly equipped peasants stung, and stung hard.  This is a voice who deserve to be heard.For a wide range of historians and theorists, this is a valuable work.  I can't recommend it highly enough.Edward M. Van Court

The Victorinox German Army knife is an excellent tool for adventures off the beaten path.  It has six blades with nine tools (lock blade, wood saw, can opener, bottle opener, wire stripper, awl, two slotted screwdrivers, and a Philips head screwdriver, and the large slotted screwdriver locks open).  The metal parts are all a good quality, corrosion resistant steel, and the scales are green plastic with a good, non-slip surface.  Both the lock blade and saw cut well.  The blade is partially serrated, on the half closer to the point, which is a little unusual, but has worked well for me.  The thumb hole allows easy opening with one hand, and the blade locks open with a click and no play.  The saw is double cut, and the most efficient design you can find on a knife.  The can opener and bottle opener work well.  The slotted screw drivers could be finished a bit better, but despite the slight rounding, they work well enough.All together, this knife is an excellent combination of tools made to a high standard.  Good pocket knife, if a little large for carrying in town.Edward M. Van Court

This and the L&L Hawaiian Barbecue cookbook are tied for top position on my cookbook shelf.  I love New Orleans, and the cuisine is more than half the attraction.  This cookbook captures some of my favorite dishes from the Crescent City.I have tried more than a dozen of the over fifty recipes in this book, and any time the result wasn't absolutely amazing, I could figure out what mistake I made.  The Lundi Red Beans can be lunches for a week, savory, filling, and a serious risk of over-eating.  The Crab Mornay has become the most requested dish if I am bringing something to an event.  The Crawdad Etouffee is amazing with shrimp and does not last long.  I could go on, but to summarize,  the recipes are clear, easy to follow, and yield dishes that will make your cooking more popular than you want it to be.E.M. Van Court

Barilla makes good pasta.  This one is no exception.But when the chairman of the Barilla Group, Guido Barilla states that he does not care if gays use his products, that he believes in a woman's role in the kitchen, and that he won't have a gay family in his advertising, there was, unsurprisingly, some blow back.So, if you can look past the politics, good pasta, but I won't be surprised if you can't.

The OXO silicone sink mat is one of those things that seems frivolous until you use it.It is a neutral grey, and doesn't stand out visually in a steel sink.  What it does is keeps thing from sliding around while you are trying to clean then, and prevents dishes from becoming drain plugs when you want the sink to drain while you work.  It also makes the sink quieter as it keeps flatware and dishes from clattering, a boon if you share a home with a light sleeper.E.M. Van Court

When they said small tents, I figure these would be some sort of camping equipment.  One of these won't even keep the rain off my nose.On the other hand, if you need to print place cards for a dinner or meeting, these are pretty good.  Sized for standard printers, they come apart neatly, and present a professional appearance. Word templates for these can be found at the Avery website, and worked well for me.E.M. Van Court

This is a first rate steel water bottle.The intent of this product was to avoid keeping your drinking water in plastics that might be health concerns.  This it does.  The cap screws down tightly and doesn't leak even when shaken.  It is steel, so there are no questions about the bottle.  It isn't clear what plastic the cap is made out of, but I could not detect any odor.  I am curious which steel it is made of, as I know people who are allergic to nickel, and unless it is surgical steel, there is a chance my friends could react to it.Good product if this is what you are looking for.E.M. Van Court

Kelly Link is off to a great start.  Her stories are imaginative and engaging.  The plots range from classic to surreal.  The descriptions are vivid and bring the stories to life.Her style is reminiscent of William Gibsons prose, placing you in the setting quickly and building the milieu around you as the story progresses.  But instead of a grimy future, it is a world of elves and ghosts, sunshine and twilight, innocence and sinster intents.  My favorite was Summer People, a tale of elves in a rundown rural setting.  Many of the elements of classic fairy tales were there, but new nuances were introduced to make the elves contemporary.  The Valley of the Girls puts an ancient Egyptian on modern youthful romance.  And the Lesson, well, you'll have to read it.I forward to seeing more of her work.E.M. Van Court

"Resistance Will Win" by Truong Chinh is the essential text to understanding the wars in Vietnam from the end of World War II through the mid-nineteen seventies.One of the fundamental problems in understanding the VIetnam wars for Americans and Europeans is that the conflicts are viewed through the lens of the French and American perceptions of the war and the French and American ignorance of Ho Chi Minh's and Giap's mindset and approach to the conflicts.Often referred to as "Dau Tranh" ("One Struggle"), the key aspects of Vietnamese military theory were protracted struggle and complete unity of effort.  The Vietnamese saw time as being on their side.  As long as they did not quit, they would win.  The other piece was that political, economic, cultural, and military means were all brought to bear on their war of liberation from outside influences.A very different take on strategic theory and the Vietnam conflicts than most Americans or Europeans hear.Edward M. Van Court

My reflective belt is my best friend. It is my life. I must master it as I must master my life.My reflective belt, without me, is useless. Without my reflective belt, I am useless. I must wear my reflective belt true. I must be more visible than my enemy who is trying to kill me. I must be seen by him before he has an accident involving me. I will...My reflective belt and I know that what counts in this war is not the rounds we fire, the noise of our burst, nor the smoke we make. We know that it is safety that counts. We will be safe...My reflective belt is human, even as I, because it is my life. Thus, I will learn it as a brother. I will learn its weaknesses, its strength, its parts, its accessories, its velco and its adjustment. I will keep my reflective belt clean and ready, even as I am clean and ready. We will become part of each other. We will...Before God, I swear this creed. My reflective belt and I are the defenders of my country. We are the masters of our safety. We are the saviors of my life.So be it, until safety is America's and there are no accidents.The reflective belt.  Doing more damage to morale and combat readiness in the U.S. Army than the Soviet Union did in over forty years.E.M. Van Court

"People's War People's Army" has more theory than the author's "Military Art of People's War", but that is not saying much.  This work is more of a detailed history of the Vietnam war from the 1940s through 1960 or 61, with some commentary on the underlying theory, and a lot of anti-American, and anti-French propaganda.To its credit, this book does an excellent job of describing the strategic and operational level thinking of the Vietnamese communists in the period covered.  I would strongly recommend this book to anyone studying the Vietnam war, so they can get a well rounded perspective of goals and intentions of the Vietnamese communists.I was hoping for more discussion of Vietnamese military theory, but the underlying theory behind the North Vietnamese military plans and actions was not well addressed.  Strategic thinking was articulated, but how they decided on these ends and ways was not.  On the other hand, Giap recommended "The Resistance War Will Win" by Truong Chinh, so I guess I know what my next book will be.E. M. Van Court

The comic anti-hero, Doctrine Man flies again.  With his teammates, the Bright Idea Fairy (BIF), the Irish Chaplain, The Great Satan, the ancient Colonel, the Air Force Guy, the guy with the red velvet codpiece, and others, as well as his nemesis, The Blue Falcon, DM shines a light on the foibles of all levels of the Army's silliness.From "Just livin' the dream" among the ruins and goats of Iraq, to PowerPoint at the Pentagon, nothing is off the table.  The despised and contemptible U.S. Army Reflective Belt gets the special attention it richly deserves. The crack about the State Department's "touch rugby league" was amusing and representative of many service members' attitudes towards State Department.I would toss it out there that if an anthropology student is trying to study the culture of the military, they could do worse than to take this book, and as service members to explain the jokes.  In many ways, this book is for a narrow audience, and might take much context to make sense to outsiders.  Never the less, it is hilarious for the right audience.E.M. Van Court

The author makes the case that Joint military education, where officers from all services are in a classroom together, should start with lieutenants and captains (Navy lieutenants junior grade and lieutenants) rather than majors and lieutenant commanders.  Given that all military operations in the future will be joint, collaborations between two or more services, the need to develop rapport between officers of different services is being forced down to a lower level, and the formal education process should include a joint aspect at lower levels.Excellent scholarship.E.M. Van Court*Full disclosure -  I was a proof reader for this thesis.

Okay, no bones about it.  This thing is ugly.Now that we have that out of the way, it is warm and comfortable.  It was designed as an improved liner for a military cold weather jacket.  The improvements were that it can be buttoned and worn without the shell, and the knit cuffs.  The knit cuffs make a big difference; no more drafts up the sleeves.What it is perfect for: an office, home, or other environment where there is disagreement about thermostat settings, and the the person who likes it cold plays the "I'm too hot, I'm getting nauseous" card all the time. This makes up the difference between refrigerator room temperatures and a comfortable room temperature very nicely.E.M. Van Court

The best Tabasco ever!  I tried it at a restaurant recently and it is going to be a permanent part of my cooking from here on out.It has a little bit of the burn, but the flavor is so amazing that the heat will be completely worth it.  Rich, smoky, savory; all that is right with chipotle is here.Wonderful stuff.  If you like chipotle at all, give this a try.E. M. Van Court

I purchased General Giap's book trying to understand his military theory and outlook on leadership.  While I found a few nuggets, there was a lot of dross to plow through to get to the parts that answered my questions.While this book didn't do much for me, I can see how someone else might view it as the jackpot.  While it isn't much on the tactical, operational, or military strategic fronts, it is excellent on the political strategic and psychological framework of conflict.  Giap spends a lot of time laying out the arguments used to motivate the North Vietnamese Army, the guerrillas, and the peasants.  He discusses arguments to be directed at the enemy troops and citizens.I found Giap's constant verbal attacks on the United States both interesting and distracting.  No exaggeration; Giap could not mention the U.S. without a negative adjective or attribute in the same sentence.  What was telling was the more effective a given action by the U.S. the more venom was poured on.  To be fair, the U.S. had worked with Giap's boss, Ho Chi Minh, through World War II, and was ready to leave Ho in charge, but knuckled under to DeGaulle, when the French wanted Indochina back after the war.  Rather than risk the nascent NATO, the U.S. threw Vietnam under the French made bus.  But this also suggests that Giap's audience receptive to the demonizing of the U.S. and it served to reinforce the messaging Giap wanted.For me, this book was of limited value, but it is a primary source for the Vietnamese strategic thinking during the VIetnam war, so it is a historical document than should have great value to many scholars.E.M. Van Court

If I throw the book at writing students, this is the book I throw.  This small book is the best single reference for clear and concise writing.  Strunk and White addresses grammar, structure, and pitfalls that most new or out-of-practice writers fall into.  It is divided into sections on the rules of usage (grammar), composition (structure or content of writing), form (rules for punctuation, use of hyphens, headings, margins, and other topics), commonly misused words and expressions, and a collection of other reminders about style.If a student complies with all the guidelines in Strunk and White, and makes the length requirement, the worst they would get is a B.Excellent reference for any student or writer.E.M. Van Court

Good as canned tuna goes, but it is still canned tuna.Mild flavor, nothing untoward about the smell or appearance.  Highly suitable for tuna salad or casserole.On the other hand, I am a sucker for the World Wildlife Federation, so I wouldn't mind a slight mark-up over other brands.  The mark up, however, is kind of steep.  If the price comes down a bit, I would buy this one.E.M. Van Court

Build QualityIf you're like me and looking at this case then you hate cases that add too much bulk to your phone?  It totally destroys the aesthetics meant by the manufacturer, right?This is the 3rd time I've ordered the Slim case from spigen for 3 different phones.  The nexus 5, nexus 6 and now the 6p.  And just like the past 2 times it feels great.  Doesn't add much bulk at all.The key things you need to know are:-cut outs where you can actually press the phone's buttons, which i love.-raised lip so the screen doesn touch the surface when faced down-has all necessary cutouts for mics and fingerprint sensor-fits very snug-doesn't cover the back glass "visor" where all the sensors and antennas areConclusionThe perfect slim case imo.  Go buy it!

Build QualityExtremely solid but light weight.  Nothing seems flimsy.  Minimal footprint so it won't take much space on your desk/table.  Has removable and replaceable rubber feet/ends that serve with the dual purpose of preventing the hub from rolling away and sliding around.  It comes with a few colors of grey, blue, orange and green.The usb ports are snug but not overly tight where it seems impossible to plug or unplug anything.  It has a very premium feel to it.PerformanceHas no slow down with transfers.  Was able to move large and small files with no hiccups.  Connected via type c cables and regular usb 3.0 cables just fine.  Tried it a friends mac and my regular usb 3.0 port on my pc.ConclusionVery happy with the purchase.  My go to hub for my laptop and traveling!

*Build Quality/Performance*Built like a tank!  Feels extremely solid in hand!  Small enough to fit on your pocket comfortably.  Trying to bend the unit caused no bending or creeking.  Can easily fit into and bag and charge devices discretely!It's completely matte black which I like.  Two usb ports and one button to check how much charge is left on the battery pack.It handled charging all sorts of devices in various combinations.  Devices included:Mp3 player, camera, nexus 5, iphone 5, iphone 6, S6 Note 5, S4, nexus 7 and oneplus one.Never had any hiccups, charged it as fast as a wall charger.*ConclusionIf youre looking a big capacity in a small package then this is it.  It's my new go to battery pack!
Simple charger that simple works.  Feels solid.  Single port, would have been nice to have atleast 2 ports.  Charges all my devices with no problem.

Build Quality/ Performance*Packaged really nicely.  Come's with a really short micro usb cable to charge the speaker, wish it come with a longer one.It has a really nice glossy finish to it.  Very stylish and minimal.  I like how it has a rubber ring at the bottom to prevent sliding on desktops.Feels pretty solid in hand because it had a nice weight to it.  The goose neck is something I am a bit worried about.  Definitely the weak point on the unit.  Wouldn't recommend tossing it any bag and traveling with it.The controls are at the very top and touch sensitive buttons.  Really simple and really use to use.  There is a power button at the bottom that automatically put the device in pairing mode.  Pairing was a breeze, took maybe a minute and subsequent pairings took less than 5 seconds.Sound is decent but not the best, the treble/highs it gets distorted while the bass isn't the greatest.  It DOES it pretty loud but don't throw a party with it.*Conclusion*While it is a solid unit there are better units for the price.

*Build Quality*The case itself is quite nice.  It's has a premium feel to it and has a great snug fit to it on the phone.  I've drops the phone a few times with the case and nothing has broken on the phone or case.Where it gets a little iffy is the kickstand.  It doesn't feel the sturdiest but its never failed so far.  When pulling it out of the slot to use the stand it doesnt have a premium feel to it.The cutout for everything is spot on.  The buttons have a very satisfying feel to it when pressing them for the volume and etc.  Very well protected.*Conclusion*I would recommend this case just for the looks and the feel of the case alone.  The stand could be better.  If you want a case more than a stand this is the case for you if you only plan to use the stand sparingly.

*Build Quality*Very solid.  There is a nice rigidness to the leather but not overly stiff.  It does have some give to it when bending but not cheap feeling.The magnet has a very satisfying snap to it and it never falls off by itself.  The "pockets" for cards and ID's are not meant to carry everything but just an item or two.  If stuffed too much, the magnet will lose effectiveness.It's nice to have when going out and all you want with you is your ID, credit card and a few bills on you.  Definitely beats having to worry abut your phone AND wallet.It's quite stylish and gotten a few comments on where to get the case when out and about.*Conclusion*Very convenient to have your necessities on you when going out in just one package.4 stars just because it slides around quite easily, other than that its amazing!

*Build Quality/DesignLike all anker products I've had; its build quality is top notch.  I have yet to have an anker product break or fail me.From the base to the cable to the lightning connector its solid through and through.  I've used it exclusively for awhile and it won't surprise me if it lasts until apple comes up with a new connector type.  The wire is fairly thick and durable.  The strain reliefs is what I'm most impressed with.  Nothing to worry about broken connections like other chargers.It has a very satisfying snug fit in the lightning port.  It's not overly loose or two tight.  It's just right.I love the color combo.  My two favorite colors, but it would be nice to have different options*PerformanceIt charges the phone just fine, not once was it not recognized or failed to charge the iphone.*ConclusionFor the price and build quality its a no brainer.  Also, not having to put wear and tear on your regular use cable is a plus.  I recommend this to anyone.

Build Quality/DesignThe speaker itself is a basic compact rectangular design.The build quality is top notch!  Extremely solid, nothing loose or flims.  The weakest point is the grill/mesh but even then it's good enough for everyday use.  Made out of metal and not some cheap plastic.  I've used and traveled with it on my bag for a month now and it still looks new and nothing fell apart.It has a rubber strip of buttons on the top.  Mode, volume down/back track, phone call/play/pause, volume up/next track.  The bottons have a very nice tactile click to them and not mushy at all when pressing them.Functions/PerformanceSoundI've had cheapo Bluetooth speakers before such as targus and rocketfish but these sound soooo much better than those. I've heard a lot more expensive Bluetooth speakers such as UE Boom, Logitech and Beats pill and the anker more than keeps up with them.At max volume, it doesn't distort which is a very big deal as a lot of speakers have that problem. I was pleasantly surprised how loud and the quality when at full volume.There are 2 ways to raise the volume. First is on the phone/device itself and then on the speaker itself. So you set the speaker at highest volume, then adjust it via the device. However if you set it at the lowest volume on the phone, no matter if you press the volume up on the speaker the volume will not go up. Hope that makes sense.You can use it as a "headset" while making calls. If a call comes in a quick press of the "play" button answers the call. Holding the "play" button denies the call. The mic is best used within 3 feet. After the 3ft the quality drops. So don't expect to be able to use it from across the room or anything.***Note, you can set your phone to pick up calls via the phone instead of the speaker on the Bluetooth settings for the speaker**The battery has lasted all day with no problems.ConclusionFor the Price, it hard to not recommend this product.

*Build Quality/Design*The unit itself is very simple and minimal.  Looks just like a flash drive; plug it in and its powers on*Functions/Performance*Setting up was a breeze. Initial sync was super easy and straight forward. Subsequent syncs took less than a second.Sound quality was very good, nothing ever choppy nor was there ever any dropped audio.While using it in the car for streaming music (Pandora, iheart, Spotify) was simply amazing. Its a must have if your car stereo deck doesnt have built in Bluetooth.*Sound*Amazing quality!  CAN'T TELL THE DIFFERENCE IF IT WAS STRAIGHT AUX CABLE.*Conclusion*Would recommend this to anyone!

*Build Quality/Performance*Let me go ahead and mention that this thing is a beast.  Rated at 23000 is just ridiculous.  This is meant for true traveling warriors.  This thing has ability to charge youre laptop, tablet, phone and pretty much anything else you could think of.  Its about the size of my Nexus 7 (7 inch tablet).It has a nice two toned appearance.  A faux brushed metal look and a glossy finish.  It has a good look to it and feels like a premium product; which it should.Holding it in the hand, it definitely feels solid.  Nothing bends or creaks that would cause concern.  It has a nice little lcd screen telling you the exact percentage of charge left and the output voltage.  The voltage is more specifically if youre charging a laptop that has very specific needs.  9V/12V/16V/19V/20V are all selectable output voltages.  It pretty much has all the connectors for ever type of laptop you can think of, 10 in total.It also has 2 usb ports, a 1 amp and a 2.1 amp output.The thing about smaller capacity battery packs is that you end up charging the thing fairly often if you use it a lot.  With this.you probably would charge it once a week and thats with super heavy use throughout the week.I was able to charge my Nexus 7 and Nexus 5 at the same time with no problems.  I also charged many different combinations of phones and tablets comprising of Ipad 4 Retina, Nexus 7, Iphone 5, Nexus 5, Samsung Galaxy s2, S3 and Ipad mini.It take 2 whole days to pretty much go from 100% to 0% charging various devices.Nexus 5  63% > 100% = 851mahNexus 7  89% > 100% = 435mahIpad 4  52% > 100% = 5548mahNexus 5  89% >100% = 253mahIpad 4  87% >100% = 1502mahNexus 5  58%>100% = 966mahNexus 7  88%>100% = 474mahIpad 4 -59%>100% =  4739mahNexus 5 -0%>65% = 1495mahNexus 7  85%> 100% = 592mahIpad 4  86%>100% = 1618mahTotal MAH actually charged via devices = 1847318473/23000 = 80% efficiency of the battery to charge other devices.Basically 80% of 23000mah is actually useable.  Which is a really good % compared to other external battery packs.Also, it was able to charge my Lenovo Y510p laptop no problem but I didnt use it in the testing as I mostly used it when I was out and about.*Conclusion*If youre looking for something that small and portable to use around the city this probably isnt for you but if you fly all across the country and dont want to worry about any of your devices running out of juice or having to find a wall socket then this would be.  It is a monster of a battery pack meant to do serious work.  For the price of 100 bucks, the ability to charge me laptop and every other device is a no brainer.  Especially not having to worry if the battery is charged all the time.

*Mpow FreeGo*Over the course of the years Ive tried many, many Bluetooth headsets and VERY few lasted more than a few days of use.  A lot had poor performance, extremely uncomfortable or both.I travel a lot and sometimes its just cumbersome having to hold the phone when talking and trying to multitask.  So I gave the FreeGO a try and Im glad I did.*Performance/Build Quality*When first looking at the unit; I was worried it was going to be too heavy with the size but I was pleasantly surprised when picking it up.  Its a lot lighter than I expected.  Even though it was light weight it didnt feel cheap in the slightly.  Nothing flexed, or creaked to the point where I was worried about it falling apart.The unit itself has a two toned looked to it.  A shiny glossy part and matte soft rubber part.  The soft rubber part is what actually is in contact with your ear.  This makes it extremely comfortable to wear.  So comfortable that Id forget I had it on to be honest.  The silicone ear tip that creates a seal for sound doesnt really create a seal as the tip is oddly flat shaped.  Its not like the tips on earphones/earbuds where you would jam them in your ear canal.  It simply hovers over the opening.  This worried me at first that calls or sounds would be difficult to hear.  Once again it surprised me.  Calls still came in crystal clear, music sounded good and never missed a notification sound.  I think the odd shape and not shoving them in the ear canal is what makes the headset so comfortable.Can be used on either ear.  The earpiece has a 180 Degree Flip-boom arm for both left or right ear.  Which is really convenient depending which ear you want to use it on.The unit has 3 buttons: Volume up, volume down and answer call.  All were easy to access when worn and always responsive.  Pairing it to my phone or tablet was a cinch and took no longer than 2 minutes for initial pairing and subsequent pairings took seconds.Sound quality was just amazing.  Never did I feel like it wasnt clear.  The mic also performed superbly.  The person on the line never had a problem hearing me or asked me to speak louder.  What else can you ask for?Last; it stayed in place.  Im sure everyone had that headset that was just impossible to keep in place and you ended adjusting it all the time.  Not this one; I had it on the ENTIRE day and not once did I have to adjust it.*Packaging*It comes in a simple box.  Has 3 different ear tips, a small faux leather pouch and a micro usb cable (flat cable which is a nice touch).  The micro usb cable is of decent quality which is a plus in my book.  It did not come with a wall plug though.  So either use your phones or plug it into your computer to charge it.*Conclusion*Its a no brainer for me if youre looking for a great value Bluetooth headset.  Good performance, good price and comfortable.  Id recommend it to anyone.

Anker Portable Bluetooth 4.0 Speaker 4WManufacturer DescriptionExperience your tunes in high definition and surprising fullness realized through a 4W / 2in driver and bass port - outclassing other similar-sized portable speakers.Unrivalled 15 to 20-hour playtime powered by a built-in rechargeable 2100mAh Li-ion battery.Automatically connect to the last-connected device when turned on enables one-step music streaming. Compatible with all Bluetooth-enabled devices (2.1 and over). 3.5mm audio port for non-Bluetooth devices.Outstanding connection range of up to 33 feet. Built-in microphone with a 2-feet pickup range allows the speaker to double as a speaker phone.Package contents: Anker MP141 Portable Bluetooth Speaker, micro USB cable, 3.5mm audio cable, travel pouch, instruction manual. 18-month warranty and free lifetime technical support.Build Quality/DesignThe speaker itself is a basic compact cube design. Like recent Anker products, it's a two toned grippy matte black finish and dark gray. The matte finish is a finger print and oil magnet however.Its built like a tank as nothing loose or flimsy about it. The grill, unlike other speakers, doesn't seem to bend easily when pressing on it. The bottom has a rubber not slip pad so it won't move around so much. Holding it in hand, it has a great feel to it that just screams quality.The side had the micro usb charge port with LED indicator, power switch and the AUX port.
