The Aux port is for any device that doesn't have Bluetooth. You can attach said device with the supplied 3.5mm headphone cable. The front has three buttons; Volume up, Volume Down and Play. At the top front is a nice blue led power LED that's not annoyingly bright. Last, at the bottom of the front panel is a mic when picking up calls and such.LED indications:Side power Red LED:Blinking Red: low power (the speaker will also announce/say, "battery low""Steady solid red: chargingNo light: fully chargedFront Blue connectivity LED:Blinking Blue: pairing mode (device and speaker not connected yet)Solid Steady Blue: Speaker and device are connectedFunctions/PerformanceSoundI've had cheapo Bluetooth speakers before such as targus and rocketfish but these sound soooo much better than those. I've heard a lot more expensive Bluetooth speakers such as UE Boom, Logitech and Beats pill and the anker more than keeps up with them.At max volume, it doesn't distort which is a very big deal as a lot of speakers have that problem. I was pleasantly surprised how loud and the quality when at full volume.There are 2 ways to raise the volume. First is on the phone/device itself and then on the speaker itself. So you set the speaker at highest volume, then adjust it via the device. However if you set it at the lowest volume on the phone, no matter if you press the volume up on the speaker the volume will not go up. Hope that makes sense.You can use it as a "headset" while making calls. If a call comes in a quick press of the "play" button answers the call. Holding the "play" button denies the call. The mic is best used within 3 feet. After the 3ft the quality drops. So don't expect to be able to use it from across the room or anything.***Note, you can set your phone to pick up calls via the phone instead of the speaker on the Bluetooth settings for the speaker**To make a call, hold the "play" button until the Google Now prompts you to say the name of the person you want to call.The battery lasts up to 20hrs according to Anker, I'm currently around the 21hr mark and it's still going strong.ConclusionFor the Price, I seriously doubt there is a better Bluetooth speaker. Don't spend a fortune on other name brand speakers and get this one. Trust me, you will not be disappointed.*Note: Sample was given in return for an unbiased review**

I've tried lots of portable speakers. Mostly of the "budget" category. Never bought beats, jambox or bose but usually went with the cheaper products. I have to say I was quite surprised by this speaker however.*Build Quality*It has a very rugged design that looks like an "egg". Holding it hand it has a good weight to it and feels rock solid. It looks like it could take some abuse from day to day use. Not once did I find anything flimsy or loose. It comes in two colors red and black.All it comes with is a micro-usb charge cable. Which is fine with me.*Performance*Just like the build quality the sound quality is top notch. I was pleasantly surprised by it. A lot of the cheaper bluetooth speakers of similar size sound thin and starts to distort when the volume is raised too high. The Taotronic has a very nice full sound with more bass than I was expecting. I don't think its been noticed but there seems to be two speakers in the unit! EDIT - conformed via Taotronics support. There is 2 speakers! One for highs and one for bass!One at the bottom facing up for the bass and a top speaker facing down for the highs. Please check the photos. I'll contact taotronics and find out.It has a built-in rechargeable battery. So far I've used it for about 5 hours and its still going strong on a relatively high volume.Connecting was breeze. Each subsequent connection is easy.I did try to use the phone mic feature and while it was good when speaking with 3ft; anything past that and its pretty useless.There is a aux 3.5mm jack if using an older mp3 player with no bluetooth.There is a toggle switch that has multiple uses. It can play the next song, previous song, stop and play. Holding it to the left will lower volume while holding it right will raise the volume.*Conclusion*The sound quality can not be beaten in the price range IMO. It will surprise you I believe. Don't expect it to outdo the larger bluetooth speakers that are 10 times the price.Note- I have been given a sample for a fair, unbiased review.

Looking for a cheap bluetooth keyboard that's portable, decent build quality for a low price? This keyboard just might be for you.*Build Quality*Pros:lightweightgood tactile feel when typinglow profile and portableCons:plastic not metalquite a bit of flex in the bodyhas some battery rattle when shaking the keyboardThe plastic isn't really a con when you consider its only 14 bucks.The battery rattle was fixed by simply sticking a piece of paper between the battery cover and the battery.*Performance*Connection is quite easy. You need to connect to it and it will prompt you to enter a pass code to connect. Each time you pair it a new pass code will be generated. Since a new pass code is needed each time, you need to "forget" the keyboard each time and refind it. The extra hassle is a cumbersome but I Don't use keyboards with my tablet too often.It types real well with no noticeable lag between pressing the key and it showing up on the screen.Not all the shortcut keys work on the Nexus 7. Than again I'm using ParanoidRom.*Conclusion*For the low price of 14 bucks, it seems like a no brain if you will casually use a keyboard for those rare moments you need to get serious work done on your tablet. If you're a weekend warrior that travels and do a lot of work on your tablet, another keyboard might be better.NOTE - I was supplied a sample for an honest review

Let's start off by saying I spend a LOT of time at my desk.  Doing paperwork, on the computer, listening to music and everything else.  And I never found a desk lamp that I really liked and always ended up going back to the main light in the room.  Until now that is.*Design/Build Quality*The design has a modern look, with clean sharp edges, simplistic and unobtrusive.  It has a great glossy black finish that goes well with most electronics.  It can be folded in a upon itself to take even less room.  When put in various positions, it never went out of position.  Meaning that the lamp didn't start drooping or sagging or shifting from the position I placed it in.  Which some lamps have a habit of doing.You can bend and position the lamp in almost any manner to get the best light for you.  It has 3 settings on light temperature.  The temp determines how white or yellow the light will be.  Which I like.  Some people prefer older halogen bulbs with a yellow tint and some prefer fluorescent white lighting.The brightness can also be adjusted.  Within each of the 3 preset light temps.  There's even a sleep timer button to automatically turn off.Last, a usb port for charging phones, mp3 players, tablets can be found on the base of the lamp.  Which is find really convenient.*Conclusion*For the money being saved in electricity, the convenience and features it has.  To me this buy is a no brainer.  Especially if you're like me and spend a lot of time at your desk.

So I have a lot of those universal Docks for tablets, phones and mp3 players that require a a 3.5mm jack.  And while the docks are good quality and nothing wrong with them, they aren't as convenient as a bluetooth dock.  I also have an A/V reciever that doesn't have a built in bluetooth module.  This little guy comes and saves that day!First,  Let's talk about accessories!  This guy has everything you would need to connect it to pretty much anything.  It's has a standard aux cable (3.5mm to 3.5mm headphone plugs), also a 3.5mm to rca to connect to A/V receivers.I can connect it to my reciever, unplug some connections, connect it to my car and not miss a step.Yes, the module doesn't automatically turn on bluetooth pairing mode when you turn on your car, AV receiver or whatever else you're trying to connect to But thats the trade off you get for not buying the equipment with bluetooth built in.  Even then, most of the time you have to turn on the bluetooth setting.For the convenience, build quality, and features.  I think it's a no brainer!

At first, I was skeptical on how useful the remote would be.  Boy was I pleasantly surprised how amazing it is!I've used other LED bulbs before but not ones with a remote control.*Build Quality*The bulbs are constructed very well.  It has a Heat sink, nothing was loose or flimsy.*Performance*First, this isn't an omnidirectional bulb.  It's not the conventional bulb where light shines everywhere but great for lamps that shine up or light fixtures that shine down.I placed them in corner lamps and hard to reach lamps.  Everyone has that lamp where its just seems out of the way and you placed them there because well; its out of the way.  It was just a pain having to turn it on/off.  With the remote I never have to go to the far corner of a room to turn on the lamp.  Which is just awesome!The bulbs can be adjusted on the brightness and "temp" of the light.  Provided pictures on how bright it can be and the "temp" can vary.The remote is pretty straight forward, both bulbs were already "connected" to remote.The remote control is very straight forward and easy to use****please see customer images***First, lets start by saying you can control all the bulbs "connected" to the remote or control each bulb individually.There is a center Ring.UP = increasing brightnessDown = decreasing brightnessLeft = decreasing tempright = decreasing tempAt the very top, there are two buttons "on" and "off.  Which would turn ALL bulbs connected to be on or off.Once you have turned on the "group of bulbs" you can adjust the brightness and temp of all bulbs in the group.At the bottom, you have individual controls for each bulb.Pressing the "on" button on "bulb 1" now gives you control on "bulb 1".You can change the brightness and temp of "bulb 1" individually while not changing other bulbs.Pressing the "on" button of "bulb 2" now gives you control of "bulb 2".Now you can change the settings of "bulb 2" while keeping the settings for all the other bulbs in the group.*conclusion*For the price; its hard to not recommend these bulbs due to the sheer convenience it brings!

After getting my Nexus 5 and getting spoiled with wireless charging, it was quite troublesome to charge via a usb cable when using my s3 as a secondary phone.  So I wanted to get a wireless receiver to go along with the Nexus 5.*PackagingNot much to talk about here, simple box containing the unit with a small plastic wrap inside.  No frills.*Build QualityThe receiving tag is very thin, I can't compare it to others but im guessing they are all comparable.  I had no problems putting the back cover on.  There wasn't a huge bulge were the tag is.  There is a slight bump but you would really have to be trying to feel for it to notice its even there.*PerformaceUsing my Ravpower Qi Charger it detected the tag instantly.  There wasn't any time where I had trouble with getting the S3 to start charging.  It didn't get any warmer than usual when charging with a usb cable.I have a Diztronic case on my S3 and it charged it just fine through the case.  I've tried other cases such as the ZooGue case had the same results.*ConclusionFor a mere 10 bucks, its sort of a no brainer for the convenience of wireless charging.  I been using it for over 2 weeks and never had a problem with it.

Build Quality/DesignLooking at it; it looks similar to their larger full size charger with their non-slip grey ring and glossy white top.  Playing with it in hand; I couldn't find anything loose and creeks when pulling/pushing on it.  It's fairly light weight, but not so much where it feels like a toy.  It has a good solid feel to it.Like it's bigger older brother, it doesn't have any non slip rubber feet at the bottom.  So it slides around fairly easily.  It's quite compact and intended to be a travel buddy especialy with its attached cord that wraps around the body for storage.  For those with a smaller work space/table/desk this is for you as its less than half the size of the full sized charger.It does have a charging indicator LED thats red when its not charging and Green when it is.Performance/TestingI could write down the numbers but lets just say it charged my Nexus 5 and Nexus 7 as fast as its full sized brother.Another thing, if you have a battery pack, you can attach it'll charge your phone through qi just fine.  I know I know, why not just connect the battery pack to the phone?  Well some people don't like connecting the the micro usb to often as it cant be damaged and doing so would eliminate that risk.ConclusionThis is a great little compact Qi charger that won't take that much space that works just as well as the bigger ful size chargers.

This book has a lot of good pieces to it and the premise is solid. There is one for each country in the world. These pages includes interesting facts and high quality pictures. So, why three stars and not four or five? Because some of the choices for focus really have me scratching me head! One example - using the limited space for the country of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines to include a picture of Johnny Depp as Jack Sparrow and including a short paragraph of Captain Jack Sparrow being marooned on the island twice. Really? There are also pictures of a couple honeymooning on the island - again, really? Instead of focusing on the actual people of the country we focus on tourists and movies? Letting kids know Rihananna is from Barbados is fine, but Johnny Depp - really? Another head scratcher is Brittany Spears being profiled on the pages for the country of Somalia! Why? Because Somali pirates were blasts by ships playing a Brittany Spears song by the Royal Navy. Really?

This book was really well done. Let's start reading level. This book will be independently readable for any child reading at the 4th grade level or higher. As far as content, I would put this in the tween/early teen category. I might not want my 8 year olds reading it, but it would make a good booklist for the 5th - 8th grade group.I don't want to give away too much of story, but the premise is bullying has consequences, not only for the bully - but for the person being bullied. The message is appropriate - find someone you trust that can help you get through the hard parts of life, of which bullying is unfortunately a part. I want to say if I put myself in the category of a very depressed tween/teen - this book might lead me to be even more depressed because at least these three kids (and one ghost kid) found their "tribe" and I might still feel all alone. So, this isn't a story to cheer up a child that currently needs counseling, but, it is a great book for kids that might be entering into the fray of very confusing emotions.All in all a good book. Not great, but definitely good.

I am a solid "medium" and normally wear a size 8 petite. I am 5 feet tall, so these pants were definitely too long. However, they aren't marketed as petite, so I didn't take any stars off for that. It is kind of weird, but while these pants fit - I felt "fat" in them. I know they are yoga pants, so I should be worried about working out rather than looking good - but I really hated the way I looked in these pants.I roll down portion at the top worked, but it might get annoying after a while. The material felt absolutely wonderful - very soft against the skin. If I didn't feel like a fat blog in the pants, I would wear them all day. I guess the reason why I was so taken aback by how I felt in the pants was that I recently actually lost 16 pounds and almost 20 inches, including 8 inches from my waist. My waist is now in the "healthy" range. I had been pulling on everything in my closet and going to the store feeling like a rock star - even in yoga pants type of clothing. So, I am not sure what it is about the cut of these pants the pulls out every hideous feature left for me to overcome. I may also be that because I am so short, I need a pant made just for petite women.

Another great project from Playmobil. The kit has 68 pieces total. Another thing that I really like about this toy is the attention to details. There are so many intricate pieces that help to make the vehicle very interactive. While this is a themed toy, it works even if kids aren't really into the show, we had never seen the show, but the kids were still really interested in the vehicle.I will say that playmobil pieces are very small, so I would not recommend this to people with little ones in the house. Stick with the age recommendation of 5+, because there are a number of small pieces that would be chocking hazards for toddlers.The reason for 4 instead of 5 stars is definitely the size. Some pieces are so small that I know if dropped they will be gone forever as they would not be found and would be vacuumed up with ease (never to be found again). Overall a really neat toy.

This kit was really well done and fun to use. The favorite activity was growing the crystal tree - it actually got amazingly big. Is started to grow within a few hours, but reached full bloom after a couple of days. The crystals started to fall off after about 5 days which was also neat, kind of mimicking the thawing of a tree in winter (the crystals grew white).This would be a great hands on activity for a history unit or just a fun toy to pass the time on a weekend. The included wooly mammoth is very real to life in details.

I am really frustrated with this kit because it was so close to being perfect, but the things that were wrong made me so angry I took off 2 stars. Let me start by saying the kit is well made, the pieces are great, they are really good quality wood. The kit comes with a nice book on Modern and Post-Modern Architecture. This is where the first start was deducted. While the booklet introduces kids to many styles of architecture and gives really neat details, there are only plans for building 2 styles with the pieces in the kit! Why show kids all these neat forms of architecture with no instruction on how to take this pile of blocks to these beautiful designs? Yes, blocks should encourage free play. However, there is also something to be said for being able to duplicate a beautiful design.Included in the kit is a packet for "ArchiQuest University" and where the kit lost yet another star. Why? You are supposed to go to a website where you can become enrolled in a "University" and master different levels of architecture knowledge. You can earn the levels of apprentice, mason, master mason, architect, and master architect. Why did I take off the star? There is supposed to be a student I.D. number on the card so you can get access to the university. Well, guess what? Where the number "should" have been stamped was blank!!!! Now, this made me particularly angry because my 8 year old son really has a strong interest in architecture. He is currently taking a beginner's course and this would have been a great supplement. We were both so excited for him to start this journey we could hardly contain ourselves. Then we sat there looking at a blank spot where the I.D. number "should" have been. I went to the website anyway and while there is a lot of good general information on the card, yup - no access to the information for the "university" without a student I.D. number. So, learning about fascinating history of architecture, its language, secret symbols, and incredible feats of engineering. Using you knowledge and building and an amazing 3-D program, creating and building your own architectural structures. And on, and on, and on with all the really neat, really cool, really amazing things that can be done to take this kit from a pile of blocks to true architecture - gone, because someone forgot to actually print an I.D. number on the card!!!

This is a great little kit to allow a kid an opportunity to explore CSI work. You get to solve 3 crimes using various methods, including reading fingerprints. This kit was an absolute blast - just enough to introduce kids to the real work of crime scene investigators, but still feeling like fun and not like school. Definitely recommend for the 8 - 12 year old age category.

This kit ended up being really fun for a rainy day. The great thing is that all of the experiments worked! The major experiments are: Balancing Nail Puzzle, Salt and Marble Challenge, Balloon in a Bottle. For each experiment there is a "take it further" challenge that helps you get to the 9 "experiences". The reason why I gave 4 instead of 5 stars is because I thought the explanations for why things worked they way they worked.

Let me start by saying I did not use this headphone set for gaming purposes, I used it in an online classroom setting. Granted, one class was actively using Minecraft, but still nothing close to using the headset for Halo or another type of intensive gaming experience.I will compare these headphones with another high quality headphone set, Logitech and found they are similar in quality. The headset is comfortable and can be used for children as well as adults (used with an 8 year old boy and an 8 year old girl). Sound came through clearly and evenly. There are a lot of options with these headphones, but the use isn't intuitive for first timers like myself. There is a quick guide that comes with the headphones with separate instructions for PS4, Xbox One, and PC/Mac use.I used the headphones with a Mac. You will be plugging the headphones into the amplifier, then plugging the amplifier into the Mac for charging. All of the cables needed for the Mac were included.The sound is crisp and the headphones are comfortable. However, they are also a bit heavy and I for me I can't imagine long term use. However, true gamers may be used to this weight for quality and might not mind. I actually liked the padded covering on the mic, it didn't affect the output and I think it is great when things get intense - especially for a braces wearing 8 year old who got a little excited in Minecraft and bumped the mic with her mouth - padding equals no broken braces components.The headphones are supposed to be able to be used for 30 hours on a single charge, I have tested this with 30 hours of use just yet. The virtual surround sound was pretty awesome and definitely something my Logitect headphones couldn't deliver.All in all I think these are great. Might be a bit of overkill for the none gamer, but it may just transform a none gamer into a gamer because these things really do make you feel like you are "in" the action

The charger has worked perfectly for me with no problems. I have used it to charge my iPad on several occasions. I truly love the longer cord. I keep this cord with me as a backup so I don't have to take my factory charger from the house when traveling. I also like that it is black, easy to sport.  I have had some non-Apple chargers that didn't seem to work very well, but this one truly works perfectly. I haven't had any issues - it charges as effectively of the factory charger that came with it.

I received a Tea Beyond flowering pot as well as a 12 pack of the Fab Flowering Blooms Tea in exchange for an honest review.I'll be honest, I'm I'm not a huge tea connoisseur and have never tried a product like this before, so if you are someone who drinks tea often and/or have tried many different kinds of flowering teas, then my review probably won't be helpful to you. But if you are someone who was enticed by trying something new, and the beautiful presentation of the product, then this is the review for you.The pot itself is beautiful and is nicely put together so that the bloom fits in the inner chamber while the water can defuse out to the rest of the pot. You can also refill the pot to make more tea from one flower.I love the fact that not only is it easy to do, but it's really aesthetically pleasing. You put the bloom in the inner chamber, fill it with boiling water, and watch it bloom. It unfolds in less than a minute and the color of the water becomes a nice amber color. That part itself was entertaining, to be able to see the flower spread in the water, not to mention beautiful.Then the tea itself has a wonderful subtle flavor, tasting of flower and delicate nature. I really enjoyed it and drank several cups in one sitting.I'm definitely thinking of purchasing this for friends for a fun gift for a birthday or Christmas. Great product!

I received a Tea Beyond flowering pot as well as a 12 pack of the Fab Flowering Blooms Tea in exchange for an honest review.I'll be honest, I'm I'm not a huge tea connoisseur and have never tried a product like this before, so if you are someone who drinks tea often and/or have tried many different kinds of flowering teas, then my review probably won't be helpful to you. But if you are someone who was enticed by trying something new, and the beautiful presentation of the product, then this is the review for you.The pot itself is beautiful and is nicely put together so that the bloom fits in the inner chamber while the water can defuse out to the rest of the pot. I was given this book from the author in exchange for an honest review.Monster Boy by Ruth Sinclair is a refreshing indie middle grade read. I have been sent several indie reads by authors recently and was starting to feel disheartened by the quality of work I had been given. But then Sinclair, who had written the wonderful City of Silver Light, approached me, and I knew I had to give her book a try. And I'm delighted to say that I had a big smile on my face even after the first few pages.Monster Boy stars Zach, who seems to have an ideal middle class life-- he is an only child with parents who adore him, he gets treats whenever he wants, and let's face it, he's pretty spoiled. He goes to school where he's not super popular, but has a best friend Ryder who is a loyal sidekick. The way the first few pages read, it feels like he's almost Dudley Dursley from the Harry Potter series, but gets to star in his own book. But soon, his world gets turned on its head. The town lies adjacent to a town full of foul smelling gas and monsters, only separated by a wall. The mayor decides to tear down part of the wall in a Grand Gesture, but realizes quickly that this is a mistake. Meanwhile, Zach's parents decide they want to adopt a new child, and this is Morton, a monster boy that has come over from the other side and has been placed in an orphanage, and in a sinister turn of events, children in Zach's town start to go missing. Will Zach be able to overcome his jealousy for Morton and be able to figure out what's going on in his town?There is so much more depth in this book than I can do justice to in a few lines of synopsis. I love how the parents play such a pivotal role in this book and serve as such good role models for tolerance and standing up for what's right. I also love Zach's character development throughout the book as he realizes that maybe his preconceptions of what "monster" mean aren't right at all. Morton himself is a complex character that intrigued me and has his own arc. The writing is completely delightful and is reminiscent of the style of JK Rowling or E. Nesbitt in the way that it starts off-- the mayor being kind of a foppish caricature, and even Zach as well. But the whole book takes on a whole new level after the halfway point. The end has a series of twists that completely threw me off guard in the best way possible, and ended in the only way it should have.My only concerns is that this book is extremely long, but it does a lot in the space it has. Sometimes the pacing gets dragged down in the middle, but never enough for me to put the book down for good. I always wanted to come back to it and see what happens to Morton and Zach.Overall, a wonderfully written indie MG fantasy that has wonderful lessons about tolerance, growing up, and the importance of family and friendship.

These compression socks really work and they have been very durable so far going through several washes in the machine. They are about as comfortable as compressions socks can get, and the nude color makes them practically invisible, which is nice. Because they are thick stockings, they do get hot in the summer, but I don't know how that would be avoided. Because of the socks, I can fit into my shoes and get through the day with my feet a pretty normal size. It usually helps with pain in my feet as well from the swelling on most days. I would highly recommend these socks.

I was very excited when I received this product. The pattern and color are very flattering and while I haven't used it for nursing yet, I can see how it can be very accessible for nursing. Not only that, but it's super comfortable, and I've been using it to wear around the house. I haven't had any clothes that aren't constricting that I can wear around the house without feeling like a complete hippo, so this was a huge relief. I want to get the same dress in another pattern.

I was looking for slippers that would support my flat arches as well as could be worn out to a nice dinner. These fit all of those criteria. Several people have complimented me on how cute they are. In addition to that, I've worn them to work and been on my feet all day, and they wear similar to tennis shoes-- super comfy and cushiony. Even though my feet are generally tired at the end of the day, these shoes really make a difference from even just straight flip flops. If you are looking for something cute as well as comfortable, get these right away!

I ordered this dress initially in large. I received it and was really excited because the style is super cute with sleeves, which is really hard to find, in addition to it being for nursing, which obviously is great. But for some reason there is a weird puckering on my body on both sides with the pleat they have sown in and it also flares off my body on my backside, which is really unflattering and makes me look lopsided. On the model in the picture for Amazon, you see that it fits perfectly, but I would have to safety pin either side to make it look flattering like the picture, and the thought of spending the money to just have to alter or "fix" it each time didn't make sense. I liked it enough to order it in medium to see if that would solve the problem, but it didn't. All this said, returning the item has been super easy, and I really appreciate that service. I've already received a refund on the first dress.

I really enjoyed the Testing, the first book in this trilogy because of the fast paced plotting, the great protagonist, and the puzzles she has to go through.The second has Cia at the University being tested in other ways. She doesn't remember anything that happened during the Testing, but she knows it wasn't good. While she struggles with that, she has to do everything in her power to get through the extensive hazing in her group to score the best internship and avoid being kicked out of University. As usual, secrets pile upon secrets, and it's up to Cia to figure out what's going on before it's too late.Like the first book, this isn't a perfect book-- the writing is not polished and Cia does seem a bit too perfect as a protagonist. She thinks of everything and there are no negative consequences to her decisions because she always makes the right one. That said, there's something so addictive about these books. I can't put them down once I start reading because the puzzles that Cia goes through are fascinating, and I'm a sucker for puzzles. These are clearly Charbonneau's strength. Don't expect a compelling romance between her and Tomas. It's never been the strong point of these books, and Charbonneau herself says that she's not good with romance. It didn't bother me though because the rest of her book is so compelling.Overall, a strong sequel to the first installment, and this had me eagerly awaiting the final book in the trilogy.

I received a copy from the author in exchange for an honest review. Thanks!Dirty Little Secret by Jennifer Echols is the first book I've read by this author, but she's been on my to read list for a while now! This book stars Bailey, a girl who has grown up with music-- in fact, her whole family has been in the country music business. The problem is-- she was a duo with her sister, but her sister made it big and she hasn't. Now she's stuck behind while her sister is touring and has been told by her parents that she can't play music. Of any kind. This all changes when she meets a boy, Sam, who wants her to join his band. She can't resist him or playing the fiddle with his band. Will Bailey be able to figure out what she wants for herself and stop lingering in anger in her sister's shadow?There were so many things about this book I loved. Highest on the list was the authenticity of Bailey in her music groups. Every time I read a description, I almost shouted, "YES!" I also have perfect pitch, and the way Bailey described it, was absolutely true. It's almost a curse and painful when you hear an off note. I loved all the scenes with the band, but probably my absolute favorite part was the end, when Bailey's sister comes back into the picture and we see some interactions with her family. The prose is well written, and I definitely am going to pick up more of Echols books!I have two main issues with this book. One was the decision about how her relationship with Sam would go. I totally get this, but it was hard for me to like him as a love interest. But actually, this was not the problem, as it was pretty realistic as to how it all played out-- I just wish that Bailey reacted a bit differently to the situation. Secondly, I didn't understand what was going on with her parents AT ALL. I wanted to know more about her relationship with her parents separately and most of all, her sister. They are absent except for her remembering the past until the very end and at that point, it's almost too late to make an impact because we don't understand their relationship at all. I think part of the problem is that what Bailey did to ostracize herself was held back as an eventual reveal, but I didn't think it was too much of a twist. In fact, the magnitude of it was so small, that it made her parents seem like actual villains. I don't think they are, and I'm not sure Echols actually intended it that way.Overall, a beautifully written read with very authentic scenes in music and a terrific main character!

I award this book 4.5 stars.I really enjoyed the first two books in this trilogy and this last installment doesn't disappoint. Ludaina is on the brink of war and Charlie has to go on a harrowing journey to try to stop it from happening. Once again Charlie doesn't trust Max, which rubs me the wrong way. But he forgives her, so I try to do the same. That said, the rest of the book is so flipping good that I quickly forget about that fact. The pacing is great, the characters are solid, and the conclusion is satisfying. This is one rare trilogy that will stay on my shelf. It's a must read, go get it now!

I really enjoyed The Pledge a while back, and knew I had to get my hands on the sequel. The Essence takes place right where the Pledge ends. We quickly learn that Charlie didn't come out of the Pledge as unscathed as we thought. We quickly get sucked into Charlie's new life as queen. Traitors are in their midst and Charlie has to maneuver through treacherous waters.I really enjoyed this installment-- once again, Derting has wonderful writing that kept me captivated with good pacing. The characters are intriguing, and Charlie is likeable, even though she seems a little too willing to play the martyr. The biggest issue that I had was the fact that Charlie isn't honest with Max about the presence of Sabara. And this is one of the biggest plot points in the book. This decision just didn't make any sense to me-- doesn't she trust him?Other than that, however, it's a fun read that kept me engaged and wanting to figure out how Charlie was going to get out of her sticky situation. I definitely wanted to read the final installment after I finished this one!

I bought this book at a Dark Days signing because Kimberly Derting's introduction of the book really piqued my interest-- plus, I really love her entire Pledge trilogy! So I knew I had to get my hands on it. Man, I'm glad I did because it's my current favorite of her works.The Taking by Kimberly Derting stars Kyra, who at the beginning of the book just won a key softball game. But while on the way home, arguing with her dad about going off to college with her longtime boyfriend instead of pursuing her own dreams, she leaves the car and suddenly in the flash of bright light, she's 5 years later in the future. Everything has changed. Her parents are no longer together, her father's been chasing aliens ever since she left, and now her mom has remarried and had a new kid. Kyra can't remember a thing about the past 5 years, and honestly, she feel exactly as if the softball game was yesterday. Then, there's the matter of the boy next door... Will Kyra be able to sort things out before it's too late?I loved this book so much. It's fast paced from the opening of the first chapters. You may think I spoiled you a lot, but all of this happens in the first chapter and a half. And it doesn't slow down one iota from there. Derting has lovely prose and she puts it to good use here. And then the relationship with Tyler. There are issues with it, sure, and I am doubtful that no one in her life would be weirded out by it-- but when they are together in the book, I forget about all of that (and so does Kyra), and sparks fly. I don't think I've had a true book boyfriend before, but this guy... yeah. He's the one :-)I thought Derting handled the characters really well, and their reactions to all the events made a lot of sense. She combines some sci fi and paranormal elements to the story, and it doesn't distract but adds to the story. The book feels like a complete first chapter, but it does end in a cliffhanger unfortunately, because now I'm dying to get my hands on the next one.Overall, a must read, paranormal YA which will keep you simultaneously swooning and on the edge of your seat as you race to the finish!

There's just something about Emmy Laybourne and the way she writes. I don't even know if there was really the typical formula of the inciting event, climax, etc. I just know that she writes in a pulse pounding kind of way, a way in which I can't put down her books.I loved the first one, which some people say doesn't have a plot. I see what they are saying, but it's such a window into a psychologically tense situation that I didn't care-- I stayed up late into the night reading it. The second I still enjoyed but not as much because the world suddenly got really big and we lost some of the claustrophobia that made the first book so good. This final book takes the best of both books and gives us an ending we'll never forget.I was really satisfied with the ending and the alternating perspectives of Dean and... well, I won't tell you who the other person is, because in a way, it's a spoiler. Just know that this third and final installment doesn't disappoint.Overall, a terrific and harrowing ending to the Monument 14, and becomes one of the rare trilogies that works as a whole. Pick it up.

I've only read a few books by Kelley Armstrong, but this high fantasy seemed right up my alley.Sea of Shadows stars two twin girls, Moria and Ashyn who have been destined since birth to be Keeper and Seeker of their town. They each have an animal companion as well. The story alternates between their perspectives in third person. Something horrible happens that separates them near the beginning of the story, after Ashyn's trek into the Forest of the Dead, and during their journey back together, sinister and fantastical things continue to happen. Will they find their way back together and piece together what has happened to their town?I thought this book was well written, and honestly, I've liked it better than the other books I've read by Armstrong. Her craft has definitely improved. Of the two girls, I liked Moria more, because Ashyn comes off a little too dainty and hesitant, and just plain naive. I guess I was a bit surprised at that because you'd think that Moria would have educated her a bit better! I liked their animal companions, and the two love interests were passable. The pace was a bit slow for me, but the writing and plot were solid and kept me going. I'm definitely going to pick up the next installment as I'd like to see where she's taking this.Overall, a solid start to a fantasy with some intriguing characters and plot points.

I just finished reading The Archived, another one of Schwab's books, and knew I had to pick up Vicious, which has been on the favorite book of the year list for many of my fellow bloggers. They were right.Vicious by V.E. Schwab is told mostly from the perspective of Victor, who was college best friends with Eli. Victor and Eli dabbled in finding out why some people were E.O. (ExtraOrdinary) with out of this world paranormal powers. Quickly, they discover that near death experiences are important to this, and Eli and Victor cross ethical boundaries in order to find out more.It's so difficult to distill this book into a few synopsis sentences because the book jumps from past to present and back again. Victor is now much older, having had just gotten out of prison, and he's determined to find Eli and kill him. There are secrets upon secrets that hang in the balance, and each is revealed in its due time.The book is dark, twisted, and fabulous in so many ways. Every single character in this book is neither totally good or bad. They actually might all be called villains in some sense of the word. Each of them has reasons for doing what they are doing. You have one character who is doing the "right" things for the completely wrong reasons. You have a character doing the wrong thing to try to do the right thing, and you have others who drift along for the ride because they aren't sure what to do. It's such a clever foray into the realm of the anti-hero, and you can't put the book down until you see it out to its ending.Overall, a thrilling ride that makes you question what makes a hero and is a pitch perfect portrayal of insight into the blurred lines of gray between right and wrong. It's a must read.

I won this book in a giveaway.I've been very interested in reading this book for a while because the premise seemed so intriguing to me. The book is focused on the perspective of Parker, who can't get a good night of sleep because he also gets sucked into the dreams of the person he's looked straight in the eye last in the day. Something about being actively in someone else's dreams prevents him from getting enough sleep. As you might imagine, this causes havoc in his daily life and it becomes clear that he's going to die if he doesn't figure a way out of his situation. There's a new girl at school who he looks at and realizes that night that he is able to sleep within her dreams because they are so simple and straightforward. This leads to him having to stalk her to prevent his own death but then realizes that she is getting death threats from someone else, but when Parker realizes that he doesn't remember everything during the day...maybe... just maybe, it's him.It's definitely a good premise, and I like the idea behind the story. But even though it's understandable how desperate Parker is to stay alive and the fact he'll do anything to stay alive, the stalkerish nature of how he's following this girl all the time is just too creepy. I'm not sure how it could have happened differently, but it made it hard to like Parker as a protagonist. He did redeem himself in the last 20% of the book, but I just couldn't reconcile how he was at the beginning with how he was at the end. However, the end was interesting, so I do think I'd like to see how this will play out in PARANOIA the next book.Overall, interesting premise with some great side characters, but the protagonist was at times difficult to like and his actions hard to get over.

I actually tried to read this book one time before, but couldn't get into it. I thought it was because I wasn't actually in the mood to read at the time, and that is probably a factor for sure. But The Forest of Hands and Teeth is undoubtedly beautifully written with some terrific turn of phrase, and it's clear to me that Carrie Ryan can write. That said, this book just didn't affect me the way I hoped it would. I award this book 2.5 stars.The Forest of Hands and Teeth by Carrie Ryan is about a zombie apocalypse although the word "zombie" is never uttered in the book. Mary, the main character, is in bad straits-- she lives in this awful world, her father is missing and likely dead, her mother has lost her mind in grief and gets bitten in the first chapter, her brother pretty much disowns her, and the boy she loves gets engaged to her best friend. Now because no one has spoken for her, including Harry, the brother of Travis, her true love, she is destined to be cloistered away in a convent for the rest of her life. OK so this is the gloomy beginning of her story, and I don't blame her for wanting to run away.But the book, while eloquently written, drags. We get stuck in limbo for a long time. There's action no doubt, but I'm not sure that Mary herself really changes much. I feel like how she is at the beginning (rebellious and selfish), is how she is at the end (rebellious and selfish). She doesn't really care about anyone or anything except herself, and while I get it (see above), it doesn't make me like her that much or want to root for her. There are several moments where I think she'll be bitten, and I'm ok with it. Mary has this preoccupation with the sea after her mom has talked about it her entire life. And she's determined to find it no matter who gets killed along the way. While Mary isn't the most likeable character, I don't really like any of the rest of the cast either. They include a whiny best friend, a guy who loves her and is determined to have her even if it makes everyone else miserable, a brother who has been crappy to her and then suddenly expects compassion, and a wishy washy love interest that doesn't communicate. I had to flip quickly to the end to see what happens, and if it's at all possible, I was more disappointed than I thought I could have been.Overall, a lackluster book with beautiful writing, but unlikeable characters and a dragging plot without any growth in the characters or plot twists. I would look elsewhere.

I've had this on my TBR list for quite some time now, and now that the companion novel is coming out soon, I knew I'd better read this one first. I was completely floored by this book and emotionally spent.Not a Drop to Drink is a tough dystopian YA read about Lynn, who defends her little house and the pond, the source of their water, with her mother. They have tough days purifying their water to protect themselves from cholera and other waterbourne diseases that have been plaguing the rest of the country. From the first pages, we get the immediate sense that Lynn has been taught to shoot trespassers on sight, no questions asked. It's a harsh world, and Lynn knows that their water supply is a precious resource that is worth killing for. But tragedy occurs, and Lynn has to adapt her life in ways she never imagined. She has to be able to trust strangers, and try to change her very black and white mode of thinking. When a little girl, Lucy, comes into her life, everything changes.I know a lot of people thought this book drags a lot in the beginning, but honestly, the way it was written, I was hooked from the start. It almost reads like one of those old Westerns you see, but with tough women being at the heart. Lynn is a great protagonist, and her character development is gradual but totally believable. The description is beautiful, and the story is haunting and emotionally devastating. I thought the pace was perfect and as more is revealed in her little world, each step is deliberate and perfectly placed. The side characters were also really wonderful, especially her next door neighbor and the spunky little Lucy. By the end, you want Lynn to protect her new little family just as much as she does. The choices she has to make and the events that unfold in the last 100 pages just made my heart clench and I know this story will stay with me for days.Overall, a beautifully written and believable dystopian YA that will drain you emotionally, but will be worth the ride, because it really is that good.

I've loved both The Archived and Vicious, so I knew I had to get my hands on The Unbound as soon as I could. It was absolutely fabulous like its predecessors.We return to the story and reunite with the protagonist Mackenzie, who is still on thin ice with the Archive, and her sexy love interest and partner in crime Wes. But the first thing she has to tackle is... her new school. And it sounds totally cliche, but I really enjoyed all of the scenes at her school, because there's a nice balance between the paranormal and the normal. We get introduced to another possible love interest, Cash, as well as other interesting side characters. At the same time, people that Mac has been interacting with suddenly start disappearing and she's the only link between the missing people. Not to mention she's been having blackouts where she is missing time. Can Mac figure out what's going on before she loses both of her lives at the Archive and at home?I love love loved this book. I possibly loved it more than the Archived because there is so much more at stake, and new great characters. The writing is gorgeous as always, and the pacing superb. I literally couldn't put it down and stayed up two nights reading it instead of sleeping like I should have been! I love the world building, and how we learn more about the structure of the Archive. I do have a soft spot for Cash (I totally would have crushed on him myself!), but Wes is a much better fit for Mac. You'll see who she picks.Overall, a superb second entry in the Archived series. There's much more to explore so I wouldn't be surprised if there is another installment when Mac becomes Crew. That said, these two can stand alone as a duology, and will entice readers for years to come.

I had mixed feelings about the first book, Sweet Evil, because the protagonist was a bit too sweet and perfect. But I'm glad I made it through because in the last 20% things got more interesting, so I figured I'd pick up the second when I got a chance.Sweet Peril starts a bit after Sweet Evil. Big events have happened at the end of the last book and because of them Anna and Kaidan have been torn apart. We get to learn more about Kopano and what Anna might play in the future fight between good and evil. But will she be able to fight her undeniable attraction to Kaiden and fight against her own temptations to achieve what she needs to?I enjoyed this installment a lot more than its predecessor. Anna has more edge, has to deal with the fact that she has her own temptations, and that a lot of the world is shades of grey not black and white like she initially thought. We learn more about each of the characters, and I ended up liking Kaidan a lot more in this book as well. I really love the twins in London, who we see occasionally, and some new characters are intriguing. The middle of the book drags a bit, but we get enough character development to keep my interest. I really need to get my hands on the last book!

I won this ARC from a blog giveaway, thanks! This has probably been my favorite read in the past few weeks, but I couldn't give it five stars for issues that I couldn't ignore.The Testing by Joelle Charbonneau has been on my list to read for a long time. It's been compared to the Hunger Games, and stars Cia, who is in one of the colonies who have not had any candidates selected for The Testing in a long time. The Testing has been put in place after war has devastated the world to find the best candidate leaders of the country to go to University. No one in Cia's town knows much about The Testing except for her own father, who refuses to speak about it. Cia is chosen with three other people in her class, and she starts a difficult and treacherous journey where either death or glory can await.I admit I was really into this book. Cia is a great main character-- she's humble, gracious, and has a good heart. But at the same time, she is super intelligent and has obviously been trained well by both her school and her father. Other reviewers have mentioned that she may be too perfect, at least in the sense of being able to do things and always being right for the most part, at least about her instincts on traps and puzzles. I agree. It would have been nice to see other characters contribute as well. They obviously were smart enough to get there.Some reviewers were upset with how "boring" the testing part was, but actually, I loved that part. I really enjoyed  the section where Cia figures out something key that allows her to pass to the next test and thought it was pretty clever. The test revealed something about several of the characters. I did think it was odd that even though her father gave her the warning not to trust anyone, she seems to have developed a sixth sense suspicion, which seems almost too good to be true. I also liked the descriptions of the other tests. It shows what kinds of things Cia is good at before she gets tested further in the third portion of the test.The journey Cia takes with her love interest, Tomas, from thereon out was gripping, and I wanted to know what each of the characters were hiding. I was definitely surprised by some of the outcomes. This was the first book in a while that I was contemplating buying the next book on Kindle immediately to see what happens next.That said, other than the issues I alluded to above, there were a couple of other problems. I agree with others that the love connection between Cia and Tomas seems kind of quick and unbelievable. There are "hints" to the past, about looking longingly at each other during a dance, but we never see that, so we never really feel for them and root for them. And lastly, the world building isn't perfect. I definitely don't get why people have to die during the Testing. And what happens to the people who fail? It isn't clear what happens to them-- but I feel like the book hints to them being executed. It seems to me that people that put their own gain above the needs for others (meaning people who kill to "win") would probably not make very good leaders, but hey, that's me. Hopefully, more world building will be revealed in the next book.Overall, there are definite similarities between this book and The Hunger Games, and probably has been in somewhat inspired by that trilogy, but I believe it stands on its own. I don't know if it's because I haven't read a dystopian in a while (I burned myself out like many other reviewers and then took a long break), or what, but I really like the "test" aspect to the whole thing, which was definitely lacking in The Hunger Games, which it should, since that wasn't the focus.I think this was a great first novel in the trilogy, and Charbonneau definitely has a talent at keeping us on our toes and glued to the page. Even though I have 20 more books to get through, I may just take a break from my reading list and pick up the second today.

I was given this book by the author in exchange for an honest review.Isabella Rockwell's War by Hannah Parry stars Isabella who is a courageous twelve year old in a bad position. She lives in India but because of terrible circumstances, she is forced to leave by herself to go to England, a cold, harsh place she's never known. Her choices as she arrives are thus: either become a street runaway and have independence or stick around and be sent to an orphanage where she'd work as a servant. She decides to run away and the group of kids she meets and a beautiful girl she saves changes her life forever.I admit that I got behind on my reading and so I didn't pick up this book until a few days ago. I'm hitting myself, because this is one of the gems in the self publishing world. The tone of the book reminds me of a mix of The Secret Garden and The Little Princess. It's been a while since I read a middle grade book, but this is one that doesn't dumb down the story for its readers. The pacing is great, and I really liked Isabella as a protagonist, who carries the story with her spunkiness. The twists are great too-- I definitely didn't suspect the right person!The only thing I would suggest is having us meet Alix a little quicker since she is even mentioned in the synopsis. Otherwise, I think this is a very strong debut.Overall, a really great middle grade read that I'll definitely suggest to that age group to read.

I received an ARC in a contest giving away books.Truth or Dare was a pleasant surprise after reading some disappointing books prior to it. I usually don't like more than alternating POV's but Green does a great job getting us into the heads of three very different girls: Sydney, the artsy photographer, with a deadly secret, Caitlin, a pretty and popular but sweet girl who is buckling under pressure to get into Harvard, and Tenley, the mean girl who left town and is back to reclaim her throne. Soon, we realize that someone is playing a very nasty trick on these three girls and somehow, they are connected in ways we don't know. Will they figure out who is playing them before it's too late?I loved the prose in this novel. Usually in books like these that sort of represent the Christopher Pike genre back in the day are not very well written (i.e. the recent Ten), and I can barely get through them. But this book is very well written, and every description is meaningful, every word is on purpose. The plot is very fast paced, and while I figured out who the trickster is about 25% in, I didn't really care because I wanted to find out what happened to the girls, and there are plenty of other mysteries that need to be solved on the sidelines. It was really worth the ride. I started to care or at least be interested in each of the characters and their many secrets and was definitely surprised by many of them.So you are probably asking now, so why only 4 stars? Honestly, I totally would have given in 5 except for the really big fact that this is the FIRST BOOK IN A TRILOGY. I feel like the remaining mysteries could have been resolved pretty easily in the first and made this an extremely strong stand alone. Instead, this story is going to be dragged out for two more books? Of similar length? (this isn't a short book). I can't say that I'm that excited to pick up the next one, although Green is undoubtedly talented, but I think this was not the right move.Overall, a well written, gripping, intense ride in three points of views-- you'll want to pick this one up. But just beware, it's the first in a trilogy.

I received an ARC of this book from a friend who was passing it along (which I will also do to pass along good will!).Dualed by Elsie Chapman stars West Grayer, who is part of a dystopian civilization where every child is born with a twin, but the two twins are raised in different families. At a certain point, they are activated and have 30 days to kill their Alt. This way the hardiest and most killer like people survive in case there is need for an army. Something tragic happens to West (honestly, in a world where tragedy is a norm), and she decides to take matters in her own hands and take on a dangerous job while she's waiting. When she finally gets activated, will she be able to kill someone who looks just like her?First, the prose is solid and the plot fast paced. I liked the idea behind the story, and I liked West enough to stay in the story. I read the whole book in a couple of hours, so that was no problem.But when I reached the end, I just felt... disappointed. I thought there would be more twists. There aren't. The world building, while the initial idea is interesting, just falls apart with holes you could drive a car through. Another reviewer very aptly asked why an Alt couldn't just find out where the other Alt lived and gather data for years before activation even starts? I don't get a good grasp on West, and she makes some decisions that I cannot fathom.MINOR SPOILER: So it's ok to kill other people but just not someone that looks like you?Really? And there are some plot reveals that happen near the end with her Alt that also make no sense to me from what was described earlier on. I just couldn't get behind it.Oddly enough though, I was entertained, so I would totally pick up the next book at the library to give it a shot and see what Chapman has up her sleeve next.Overall, a fast paced first novel with an intriguing premise, but has shoddy world building and character development.

I received this book from the Goodreads First Reads book giveaway, thanks!Dangerous by Shannon Hale is the first book I've read by her. I've heard great things about her Princess Academy and the Goose Girl books, and this apparently is a pretty big divergence from those books. We are introduced to Maisie Danger Brown who is a genius and is the kid of two very bright scientists and is homeschooled. She wins a prize to go to a smart kid camp with one of the greatest scientists in the world. At the camp, she meets a sexy guy, and friends that understand who she is (other than her best friend at home, Luther). But quickly, after a space trip goes awry, Maisie realizes that she's gotten more than she's bargained for at this camp.I'm going to remain vague at this point so the reader can discover the book's secrets for themselves. The premise was pretty entertaining and the plot fast paced. Probably out of all of the characters, I liked Maisie's parents the best. I love that we have a YA book where the parents are still alive and obviously love their kid very much, so I appreciated that.I had a ton of issues with this book, however. The prose is extremely choppy. I'm not sure if that's just Hale's writing style in general, but all of the sentences are short to the point that it was very obvious after a few pages. The characters are not well drawn out so I didn't feel that connected to any of them. The head scientist was supposed to be quirky and maybe on the autistic spectrum, but just ended up being weird to me. And everything just seemed way over the top, and as the pages were turned, the body count piled up, as if there was nothing wrong with that. No one really cared when people died in this book, so that made me less willing to care. The love story between Maisie and other kid was not that convincing and it made her look wishy washy as a character to keep oscillating in her feelings for him. To me, he wasn't that great.Overall, fast paced adventure, but I would not rank this in my favorites of the YA sci fi genre, and the characters are pretty lackluster.

I absolutely loved AG Howard's debut novel, Splintered, last year, so I had to get my hands on this beautiful second installment, Unhinged, as soon as it came out. The covers of both books are gorgeous, are they not?Unhinged by AG Howard picks up several months where Splintered left off. Alyssa is struggling with her relationship with Jeb, who seems more interested in starting a career than spending time with her. Plus, he doesn't remember any of their adventures in Wonderland, and Alyssa is wondering if she should tell him. Unsurprisingly, Morpheus shows up in her dreams again and in the living flesh to shake things up. To make things more tricky and interesting, we learn new things about her parents and their relationship, which clarify a lot of things and put a new spin on some of the events that happened in the last book. Will Alyssa be able to navigate her feelings about Jeb, Morpheus, and her parents and save Wonderland again from eminent danger?I have said this before about trilogies. Second books are hard. They just are. Even if you have a kickbutt heroine, there still has to be character growth (or more likely, setbacks) in the second, so that in the third, she can rise to the occasion and show everyone just how far she's come. Alyssa is not as likeable in this installment, but understandably so, because her world has completely turned upside down. She doesn't know who she is, and it doesn't help that she's split between two worlds and two men that are different as night and day. All of her personal relationships have just (for lack of a better word), "splintered," and she has to pick up the pieces and see where she fits into each of their lives and how they fit into hers. She regains some of her momentum by the end, as she should. Jeb and Morpheus are still smouldering as her leading men, but while I've always loved Morpheus, I thought they ended on rather even footing in the last book. This book I feel is essentially Morpheus' book, as we learn more about him and his inner workings. That said, things are never clear in Wonderland or this trilogy, so we'll just have to see how it all plays out in the last book.I love AG Howard's writing. It's dark, twisted, and sinister, just like you'd think this sort of Wonderland would be. She has a deft sense of words, and it plays out well in this installment.Overall, while it wasn't quite as fun as the first book, which it really couldn't be in order to progress the story, it is definitely a wonderful ride all on its own and a deeply satisfying sequel. We get to see some terrific reveals about all of the characters, and reintroduce ourselves to our favorite characters, which is the whole point, right? I am already itching to get my hands on the last book, which I know will be the most fantastic, chilling installment of them all.

I've been waiting for a year to read Infinite by Jodi Meadows, the last installment of the Incarnate trilogy. I wasn't disappointed. I received this ARC from Harper Publishers in exchange for an honest review. I award this book 4.5 stars.Infinite by Jodi Meadows takes off where Asunder left us. We are taken right to the action with Ana and Sam, as they frantically try to figure out how to prevent Janan for ascending. Ultimately, a small group of them have to leave Heart to try to figure out their ultimate plan. Will Ana sacrifice her chance for love and happiness for the greater good of all souls alike?I don't want to say too much in the synopsis, because this final installment is chock full of really great reveals that all of us have been wondering for ages. Let's just say that every character you've loved in this series gets their due. Ana really comes into her own, Sam continues to be one of the most loveable characters in YA, and other side characters come in different forms, which really enhances the world building.I really felt the book came into it's own around page 100. It was good up to then, don't get me wrong, but after that point, it became increasingly difficult to put it down. I loved how we got to learn more about dragons, sylphs, and phoenixes. There is one particular reveal that I loved because I never suspected there was more to it. But Meadows never forgot, and it's pretty amazing.I really liked the ending, but it almost seemed too perfect. That said, it was really satisfying and beautifully written, so I just went with it. If a writer can get my doubting self to just disappear, that's pretty awesome.In a world chock full of ending YA trilogies, this one stands out. It started strong and ended stronger, with a great middle installment, so as a whole, it was really great. This is hard to do. I feel like several trilogies have failed on one book or another, or disappointed me in some way. The Incarnate trilogy didn't, and I'm thrilled to add it to my very short list of must read trilogies.Overall, a fantastic and worthy ending to the Incarnate trilogy with great characters, prose, and plot twists. Everyone needs to get their hands on this book as soon as it comes out!

I won a copy of this ARC from Disney Publishers, and I haven't gotten a chance to read it until now. What a mistake. This is by far my favorite YA read from 2013.These Broken Stars, written by the duo Amie Kaufman and Meagan Spooner, takes us to space aboard a massive luxury ship, similar to the Titanic. We immediately meet our two main characters-- Tarver, a solider, and Lilac, the daughter of the richest and most powerful man in the universe. Right away, something happens to the ship, and the two of them are stranded on a deserted planet left to forage and survive on their own without help. Slowly, something happens between them, beautiful and fragile. And in the end, Tarver and Lilac will have to make the difficult decision of giving up the wonderful peace they've found with each other to find their way back to civilization.Any plot synopsis won't do this book justice. The way Lilac and Tarver interact is perfect. The prose is gorgeous. The world building is immense and believable. And I even went along with the science, because it's clear that these two authors have done their homework. Just fantastic. I can go on and on about the lush description, the pitch perfect characterization, and the most successfully done dual POV I have seen maybe ever in YA. I actually wonder if each voice was written by a different author, because the two voices are very unique, and I never wondered whose perspective I was in. Each scene is deliberate, ramping up the tension and the stakes, and ultimately, having us care about these two characters so much that one heart wrenching plot twist is entirely a shock to the system. I had to sit stunned for a day before I could continue, and then devoured the pages until the end to see what happened.Overall, this book is a gem. I can't think of a single criticism, and my inner writer is salivating with jealousy. I can't say enough how people must read this book immediately. It's beautifully written, described, and characterized with perfect pacing. My favorite YA read of the past year, and I'll be waiting impatiently until I can get my hands on the next installment.

Erin is a good friend on twitter, so I admit I was worried. I always worry about reading friends' books because you want to be honest, but let's face it, it always sucks reading a book you don't like that was written by a friend. Thank goodness, this wasn't an issue because The Prophecy ROCKS! :-)The Prophecy by Erin Albert is the first book of a YA fantasy trilogy that whisks us away to the nations of the Vanguard and the Ethereals. Layla is our main protagonist, although the perspective of the book shifts from character to character effortlessly, and she is one of the Vanguards. Her adoptive family is worried that she may be the Fulfillment because of her black hair and purple eyes. It's been foretold that the Fulfillment will bring the two kingdoms together in peace.All Layla wants to do is go to the Vanguard celebration and get some sweet bread. She doesn't feel like the Fulfillment, but she's quickly found by a zealot and taken off to become Wil's bride. Wilhelm is the heir to the Ethereal throne. As Layla meets both Wil and a mysterious boy named Nash, she will be forced to decide between her mind and heart on every level, and make a choice that may save or destroy the kingdoms and the hope for piece.I loved this book. It was fast paced, and the world building was seamless. I've seen books that completely fail on that level, but The Prophecy had a wonderful balance between world building, character building, and plot. Each of the characters were well described, and I found myself rooting for each of them. I loved the plot twists, and I found a new book boyfriend in Wil, who is one of the sweetest characters I've met in a long time.Layla was hard to like initially, but she quickly won me over, which is critical in a book like this. I also loved how the older generation of kings and queens played a large role in this book as well.I wasn't a huge fan of Nash, and I felt like some of those scenes were forced. However, this is my only slightly negative comment about the whole thing, and I know this is just a personal preference. There are several people out there who are glad I don't like Nash so they can have him for themselves!Overall, a really wonderful YA debut by a wonderful person. I'm beyond relieved that this book is terrific, because it makes my job as an honest reviewer that much easier! I'm dying to get my hands on the next installment!

I was asked by Left Bank Books to check out this book. Man, I'm glad they pointed it out to me. Michael Vey: The Prisoner of Cell 25 was an unexpectedly good read for me. I actually didn't read too much about the book, so all I knew going in was that it vaguely had to do with super powers.Michael Vey seems to be an ordinary 14 year old, but we find out in the first chapter that he has a hidden power. To make matters worse, he has Tourette's, which makes him have the unfortunate habit of saying the wrong thing at the wrong time, and getting himself into trouble because of it. His powers are a secret, however, so he is forced to suffer in silence. When the prettiest girl in school approaches him, Michael realizes that maybe it's not so bad being him after all. The two of them and Michael's best friend Ostin (yes, his mother mispelled the name of the Texas capital) band together to try to figure out the mysterious origin of their powers. They discover deeply buried and explosive secrets (pun completely intended), and Michael has to decide between what is right and what is easy.Okay, so I totally ripped off a promo for a movie or something. Not sure which one that phrase came from, but just let it suffice to say that I totally didn't make that up by myself. Anyway, what makes this book is the characters. We've all read books about kids with secret powers-- it's been overdone. How many books similar to the X-men have we all read?  But Michael is hysterically funny, and has a unique voice, which completely makes this book succeed. Add a feisty, cute love interest and a hilarious sidekick best friend who is smarter than everyone else combined (including the adults), and you get a terrific, fast paced read.This book doesn't reinvent the wheel, and I'd like to see more growth in the main character, which is why it didn't get a perfect score, but this is only the first book, and it sets up the next two in style.Overall, a terrific and fun read, and I can't wait to pick up the next book in the series.

This is the first book I've picked up recently that I didn't have to review or read for any reason other than I really wanted to. I loved the first four books in this series, and have been dying to read the rest ever since. This book will contain spoilers from the previous books.Spirit Bound by Richelle Mead picks up where we left off in the previous book. Dimitri is Strigoi, and Rose has returned from trying to kill/save whatever it was that she was thinking of doing (but knowing Rose she wasn't really thinking, just doing). She's just found out that there may be a way to turn him back to a dhampir, but of course, this possibility is riddled with both doubt and also complications to get the answers she seeks. That said, this is Rose Hathaway we're talking about, so she'll do what it takes, no matter how messy it is. Joined by the rest of the great cast, including the sexy Adrian and the golden Lissa, we blaze to the end, which of course is a cliffhanger.I have great admiration for Richelle Mead. She's created a cast of characters that are so real and believable and let's face it, just plain fun, that we WANT to read six books to see where the characters and plot are going. Most series have issues staying good for two books. Mead has also perfected the art of figuring out how to do an entirely first person book, but seeing into the minds of others and getting us perspectives in a third person way. It's a trick that I still marvel about since the first book. Also, all the characters (and there are many) are easy to keep straight. They are so unique, and characters that I haven't read about in a year, I still remember like yesterday. That's darned hard to do. Lastly, she creates a world that is intriguing and unique. Even though it's been several years since the first one was written, I don't have any other stories to compare it to. That's staying power for you. There are definitely some books I've read recently that I wonder if I would have enjoyed reading three years ago when they came out. I don't think it would have mattered when I read this series. I would have loved it anyway.Specifically to this book, it wasn't my favorite in the series because of certain plot points that were necessary. So my rating has nothing to do with the pacing, characters or anything like that. I just personally liked it slightly less than some of the others in this series.That said, I've already picked up the last book, and can't wait to see what happens to these characters. I have conflicting feelings because while I want to see the end, I don't want it to end! And that, my friends, is what every author strives to do. And Mead does that with flying colors. Can't wait to start the next of her spin off series.

Bloodrose by Andrea Cremer is the third installment of the series that started with Nightshade. I had mixed feelings about the first two books, but once I got past some of the issues I had with them, the third one was much tighter with pacing, writing, and great twists.The story continues with Calla, Ren, and Shay, as they struggle to figure out how to get rid of the Keeper's power once and for all. There are other side plots that I won't go into in case those of you reading this review haven't read the first two books.I think a lot of the people reading this book were dismayed by the ending because of certain events. It didn't really bother me, to be honest with you, because I never really connected with either of the two male leads, so I didn't care which one she ended up with. I still had issues with how everyone just had their designated "place" in the hierarchy just because of what role they were born into, but after I got past that, I just sat back and enjoyed the ride.As I stated before, everything was stronger in this story. I got through this one much faster than the first two because the pacing was better, and so was the writing. The ending was actually a surprise to me because I didn't think Cremer would take the story there, but I admired her decision. As the other reviews show, it's not necessarily the most popular decision, but it makes sense, and solidified that I'm going to give this book four stars, the highest rating I've given any book in this series.I'm not sure I would recommend this series as a whole because you have to get through two books to get to the one that's worth reading. That said, I think that Cremer will just continue to get better with each book.

I got this book from my library, and I award it somewhere between 3 and 3.5 stars.Wolfsbane by Andrea Cremer is the follow up to Nightshade. We once again meet up with Calla and Shay, as they navigate through this new world they've discovered after many of the lies have been revealed at the end of Nightshade. Calla is also still struggling with her feelings of Shay and Ren, the boy she left behind.
