Will Calla be able to reunite with her pack or will they label her as a traitor after all?There are some great things about this novel. It's overall better written than the first. Cremer is definitely growing as an author. The last 50 pages really pop with some great revelations. I liked some of the twists a lot. We also get a crowd of new characters who add something different to the table.That said, I still had a multitude of issues with this book. First, 300 pages is just discussion of backstory in conversation between characters. I liked how it was done in the first book because it was limited and necessary. This just seemed like overkill. Because of this, the second book almost entirely felt like filler until the last few pages when all the action and twists occur. I discovered a lot about the history of the world, but found my attention drifting because it was just too much all at once. And like in the first book, I find myself irritated by how the whole wolf/alpha thing works. It's as if the people in the story have no say in who they hang out with or who they obey because of their natural wolfie instincts. And Calla does a lot of questionable things just because of her "alpha" driving her to just react and not think. I guess but I'm not really into that kind of person, and is likely why I've never really got into Calla as a main character.Overall, a better written follow up to the first with great twists at the end, but needs better pacing for the world building.

I have the ARC for the fourth book in the series, so I figured I'd better get a move on. There may be some mild kissing spoilers.Nightshade by Andrea Cremer is a book about teenaged werewolves. It stars the stuffy Calla, who is the alpha of her pack. She's destined to mate with Ren, the alpha of another pack. And these two packs stroll the halls as the most popular kids. During the very first pages, Calla rescues a mere human, named Shay, and introduces him as the third wheel in the love triangle. With Shay, Calla teaches him the background of her people, the Guardians, and he shows her that not all is how it seems. Will Calla be able to become the individual that she's always dreamed of becoming?I can see why people like this book. It's pretty fast paced, and there's some interesting world building. I like the ideas that stem with the mythology of the Guardians, Keepers, and whatnot. I also liked how Cremer shows us a lot of this as Calla is explaining her world to Shay. There are some pretty good twists that develop throughout the plot, and leaves me interested enough to stick around for the sequel.That said, I had a ton of issues with this book. I wonder if I'd have liked it better three years ago when it first came out. The dialogue is so stuffy and stilted-- all of the characters sound middle aged, especially Calla. And she is way too easy with her lips. She very frequently kisses different boys right after one another. Sorry if that's a spoiler, but if you don't know there's a love triangle by page 5, shame on you! Also, I don't understand why these kids are taking some high brow college courses in high school. Are they in a magnet school or something? Organic Chemistry? Some other crazy philosophical course? Most kids would be lucky to be in a school like that separating caffeine from tea. I'm rather jealous actually. Both of the boys seem pretty pushy, so I'm not really digging either one of them. I wish Calla would just tell them both to take a hike and go on a girly vacation with Bryn or something.Overall, good world building and some interesting twists, but I'm not yet convinced by the characters, how they talk, or where this is going. We'll see how the next 3 books go.

I've been waiting on pins and needles for Fire and Ash, the conclusion of the series by Jonathan Mayberry that started with the wonderful Rot and Ruin. I was not disappointed. I award this book 4.5 stars.Fire and Ash takes place a bit after Flesh and Bone, the third book in the series. Chong is in dire straits, while Benny, Nix, and Lila are at Sanctuary, finally, but with more questions than answers. The legendary Joe Ledger is also there, who stars in his own books in the adult fiction world. Together, this ragtag band strives to save Chong and the same time, save the world from the Reapers and the completely creepy Saint John.I was thrilled to see Benny finally get his day in the sun. I've been waiting for this last part in his growth (apparently, Nix was too), and while I'll always have a soft spot in my heart for Tom Imura, Benny is a pretty cool samurai himself. The pacing was as good as the previous novels. I've been struggling to get through novels recently, and this wasn't one of them. It's a good size, the size of a Harry Potter book, but I blazed through it just as fast. We also get to see some old friends, and this comes to a wonderfully satisfying finish.It's not a perfect novel-- I'm a little sketchy on some of the details of the science, and it almost seems to wrap up too easily at the end. But that said, that didn't stop me from thoroughly enjoying myself from start to finish. There were some great twists that took my mind away from these small details.Overall, a worthy ending to a phenomenal series. If you haven't read these yet, get them NOW. They'll stand the test of time. I guess I'd better start picking up some of the books on Ledger until Mayberry writes another YA novel. I hope it's soon.

I read and enjoyed the first book in this duet- My Super Sweet Sixteenth Century while back. I knew at that point Rachel Harris was talented, and that I'd better continue to pick up her books as I suspected she'd only get better with time.Boy, was I right. I was lucky enough to win this copy in a twitter giveaway. A Tale of Two Centuries takes place a bit after the first book-- and what's wonderful about this book (and I'm enjoying this new trend in YA quite a bit) is that it's a companion novel and a stand alone in its own right. So you can easily pick this one up and read it by itself, but if you've read the first one, it only enhances the second.In this book, instead of getting the perspective of Cat, the fiery protagonist from the first book, we get to see through the eyes of Less. I think I identified a lot more with Less, and absolutely loved her from the first book, so this even made me enjoy the book more. Less has dreamed of the freedom to choose what to do with her life as well as pick who she should love. Fortunately, Reyna, the gypsy, has heard her plea, and Less gets to journey to the modern world to visit her relative, Cat. Although this world is shocking to her in many ways, at the same time, she is able to do so many things she wasn't in her world. She is able to pursue acting and meets a gorgeous guy named Austin, who makes her (and me) blush. Will she be able to leave all of this behind when the time comes?I can't say how much I loved this book. I felt like Rachel took all of the parts I loved in the first book and totally enhanced it in the second. Less is a wonderful protagonist, and it was a wonder and delight to see her grow and develop into the person she always wanted to be. And deserved to be. I've always enjoyed watching her interaction with Cat, and we got loads more of that in this book. Some of her mistakes in this world were absolutely hilarious and totally made sense. And finally, Austin is a very swoon worthy guy. I don't usually go for the bad guys, but he's one of the very rare exceptions. You can't help but fall head over heels for everyone in this book.Overall, the perfect frosting (with depth too!) to my night, and I blazed through it from cover to cover. Everyone needs to read this book and will continue smiling after it's finished for a long time.

I picked up Icons because I wanted to try something different of Stohl's than Beautiful Creatures, which I could see she had talent, but didn't really get into that story.I chose this book from a blog giveaway.Icons takes place after the world pretty much ends. It's a paranormal dystopian, a combination genre I really enjoy. We are in the perspective of Dol, a girl who has been orphaned by the Icons taking over the world on one Day (and yes, unfortunately, that is capitalized in the book). She and her best friend Ro have unusual powers but are two of the few people to live in the Grasslands, away from the influence of the central government. They are captured and meet up with two other kids, Lucas, the Ambassador's son, and Tima, another girl with powers. For some reason, these particular kids seem to be the key to fighting back the alien invasion, and this book is their journey to figuring this and themselves out.At first, I wasn't sure if I liked this book or not-- but after about 100 pages, I got sucked into the story. I liked Dol, and I wanted to figure out where they got their powers, what the backstory was, and where things were going. Lucas was an atypical love interest as well, so I really liked that. He understandably thought the way his mother thought about things, having grown up that way, and didn't just believe that rebellion was the way to go. Also, there are some hints that Stohl has done some medical research. A lot of the premise is a bit farfetched, but I liked that she took the initiative to at least put some possible explanations that had some scientific grounding.I thought I was going to give this book four stars, but the ending really disappointed me. It suddenly became a very typical book with a typical ending, and it didn't feel like a natural progression as to what happened before.Overall, interesting premise and characters, but doesn't deliver in the end.

I received this book from Goodreads in exchange for an honest review.A Darkness Strange and Lovely by Susan Dennard picks up where the first left off. I had several issues with the first book, the main one being that I was really confused as to setting and time period-- and the beginning was rather odd. However, I could see that Dennard could write beautifully and it ended at a place that I figured I'd give the series another try by picking up the second book.We return to our friends Eleanor who is dealing with the aftermath of the first book. She's on the brink of poverty, but soon she realizes she has to find the rest of her friends again to deal with Marcus. After meeting a demon, she journeys to Paris, which is a lovely setting, and runs into Jie, Joseph, and her first love, Daniel. At the same time, she realizes she may be more similar to her brother than she ever thought and is tempted by great power. Will she be able to decipher Elliot's letters and control her growing talents before she ostracizes everyone she knows and cares about?Let me be direct-- I do think that this book is an improvement on the first one. The prose is much more straightforward and understandable. I never for a moment was confused where we were or what the setting was. Paris was a wonderful place to set the majority of this book and I think that's the strength of Dennard's writing. There were wonderful moments of description. Also, Jie is one of my favorite characters, so I loved seeing her again.So what were my issues? I'm starting to think any sort of historical fiction may not be my thing. I've never connected to Eleanor, and I know part of it is that she's a girl in the 1800's. Her infatuation with Daniel seems too stereotypical, and both of them throw hissy fits very easily without sticking around for explanations. They are typical of some teenagers, I admit, but not ones I really want to read about. Because of this, I put down the book at 250 pages, and scanned to the end to see if I was missing anything. There are some twists, but not enough to continue this journey with Eleanor.Overall, beautiful description and improvement on the last novel, but overall, I think the time period and characters weren't for me.

I won this book from a blogger giveaway.Origin by Jessica Khoury is about Pia, the perfect girl who has been created immortal and who is destined to take over the scientific team who wants to create a new race of immortals. She has been raised in Little Cambridge, which is in the middle of some kind of tropical rainforest setting, but she's never been outside of its walls. One night she creeps into the jungle and meets a boy. She never realized there was life other than what she's experienced and she starts to question everything. This book is her journey on finding some answers.What I liked: I liked the descriptions of the forest, the village in the forest, other natives and their language. I liked Uncle Antonio and Aunt Harriet, who were probably the best characters and the most three dimensional of the lot. Khoury brings up some interesting ethical issues.Why this book was a letdown for me: the science makes no sense to me. These people are supposedly scientists but none of their "experiments" follow any sort of scientific method I've ever known. Apparently these people and Pia herself are supposed to be highly intelligent. I work in a laboratory setting and the individuals there (who are graduate students) are way more intelligent than these people. Where are the controls? What are the experiments? What are they testing really? These tests that they are giving Pia are just regurgitation of facts. Sure, she's good at memorization, but she seems not very bright otherwise. I know she's sheltered, but she just seems really slow in general. Not to mention how tired I am of the trope of the evil scientists who have no morals and who are only in it for glory and money from the evil, shadowy corporation. Really? Then there's the insta-love that takes place, which I won't get into, but that seems very groan worthy. And I won't talk about the Wickham tests, but they're ridiculous-- you'll have to read it to figure out what they are.Overall, a beautifully described setting, but with overall lackluster characters and terrible science-- a disappointment.

I unexpectedly received this book in the mail a few days ago from Penguin Teen and was curious about it, so immediately picked it up. This is my favorite kind of book-- I go in with no expectations, and come out, moved.45 Pounds by K.A. Barson is about every girl Ann, who is overweight, wears a size 17, and is incredibly embarrassed about it. She has a stick thin perfect mother who has apparently never worried about weight her entire life, and has difficulty making new friends. She's struggled through many different diets, but this one is different-- her aunt has a wedding coming up, and Ann is determined to fit into a cute bridesmaid dress. This all seems very stereotypical to teen literature, but this book takes a generic idea and makes it new.I admit that the first 100 pages were very painful for me to read on so many different levels. Ann is the perfect teen protagonist-- very insecure with many flaws, but with so much room to grow. She's like any of us were when we were at the awkward teenager stage where all we wanted to do was belong. I'll be honest-- I almost wanted to put it down because reliving those years was not my idea of relaxation. But then midway, something changes. Ann realizes that her sphere is larger than just around herself and that everyone has their own history, their own insecurities, their own fears. Barson introduces some really wonderful supporting characters-- Raynee, Ann's new friend, was probably my favorite of them all, and they take this book to a new level. The writing is crisp and the pacing makes absolute sense.The resolution of this book is perfect-- and it brought tears to my eyes. In contemporary YA, the characters are the center of stories, and this book is chock full of it.Overall, a book bursting through the seams with heart, courage, and depth that I was not expecting. A must read.

I was very lucky to receive one of these well anticipated ARCs from the author in exchange for an honest review.I loved Black City, so I was thrilled to receive this follow up. In Phoenix, the sequel, we are thrust back into the action, right where we left off in Black City. Ash and Natalie are still in love, and still reeling from the events in the last book. Rose's Law is up for public vote, and unsurprisingly, we get some sinister threats from Purian Rose, the enemy. The basic idea that Ash and Natalie are fighting for is equality among all races, Darklings and humans alike (as well as some other interesting species mixed in). A lot of forces stand in their way.I don't want to give away any more information, because there are several twists that are a delight to find out. Again, this entry is very well written, and I found myself immersed in this dangerous world that seems like a combination between the world of the Hunger Games and that of the Holocaust. Horrific things happen in the name of power, and while at times, it seems almost unbelievable, you just have to look at WWII to remember that such atrocities have happened in the recent past.If I'm completely honest, I didn't like this entry as much as the first-- not because it's not as well written, but certain events had to happen, which make me not the biggest fan of Natalie by the end of the book. But I understand she has time to redeem herself, and another book to get there.Overall, a thrilling and dark second installment in the Black City trilogy. It's a must read, and I'm itching to get my hands on the third as soon as possible.

I was given this book by the author in exchange for an honest review. I rate it 2.5 stars.The Widower by Ryan LaForge is about Jacob McKinley, a man who has just been widowed at the ripe age of 28. He was only married to Leah for a year and a half before she passed away. Since then, he's been carrying a lot of grief and guilt that he wasn't the best husband as he could have been and now he isn't sure he can move on. Certain events take place after this that change his life forever.What I liked: it's pretty well written from a grammatical and prose standpoint. I love when indie authors heavily edit (or have it heavily edited by pros) and put their best foot forward. Some of the description is spot on and beautifully done.What I had a very big issue with is how trite a lot of the plot is. I felt like this novel tried to be a version of a Nicholas Sparks novel, but every time another plot point occurred, I silently groaned to myself. Because of this, it was very difficult to get through and I would have been okay with stopping after a few chapters.What was worth sticking it through, is that we get introduced to another couple of characters that have a little more uniqueness to them. Rachel was probably the best character in the book.Overall, a well edited book that falls flat with some trite plot choices. That said, this can be worked on and I know that LaForge will just get better with every book.

I was given this book by the author in exchange for an honest review.The Grave Winner by Lindsey R. Loucks doesn't fall into an easy category. The genre is most similar to a YA horror/paranormal (like the wonderful Anna Dressed in Blood), but I don't want readers who aren't into horror to discount this book. It has a lot of really terrific paranormal elements and is a wonderful read. I'm not a horror buff either and I loved it! This book stars Leigh, a typical rebellious teenager that has just experienced what every other teen hopes not to experience-- the death of her mother. A popular girl at school has just come back from the dead, and Leigh is determined not to have her mother come back that way. But events take an ominous turn and she struggles to keep her family and friends safe as creepy things start to happen. She also gets into a bit of a romantic triangle between a cute graveyard caretaker and the brother of her best friend. Will Leigh be able to work all of this out in time?I loved this book. Every time I thought I could pigeonhole the book, it surprised me in some way. I had some questions along the way that I wasn't sure would be answered, but they were, in a most satisfying way. The characters are terrific-- I think I would have been lucky to have friends like Leigh and Jo in high school. The two love interests sizzle, although I think I definitely have a soft spot for the best friend's brother, Callum. The setting is creepy and appropriate.I have to mention this as well-- Loucks has the best swag I've ever seen any author have. The items she has are pivotal players in the book, and I was delighted to see how those elements revealed themselves. I think it's a talent to have swag that enhances the book even more.Overall, a terrific and creepy read-- make sure you have a warm blanket, pet, or significant other to squeeze during the scary parts! I'll be watching Loucks career from here on out.

I received a copy of this book from Epic Reads, thanks!I tried to read The Selection by Kiera Cass in the past. I thought from the first few chapters that it wasn't the book for me. But when I received it from Epic Reads and also saw some rave reviews from bloggers that I trust, I knew I had to try it again. And for a book I didn't think I would like, I sure enjoyed reading it a whole lot!The Selection stars America, who is a Five, or a lower class citizen. The upper classes are One through Four. She is in love with a Six. But every royal prince goes through The Selection to select his queen out of a group of lucky girls. America turns out to be one of those girls. She knows that she can never love Prince Maxon, because he has to be a stuck up Royal, right? But when she meets him and actually gets to know him, she realized she was completely wrong. Will she fall for him after all?This book is kind of like a mix of the show The Bachelor with a dystopian world. I thought it was a really unique idea, merging the two together. Prince Maxon is a little naive but endearing, and I grew to like him a lot more throughout the book. Aspen, the other love interest, is unfortunate, because we don't get much time to know him like we do Maxon. We get to know Maxon at the same pace that America does, and it's much easier to fall in love with him. The writing is solid and the pace is just right. I want to know a little more about the world, and Cass hints that there are secrets that the monarchy are hiding from us.While a solid book, it was centered on a love triangle, and while I know a lot of other readers will love that aspect of it, it's not my personal favorite plot twist.Overall, a fun and intriguing read with some great characters-- I'll be sticking around for the next one!

The author gave me this book in exchange for an honest review.I really enjoyed the first two installments of this series, which is a play on the Persephone story as well as other Greek myths. We have been following Persephone, her husband and fortunately, the man she loves, Hades, and a long list of other characters, all who have their unique spin. We continue the story from the first two books, where Persephone has gotten a lot of attention for her potential for having lots of power. She has been kidnapped and is now being tortured by the powerful being who whisked her away at the end of the second book. We follow her, Hades, and Aphrodite.I was delighted to see that we got to see in Aphrodite's head this time, who has consistently been one of my favorite characters. She didn't disappoint in this entry. The rest of the characters continue to be terrific and interesting, and there are some nice plot twists along the way, with the humor that we've learned to love from Bevis.I wasn't as enamored by this book as the others because there is a lot of torture in it, which was hard for me to read and get through, and the villain is pretty two dimensional. Lastly, I had trouble at times with the very short chapters and going from perspective to perspective.That said, the end was not completely an ending, so I can't wait to see the next installment in this series!

I was given this book by the author in exchange for an honest review.Hockey Player for Life by Howard Shapiro stars (as in all of his books thus far) Tom, a 13 year old hockey player, who goes through the ups and downs of the competitive sport. He is initially very full of confidence almost to the point of arrogance, and thinks that nothing can go wrong with his fledgling career. Something happens, however, and he has to rethink his entire plans for the future and what hockey really means to him.I loved this book. Shapiro is remarkably good at channeling pre-teen and teen boys-- their sense of invincibility but also showing how they can grow and develop as they meet new challenges and unexpected disappointments. This book is not a graphical novel, but is similar in tone to Stereotypical Freaks, again about Tom (but he is 15 years old and in high school), which was one of my favorite reads of the year. The pacing is perfect, and my two favorite characters were his father and his best friend, Terry, who in different ways, teach Tom the true meaning of being a hockey player for life. In a deluge of young adult books where the adults are more infantile than the children, it is so wonderful to see a great parent described.Overall, a wonderful read for young boys, but that will be universally enjoyed by anyone. Another must read from Howard Shapiro.

I was given this book by the author in exchange for an honest review.The Vampire Code by E. C. Adams is about a young and talented lawyer, Aurora, who is approached by Sebastian Fiscard, a vampire in the most prestigious vampire families, to help him defend his brother in court. His brother is being tried for murder because the vampire that he turned (his wife) killed another woman in cold blood. Aurora learns that the Vampire Code is set up very differently than the human legal system, so she navigates through this new territory as well as fights off her growing feelings for Sebastian. She is also being pursued by the Resistance, who wants to see her dead for showing her face in vampire court. Can Aurora survive in this brave new world?I loved this book. LOVED. I don't say that lightly. And I'm even more happy that this is a talented new writer. There has been a ton of speculation as to where this book lies-- it's either New Adult or Adult (I think it's the latter), but honestly, it doesn't really matter. I think young adult readers as well as adult readers will gravitate towards this book because the characters are great (I think I have my first ever vampire crush, and I've read a lot of vampire books), the pacing spot on, and the world building with the Vampire Code just fascinating. There are also a lot of great plot twists that I won't tell you about so that you can discover them on your own.My one small issue (and this is really just a personal preference that did not change the rating) is with the medical stuff later in the book. The details don't really make sense to me, but I was okay with glossing over that (which I usually am not okay with!) to get back to the story at hand.Overall, one of the best indie reads I've gotten my hands on this year. I will be closely following E.C. Adams' career from here out.

I was given this book by the author in exchange for an honest review. I award this book 3.5 stars.Hockey Days by Howard Shapiro is a cute picture book about a boy, Tom, who loves hockey and misses his grandfather, who has passed away recently. A mystery box comes to the door, and what is inside is a surprise to both Tom and his father.This book was a quick, fun read, and a nice preview to the books that are to come. I can quickly sense that Shapiro needs a bigger venue to express some deep ideas, and unfortunately, this packaging makes it very difficult to do that. There are some really wonderful and mature ideas placed into simplified text. I am a little bit biased as I go into reading this one, because Shapiro's Stereotypical Freaks, which is a full length graphical novel, is exactly the solution to the issues I had with this book. It's definitely worth taking a look at, however, and appropriate for younger aged readers.

This book was on sale on Amazon (if you guys don't check out Kindle daily deals you are missing out!) and has been on my to be read list for a while, so I was excited to get started. This book was extremely hard to rate, and I give it 3.5 stars after much thought.Sweet Evil by Wendy Higgins stars Anna, a very sheltered Southern girl, who has never done anything wrong in her life when suddenly, she meets Kaidan, a bad boy who makes girls like her turn bad. She also has always had powers to see people's auras/feelings and has never figured out why or how she has these powers. It turns out that has both heavenly and hellish parents, and with Kaidan, she journeys to find out more about herself.I want to say first that Wendy Higgins can obviously write. Her prose is very clear and beautifully described. I think that she'll only get better and better. That said, let's talk about my difficulties with this novel.There will be some slight spoilers in this review from now on, because I can't help but cite specific issues I had. First, while Anna has a good reason to be sheltered, she is just SO sheltered for half of the book, that it's extremely difficult to be in her head for a long period of time. I almost chucked the book across the room groaning because of all the cliched things she thought or said, and the fact that she was swooning over Kaidan, the stereotypical bad boy. When we got to "the sword of righteousness" smack dab in the middle of the book, I was pretty much done and would have stopped there.But then part II started. Instead of focusing on the two dreary lovebirds, we get introduced to a whole new crowd of interesting characters of different flavors. I was drawn into the story like the first half never did for me. We get introduced to Anna's father, who is one of my favorite characters, and Kaidan's fascinating friends. I also very much like Anna's human friends. The pacing was much better and we race to the end.Overall, a very difficult book to read and rate-- the first half very nearly had me stop reading it because of the overly sheltered voice of Anna and stereotypical romance, but the second half really brought the book to a new level and saved the read for me.

I've seen good reviews of this book hanging about and I knew I had to pick it up. I don't think I realized it was a middle grade read, but I have to say this is the best middle grade/younger adult book I've read in a long while.My Life in Pink and Green by Lisa Greenwald stars Lucy, one of the spunkiest and smartest 12 year olds I've ever read about. She has a mother that still lives at home and a grumpy grandmother who is trying to hold their finances together. They all work/live in a pharmacy that has been in their family forever. It's barely holding on, and they are struggling to pay the bills. Lucy has a terrific idea to help save the pharmacy and go green (her mom is an activist) to bring together the disparate personalities of both her mom and grandmother and stay lucrative. On top of all that, she deals with first crushes and her new burgeoning makeup side business. Will Lucy be able to pull all of this together to save her beloved pharmacy?Lucy is a TERRIFIC character, and I don't say that lightly. I was thinking while I was reading this book, that she is definitely in the top five characters that I would love to meet in real life. When I have a child, I'd be ecstatic if she had a fraction of the drive, passion, and just overall curiosity and love for life and learning as Lucy does. She is what makes this book-- and her voice definitely sounds 12 even though she's obviously doing a lot more than most 12 year olds (and most growups). I think this book has mass appeal to both the 12 year old audience, and people... my age. :-)My only caveat was that Lucy's personality is so big, and her character so terrific, that she can't be contained in just one book, and at the end, I was so sad to see her go. When preparing for this review, imagine my excitement that there is a followup to this book! I don't actually usually clamor for sequels, but this is an exception to the rule.Overall, a terrific middle grade read that everyone will enjoy with one of the most engaging protagonists I have ever read about. Greenwald puts everything together seamlessly, and I will definitely be watching her career from now on!

I saw this on sale on Amazon so I knew I had to pick up a copy, especially since I really enjoyed Anna and the French Kiss.Lola and the Boy Next Door by Stephanie Perkins introduces Lola, who is unlike any character I've ever met. She's creative and spunky, but still very much a teenager. She has the perfect rocker boyfriend, two very loving and protective dads, and she wears something crazy every day that she has created herself. But then a childhood crush moves back next door and somehow everything falls apart. Will Lola be able to figure out how she really feels before things really spiral out of control?I absolutely LOVED this book. While I liked and enjoyed Anna and the French Kiss, I loved this book a million times more. I loved Lola, and I loved her character arc. I didn't always like her or agree with her decisions, but she learned a lot and grew, which is the important thing. I loved every description about her awesome gay parents, the details of living on Castro street, and her friends. Lindsey was awesome (can't go wrong with a nerdy Korean best friend!), Cricket was super sweet and hot, and we even get to see Anna and St. Clair again. I think that my favorite character would have to be Calliope, Cricket's talented twin sister, and her arc ended most satisfyingly.At one point last week, I wondered how contemporaries could ever be entertaining since they can't really make up new worlds or magical powers. Stephanie Perkins reminds me how wrong I am-- if a book is written well, regardless of the genre, it can be magical.Overall, a perfectly written book with beautiful descriptions and a unique, unforgettable protagonist. This book is a must read and one of my top reads thus far this year. I will definitely pick up any book Stephanie Perkins writes.

After enduring several duds on my list, I decided to treat myself to a book I've been dying to read for a while. I'm not sure what I was expecting, but I loved this book!Unraveling by Elizabeth Norris is about Janelle, a teenaged girl who seems just like any other ordinary teen, until she dies... and is brought back to life by a boy she's never noticed. She believes she has been given a second chance and is determined to live life to the fullest. But she also has a streak of curiosity and wants to find out Ben's secret in addition to helping her FBI agent dad solve a case about several dead people who have apparently been killed by a healthy dose of radiation. To make matters worse, her father has found a device that is ticking down to a certain doomsday. Will Janelle be able to figure out the answers before the clock reaches zero?If I could describe this book in a tagline, it would be Veronica Mars meets Fringe. The first 60% of the book, while beautifully written, doesn't have a ton of surprises. Instead, I would say it is almost an homage of all the wonderful books, movies, and shows that have come before it. In addition to the two I mentioned above, there are shout-outs to X-files, Ender's Game, Before I Fall, and some plot twists that are similar to the teen series and show Roswell. The characters are terrific-- Janelle is a wonderful protagonist-- spunky and smart. Her best friend, Alex, may be my favorite character. Ben is a fascinating love interest, and even though when I realize logically that the way he knows Janelle is kind of creepy, Norris masterfully weaves the story to make it seem normal. The pacing of the story is great, and the last 40% of the book approaches unknown territory, which makes it fun to keep guessing.Overall, a terrific addition to the small but persistent genre of YA science fiction with a great protagonist and plot twists-- I can't wait to pick up the next installment.

I was given this book from Netgalley in exchange for an honest review. Caveat: I feel bad about this review and want the reader of this review to understand that I didn't gravitate towards the first book, so it was highly unlikely that I'd like this one either. If you really loved the first book, you'll probably really enjoy the second book as well because they are similar in content and feel. If I hadn't gotten the book from Netgalley in exchange for a review, I probably wouldn't have read/reviewed it in the first place for those reasons.Point of Retreat by Colleen Hoover takes place soon after the events in Slammed. This time, we see the story through Will's eyes instead of Lake's. Lake's mom has just passed away, and the two of them are raising their brothers simultaneously in neighboring houses. Some events happen to make Lake really question their relationship (and me to question why she is questioning it and punishing Will so much for it), and for Will to get very defensive and whiny, similar to how Lake was in the first book.The strengths of this book are in a couple of places-- a vase that Lake's mom has left for them as a fount of advice, which pulls some heart strings. The second is a moment where we see one of the younger brothers do a very moving slam. It was the first slam that I actually got and FELT.My issues with this book are similar to that of the first book. The YA tropes are again generic and the teenaged issues seem very forced. The Point of Retreat is their label for avoiding sex for the time being to respect Lake's mother's wishes. We see Will overexpressing his feelings physically for her in front of his GRANDMOTHER for peet's sake and he doesn't realize until later how Lake feels about that? There are other forced plot twists that make me want to just shake both characters and tell them to communicate for ONCE, and stop saying "carving pumpkins" over and over as if that's a meaningful phrase.OK, end of rant. Again, if you loved the first book, read this one because you'll enjoy it. If you didn't love the first book, pass on this one as well.

I received the sequel to this book, Point of Retreat, so I knew I had to read this one first. It's been getting a lot of buzz in the blogosphere so I already had it on my TBR list.Slammed by Colleen Hoover stars Layken, a teenaged girl who just lost her father and then was forced to relocate with the rest of her family to Michigan. She meets a handsome boy next door who she realizes later is her teacher. They both battle their feelings for each other as they know their relationship can't happen.We've all seen this movie. Girl falls in love with unattainable boy for some reason-- here he's a teacher. There's some poetry involved, which is rather unfortunate because even though it is the most original part of the book, it loses a lot of its possible effect in text form. We have to imagine the cadence of the words that are italicized for emphasis.I don't really understand why there's so much manufactured drama in this book. Sure, he's her teacher, but she's a senior, and is going to graduate soon. Why can't they wait a year? But there's a lot of crying and carrying on. There are also some plot twists that made me groan out loud-- a trope that has been overdone.The best part of this book was Layken's best friend, Eddie, who was original. I think I would have liked a book in her perspective.I have to say I was pretty disappointed in this book-- I hope that there is a bit more originality in the follow up.

I was given this book from the author in exchange for an honest review.Finding Abigail by Christina Smith stars a woman stuck in an impossible situation. She's fallen in love with a guy who reveals his true nature after they get engaged-- he physically abuses her. She knows she has to escape, and when she does, she starts her life over. Will she be able to get over her past in order to move forward with her present and possibly find love?Finding Abigail treads familiar ground. We have the woman who is stuck in a bad relationship, and a guy who is controlling and beats her. When Abby changes her name and her life, we've seen this before in multiple romance novels. That said, the characters are what make this book succeed. Abigail is a terrific character, and I loved all of the background about her being a writer. I do feel like this is a case of writing what you know, and Christina Smith definitely knows about this. I enjoyed the supportive cast a lot-- Abby has some really great friends that pop off of the page. I also love the grandmotherly figure who plays a key part in her life in multiple ways-- I'll leave the reader to discover her on his own.I have to say, I wasn't too thrilled by the second love interest. Noah is also overprotective and pretty pushy with Abby. I guess she gravitates towards that sort of man, but I love when her confident side comes out and wished I saw that more. I also have an issue with epilogues in general, so everything seemed to resolve a little too easily.That said, this was a great beach read. It's well paced and a quick read with a engaging protagonist.

I was given this book by the author in exchange for an honest review.Aire by Lena Goldfinch is a historical fantasy that stars a young Italian princess named Anna, who has the power to see the future. This is a power she keeps hidden from everyone because others might not understand. Her hand in marriage is given to a suitor who she doesn't love, and in a burst of rebellion, she flees the dance that would announce this betrothal. As she flees, her boat is caught by mercenaries who mistake her clothmaiden for her. What happens next is a whirlwind of Anna trying to find her missing friend, falling in love for the first time, and learning how to think for herself.The setting of this novel is beautiful-- we get the sense of the vastness and gorgeousness of Italian royalty. There is plenty of intrigue and plot twists. Anna is a good protagonist, and we also get to see in the head of the male protagonist, Jovanni. The supporting characters are strong, especially Ilan, one of her favorite servants. The last 20% of the novel moves at a quick pace and at that point, is hard to put down.I did feel that the middle section dragged quite a bit, as we keep getting told that Anna and Jovanni are looking for the missing girl, and a lot of wandering takes place. I also wasn't a big fan of the Italian words that were plugged into the text to remind us she was in Italy-- but that's more a personal preference.Overall, a beautifully written historical fantasy that introduces us to some great characters.

I was given this book by another blogger in anticipation of the sequel coming out. I figured I better get caught up with this first installment.The Serpent's Ring by HB Bolton is a middle grade fantasy that reminds me at time of Percy Jackson and his adventures or The last of the really great whangdoodles by Julie Andrews. We join two siblings, Evan and Claire, as they find the magical Serpent's Ring and are swept away to another world by a couple of imps. Quickly, the ring is stolen, and the two siblings have to use their newfound powers to get it back. They meet some wonderful friends along the way who help them on their journey.I really enjoyed reading this first installment. Bolton has a great imagination and she makes up some great new creatures as well as new recipes (that you can even make at the end) to entice the reader. The two siblings are very likeable as well as their companions that they meet along the way. The pacing is good, and we are whipped from place to place as they strive to find the ring.Overall, this is a fun quick read, and I look forward to reading the sequel!

I want to thank Winterhaven Books, a wonderful blog, who hosted a terrific interview with the author, Tabitha Suzuma. I would also like to thank Tabitha, for sending me a beautiful hardcover and signed copy of Forbidden. It has made its way into my heart and also my favorite books bookshelf.Forbidden by Tabitha Suzuma is about two siblings, Lochan and Maya, who are closer than most. They have been placed in an impossible situation-- a father who has abandoned them and a mother who is an alcoholic who tries to forget they exist as well as three younger siblings that they take care of in addition to their heavy load of schoolwork. It is clear that they can only depend on each other and that no one else can understand their situation. But this abnormal situation leads to an even more dysfunctional outcome-- they fall in love. As their feelings for each other accelerate, they strive to keep their home life as normal as possible for the other children. It is a tricky balance to maintain, and unsurprisingly, everything starts to fall apart.I have to give major props to Tabitha. This book was an extremely risky one to write with its very taboo subject of incest. She took a very repugnant topic that most people can't even think about without gagging, and introduced two very compelling and relatable characters who are caught in a situation that they never wanted to be in. You can't help but fall in love with both Lochan and Maya and almost root for them, knowing that this relationship can't end in any good way. The prose is absolutely beautiful, and devastatingly so. Suzuma writes gorgeously, and I felt swept away by both the emotion in the alternating voices of her protagonists as well as the rich description she embodies in her text. The pacing is pitch perfect, and the supporting characters are deftly drawn.Overall, this book is a risk that pays off-- Suzuma has written a masterpiece--a novel that will stand the test of time. This story will haunt you for days to come.

I won this book from Keely of the wonderful blog Realms of an Open Mind. Honest disclosure: I've heard great things about this book on the internet, but the cover is not my favorite-- so I really wasn't sure I'd like it. Once I cracked open the cover and started the first few pages though, I was hooked.The Collector by Victoria Scott stars Dante Walker who is the bad of the bad. He collects souls for the Big Boss (I think we all know who that is alluding to). To get the promotion he's been waiting for, he has to lure a girl, Charlie, to the dark side. Charlie is a teenaged girl-- but unlike a lot of our typical heroines these days, she's nerdy, unattractive, and gangly. Dante doesn't know why she is so special, and he has 10 days to get her soul. But a few days with Charlie shows him what he's been missing his whole life-- what will he risk for this girl he just met but strangely, starts to care about so deeply?The Collector doesn't have a whole lot of unique ideas-- we get the good girl seeing the "good" in the bad guy and changing him slowly to the good. We have devils and angels. And yet... Dante is a very unique perspective. I've never heard anything like his voice, and he is truly what makes this book work and succeed. Dante is a hugely flawed character, but you can't help but like him (even when he is crazy full of himself and flaunting his assets). Usually, I don't like expletives in YA, but for Dante, it just fits his voice, and honestly, I didn't even notice it, I was so drawn to his character. OK, and yeah, he's a bit hot. I thought I was over the whole bad guy craze, but apparently, not so much. :-)And don't even get me started on Charlie. She's the other unexpected surprise in this book. She is so atypical for a heroine but so honestly good that you can't help but love her. She reminds me a lot of myself when I was her age-- just very awkward and definitely not popular and sheltered, but at the same time, very firm in her beliefs.Overall, The Collector is the first terrific entry in the Dante Walker series. The characters are truly what makes this book sing-- they are unique, fascinating, and above all, likeable. Victoria Scott is an author to watch.

I was given this book by the publisher in exchange for an honest review.Too Much Blood is the second Toni Day Mystery book by Jane Bennett Munro. Toni is a pathologist who works in a small town and finds herself caught up in the mysterious death of a slimeball that enrolled most of the doctors in the town in a Ponzi scheme, which lost them most of their savings. Needless to say, plenty of people wanted this man dead. At the same time, Toni is struggling with her marriage-- it seems that her husband is drifting. Will she be able to solve the murder mystery and save her marriage at the same time?OK. I give this book props for having a lot of accurate medical details, because I'm really into that. But what sorrows me is that I really wanted this to be a book I liked, since this is my kind of genre. Unfortunately, I was seriously disappointed.I had a ton of issues with this book.1. In the very first chapter of this book, Toni's home phone rings in the middle of the night and her husband picks it up. First, what about a pager? A pager on vibrate? A cell phone? How has this never occurred to her through medical school, residency, and now her job? If I were her husband, I would have lost it much sooner.2. Toni Day is extremely nosy and a really unlikeable character. If a character is going to carry a whole set of books named after her, she'd better be someone people want to read about. I was hoping she would grow and develop over the book, but she was the main reason I couldn't finish it. She is pushy, arrogant and says the most inappropriate things like she is on the autistic spectrum. I personally would want to divorce her too.3. Toni uses the excuse that since she did the autopsy on the dead man that this gives her the right to ask all sorts of invasive questions to people she barely knows. In what universe is this okay?4. Toni looks up confidential medical information on several people who are definitely not in her care (she's a pathologist for crying out loud, she doesn't take care of live patients) in order to "solve the case." Again, HIPAA laws anyone? That is completely inappropriate and really puts doctors in a bad light, because it suggests that we think this is okay. It's NOT. People get fired for doing things like that all the time.5. Pacing. This book just could not keep my interest.In the end, I just had to put it down. Because of the unlikeable protagonist, the plot devices that just didn't make any sense, and the lack of good pacing, this book was definitely not for me.

Ok, I super like this product. I have a 4 port charger but even though this one is just 3, i will still give it 5. I am elated about this product.  I have been using the Eucerine moisturizing (heavy) cream on my 9 year old for years.  It is hard to work into the skin and is very sticky, but has been the best product I have found until now.This is a heavy lotion, not a "cream". It too is sticky, although not quite as sticky, and the feeling goes away decently fast.  Within a few hours his dryness was noticeably less.  I will continue to use this.The only thing that was crazy was the tube was so full that it kept spilling out.  I wish they would make the tube bigger.  We probably lost almost half an ounce just spilling out for the first few days.  Now it is fine, but the top is very messy from spillage.

These are right on par with cadbury fruit and nut bars.  These were so amazing.  The think I liked best is that they weren't stingy on the pistachios. I know the research is back and forth on probiotics, but my doctor told me that I might as well give it a try, as I have had stomach problems since I was a child.  I now eat 5 small meals, and one bigger meal with a daily probiotic, and I am feeling so much better.  I am a believer!My doctor also taught me to look for different probiotics.  They are naturally found in many dairy products.  These are plant based.  They seem to be better than the soy based ones. Soy based products can often cause indigestion, which they did for me. I definitely think you should give them a try.

This is perfect for your 10 year old jedi fan, or the ultimate collector.  It is basically like 20 questions in a little box.  You really have to know what they are talking about though.  Even my boys weren't quite sure many of the questions.  For the price, it would be a nice add on for Christmas, but you wouldn't want this to be their only Christmas gift.

So far this product works fine, I noticed that some had them break right away. It comes with a charger and two bits, and that is it.  I purchased one from sears a few years back and it comes with a dozen bits, a stand/case /charger in one, and it was right around 20.00. I think you want to keep looking on this item.  This is an item that we use weekly, and I want it to last.  This seemed very expensive for what I got. I would recommend to keep looking.

I have been taking this for a little while now, and I am not sure I have noticed any difference.  These are soy based, and it says to take up to three times a day, but I take them twice a day. I really like this product.  It comes with several items, including little boxes that hold all the stuff for 2 different little girls, with the idea that two best friends can use it.Pros:1 - Household items are easily obtained (baking soda, dish soap, lemon juice, water etc.)2 - Teaches you how the cool things work. (I also like that it gives you alternatives - Yellow highlighter3 - It doesn't just give you all the products, it teaches you how to make some of them (cabbage paper)4 - Well constructed kit.  Everything didn't just fall apart, and a lot is includedCons:1 - My one con is a little unfair, I will admit, I don't like that it is only marketed to girls.  Boys have the spy products, but this is one of the better kits I have seen, and it is marketed only to girls.  My boys do a lot of this secret code stuff on their own, and this would be fun to have for them too.  I don't mind it being marketed strictly to girls, but why not have a boys version too?  My boys don't mind the pink/purple, or the hearts, but almost every page in the book has just girls on it.  And it is marketed to two girls as best friends, not a boy and a girl, or two boys.

These are truly crack resistant!  At first they seem like a flimsy cup, and the material is light weight, so they will blow in the wind.  But I crushed the cup and pulled it back together several times and we have yet to crack one.  My kids tried tearing them apart, and no luck.  I am sold.  I will look for these in the super market.

Almost every single Lego book I have purchased in the past has basically been a catalog of their kits.  This is ACTUALLY an IDEA book.  At first I was a little disappointed that there were no step by step instructions, but then I thought through that.  First, it would take a lot more pages, and would either miss a golden price point because the book was too expensive, or there wouldn't be as many ideas.  I also like that it sparks creativity, instead of the step by step instructions.  The more I got into the book, the more I liked it.  It seems that Lego sets these days are built once, and put away.  I loved the Legos in my past that inspired us to create from our own minds.  This adds to that.

These are nice for throw aways.  I like these because with this pack I can just throw one in each travel bag, and one in each shower, and always have one.  They are a lot nicer than some that you buy.  They don't last really long.

These are nice, heavy duty plastic cups.  These are thicker than the standard red Kirkland or solo cups.  They don't break easy, so you can easily refill them. These are awesome! You throw these in the freezer and they keep your food cold for a good part of the day.  I noticed their have been some reviews about poor construction, and I am thinking they may have fixed that.  This seems well constructed, and with the zipper, better quality and functionality than the ones I have had in the past.The one trick with these has always been how to wash them.  You obviously can't put them in the clothes washer.  I spot wash every couple of days, and then I throw them in the dishwasher (top rack, non heat dry), and it seems to do fine.  I make sure it is not on the sanitation cycle, just a quick wash.  This isn't something the manufacturer guarantees, but it has worked for us.  I do wish they had removable gel liners though.

These surprisingly have great flavor! They were a hit with my kids.  You do have to watch because the serving size is small.  Also, we make with milk, and not water. These are not the same as the yellow ones that come in the 40 per package.  These are small, white and hard.  They are stingy, and DO NOT taste like the original ones.Skip this pack!

All of these science kits are the same.  A good booklet, and extra "junk" to put in to make the flashy box look worth the 20+ dollars you pay. But, it took the use of a smart phone, which neither had.  So I made my 7th grader lend his :)

So far so good.  I have been taking these for two weeks.  My son was put on these by his doctor and takes them off and on, exchanged with yogurt and other foods that contain similar properties and it has really helped his stomach aches.  It has helped regulate my stomach as well.  I haven't seen a huge change, but I used to take two tums every morning, and I have been able to go off of those and feel a little bit better.

These are great for the price.  I do not recommend them in a smaller size.  Really, the only ones I buy for newborns are pampers.  I then switch to huggies for size two because they hold the most.  These are the  least expensive of the big brands and are comparable in the 3s and 4s.

So happy with this mobile power pack.  This is perfect when your phone is a year old, and your battery life instantly drops to 50%.  I have now used it while hiking, biking, and at an amusement park. It is small enough to fit in your pocket, and perfect if you are ever caught without a chance to charge.Works well, no suggestions. This should be labeled NEW! It is not the old Charmin that leaves lint flying everywhere! This is a lot like Northern, but a little softer, and LOVE the mega rolls.  The rolls have gotten smaller than in the past, and the Mega is what keeps me from having to change the roll so much.

To start off, this is built so much better than the old hot wheels sets.  Those sets would come apart before you even had a chance to try them.  They have the new tongue and clip pieces to keep them together.  I do think however that if you took this apart it several times it might start to come apart easier.  This is definitely a toy that you will have to setup and store setup.  The dimensions on the website are for the box only.  I would recommend a 3 x 2 foot area for good play.The coolest part about these sets, besides going back to the old school track packs, is that you can add additional sets.  You could build a huge track.  I remember as kids we just had the track packs as kids and would set up huge racing courses. That was so fun.I will mention that this only comes with one car.  I wish it came with more, but as these are reasonably priced toys, that is okay.

This is just the absolute best grill cover ever! I have had several grill covers to try and review, and while I thought I had found the best cover on my last one, this is far superior.As with all grill covers, time will tell, but this material is just amazing.  I have loved my canvas covers, but they seem to last two seasons at most.  I have tried some of those light weight covers and they get shredded in the wind within a couple of months.  There have been some blend materials that I have loved, and we are still watching those.  This one is a heavy duty PVC with double stitching.  I will be interested to see if it loses shape in the heat, or if the stitching tears.  With the canvas, I have always had tears before the stitching breaks.This cover is dark black, so it is hot to pull off.  It is also decently heavy.  It has side mesh vents on the bottom, as well as velcro for a tight fit.We have a kenmore grill that is 58" across and this fit nicely.  I generally buy a medium grill cover, but this one fit nicely in a large.  Very happy with it.

These look terrible in the picture, but in real life they sparkle!  I absolutely love them!  They are pretty big, so they hang below the ear lobe. You can see them from quite far away.  I highly recommend them.  I am going to look for others in the same collection with similar stones.

We started off loving the Spirit Animals series.  But like the past couple of books, this one falls short.  This is a new series spinning off of the Spirit Animals.  It has a similar story line...bad guys, good guys, animals. I didn't feel like there was any one character that you fall in love with and want to follow through an adventure.  My kids also struggle as they switch off authors and writing styles from book to book.  I have two animal lovers (in fact one loves animals so much he is a vegetarian), and neither really felt interested enough to read another one in the series.I do wish this series would have resonated more with my kids.  It is so hard to find age appropriate books for advanced readers, and these are it.  If they just held their interest better.  I do hope they get better, and I will try the next one in the series.I love what another reviewer said...you don't love this book, but it isn't the worst either.  This book is for younger kids that want to read everything.
This is not in Portuguese as advertised.  This is so annoying.  This has happened more than a half a dozen times to us.  I am tired of returning these to Amazon.

First off, I love that wiper blades can be purchased as a single, because almost always one goes bad before the other, however I wish they would offer a value pack for when you do want to buy two.  I do like to keep a spare in my car.  Just the other day my SIL had one of her brand new wipers fly off her car (installed at Jiffy Lube), and she sat and waited out the storm.  At any rate, very easy to install.  The fit was perfect for our Subaru Legacy.  So far it is working great.  Time will tell on this product and I will update if my opinion changes.

This is a very nice quality game, and pretty fun.  Our problem was finding somewhere to hang it and play it the way it was intended.You are supposed to hang the plaque on the wall. One end of the string is supposed to tie to a hook on the ceiling or an overhang, then the other end of the string is tied to the ring (pictured)  You then swing the ring over and try to get it on the hook.We had intended to play this in our game room, but we have 15 foot ceilings, so that didn't work.  My kids ended up putting it in one of their rooms, but even then, they have 10 foot ceilings, so it was a trick.If you have the right ceiling, it is fun!

If I were to review these books I would give them a zero star review.  They are crass and silly, and perfect for boys in first and second grade, their target audience.  With that in mind, my kids, having loved books 1-10 (they hated 11), give it a one or two stars.  This review is composed of my children's opinions:It is boring.  (The potty jokes are actually pretty minimal in this one.  The ones that I saw in there, I don't think the kids understood.)  The book has the characters going to the future and becoming parents.  This created many adult themes that kids mentioned and didn't care about.  They don't like to think about being parents.Flip pages didn't work.  It was a good idea, but my kids tried, and they just didn't work with their smaller fingers, and such few pages.At the end of the day these books have always been written to a second grade audience.  The potty humor is great for kids, I think most adults are just thrilled their children are reading.  But in this story they go into the future, and they are grown-ups, talking about grown-up things.  My kids lost all interest.  In the past the books were about their silly escapades at school and other kid realms.  This book is touching on hot button issues that don't seem to resonate with the kids.  They are touching on going to a mental hospital, one of the characters is gay in the future, ladies are drawn in their underwear.  The themes just weren't anything my young kids relate to. I personally would rather talk to my kids about some of these things, especially mental hospitals, in a more sensitive manner.  Our world is in crisis, and it just felt like a strange arena to be touching on sensitive issues... in a potty book.**I gave it two stars, instead of one because he made a note that it was going to be more adult because of the complaints.  It was what he watned to do, it just misses the target audience.

I am a size 12 and I ordered a Large.  It really does slip you down.  I like it better than spanx, because with spanx, the tummy part always rolls over and all my tummy ends up on top of the shorts.  This has a double thick tummy band that is made out of different material.  The rest of the shorts are made out of the standard spanx type material.The only thing I didn't like were the seams. The tummy seam really showed through on some of my skirts, especially maxi skirts.  The top material didn't allow my skirts to sit quite as nice, but I really liked how well it held, so it was worth it.

This product worked great, and is all natural.  We have a pool in our backyard and are constantly trying new sunscreens.  It is supposed to be waterproof, and gives instructions of applying after 80 minutes.  We had to reapply after about 60.  You could start to see some color on the kids.  I am not sure about the 30 for babies.  Research is all over the place.  We generally use 30 for everyday use, and 50 plus at the pool.  We also didn't try this on our faces.  Most sunscreens sting, and no one was brave enough.  We use the copportone face sticks.  We are just sold on those.  Tired of stinging eyes.

I love this.  I will never buy a non ceramic iron again.  I have long, thick hair, about three inches below my shoulder (It takes over 15 minutes to dry with a blow dryer). The iron  heated quickly and I could curl a fair amount of thick hair in a quick time.  In less than five minutes I had my hair just the way I like it with heat rollers, only those don't curl evenly.  The roll function worked great, but it takes some getting used to.  You have to make sure you don't get other hair tangled up while it rolls up. It comes with a hot pad so you don't burn your hand, but I don't find that very useful.  The tip did get fairly hot which surprised me a little.I would recommend this product, I liked the large size of the barrel.  It was easy to use, and heated quickly.  While this brand of products is of high quality, I am thinking this would really just be beneficial to someone that styles hair all day long, but I am thrilled with it for every day use.Pros:Ceramic barrelSizeEven heating of hair.  Less than 30 seconds for strand to curl.Heats up in secondsElectric roll function was nice and easy.Cons:I don't really understand the heat/function buttons, but it doesn't seem to change the functionality of it.PriceI will update my review as I continue to use it.

This is a supposedly a more natural approach from Miracle Grow.  I thought from their website, and the product description it would be "organic", but they never actually say that.  You still cannot use it on the vegetables the day before, or the day of harvesting.  It is still considered a pesticide.  You still have to be careful how you treat with it, and dispose of the bottle.  It still has chemicals in it.  That being said, the stuff seems to work. I put it on some small rose plants that had aphids on them and took care of them right away.We have several beehives, and year after year our bees are taken out by pesticides.  We lose at least one hive a year.  The very best thing you can do for your plants is get some bees.  Our neighbors love it.  Their fruit production has at least doubled from the work of the bees.  You will still get bugs, and in cooler climates, you may need vitamins and things in fertilizers to beef up your plants before winter.  Having said that, it is important to be careful.  We have used a liquid soap spray on our fruit trees, some people spray oil, and try not to use anything on our plants.  Sometimes you have to, and I am glad they are making this type of product.

This was a fun little product.  I was happy to add it to the nerf arsenal. My boys feel like hawkeye on the avengers.  They tuck this in their side pocket as an extra weapon. The aim was good, but tricky for smaller hands.  8 and above was an appropriate recommendation.  There are only two bullets.  Buy more.  I was surprised it didn't come with more.  I also wish it had some kind of carrying pouch.

We own almost every nerf gun that was ever made, and this one is an average gun.  The price point is pretty low, which is good.  Most of their guns are 20+ dollars.  We prefer the disk shooters, but have several of these.  The downside is always the load and shoot one at a time.  The aim and shoot on this were poor performers.  The aim was off, and it didn't shoot very far.  I don't know if it was just ours, or what.  Also, the extension broke off in the first battle.All in all I wouldn't pick this gun unless you need a cheap birthday present.  At this price point it is a large gun, and you probably won't shoot anyone's eye out. But as for adding this to your personal arsenal, skip it.

I immediately dropped from five to four stars because of the batteries!  The next star was lost because there is almost no water storage.  You have to refill quite often, and refilling wasn't that easy.  The gun isn't very good.  The spray was okay, but after a few sprays you are out.  For this price point, it would be better to find another gun that doesn't require batteries and is easier to refiil

Love! These are soft, absorbent, and most of all they leave almost no lint. They are cute and did not bleed at all when washing your using.  These are cute to store around the kitchen and would make a nice gift in a red gift basket.  Very affordable.

My kids love the simon game.  This plays almost exactly like the big simon, if not exactly.  You can play challenge, or single.  It lights up the buttons, and you repeat the pattern.  It gets harder as you win more rounds.This is the best travel game we have, besides sorry.  There are no pieces to get lost, and it functions similar, if not the same to the real game.  The only downside is that it needs batteries.  But, easy to throw in a backpack, great for players young and old, and no lost pieces.This did come with batteries, and ours were working, but after a few hours they were dead.  It said duracell, so I am guessing that they had just been in there a while, as I don't think this game will eat batteries.  I will update if I change my mind.

Orbit has won me over with their freshness!  My boys and I went on a serious gum hunt last year and tried almost all the gum out there.  The freshest, best flavor I found was the rain 5 from wrigley.  But the sweet mint from Orbit takes the cake.  The flavor is strong, and lasts a long time.  The gum doesn't get hard for quite some time.  I am switching!For reference, the gums that we didn't love were the following:Extra - the flavor didn't last very longTrident - In the cup, the pieces didn't stay fresh, they got hard too fastTrident - packaged the same as orbit - lost the flavor quickly, but we liked the flavor

These are cute, and they work great.  These could easily be used as a kitchen dish towel. They come in so many different patterns and colors.  The green is a nice subtle color and design, but the oranges are fun and cute.The towel itself is highly absorbant, and washed up well.  It did not leave any lint when cleaning.  They are very soft, and I was surprised how thick they were.  Not as thick as a cotton towel, but I was worried they would be thin, similar to a paper towel type material.  I would highly recommend.

I do not like the wild berry skittles alone, I would much prefer the regular ones, but these two flavors blended together are my favorite!  I hope they make this pack.Each bag is like four regular sized bags.  They are not like those huge bags you get at Costco or Sam's club.

Love the hat. I have one of those heads which always falls between sizes, and this hat was no exception -- according to the measurements, my head was exactly between medium and large. Based on other people's reviews here, I went for the medium, and it turns out to have been a perfect fit.I know the chin strap is considered a selling feature, but honestly I don't like how it looks and there's no easy way to tuck it out of the way without complicated and unsightly looping around the brim. So I just removed it.Even though the hat is labeled as men's, it looks just fine on me and yesterday when I was out shopping, I received two different compliments on it.Pros: Weathered but not tattered look. Comfortable to wear and not too hot. Overall, an attractive hat that looks like it'll keep its shape, and it seems pretty durable overall.Cons: Not all might like the weathered look, and whatever one gets is going to be somewhat random. Mine looks most artificially worn near the top of the crown, but it's even and doesn't look fake or like I dumped bleach on it. Another downside is this isn't a hat I'd take where it's going to need to be crumpled, because it pretty clearly wouldn't handle that well -- the wire shaping the brim, for example, doesn't seem like it'd take being crushed that often before breaking.Overall though, this has become my new favorite hat, and it was very reasonably priced, too. Even if I only get a few years' wear from it before it needs replacing, it will have been worth it, I feel certain.

I'm a total convert to 'BoreSnake' gun cleaners now, after decades of using those screw-together aluminum rods. I've done side-by-side comparisons of cleaning guns from .17 varmint rifles to shotguns between traditional cleaning kits and the BoreSnake method -- and in every case, the BoreSnake results are faster and visibly cleaner. It's my opinion as well that it's a whole lot easier using the BoreSnake than it is to try to force cleaning patches through the smallest caliber long-guns, such as the aforementioned varmint rifle.I have noticed at times though that it can be a little rough pulling the cord through. So one thing I've done with my cleaning kit, is I've added a notched dowel rod about an inch in diameter and about four inches long. I wrap the end of the BoreSnake's cord around that and it's way easier to pull it through the barrel. Easier on my hands anyway.

Nice key holder to solve that problem of "Ow, my keys keep jabbing me in the leg." It does a nice job of holding keys securely and compactly.Pros:- Expandable from 2 to 8 keys- Includes lots of spacers and also some screw-in extenders to make change the base model from 2-4 keys up to 5 to 8 keys.Cons:- There are no instructions provided. You have to go online to find them and even then they are extremely sparse and not very clear. Basically, the idea is you need to have an even number of keys and/or spacers (or the lanyard holder) on both sides in order for the thing to screw back together again. And the stacked keys and spacers must be flush with the top of the pivots.- You cannot use any plastic-coated keys inside the unit, as they will be waaaay too wide to fit. Also, there are some keys with plastic or rubber inlays, such as one of our Kwikset keys, which doesn't fit...I had to switch to a spare one we'd had cut at the hardware store.- For the price paid, it would've been nice to have the expanders and the spacers in something other than a plain tear-open plastic bag.

Gorgeous ambient in a genre I always label "Space Music" in my collection. While I like nearly all of the tracks, I would have to say it's the first two -- One Way Voyage and Nebula -- which are my 'five star' favorites. If I had to pick "artists Dave Luxton is similar to", I'd go with Steve Roach and Jeff Pearce, with a bit of John Serrie thrown in.

Rather nice painting and a good size for the application I needed it -- to conceal an electrical access panel in a guest bedroom. It's very attractive and received a number of compliments. I deducted a star only because the mounting hooks were included separately and I had to go through some effort to figure out how and where to attach them to the wooden frame.I'll say this much: It's way better than buying a framed poster or litho-print.

The Nebo Big Magnum Larry is a really nice area/worklight that is crazy super-bright. It came with 3-AA batteries already installed and I about blinded myself when I first turned it on. I'm both surprised and impressed by the sheer lumen output of the light, which is this newer COB (chips on board) LED technology. Instead of just a point source, the whole yellow area on the front of the light shine evenly. The illustrations don't totally make it clear, but it's about 7 1/2 inches long and roughly 1 inch in diameter (wider at the light part).Pros:- Very well made out of machine-grade aluminum for all parts but the rubberized push-button switch on top and the plastic lens in front of the LED stripe.- Not kidding, on the high setting, it's like a bright lightbulb in your hand and it really floods the entire area with light.- Has three settings -- 400 lumens super-bright, 150 lumens dimmer (still enough to see by in many circumstances), and a red flashing mode (honestly, I'd trade this for three brightness settings, like 400, 200, and 100...I cannot ever see a need for a flashing red flashlight for my intended uses).- According to the box, it should be good for about 4.5 hours on high, 15 hours on low, and 40 hours on flash. That's really good for just three AA batteries.- The fact it uses standard AA batteries and not some specialized or rare type.- Magnet on the base is strong enough to hold the flashlight in a horizontal position, but it should be noted that it can slide if on a really smooth surface (learned that when I knocked it off the metal waste basket I was testing it on).Cons:- It is heavy, not the kind of flashlight one could easily carry in a shirt pocket.- Bit of a shame there isn't any kind of clip or hook on the light. It'd be awesome otherwise, and I think the only major problem with this particular flashlight. However, given the price I paid, it's not enough to consider deducting a star. (I'm thinking maybe if I could stick a metal cup-hook of some kind onto the magnet, that might do the trick for times when I need to hang the light.)- I do have some concerns that it might be possible to scratch or break the plastic lens over the LED strip. Let's just say I won't be tossing this into my toolbox.- Noticed the batteries rattle a little bit inside when the flashlight is shaken. Shouldn't be a big problem though, and the light itself doesn't flicker when I do this. Still, I might make myself a thin cardboard spacer to run down alongside the batteries to hold them a little more firmly."Just Is":- The yellow strip you see on the upper front of the flashlight is all there is, which makes this a great area worklight, but it doesn't have any kind of focusable beam LED like I've seen on some other models.Would I buy again? Absolutely, especially for the price I paid. I do a lot of computer hardware work and DIY work around the house, and this little worklight is exactly what I needed. Would I recommend it to others?
