Yes. Flashlights sure have come a long, long way since I was young...

Good story, but it looks like there are tons of defective discs still floating around out there, including the one I just ordered from Amazon Warehouse Deals (Aug 2015). The disc itself appears undamaged, but it will not play at all. My computer says there's no disc and the DVD player just sticks on 'loading' forever before eventually spitting it out.Kudos as always for Amazon's return policy, but it's disappointing to see how after so many years, the defective ones for this episode are still in circulation and being sold.

Good hard-sole moccasin, but it's taken some time to stretch them to be comfortable. I bought these in my normal size and found them to be a little bit pinchy on the sides. In general though, the size (in length) seems about right.Basically, I've tried other brands, but I keep coming back to Minnetonka, because even when they're not totally perfect, they're still better than any other mocs I've ever worn.

Hopefully this is reasonably accurate, but the meter arrived with dead batteries, which weren't that cheap to replace. On the other hand, the numbers it read from the well water and rain water I needed to test appeared to be about right, so I can't complain too much. Nevertheless, shipping with dead batteries is why I rated at one star only.If there's a chance of discharge, the batteries should've been protected by a removable plastic tab or something.Update: 21 July 2015 -- The seller reached out to me and sent me replacement batteries. As a consequence, I've upgraded this particular review from 1 star to 3. The main reason for not going higher than 3 is the TDS Meter is rather cheaply made, not the seller's fault, just an example of 'you get what you pay for' -- which in this case isn't a whole lot. But at least it works and I have some replacement batteries now.

Easy, hassle-free home lighting automation in a box -- and at a decent price. I'll be honest and admit I had no great desire for app-enabled part of the Hue system. I do not carry my smartphone with me all the time. This, plus the extra light switch unit seemed too much money for no real added convenience.But pair this with an Amazon Echo? "Alexa. Office lights, sixty percent." "Okay." Instant techno-squee. (If Amazon ever adds Hue's 'Scenes' support to the Echo, it'll be perfection.)The other nice thing about the Hue hub system is many other lights and devices appear to be compatible with it, including the very affordable GE Link LED bulbs. I started with just the two bulbs in this set. Then added two more Lux bulbs for my Tiffany-style desk lamp. Then added several GE Link bulbs in other lamps and light fixtures. I think we're up to ten bulbs total now, and Alexa can control them all. I love it.One day I might add some of the actual Hue bulbs to the setup...but for now, just having voice-controlled lighting is awesome. As for the Hue unit itself, setup was dead easy. Plug it in, pair it with the lights and name them, create some scenes for group light control. The one suggestion I have is to add just one light at a time -- the hub seems to get confused when several bulbs are attempting to pair at the same time. The only complaint I have/had is the included instructions do not make it clear that in order to complete the setup, you MUST go to the Google Play or Apple App store and download (and use) the Hue app. The app is also required when adding more lights to your setup. The hub's blue LEDs are kind of bright, too...probably best to hide it somewhere out of sight. You also need to have a home network to use this product (as in, the hub needs to be plugged into your router).Pros:- Easy setup (once you have the app installed and running)- Seems quite good at finding new lights when we add them, but sometimes it's necessary to press the pairing button on the hub- Very good, natural light color from the Lux bulbsCons:- Not clear at all from the instructions you have to have the app- Can't control your lights if your home network is down, but it does seem you can at least turn on/off your lights from the switch they're already on- If you have a very large house, there might be hub range issues (although we haven't encountered these, as our place isn't that big)Wish list:- Wish they had a brighter A19 style bulb. These emulate an old-style 60w incandescent and are bright enough for that, but in some places it'd be nice to have a 100w equivalent, as in a 15w LED type.- Wish the Hue bulbs and LED strips were less expensive.

As I've remarked in other food-related reviews, taste is subjective. Chances are you'll either really like the Shin Noodle Black or really not like it. I fall into the former category. I found a case of this instant soup at our local Costco about six months ago...and then never again. Found individual cups available at our local grocery store...and balked at the ridiculous price for it. We're talking nearly four bucks for a single cup.To heck with that -- I looked on Amazon and almost instantly added two cases of six cups each to our bi-monthly Subscribe & Save list.In terms of portion, this is a rather hearty size, larger than the usual instant noodle cup, although it may look like less of a portion because the dried noodles only come up to the halfway point or so in the cup. There are two 'flavoring' packets to be added before the boiling hot water. Although the fill line is only around the point of the dividing line between the top black stripe and the middle red one, I usually fill to within a half inch of the top -- just because I like the broth. It's rich, spicy, and flavorful...and light years better tasting than the usual chicken or beef-flavored (emphasis on the 'flavored' part) instant noodle cups.I also rather like the fact the cups aren't styrofoam, but waxed cardstock.For what it's worth, if the cost is still too much, there are less expensive Nonshim Noodle Cups, with smaller portions and just one flavor packet. Tastes almost as good...but I like to splurge a bit on these Black cups instead.

Got expensive drill bits for drilling into metal? Buy this cutting oil. Not only does it help to protect the drill bits and hole cutters, it also makes the drilling go faster.We bought a set of cobalt bits for putting up a metal pipe-frame structure, because much of it required putting in so-called 'self-tapping' screw-bolts -- where the 'self-tapping' part was a joke, especially on curved steel pipes. The cutting fluid/oil made a world of difference for drilling pilot holes.I also used the CRS 03400 on some Greenlee hole cutters for going through the side of a steel building and it helped a lot. The nice thing about this cutting fluid over 3-in-1 or other cutting oils I've used in the past is this is nice and thick and will stay on the drill bit pretty decently. Definitely recommended.

Tired of plastic bag clips always breaking, we decided to get these Mighty Clips -- and glad for it. They're made of pretty thick metal and the springs are very firm. Good variety of sizes, too. My only small complaint is some might find the edges a little sharp or hard. Still, hard to beat the price and we'll never have to replace these clips.

Good bright lantern, really lights up a room, even at just 180 lumens. My only quibble is you have to slide the cover all the way up to get at the switch. The other minor annoyance is the batteries were tricky to get in right. Otherwise though, a good combo flashlight/lantern at a good price. Would buy again.

Although a little more uneven than Season 1, the second season of Frisky Dingo heads an entirely different direction.At the end of Season 1, Killface -- or rather his son -- attempted to destroy the Earth by flinging it into the sun, by way of a gigantic rocket motor. Well, the plan failed and instead the planet was moved a few feet away from the sun...coincidentally solving the problem of global warming. (Not at all what Killface had in mind.)As one might surmise from the DVD cover, Killface decides to use his accidental fame and run for President of the United States. Weirdness and hilarity ensue.The only sad part is Season 2 is where the Frisky Dingo saga comes to an end. The planned 'Xtacles' spinoff show never came to be. Still, glad to have this as part of my collection.

As with many, I ended up checking out Frisky Dingo as a fan of the FX series "Archer". The odd animation in FD can take some getting used to, but the story is laugh-out-loud funny. I'd watched some episodes via streaming, but as soon as I saw the discs here on Amazon, I just had to get them.The only odd detail I'd like to mention is the DVD menus are a little weird and it's not totally obvious there's a 2nd page of episodes. I watched the first bunch, then skipped along to the second disc without realizing I'd left out a bunch. Anyway, the narrative discrepancy and "Previously, on Frisky Dingo" summary clued me in.

Floppy, vaguely tacky to the touch, no easy means of sticking it to a counter...  I suppose this seam cover might be okay in a laundry room or something, but it ended up being something I didn't want attached to the counter next to our new GE electric glass-top range. Not pleased with this particular purchase, just glad I did not waste too much money on it. We'll have to find some other means of closing that gap. Might do it with a custom piece of hardwood or something.

Really good desk-drawer or glovebox flashlight. I'm kind of surprised this hasn't been around before, but it's a great concept. Take a 9v battery. Put a flashlight attachment on top of it. Simple, elegant, and handy.In this case, the switch is a simple mechanical one, so there's not much that can go wrong with it. And, when the battery wears out, which will take a very long time given the low draw of LEDs and the high capacity of the average 9v battery, it's simple to replace it.I would definitely buy this again.

Good suction and cleaning, like the no-bag part, but there's one critical design problem with the Dirt Devil Featherlight Cyclonic: If you pick up the cannister, it is very, very easy to have the dirt collector come off in your hand and the cannister part fall to the ground. I was up on a ladder trying to clean the tops of pot-shelves with this vacuum when twice the collector came off and I nearly broke things as the heavier motor part fell to the floor.Pros:- Cleans very well- The handle has a very long reach, with a telescoping metal part- Spring-loaded auto-retracting cord storageCons:- The aforementioned problem with the dirt collector coming off too easily (seriously, there should be a lock button or lever or something).- Unit is fairly heavy despite the 'Featherlite' moniker- The utility tool caddy on the handle gets in the way far more than is useful for anything other than storage when not in useWould I buy again? Perhaps. For the price, at least it got the job done. But I'm not crazy about the separation issue.

Our old canvas bags were still sturdy enough, but grocery store baggers *hated* them because they wouldn't stand up at all. The Simply Green bags aren't quite as thick on the fabric, but they make up for it in convenience and the fact the bags will stand open even while empty. Plus our bright purple bags never fail to draw compliments.It looks like the bags themselves will fold flat two different ways. One is with the bottom V-ing up, and the other with the bottom folding over. Either way, a stack is nice and flat and easy to handle.The nice thing about the 10-pack is we have PLENTY of bags.

The GE Links are really great 'smart/connected home' LED bulbs at a very good price from Amazon. After they added home automation connectivity to the Amazon Echo, I just had to add some lights. The Philips Lux starter set is okay, but the main thing I wanted from it was the hub, which is capable of controlling more lights than just Philips Hue or Lux. The GE Link bulbs were found by the hub without a problem and the color and brightness of them is really good.Just know that you *will* need a hub controller of some kind to run these. GE sells their own 'SmartThings' hub, but as I said the Hue hub works, too. I really like being able to ask Alexa (the Echo) to turn the lights on or off, set brightness and so on.

Gets the job done, nothing fancy though. Clamping the cable can be a bit tricky because the thumb screw isn't very precise. But basically you clamp the cable, squeeze the cutter with one hand to bring the cutting disk into contact with the cable, and give the handle a few turns until it spins freely. After that, you can slide the cut metal part off the end of the cable.Main caveats as I saw them are twofold: (1) After cutting, you have to slide the outer cladding off the end of the cable; there's no way to remove the cladding from the middle of a line. (Not sure why one would want to do this, but I just thought I'd mention it.) (2) The edge in the cladding left behind can be jagged and sharp. Best to have a pair of pliers to bend or cut it or a file to smooth it out

The Melita #2 natural brown is a really good filter for pour-through coffee. Does the job and is compostable, which was a requirement for me. Only advice I have for folks not familiar with these kinds of filters or using a pour-through cone is you HAVE to fold at the creases or else risk a seam rupture and a ruined mug of extra lumpy coffee. First fold the bottom edge just above the pressed-seal crease, then fold the side at that crease. Put into the cone and fill with appropriate amount of fresh ground coffee. (I have a large mug; for me it's 3 1/2 scoops.)For the best coffee, drizzle not-quite-boiling water over the grounds until they're reasonably wet, then pour a bit at a time, taking care not to flood the grounds too much. Seeing a light layer of foam appear on top of the grounds is a good thing. Keep pouring a bit at a time until you're done.

I needed a set of lag screws and tar pads to install a tripod mount at the peak of our metal roof and these were perfect for the job. I did drill some pilot holes to start with, but the screws went in just fine and securely. And with the tar pad, I feel confident the holes I just put into my roof won't leak. My only advice would be to be sure you can order these via Prime or otherwise free shipping, because they're worth what I paid (about six bucks) but not more than that.

We needed a good sturdy and stable mount to move a WAN WiFi receiver from a dormer roof up to the peak, in preparation for installing solar panels on a nearby garage which was going to otherwise block the receiver. Further complicating matters is we have a fairly steep-pitched metal roof. This tripod mount seems to have been perfect for the job, with the L-shaped feet able to rotate so as to lay flat against the slope, with one leg on one side of the roof and two legs on the other. I had been worried I might have to bend the feet to fit the roof, but that turned out not to be the case.The construction of the mount is solid and the brass nuts at the middle and top allow for pretty easy leveling of the post once installed. The post itself is steel apparently, which meant I was able to just use a small magnetic bullet level for that part. It was a little fussy to get the post perfectly vertical, but not that bad. You might need a wrench to loosen them a bit to start with.If installing permanently like I was doing, you will need mounting bolts, and in our case we wanted a some protection and sealing. For that reason, I also ordered the 'Ambient Weather EZ-46-3 Tar Pad Kit for Roof Tripod Installation', which comes with six appropriately sized lag screws and three tar pads to go between the tripod legs and the roof. The whole thing took me maybe 30 minutes to install and it seems really solid.

I've had my Echo since February, and it's just become part of my home office. From news, music, weather reports or general information, Alexa is just right there. I've already forgotten how to set our oven timer because I just ask Alexa to tell me when the time is up. Amazon has been on top of adding new functions, too, although to be fair there's still a ways to go yet.Pros:- Very good news and weather summaries, and they just added Google Calendar integration and Audible books reading- Increasing integration with other 'smart home' devices...makes me want to buy a WiFi thermostat just to be able to ask Alexa to change the temperature for me- Excellent support for streaming music, including Amazon Prime music, Pandora, iHeart, etc.- For the most part, the Echo is pretty good at hearing what I'm saying, even when music is playing- Good overall sound from the Echo unit itself- Love both the timer and alarm functions (but needs multiples of these, not just one of each)Cons:- I so want a second unit for the bedroom, and my spouse wants one too, but we can only have the one so far.- The To Do and Shopping lists are really limited, in that you can only have one of each. Sorry, but I have work-related To Do items and household, and my shopping lists are usually specific to the store involved.- The Bluetooth connectivity is sometimes wonky, and only goes in the direction of Device --> Echo. In other words, if you pair your phone or computer to the Echo, the Echo can play your transmitted music, but it can't do things like sending your streaming Prime music back to your computer or Bluetooth-enabled stereo receiver, nor can it operate your phone to make hands-free calls.- Amazon needs to continue to do work to improve the general questions recognition. Very often I'll ask a rather plain question and I know if I were to type it into Google or Bing, I'd get a sensible result -- but Alexa says, "I'm sorry, I can't understand that request." Still, it's not bad.Wants:- Really wish the Echo had a small LED display just to show status, current time, perhaps even current timer or alarm settings- As I indicated, it'd be great if the Bluetooth was more advanced and able to push audio and/or to operate as a phone hands-free device

Very quiet fan on the lowest settings. Price may be more than some are willing to spend. I deducted one star for three reasons. First, although well-built in my opinion and easy to assemble, I should think the Rowenta table fan should be around fifty or sixty bucks and this floor fan around eighty or ninety-ish. However, after having read the reviews and having had personal experience with the usual cheap floor fans on discount, I decided to spend more and hope for better results.Quiet is very important to me, so much so when I built my computer, I used ultra-quiet components and sound-insulated the case. I hate loud fans. For example, I have an older model Vornado circulator fan (280SS, which isn't made any more...a real shame), bought back when they still had the (almost) infinitely variable speed dial; it's a good fan, has lasted forever, and I like how much air it can move, but I don't like how noisy it is. In this respect, the Rowenta is clearly the most quiet I've owned, particularly on the lowest two speed settings. On the highest or on Turbo-mode, yes, it's going to be loud, but that's to be expected.The second reason I deducted a star is because the assembly instructions were very difficult to locate. I finally found them wedged between the two halves of the wire fan-cage, which was in a semi-opaque plastic bag which made the instructions even less obvious to find. The assembly instructions should be the first thing you see when you open the box.A remaining reason for the one star deduction was their not bothering to include a couple of AAA batteries for the remote. C'mon, a fan like this at a premium price ought to come with the batteries.Pros:- Well-packaged and arrived undamaged -- product box inside another sturdy brown cardboard box (probably would've sufficed for shipping, but Amazon went ahead and put this inside yet another box, along with a couple other items I'd ordered).- Really heavy and sturdy pancake-shaped base, unlikely for the fan to tip over unless you plow into it.- Good construction quality in general, although the fan blades seem flimsy...but I'm sure that's part of what helps make it more quiet than other fans. Other than that though, nothing about the fan looks cheap.- I like the goose-neck design, so that you can see the controls from any angle, even standing at the fan. Too many fans I've owned either put them on the front (meaning you'll have to crouch or bend over to see them) or else on top, in which case you can't see them unless you're looking down right at the fan.- Remote control (alas, the remote doesn't turn the swivel on/off, which would've been really nice).- Significantly less expensive than a Dyson (which, to be honest, I actually found rather loud the last time I checked them out).Cons:- Expensive. A bit more expensive, in my opinion, than the fan is worth, but I needed a quiet, decent quality pedestal fan and there weren't any others which I felt met my needs and required quality standards.- Probably doesn't move as much air as other fans, due to the attempts to make it more quiet.- For obvious reasons, I wouldn't recommend this or any other pedestal fan for homes with small children or large unruly pets, although in terms of being 'tippy', this fan is far less so than most.- Some might not like the beep the fan makes when changing settings, and there's a blue LED which could bother some (but this latter could be taken care of with some electrical tape easily enough, or even just some colored plastic).Observations & hints:- Ultra-quiet on the lowest setting (just the air movement and a little bit of a hum), pretty quiet on the 2nd (louder whoosh, and the sound I refer to as 'plane prop' just barely evident). Significantly louder at high and turbo, but not quite as noisy as most fans I've heard; still I doubt I'll be using those settings often, except maybe for a minute or two if I need an urgent cool-down after working outside.- To maximize the quietness, don't put the fan too near objects or walls which can interfere with the airflow (thus making it uneven because turbulence = noise). Also, it's not going to seem super quiet if you're right up next to it. Halfway across a room though, on low, I can barely hear it; the refrigerator is actually significantly louder.- The fan base does not have wheels, meaning it's not really intended to be portable. It sits flat on the floor on three rubber feet, under the heavy circular base. If on a hardwood or fancy stone floor, I'd recommend putting a rug or something like that under it to avoid marks or scratching due to the fan vibration.- The instructions say not to engage/disengage the swivel motion while the fan is on. Makes sense. Also makes sense never to try to move the fan or adjust the fan positioning while it is running. That's just asking for trouble. My suggestion is if planning to move the fan to another room would be to (1) unplug the fan, (2) loosen the knob attaching the fan head and assembly to the base and remove it entirely, (3) carry the base and fan head ass'y to the other room separately, and (4) reassemble in place, then plug it in.- The knob that holds the fan blade assembly to the motor shaft is reverse threaded (meaning lefty-tighty, righty-loosey, opposite the normal directions). Just something to keep in mind when assembling or disassembling the unit.Summary: If you want a good quality and nice-looking pedestal fan, one which is really rather quiet compared to its competitors, the Rowenta VU5551 is a good choice. On the other hand, if quiet isn't important to you and you want to save some money, some of the less expensive fans may suit better, but the 'you get what you pay for' maxim comes into play.

The more I've used my Fire TV stick, which I originally purchased last year during its $20 intro price for Prime customers, the more I've come to like it. I use it for Amazon programming (mainly Prime and free, but occasionally purchased on-demand series like The Walking Dead and Orphan Black), as well as Netflix and Plex. The picture and sound are quite good and the user interface pretty easy to maneuver within. Not long ago, I upgraded to a new Kindle Fire and have been discovering the benefits of the integration between the two devices.More recently, I was on a vacation and although the hotel where I stayed was pretty decent, its TV left much to be desired. It was an older non-smart model paired with a Comcast cable box that displayed a totally mismatched resolution. In the past, I would've just plugged in one of my media sticks and watched some videos from that -- but this TV wouldn't support that either. I'd just tossed the Fire TV stick into my suitcase on impulse at the last second, but was happy to see it worked just fine with this not-new-enough-or-smart-enough television. Even more impressive was the fact it was able to connect to the hotel wifi and stream through it. I think there were just two times when the message popped up about there not being quite enough bandwidth for good streaming, but these were both at bad times of the evening; before long again, all was fine and I was able to entertain myself with MY viewing choices, not just what was available on squish-distorted viewing via the cable box. All I can say is if you do want to take it on the road with you, don't forget the power adapter and remote control.Personally, my feeling is the best value in having the Fire TV stick is when you also have Amazon Prime, because it opens up the whole Prime library for viewing or listening.

Did not work at all. I know I wired it correctly, both in and out, and it doesn't do anything. The strip comes on at full brightness and doesn't move from there. I double and triple-checked the in and out lines. When I connected an in-line dimmer (plastic, with the knob), it the LED strip dimmed just fine.Not worth sending back, however.

Pretty nice tablet stand with only a few drawbacks. I've been wanting a tablet stand for a while now, ideally one that holds the tablet up high enough so that I can have the power cord plugged in from the bottom (check) and to be adjustable (check). I do still have one of those leather folding covers that if you futz with it can hold a tablet at an angle -- but only in landscape mode and in that position, it can't be plugged in to the charging/data cable.I rather like the adjustability of the Aleratec mount, especially how the tablet can be positioned in a variety of angles and rotations (including portrait or landscape). The mount arm also rotates on the bottom base, although it's not a terribly useful feature. The large disk shape that sets on the back of the tablet is actually a hand-hold with an adjustable velcro strap on the back.As I said in the title, yes, this does fit the Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.5 tablet, but you have to use the larger of the two sets of rubber holders, and it does take a little more work to get them around the opposite corners of the tablet.Pros:- Highly adjustable and clearly will work with a wide variety of tablet sizes- Pretty sturdy and will hold a tablet at a good height- I could easily see pairing this with a Bluetooth keyboard and mouse for travel and basically having a fairly light computer availableCons:- It can be tricky getting the rubber straps around the corners of some tablets- As the two-star reviewer noted, the stand can't be folded down to a flat position, which would've been nice if it had been possible- The unit (stand plus mount) is going to be heavier in many cases than the tablet they're meant to hold...which makes it not terribly travel-friendly- On a tablet the size of the Galaxy Tab 10.5 (or similar), the holder is rather close to the middle of the back of the tablet, which could make long use somewhat uncomfortable- No way to set the tablet down flat and have it be usable that way without removing the holder first- I wouldn't expect to be able to do a whole lot of touch-screen action with the tablet in the stand because while sturdy, it's not that sturdy. Repeated touches cause it to start to wobble. However, it's probably okay for turning pages in an e-book.Would I buy this again? Sure -- I got a terrific deal via an Amazon Lightning Deal on it a few days ago and it was certainly worth what I paid at the time. It does something I need. However, I can already tell it's not going to be a 100% replacement for the leather cover I normally use. So I 'Like' the stand-mount, but I don't 'love' it. I think one thing that would've taken me over that line would have been if there was a way to use the mount without the holder on the back. I'm actually giving some thought to how I might add a shelf to the arm, so that I could just set the tablet on it easel-style.

In the introductory section on opposing commanders in his latest book, The Naval Battles for Guadalcanal 1942, naval historian Mark Stille makes an important point: [Japanese Admiral] "Yamamoto never realized that Guadalcanal was the decisive battle that he had been seeking." This cuts to the heart of the matter, in regards to the months-long battle for naval superiority around Guadalcanal in 1942. While the United States Navy treated this area as a priority for resources, Imperial Japan nickled and dimed their forces in the region, and were defeated piece-meal. Readers familiar with the author's other volumes on US and Japanese battleships, cruisers and destroyers will find familiar threads here, but no redundancies. The section on opposing fleets is beautifully written, providing just the right level of detail and insight. The Japanese had better torpedoes and night tactics, but the US advantage in radar was increasingly important. As usual, the author's text is complemented by stunning period photographs of the warships involved. The author also uses his intimate knowledge of  naval operations and technology to good advantage, explaining how things happened and why. After the obligatory introductory sections, the volume is sub-divided into the five major naval actions near Guadalcanal fought between August - November 1942. I like the fact that he provides a specific order of battle for each action and a map, which makes each action very easy to follow. The artwork by Howard Gerrard is good and highlights key moments in the battles. The author's battle descriptions are superb and I like the fact that he points out mistakes made by each side, such as failing to report contacts or communications problems - this is the kind of detail that often shapes the outcome. Although all these battles were essentially gun/torpedo actions, the author concludes that it was US airpower (in preserving Henderson Field) that determined the campaign's outcome. American and Japanese battleships met in battle for the first time off Guadalcanal, but only in one action of the five actions. As the author notes, the appearance of the Yamato and Musashi off Guadalcanal might have made a major difference in the outcome, since US battleship strength was still much inferior to the Japanese. Given what we know about how much punishment these ships could take, it is doubtful that a dozen dive-bombers from Henderson Field could have seriously damaged a Yamato-class battleship. Had the Japanese Navy made a major effort, with air support, the US offensive in the Solomons might have been temporarily halted. Yet therein we come back to the author's observation about Yamamoto - the Japanese commander did not recognize the moment for decisive action had arrived.

Over the past several decades, the historiography of the American Civil War has been taken over by eager amateurs/buffs, who are often passionate about some aspect of the conflict. Indeed, we have been bombarded by an unending avalanche of new studies on the American Civil War, that cover heretofore neglected aspects, such as women in the war or the economic aspects of the war. There have also been many new books on battles and campaigns, although most have a worrying level of sameness, in discussing Regiment X attacking Regiment Y. Actual military analysis on the operational level of the Civil War has been Missing in Action. This new account, by authors Clayton and James Donnell, on the famous Shenandoah Campaign of 1862, is clearly an effort to deliver an operational-type summary of the series of battles between "Stonewall" Jackson and a coterie of Federal armies led by political dilettantes. Typically, this campaign is presented as a great triumph for the Confederacy and proof of Jackson's genius. On the surface, this is an attractive study, with some nice color plates and 3-D BEV maps, but the actual level of military detail is anemic and the level of analysis swims only in the sea of blatantly obvious. Thus, if you generally like how current Civil War history is written, then this volume should satisfy you, but if you are looking for insight, it won't. The authors spend the first third of the volume with introductory and background material. I was let down to see space wasted on basics like the Union defeat at First Bull Run, Scott's Anaconda Plan, Lincoln's call for volunteers, etc. This part of the volume appears written for people with almost no prior knowledge of the Civil War and is too basic for Osprey readers, most of whom likely already have other volumes on the Civil War. Having written many volumes in the campaign series myself, I know that space is at a premium and that you have to focus laser-like on your subject in order to deliver and you can't waste space on fluff. There is too much fluff here. The section on opposing forces is remarkably bland and the authors would have best focused on a few individual units to provide some detail about typical unit strengths, level of experience, etc. Once the authors get into the campaign narrative per se, the pace picks up a bit, but essentially the tale is told on two levels: (a) operational-level communications between commanders and their subordinates and (b) tactical-level movements on the battlefield. The authors feel the need to discuss many letter-writing exchanges in some detail, when a simple sentence on the results would have sufficed. As usual in Civil War books, the text regales the reader with tales of regiments advancing hither and yon, occasionally firing a volley and then one side or the other retreats. The better efforts at military history don't settle for this banal method, which tells us nothing about the who, how or why of a battle, but this account settles for just that standard. They don't even bother to provide information on strengths engaged or casualties for all the actions described, and given the few regiments involved, should have been able to provide more breakdown on individual unit losses. Logistical issues are also given short shrift. Readers may wonder why Stonewall even won some of these actions, since his tactical performance was more hit-or-miss. Indeed, I believe that Stonewall may be the most over-rated commander of the American Civil War and he was lucky to make his reputation early in the war and against the Union's third-string generals. Far from winning out-numbered, the Donnell's point out that he actually had numerical superiority in most of these battles, except Kernstown (which he lost). The author's contention that Jackson's Valley Campaign had major impact on McClellan's Peninsula Campaign is very contentious (after all, even Jackson left the valley to go help save Richmond,rather than make a feint toward Washington as Lincoln feared). The fact is that Mclellan's campaign failed because of his lack of fighting spirit, rather than due to events in the valley. Overall, a rather so-so volume and not up to the caliber of even earlier Osprey Civil War campaigns. It will please if you really like the Civil War and are a voracious reader of all things concerning it, but it lacks quality and detail as a piece of military history. Unless you have a short attention span, readers would be better advised to read Peter Cozzen's book, instead.

The Battle of Manzikert in 1071 is one of those events that echoes through the halls of history, yet there are not a lot of books written about it. As typical of Medieval warfare, there are limited primary sources on this battle and what exists is not exactly replete with military details. Dr. David Nicolle, Osprey's resident Medieval Mideast specialist, handles Manizkert in his usual erudite fashion. As is his bent, the volume is full of cultural and political insight, but very sparse in terms of military details. For example, the back cover of the book states that, "much of the fabled Varangian Guard was killed [at Manzikert]" but they are never mentioned once in this volume. While the author does provide a general lay-down for the Battle of Manzikert, the level of detail is minimal and his exposition on how the Byzantines were defeated is based heavily upon conjecture. Thus, for a book about a major battle, Manzikert 1071 is a great disappointment. The first one-third of the book covers the general political-cultural situation in the Near East in the mid-Eleventh Century. Only bits and pieces of this lengthy discussion are useful for understanding the battle itself and the rest is just long-winded digressions on Islamic cultural issues. The section on opposing armies says essentially nothing that is useful for understanding the forces or tactics used by either side. The only section with any merit is opposing plans, which at least points out that the Turks were more focused on Fatimid Egypt than the Byzantines. A lot of the content is incomprehensible - photos of the Great Mosque in Isfahan, or modern Turks fishing in the Bosporus or scenes of the Crucifixion - I just don't get what this adds other than useless filler. On the other hand, the author does provide some really nice photos of fortresses in the Mideast and he should really consider doing a coffee table book on that subject. As the battle approaches, the author's narrative does become a bit more focused, but the reader will sense that important pieces are missing (like the strength and disposition of the opposing forces).  The artwork by Christa Hook adds very little to the volume. The 3-D BEV maps are decent and allow the reader to follow the author's version of the battle, but again, the events are very generalized. The author doesn't even bother to speculate about Byzantine losses at Manzikert and there is no attempt at military analysis of the battle. Instead, the author seems satisfied that the Turks won and that's good enough for him. He believes that it was not the battle that hurt the Byzantine Empire so badly but the civil war that followed, although he has little to say about that. This section desperately needed expansion and a full discussion to place the battle in its proper historical context, but he seemed eager just to wash his hands of this nasty, brutish battle and move back to discussing Islamic culture. There is more in this volume about raki, a Turksh drink, than there is about the Varangian Guard. I love it in the Battlefields Today section when he mentions that visiting modern Iran is "far more straightforward than is generally realized," but he didn't mention that you would not be able to use a credit card because of sanctions. Minor detail.  Like all the others he omitted.

I wish that the U.S. film industry would learn some lessons about how to make an excellent character-driven drama from the Australian Film Industry. In Beneath Hill 60, the Australians continue to demonstrate the art of fine film making. It is not about non-stop special affects or ridiculous love triangles, but developing characters so that they seem like real human beings. Even though the film focuses on an Australian Tunneling Company at the Battle of Messines Ridge in June 1917, where thousands died, the film manages to evoke empathy for each character and deaths are thus more painful. The story is dramatic and well told, of how the Australian company assisted in completing a tunnel underneath a key German position on Messines Ridge. Interestingly, the film also depicts several German characters and their attempts to detect and defeat the Australian tunneling effort, so there is a cat 'n mouse aspect which adds tension to the film as well. There are some cliches in the film, such as displaying British senior officers as pompous and careless with men's lives, or the father-son team that you just now will end in tragedy. Nevertheless, Beneath Hill 60 is an excellent war film and succeeds in highlighting an aspect of the First World War (tunneling) that has not been covered in any detail before.The film starts with the entrance of Lieutenant Woodward to the Australian mining company, presumably in early 1916. Initially not like \d by the senior non-com, Sergeant Fraser, Woodward eventually wins the men's loyalty by his caring attitude, technical competence and willingness to stick his neck out for his men. This aspect of the film is basically a primer on effective small unit leadership. Once all doubts are removed, Woodward (now captain) leads the company on the next asssignment to Messines Ridge. I was a bit surprised how the company was depicted - always the same 8-10 men and the unit can all move in one truck. The film mentions briefly that hundreds of men are working on the tunneling project and surely Woodward's company had more men, but they simply aren't depicted. It's also odd that he has no second-in-command (CPT McBain appears, but is commander of another outfit). The film goes to great lengths to depict how tuneling was done and the difficulties of dealing with the wet clay around Ypres. Viewers may not understand why the British/Australians were going to all this effort, since the film really doesn't discuss previous efforts to dislodge the Germans from this terrain. While the frequent flashbacks to Woodward's past in Australia are useful, a flashback that explained the missing "why tunnel?" aspect of the film might have been useful for viewers.The final part of the film focuses on Woodward's efforts to complete the project before the Germans discover it. One German sergeant is depicted as identifying the Allied tunnel and makes a last-minute effort to destroy it. As with most Australian film efforts, the quality of the cinematography is gernerally excellent - they have a talent for displaying wide tableaus. The combat scenes are generally good, particularly an early effort to destroy a German machinegun position. Some scenes - such as the final detonation of the mine and the British bombardment - are a bit underwhelming. The special affects - such as artillery explosions - are not that realistic and look like TV affects. In the First World War, soldiers differentiated between mortars, light artillery and really heavy artillery and acted differently, based upon the particular weapon's lethality. Like most movies, the actors run around like wet hens whenever any shell lands in the area. I think that both All Quiet on the Western Front and the Price of Glory addressed this issue more realistically. It would also be great if film's like this tried to use more "soldier dialogue" specific to the time period - read any account of the Western Front and they are loaded with jargon, but the films avoid it. Jargon could be explained to the audience by using the "new guy" as a device to explain lingo. Without the soldier jargon, it's sort of like the film Troy's efforts to depict Ancient Greeks with all references to the gods removed.Nevertheless, an excellent film and well worth watching.

Aside from the German victory at the Battle of Tannenberg in 1914 and the legendary mismanagement of Tsar Nicholas II, the Eastern Front in the First World War has barely been covered in English-language historiography.  Norman Stone's book, the Eastern Front 1914-1917, was a landmark book when it appeared nearly four decades ago and still remains one of the best available baseline narratives on this topic. By design, Stone's book is a survey account and it tends to view events from the Russian perspective, although he is even-handed with the Germans and Austrians. Throughout the book, the author makes great effort to expose oft-repeated canards about the Eastern Front, particularly the claim that Russia's economy was too backward to sustain a modern war. The book is divided into thirteen chapters and begins with a discussion of the army in the Tsarist state (oddly though, he makes no mention of its role in regime protection). Contrary to the stereotype about Russians officers deriving solely from the aristocracy, Stone reveals that about 40 percent actually came from peasant or lower middle class backgrounds. Unfortunately, the regime did not know how to make best use of its human material. It is also evident that Tsarist Russia was never capable of harnessing Russia's vast pool of manpower in the manner that the Soviet state achieved in the Second World War. The Tsarist Army was also dominated by a backward-looking cavalry elite who resisted technological and doctrinal changes, to the detriment of Russia's military effectiveness. In particular, the author notes the devotion to spending the bulk of the army's modernization funds in 1906-1914 on upgrading fortress artillery at the expense of field artillery. In the chapters on the campaigns of 1914, the author exposes the inherent inability of the Stavka (Supreme Headquarters) to conduct effective operational-level planning or even to coordinate multiple fronts. Indeed, the primitive state of Russian C2 in 1914 was criminal. The Russians did perform well against the Austrians, who were even more poorly led. Several chapters cover the campaigns of 1915, culminating in the Russian retreat from Poland. As the author continually hammers home, the Russian soldiers were not as poorly-armed at this stage of the war as often portrayed, but the real problem was incompetent senior level leaders in 1914-1915. This did begin to change in 1916, when military technicians such as Brusilov were finally given a chance to show what well-led Russian armies could achieve. The author covers the Serbian front in passing, but devotes a complete chapter to the Romanian Front. He does discuss deliberations in the German and Austrian war councils, but at a high level. He spends a chapter on the Russian war economy which was very difficult to digest. His points about the impact of inflation on the Russian war economy were certainly germane, but since inflation affected the war economies of each combatant, I could not really discern what was unique for Russia in this regard. He did make clear that Russia's preference for foreign arms deals was a huge mistake. My only real disappointment was that the author's narrative drops off suddenly in early 1917. Although he devotes a chapter to the Russian Revolution, he does not discuss revolutionary agitation in the Russian army or navy, or the disintegration of military discipline. Several major events, like the German capture of Riga and the Kerensky Offensive are completely omitted. Nor is there any real discussion of air warfare on the Eastern Front, naval operations or the Russian war against the Turks in the Caucasus. Thus, the perspective is narrower than it should be and fails to capture key facets of Russia's war. In short, this is a good but dated history, in urgent need of expansion and revision. It should suffice for readers seeking an affordable and easily-accessible introduction to its subject, but will fall short for readers in need of greater detail.

The Battle of Salerno in September 1943 is one of those battles of the Second World War that has really never found a niche, like D-Day, Guadalcanal or El Alamein. Even among the battles fought in Italy, Salerno tends to get crowded out of Second World War historiography by Anzio, Monte Cassino and Sicily. In Osprey Campaign No. 257, author Angus Konstam provides a summary of the Allied landing at Salerno and the German counterattacks. The battle was notable in deciding nothing, which is one of the reason that it was not notable, except for the participants; the Allies got ashore in mainland Italy but took enough of a drubbing to not taste like victory. The Germans simply fell back to the Volturno River, waiting to inflict more pain and humiliation on the pursuing Allied forces. The volume focuses squarely on the ground fighting in the period 9-19 September 1943, to the determinant of air and naval operations.  The Salerno landing was a joint Anglo-American operation where the mechanics of inter-Allied coordination were still being learned, but the author steers clear of any controversy and sticks to which battalion moved where. In short, it is a useful, but plodding narrative. Looking at the sources, it is amazing that the author failed to use Rick Atkinson's recent Day of Battle or any German sources. Indeed, very few of the sources used were written in the last twenty years and this volume has a distinct 1960s-feel to it (e.g. no mention of the role of Ultra in pre-invasion intelligence). The author begins by sketching out the strategic situation with Italy about to switch sides and the Germans swooping in to take control of key points in Italy, including the coastal defenses at Salerno. If the author had bothered to consult Atkinson, he would have learned how the Italians turned over a mass of information about the German units in Italy to the Allies and how the Germans shot the Italian general in charge of the beach defenses at Salerno. The section on opposing commanders is far too high-level, with too much about remote commanders like Alexander and Kesselring, while saying very little about the men who made the real decisions. I'm kind of annoyed with the space wasted on Mark Clark, who could have phoned in his performance. Very few Anglo-American historians have yet dared to speak the truth that many of the senior military leaders of 1942-44 were simply low-capable buffoons who had no business being put in charge of large operations (granted, there were few alternatives, but even Montgomery looks like Napoleon next to Clark or Alexander).  The section on opposing forces is inadequate, with no mention of either the Luftwaffe or Allied naval gunfire support/air support. Even German armored strength - which was critical - is not discussed in any detail. On the plus side, the 3-page order of battle is nice. The Allies had big advantages at Salerno - there were no beach obstacles or coastal artillery and they had a fair idea where the German 16 Panzer Division was located. However, the Allies failed to use their firepower for fear of killing Italian civilians and the British and American beaches proved to be too far apart to link up soon after landing. Although the author does not notice, it is obvious to this former staff officer that the Allies failed to appreciate the terrain and obstacles behind the beaches. As he notes, the US Rangers and British Commandos performed spectacularly in their secondary landings, but the main landings were less than spectacular. It is clear that the British divisions were very slow in advancing, while the American 36th Division was clueless. Although the author notes that the British got tanks and 17-pounder anti-tank guns ashore just a few hours after landing, the Allied troops seemed to be victimized by even small groups of 2-3 German tanks.  Both the British and Americans failed to establish proper defenses around their beachheads, failed to link-up and sent individual battalions inland to get demolished by the Germans.  Indeed, the number of Allied prisoners taken by the Germans at Salerno was shocking - 1,500 in one day - and speaks volumes about the unpreparedness of the landing force and its commanders. At Salerno, the Germans fought a combined arms battle, putting in a very good performance and inflicting 3-1 losses. As a delay operation, Salerno is a great model. On the other hand, the Allies did not fight a combined arms battle and were unable to use their superior numbers or firepower. For example, the author notes how one German battalion defeated four US battalions. There are too many omissions in this volume for this to be considered a balanced coverage. For one thing, the author fails to mention that Clark seriously considered evacuating the beachheads - which would have given a clear victory to the Germans. He also only mentions the air-sea situation at the tail end of the book, but the German introduction of the Fritz-X guided missile was nearly decisive and had a major impact on Allied naval support.  Montgomery's march through the boot of Italy is mentioned, but there is no map and no real detail about their rate of progress. The maps are difficult to use, since they are split between the US and British sectors, so you are forced to constantly flip pages. I found the photos to be very bland, but Steve Noon's artwork added a splash of color. Overall, this was a low-ball effort with no new research or insight, but if you are looking for a basic summary of the operation, this should suffice.

Erich Barenfanger is not one of the names that is often mentioned in most histories of the Second World War, but his career neatly encompasses the story of the Third Reich. Franz Kurowski,who has put together many German-language  East Front and Wehrmacht histories authored this book, using a variety of sources. It provides only scant information on Barenfanger's career before the war began (he joined the Nazi Party and the SA), but focuses much of the book on his wartime exploits. This book is entirely in German.The first section of the book covers Barenfanger's opening combat experiences as an infantry platoon leader and then company commander in the 50. Infanterie-Division, during the French and Greek campaigns. The middle section of the book deals with Barenfanger's career in the Crimea in 1941-42, where he really made a name for himself. It is a sad fact that war is very good to some people and the Second World War was very good to Erich Barenfanger. He managed to get command of an infantry battalion while still an oberleutnant and distinguished himself repeatedly during the Battle of Sevastopol. He was promoted and received the Ritterkreuz, which started him on his rise.The final section deals with Barenfanger's career in 1943-45. He ended the war in Berlin, where Hitler promoted him to generalmajor and he played a major role in the defense of the Reichstag. Unable to accept defeat, Barenfanger committed suicide in the ruins of the Third Reich. This book is a Greek tragedy in three parts. Very edifying.

It is an exciting time for those interested in the history of the war on the Eastern Front in 1941-45 right now, because Russian historians like Valeriy Zamulin are ripping the shroud off decades of misinformation and white-wash to reveal heretofore unavailable detail about well-known battles like Kursk. Zamulin set out to write an honest account of the action at Prokhorovka on 12 July 1943 - which most historians have long-regarded as the climax of the Battle of Kursk and the moment where Germany's best panzer divisions were shattered. Traditional historiography for years has told tales about "the largest tank battle in history" that "involved up to 1,500 tanks on both sides" and describes a vast meeting engagement with Soviet T-34s charging in to fight German Tigers at close range. Professional historians with access to German WW2 records have known that this version was incorrect for years, but the "myth" has developed a life of its own and continues to be touted as truth in secondary sources. Zamulin is in a unique position to bust this myth, since he likes in Prokhorovka and worked for the Battlefield Museum, giving him access to the terrain and Soviet unit records. This is a landmark book on many levels, including the degree of honest accounting of Soviet mistakes and fact-checking. For those wondering how Zamulin's book compares to David Glantz's earlier book on Kursk, I would say that Zamulin displays far more rigorous attention to detail (e.g. Glantz rarely bothered much about what kind of tanks were involved in a particular action) and critical eye, whereas Glantz often accepted Soviet-era claims at face value. Zamulin does include some German information and accounts as well, more than previous Soviet-era histories. This book, Demolishing the Myth, sets the standard for assessing the portion of the Battle of Kursk that it concerns - be advised, it only focuses on the southern portion of the battle and does not cover the struggle on the northern side of the Kursk salient. The translation by Stuart Britton is excellent - the book reads as if it were written in English. Also, the physical quality of the hardcover Helion edition is superb. The first three chapters, which consist of about 60 pages, provides an overview of the Battle of Kursk, the defensive preparations of the Voronezh Front and an overview of the 5th Guards Tank Army (5GTA) and its commander, Pavel Rotmistrov. A key point that the author makes here is that the German commanders were not certain that they would be able to break through to their strategic objective (Kursk) but instead pinned their hopes from the beginning on finding and destroying the Soviet armor reserves, which they believed would appear around Prokhorovka. Both sides planned to commit their main armor in this area from the beginning. The next several chapters deal with the initial German attacks against the Voronezh Front on 5-9 July, the steady advance of the II SS Panzerkorps and the commitment of the 5GTA into the battle. The 200-km long march of the 5GTA to battle is quite interesting and the author provides details on how each unit performed, which provide valuable insight into the Red Army's operational-level mobility. The author gets into the Battle of Prokhorovka proper about one-third of the way through the book and aside from some digressions to deal with the flank attacks of Armeeabteilung Kempf against the Soviet 69th Army, stays on target.  In a nutshell, fewer tanks were involved at Prokhorovka, which was not really a meeting engagement at all. Rotmistrov's 5GTA was hastily thrown into an all-out counterattack as soon as it arrived, despite lack of reconnaissance, air or artillery support. The German II SS Panzerkorps saw the Soviet punch coming and reverted to a hasty anti-armor defense, on good terrain. On 12 July, the 5GTA attacked in a very poorly-planned and uncoordinated fashion and two of its corps lost most of their tanks. German losses were significant, but not crippling. Zamulin reveals that one tank corps commander was relieved after the battle and that Stalin sent a special committee to investigate the heavy losses. Thus, the Germans were indeed stopped at Prokhorovka, but 5GTA was nearly wrecked in the process. It is amazing to read in these pages about Soviet commanders or troops abandoning their positions without orders, incidents of fratricide and just plain stupid mistakes. That is war. For decades we have been presented with white-washed Soviet version of the war that lionized Red Army heroes but ignored losses or mistakes. German histories have done this to some extent as well, tending to blame Hitler for mistakes that were often made by operational-level commanders. German-based histories are still loath to discuss wartime atrocities or misbehavior of Wehrmacht troops. The amount of information packed in this volume is impressive, including very detailed orders of battle and tables on losses. Make no mistake, this book is not intended for general readers or history novices, but readers who already have a good background on Eastern Front warfare. This book is likely to remain the best Soviet account of the battle for some time.

This is the first multi-player strategic game on the First World War that can be played by a broad range of people (eg the entire family, not just a few war game grognards) that I have seen, overall, it is excellent.I number of other reviewers have noted the limited numbers of counters, which we noted as well the first time that we played the game. This was easily rectified by purchasing a few spares on-line, now we can play without shortages.Overall, the game mechanics function well - it is a very playable game. However, the game balance is really tilted toward the Central Powers, and the Allies have little ability to win. I suspect that this game will be updated in about a year with some rules tweaks. For example, the Germans can initiate unrestricted submarine warfare to take away production points from the UK and the US, but the Allied naval blockade is completely ignored. The German economy is simply too strong and in real life, the German army was nearly starving and running out of ammunition by 1918.Austria-Hungary is also too strong in the game and overruns Serbia in one turn - in real life it took nearly a year and required help from Germany. I think the Serbs need a replacement rate of 1 infantry per turn to make them more of a player.Given that this is a WW1 game, I think it odd that there are no trench markers or forts, like Verdun. This is essentially to increase the power of the defense in certain key areas, because in WW1 more infantry did not always equal victory. A fort marker could absorb two losses and a trench marker one, or something like that.There should probably be zeppelins, AA and bombers, to make the air war a little more interesting, too.However, I think the biggest thing that the game needs is better political rules. The Russian Revolution is simply too easy and certain to induce, whereas I think it should be a die-roll if certain conditions are met. Also, the fall of the Tsar did not mean the end of Russia in the war, since the Kerensky government continued to fight for another six months. Turkey also needs some political limits, since the idea that they would invade India and overrun all of Africa - which is quite possible in this game - are ridiculous.The game also needs a strategic movement to reflect railroads. In real life, the Germans could transfer forces from the East Front to the West Front in a matter of weeks or months, but here it would take 4-5 turns. That's a lot.I suspect that a number of these points will get worked into a revised issue of the game, just like the basic WW2 Axis & Allies game has been updated many times. Nevertheless, a very enjoyable game.

This is a basic 1/35 scale JS-2 kit. The main things I liked about it were ease of construction and reasonable cost. Too many kits today are adding $20-30 for optional parts that aren't even used or other little perks, rather than selling them as add-ons for the few people that want them.This kit has a few photo-etched parts for the engine grill and two sets of tracks, so you can use either the block-by-block method or one-piece track.There are three crew figures, but only one is head-to-toe, the others are just upper torso figures. I would have preferred one complete figure for outside of the tank, either loading ammo or doing track maintenance.Overall, a decent but very basic kit, with no interior and limited external extras.

Conventional wisdom tells us that Germany began the First World War as an act of aggression and that the Schlieffen Plan, drafted around 1906, was the basis for their conduct of the war.  Dr. Terence Zuber, who is well-known for his in-depth German archival research and controversial revisionist theses, says in The Real German War Plan 1904-14 (2011) that conventional wisdom is wrong.  Zuber advances two theses: that the so-called Schlieffen Plan was not used in 1914 and that German pre-war planning does not indicate a predilection for aggression.  This is a detailed, thoughtful piece of military history, intended for military theorists, not general readers. The author's theses are critical for understanding the beginning of the First World War, but his methods of mowing down all previous theories is not going to win him many friends. Further, the author's pro-German chauvinism - which was evident in his previous books -undermines his objectivity even when he is clearly correct. For any serious student of the First World War, this is a must-read book and there is no doubt that Zuber has succeeded in redefining what we "know" about the beginning of the war. However, parts of the book are offensive and indicative of a brutal and coarse approach to scholarship. The first fifty pages of the book focuses Alfred Schlieffen's planning during 1904-1906. The author uses official records, German intelligence estimates, wargames and memoranda to make his case about exactly what Schlieffen's plans represented. There is little doubt that the author completely succeeds in validating his first hypothesis, in conclusively demonstrating that Schlieffen's plan was designed around a one-front war in the West and that the driving concept was a German counteroffensive after an enemy declaration of war against Germany. Ergo, the 1906 Schlieffen Plan does not fit the events of 1914. During this section, he does make some mention of how he thinks conventional wisdom got the story so badly wrong, but it is difficult to follow and since the official Germany history of the war endorses the Schlieffen Plan as legitimate, one has to accept a certain amount of the author's conspiracy theories. The next 90 pages covers German war planning under von Moltke during 1907-1914. This is a dense read, filled with sketch maps. Herein, he makes his main point: "Obviously, in 1907 the Germans were planning to fight a two-front war in which both the Russians and the French would be attacking. Just as obviously, Moltke had wholeheartedly adopted Schlieffen's counter-attack doctrine. There is no trace of the Schlieffen plan to be seen."  He also depicts German pre-war planning to invade Belgium as a defensive measure to "meet the French offensive head on." He claims - with no proof other than a few French opinion pieces - that France would have invaded Belgium even if Germany hadn't, so it was best for Germany to get in there first. No mention that Belgium was neutral and not allied against Germany and somehow their resistance at Liege is depicted as unsportsmanlike. The author spends great effort to point out that Russia was re-arming after the Russo-Japanese War and that their "rising" strength was an existential threat to Germany. The use of a "rising Russia" was part of standard German arguments for a preventative war before the Bear became too strong and was similarly to Hitler's justification for invading the Soviet Union in 1941. You see, poor Germany had to act before they were overwhelmed by the Slavic hordes. Zuber betrays anti-Slavic racism at some points, particularly when he fails to comment about German intelligence estimates stating that Slavs were "mentally slow and lacked initiative." He also has the audacity to claim that, "Germany, which had no other continental goal than the preservation of the status quo, was politically on the defensive." Kaiser Wilhelm's truculent outbursts were certainly not regarded by anyone else as defensive and if Germany wanted to preserve the status quo, it should not have declared war on France and Russia. The author claims that France's aggressive war plans and Russia's "secret mobilization" warranted the declarations, which in no way proved aggressive German intent. At this point in the book, the level of double-talk and deliberate omission of fact goes from annoying to downright weird. The author claims that by 1911, "the German military situation was becoming critical," due to Coalition war planning against Germany. He states that the French expected a German attack through Belgium and that the Germans had no hope for a quick, decisive victory, but a few pages later, they needed a quick victory in the West so they could transfer troops to the West.  There is a major flaw evident in Zuber's thesis about the German counter-offensive strategy that he depicts, since there appears to be no way for Germany to successfully conclude a protracted war against a stronger Allied coalition. While German armies might win impressive operational-level victories like Tannenburg, he does not indicate how they could force the Allies to the peace table. If this is the case, Germany should have avoided war at all costs. Furthermore, he does not address how Germany could prevent long-term strangulation by the Allied naval blockade or what they could do if the Allies simply sat on the defensive and let the Austro-Hungarians implode. In the end, Dr. Zuber paints Germany as the victim of aggression and says that they never intended to take Paris. He never uses the word "invasion" when describing German moves into Belgium or France but instead depicts them as defensive measures. He concludes the book by low-class mud-slinging against historian Holger Herwig and Wikipedia! A serious author does not stoop to debate the relative merits of a Wikipedia article.  Dr. Zuber is making some important contributions to First World War historiography but his methods are quite coarse and lack objectivity.

When you think of naval operations in the First World War, usually the Battles of Jutland or Coronel come to mind, or perhaps Gallipoli, but the Adriatic is certainly off most reader's radar screens - which is the appeal of Paul G. Halpern's The Battle of the Otranto Straits. This book covers an Austrian cruiser raid against the Allied anti-submarine barrage flotillas in the Otranto Straits on 15 May 1917, which resulted in a dramatic but forgotten naval action. The book is well written and very well researched, making it a pleasure to read and it almost flows like a novel at points. The action in the Otranto Straits was a small-scale thing, no Jutland, but it nicely illustrates the difficulties of coalition naval operations and naval command and control of dispersed forces, as well as the early influence of aviation and submarines upon surface warfare. This book is a must-read for anyone attending a naval academy. The author begins by outlining the strategic setting in the Adriatic Sea that led to this naval action. In a nutshell, German and Austrian submarines used Austrian naval bases in the Adriatic to conduct anti-shipping operations in the Mediterranean, which led the Allies to try and erect a complicated anti-submarine barrier of nets and minefields across the narrow Otranto Straits. A large flotilla of converted trawlers, mostly British, was used to service the barrier, while the Italian and French navies provided warships to protect the trawlers. However, the level of inter-Allied coordination was poor, which impaired their ability to respond to Austrian raids. The author also makes a good point that the French and Italian navies had not properly evaluated their likely wartime missions, which resulted in them building too many heavy ships at the expense of light forces. Neither the French nor Italians wanted to risk their heavy ships to save trawlers that operated in submarine-infested areas. A considerable amount of effort is focused on the Austrian raiding force, consisting of three modern light cruisers, which were faster and better-armed than most of their Allied opponents. Nikolaus Horthy, later leader of Hungary in the Second World War, also made his reputation in this action as a cruiser captain. Essentially, the Austrian raid served no great purpose, other than to "do something" with a fleet that was sitting out most of the war. The Austrians caught the Allies completely by surprise and shot up 18 of 47 trawlers before turning for home. Allied aircraft and several surface groups pursued, resulting in a running naval action across the Adriatic. Although a British cruiser scored some lucky hits that immobilized Horthy's cruiser, the timid Italian admiral in charge opted not to close in for the kill in fear of enemy submarines. The battle ended as a draw, although it had propaganda value for the Austrians. Again and again, the problems of coalition naval operations are highlighted in this book. The British, French and Italian warships all used different codes and map systems, as well as different time zones, which made effective coordination in battle well-nigh impossible. Some lessons were learned from this action, but many of the same mistakes were repeated in the Second World War.

Histoire & Collections runs a series of short historical books known as the Men and Battles series. In this series, author Philippe Naud has written a 82-page volume on Kharkov 1943, otherwise known as "Von Manstein's Backhand Blow." Among history aficionados, this is a popular subject and this colorful book appears to nicely fill a niche for readers who don't want to read the longer books such as George Nipe's Last Victory in Russia or David Glantz's From the Don to the Dnepr. Superficially, Kharkov 1943 looks like a volume in Osprey's campaign series, but it lacks the sub-sections that deals with opposing leaders and plans or a campaign chronology. However, the most serious deficiency of this volume is that it was poorly translated from French into English, with numerous spelling and grammatical errors. The narrative flow is very poor, made worse by an uninspired translation, which makes reading this volume quite tedious. To say that this is a summary, the author does not seem to know how to summarize and tries to walk the reader through every little action that resulted in a couple of tanks being knocked out. Nor are the four lackluster maps provided much use for following the campaign. Consequently, the volume reads poorly and is difficult to follow - it is only the generally good assortment of photos provided that make it possible for the reader to make it to the finish. Overall, this volume is useful for someone who doesn't want to read Nipe or Glantz, since it does summarize much of what they wrote, but the journey will seem longer than 82 pages. The volume begins with the continuation of the Soviet Winter Counteroffensive in early 1943, with several Soviet fronts pushing toward Kharkov and the Dnepr river. The Germans were reeling after Stalingrad and this was a tense moment on the Eastern Front. The author outlines German efforts to reconstruct a new front, while the Soviets believe that a strategic victory is within sight. In a nutshell, the first half of the volume deals with the Soviet offensive that liberates Kharkov and the second part deals with von Manstein's counteroffensive that recaptured the city in March 1943. At center-stage in this volume is the SS-Panzerkorps, which just arrived from France with the LSSAH, Das Reich and Totenkopf divisions. To be frank, too much of the volume focuses on these three Waffen SS divisions, while the equally important contribution of several army panzer-divisionen is barely mentioned. Much of this portrayal apes Nipe's depiction of the campaign, which is very detailed but close to SS hero-worship at times. This volume is also too focused on tanks, while virtually ignoring artillery, air support, engineers and infantry - all important parts of the combined arms battle. The author spotlights the role of Tiger tanks in the campaign, even though their contributions at this point were modest. I found this volume to be sloppy in many regards (the map on the back cover is in French, but others are in English) and I didn't see a whiff of original research in it. Since I have both Nipe's and Glantz's books on this subject, this volume really serves no purpose beyond some nice photographs. The tortuous writing style further reduced the value of this volume.  Quite frankly, it is not up to the standard of even the mediocre Osprey Campaign series volumes.

The number of personal memoirs by survivors of the Battle of Stalingrad are quite rare, so each one has considerable historical worth. Wigand Wuster, who served as a junior officer in the 71. Infanterie-Division during the period of May 1942 to January 1943 is the protagonist of An Artilleryman in Stalingrad. This memoir is also unusual since the author was an artilleryman, which offers a very different perspective on the Battle of Stalingrad. As memoirs go, this one is darn near the top and certainly better than more air-brushed accounts like In Deadly Combat. The author is honest enough to show us his quirky side and his real opinions, instead of post-war sanitizations. At one point, he admits that he admired Hitler and another point he drops in some Nazi propaganda about American Zionists, which seems much more likely for that time than Germans who try to pretend in their memoirs that they were part of the "silent resistance." Like many young lieutenants, Wuster was impetuous and apparently didn't think that he could be killed - many of his actions, particularly his decision to fly back into the Stalingrad pocket, appear almost suicidal. Yet it is his honesty and candidness that make this such a wonderful memoir. Adding on top of that, Jason Mark has added photos and maps that really bring Wuster's account to life.  Overall - excellent. Wuster begins with his artillery battery arriving at Kharkov just as the Second Battle of Kharkov was beginning. He was a shutterbug and took numerous photos, many of which appear here. He gives a good introduction to battery life, his early combat experiences and his trouble with his battalion commander.  This part of the book, about one-third, is really great. He gives great perspective on the German army's mobility problems and the necessity of acquiring Russian farm tractors to pull their howitzers. Everything in the German advance to the Don river seems based on expedients, rather than real planning. The author was involved in a number of minor skirmishes before Stalingrad, which he details. Once his unit reaches Stalingrad, Wuster provides great detail on how he selected positions for observation posts and his guns, which were quickly dug in and then never moved again. Some of his photos of Stalingrad's streets in September 1942 are chilling. He makes it clear that artillery could play little role in the street fighting and that the infantry-artillery coordination was not always so good. Just before the big Soviet counteroffensive in November 1942, Wuster went home on leave and missed being caught in the pocket. His description of the furlough trains at Kalach are one of the most poignant aspects of this book - apparently the once-great Wehrmacht could not even properly organize transport or housing or food for troops going home on leave.Amazingly, he spurned advice from other officers to simply attach himself to another unit and made repeated efforts to fly back into the pocket, which finally succeeded. He said as soon as he saw how bad things were, he realized that he'd made a big mistake. He makes an interesting point toward the end of the battle when he gave an order to his men and noted that, "I suddenly realized that my authority over my men was waning." Wuster's description of the conduct of senior German officers in the pocket is also very interesting, and he says that he didn't consider officers who blew their brains out with their pistol while in a drunken stupor didn't seem particularly heroic. The author criticizes Goering for his failure to keep the airlift going, but reserves most of his criticism for Paulus, commander of the trapped 6. Armee; his depiction of Paulus' complete apathy and indecision seems well-deserved. He also discusses the onset of despair, as his division commander seeks death in battle and most of his regimental staff committed suicide. His description of the final days in the Stalingrad pocket make for gripping reading.
