Wuster was one of the lucky ones, who survived Soviet captivity and returned to tell the tale, of the late great 6. Armee. It is a very interesting tale, as told by Wuster.

Military memoirs can be a tricky thing, based upon how long after the event they describe that they were written, any agendas the author may have and how the memoirs were edited. In Deadly Combat, written by German army veteran Gottlob H Bidermann was written in the 1950s after the author had returned from three years in the Soviet gulag. Although the memories were still fairly fresh, no doubt the years of malnutrition had an impact on the author's ability to recall certain details or episodes - this appears sporadically throughout the book. It's not immediately apparent that the author has any real agenda, although throughout he is only willing to point fingers at the Soviet enemy, various Nazi big shots including Hitler, and the Western Allies. The editing, done by American military veteran Derek S. Zumbro, is good in most appears, but lags at one point in the center. Biderman's memoirs depict his unit, the 132. Infanterie-Division in three set-piece battles: the Crimea in 1941-1942, Leningrad in 1942-1943 and Courland in 1944-1945. The book benefits from the author's rise through the ranks from enlisted to junior officer during the course of the war and his participation on the Eastern Front from July 1941 to May 1945. Such accounts are rare, particularly from front-line soldiers. Overall, In Deadly Combat is a very good memoir - with a few odd exceptions - that offers considerable insight into the German perspective of East Front combat in 1941-45. The book begins with the author's unit marching into the Ukraine in July 1941. Initially, he is an enlisted men in charge of a 3.7-cm Pak gun in a regimental-level anti-tank unit. I thought that the book started a bit too abruptly, with no mention of the author's background or even hometown (later revealed to be Stuttgart) and he does not provide much information on his peers until the last page of the book. It would have been useful if the editor had provided some of this in his introduction, since people seem to come and go in the narrative without much context. The author sees sporadic action in the pursuit across the Ukraine, but then things shift into high gear when he reaches the Crimea. Here, the author was involved in the first assault on Sevastopol, the counterattack at Feodosiya, the fighting around Kerch and the final assault on Sevastopol - all very good material. The author generally maintains a first-person narrative format in the Crimea section, but sometimes starts slipping in information he gathered from post-war secondary sources, such as technical information on the Karl and Dora heavy artillery pieces - information he clearly did not know in 1942. On another occasion he discusses Stalin's pre-war purges, which were also outside his purview. Nevertheless, the Crimea section was a satisfying, if not always insightful, read. Around August 1942 the author was selected for officer training, but he provides almost no detail on this, which is a pity. It is often argued in history circles that German officer training declined quickly after 1941 and Bidermann could have provided interesting perspectives on this. The second section of the book covers the transfer of the author's 132. Infanterie-Division to the Leningrad Front in September 1942. However, the author missed much of the Leningrad action because he was in France in an officer training course, so this section shifts to a very high-level coverage of events, rather than the first-person style used in the Crimea. The Leningrad section was disappointing and the period from January 1943 to June 1944 is covered at a much quicker pace, with the emphasis on repeated Soviet attacks that are defeated one after another. Frankly, the editor really needs to re-work this middle section because it flows poorly and doesn't mesh well with the rest of the book. The third section covers the author's last year of the war and his unit's ordeal in the Battle of the Courland Pocket. This section was easily the best and it is clear that the author's memories were sharper here. There are some excellent combat vignettes in this section, including the author getting surprised by Soviets while sleeping and later, knocking out a Soviet tank with a Panzerfaust. The author also had a number of interesting experiences in the last few months of the war, such as being given a rare furlough in December 1944 and crossing the Baltic on a fishing boat to return to Germany.  At the end, the author surrenders with his unit in May 1945 and spends more than three years in Soviet prison camps before returning to Germany. The author himself is an elusive character throughout the book. I had the impression he was a decent front-line officer who had the respect of his troops, if not always his superiors. He frequently criticizes Hitler and the Nazis, although he does not reveal until the end of the book that his father was a police official - meaning that the criticism was likely retrospective. As a number of reviewers have already mentioned, Bidermann says that he never saw any mistreatment of civilians or prisoners. I'm willing to take him at his word, but he later criticizes the Nazis for harsh measures in the East so if he was unaware of atrocities, why bother condemn the Nazis for them. I don't think the author was covering up anything, but he appears to block out anything that would make the Wehrmacht look bad. Overall, In Deadly Combat should be taken as an honest effort to provide a first-person perspective of the German experience on the Eastern Front in 1941-45. It does have some flaws, but admirably conveys the emotions of a valid combat memoir.

Osprey's Men-at-Arms series has become a very mixed bagged, with some volumes actually trying to provide a good summary history of the unit(s) in question and others settling for being a list of obscure uniform details. Unfortunately, the recent volume on Polish Armies of the Partitions 1770-94 falls into this later category. As a Polish-American, I was hoping that this volume would actually provide some insight on Polish military forces in this period, but like many of the recent MAA titles, it is little more than a uniform pictorial. To be fair, the author does provide some historical context in the first few pages, but it is very brief and of little value unless one already has some background in Eighteenth Century East European Military History. I can't imagine that there are too many re-enactors out there who cover this period and model-building for this era would also seem marginal, so I'm not sure who the author thought was his intended audience. As expected, the color plates are excellent, but the captions provide few details beyond uniform descriptions. The list of regiments does include battles that each unit is known to have fought in, but that's it. Here and there, there's some skimpy data on what authorized unit strengths were supposed to be, but little indication of what the various units really did. Chart after chart lists the coat color, facings, buttons and lace for each regiment, which is the kind of information that gets me flipping through pages quickly. In short, there was very little meat in this volume.  While written as an introduction to its subject, it barely suffices as a drive-by.

Naval historian Mark Stille's USN Destroyer vs. IJN Destroyer 1943 is an excellent addition to Osprey's Duel series. In this volume, the author details four actions between American and Japanese destroyers in the Solomons region during August-November 1943. The author expertly combines  a good mix of combat narrative, technological discussion and doctrinal analysis in order to deliver a very nuanced and insightful picture of why U.S. destroyermen were able to learn from prior defeats and ultimately achieve tactical dominance over their opposite numbers. Given that much of the Pacific War historiography tends to revolve around carrier battles and major fleet actions, a volume like this is very helpful for depicting the more day-to-day kind of naval activity going on in the South Pacific. Overall, a very solidly-researched and constructed volume. The volume begins with an interesting analysis of how U.S. and Japanese naval doctrines shaped the designing of their respective destroyer forces in the 1930s. The Japanese viewed destroyers as primarily an offensive platform for their superior torpedoes, while the Americans emphasized multi-role ships and gunnery. The author notes Japanese investments in optical developments and night training, which gave their destroyers a significant edge in night combat for the first year of the Pacific War.  This section has color plates on Japanese and American destroyer armament. The author also notes that the US Navy completely missed the significance of the Japanese Type 93 (`Long Lance') torpedo and did not fully comprehend its capabilities until late 1943 - surely this was one of the more costly American intelligence failures of the Second World War. On the other hand, the US Navy had a big advantage in radar, which he estimates was the "single most important factor leading to the demise of the Japanese destroyer force."  He then proceeds to provide a brief summary of each major destroyer class in both navies. The section on the naval actions has a map for each engagement, making the action fairly easy to follow. The integration of first-person accounts increased the realism of the battle narratives, and the author provided his usual insight on naval operations. This was a satisfying volume that clearly demonstrated how American forces `won' the destroyer duels in the Solomons and defeated the heretofore invincible Imperial Japanese Navy.

Fallen Timbers 1794 is the follow-on volume of John F. Winkler's history of the conflict between the nascent U.S. Army and various Indian tribes in Ohio in the first decade of American expansion. Winker's previous volume in Osprey's Campaign series, covered the Indian victory at the Wabash in 1791. The author covers the Fallen Timbers campaign - which is not well-known today or even taught in classrooms - in great detail, perhaps too much at times. While the artwork by Peter Dennis is first-rate, the narrative is rather plodding and the author does not begin to discuss the actual battle until page 61 of a 96-page volume; the actual text is equivalent to less than 10 pages. Much of this volume focuses on Major General Anthony Wayne's efforts to pull together an effective army, the intense political machinations and conspiracies attempting to thwart this effort and the recurrent Indian raiding along the Ohio river that necessitated a response from the Federal Government. Along the way, the author also tosses in Citizen Genet's efforts to enlist American volunteers to fight the English and Spanish, various frontier political issues including the Whiskey Rebellion, and British discussions about pursuing their territorial objectives in the area. Simply put, this was too much diversity for a volume this size and led to clogging up the narrative. Consequently, this volume does not read as well as the last volume on the Wabash and lacks the "tightness" of other Campaign-series volume. Overall, it is worth a read, and the portrayal of Wayne is excellent, but this volume was a bit disappointing. The author begins with a 12-page introduction that sketches the strategic situation in the Ohio valley after the American defeat at Wabash and the creation of the Legion of the United States. The Indian tribes were feeling their oats after their victory at Wabash and they murdered two U.S. peace envoys and escalated their raiding against American settlements north of the Ohio river. When the U.S. Government tried to resume peace talks, Indian leaders attempted to dictate the boundaries of the United States, which clearly led to a resumption of warfare. The section on opposing leaders starts well with a spotlight on Anthony Wayne, but then degenerates into a dissection of all the various sub-unit commanders within the Legion - a line and block chart would have been better suited. The Indian leaders get less than a page. In the opposing forces section, my main take-away was that Wayne was the first American army leader to train with an OPFOR (Opposing force), dressed like Indians and instructed to use Indian tactics - the first use of realistic training in U.S. military history.  The section on opposing plans was a bit overblown, given that Wayne's plan was not particularly complicated and the Indian plan was to wait and see. Wayne's march into Ohio is covered in 20+ pages in a rather rambling narrative, that veers between describing Indian raids, American, French and Spanish conspiracies, Wayne's supply problems, political matters in the East, etc, etc. This part of the volume became rather tedious and I grew tired of reading that "Wayne's army reached its fourteenth camp," then its fifteenth, then its sixteenth, etc. Nor were the maps in this section particularly helpful - I had  difficulty following Wayne's advance. When he gets to the actual battle of Fallen Timbers, the author encounters his true nemesis - which is a preference for discussing tactical dispositions down to the Nth degree. Paragraph after paragraph was spent detailing where each unit stood in relation to its neighbor, while discussion of the actual combat and maneuvering was overly-succinct. After reading this, I only had a vague impression how Wayne used his artillery and his reserve, which appeared to be committed too soon. Describing a battle in a way that reduces the chaos and makes the key aspects discernable is no easy task, but here the author achieved only a partial success. He does effectively make the point that Wayne deployed his army in a way that made it difficult for the Indians to surround and that he was able to defeat their efforts at envelopment. However he fails to mention Indian casualties, which is an important point - no more than 2-3 percent of the Indian warriors were casualties at Fallen Timbers, so the "decisive" aspect of the battle appears more contentious than it would seem. Unable to surround Wayne, 97 percent of the Indians succeeded in disengaging and living to fight another day. Perhaps if less space had been devoted to tangential issues, the author could have spent more time discussing the impact of the battle and why it should be regarded as a great American victory, rather than a large skirmish in the woods. In truth, there were no decisive battles in the long Indian Wars, only skirmishes of various sizes - the defeat of the Indians in any given area was a process, not an event.

Thumbing through Benjamin Lai's The Chinese People's Liberation Army Since 1949: Ground Forces, a recent addition to Osprey's Elite series, it's clear that China has some very eye-catching uniforms and equipment. Of course, the author does not mention that the only successful major combat action conducted by the PLA in the past thirty years was murdering 3,000-or-so of their fellow countrymen in Tiananmen Square in Jun 1989 (referred to as an "episode" herein). That's the basic issue with this volume: excellent photos, thorough soup to nuts summary of PLA organization and equipment, but accompanied by a subtle whitewashing of history. The author mentions that the PLA crushed the Tibetan revolt but chalks it up to a CIA plot - the idea that Tibetans don't want to be part of China is not mentioned. This volumes serves to highlight the progress that the PLA has made in modernizing its ground forces and does not want to look at anything that detracts from that - like the fact that the PLA has far less combat experience than any other major army on earth. Lots of toys, no experience.  The whole question of mission is also conveniently ignored (if it's strictly defensive, why all the paratroopers, marines, tanks, missiles, etc). Nor does the author discuss PLA doctrine, although that would have been more relevant than all the space that he devoted to the People's Armed Police (PAP). Overall, this is an interesting volume but it leaves a faint aftertaste of propaganda. The volume begins with a discussion of the origin of the PLA  - as the "armed wing of the Chinese Communist Party - and spends ten pages summarizing its major activities since 1949. He provides only two short paragraphs on the Korean War, which is not much considering that this was the PLA's largest operation since it was created. The 1962 Indo-Chinese Border War gets two sentences, even though this was the only clear-cut victory achieved by the PLA over a foreign adversary and it demonstrated the tactical adaptability of Chinese troops. In contrast, the author gives more coverage to the brief Sino-Soviet skirmishes in 1969 than he does to the Korean War. He does spend about 1  pages on the 1979 Sino-Vietnamese War, but tries to put it in a positive light (no mention that China attacked Vietnam in support of its genocidal ally, Pol Pot).  Most accounts suggest that a much smaller Vietnamese force roughly handled the PLA invaders and that it was China that was "taught a lesson." By the time that he gets to 1989, the author refers to Tiananmen Square as a "controversial internal security operation" - oh that's right, its censored in China, where the author resides. Nor is there any mention that a good part of the PLA is deployed to invade Taiwan, if that proves necessary. In the next section, the author discusses the higher-level organization of the PLA and then delves into tactical structures down to battalion, company and squad level. I was actually surprised how many cooks were in a PLA infantry battalion - at least 25. He then discusses key combat arms, including armor, aviation, special forces, airborne and missile troops. Most of the photos in the volume are in color and very nice, but too many of the troops look posed. The author's captions indicate that many were taken during military open house events and even the "tactical" scenes look staged. Looking at the uniforms, a soldier's eye can note that the uniforms and equipment all look brand new - no wear and tear. An infantry squad moving next to an IFV is horribly bunched up -looks like a `human wave assault' - and despite their new helmets and camo uniforms, they are wearing 1950s rubber shoes and white socks. An infantry patrol is shown with every member of the patrol having untied boot laces - did they have to borrow the boots for the photo? I love the ZTZ-99 tanks with white road wheel rims - that sure makes them easier to spot! In the U.S. Army, when you see all polished equipment like this, it's recognizable as a "Dog and Pony Show" to impress visitors and the military-ignorant.  The discussions of the SF troops and airborne border on comical, giving the impression that these units are all very highly capable and equivalent to the best Western units when in fact, the PLA has no combat airborne drops to its credit and precious few peacetime ones either. In the final sections, the author discusses recruitment and uniforms. He suggests that the PLA is moving to a professional force, but adding 600-1,000 NCOs a year for an army that size is a drop in the bucket. He states that NCOs can marry but that their wives are only allowed to visit once a year - that sounds more like prison than a professional army.  Despite its modern Western affectations, the PLA is still very much a party-dominated conscript force and it may have 21st Century weapons, but it's still using a 1950s approach to its soldiers. I hope the author does volumes on the naval and air forces, but readers should be aware that this is a very glossy coverage, without any attempt at a balanced assessment.

Generalfeldmarschall Erwin Rommel, commander of the Deutsches Afrika Korps, once joked to his Italian allies that Italian tanks had five gears  - one forward and four in reverse.  Perhaps Rommel would have benefited from reading Pier Paolo Battistelli's Italian Medium Tanks in Osprey's New Vanguard series, in order to learn more about the capabilities of his allies' tanks. As the author notes, Italian medium tanks quickly acquired a reputation as poorly armed, poorly protected and not very fast, but Italian tankers learned to make the best of their equipment in North Africa. While the M-series tanks never matured into truly effective medium tanks, the Semovente self-propelled guns remained useful up to the end of the war. Overall, this volume is well-written, beautifully illustrated and chock full of useful information; it is easily one of the best New Vanguards in the last several years. The volume begins with the first Italian medium tank, the unsuccessful M 11/39 tank, but the bulk of the coverage is on the M13/40 and M14/41 tanks. A number of interesting points are brought out by the author, including the inability of Italian industry to manufacture welded armour plate in the early stages of the Second World War, which forced the use of out-moded riveted armour on their tanks. Specific technical deficiencies, such as problems with the intercom system and the hydraulic pump that traversed the turret are addressed, as well. The author also notes German efforts to assist Italian industry in either building licensed-versions of German tanks or improving Italian-designed tanks with German engines and weaponry, but how these attempts all failed. He also details the use of Italian tanks in combat in North Africa in some detail, as well as the German use of captured Italian tanks after the Italian surrender. A great deal of information was packed into this small space.The volume has nine very good color plates (M11/39, M13/40, M14/41, M15/42, P40, Semovente M40 75/18, Semovente M43  105/25, tactical markings and symbols), a very detailed Interior cut-away of a M14/41 tank and two battlescenes depicting an M13/40 of the Ariete Division in the Western Desert in August 1942 and a Semovente 75/18 in the Western Desert in January 1942. The photographs in the volume are excellent and include excellent period B/W photos as well as modern color photos, including a number showing the interior of tanks. Indeed, the graphic quality of this volume seems to be well above the norm for Osprey's New Vanguard series. The author also provided a very useful table on tank production, by model, from 1940-45 and another on specifications for the three main medium tanks. Altogether, the graphics and data presented in this volume make it an excellent reference on Italian tanks in the Second World War and certainly the best at this price.

In standard World War Two historiography, the Imperial Japanese Navy's carrier force was destroyed at Midway, completely swinging the initiative in the Pacific to the U.S. Navy. Unfortunately, this standard view tends to ignore the two carrier versus carrier actions that occurred just 2-4 months after Midway: the Battle of the Eastern Solomons (24 August 1942) and the Battle of Santa Cruz (26 October 1942). As naval historian Mark Stille notes in the latest Osprey Campaign volume, Santa Cruz 1942, "it is noteworthy that, four months after midway when the Japanese carrier force was supposedly smashed, it was able to defeat its American adversary." This volume details both the Battle of the Eastern Solomons and the Battle of Santa Cruz, which occurred when the issue of naval supremacy in the waters around Guadalcanal were still very much up for grabs. Like Midway, the U.S. carriers were out-numbered in each battle but unlike Midway, the U.S. Navy did not have a big advantage in terms of intelligence or surprise. Consequently, these two battles make for excellent case studies of Japanese versus U.S. carrier doctrines. Overall, this is a fine volume in the series, written by a historian who is intimately acquainted with his subject and who can also integrate his own naval service on U.S. Navy carriers to provide useful insight for the reader. The volume begins with the usual sections on opposing commanders, opposing forces and opposing plans. In the section on the U.S. carrier forces, the author notes that, "a continuing weakness of the U.S. Navy's carrier force in 1942 was its difficulty in conducting coordinated air operations." Even after Midway, the U.S. Navy's ability to coordinate the strike of multiple carrier air groups against a single target was negligible.  American radio intercepts and code-breaking, which had proved so valuable at Midway, suffered when the Japanese changed their radio calls signs just before the Battle of the Eastern Solomons.  The author notes that, "the intelligence provided to Nimitz and Halsey before Santa Cruz was not only vague, but turned out to be incorrect." In contrast, defeat at Midway forced the Japanese to adapt and in many respects, their remaining carriers were even more potent during the Solomons campaign. The Japanese had improved their ability to conduct area reconnaissance as well as generating multi-carrier strikes, and their air defense had improved somewhat. As the author demonstrates, in his blow-by-blow style battle narratives, the Battle of the Eastern Solomons was an American tactical victory because an important Japanese convoy to Guadalcanal was stopped, but Santa Cruz was a clear-cut Japanese victory that ended with a U.S. naval retreat. The author's dissection of U.S. and Japanese carrier tactics and doctrine in both battles stands in contrast to Parshall and Tully's views in Shattered Sword, which only analyzed this in terms of Midway and unequivocally claimed that U.S. carrier doctrine was superior. Here, Japanese carrier doctrine looks better in both battles and Midway looks more like an aberration. In any case, this volume provides a useful starting point for professional discussions on this subject, in light of two carrier battles that get much less attention. Overall, this is a very good volume in the Campaign series and the photographs are excellent.  The volume has five 2-D maps and three 3-D BEV maps; the BEV maps depict aerial attacks on carriers and have altitude markings. The three color battle scenes by artist Peter Dennis are up to his usual standard (the US attack on the carrier Zuiho, the Japanese attack on Enterprise and the end of the USS Hornet).  A very well written and professional piece of naval history, useful for both the general and specialist reading audiences.

David Stahel, an Australian researcher working in Berlin, wrote a dissertation on the "crisis" in the German high command in July-August 1941 over how to accomplish the objectives of Operation Barbarossa, the invasion of the Soviet Union. Now in book form, Stahel argues that Germany irretrievably lost the Second World War in August 1941. At points this book reads like a dissertation, but it is fairly well-structured and meticulously researched, unless you count the fact that it includes virtually no Russian sources. Up front, the author states rather defensively that combining Soviet and German archival material "should not be mistaken for the benchmark of good research." Instead, he asserts that his German-centric approach to understanding the outcome of Operation Barbarossa is perfectly legitimate and then proceeds to air-brush the Russians out of most of the book. The author also regards military history as linked to "peace studies" and has been influenced by current German attitudes toward military historiography, which seeks to affix blame upon members of the German military for participating in Hitler's criminal aggression, rather than analyzing military operations in detail. In his calculus, which he argues relentlessly from beginning to the end of the book, Barbarossa was "doomed to fail." Readers looking for a straight-up military history or an insightful piece of military analysis will not find it in these pages, although the author does present a great deal of information. I give him credit for laying out his case and for readers not familiar with the Eastern Front, it might even be convincing. However, rather than asking `could Germany have defeated the Soviet Union?'  the author employs a Reductio ad absurdum approach that leads to no useful conclusions. In his calculus, the Third Reich lost because it had to lose. Complex historical events, like a war between two great powers, are not usually determined by single causes, nor is it so easy to announce "this was the moment!" that a conflict became irretrievably lost.  However, the author makes reference to Clausewitz's theory of the culminating point in an offensive - the point at which the attacker's capabilities no longer exceeds the defender's - to claim that the Battle of Smolensk in July 1941 was that point in the Second World War.  To be fair to the author, David Glantz's has been making some similar claims for the importance of Smolensk in frustrating German plans, but without the same level of totality expressed here. Unfortunately, the author does not understand Clausewitz's theory of culmination very well; once an attacker has culminated, his forces are no longer strong enough to achieve any significant victories. However, the Wehrmacht won huge victories at Kiev, Vyazma-Bryansk and then advanced to within 10 miles of Moscow months after the Battle of Smolensk - clearly demonstrating that the Wehrmacht's combat power still exceeded that of the Red Army's until late November 1941. Yet the author minimizes these German victories, claiming that they had no real bearing on the outcome of the war.  The author also spends a great deal of time on Franz Halder and the German failure to take Moscow in 1941. It has been a truism in warfare for centuries that no plan survives contact with the enemy, but the author holds Barbarossa's intended goal of the rapid destruction of the Red Army as the only possible favorable outcome for Germany, while neglecting to mention that the Red Army never even came close to meeting its MP-41 plan's goal of fighting on foreign soil. In other words, the Wehrmacht failed to accomplish all of Barbarossa's goals and the Red Army failed to accomplish any of MP-41's goals, so Germany lost the war. How is that logical? A large part of the author's hypothesis rests on his contention that the offensive capability of German panzer divisions declined rapidly soon after the beginning of Barbarossa and became critical after the Battle of Smolensk. He presents selected statistics to buttress his arguments but misses several key facts. First, it is true that most German panzer units were down to about 50 percent strength in tanks after Smolensk, but all of the pre-war Soviet mechanized corps were gone after mid-July 1941 and the Red Army had even less tanks on the battlefield after Smolensk. Second, the author completely misses the arrival of the 2nd and 5th Panzer Divisions from Germany in September 1941 - both at 100 percent strength - which gave the Germans a numerical edge for Operation Typhoon.  The new Soviet rifle divisions raised after Smolensk had so little artillery and anti-tank guns that even depleted panzer divisions had little difficulty punching through them.  The author tends to exaggerate all German losses, eventually claiming that Army Group Center was "crippled" at Smolensk, while disregarding Soviet losses and problems, stating that Soviet production could make good any losses. In fact, in 1941-42 the Germans were destroying Soviet tanks as fast as they were being produced and the Red Army did not gain a real edge in armor until 1943. Conventional wisdom suggests the Barbarossa was a darn close thing and that the War in the East was not irrevocably lost until Stalingrad. Although well-argued with the facts and narrow perspective he chooses to use, the author's hypothesis remains unconvincing. Throughout the book, the author single-mindedly pushes his hypothesis like a political candidate trying to stay on message, rather than as a historian who objectively analyzes all relevant data, from multiple angles.  The entire idea that only German actions and decisions really mattered and that Soviet victory was a given due to a superior production base is more representative of the author's a priori agenda, than objective historical method. In order to win, the Red Army had to do more than just absorb punishment - it had to demonstrate the ability to conduct successful large-scale offensive operations, which did not occur until November 1942.

The vitality of Great Britain's economy in the Nineteenth and early Twentieth Centuries depended upon international trade and the Royal Navy played a vital role in safeguarding the global trade routes from adversaries. Several classes of armored and protected cruisers were developed with a primary mission of trade protection beginning in the 1870s and continuing until the First World War. However, the intense naval combat of the First World had a profound impact upon cruiser design, with a recognition that cruisers might have to take on more heavily-armed opponents than previously envisioned. Consequently, even before the war had ended, the Royal Navy had begun constructing the large Hawkins-class cruisers, weighing nearly 10,000 tons and armed with 7.5-inch guns. After the war, when international naval disarmament talks began in the 1920s, the Hawkins class became the standard for a new type of warship known as a heavy cruiser, displacing 10,000 tons and armed with 8-inch guns. The British Admiralty estimated that it needed 70 cruisers of all types to fulfill its strategic requirements, but financial constraints prevented the Royal Navy from attaining this force level. Instead, between 1924 and 1931, Great Britain built a total of 13 heavy cruisers in five classes (Kent, London, York, Norfolk and Exeter). The heavy cruisers were assigned a primary mission of trade protection, but were also tasked with supporting the main battle fleet in surface operations and providing naval gunfire support. During the Second World War, these thirteen heavy cruisers served for the duration and four were sunk in battle. Angus Konstam provides a succinct look at these warships in the Osprey New Vanguard title British Heavy Cruisers 1939-45. He begins with the Hawkins class and the factors that shaped the design of the succeeding five heavy cruiser classes in the 1920s. It is clear that Washington Naval Treaty restrictions and cost had a major impact on limiting the armored protection, firepower and speed of these warships. Every navy had to make compromises in designing their heavy cruisers; the Royal Navy opted to skimp on protection and firepower in order to get cruisers with the range to accomplish their trade protection mission. The author begins by describing the genesis of each class, then provides data plates on each class, then provides capsule histories, then provides a section on armament and other equipment. The volume has color plates of HMS Cumberland, HMS Suffolk, HMS Norfolk, HMS York, HMS London, HMS Sussex, HMS Exeter and HMS Frobisher, as well as a 2-page cutaway of HMS Cornwall  and two battle scenes (HMS Berwick at the Battle of Cape Spartivento on 27 November 1940 and HMS Exeter at the Battle of the River Platte on 13 December 1939). This volume is a decent introduction to British heavy cruisers of the Second World War, but it suffers from inadequate technical details. To begin with, the author failed to discuss the troubled development of the 8-inch Mark VIII L/50 gun, central to the heavy cruiser's firepower. It took over four years to develop this weapon and it was not ready when first emplaced on the new heavy cruisers. He fails to mention that one of HMS Devonshire's 8-inch guns exploded during gunnery trials in 1929, killing 18 of her crew and requiring extensive modifications to the weapon. Even afterward, the Mark VIII suffered from a low rate of fire compared to other cruiser guns.  Improvements in British gunnery due to the partial introduction of DCTs in the 1930s is only briefly addressed, without indicating its significance. Although the author makes it sound that these cruisers were little modified during the 1930s, improvements in gunnery/range estimation technology dramatically improved the accuracy of their firepower over their First World War predecessors. Nor does the author fully explain the armor layout, with a box protection scheme of 4-inch thick armor around each of the four turret barbettes and magazines and just 1-inch of armor on the rest of the hull - he mentions it, but almost in passing. Readers might also wonder why the Royal Navy stopped building heavy cruisers in 1930; that's because the author failed to mention that it was the tonnage limits of the London Naval Treaty of 22 April 1930 dissuaded the Royal Navy from building any further heavy cruisers. In sum, this volume is attractive and engaging, but ultimately too superficial to render an effective portrait of its subject.

Dr. Pier Paolo Battistelli's Albert Kesselring, No. 27 in Osprey's Command series, offers a succinct look at Generalfeldmarschall Albert Kesselring, one of the most unusual German commanders in the Second World War. As the author notes, Kesselring rose very rapidly in the German army, transferred to the new Luftwaffe in the 1930s and then occupied key joint-service command slots during the Second World War. Aside from his own memoirs and one dated biography in English, Kesselring hasn't been covered much in English-language history so this volume has merit. However, the 64-page format is tough to pull off (as I can attest personally, having written three previous volumes in this series) and in this case, is only a partial success. I suspect that a good amount of information that fell on the cutting room floor and the volume seemed to lack continuity at parts, which could also be indicative of too much editorial meddling. In any case, this volume is a decent introduction to Kesselring and his role in the Second World War, but essentially just scratches the surface. Kesselring's early life and career are covered in a few pages in the introduction. One thing that struck my eye was that, "Kesselring did not serve in the trenches or even the front line [in the First World War], he was awarded the Iron Cross first and second class..." Instead, he spent much of the First World War as an adjutant in various artillery units. Afterwards, he spent much of the 1920s in Defense Ministry postings, with only minimal command time. It is also interesting that Kesselring never really served in the hardcore staff position so exalted in the German military - operations officer. When he transferred to the Luftwaffe in 1933, Kesselring continued to occupy high-level ministry positions. All this begs greater insight into Kesselring's political instincts and ability to climb the career ladder so successfully, but without the usual credentials. However, this volume provides no insight into how Kesselring achieved such rapid career success. The author then spends a bit more space discussing Kesselring's role as Chief of Staff of the Luftwaffe and then commander of an Air Fleet in the 1939-41 campaigns. Nothing really new here. He then spent the period 1942-44 in the Mediterranean theater, where he made his most noteworthy contribution by the tenacious defense of Italy. As another reviewer noted, the volume actually says little about Kesselring's command style. A good approach might have been to zoom in on a particular battle, like Monte Cassino, and review key decisions made by Kesselring during a day or two of combat. The section on opposing commanders is little more than capsule bios, with no real comparison of how Kesselring stacked up against opponents like Harold Alexander or Mark Clark. The final section focuses heavily on Kesselring's alleged role in war crimes in Italy - thought there was a bit too much on this for a volume this size. The author only partially sums of Kesselring's individual contributions and faults, citing his excessive optimism in particular. I'm not sure that characteristic was either unique to Kesselring or necessarily pernicious. A good commander has to be optimistic even in the most critical situations; what was he supposed to do in 1943, throw up his hands and say `we're all screwed! The war is lost!' The ability of commanders like Model, Rommel and Kesselring to inspire their troops with optimism in 1944 was a critical combat multiplier for the Wehrmacht and not a fault from their point of view.

When I heard that Osprey was including The Battle of Borodino in its line-up for their 2012 Campaign series, I was both interested and worried. For true Napoleonic fans know that Napoleon's hash was settled in Russia, not on the fields of Waterloo, so any new books on Borodino in English are welcome. However, I was concerned that Osprey would make the same mistake it did years ago with Stalingrad and try to cram too much into a slim 96-page volume. After finishing Borodino 1812, I felt that some of my concern was justified - trying to jam Napoleon's entire Russian campaign into one volume weakens the value of the final product - although the author, Philip Haythornthwaite, had the skill to carry it off with great aplomb. In short, Napoleonic aficionados will appreciate the artwork but probably bristle that barely twenty pages of text were given to the actual battle. On the other hand, general readers who don't want to tackle the 1,000+ pages of Austin P. Britten's 1812: The March on Moscow (1993)will appreciate this as a good introduction to  the Russian Campaign. Overall, the author provides a good narrative with excellent supporting artwork, although the maps are not always adequate for following his narrative. The initial sections of the volume, on opposing commanders, plans and forces, are a bit brief. The author provides capsule bios on eight French/Polish and nine Russian commanders, which should be more than sufficient for general readers. The other two topics are lumped into one 8-page section, which does not flow particularly well. There is no real discussion in this section about the strengths and weaknesses of the opposing forces, merely a general laydown. The author does provide a 3  page order of battle, which extends down to regimental-level. Napoleon's initial invasion, the Battle of Smolensk and Kutusov's assumption of command are covered in 12 pages, which is quick but adequate. The Battle of Borodino is the main part of the volume and the coverage is fairly decent. There is more detail in this section about what specifics units and commanders are doing, although still mostly at the division-level. The final section covers the fall of Moscow and Napoleon's retreat to the Berezina; here and there, the author inserts something I haven't read in the last 4-5 books I've read about this campaign, but nothing terribly unique. The author's account of the retreat is solid, if brief.  As for analysis, the author suggests that Napoleon underestimated the task in invading Russia, which would seem blatantly obvious. The last section, on the battlefield today, was disappointing, with no photos of any current monuments at Borodino and precious little information about the museum. Looking at the bibliography, I was struck by the fact that all the sources listed were either English or French - apparently he made no effort to find any Russian sources. Taken together, it would appear that the author neglected to make use of the Internet in researching this volume, which marks it as an Old-style approach to history, seen primarily through English eyes. Borodino 1812 has three colorful battle scenes by Peter Dennis (Murat at Borodino, fall of the Great Redoubt, the retreat from Moscow). The maps in Borodino 1812 are not very effective. The five 2-D maps (strategic situation at the beginning of the campaign; the line of Napoleon's advance to Borodino; the Battle of Smolensk; Borodino, the opening dispositions; the retreat; the Berezina) are OK as far as general movements and dispositions, but primarily depict corps and division-size formations. The three 3-D BEV maps all depict the Battle of Borodino at various stages during the day, but again, depict mostly corps and a few divisions. The problem is that the BEV maps are too "zoomed out," with gridlines 1-km apart, so that even key features like the Raevsky Redoubt (which is smack-dab in the machine fold of the volume, as usual) and the fleches are lost in the map. The BEVs should have been used to show tactical actions down to at least regimental level (since the text covers this) by zooming in on the key terrain, not trying to show the entire battlefield (and thereby showing little). In an otherwise fine volume, the maps were a disappointment.

While most Americans are familiar with the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in December 1941, relatively few know anything about the man who ordered and directed the attack - Admiral Yamamoto Isoroku. In the past fifty years, there have only been a handful of books in English on Yamamoto and earlier works failed to incorporate Japanese insights. Noted naval historian Mark Stille provides an excellent introduction to Yamamoto's career and his impact on the Pacific War in one of the latest additions to Osprey's Command series. While popularized depictions of Yamamoto tended to cast him as a great admiral and a man who sought peaceful relations with the United States, the author makes an excellent case that, "while gifted in many ways, Yamamoto was no military genius." This is one of the better volumes in the Command series and belongs on the shelf of anyone with a serious interest in the Pacific War. The volume begins with a discussion of Yamamoto's origins, which can be confusing (since he was born under the family name Takano). The author discusses Yamamoto's quick rise through the ranks of the Imperial Japanese Navy (IJN), his wounding in the Russo-Japanese War, trips to America, diplomatic experience and staff roles. In particular, the author notes Yamamoto's opposition to the construction of the Yamato-class battleships and favored greater investment in naval aviation. Instead of battleships, Yamamoto pushed for long-range bombers like the "Nell" and "Betty" bombers, which would prove their worth against the British battleships Repulse and Prince of Wales in 1941. Yet the author successfully argues that while Yamamoto had positively influenced how the IJN was configured and trained for war, he was a less than optimal choice to lead the fleet in war since he was essentially a "political admiral" with "little command experience." Yamamoto was the kind of officer, perhaps like an Alfred Thayer Mahan, whose best role was in an intellectual capacity rather than battle command. When Yamamoto was chosen to command the IJN in 1939, he became involved in the politics leading up to Japan's involvement in the Second World War. Yamamoto became involved in arguments with the General Staff and developed a pet theory that attacking Pearl Harbor could cripple American resolve, even though other senior Japanese leaders believed that America might not intervene to stop a Japanese attack on the Dutch East Indies (probably correct) and even if it did, a raid on Pearl Harbor was too risky. The author notes that Yamamoto began employing his tactic of threatening to resign unless he got his way - not exactly an effective command style, more like a politician. Throughout, the author shows inconsistencies in Yamamoto's behavior that led to later disasters, such as failure to listen to alternative views or to incorporate any degree of flexibility into his planning. If anything, Yamamoto comes across as overly-rigid, inflexible and willing to allow preconceived ideas rather than battlefield realities to guide his decisions. After Pearl Harbor, Yamamoto was looking for an off-ramp for Japan to get out of its predicament of being in a war with the United States that it could not win. The author notes that Yamamoto regarded the period after the fall of Singapore as the optimal time to negotiate, but was disappointed that Japan's leaders made no diplomatic overtures to the U.S. This was actually rather a moot point on two counts: first, Japan's political leadership was unwilling to compromise on its conquests in any way and second, the Americans would not consider any political deals with Japan after the diplomatic deceptions employed prior to Pearl Harbor. Yamamoto apparently didn't get the memo: after Pearl Harbor, it was a fight to the death. Nowadays, Japan's decision to attack the United States is generally regarded as an act of national suicide and Yamamoto was the man holding the knife, just without much self awareness. Yamamoto "succeeded in hijacking the formulation of Japanese naval strategy," which led to the debacles at Midway and Guadalcanal. His operational plans were too complex and his battle command style too loose and remote, content to remain isolated on "Hotel Yamato" (his flagship, the battleship Yamato). Even when his forces scored a success, like the Battle of the Eastern Solomons in October 1942, Yamamoto failed to capitalize on it. Indeed, his behavior became increasingly fatalistic and passive after Midway, allowing the U.S. Navy to grab the strategic initiative. In the last part of the volume, the author contrasts Yamamoto with his primary opponent - Admiral Chester Nimitz, and Yamamoto does not come off very favorably. The author makes a good point that Yamamoto was not really a modern admiral, for a number of reasons, and remained mired in old-style thinking (as in regard to battleships). In the final section, the author covers Yamamoto's death in some detail and his post-war reputation. The volume has five maps and three battle scenes by Adam Hook, as well as a short bibliography. Overall, a very compelling assessment of Japan's principle naval commander in the Second World War.

The book entitle "Knights Cross Panzers" is an anthology of German first-person accounts, usually written either during the Second World War or during the 1950s, concerning the operations and personalities of Panzer-Regiment 35. This regiment was normally an integral part of 4. Panzer-Division, but one panzer battalion was detached to the 11. Panzer-Division in 1942-43. The accounts are not always polished because they were not intended for publication - rather, they were written for post-war regimental reunions. Consequently, some of the accounts are quite good and others are not. This book was lightly edited, with occasional explanatory notes, but the continuity between chapters is very loose. There is little or no effort to put the regiment's activities in perspective with the "big picture" and even the rest of 4. Panzer-Division is only rarely mentioned. The accounts begin with the invasion of Poland in September 1939 (32 pages), then the 1940 French Campaign (32 pages), but spend the majority on the Russian Campaign until the regiment was finally crushed in 1945 (360 pages). It is also important to emphasize that this book is not a proper unit history with exact dates and numbers; large chunks of time or some events are just not covered. Overall, I would say that the book starts out fairly strongly, with the best accounts in the period 1940-41, but it starts to skip around a lot in 1942-43 and becomes quite tedious and obtuse by 1944-45. In the Polish Campaign, Panzer-Regiment 35 was involved in a costly effort to capture Warsaw on 8 September 1939, which was repulsed with heavy losses. The accounts mentioned here mentioned some of the losses, but fall short of criticizing the poor decision to use tanks in city fighting. Instead, the contributors vent spleen on the Polish "not keeping their word concerning Warsaw being an open city." Typical German wartime attitude - anger at people defending their capital from German invaders.  The section on the French Campaign is fairly decent, with brief accounts of the tank battle at Hannut and the Somme offensive. The accounts of the Russian Campaign are best for 1941 and it was interesting the Panzer-Regiment 35 was running out of fuel on just the second day of the invasion and forced to request aerial resupply. It is also interesting that the regiment was dealing with significant problems with heavy rain and muddy roads in early July, well before the official start of the autumn rasputitsa.  Indeed, the regiment seems to struggle more with the terrain in the early stages of Barbarossa, than the Russians. Most German tank losses in PzRgt 35 in the early days of the invasion were caused by Soviet artillery or anti-tank guns, not Soviet tanks.  Interestingly, by D+30 of Barbarossa, the regiment only had 44 operational panzers out of an authorized total of about 170. The period July-September 1941 is the best covered in the book, with considerable detail on individual actions. While the battle accounts are interesting, they are not always accurate and this becomes noticeable with the account concerning the Battle of Mtensk in October 1941; these accounts were written before access to wartime records and material from both sides were widely available and often represent narrow viewpoints, based on incomplete information. I also began to notice an annoying tendency for many accounts to incorporate anachronistic, American-style phraseology that appears inserted afterwards to enhance readability for American audiences. It is also noticeable that nowhere in these accounts do you see German attitudes toward the Russians or the war, even though most German wartime memoirs make it clear what these attitudes were. In other words, this is a "sanitized" narrative, not intended to offend anyone. Instead, we see just a bunch of clean-cut, German comrades having the time of their lives and getting lots of medals. Indeed, there is a subtle "fake" quality to this book.  It is apparent that German tankers exhibited some bizarre behavior sometimes. After a tank raid into the city of Orel, all the crews of one company parked their tanks and went to sleep soon in a nearby building. Soon after, Soviet tanks counterattacked into Orel and the German tankers had difficulty getting back to their tanks. The idea of leaving one's tanks unguarded in a hostile city and going to sleep seems like comfort trumping good judgment. The German habit of digging foxholes under their tanks so they could sleep safe from sudden artillery barrages also seems a bit foolhardy; it is noticeable how many German tankers were wounded outside their tanks. On the other hand, some accounts provide interesting details on how German tanks figured out how to defeat the T-34 in 1941-42. During the Winter of 1941/42, Panzer-Regiment 35 lost almost all its tanks and only had one panzer company left for months. There are many interesting accounts in this period on logistical shortfalls, winter expedients and the impact of disease on the regiment. However, much of 1942 just falls off the radar screen and before you know it, the book arrives at the Battle of Kursk. From Kursk to the end of the war, the book begins to trail off into a mushy mish-mash, with less detail and insights. Lots of tanks moving around through villages or woods, knocking out some T-34s, but all rather incoherent. The fact that the Germans were getting their butts kicked is coolly ignored. There are quite a number of B/W photos included, many of which are unique, but their quality is exceedingly poor. A good number of maps are provided in the middle of the book, although I did not find them particularly helpful - most of the time I had difficulty finding the right map to go with particular accounts (this is where an editor could have helped).

Storm of Steel is a historical analysis of the development of German and Soviet armored warfare doctrine in the period 1928-1941, written in 2003 by Mary R. Habeck, a history professor at Johns Hopkins. This is a dry, academic-style doctrinal study, but it is rewarding for those readers with more than a passing interest in how both country's created and developed their tank units in the Interwar Period. Storm of Steel is well organized and very well footnoted, as one would expect from a university professor, although the use of tables and charts would have been a useful addition. The book is well-written, if a bit wooden at times, and the author's main thesis that both country's doctrine was shaped by similar factors is sound. There are issues - such as the evolution of tank technology - which the author spent little time upon, even though germane to doctrinal development. Overall, a decent academic history, although the narrative lags at times. The Storm of Steel is divided into seven chapters, beginning with the period immediately following the end of the First World War. During 1919-23, both the post-war German Reichswehr and the Soviet Red Army had no tanks and spent this period trying to decide what future role tanks might provide. As early as 1923, the Soviet Union became interested in developing a large tank force in order to match Western capitalist armies, although the author notes that the Red Army initially devoted only one percent of its budget to tank development.  The second chapter covers the debate over mechanization, which occurred in both armies during 1923-27. The author discusses how conservative cavalry officers in both countries opposed the tank and mechanization for a variety of reasons. In addition, the advocates of "moral" power (as in Napoleon's maxim, that `the moral is to the material as three is to one') argued that reliance on tanks rather than the willpower of their infantry was a mistake; this argument still retains some saliency even today. In the third chapter, the author discusses the beginning of covert Soviet-German technical collaboration at the Kazan Tank School and the weaknesses that led both sides to cooperate with each other. Due to the weakness of Soviet industry, the Soviets needed foreign technical help in developing tanks and due to the Treaty of Versailles the Germans needed a quiet place to (illegally) test new weapons and tactics. This chapter is very rewarding in that the author effectively demonstrates that the Germans did not influence subsequent Soviet tank doctrine and the relative backwardness of Germany's inchoate tank doctrine in comparison to Soviet Deep Battle theory. The author also details the success of Stalin's First Five Year Plan in rapidly building up the Soviet Union's tank production capabilities in an amazingly short period of time - something Hitler would have been wise to emulate. Important developments, like the Soviet creation of a Tank Directorate (UMM) and new field regulations, are discussed in some detail. Chapter four, covering the period 1930-31, discusses the development of Germany's first tanks and Soviet efforts to refine Deep Battle theory into a workable doctrine. The fifth chapter covers the end of Soviet-German military collaboration and doctrinal evolutions in both countries. Whereas the Soviets had a fairly uniform view of tanks by 1933, the Reichswehr was still very divided about tanks when Hitler came to power. When Hitler's plans to expand the Reichswehr were first discussed, there was no provision for panzer divisions, even though the Red Army had already formed its first mechanized corps. However, the Red Army had difficulty actually conducting Deep Battle in its summer maneuvers, and learned the difficulties of supplying a large mechanized formation (with no solution in sight). Interestingly, the author contrasts the Soviet preference for creating a checklist-like playbook for Deep Battle versus the German preference for a more ambiguous doctrine that left room for lower-level initiative in combat. Chapter six discusses the role reversal of 1934-36, with the Red Army losing much of its advantages in tank development and doctrine due to the Stalinist purges of the military, while Hitler's newly-formed Wehrmacht formed its first panzer divisions. However, the author makes an important point when she states that, "despite these triumphs, the Germans would never catch up with their Soviet counterparts in one vital area: the mass production of tanks." Just as the Red Army enshrined Deep Battle as official doctrine in the PU-36 Field Regulations, Stalin imprisoned or executed all its key advocates, effectively strangling it at birth. On the German side, the author spends considerable time on the Guderian-Lutz-Beck debates on tanks, but misses the creation of the Sturmgeschutz (assault gun) by Manstein as an effort to keep some armor in the infantry support role. Likewise, the book is weak on assessing the impact of new technologies on doctrine, such as the Soviet development of the V-2 diesel tank engine and incorporation of sloped armor in designs. This would have been a good time to discuss how Hitler - who had some good ideas about tanks, such as better armament - was ignored in designing Germany's panzers. In contrast, Stalin had a major say in the development of individual Soviet tanks. The final chapter discusses the impact of the Spanish Civil War, the Chaco War and other small conflicts on tank developments in both countries. Two other topics which I felt the author skimped on was on how the first tank units were created in each country (mentioned only very briefly) and how personnel were trained in each country. Developing doctrine is one thing, but the question of how it was taught to tank crews was essentially ignored. Overall, Storm of Steel is informative, erudite and persuasive, although certainly only for those with a strong interest in doctrinal studies.

The historiography of the 1944 D-Day invasion has been so shaped by the iconic images of Allied paratrooper/glider assaults and amphibious landings that it is often easy to forget about the French population, the people we were trying to liberate. The history of the French resistance or Maquis is also very controversial and thus, is often omitted from standard works on the campaign in Normandy. In Das Reich, written in 1981, British historian Max Hastings shows Anglo-American readers a completely different version of what was going on in France in June 1944, from the point of view of French Maquis and civilians, as well as a handful of British and American special operatives. The main antagonist is the German 2. SS-Panzer-Division Das Reich, which was stationed southeast of Bordeaux. As Hastings lays out in the book, the Allies anticipated that the Germans would attempt to move the Das Reich toward Normandy as soon as the invasion began and they hoped that the French resistance - with help - could slow it down. This book is the story of that effort, told from both the French, Anglo-American and German viewpoints (Hastings wrote this when far more veterans were still around). At times I found that the author wandered a bit, discussing some personality feature of some French resistance leader who actually played no major role in this episode, but on the whole reading the book was quite rewarding. In particular, the author's narrative of the massacre at Oradouor and the SAS Operation Bulbasket are first-rate. As usual, the author is both incisive and pithy, as a good British historian should. In the first several chapters,  the author describes how the badly-depleted Das Reich Division was sent from the Ukraine to France to rebuild, as well as the British effort through the Special Operations Executive (SOE) to establish espionage and sabotage networks with the French resistance. The author puts in a lot of detail about the training and background of SOE agents before they were parachuted into France and the idiosyncrasies of the pro-Gaulist and pro-Communist resistance factions. Some of this can get quite Byzantine. On top of that, many Frenchmen mentioned in the narrative were also collaborators with Vichy and the Germans. The author paints a pretty woeful picture of the French resistance, describing many as unmotivated and little better than bandits, with their priority being to avoid forced labor in Germany - not fight Germans. Indeed, the author claims that, "Without SOE, Resistance could have achieved nothing."  This might be a trifle Anglo-centric. While the first third of the book focuses on clandestine operations, once D-Day occurs, the Resistance mobilize en masse to cause problems for the Germans, particularly in disrupting the rail lines. Then the Germans made a major mistake - one that is rarely credited in other D-Day histories - they decided to commit the Das Reich to suppress the partisans in southern France, rather than heading directly to Normandy. Infuriated by recurrent small-scale sniping and sabotage, the Das Reich began their two-week march to Normandy with the primary intent of conducting a show of force against the French resistance. However, not all the French resistance got the message. In Tulle, a small town northeast of Bordeaux, the local French resistance defeated most of the local German garrison and proclaimed self-liberation. Within hours, the vanguard of the Das Reich arrived and put paid to the liberation and hanged 97 local civilians in retaliation for the alleged murder of German prisoners. The author spends two chapters on Tulle, which give a very good tactical feel for partisan and anti-partisan actions. The Resistance members showed a total lack of tactical skill, including the non-use of surprise, so it was no surprise that Das Reich handed them their heads. The author then discusses the Jedburgh teams, which included American OSS types, which were sent in to organize attacks after D-Day. The commentary by one American Jedburgh team leader, about the near-total uselessness of the resistance, are quite revealing. The last couple of chapters deal with the grisly massacre at Oradour and the failed SAS operation Bulbasket. At Oradour, the author believes that a local German commander made the snap decision to murder everyone in the town, but that the ethos of the Waffen SS and the climate of retribution encouraged this type of decision. He also notes that after the Oradour massacre, resistance activities against the Das Reich fell off to zero - indicating that harsh measures can be effective at intimidating insurgents. At least that was the German take-away. As for Bulbasket, the decision to parachute an SAS squadron into France armed only with pistols borders on the idiotic, as the author notes. Although the SAS troopers had one clear success - directing an RAF raid on German fuel tankers - their base camp was eventually discovered and overrun by the Germans. All the SAS prisoners were executed, making this a very expensive fiasco. Overall, Das Reich adds a good deal to D-Day historiography, although hardly flattering to the participants on both sides.

Although ground warfare in the First World was characterized by indecisive, static trench warfare, there were moments of mobility and decisive combat. One such moment was the German-Austrian Gorlice-Tarnow Campaign in May 1915. A joint German-Austrian force, under the command of Generalfeldmarschall August von Mackensen, was able to achieve a major breakthrough that had two major strategic effects: it removed the Russian threat to Austria-Hungary in the Carpathians and eventually led to the collapse of the Russian line in Poland. Yet, the Gorlice-Tarnow Campaign is not well known in First World War historiography and Professor DiNardo's book Breakthrough represents a significant leap forward in scholarship on this important battle, at least in English. However, the book is fundamentally undermined by its maps, which are grossly insufficient for readers to follow the author's campaign narrative. Another key problem is the lack of balance - the book is overwhelmingly told from the viewpoint of the Central Powers, with only the briefest nod to Russian circumstances Overall, this is an important book, but one which fell far short of what it could have been. Breakthrough is divided into nine sequential chapters. The first two chapters cover the strategic setting and the problems of coalition warfare.  The author provides good perspective on both the Austrian and German senior leadership, Conrad and Falkenhayn, and their professional relationships. It was Falkenhayn who made the key decision to commit the small German strategic reserve (barely eight divisions) to the Eastern Front to prevent an Austrian debacle on the Carpathians.  The new units were formed into the German 11. Armee under Mackensen and as the author notes, these were picked troops, including the Prussian Guards Corps. German leadership was excellent, with Hans von Seeckt serving as Mackensen's chief of staff and Major Fedor von Bock (future Army Group Center commander in 1941) as operations officer. Wilhelm von Leeb, future commander of Army Group North, was also involved as a staff officer. As the author notes, "the true power of Mackensen's army lay in the additional artillery attached to his component corps." For the first time, the Germans decided to use 21-cm and 30.5-cm heavy howitzers against field works. However, German logistics behind the offensive were insufficient, with only 300,000 shells stockpiled for Mackensen's offensive.  This was not much by 1916 standards, but both the Allies and Central Powers were very low on artillery ammunition in early 1915 (the "shell scare") due to failure to anticipate wartime demands. The author's details on the planning for the offensive and the movement of German troops to Galicia is very good. Mackensen's initial offensive in May 1915 is covered in the fourth chapter. The 11th Army achieved all its objectives - which were rather limited - in the first week and pushed back the Russian 3rd Army. However, the Germans quickly ran into logistic difficulties after an advance of even 20 miles and the operation degenerated into something of a "stone soup offensive," with the Germans pausing every few weeks to reorganize and wait for supplies to catch up. The Russians were pushed back and large numbers of prisoners taken, but no decisive encirclements occurred. The author provides a decent amount of detail on German-Austrian operations, but the reader will not be able to follow this on the sketch maps, which are hopeless. The maps lack major terrain features like rivers, as well as important towns, fortresses and hills mentioned in the text, nor do they have a scale bar. Furthermore, most units (armies and some corps) are simply depicted with a flag in their general location; the location of division-size units and below remain a mystery throughout.  The lack of first-person tactical accounts also makes the text fairly dry, lacking a feel for tactical action. The remaining chapters discuss the subsequent German capture of Lemberg and the eventual Russian withdrawal from central Poland. Mackensen's tired army is eventually broken up in September 1915, having accomplished its task. The author concludes that German success was dependent upon three factors: air reconnaissance, heavy artillery and communications. Even though the Germans did not have a great deal of artillery ammunition, they used aerial reconnaissance to spot Russian positions, so rounds were not wasted. Superior communications enabled Mackensen to react more quickly than his Russian opponents. The author also notes that the Russian failure to defend in depth and their insufficient artillery support seriously compromised their ability to stop Mackensen. All in all, this is a good book and the author is to be applauded for his trail-blazing effort, but more work needs to be done on this topic to add more on the Russian perspective and to develop a more coherent campaign narrative, complete with map references.

Barbara Tuchman has always been one of my favorite popular historians because she wrote better than many scholarly historians and she had a knack for capturing important facets of history and transducing them into simple but captivating themes. Some would say that she possessed Herodotus' skill at sifting through events and determining their greater meaning. In The March of Folly (1984), Tuchman decided to examine the role of folly - which she defines as a conscious decision to act against one's own best interests - in government, from Ancient times to the Vietnam War. As usual, the March of Folly was a darn good read; coherent, well-argued and studded with pithy observations. I felt that I learned something new or learned to think differently about something I already knew on almost every page - which is a rare quality in books today. On the other hand, I can't say that the author has really proved any grand hypothesis about the role of folly in human history - although her comments about how leaders make faulty decisions does ring true for our current leaders, as well. Nor was I so sanguine about all of the author's analysis of each of the three epochs involved, particularly the final section on Vietnam. Unlike her previous efforts on the First World War and the Middle Ages, the author strayed into personal bias about a period that she lived through and lost some of her objectivity along the way. It is easy to be wise after the fact, but Tuchman's deconstruction of how past leaders always had an alternative to the course of folly that they actually chose may not be valid in the real world. The March of Folly is divided into three main sections, which discuss the Renaissance Popes and the beginning of the Protestant reformation, how Britain lost the American colonies and the United States in Vietnam. Tuchman uses these three examples to build her case that there is a common theme of political misjudgment in high-level decision-makers, particularly in powerful states or organizations. The section on the Renaissance popes in the period 1470-1530 is the shortest in the book, at about 72 pages. She certainly hits the nail on the head in depicting the corrupt antics of six of the worst popes, who through their vile behavior incited resentment and revolt against the Church. Tuchman notes that a large part of the problem was that these popes adopted the mores of medieval Italy, which was violent, corrupt and self-aggrandizing. However, the popes were hardly unique in their corruption, since most secular leaders at the time were just as self-serving. Marxists would say that this was the ideology of the ruling class in pre-modern Europe. It's not like the Reformation brought peace and prosperity to Europe - it brought war, persecution and ethnic cleansing. I also detected a bias by the author against the Church; she condemns the later revocation of the Edict of Nantes by Louis XIV in 1685, but says nothing about the policies of religious intolerance by English Protestants against the Irish that led to mass migration to America. The section of Britain and the American colonies was particularly fresh because Americans tend to view this period through our lenses, but pay little attention to how and why the British made the decisions that led to a break. Tuchman views the period entirely through British perspectives and it reveals a great deal that is omitted from standard accounts. She quickly dismisses the whole `taxation without representation' argument deftly by pointing out how few Englishmen were actually represented in Parliament and that American agitators were not really interested in token seats in Parliament even if offered. She also does a great job with the hard numbers on revenue the British expected to raise with the Stamp Act and the cost to the British economy of American non-importation boycotts. Most of the British politicians are shown as amateurish twits, more interested in drinking themselves to death and fox hunts than serious policy-making. British policies against the Americans are revealed as a series of incoherent and ad hoc efforts, not part of any coherent strategy. It is particularly revealing when she relates that no senior member of the British government bothered to visit the colonies or discuss issues with American opinion-makers in the decade leading up to the Revolution. As Tuchman concludes, the best British choice was not to try and impose a rule upon the colonies that they could not enforce, but to adopt a laissez-faire attitude that would have eventually allowed the Americans to move toward self-rule. While the American Revolution certainly served no British interest, it's hard to see how resigning oneself to the loss of a continent serves British interests, either. The final section on Vietnam covers the period of US involvement from Truman to Ford, with the emphasis on LBJ's War. It's clear from the beginning that Tuchman wants to absolve Kennedy from any serious guilt, even though the establishment of MACV and the surge in advisors occurred on her watch. As Tuchman sees it, all the US leaders in this period either misread or ignored the tea leaves and plunged us into a no-win situation in Vietnam. However, her depiction of the war grows increasingly shrill throughout this section, beginning with an obscene generalization about "napalm amounted to official terrorism" by targeting civilians. She displays anti-military attitudes by writing that, "the military misleads from habit." She suggests that the US military could not adjust to counterinsurgency warfare, but fails to note that spectacular growth and resources devoted to Special Forces. The author is quick to grasp at any straws, such as various UN overtures to Hanoi, as a means that we could have "gracefully exited" the conflict. In short, Tuchman's conclusion seems to be that when faced with poor alternatives, leaders should take the path of least resistance and run away. This is not leadership.

While the Forbes Expedition to western Pennsylvania in 1758 may not appear to be one of the most fascinating chapters in American military history, Rene Chartrand delivers a gripping narrative about it in Osprey's Tomahawk and Musket. This entry in the Raid-series is designed both to tell the story of two raids during this campaign of the French and Indian War, as well as to illustrate the nature of forest warfare tactics in the Eighteenth Century. Although the volume has a definite slant toward the French side, the Anglo-American side of the story is also told very well. The overall high quality of the narrative, combined with excellent graphics, maps and eye-catching cover make Tomahawk and Musket a must-have volume for readers interested in military history.  The volume begins with a rather lengthy introduction that sketches the relationships between the British, American colonials, French and the main Eastern Indian tribes. The author's research - as always -is impeccable and he manages to provides new facts and insights even on familiar topics. His main point is that before the French and Indian War even broke out, the French had forged close military-economic ties with all the major Eastern tribes except the Iroquois confederation and that together, the French and Indians had developed a very deadly tactical doctrine for forest warfare. In contrast, Anglo-American relations with most of the tribes was antagonistic and the British were smugly confident that regular troops could operate anywhere, even in the wilderness. This smugness resulted in the 1755 Braddock disaster, which caused the Anglo-Americans to seek a re-match in the Ohio Valley, but in more controlled circumstances.
