The author then outlines how the Forbes expedition, intended to eliminate French-held Fort Duquesne in the Ohio Valley, was part of an overall British strategy to mass superior force against key French positions in North America and seize them. The planning for the Forbes expedition and the march through western Pennsylvania occupies  about one-quarter of the volume. The raid sections consist of Grant's raid on Fort Duquesne and Aubry's raid on Fort Ligonier, each of which has a 3-D BEV map and a battle scene by Peter Dennis. The volume concludes with the French decision to abandon Fort Duquesne and the British occupation of the Ohio Valley. Overall, this is first-rate historical writing and presentation, of interest to both special readers and a general audience.

While the battles of Marathon, Thermopylae and Salamis from the Graeco-Persian Wars are still well-known today, the climactic Battle of Platea (479 BC) is virtually unknown.  This obscurity is a bit surprising, given that the same Spartans who have received such adulation in popular film and fiction for their stand at Thermopylae played a central (and more successful) role at Platea. Despite winning at Salamis the previous year, a large Persian army still threatened the Greek homeland in 479 BC and succeeded in burning Athens. Most, but not all, of the Greek city states rallied together for a great land battle to drive out the invaders, once and for all. Here in William Shepherd's Platea 479 BC, we see Spartans and Athenians fighting side by side, which creates a captivating image of Hellenes in their finest hour. The volume is based upon the author's interpretation of Herodotus, as well as field research on the actual battlefield in Greece. The splendid artwork of Peter Dennis, accompanied by nice maps, makes this an attractive and erudite addition to the Osprey Campaign collection. The volume begins with a rather lengthy 11-page introduction that outlines the origins of the Graeco-Persian Wars. The relatively brief section on opposing commanders focuses on the Persian Mardonius and the Spartan Pausanias. The section on opposing forces is quite longer at 16 pages and is well suited to explaining the Hellenistic and Persian forms of warfare to newcomers. The section on opposing plans is much briefer. The next section covers the beginning of the campaign and initial moves by each side, although there was no real combat in this phase there was considerable diplomatic action with the Persians attempting to divide the Greeks with bribery. The actual Battle of Platea is covered in a 28-page narrative, but once illustrations are deducted, the fighting per se is covered in just 8 pages. Those expecting a straight-in battle narrative like Thermopylae will be disappointed; the first two weeks of Platea were characterized by `sitzkrieg' and posturing and both armies seemed reluctant to come to blows. The maps support the text very well, particularly for an Ancient battle, where sourcing is difficult. There are a total of 6 2-D maps and one 3-D BEV map. One pleasant surprise is that this volume has four battle scenes instead of the usual three and Peter Dennis does his usual excellent work. Three of these battle scenes involve birds-eye view representations that depict hundreds of soldiers in action, which is truly an impressive amount for any artist to complete. The volume concludes with actions at Mycale in Asia minor and then a discussion of the battlefield today. The author provides a useful bibliography. Throughout the volume, the author's approach is quite conservative. He tells the story from trusted sources and offers analysis only when necessary. However, he does stick too close to Herodotus and could have tried a bit more personal analysis. Overall, a very good volume in the series.

Although the 105-day siege of Kholm in January-May 1942 was one of the most dramatic and intense defensive battles of modern military history, it is virtually unknown in  the English-speaking world, except among a handful of specialist readers. Jason Mark, an inveterate researcher who has previously written landmark books on the Stalingrad Campaign, provides a wealth of information about the Kholm Campaign in his new book, Besieged: The Epic Battle of Kholm. Besieged provides a chronological, day-by-day account of the siege, primarily from German primary records from NARA, but also with some interesting accounts from the Russian side as well. The book is pricey and will no doubt triple in price once out of print, but well worth every cent due to the content of its research and high production values (quality paper and binding, excellent photos and maps, multiple appendices). The book does have some limitations, since it tends to focus so heavily on the tactical German eye-level that it sometimes glosses over or omits important details about events that were beyond the outskirts of Kholm. For example, although the author often mentions problems with the German effort to supply the garrison in Kholm by air, he barely mentions that the Luftwaffe had an even bigger responsibility to supply the nearby Demyansk pocket, which had twenty times as many encircled troops as Kholm did. Indeed, Kholm and Demyansk are really inseparable and readers will have to consult other sources to get the "big picture." Besieged is divided into five chapters, one for each month of the siege. Each day is covered in considerable detail, relying heavily upon the official daily reports submitted by Generalmajor Theodor Scherer, commander of the Kholm garrison, to XXXIX Armeekorps (the relief force). The book also have even superb appendices (myths and misconceptions; numbers; officer biographies; Oskars Perro; German Units in Kholm; glider landings in Kholm and plane landings in Kholm). The level of detail provided - down to how much food or ammunition was provided on each glider - is astounding. That's one of the really great things about Jason Mark as a historian - he's a detail guy and does not write in the kind of generalities that other authors use. On the other hand, the book is very German-heavy, with no Soviet order of battle or biographies provided. If he could have provided a similar kind of detail on the Soviet side, sources permitting, this book probably would have been the definitive tome on this subject. As it is, it is darn good. The fighting Kholm was intense and virtually non-stop for four months and that comes across on page after page in this book. The narration on the fighting around the GPU building, where the German defenders used up to 1,000 hand grenades in a single night, is gripping. The desperation of the encircled defenders, running short on food and ammunition, and with nearly half the garrison dead or wounded, is palpable on each page. Scherer's pleadings with corps to deliver supplies and speed up the relief effort tends to focus much of the narrative on him and make him a sympathetic character. Scherer has always been at the center of the Kholm story because that is the way that Nazi propaganda wanted it - he was a soldier's soldier and an admirable figure (although the author does not mention the Soviet partisans/civilians he hanged). Many of Scherer's subordinates come to life on these pages, too, which is exceptional. Here and there, some Soviet soldiers are singled out. As battle narrative, this book is impeccable. One item that caught my attention was the relatively callous attitude that the German High Command had to many of the survivors after they were relieved; many of the walking wounded were forced to remain on the line in Kholm for weeks after the relief before finally being sent home. Awards for a number of key indivuduals in the garrison were denied, which seems incredibly petty. Scherer was fetted as a hero, but many of his men were treated rather shabby. As military history, Besieged does fall a bit short, primarily due to the lack of sufficient analysis. After amassing all these great facts, the author makes absolutely no effort to assess why the Germans succeeded in holding Kholm or why the Soviets failed to take it. Indeed, German casualties are listed in considerable detail, but no similar effort is made to assess Soviet casualties. In fact, the failure to capture Kholm prevented the Soviet Northwest Front from inflicting a catastrophic defeat on the Germany Heeresgruppe Nord in its Winter counteroffensive by driving even deeper into the German lines of communication in northern Russia. The German airlift really needed assessing, as well.  Overall, this book is a superb piece of research but it seems to be missing some vital components - the Soviet view, the `big picture' and analysis - which make it feel a bit "hollow" as military history. Nevertheless, Besieged is still an impressive book on a battle that deserves greater attention and hopefully this book will help in that regard.

Men in War (1957) is a standard small unit war drama film, which depicts the remnants of a platoon from the US 24th Infantry Division during the opening stages of the Korean War. All of the events occur on a single day, which is listed as September 6, 1950. The main protagonist is Lieutenant Benson (portrayed by Robert Ray) and the main antagonist is a Sergeant First Class Montana from the First Cavalry Division (portrayed by Aldo Ray).  The film begins with the aftermath of a North Korean attack on Benson's unit, which has left him isolated from his normal chain of command. Apparently the rest of his battalion `bugged out' or was killed and the sole radio is soon knocked out by a sniper. Ray shows up with his catatonic colonel, in the process of `bugging out' himself. This film was produced without DoD cooperation and on a very low budget and it shows throughout. Indeed, the quality is about that of an episode of the later TV series Combat! (and since Vic Morrow has a minor role in the film, it really feels like Combat!, just minus LT Handley and Kirby). Overall, Men in War is a pretty mediocre war film, which is why one reason that it is so obscure, but it is mildly entertaining and the other reason for its obscurity derives from the amnesia that the United States has about the Korean War.While the enemy only make rare appearances in Men in War, there are a number of other items that were omitting that greatly reduce the verite of this film. First, there are no Korean civilian refugees, even though this was a major problem for the US Army in Korea in September 1950. Second, there is no indication of US aircraft overhead, even though the US Air Force was pounding the North Korean Army pretty hard at this point. Third, heat does not appear to be a major factor in this film but in the real Korean War in September 1950, heat exhaustion and dehydration were real problems, too.  In addition, the filming location in California is a poor substitute for the mountainous terrain along the Naktong River - it simply isn't even close. Put it all together and you get a rather generic war film, as if Platoon had been filmed in somebody's backyard.The film is obviously set up to focus on the conflict between LT Benson and SFC Montana, despite how silly that appears to anyone with military service experience. This device has been used repeatedly by Hollywood, including in Platoon and later movies, but it usually just nonsense inserted to add dramatic tension. It's a war for Pete's sake, isn't their enough dramatic tension already? Despite what other reviews have expressed, I found Robert Ryan's portrayal of LT Benson as rather weak. Ryan himself was nearly fifty when he played this role, which makes him ludicrously old for this rank. He also spoke pretty good Korean, too, for someone who could only have been in country for at most two months (more than I could speak after a year as a LT in Korea).  I was struck by his casual lack of concern for the welfare for his men and his pig-headed pursuit of a `mission' that was clearly OBE (overcome by events). Aldo Ray's character is far more in tune with the situation and most of what I liked about this film was SFC Montana. He knew the deal and seemed to be the only one with any real combat savvy.  Ryan leads his half-platoon to utter obliteration in pursuit of a ridiculous objective and then seems to shrug his shoulders, "guess my boys are all dead."  He reminded me of Rip Torn in Dr. Strangelove: "My boys let me down." Not exactly paternalistic leadership.The other thing that's memorable about this film is the sense of defeat and isolation, which is something that modern audiences are not so accustomed to seeing in a film about American soldiers. Most modern war film tend to emphasize technology and how ours is so much better than the opposition's, but in this case, it's just not a factor. The US Army suffered some terrible defeats in the opening months of the Korean War and it was not unusual for small units to find themselves on the run, as depicted in Men in War. Despite possession of atomic bombs and strategic bombers, the US infantry were hard-pressed and often fighting for their survival. Today, war is almost seen as a "safe thing" (low casualties, robot drones, minimal risk of defeat, etc), but if Men in War can remind even a few people today that there are no guarantees in war - even that our troops can lose - it may still have some value.

Although the Chaco War between Bolivia and Paraguay in 1932-35 is not usually high on many people's military history read-list, Alejandro de Quesada's latest volume in Osprey's Men-at-Arms series deserves a read by anyone interested in a different type of military operations. When the Chaco War is discussed, it is usually in terms of how modern military technology such as aircraft and tanks were used, although the author shows that there was precious little of that. This is one of the better recent MAA titles, focusing on operations and units, not buttons and service piping. Overall, this is an excellent introduction to this mostly-forgotten conflict and one that deserves attention. The author briefly sketches out the background to the Chaco War and provides a B/W sketch map of the area of operations. Bolivia and Paraguay's military forces are outlined in four pages. The author makes clear that Bolivia had the larger, better-equipped army but Paraguay's forces were better-led and more aggressive.  The course of military operations in 1932-35 is described in 12 pages, with a fair amount of tactical detail about several key actions. In essence, Bolivia lost the initiative in 1933 when two of its divisions were surrounded and forced to surrender, but Paraguay unwisely accepted an internationally-sponsored ceasefire, which allowed Bolivia to avoid complete military collapse in the Chaco region. The maneuver warfare practiced by the Paraguayan forces is quite interesting and worthy of study, which this volume serves to act as an introduction. The author then spends about 10 pages discussing major weapons used and air operations. Unusual for the MAA series, he provides a useful bibliography. The volume has 8 color plates, which are adequate but not great (only three depict field uniforms). The B/W photos are decent. Since so much of the fighting revolved around forts, it would have been nice if the volume had a color plate depicting the layout of a typical Bolivian fort. I enjoyed this volume and found it quite readable and insightful.

The Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor ranks up there with D-Day and Gettysburg as one of the most covered subjects in American military history and Osprey had already covered this subject with a campaign volume in 2001. Thus readers might wonder whether Osprey's new volume in the Raid series entitled Tora! Tora! Tora! is worth buying or reading. Two words: Mark Stille. The author is a professional naval historian (who studied under Gordon Prange), a seasoned analyst and retired naval officer, which makes his narrative far more insightful and useful than many previous efforts. The author skillfully manages to tweak new facts out of existing material and pull them together into a far more coherent conclusion than you will find elsewhere, even in Prange's ground-breaking works. When you add in some of Osprey's best artwork and maps to date, the result is spectacular and this is easily one of the best Osprey volumes of 2011. Overall, a superb piece of naval history.  Tora! Tora! Tora! begins with an introduction that outlines growing US-Japan diplomatic tensions in 1940-41 and the Japanese decision to use violence to prevent U.S. efforts to block their hegemonistic ambitions in Asia. The author spends about twenty pages discussing the genesis of the Japanese plan to attack the U.S. military base at Pearl Harbor, beginning with the strategic concept and then moving into detailed tactical planning. He does a great job both depicting Admiral Yamamoto's thinking on the raid - much of which is show to be far from "brilliant" - and the `nuts `n bolts' planning and training accomplished by his subordinates. There is excellent detail on the Japanese training program for the raid, which breaks down torpedo and dive-bomber accuracy levels achieved prior to the raid. The volume also has a very nice color plate of all the aircraft types used in the raid alongside a table that lists units and targets - very nice. The author makes the interesting point that the level of training among the Japanese aviators was not universally high and that the Fifth Carrier Division pilots were not night-certified, so the Pearl Harbor raid had to await dawn to launch to accommodate them. He also raises valid questions about Yamamoto's inclusion of the midget submarine force in the plan, which risked losing the element of surprise. The raid itself is covered in 36 pages and is supported by two 2-D maps and two 3-D BEV maps. The artwork by artist Jim Laurier (torpedo plane attack and USS Ward versus mini-sub) is stunning and captures important moments in the raid. The author dissects the raid in great detail and does so in a manner that goes beyond merely recounting well-known facts. The sloppy execution of the Japanese torpedo-plane attack is carefully analyzed and Japanese performance looks far less flawless when actual numbers of weapons expended are examined. The Japanese expected to get 27 hits out of 40 torpedoes expended, but actually got 19, with most weapons expended on only two battleships. The horizontal bombing attack was also far less effective than often depicted, with only 10 out of 49 hits against stationary warships. Only the lucky hit that destroyed the USS Arizona provided the level-bombers with any major success. Japanese dive-bombers were equally ineffective, scoring only 20 percent hits. Although the Japanese demolished a great deal of US parked aircraft and sank four battleships, the results were far from catastrophic. The author provides an analysis section at the end which spells out losses in detail. As the author concludes, "it is common wisdom to state that the attack on Pearl Harbor crippled the US Pacific fleet. This is patently untrue." He views the Japanese raid as a tactical and operational-level success but a strategic failure, which galvanized America's willingness to enter the Second World War. He also puts paid to the notion that a third strike would have made a difference or that destruction of oil storage/repair facilities would have delayed a U.S. island-hopping campaign in the Pacific. Overall, this book offers fresh insights into a well-known battle and does it superbly.

Although American troops had seen action in France earlier in 1918 - notably at Chateau Thierry and Belleau Wood - the assault by eight American divisions on the German-held St. Mihiel salient on 12-16 September 1918 is generally regarded as the first real test of the American Expeditionary Force (AEF) in the First World War. Compared to other operations of that conflict, St. Mihiel was fairly short and relatively inexpensive, particularly compared with the subsequent Meuse-Argonne offensive. Thus, the operation is compact enough in time and space to make it well-suited to the Osprey Campaign format. Author David Bonk provides a succinct account of the St. Mihiel operation and is able to delve down to battalion-level accounts. While there is not any obvious original research - particularly on the German side - the author successfully synthesizes existing primary and secondary source materials to produce a coherent narrative of the operation. St. Mihiel 1918 is a solid narrative which First World War enthusiasts should find useful. The author begins with the usual introductory sections on opposing plans, armies and leaders. They are adequate, if a bit brief, and readers may want to consult additional sources for more information on the AEF. The opposing plans section was more detailed and it is interesting how he compares the American planning for the offensive while simultaneously the Germans were planning for a withdrawal. The offensive itself is covered in 55 pages of text, most of which focuses on only 12 September, so the level of detail is comparable to what one might expect in a longer book. Essentially, the Germans began to withdraw just at the start of the American attack, but the Germans fumbled their withdrawal and nearly suffered a mini-disaster. As the author notes, American command inexperience failed to complete the encirclement in a timely manner, allowing 40,000 German troops to escape. The author depicts the ground fighting in each division sector, as well as discussing air operations. He deftly incorporates official reports with various secondary sources to produce a clear overview of the operation. However, the author's writing style is a bit wooden and some sections seem very repetitious at times (e.g. `unit x advanced 1 km'). More use of first-person accounts to humanize the battle would have been a step in the right direction.  Areas where I think it would have been better to have more detail would have been logistics (since that is what made George C Marshall's reputation) and analysis. There is no breakdown of casualties beyond the total of 7,000 American killed and wounded. Seems like with a bit of effort, the author could have gotten more of a breakdown by unit and a more exact death toll.Graphically, St. Mihiel has a high standard of visual presentation, with six 2-D maps (strategic overview of the St. Mihiel salient; German and American deployments, September 12, 1918; American advance, September 12-16, 1918; Operations of the 42nd and 89th Divisions, 12 September; assault of the 90th Division; night march of the 26th Division) and three 3-D BEV maps (89th Division's assault, American tank operations, operations of the 2nd and 5th Divisions). One of the 2-D maps was confusing, with two US divisions denoted as French and some advance lines difficult to distinguish because they are all blue, but these were minor hindrances. The BEV maps are quite good, with 1 km grid lines, which is the perfect scale for this type of depiction. The three battle scenes by Howard Gerrard - some of his best work - are: combined arms attack on Beney, fighting in the Bois de Friere, American tanks at Jonville.

Nowadays, it is fashionable to depict the American Indian as victims of America's insatiable greed for land and racial prejudices. However, it is a sure bet that none of the folks espousing this kind of rhetoric had to face getting scalped, as so many Americans in the Ohio and Kentucky territories of the late 18h Century did. John F Winkler's book Wabash 1791: St. Clair's Defeat in the Osprey Campaign series takes readers back to a time when the power of the Federal Government was quite weak and the Indian tribes of Indian a lethal threat to American civilians. In a single day, the local Indian tribes were able to unite and destroy more than half the entire US Army at the Battle of the Wabash. This account is an excellent campaign history and provides a detailed look into the savagery of frontier warfare, which should be required reading for anyone interested in this phase of American history.  The author begins by outlining the situation along the Ohio River frontier in 1790, when the United States Government was only one year old. Population pressure was pushing Americans across the Ohio River into the Northwest territories, which had been granted to the Americans by the peace treaty with Britain. However, the British failed to evacuate all their forts in the region and provided covert military assistance to the local Indian tribes to resist American expansion and conduct raids on settlements. In April 1790, the U.S. Army conducted its first military operation into Ohio to counter these raids, but Harmar's small command was defeated. In response, the US Congress raised funds for a larger, 5,000-man expedition into the Ohio wilderness to crush the center of Indian resistance at the town of Kekionga. Major General Arthur St. Clair was picked to lead the expedition, which would include virtually the entire US regular army. This introduction is decently written but the map fails to depict the location of Kekionga or the disposition of Indian tribes in the region (the mix is quite confusing). The author then provides the usual sections on opposing plans, armies and leaders. In the armies section, the author highlights the gross logistical failures that significantly reduced American combat power. In essence, the expedition was thrown together to an army that had virtually no staff and the result was recruiting problems, deployment issues, shortages of key items and untrained troops. On the other hand, the Indians were exceedingly skilled in irregular warfare and received valuable coaching from British advisors on how to eliminate American artillery. The author notes that the assembling of this army was the first major national under-taking in American history, but it was rushed and amateurish. Despite receiving less than half his promised troops and scanty supplies, St. Clair decided to begin the campaign late in the season, rather than wait for a better-planned campaign in spring 1792. Indeed, St. Clair was not even certain where Kekionga was located and had no local guides or scouts to help. I began to notice here that the author was handling St. Clair's reputation a bit too daintily, rather than pointing out that he was making one stupid, pig-headed decision after another. The author spends about 14 pages and two maps detailed the American advance from the Ohio River to the Wabash River, between September-November 1791. St. Clair advanced at the ponderous rate of 2-3 miles per day, cutting a road through the wilderness and building multiple camps. His army began the campaign with only a few days rations on hand - an amazingly irresponsible decision by a commander - and was quickly put on half-rations due to the quartermaster's failures to push sufficient supply convoys up the road from the Ohio River. Although the author does not address this issue, clearly logistics was the American center of gravity and the Indian failure to attack the poorly-protected supply convoys is mystifying, since it would have stopped the American advance. The weather also made the advance a misery for the troops and enlistments for some levy troops began to expire (why would St. Clair began a campaign with troops who only had a few weeks left on their enlistment?). By the time that St. Clair's small army reached the Wabash n November, his troops were already pretty well useless. The actual Battle of the Wabash is covered in 34 pages and is supported by three nice tactical 3-D BEW maps and three excellent battle scenes by Peter Dennis (two of which depict scalping). The author lays out in detail St. Clair's faulty dispositions which allowed his army to be surprised and defeated in detail. Many of the American troops put up a poor fight and the author notes militiamen dying "like a herd of cattle." St. Clair himself was so paralyzed by gout that he could not stand or mount a horse, which makes his decision to continue the campaign all the more foolish. Indian savagery is detailed: "Some Indians were killing and scalping the women and children. Others were throwing wounded men into the cooking fires."  Finally, just as the encircled American force was about to be annihilated, a junior Maryland militia officer led a breakout charge that allowed about one-third of the Americans to escape. The author's description of the brutal retreat to the Ohio, with the sick and wounded being abandoned along the way, is gripping. Over 1,000 Americans died on a single day - one-third as much as on 9/11 - yet St. Clair's defeat is not something that young Americans learn about in history classes. Amazingly, St. Clair was exonerated by Congress but the defeat was a valuable learning experience for the infant US Army, which led to the victory at Fallen Timbers three years later. Overall, a very good book and one that should remind us of the true history that political correctness has been trying to obscure for decades.

Naval warfare during the American Civil War was in a period of great flux, with new technology forcing a re-think of tactics. In CSS Alabama vs. USS Kearsarge 1864, in Osprey's Duel-series, naval historian Mark Lardas brings some of these changes into sharp relief through the lens of Union attempts to bring elusive Confederate raiders to heel. The CSS Alabama is at the forefront of this account, but the CSS Sumter, Shenandoah and Florida are also featured. The author mounts his narrative atop two pillars - a discussion of evolving naval technology and a tactical dissection - although other aspects of this duel are covered, as well. Overall, this is an excellent, engaging narrative and should be in any Civil War library. In the opening section on design and development - which is very well written and understandable - the author discusses how three revolutionary technologies (steam power, iron construction and percussion fuses) dramatically changed warships just prior to the Civil War. He notes that although many Civil War warships looked superficially similar to earlier warships, they were in fact quite different. He notes that changes in armament, such as rifled barrels and explosive shells, as well as the shift to fewer but larger guns had a big impact upon naval combat. Ships were also becoming double the size of previous warships, but with smaller crews. He then discuses the specific evolution of Union cruisers and Confederate raiders, and provides a side-view plate of both CSS Alabama and USS Kearsarge. The author provides a 5-page section on the strategic situation, which includes a map of raider operations in 1863-65. Unfortunately, this map is not very useful because it does not depict Union Navy anti-raider deployments or ports where the raiders could expect to purchase coal or areas where Union shipping was attacked. I was also disappointed that there was no discussion of how the Union Navy went about hunting raiders; he simply says that they sent a few cruisers in pursuit, but there is no mention how they went about this. Nor is there any real discussion of efforts by the US Navy to compile information from sightings of raiders from various sources. Indeed, a duel such as this has a vital strategic/intelligence component which was omitted. Following this section, the author discusses the technical specifications (armament, structure, and propulsion) of the major participants. A 10-page section discusses the combatants, including profiles of Raphael Semmes and John Winslow. The section on combat is 17 pages in length and focuses on three actions: Alabama vs. Hatteras, Alabama vs. Kearsarge and Wachusett vs. Florida. There are three color plates by Peter Dennis and one map to support this section. The author's combat narratives are succinct but incisive. I particularly liked the way that he dealt with the controversy surrounding the end of CSS Alabama (Confederate gunnery just not very good, Union "chain armor" not a major factor). The combat section is followed by a 6-page section on statistics, which provides data for each action. As the author notes, victory depended upon accuracy rather than volume of fire, as it did in times past. Overall, CSS Alabama vs. USS Kearsarge 1864 is an excellent volume, although there were some areas that I felt came up short. Graphically, the volume is a bit weak, even with the Peter Dennis artwork; the previous New Vanguard title had much better artwork on Alabama. As mentioned, the strategic aspect of the duel was barely touched. Finally, the author makes a big point about the role of gunnery in the duel and cites the CSS Alabama for inadequate gunnery training, but missed an opportunity to discuss gunnery training in the combatants section. It would have been useful for him to discuss how gunnery training was conducted (what ranges? What types of ammunition?) and more specifics about gunnery in combat, such as how do you "aim" a weapon with no sights? Issues such as roll of the ship would also seem to be important, since CSS Alabama kept "shooting high." Were they timing their salvoes wrong? Nor does he discuss whether guns fired individually or in salvoes or how fire was directed. To be sure, these are tiny distractions from any otherwise excellent volume, but they do invite further research and writing on this topic.
I couldn't rate this higher because it is cut very high at the neck and at the underarm area.  Not for me.
I love these tanks and can only find them on Amazon.
Bought this for a choir friend at church and she loved it.  She even asked where I got it so she could give one to a friend.
Nice informal jacket, but runs small--order a size up.
Hard to review because a this is a collection of stories.  Some okay, one quite good.  None were bad.
Great book.  If I had read this as three separate books I would not have been impressed because they would not have concluded the story of this couple.  This complete work was great.
3 1/2 STARS-Well written, sweet historical romance.  Short so not a lot of character development, but what was there was well thought out and well written.
This book was okay.  Not enticing enough to make me follow the series.

Nothing makes me angrier than part of a book called a novel.  Really?  Can't you sell your books without this tricky stuff?  And for Pete's sake why doesn't a reviewer bring this to our attention before we end up in this trap.  I, for one, did not think the book work buying the next installment even if it is on $.99.SPOILER:  This book ends with Moirra being arrested for killing her last husband.  Which we readers know is not true.  No finale and then you get a message from the author that this is essentially part of a book.
Okay, but not compelling enough to make me want to read more by this author.
Sweet story.  Nothing special

Bracelet okay once I fixed the clasp that you could not possibly get closed with one hand.  After I did some serious adjusting I could get it on and locked with one hand.  My problem is that this item is horribly over priced for the light weight and thin silver used.  You can do a lot better if you shop around.  It is attractive but should cost about half of what it does.
Great story

I really loved this story until about 3/4 through.  All of a sudden the author decided to tie up unrelated relationships.  The tangents went on for several chapters before returning to the story line of these two characters.  Not her best work, but still good.
Great story, wonderful characters and good writing.  What more can you ask for.

Loved each of these books.  The last one was somewhat disappointing only because the author tried to put too many resolved relationships into the story.  It went off into too many tangents and finally returned to the H and h of the actual story.

No ending.  Too bad this author is not confident enough in her writing to sell books by virtue of their being worth purchasing.  Instead, she writes them with no ending so you can buy "Part Two" of their story under a different title, when Part One is incomplete.  Don't fall for it folks, her writing is not that good and you must like lots and lots and lots of sex.
Okay
This one I did not care for.  Didn't like the characters or the plot
This book was okay
Okay.  Sweet stories, but inferior writing at every level
2 1/2 STARS-  These books are sweet stories, but lack any development.  The writing is pedestrian.
Another great book by this author.  Good plot, excellent character development.

Really terrible writing.  This, like the others in this series, is a sweet story, but wrong names are used throughout so you have no idea who is doing what to whom.  No editing or proofreading.  Very hard to follow.  Heroine is with Ryan and all of a sudden Ian is there, only he's off somewhere else with this wife.  This last sentence gives you an idea of how confusing this book is.

2-1/2 STARS  This was a sweet story, but there is little writing talent in any of these books.  Terrible grammar, run on sentences.  Really disgraceful.  Like a high school student (sad, but true) wrote them.
Just okay for me.

3 1/2 STARS-  I liked the story overall but felt it was over long and drawn out.  There were scenes which I had a difficult time following and found myself rereading and still not understanding what was going on and how it related to the plot.  Not my favorite by this author and I do like her work very much.  I think some serious editing would be a great help here.

3-1/2 STARS.  I found this book interesting.  Some people want a kidnapping or other action to make a book interesting to them.  If that is what you are looking for, this is not the book for you.  This book contains interesting characters that are well developed, a plot that entails much emotional struggle, and good Christian messages throughout.  It fell short in some areas.  If you intend to write in a particular era, you need to stick with that era, including language and surroundings.  This author failed at this much of the time and it did distract from the book.  I also found some of the interaction between her sister, Greta, and Greta's admirer rather progressive for this era. Some of her conduct would have totally ruined her reputation and had her shunned by polite society.  Instead she went along like nothing had happened.  That didn't ring true for me.

Generous when giving three stars.  I think the people that rated it high must have absolutely no writing standards whatsoever.  These books all need serious editing and proof reading the mistakes are glaring and require rereading sections to figure out who is "on first".  Drove me insane.  The story lines are cute.  The whole big woman thing was a little off for me, but whatever!
Story okay but writing not so good.  Needs serious proof read and editing.  A shame really!

These books were all overall good stories, but all in serious need of editing and proof reading.  Sometimes they are referring to a completely different sister or brother-in-law than the main character.  Very confusing.
2 1/2 STARS.  This one just didn't do anything for me.  Sorry
Short and sweet

I thought this was a very good story and had it been longer and more developed would have been excellent.  These short books really limit an author's ability to "strut their stuff".  Based on the little there was, I would say this writer should write a real length novel and would do very well at it.
I wouldn't call this a mail order bride story at all, but it was a very sweet albeit short story.  I would definitely read others of this author.
Nice story and well written.  I enjoyed the characters and the overall plot.  It was extremely predictable at all fronts, but still fun.

This was a little long than the first installment allowing for more plot and character development, which the author did well.  I might have liked it better if the hero had been just a little bit charming, he wasn't.  While he was basically nice and provided well, he had little or no emotion other than sex drive (if that can be called emotion).
Endearing story.  Very hard to develop characters and plot in so short a writing, but it covered the basics and the characters were charming.
While I thought this was very sweet and well written, it didn't find it particularly compelling and it was very, very predictable.

Great story.  Very well written and well edited.  But for a reference to Abby calling out to Abby (herself) instead of Bethanne,  it was great.  Both of these books made me laugh and cry.  I felt like they were the advanced years of the girls on "Little House on the Prairie".  Really good reads.
Sweet, but under-developed plot and characters.  I believe the grammatical and proofreading errors have been corrected.
Short, sweet and to the end.  This author has potential but should work on an actual novel and develop her skills more fully.

Each book stands alone so giving star quantity to whole is difficult.  I liked the first story best but even that would not get more than 3 stars from me because like the others, it is too short with little or no development of characters or plot.  The last story is out of place in this set and ridiculous.  At the time it was supposedly written an American would never advertise for a Japanese bride.  In fact, immigration laws at the time would not allow a woman from Japan to enter the U.S. except as a bride to the existing Japanese work force. Any American with a Japanese wife would have been totally ostracized by other Christian Americans.  While this plot may seem romantic and very politically correct in our current era, you cannot rewrite history.
Very sweet western romance.  I believe the editing and proofreading errors mentioned in other reviews have been corrected because it read smoothly for me.  Well done for a short book.
4-1/2 STARS-Incredible writer and great plots.  The characters are well developed and the plots are unique.  This is a gifted author whose work I continue to enjoy.
Very sweet western romance
Sweet western but need proof reading badly
Okay sweet story but no editing and no proof reading makes the going rough
All of this series were sweet stories. Unfortunately the incredible number of typos and grammatical errors interfered with the reading enjoyment.
I gave the first book two stars, which I felt was generous.  This one is worse, which I didn't think was possible.

I cannot believe anyone gave this more than two stars.  Low expectations, clearly.  When I think of humorous Regency Romance, I think of great and witty dialogue.  Well, that is absent here.  I have a wonderful sense of humor and make people laugh all the time so I know humor.  This is  very poor slap-stick comedy with goats living in ducal mansions, highway men who befriend ladies.  Really not funny in any way.  If I hadn't been on the elliptical trainer needing a distraction, I would never have finished this hash of a book.
okay

I wear a size 8 in pants all brands, including Anne Klein.  This size in a 10  was too small.  I didn't try a 12, but they probably would have fit fine.  I wasn't brave enough to try again and didn't care for the tight  "skinny" style pant anyway.  But the color is truly gorgeous.
Order up 2 sizes.  I wear a size 8-10 in all my Anne Klein clothing and other  brands as well.  I am slender but busty.  I needed a 12 in this.  The color is lovely.
Perfect for sleeping bags that don't come with a cover.
This bag is perfect for carrying my swim snorkel and goggles to and from the pool

2 1/2 STARS-  Like most of these stories, they are so short that there is little to no character development.  They are enjoyable reads and I have consistently given them 3 STARS.  This one needs a serious proof reading.  It is full of typos and other editorial issues.  I had to ding it for that since it slows down and detracts from the story.
Wow!  Could this woman write.  I loved all of these books in the collection and am moving on to Collection No. 3.  Wonderful series

It's a bit expensive for what you're getting. It also only lasts about 2.5 years with heavy usage. I use my office chair a LOT, and I should have replaced this a good 6 months ago. Right now it's in tatters, and plastic bits are sticking up from the wheels cracking through the vinyl. My carpet is pretty thick, though. This might last a lot longer on carpets that aren't as thick. The problem is there aren't many alternatives that are better.

9:56 Mins So this is one of those rare products I give 5 stars on, simply because it's easy to use, gives visual progress, and can handle giant portions of food. Also has an accessory port for sealing jars and other FoodSaver accessories.

Nothing but a good experience with this tower. I use it primarily for recording music, using some fairly demanding applications that have virtual instruments. I've yet to have this machine bog down, despite many tracks, multiple effects, and tons of virtual instruments playing, all simultaneously.

I'm usually fond of writing at length, but for a network switch there isn't much to really write about, is there? It really boils down to functionality and looks, and most of the functionality isn't really easy to determine. I have WAY too many devices that use internet connectivity. I've finally outgrown standard 6 port solutions, and needed something that I could expand on. Enter this guy. The price was right, it looks nice but not outlandish, and as such it blends in with my other devices without sticking out like a sore thumb. So far I have had zero problems with it. It simply does what it's supposed to, which is all I want. I didn't need any fancy monitoring, or QOS stuff, just a way to hook up more devices. For under $80 at the time of this writing, it does the job, and that's all I asked for. I recommend this product.

Works as advertised. They fit small wires, like one or two standard AC cords, inside. It's a flexible kit that allows for mounting around corners, both inside and outside corners. Like any double-sided tape, make sure you use a bit of rubbing alcohol or a soapy solution to clean the surface before applying. If you use rubbing alcohol test a small inconspicuous area first, as it can discolor some surfaces. I just like it because it evaporates incredibly fast. Once you've got your wires squared away with this, you'll be happy you spent the money on these. They really help to tidy up ugly wires hanging off of walls.

I love LED flashlights, and pretty much any LED technology for that matter. The brighter the better, and as far as I'm concerned you can never really have too many sources of light. Where I'm at there are a lot of trees, and storms with high winds have a bad habit of knocking the power out now and then, so that's when all these lights come in handy. So the TK120 is yet another light I bought.It's constructed very nicely. All metal exterior, I am guessing aluminum, and the coating is anodized so it should last a very, very long time. The two places it screws together, toward the front and the back, have a rubber O-ring so moisture and dust won't be an issue with this light. The switch to turn the light on and off is on the back, and is protected by a thick rubber membrane which also serves to keep out dust and moisture. The light operates in 5 different modes: constant (bright), constant (medium), constant (low), strobe and SOS. These modes are activated by quickly turning the light on, off and then back on.The angle of the light's beam is adjustable. The head of the flashlight slides forward and  backward to adjust it. With it extended all the way out, the  beam is very tight and focused. On the highest setting this is incredibly bright and can easily temporarily put some serious spots in your eye. With it retracted, the beam spreads out in a wide angle, easily lighting up a large area.The metal case has a rough texture at the back, ensuring your grip won't slip even in wet conditions. The head of the light is fluted to provide a surface that's easy to hold as well. The nice thing about the sliding design for adjusting angle is the operation can be done with one hand, which leaves a hand free.The TK120 comes with two long-lasting 3,000 mAh lithium-ion 188650 3.7V batteries, as well as a charger which can charge both batteries simultaneously. It also comes with a wrist strap to help prevent losing the light.So with all that said, I give it a 4 out of 5 stars as there are other flashlights that are built just as solidly, and just as bright, but for half the cost of this light. I bought a different brand for my wife, and side-by-side her's is just as bright as this one. The only real difference is with hers the beam is adjusted by turning the head of the light. But I don't feel that the sliding mechanism of this light justifies the price tag at twice the cost. If they'd drop the price a bit I think this light would be more competitive, but as it stands I'd say the CVLIFE 2000Lm is a better deal.

OK I've been using this thing for over a month now, and I can safely say that it's a very nice mouse. It's well built, the clicks on the top buttons are slick and give good feedback without feeling cheap. The middle mouse wheel is a thing of beauty. It's very heavy feeling, and has some sort of mechanism inside it that keeps the wheel spinning for a bit if you give it a very aggressive spin. There's a small button in front of the wheel that toggles the wheel mode. In one mode, the wheel feels like it's riding between the teeth of a gear. In this mode the wheel stops in between the gear teeth (this is the only way I can describe how it feels). In the other mode, the gear teeth disengage, and the wheel moves freely without the feeling that it's riding against a gear. My personal preference is the "geared" mode. The other mode feels a bit too sensitive for my taste, but it's awesome to have a choice between the two modes.The side wheel doesn't have the internal weight that the middle wheel has or the "geared" feeling, but it still feels like it's a precision-machined part. Really there isn't a thing on this mouse that feels cheap. It's a pretty heavy mouse, so you don't have to worry about one of those light-weight mice which feels like a casual flip of the wrist will send it off the desk. The side buttons are a bit on the small side, and feel a bit awkward. They're basically very small raised buttons in the shape of something which resembles a teardrop. The top one is the "forward" button and the other is the back button, at least as far as your browser is concerned.There's a nice deck where your thumb rests comfortably. It's a shame there isn't a deck on the other side too, for a pinky rest. The overall shape of the mouse is one thing I'm not overly fond of. I feel like my palm doesn't sit very well on it, and I find myself gripping the mouse between my thumb and pinky, and my palm is arched up a bit off the mouse. If it was curved a bit more I think I'd find it perfect, especially if there was a deck on the right side for my pinky finger.As for the wireless aspects of it: it's been nothing but a pleasant experience. This is the first wireless mouse I've owned, and it's really amazing how much you notice a wire once you're used to a wireless mouse. As for their claims regarding the battery lasting up to 40 days, that seems more like a claim that could be made of a casual user, not a hardcore gamer. I play for hours and hours, and the weekends are almost all gaming. This mouse lasts me about 3 or 4 days before I need to plug it in and charge it. There is a battery life indicator on the side of the mouse. Would have been nice to have some kind of vibration, beep, or something to that effect that the mouse's battery is low. When it dies, it will just die without warning.So the product was dinged for three things - bold claims for the battery life that don't even remotely approach real world usage, no low battery warning, and the general shape of the mouse itself not being ergonomic enough. But really the bottom line is this is a very high quality mouse, and the build is rock freaking solid. I will most definitely be using this full time.

If you're in the market for something kind of cheap and adjustable to move a mic around, then this is definitely the item for you. It's a very no-frills mic scissor arm. I've used this for months now, and it's held up very well to almost daily use, for hours on end. They were smart and used lock nuts everywhere on it, so looseness is non-existent.The mount used to affix the device to a surface has cushioned foam pieces on the insides to prevent scratches. There's only a single point where the arm can be adjusted, and that's at the mid-point where it bends. Tension applied controls how easily the arm bends at that pivot point. Would have been nice to have more control over this.My one real gripe with this is with the mount point for the microphone. They used some off-sized threaded post that isn't a standard mic post size. There's an adapter you must use in order to screw a mic holder on to the item. And the nasty thing is, the adapter does not screw tightly to the post or a mic holder. My solution: teflon tape, and lots of it. I had to wrap a lot around the post and the adapter so that a microphone is held securely in place. This could have been avoided if they'd just used the standard size for mic stands.That said - the product is only slightly over $30 as of this review. The better alternatives all cost a heck of a lot more. Also - there are other brands which look identical to this one, and only cost a bit over $10. I examined the pictures closely, and everything looks the same as this one. If you're thinking of getting this, you might want to save about $20 and buy the cheaper one as it looks like you're getting the same re-branded item.

If you're looking to spiffy up a costume, some props, or other creative uses where lighting could make an impact, then this is for you! The battery pack and electronics are built solidly, and the connections to the EL wire itself are protected by shrink tubing, so I would imagine they'll stand up to moderate abuse. I wouldn't go yanking on them repeatedly though.The wire will be washed out in a brightly lit room, and forget it in direct sunlight - it's a very modest glowing wire, and cannot compete against bright light sources. The "white" is actually not a pure white, rather it's got a bit of a slightly blue-gray tinge to it.The electronics do make a high pitched noise, so if you're putting this in a helmet and will be in a quiet area, you're probably going to find it very distracting. The item can be operated in continuous lighting, strobe, and fast strobe. Takes 2 AA batteries, which will light the wire for over 10 hours, and that's with rechargeable batteries. Regular alkaline batteries should last much, much longer.One nice thing is that you can cut the wire if it's too long, and it still works just fine. So cheap, flexible, adequate construction, and a lot of fun!

If you're looking to spiffy up a costume, some props, or other creative uses where lighting could make an impact, then this is for you! The battery pack and electronics are built solidly, and the connections to the EL wire itself are protected by shrink tubing, so I would imagine they'll stand up to moderate abuse. I wouldn't go yanking on them repeatedly though.The wire will be washed out in a brightly lit room, and forget it in direct sunlight - it's a very modest glowing wire, and cannot compete against bright light sources.One thing I have to ding it on - these are very much ORANGE and NOT RED. That is the only reason I am giving it 4 out of 5. Also, the electronics do make a high pitched noise, so if you're putting this in a helmet and will be in a quiet area, you're probably going to find it very distracting.The item can be operated in continuous lighting, strobe, and fast strobe. Takes 2 AA batteries, which will light the wire for over 10 hours, and that's with rechargeable batteries. Regular alkaline batteries should last much, much longer.One nice thing is that you can cut the wire if it's too long, and it still works just fine. So cheap, flexible, adequate construction, but ORANGE, so set your expectations for installing this where orange makes sense.

I dabble around helping my wife out making various costumes. I bought this to light up the edges of a sword. Lights up fairly bright, although it will get washed out in a well-lit room. Construction seems adequate, but I'd be a bit careful as I'm sure the connection to the ribbon itself is prone to being damaged if you pull on it too hard. Battery pack and electronics are reasonably sized. It has three modes - continuously lit, slow strobe, and fast strobe. The only thing I wish is an option to not cycle through the 2 strobe modes, although that's really nit picking.When on continuous, the light will remain lit for over 10 hours, and that's using a rechargeable battery (they always go dead faster than regular alkaline). Pretty impressive! So if you're looking to fancy up a costume, or some props, or any number of creative uses - these are a cheap and fun way to do it.

Talk about built well! This no holds-barred constructed gem is fantastic for desktop usage. Has everything you could want to control the mic gain, headphone volume as well as adjusting the monitor volume. The ability to add phantom power for mics is a must-have for those who use condensor microphones. I use this with my Shure AXS-5 for doing voice-over and multiplayer gaming. I've had no problems with this at all, and it's performed exceptionally well. Installation is seriously brain dead. Plug in the USB cord and in a few seconds you're ready to go. You may have to change your default recording device to the Shure, but that's about the extent of it.Highly recommended.

I love this little stand! It's incredibly flexible for creative positioning of lights. The fact that it can be used as an extremely low stand, and then convert into a stand which can boost the lights off the ground by a few feet is a plus. Even better is how compact it is when you fold the feet up! There's really no reason to not include this little guy as part of your mobile gear. It's just too dang convenient to not have.

This is one blazing fast card! I upgraded from my GTX480 just so I could play Farcry 4 without having to crank the graphics down to get a decent frame rate. With this card, I can have everything totally maxed out (except for ridiculous things like screen under-sampling, where a scene is rendered multiple times much larger, and then scaled down to reduce aliasing) and still get great framerates.The only thing that was a bummer is the power supply connectors on this. They use just regular IDE drive style power. My power supply has two dedicated connectors that connected to my GTX480 that is now totally useless. I don't know why EVGA went this route with the power connectors as most cards use the connectors I'm talking about (they're a square 6 pin if I recall), but whatever.So yeah, this card's price at the time of this review makes more sense than the GTX980, and it's still a huge jump in performance if you're using something that's a few years old (or older). I recommend this one!

What a fantastic display! I didn't think it was as large as it is until it was on the desk and powered on. The amount of real estate on it is something to be seen to be believed. The display is crisp, and seems responsive. I do not play video games on this particular monitor, so I am unsure of any ghosting it might have (if any at all). I use this exclusively with my digital audio workstation software. I can see almost every track for most songs with this monitor, without having to scroll. And a heck of a lot of any songs I'm working on are visible, too. Considering that my last monitor that was being used for this was a 24" and I think you'll understand why it's so exciting to have this huge new monitor take its place.The only thing I can ding it on is the stand. It does not adjust much You can tilt the monitor forward or backward a slight amount, but you cannot raise or lower it at all. It's a shame, too, because I really would like to raise it up a bit. Other than that it's functional and feels very sturdy at least, but it is definitely a no-frills stand.

I cut the cord with cable years ago. One thing I've always missed though is local morning news before heading off to work. Enter this antenna. I didn't want to run anything outside, so this was perfect. Attached extremely easy to the wall with the command tape strips it comes with. There is plenty of cord to run to your tuner. A breakout box houses the inline amplifier, and the cord needed to power it. It's very convenient that the antenna is USB powered, as I have a cooling fan in my entertainment center which has a USB cord that I was able to leverage in order to power the antenna. If you don't have an available USB device to supply the antenna power, it does come with a wall adapter you can plug in which houses a USB port the antenna's USB cord can be inserted into.I was able to pull in almost every channel in my area with this. The nice thing is I live in a sort of shallow basin, surrounded by a fairly large number of hills. Even so, the antenna does fairly well. Some channels do suffer from drop outs, but really that's no fault of the antenna.I would recommend this just because it's so easy to set up, and the performance on it seems more than acceptable.

9:45 Mins In this video review I go over what I like and dislike about this headset. The "too long;didn't watch" version is - the mic needs improvement, but the audio quality of the headset isn't too shabby. It's also got some amazing range. I'm not able to walk out of range of the base from inside my house. If you like range, but don't care as much about how you sound to other people, and like nifty glowing headsets, then this is the one for you!

Install is a snap. Plug it in to a free USB 3.0 port, and Windows should pop open the file explorer options. Just choose explore the drive, and then double-click on Seagate Dashboard Installer.exe. Setup will begin, and there are a few steps you have to wade through. Early in the installation an error dialog popped up for me:---------------------------RunSeagateRegister.exe - No Disk---------------------------There is no disk in the drive. Please insert a disk into drive \Device\Harddisk3\DR14.---------------------------Cancel  Try Again  Continue---------------------------I just clicked continue and install kept going. Very odd. It downloaded what I suppose is an updated version of the Seagate Dashboard software. It's pretty quick and setup was complete within 5 minutes or so. When it ran, it wanted through Windows firewall. It seems that the backup software can upload and download your data to and from Facebook and Flickr.One pleasant surprise is this SSD backup drive works with the same Seagate Dashboard as a Seagate 2TB USB3.0 backup hard drive I already have. They're both listed, which is pretty cool. The app itself is really what you're getting an interface for, otherwise this is nothing more than a USB 3.0 SSD drive. So with that in mind - the Seagate Dashboard software is generally serviceable as a mechanism to manage backups to these drives. It's somewhat unresponsive though for some tasks, for instance clicking the Test button to start testing a drive results in a very lengthy delay before the app provides a means to notify you that you actually pressed the button. It could be a combination of the app and the firmware on the drives. Clicking between drives if you have more than one Seagate backup drive is *excessively* slow.As far as actually using this to back things up goes - it's a smallish drive, so you're going to have to pick and choose what you really find valuable. Your photos, music, videos, and games are probably not good candidates unless you really don't have a heck of a lot of these. This drive I could see being used mainly for backing up the operating system, or critical files you want to ensure have redundant copies. I created a backup plan for this drive which only backs up documents and personal files.The other backup solution this drive/app provides is for your social media. I'm actually using this for Facebook, and it's really *really* easy to use. From the Seagate Dashboard home page, click on Social, and then click on Save. I used Facebook here so I click on the Facebook button, provided my login details when prompted by Facebook's website, selected to share with me only, and that was it. It started to download all the media I have on Facebook onto the USB SSD backup drive. Couldn't be easier (well unless they introduce mind reading, but I don't think that will be available for a very long while hehe).The hardware isn't really much to write home about, but there aren't really any complaints, either. It's a very small drive, lightweight, encased in plastic so durability could be a factor. Comes with a USB 3.0 cable also.So for a tiny drive that doesn't take up squat for room, it's a great product for Flickr, Facebook, and a modest amount of video/images/music. If you have a lot of all of these, a larger solution might be a better bet.

It's difficult to *not* like an SSD. They're fast, silent, small, did I mention fast? Well, the OCZ is no exception. It's got good looks to boot, too.Typically most of my work is in multimedia (video editing) or music production. Having fast drives is critical, especially for multi-track video editing where more than one file is being streamed off the drive. Old SATA and IDE drives were OK, but the breakthrough really came with the advent of these bad-boys. Suddenly the choppiness and stuttering was a a thing of the past during edit sessions. I've been using this for months now, and it's still performing every bit as well as it did when I first got it.So, with that out of the way, it's one thing to give anecdotal evidence, and another to provide some statistics. I could either trust OCZ's claims, or do some testing of my own. They're claiming the drive can read and write at around 500MB/s. That's a pretty bold claim. So I put their claims to the test and wrote a C++ app that does a few things to measure raw read and write performance (my day job is a software engineer).So the parameters for the test were important. Windows is a multi-tasking OS, meaning that at any point in time something could come along and impact the test. Need to rule that out with multiple tests. Also, Windows will buffer reads and writes to media, so that will need to be disabled so I'm measuring the drive, not the buffer. Lastly, I'm testing an SSD. You cannot test an SSD using a standard hard drive as an SSD is many times faster than a standard hard drive. That means I needed a way to write from memory directly to disk. Not only did I need to write from memory, but it absolutely HAD to be physical memory (RAM). Windows loves to page things to disk, and if it paged to disk my test would be completely invalidated as I'd basically be reading from a hard drive to an SSD, which is what I had to avoid. So, the app would need to be able to lock pages of physical memory to guarantee that my test app would read and write directly to RAM, and never touch a hard drive (unless a hard drive was the intentional source or destination for the test).So with the test environment laid out, it was time for a program spec. The test app would basically take three args. For measuring write speeds - the amount of RAM to allocate, a destination folder for the file that would be written from RAM to the drive. For read speeds - a source argument which points to a file for reading off the drive into RAM to measure read speeds.With the specs outlined I went to town and hammered out the app. I then ran it against a number of different drives, including the OCZ of course, just to see how things measured up. Here are the results of several drives:The amount of RAM written to disk was 1.25gigs, and then the read test was conducted reading the file back into memory (so the same 1.25gig file read off the drive being tested straight to RAM).Write speeds:---------------------Crucial m4 512GB SSD CT512M4SSD2240MB/SSeagate 4TB 5400 RPM ST4000DM000-1F2168110MB/SWestern Digital Black WD2002FAEX 2TB 7200 RPM 64MB:85MB/SOCZ-VERTEX460 SSD210MB/SRead speeds:---------------------Crucial m4 512GB SSD CT512M4SSD2330MB/SSeagate 4TB 5400 RPM ST4000DM000-1F2168116MB/SWestern Digital Black WD2002FAEX 2TB 7200 RPM 64MB:87MB/SOCZ-VERTEX460 SSD210MB/SNow, I cannot say how OCZ tested their drives. Whatever they used, I cannot imagine it approaches anywhere near real-world scenarios. Heck, even my test is not real-world. Most systems are not even configured to allow pages of RAM to be locked, which is a requirement for my test program, nor are there many apps who commit all their data to physical RAM and write to drives, etc. But for the sake of it being on a real user's operating system, and under at least a somewhat real world environment (I left my PC pretty much running everything it usually does when I start it), it has to be *way* closer to reality than OCZ's testing, which tested twice as fast as my own tests.Now that's more a mark on OCZ's marketing than anything else, but I think most people expect marketing to go over the top and skew things as much as possible. I digress... as you can see from the tests, this drive blows the doors off my fastest SATA hard drive. The only thing which beat it was another SSD.So do I like it? Heck yes I do. The construction is solid, the price is right, and the performance is pretty dang good. I'd recommend it.For those curious about the program I wrote for this to see what standards I used for testing, here's the gory details. The program VirtualAllocs and reserves the chunk of RAM to use for testing based either on the file size passed in for read testing, or the alloc arg for write testing). Next allocates pages of available physical RAM to meet the demands and maps the reserved virtual ram into the physical pages. It then randomizes the newly accessible memory just so there's something there besides a bunch of zeroes. It then opens a file handle for reading or writing, depending on the args passed in, and turns buffering off for the file. Next it enters the timing phase where it starts QueryPerformanceCounter (a high performance Windows timers API), reads or writes to the drive or memory (depending on selecting operation), then checks the performance counter at the end. Calculations are done to figure out how many bytes/second were transferred, and then convert it to megabytes/second. Keep in mind it's the equivalent of having one giant file being sequentially read or wrote to/from, so there's no random access or anything like that. Just a very basic straight-forward test.
