Great cables, very sturdy. Nice thick gauge wire, too. The price was just right. Construction on these is impressive, too. I unscrewed the female end, and there's a nice plastic strain relief piece that clamps tight onto the outside jacket, so the inner wires won't get tugged on during repeated connects/disconnects. The barrel ends seem to have their bodies made of metal, so those should be able to take a beating too. Even if something does happen through severe abuse, since they are easy to take apart servicing the inside would be a snap.Overall these seem made to last, and I'd highly recommend them.

I'll prefix by saying I've been playing guitars for over 25 years. I play for fun, and even after all this time I'm not that great. Mostly because I never practice. I can, however, pick up songs and play them by ear. I also write and record my own music. With that in mind, I'm definitely not a beginner, nor am I a virtuoso of the instrument.Ok, so I was excited to check this out. GuitarHero/Rockband/clones were amusing, but if you know how to play guitar it seemed really weird. I figured this would be a great way to learn some new songs, and thought perhaps my wife might like playing guitar with guidance. Popped this in the Xbox 360, and the first thing I noticed was that their idea for a loading icon is a static microphone (or was it a guitar amplifier cabinet? I don't remember.) I wasn't sure if it was actually loading for quite a while. Get used to seeing that icon, because it loads frequently.After loading is complete it goes through a bit of calibration where you strum the guitar and it sets the levels for it. Then it takes you through an electronic tuner which ensures your guitar is in tune. All pretty straight-forward stuff. One annoying thing that is repeated everywhere in the game is how they labeled "Next" as "Skip". I sat there for a while after a voice over played, wondering if there was more. Nope. You have to click the A button to move on to the next part. I'm sure you can see how this is confusing. You're left wondering if you're skipping something instead of the game verifying that the section has completed.Next up is the ability to dive in and play a song. They tried to do a Guitar Hero/Rockband type of presentation, where notes appear moving towards you from a distant plane in 3d space. Each string is color coded, and the camera will slide to the left or right if the notes are higher or lower on the fretboard. The problem here is that unlike the other games which have a fake guitar that only has 4 buttons on it, you're playing a real guitar with 21+ frets. The way the notes fly out from infinity towards their targeted position on the fretboard can be confusing, especially when the camera starts sliding down to the higher fretboard positions. I felt like I was always struggling to figure out finger placement because of the way the notes were being displayed. Even slow and simple songs left me feeling like it was more of a hassle than it was worth.The other hindrance is latency. When you pluck the string there is a very noticeable delay between the pluck and when the note is played by the game. This makes it incredibly difficult to play notes which appear rapidly on the screen, as what you're hearing doesn't synchronize with what you're playing. There's a tip that scrolls across the screen which suggests that if there's problems with latency, try bypassing internal circuitry on your amp (mine is always direct when playing the Xbox 360) or plug in headphones. So much for being a fun thing to watch if you're a bystander. I didn't try headphones as I spend enough time when recording real music with headphones on, and since this game is more than likely going to be played on the family's TV the last thing you want to do is stand there plucking away at an electric guitar while others can't hear what you're playing against. So I was stuck with latency.Next is the voice-over. There's no way to get the guy to stop talking during a voice-over cut-scene. You will sit through what he has to say from beginning to end, unless you either exit the game or turn off your console.One thing good I'll say about it is it seems to learn how well you're doing, and adjust the experience. If you're starting to do well, it will begin throwing in more notes for you to play. I guess this is good and bad, because if you just start getting the hang of what's happening, the game starts throwing you curve-balls pretty quickly.Just as a test I had my wife, who doesn't know how to play guitar at all, give it a shot. After all, the back of the case says "Anyone can play guitar". So she gave it a shot. She was irritated she couldn't skip past the voice-over. She picked a song to play, and started it. All she was able to barely do was hit two of the notes. As soon as the camera slid up the fretboard to play different notes on different strings, she was utterly and completely lost. Needless to say, she didn't want to try it again, and was extremely frustrated by it.This game could have been fun. Marrying a real instrument with a video game console is a great idea. The things they need to do, in my opinion, to fix this:- Don't do this in a Rock Band/Guitar Hero style. That type of interaction simply does NOT work for this kind of experience in my opinion.- Add tutorial modes, where people can practice the types of notes they will be playing in a song. Let the player control the speed during these practice sessions.- Fix the latency, as no matter how fancy the graphics or brilliant the user interface is (assuming they come out with a v2 that has a brilliant interface - because this one does not) the game will remain unplayable.- Don't use "Skip" for controlling the UI when what's really meant is "Next"- Allow people to blow past voice-overs.- Don't make customers have to use a controller. The guitar they just calibrated and tuned should be used to control the game. The only exception would be to cancel a song in progress (and maybe a few other places where the game is expecting notes to be played back.)

I use SDHC in my Nikon D80 as well as my Panasonic HMC150 pro-sumer camcorder. I've been able to snap off just as many pictures just as quickly, and record at the highest quality on the camcorder, the same as other class 10 SDHC cards that cost more money. They come mailed in a sturdy cardboard envelope with a bit of padding, and enclosed in the typical SDHC plastic case. Nice since you don't have to gnaw at plastic clam shell packaging for an hour trying to get the thing out like some of the other brands. Other than that, it operates transparently, just like SDHC and other flash memory should. I can't say what difference the transfer rates are between this and other brands, but I haven't noticed anything out of the ordinary such as incredibly slow transfers, etc.Basically it's a good deal, saves you some money, and won't irritate you when the item arrives when you try to open it.
6:17 MinsIn this video I go over the Alesis RealHead 10", and compare it to a few other triggers. You'll see and hear what I mean when I say it feels like bargain gear.

I'll admit I have relied a lot on the web to research many questions and tips for mixing music. I saw this book and thought "what the heck, maybe there will be some useful things in here." I'm glad I picked it up! The way the author breaks down the effects, what they've been used on in the past, interesting applications that beginners and novices probably never thought about, and tips on when and where it's appropriate to drop them in the mix and common pitfalls. He covers it all. The end result is a firm understanding of exactly how the various common types of signal processing can be exploited to make a song go from mediocre to exceptional... at least from a mix standpoint, anyway (bad music is still going to be bad music no matter how well mixed it is!)Now, while it does a great job explaining everything, the burden is on the reader to apply the new-found knowledge. It doesn't shortcut experimentation to gain experience, but it does provide a great road map to get you there! Highly recommended for anyone who mixes their own music. I'll bet even pros could benefit from some of the author's knowledge.

I gave if 4 stars because it's a jalapeno sauce, yet the spicy level is really weak. I wasn't looking for a mouth-on-fire experience, but if they're going to put "jalapeno" on the label, it should at least have an OK amount of heat in there. You won't find much of that in this sauce. That being said, I tried this on a lot of different items, and frankly it tastes good on almost everything. Hamburgers, chicken nuggets, and of course tex-mex foods like taquitos and quesadillas. It's a creamy somewhat thick sauce, so be prepared if you were expecting a thinner style. I'd recommend it, but then again I'm not a real sauce snob (is there such a thing?) It was a surprise though, as I've never had any Taco Bell item with this type of sauce on it that I can recall. Whatever they're putting it on, I'll bet it's pretty tasty!

I like the softness of it, and the pillow compresses just the right amount to support your head. I sleep on my stomach, and the contour of the pillow feels a bit off because of this. I think I'm going to order the molded pillow instead, and save this one for occasions when I have to sleep on my back due to back or neck problems. This pillow would be perfect for people who sleep on their backs, though. Even though after trying it and finding it's not my style, it's still better than my old traditional pillow.

I've got a decent camera, and am always looking for good tips to create better looking videos. I felt like this book might offer something of value, being about film making, and claiming to get "your movie from script to screen." I suppose the book delivers on this, but you better have a budget and take movie making VERY seriously. The guy starts off with chapter after chapter about book-keeping, and lawyers, contracts, and on and on. It doesn't touch upon shooting anything at all until way deep into the book. The entire book is focused on small to large budget films. We're talking tens of thousands of dollars to millions on up. It's very difficult to sit there and read through pages of how to organize folders to hand out to crew members so they can see the day's agenda. I mean, I get it, this kind of thing is necessary for serious pictures. I just think I picked the wrong book for the types of projects I work on (aka as close to free as you can get.)Even so, be wary of the editing in this book. The spelling and grammatical errors are pretty laughable, and happen at regular intervals. The book was interesting in some respects though. If you've ever wondered what goes on to create a film this book explains it in great detail. So much so that it will definitely squash anyone's fantasies about film making being even remotely glamorous. The way it's explained makes it one of the most snooze-worthy and tedious processes on the face of the planet. At least you find out what each job does though, so I guess when you're watching film credits you'll know what all those people's job titles mean.So the bottom line is, unless you plan on trying to organize a very serious movie project, stay away from this book. It's meant for people really wanting to crack the industry and make movies with at least a $100,000 budget.

When I opened the box I was pretty surprised at how small the router was. With no Star Wars looking giant antennas and flashing lights, it's very subtle. All the connections are on the back, which is great since my router sits inside the nook of my home entertainment furniture. I have to admit though, I do like flashing lights, so I kinda miss the blinking from my old router. The other problem this can potentially create is the at-a-glance status verification goes away since you can't see the lights without flipping the unit around (so it does go beyond my enjoyment of shiny lights.) That's the only reason I gave it a 4/5 on form factor. It's a little confusing too since they have a button on the back which allows the LEDs to be turned on or off, so I'm not sure why they chose to put them on the back. This certainly is NOT a deal breaker on this item by any means though. It's the only thing I could think of to criticize on the unit.Set up is very straight-forward. The software guides you in a step-by-step process, making sure you have internet connectivity, then assisting in connecting devices. Very good for someone who's not familiar with setting up routers. There is also a web page interface you can access to make more advanced tweaking, if desired. Things such as DMZ, port forwarding, etc. It may be small, but it is definitely big on features. The web interface is laid out intelligently, and has decent descriptions to refresh your memory if you've forgotten what some of the terms mean. I certainly have no complaints about getting it up and running. I was able to swap out my old router and get this one going in less than 15 minutes.Reliability is good, so far. I have had 0 downtime with this unit, and from what I can tell there's been no change in transmission speed or latency. I have 2 wireless users who haven't said anything about connectivity issues, so it seems the wireless section works very well. I cannot give any details on range performance, since I don't use wireless and the 2 users who do only use their laptops from the couch which isn't very far from the router.Overall I'd recommend this product. It's a great unit that doesn't make it a chore to configure, and once running it seems to do its job. Especially recommended for people who don't want a bunch of flashing christmas lights on their electronics.

Well, not sure what to say since I didn't get very far. I bought it based on 1 review from another site and screenshots. I had no idea that:1) The game has an interface like Myst. Yeah. The game was released in late 2009 and the interface is from the mid 90's. It's got the "hand" that you move around the screen until it detects a hot spot. The clumsy way you interact with objects in the game is really, really bad. Frustratingly bad. It's not intuitive at all how you do something as benign as open a box at the start of the game. You'll slide the hand across it, up and down, click on it. You might eventually open it, or you might just exit the game and uninstall it first.2) No moving freely. You click in the direction you want to go, and the game moves you from Point A to Point B. Not smoothly, the screen just transitions from where you are to your next step, akin to moving one square at a time on a board game. Want to look around the area? Forget panning with your mouse. You have to click on the edge of the screen to get your viewpoint to change to that direction.3) No help. Literally, there's no help file. In the game, in the install directory, or online.Maybe some people might find this style of game play appealing, but after decades of 3D games where I can move around the world, having to point and click to move across virtual squares is not what I would consider even remotely fun in this day and age. Save your money and go buy something 1,000 times better, like "Amnesia" for the same amount of money (the game, not the state of mind, although trying to play this makes me wish I had amnesia just so I could forget I bought it.)If you REALLY feel compelled to pick this up, go look for videos of someone playing it first. I found a few after the fact, and if I had seen the video I wouldn't have made the mistake of purchasing it.

This game is great. It's a horror survival where you wander through an immense castle, searching for clues as to what you need to do to simply not die. The puzzles make you think, but they're not so difficult that you're left with no choice but to search for hints on the web. The entire time you're struggling just to keep your surroundings lit so you're not plunged into eerie darkness, where your character starts to lose his sanity. You do not fight at all in this game, so don't think you're going to jump in guns blazing. Your character needs you to use your wits and figure out how to unravel the mystery of what's happening.I can't really say much more than that without giving away anything. If you like horror survival games, you'll more than likely love this. Can't complain about the price, either!

These canisters are suggested for use by children, the elderly, or people with physical limitations, because they can be opened with just one hand. I think the average cook or baker will also appreciate being able to push a button and have the top pop off for easy removal. The lid just needs a push to go back onto the canister -- no twisting, no complicated closures. When you've got your hands in dough or you;re carrying a pan, it's handy to be able to manage these with just one hand.These also look good with my Oxo canisters, too. The styling is different, but complementary.Nice for gift packaging as well as practical for use in the kitchen, workshop, or craft room.

This ornament will make you think of Faberge eggs. The ornament is larger than I expected, but not too large for your tree. It's made of porcelain, but is not so delicate that you'll worry about it. The golden filigree decorations make it very shiny and festive, and it comes with a hanging tassel that also holds the golden tag giving the year.I've hung this in the center of my wreath, but I think that on a tree the lights would shine through the star-like openings and twinkle beautifully.Since the yea is featured, this ornament will make a great start to a collection, or a nice gift commemorating a special occasion.

People like to think they're rational, but really they're rationalizers, jumping on decisions because of (perhaps innate) emotional triggers and then trying to fit reasons to their decisions. We do this so quickly and with so little self-awareness that most of us would disagree with that statement, but the authors of this book share large amounts of compelling evidence that it is so.That means that trying to ask people what they want or to base marketing decisions on what they say may be pointless. The authors of this book recommend using more direct brain-oriented research rather than focus groups.The book is well written, with a conversational tone that makes the large quantities of data accessible. If you're a student of human nature -- and Willcox says that marketers all should be -- you'll enjoy this book.
This is a luxurious product, more like a butter than a lotion. It's unscented, and the packaging is attractive.It also feels great. It absorbs quickly, feels nourishing, and leaves skin soft.

This charger dock is attractive and sensibly designed, with firm connections and non-slip surface.It's nice to have your phone upright so you can quickly glance at the messages that run across your screen as it's charging, and the dock is even a handy place to store your phone on your desk.I tried it out in my car, too. I was pleased to find that it sat neatly on the dashboard without sliding. Since I live in a hilly place, I also figured there might be terrain that would be more challenging, and made sure that it would fit securely in the cup holder. It's certainly lightweight and compact enough to carry around with you if you never know where you might want to charge your phone.

These are extremely beautiful stickers with a high level of detail and design. The stickers are heavy weight, like thin card stock, and they lift cleanly from the backing. The sticker page is large and crammed full of stickers of various shapes and kinds, from long strips to tags, circles, ticket shapes, corners, and fancy banners. The smallest on this sheet is less than half an inch and the largest is about 3" by 6".This set is suited for Hallowe'en, for sure, with a green/orange/purple color scheme and sayings like, "You Bewitch Me" and "Beware." But there is also a fairy tale theme going on, with vintage illustrations of classic stories like "Rumpelstiltskin" and "Beauty and the Beast." Pumpkins go equally well with Cinderella and with Hallowe'en, and there are some charming floral designs. I could see this in the classroom, decorating a reading corner or activity box.I used these for a decorated planner, but they're equally suitable for party and gift decorating, scrapbooking, or paper crafts in general. The company makes sets of papers that match their stickers, so there are lots of possibilities.

I'm glad there was a Look Inside option for this book. Very little time spent reading it will let you in on a big problem with the book: the writing is so poor that you probably won't be able to read it. If you don't find yourself struggling to make it through the Look Inside sample, it might be valuable for you. For me, the effort is too great.

This plate is designed to go with the Lenox holiday china, but it will also make a very nice plate for cookies when holiday guests drop by. Nice to fill with cookies and give as a gift, too.Up close, the design has a nice hand-painted look that makes the holly design seem less formal. I also really like the fact that, even though the design is simple, they've gone with colors a little more complex than bright red and green. Touches of gold, black, gray, and even purple add a jazzy note to the orange-red and shades of green.The plate is also dishwasher and microwave safe, so you'll find yourself reaching for it all through the season. It's hefty, too, not delicate, so you don't have to worry about letting children use it.

You would think that Advent and Christmas would be easy times to pay more attention to our spiritual lives, but it can be the opposite. Not only are most of us very busy with holiday preparations and parties and activities, but it's easy to feel that we already know the story so well we have no new thoughts on the subject.In six chapters, Burkhart weaves together the stories of Zechariah, Mary, Elizabeth, John, the Magi, and a shepherd with a poignant family story of his own. He connects all the threads into a series of questions.There are five major questions:* How will I know?* How can this be?* Why has this happened to me?* What will this Child become?* Where is the Child?These are questions about the Christmas story. But each chapter also has questions for discussion. These questions cover many different experiences readers might be going through at Christmastime, from grief and bitterness to exciting times full of the promise of the future. Many of the questions are deep, asking how the past and the future are connected or how the challenges of justice and oppression can best be met in our lives.But there are also personal questions, such as how are you stewarding the blessings you have in your life, and what can you do to increase your trust in God?This book can therefore be used as a Christmas study for people at many different points in their lives.It's a quick and easy read, too, simple and down to earth. If you like to have a personal devotional book for the holiday season, this is a handy one, and the questions might provoke some important thoughts as you prepare your New Year's goals or resolutions.

It's been a few years since I looked at a new printer, and wow! This printer is part of the Internet of Things -- you know the fridge that's supposed to order milk when you're running out? Most of us don't have that yet, but the this printer will order ink for you (or, I guess, for itself) before you run out. It has its own email address, too, so you can network with it more efficiently.While these are the coolness factors, it's a nice little wireless printer. I love being able to print from my laptop without having to physically go and plug something in.It's very small and lightweight... so much so that I wondered how it would stand up to use. I was not disappointed.It's slow, but it turns out a good product. I've printed out stickers, photos, illustrations, and ordinary documents, and the results are excellent. It has a small paper tray and just a little guide for the documents, not a tray, so this is not the printer to use if you want to print out your thesis or something. I really like it for crafts, though -- it prints out a pattern or a photo beautifully from remote devices or your desktop.Setting up the network connection is not difficult. There's an online wizard (step by step by guide) to take you through the process, or you can use the software disc included with the printer. There's a fair amount of sales material included, but you can't blame HP; they have a captive audience and some nice offers, so of course they're going to do their best to get you signed up.For light home use, this is a terrific choice.

Charlotte Brody, suffrragist and plucky journalist, has left the comfort of her parents' home to join her brother in the Alaska Territory. She's ready for an adventure, but she hadn't bargained on getting involved in a brutal murder, local politics -- and a tentative relationship with a handsome lawman.As the mystery unravels, secrets from the past are revealed, and Charlotte has to face uncomfortable truths about her brother, and about herself. She also has to face the possibility that she might be in danger, and that her curiosity could lead to estrangement from her brother, rejection from the townspeople in her new home, or even death.The descriptions of frontier life are engaging, and Charlotte is likable and smart. There's enough anachronistic language to be distracting (the word "lifestyle" was not used in 1919, for example), and most of the characters are sketched in rather than developed, but it's a good story and an enjoyable read. I look forward to seeing Charlotte and her friends and family develop further in the series.

This granola is tasty, and it has 3 grams of fiber and 5 grams of protein, which puts it way ahead of the average cold cereal. It also has a mere 3 grams of fat, and just half a gram of that is saturated, which puts it way ahead of the average granola. It has no trans fats and it's certified organic, too.Plus, it has not just oats and raisins, but also crisp rice and almonds, so it's a bit different from the usual. For kids, for a sweet snack, or as a topping for yogurt, this is nice.To eat as a cereal? Brown sugar is the second ingredient, and it also includes evaporated cane juice, apple juice concentrate, and honey, adding up to 15 grams of sugar. That's more than Frosted Flakes. For me, the taste is simply too sweet, and it's more than half the amount of sugar the American Heart Association says we can safely eat in a day. Add a cup of milk and the natural sugars in the milk push you up to the limit of the AHA's recommendations.So this is not a great breakfast choice for me. If you like a sweet cereal, though, this one brings a lot more nutrition to the party than most.

However much you love your dog's, you don't love their doggy odor. And cats may not be as obtrusively scented as a dog, but one accidental spot of spray or wee from a cat advertises its presence for months or even years.I used this formula with a Bissell cleaner, trusting the claim that it would be safe with major cleaners even though the machine is labeled with warnings of fires if you use non-Bissell products, and there were no fires.There was also no aggressive cleaning-product scent. Best of all, the doggy overtones of the carpet are gone. It didn't remove an old stain, but it left the carpet clean, no longer redolent of pet odors, and noticeably softer.I had previoyusly used a different brand with this machine, and wasn't impressed with the results. Platinum Pure for Pets is an effective formula

Baking cups make the entire process of baking and serving muffins and cupcakes easier, more successful, and more civilized. So when I read that the Reynolds Baking Cups had improved on the concept even further, I had to try them.The colors of these papers survive baking. So often the bright colors of the paper liners become completely transparent once they're baked. I often put finished cupcakes into a second paper liner before serving. With these baking cups, there is no need.They stand up well after baking and make your cupcakes and muffins easy to transport in a lunch box or to a party. The papers come off the baked goods without tearing, too.

I was intrigued by the YouTube commercial featuring an elegant young woman discussing bathroom habits in the midst of a cocktail party, a cow pasture, and a crowded office. When I was offered a bottle for review, I just had to try it. And the company says that lots of people try the product out in the same spirit of whimsy -- but keep using it, because it works.Sure enough, it does work. We tried the Juniper scent at our house, and it's not obtrusive like a spray, but it also prevents the natural smells sometimes associated with bathrooms.The packaging is attractive enough to leave out for the comfort of guests and it has clear instructions: sprizt the top of the water in the toilet before you use it. That's all there is to it. You could also carry the spray with you in your purse or backpack without fear of spills or leaks.

The Founders of clothing company Life is Good share their personal and business story with charm and honesty in this inspiring book. They organize the story into 10 Superpower chapters;* Openness* Courage* Simplicity* Humor* Gratitude* Fun* Compassion* Creativity* Authenticity* LoveAll these qualities shine through in the story, along with the narrative of a multi-million dollar business. If you're willing to accept that being fun and loving will bring you this kind of financial success if teamed with hard work, you're set. But you shouldn't expect lots of business tips or a blueprint for business success. A paragraph or two is all that separate selling T shirts on the street and their first $262,000 year, and a few pages is all it takes to get to their first  million dollar year.In addition to a thoughtful and inspiring story, you get plenty of cheery artwork, playlists for each Superpower, and action steps. The action steps are things like going outdoors, unplugging from electronic media a couple of hours before you go to bed, and expressing love in daily life. Not world-shattering, in other words, but happy things to do. And maybe we forget about them too often.So begin with realistic expectations, get the book in hard cover so you can fully appreciate the artwork, take it outside, and read it. You'll be energized and encouraged.

Collagen is the stuff that keeps all the parts of your body together, and the reduction in natural collagen production as we age is the reason for wrinkles, sagging skin, and thinning hair. This conditioner uses collagen and other proteins to hydrate and condition hair.I used this conditioner with its companion shampoo. It feels luxurious in use and has a sweet, almost sugary scent that doesn't linger. That means that it won't compete with your perfume, and also that the whole family including the guys can use it.The packaging is stylish and modern, with a flip cap, not a removable cap that can lead to spills.The conditioner left my hair silky, shiny, and clean, not weighted down.

Most little girls love dolls, and enjoy making up complex stories and acting them out with their dolls. The story of Mulan, a legendary Chinese warrior, is worth acting out, and the story of her smart and sweet daughter, a Disney creation, is a good one, too -- but this stylish doll can take any part your little girl has in mind.As the mother of Eurasian daughters, I was always searching for dolls that didn't reinforce the idea that being blue eyed and blonde was the definition of being pretty and successful for girls. Barbie dolls, surprisingly, were the most ethnically diverse choices. This Hasbro doll is a fashion doll like Barbie, but without the implausible proportions. The dolls in the series have different faces and colorings, and Lonnie's outfit has elements of Chinese style. It's also modest and age-appropriate.The doll's arms and legs are jointed, and she comes with lots of accessories. She has long hair to play with, and other outfits are available. In short, a doll your child or grandchild will enjoy, and which you can feel good about giving to her.

This is a very soft, high quality rayon, wonderful for dresses, blouses, and skirts. The pattern is large and distinctive, but surprisingly versatile. I've attached a photo of a scrap of the fabric with a couple of different fall tweeds so you can see what I mean. Of course, it's good with solid greens, purples, and russet or wine shades, too.

These super cute little scrubbies certainly look hand crocheted, and the color scheme will look good in many different kitchens. Each one has a little crocheted loop so you can hang them near your sink. They have enough texture to be useful for cleaning your average dish or glass, and they're cotton, so they're comfortable to use.Scrub a few meals' worth of dishes, and your tawashi will no longer have its plum fishy shape. If this bothers you, draw around them on paper when they arrive, and when they are wet you can stretch them out on the paper to match the lines, and they will dry back in their original shape.I'll be using these for hostess gifts, to add charm to utilitarian household item gifts, and in stockings for my grown sons and daughters. They're that cute.

You've got a whole archipelago of mythical tropical islands, and you can gain control over them by building bridges from one to another. However, your opponent can remove your bridges so quickly that the entire balance of power in the game can change in a matter of moments.With cards, an attractive board, and wooden markers, there's a lot going on in the game, but points are totaled just three times, so the rise and fall of fortunes (counted in islands) can be like a roller coaster and you'll gain points only if you're ahead when the cards run out. For my family, this was a nice blend of luck and strategy, but there are alternate rules that allow you to make luck less important. You can also play with handicaps to even the game for different ages or skill levels.This is a two-player game, but it's also fun with two teams of two. Little reading is required, but strategy is complex enough to make this a fun, challenging, and nearly addictive game for adults. It's completely visual/spatial, so it makes a nice alternative to word games if your gang has uneven skills or multiple languages.

So many of us like the chalkboard look for our pantries, craft rooms, and parties. But printing out labels in that style uses tons of ink and usually gives streaky results. These labels are true inky black and easy to write on with chalkboard markers.They don't smear once they're dry, either. I like the idea of reusable labels in the pantry, since we might not want to refill that jar of wasabi peanuts with wasabi peanuts again, but the "whiteboard" type smear in normal use and there you are wondering whether this is self-rising flour or bread flour. I was able to remove lettering with a damp paper towel and re-use the label successfully, but it stays put in normal use.These are not paper; they're made of sturdier stuff. Really just perfect chalkboard labels.

These earrings are light and delicate, with the warm shine of rose gold and the cool glitter of the rhodium and diamond. The combination of minerals and the small, delicate size makes these earrings very versatile, suited to a special dress, blue jeans, or office attire.The look is reminiscent of vintage marcasite jewelry, but very up to date. They're also very pretty -- you'll reach for them often.

These little tags are perfect for crafts, art projects, showers, gift tags, and labeling things. They punch out smoothly and have a nice hang tab opening. They're tiny and delicate, not intended for high-pressure situations, but very versatile for more decorative uses.Go to Avery's "print and design" area at their website and choose the right product number (41566) and you'll find 19 different designs, including a blank template you can personalize at will. The software is very easy if you're used to using this type of software. If not, then it's not going to be that easy, so slow down and experiment a bit. For me, customizing a tag and getting it ready to print out took under 5 minutes.Printing it? Well, I put the tags in upside down first, and then worked too quickly correcting and setting up the second run, so the font was not communicated correctly on the second sheet. I'm sharing this because I've seen reviews saying negative things about the software when it was clearly user error. You're human, so -- unless you do this type of task all the time -- you will probably have a little bit of a learning curve and need to practice a bit.Having wasted two sheets of tags, I now know which way is up and that you can't rush the process, and I can make all kinds of snazzy tags with Avery's snazzy software. The templates print past the edge of the tag, so the end result has a very polished look.The software produces a nice PDF you can save on your computer and print out at any time. You can also set up an account and save your creations at the Avery website so you can keep your design in the cloud and print it out anywhere -- handy if you use them in your work or in your classroom.Of course, you can also write on these easily or use any kind of art supplies. It's a lightweight, slightly textured card.

Hattie Davish comes home to St. Joseph, Missouri, to a support a school friend at her father's funeral To her surprise, she finds that she has become a local celebrity -- for some, because she graduated from the local secretarial college and has gone on to support herself with her skills at a time when few women do so, but for others because of her involvement in murders. Scandalous or celebrated, Hattie has strong feelings and strange experiences about coming home to the town where her father died and his business was taken over by a stranger.She also has mixed feelings about her old friends from the secretarial college, not to mention some shady characters who seem to be connected with the "incidents" that are causing problems for her alma mater. Add mysterious violence, a possible mix-up among corpses, and some famous outlaws to the mix and you have a very lively visit home.This is a place and a period that is not often presented in mystery novels, and I was intrigued by the depth of detail in the presentation of the setting. Hattie is bright and complex and the supporting characters are interesting. The puzzle is complex, too, and the author plays fair and ties up all the loose ends.

These small plastic disks have a clear backing which you must remove. Once you're done this, you can stick them on your whiteboard  (you know you need more space!), your wall, your binders, your furniture, your cabinets, or any other smooth surface you have in mind.Each disk has an attached clip which will hold things and which you can also use to hang light objects. As soon as you put the disk in place it will hold paper. Let it get comfortable and it will hold a bit more...your lanyard, for example. You can use it to attach a small zip drive to your colleague's mug -- more attention grabbing than laying it on the desk -- or to hold color samples or fabric swatches. Hold a recipe in place while you're cooking.Move the disks around easily and with no damage to the surface you stuck them on. Way better than magnets.

A little of this shampoo goes a long way. It has an unusually penetrating quality, so it speeds up a shampoo, even for long hair. It leaves your hair soft and bouncy, too.The scent is mild and unisex, and it doesn't linger in your hair. This is a great shampoo for the family.

In an alternative history of England during the Napoleonic wars,  Zacharias is the Royal Sourcerer -- but an unpopular one, primarily because he is foreign and of a different race from his fellow sorcerers. He's troubled by ghosts and magical creatures, but also determined to make positive changes during what he fears might be a short tenure as the most important thaumaturge in the land. England has less magic to go around than it used to, and some blame Zacharias.Prunella is an orphan, a charity case at a special school for girls who are troubled by magic. Magic is considered a problem for women, and Prunella has access to much more of it than most of England's sorcerers can dream of. She's smart and pretty... but much good it does her, stuck away in a backwater.When they meet, each can see that each might be just what the other needs. Adventure, romance, marvelously imagined scenes of Fairy land and the magic-driven court, and complex relationships create a wonderful story.I found this book tough to read at first. When reading Austen or Heyer, you have to be prepared for antique language and casual racism and sexism; I didn't like it in a modern book. The impressively authentic period language slows the pace, and while the racism and sexism are both important parts of the story, it's not immediately apparent. Get past these things and let the story take over, and this is a very satisfying read.

Maybe you've been there... You're sitting correctly in your ergonomic chair working on something and gradually, as you become increasingly engrossed in the exciting work you're doing, you move in toward the computer screen till you're hunching over like an early primate. At this point, if you're using the Lumo Lift wearable,  you get a gentle vibration reminding you to sit up straight.The first couple of times I practically jumped out of my skin, but after a day or two I grew accustomed to it. The fact that I found it so startling just proves that the Lumo Lift is extremely comfortable -- I literally forgot I had it on. It's a small magnetic device and it comes with three other small magnets: one to attach it to your bra strap, which is my choice, and two small squares in different colors which may become coveted prestige jewelry but at the moment will be little squares on your shirt front. I'm guessing people will peer at them and ask you what they are.Download the app and hook it up -- super easy -- and work through a nice little training wizard, and you're set. When you have the coach mode on, you will be alerted any time you slouch for 2 minutes. You can change the length of time you're allowed to slouch, and you can also turn the coach off either through the app or by pressing the Lumo Lift itself. This allows you to loll around on the sofa reading without getting reminded to sit up straight.If you keep the Lift on all day, it will also count your steps for you. 10,000 is the goal. Check the app and you'll see how many hours of perfect posture you attained (4 hours is the goal) and how many steps you've taken. There are also little congratulatory notifications to your phone and email.You can turn all these things off, but if you leave them on you will have better posture and less back and shoulder pain at the end of the day. The coaching seems just right for me in the default settings, but I think it's great to have the configuration options. You can fine-tune the Lift as you go along, working toward ever more perfect posture.There's a handy USB charger that holds the Lift in the correct position for charging, too. All in all, a practical and well-designed wearable.

If you're expecting (as I did) that you can spend a few minutes in set up, write smoothly just as you do on paper, and then enjoy a search function that lets you find those handwritten notes in moments, you should readjust your expectations.The Jot Script feels nice and smooth, hefty and well balanced. The packaging is nice and has cheery little quick start guides which were not sufficient for me, but they refer you to more complete instructions online. The recharger is a sturdy USB device that holds the Jot Script upright with a magnet while it recharges, which it does very quickly.I tried Evernote and Penultimate for my iPhone and iPad. Registration and downloading and learning the apps took me less than an hour. Then I spent another hour in a meeting scrawling illegibly and often invisibly. Start with straight lines and work your way up is my advice to fellow neophytes -- by the end of the meeting I was able to get words on the screen. I was not able to write smoothly in my normal handwriting and end up with legible notes, but I'm getting better all the time.These apps allow the Jot Script to be used as a pen in many different thicknesses, as a highlighter in many different colors, and as an eraser, to clear up the many many extraneous marks I ended up with, probably because I haven't gotten the hang of it yet. You can choose from many different on-screen papers, including musical notation paper, graph paper, and more, which extends the usefulness.After continued use, I'm finding the Jot Script great for note taking and to-do lists, but it still cannot read my writing well enough to search my notes. I am confident, seeing how far the Jot Script and I have come, that by the end of conference season I will be able to use Jot Script for all my notes, and be able to read them, too.Assuming that my heightened skill will allow me to search my notes and find specific information quickly, this will be an enormous improvement over physical scrawled notes, of which I have notebooks full. Trying to go back and find what I promised to do in some meeting in the past or some piece of data that I know is in my notes from last year is much more maddening than getting used to the Jot Script.Writing notes is faster and more comfortable for me than typing, especially on a phone keyboard, so I will persevere. I expect to love this in the future.If you haven't used this type of device before, like me, then you should be prepared to feel like a kindergartner for a while. It seems unfair to give a 4 star review rather than a 5 star one when it seems so likely that it is my incompetence that keeps me from being able to use all the features successfully, but the initial frustration level keeps this from being perfect.
